pianists leon fleisher , ruth slenczynka and stephen bishop and conductor earl bernard murray .	17.343067
the leningrad kirov ballet , which opened a series of performances friday night at the opera house , is , i think , the finest `` classical ' ' ballet company i have ever seen , and the production of the petipa-tschaikowsky `` sleeping beauty ' ' with which it began the series is incomparably the finest i have ever had the pleasure of witnessing .	32.427948
i am prepared to demonstrate at anytime that it represents the spirit of imperial russia in its most vulgar , infantile , and reactionary aspect	30.351315
that its persistent use by ballet companies of the soviet regime indicates that that old spirit is just as stultifying alive today as it ever was	74.76273
that its presentation in this country is part of a capitalist plot to boobify the american people	9.365355
that its choreography is undistinguished and its score a shapeless assemblage of self-plagiarisms .	6.6456704
all of this is true and all of it is totally meaningless in the face of the kirov ' s utterly captivating presentation .	23.468733
the reasons for this enchantment are numerous , but most of them end in `` ova ' ' , `` eva ' ' , or `` aya ' ' .	9.607184
in other words , no merely male creature can resist that corps de ballet .	421.58768
it seems to have been chosen exclusively from the winners of beauty contests -- miss omsk , miss pinsk , miss stalingr oops , skip it .	21.731907
these qualities alone , however , would not account for their success , and it took me a while to discover the crowning virtue that completes this company ' s collective personality .	102.15615
it is a kind of friendliness and frankness of address toward the audience which we have been led to believe was peculiar to the american ballet .	117.09836
oh-the-pain-of-it , that convention of russian ballet whereby the girls convey the idea that they are all the daughters of impoverished grand dukes driven to the stage out of filial piety , is totally absent from the kirov .	29.826036
this is all the more remarkable because the kirov is to ballet what senator goldwater is to american politics .	60.17455
but , obviously , at least some things have changed for the better in russia so far as the ballet is concerned .	79.38641
irina kolpakova , the princess aurora of friday ' s performance , would be a change for the better anywhere , at any time , no matter who had had the role before .	55.92834
she is the most beautiful thing you ever laid eyes on , and her dancing has a feminine suavity , lightness , sparkle , and refinement which are simply incomparable .	23.303146
alla sizova , who seems to have made a special hit in the east , was delightful as the lady bluebird and her partner , yuri soloviev , was wonderfully virile , acrobatic , and poetic all at the same time , in a tradition not unlike that of nijinsky .	25.857012
vladilen semenov , a fine `` danseur noble ' '	1.4094646
and inna zubkovskaya , an excellent lilac fairy , were other outstanding members of the cast , but every member of the cast was magnificent .	28.235954
the production , designed by simon virsaladze , was completely traditional but traditional in the right way .	156.29436
it was done with great taste , was big and spacious , sumptuous as the dreams of any peasant in its courtly costumes , but sumptuous in a muted , pastel-like style , with rich , quiet harmonies of color between the costumes themselves and between the costumes and the scenery .	26.781992
evegeni dubovskoi conducted an exceptionally large orchestra , one containing excellent soloists -- the violin solos by the concertmaster , guy lumia , were especially fine -- but one in which the core of traveling players and the body of men added locally had not had time to achieve much unity .	61.997097

at last the white house is going to get some much-copied furniture by that master american craftsman , duncan phyfe , whose designs were snubbed in his lifetime when the u . s . presidents of the 19th century sent abroad for their furnishings .	35.378242
the american institute of decorators has acquired a rare complete set of sofas and chairs which are to be placed in the executive mansion ' s library .	33.48189
the suite has been in the same family since the early 1800 ' s .	30.844078
the gift is being presented by `` heirs and descendants of the rutherford family of new jersey , whose famous estate , `` tranquility ' ' , was located near the duncan phyfe workshop at andover , n . j . .	12.182291
authenticated pieces of duncan phyfe furniture are uncommon , although millions of american homes today display pieces patterned after the style trends he set 150 years ago .	173.84132
this acquisition is a matched , perfect set -- consisting of two sofas six feet long , plus six sidechairs and two armchairs .	17.700415

at 4 p . m . the president left the white house to welcome the young musicians , students from the ages of 12 to 18 who spend six weeks at the brevard music center summer camp , and to greet the 325 crippled , cardiac and blind children from the district area who were special guests at the concert .	57.404858
it was the first in the series of `` concerts for young people by young people ' ' to be sponsored by first lady jacqueline kennedy at the white house .	27.180998

`` i think they played hail to the chief better than the marine corps band , and we are grateful to them ' ' , president kennedy remarked after mounting the bandstand and shaking hands with conductor james christian pfohl .	68.18865
after paying tribute to the conductor and his white-clad youthful students , president kennedy said , `` as an american i have the greatest possible pride in the work that is being done in dozens of schools stretching across the united states -- schools where devoted teachers are studying with interested young men and women and opening up the whole wide horizon of serious music ' ' .	57.32034
he added `` i think that sometimes in this country we are not aware as we should be of the extraordinary work that is being done in this field ' ' .	46.207287
displaying his knowledge of music , the new england-born president remarked that `` probably the best chamber music in the world is played in vermont , by young americans -- and here in this school where they have produced extraordinary musicians and teachers , and their work is being duplicated all across the united states .	64.380005
`` this is a great national cultural asset , and therefore it is a great source of satisfaction to me , representing as i do today my wife , to welcome all of you here today at the white house ' ' .	46.12874

`` i was an art major in college ' ' , miss baldrige explained .	14.779803

they decided that they thought rembrandt ' s self-portrait made him look `` sad ' '	27.541517

the ceremony ended with the laying of a wreath at the crypt of pike in the house of the temple .	20.08082

the marriage of john and mary black had clearly reached the breaking point after eight years .	113.762695
john had a job in a small firm where the work was dull and monotonous .	46.043167
he would come home in the evening tired and discouraged -- in no frame of mind to play with their three children , or spend much time chatting with his wife .	50.965294
hurt by his lack of interest and attention , mary complained often that he didn ' t help around the house , and that he didn ' t really care about the family .	38.30053
he in turn told her she demanded too much .	11.204383
they were both discouraged , disgusted and miserable .	19.703732
without any definite plan in mind , she went to a judge to see what could be done .	48.844105
the judge listened quietly as the young woman poured out her frustrations -- then discussing with her the possibility of seeking aid from family service before going to a lawyer .	80.80789
family service , sharing in ugf , has five agencies in the washington area .	81.93644
they offer to the people of this community case work service and counseling on a wide variety of family problems .	100.50002
because neither of them really wanted their marriage to break up , mr . and mrs . black agreed to a series of interviews at family service of northern virginia , the agency nearest them .	56.920284
for nearly a year , they have been receiving counseling , separately and together , in an effort to understand and overcome the antagonisms which had given rise to the possibility of divorce .	47.053074
the interviews have led each of them to a new appreciation of the problems confronting the other .	86.14894
they are now working together toward solving their difficulties .	51.16982
he gives credit for the promotion to his new outlook on life .	68.22349
mary is cheery and gay when her husband comes home in the evenings , and the children ' s bed-time is frequently preceeded by a session of happy , family rough-housing .	23.110733
to outsiders , the blacks seem to be an ordinary , happy family , and they are -- but with a difference .	87.160645
they know the value of being just that -- an ordinary , happy family .	85.3293
family service has helped hundreds of families in this area .	21.114449
perhaps to some their work does not seem particularly vital .	72.989815
but to the families it serves , their help cannot be measured .	132.03218
family service could not open its doors to a single family without the financial support of the united givers fund .	50.856987
anticipated heavy traffic along the skyline drive failed to materialize yesterday , park rangers said , and those who made the trip got a leisurely view of the fall colors through skies swept clear of haze .	63.311348
one of the initial questions put to president kennedy at his first news conference last january was about his attitude toward a meeting with premier khrushchev .	49.757717
`` i ' m hopeful that from more traditional exchanges we can perhaps find greater common ground ' ' .	103.297516
the president knew that a confrontation with mr . khrushchev sooner or later probably was inevitable and even desirable .	132.39487
but he was convinced that the realities of power -- military , economic and ideological -- were the decisive factors in the struggle with the communists and that these could not be talked away at a heads of government meeting .	73.74948
he wanted to buy time to strengthen the u . s . and its allies and to define and begin to implement his foreign policy .	24.719244
president kennedy will meet with soviet premier nikita s . khrushchev in vienna june 3 and 4 .	39.062412
the announcement came after a period of sharp deterioration in east-west relations .	15.08916
the heightened tension , in fact , had been a major factor in the president ' s change of view about the urgency of a meeting with the soviet leader .	13.548057
he was not going to vienna to negotiate -- the simultaneous announcements in washington and moscow last week stressed that no formal negotiations were planned .	29.439459
but mr . kennedy had become convinced that a personal confrontation with mr . khrushchev might be the only way to prevent catastrophe .	25.07589
that objective set the high stakes and drama of the vienna meeting .	21.624462
despite efforts by washington last week to play down the significance of the meeting , it clearly was going to be one of the crucial encounters of the cold war .	29.161823
the u . s . and soviet heads of government have met three times since sir winston churchill in 1953 introduced a new word into international diplomacy with his call for a fresh approach to the problem of peace `` at the summit of the nations ' ' .	45.100086
the first time was in 1955 when a full-dress big four summit meeting produced the `` spirit of geneva ' ' .	30.132221
the spirit served chiefly to lull the west while moscow made inroads into the middle east .	72.75554
in 1959 president eisenhower and premier khrushchev held an informal session in the u . s . .	6.948087
that meeting produced the `` spirit of camp david ' ' -- a spirit , it later turned out , that masked a basic misunderstanding about progress toward a berlin settlement .	75.55811
on the third occasion -- another big four summit session at paris a year ago -- there was no problem of an illusory `` spirit ' ' .	49.62395
premier khrushchev wrecked the conference at its initial session with a bitter denunciation of the u . s . for the u-2 incident .	7.7239623
the episode tended to confirm the u . s . belief that propaganda , the hope of one-sided concessions , and the chance to split the allies , rather than genuine negotiation , were the soviet leader ' s real aims in summitry .	25.178207
thus when premier khrushchev intimated even before inauguration that he hoped for an early meeting with the new president , mr . kennedy was confronted with a delicate problem .	27.143295
shortly before his nomination he had set forth his basic view about the problem of negotiations with the soviet leader in these words	48.58865
`` as long as mr . khrushchev is convinced that the balance of world power is shifting his way , no amount of either smiles or toughness , neither camp david talks nor kitchen debates , can compel him to enter fruitful negotiations ' ' .	62.91365
the president had set for himself the task , which he believed vital , of awakening the u . s . and its allies to the hard and complex effort necessary to shift that balance .	60.035007
he did not want the effort weakened by any illusion that summit magic might make it unnecessary .	71.79578
he wanted time , too , to review the united states ' global commitments and to test both the policies he had inherited and new ones he was formulating .	67.443474
above all , he did not want to appear to be running hat in hand to premier khrushchev ' s doorstep .	33.871418
at the same time the president took pains not to rule out an eventual meeting with the soviet leader .	42.26952
ideally , he knew , it should be preceded by concrete progress at lower levels .	88.310905
but mr . kennedy saw value even in an informal meeting , provided that undue hopes were not raised in connection with it .	72.733345
it would give him an opportunity to take the measure of his chief adversary in the cold war , to try to probe mr . khrushchev ' s intentions and to make clear his own views .	32.68341
moreover , an eventual meeting was desirable if for no other reason than to satisfy world opinion that the u . s . was not inflexible and was sparing no effort to ease international tensions .	33.760433
both elements -- the caution about a meeting , the willingness eventually to hold one -- were reflected in a letter from the president which ambassador llewellyn e . thompson brought back to russia late in february .	73.27081
the letter , dated feb . 22 , was delivered to premier khrushchev in novosibirsk , siberia , on march 9 .	17.875391
it dealt mainly with a broad range of east-west issues .	3.7962108
but it also briefly suggested the possibility of a meeting with mr . khrushchev before the end of the year if the international climate were favorable and schedules permitted .	31.614388
developments over the next two months , however , caused the president to reconsider the question of the timing .	22.184866
there were intense discussions in the inner councils of the white house about the advisability of an early meeting , not because the international climate was improving , but precisely because it was deteriorating alarmingly .	33.142456
the president was especially concerned about the deadlock in the nuclear test ban negotiations at geneva .	11.601089
the deadlock has been caused by the russians ' new demand for a three-man ( east , west and neutral ) directorate , and thus a veto , over the control machinery .	46.01506
in the u . s . , strong pressures have been building up for a resumption of tests on grounds that the russians may be secretly testing .	38.93627
mr . kennedy was less troubled by that possibility than by the belief that a geneva breakdown , or even continued stalemate , would mean an unchecked spread of nuclear weapons to other countries as well as a fatal blow to any hope for disarmament .	59.716007
there was reason to believe that premier khrushchev was also concerned about a possible spread of nuclear weapons , particularly to communist china .	43.054874
the question arose as to whether a frank discussion of that danger with the soviet leader had not become urgent .	61.742733
moreover , moscow appeared determined to apply the tripartite veto principle to the executive organs of all international bodies , including the u . n . secretariat and the international control commission for laos .	21.676115
mr . kennedy was convinced that insistence on the demand would make international agreements , or even negotiations , impossible .	103.898605
developments in cuba and laos also suggested the advisability of an early summit meeting .	12.19882
initially the white house reaction was that the bitter exchanges with moscow over cuba and the conflict in laos had dampened prospects for a meeting .	27.300316
at the same time , there was increased reason for a quick meeting lest the soviet leader , as a result of those episodes , come to a dangerously erroneous conclusion about the west ' s ability and determination to resist communist pressure .	26.523556
in cuba , the u . s . had blundered badly and created the impression of impotency against communist penetration even on its own doorstep .	28.49603
in laos , the picture was almost equally bad .	70.76332
u . s . willingness to accept a neutral laos may have led premier khrushchev to believe that other areas could be `` neutralized ' ' on soviet terms .	33.626945
beyond that , allied disagreement about military intervention in laos -- despite warnings that they might do so -- allowed moscow to carry out with impunity a series of military and diplomatic moves that greatly strengthened the pro-communist forces .	53.68973
as a result , the west is in a poor bargaining position at the current geneva negotiations on laos , and south vietnam and other nations in southeast asia are under increased pressure .	61.730133
in the light of those events , there appeared to be a real danger that premier khrushchev might overreach himself .	53.18127
ambassador thompson reported from moscow that the soviet leader ' s mood was cocky and aggressive .	13.1218405
he has indicated that he plans new moves on berlin before the year is out .	90.155754
the president and his advisers felt that the time might have come to warn premier khrushchev against a grave miscalculation in areas such as berlin , iran or latin america from which there would be no turning back .	49.008663
it was in the midst of such white house deliberations that premier khrushchev on may 4 made new inquiries through the u . s . embassy in moscow about a meeting with the president in the near future .	69.96278
mr . kennedy told moscow he would give his answer by may 20 after consultation with the allies .	116.12291
the response from london , paris and bonn was favorable .	50.81028
firm arrangements for the meeting in vienna were worked out in a final exchange between moscow and washington last week .	49.040348
apparently at the insistence of the u . s . , the simultaneous announcements issued in washington and moscow last friday emphasized the `` informal ' ' nature of the meeting .	30.16661
`` the president and chairman khrushchev understand that this meeting is not for the purpose of negotiating or reaching agreement on the major international problems that involve the interest of many other countries .	56.217186
the meeting will , however , afford a timely and convenient opportunity for the first personal contact between them and a general exchange of views on the major issues which affect the relationships between the two countries ' ' .	61.66309
the vienna meeting will bring together a seasoned , 67-year-old veteran of the cold war who , in mr . kennedy ' s own words , is `` shrewd , tough , vigorous , well-informed and confident ' ' , and a 44-year-old president ( his birthday is may 29 ) with a demonstrated capacity for political battle but little experience in international diplomacy .	43.899323
the announcement last week of the forthcoming encounter produced strong reactions in the u . s . of both approval and disapproval .	40.770573
the approval did not arise from an expectation of far-reaching agreements at vienna .	33.573902
the inclination was to accept the statement that there would be no formal negotiations .	10.524959
but those who were in favor of the meeting felt that a frank exchange between the two men and an opportunity to size one another up would prove salutary .	104.87274
mr . khrushchev is known to rely heavily on his instincts about his adversaries and to be a shrewd judge of men .	22.754133
the feeling was that he would sense an inner core of toughness and determination in the president and that plain talk by mr . kennedy would give him pause .	48.207012
apart from the personal equation , another reason advanced in favor of the meeting was that too often in the past the u . s . appeared to have been dragged reluctantly to the summit .	31.630928
premier khrushchev has made propaganda capital out of that fact and in the end got his summit meeting anyway .	159.43231
this time the initiative came , in part at least , from washington .	37.138844
there was also the fact that by the time he meets mr . khrushchev , the president will have completed conversations with all the other principal allied leaders .	39.009846
thus he will be in a position to disabuse the soviet leader of any notions he may have about grave allied disunity .	67.464615
finally , there was a wide area of agreement on the value of the president ' s making a final effort in the summit spotlight for a nuclear test accord .	32.797253
there is no single issue that has aroused stronger feelings throughout the world .	22.242157
if tests are to be resumed , the argument went , it is vital that the u . s . make plain that the onus belongs to the soviet union .	28.636183
disapproval of the meeting was based largely on the belief that the timing could hardly be worse .	37.340904
after cuba and laos , it was argued , mr . khrushchev will interpret the president ' s consent to the meeting as further evidence of western weakness -- perhaps even panic -- and is certain to try to exploit the advantage he now believes he holds .	75.58676
moreover , the president is meeting the soviet leader at a time when the administration has still not decided on the scope of america ' s firm foreign policy commitments .	38.876617
the question was raised , for example , as to what attitude the president would take if mr . khrushchev proposes a broad neutral belt extending from southeast asia to the middle east .	66.90166
there are , so my biologist friends tell me , mechanisms of adaptation and defense that are just too complete and too satisfactory .	60.96015
the shell , which served the strain so well at a relatively early stage in the evolutionary scheme , tended to cancel out the possibility of future development .	27.916155
though this may or may not be good biology , it does aptly illustrate the strength and the weakness of american catholic higher education .	45.708813
there can be no doubt that the american catholic accomplishment in the field of higher education is most impressive our european brethren never cease to marvel at the number and the size of our colleges and universities .	48.757347
the deeper wonder is how this miracle was accomplished in decades , rather than in centuries and by immigrant minorities at that .	94.53816
by way of explanation we ourselves are prone to imagine that this achievement stems from the same american catholic zeal and generosity which brought the parochial school system into existence .	54.746277
there is , however , one curious discrepancy in this broad and flattering picture .	41.200172
viewing the american catholic educational achievement in retrospect , we may indeed see it as a unified whole extending from grade school to university .	58.68897
but the simple truth is that higher education has never really been an official american catholic project	283.1506
certainly not in the same sense that the establishment of a parochial school system has been a matter of official policy .	19.15917
official encouragement is one thing , but the down-to-earth test is the allocation of diocesan and parochial funds .	36.42475
american catholics have responded generously to bishops ' and pastors ' appeals for the support necessary to create parochial schools but they have not contributed in a similar fashion to the establishment of institutions of higher learning .	69.266365
they have not done so for the simple reason that such appeals have hardly ever been made .	41.878593
diocesan authorities generally have not regarded this as their direct responsibility .	163.5027
all of this may be understandable enough it is , however , in fact difficult to see how diocesan authorities could have acted otherwise .	54.64839
yet for better or for worse , the truth of the matter is that most american catholic colleges do not owe their existence to general catholic support but rather to the initiative , resourcefulness and sacrifices of individual religious communities .	38.39305
community esprit de corps has been the protective shell which has made the achievement possible .	43.44462
to understand the past history -- and the future potential -- of american catholic higher education , it is necessary to appreciate the special character of the esprit de corps of the religious community .	27.902407
it is something more than the arithmetical sum of individual totals of piety and detachment .	13.688174
a religious community with a vital sense of mission achieves a degree of group orientation and group identification seldom found elsewhere .	48.21524
the fact that the group orientation and group identification are founded on supernatural principles and nourished by the well-springs of devotion simply give them a deeper and more satisfying dimension .	38.50183
the net result is a uniquely satisfying sense of comradeship , the kind of comradeship which sparks enthusiasm and blunts the cutting edge of sacrifice and hardship .	16.8298
american catholic colleges and universities are , in a very real sense , the product of `` private enterprise ' ' -- the `` private enterprise ' ' of religious communities .	18.92699
had it not been for such private enterprise , diocesan authorities might of course have been goaded into establishing institutions subsidized by diocesan funds and parish collections and staffed by religious as paid employees .	53.92102
there is however no point in speculating about such a possibility the fact of the matter is that our institutions of higher learning owe their existence to a spirit not unlike that which produces the `` family business ' ' .	55.935406
this `` family-community ' ' spirit is the real explanation of the marvel of our achievement .	25.331768
it is this spirit which explains some of the anomalies of american catholic higher education , in particular the wasteful duplication apparent in some areas .	21.801708
i think for example of three women ' s colleges with pitifully small enrollments , clustered within a few miles of a major catholic university , which is also co-educational .	25.928406
this aspect of the total picture has been commented upon often enough .	517.24817
it would seem to represent esprit de corps run riot .	73.58077
apart , however , from the question of wasteful duplication , there is another aspect of the `` family business ' ' spirit in american catholic higher education which deserves closer scrutiny .	26.444572
for while the past needs of the church in this country may have been adequately met by collegiate institutions , which in temper and tone closely resembled junior colleges and finishing schools , it would seem that today ' s need is for the college which more closely resembles the university in its `` pursuit of excellence ' ' .	50.900898
at the earlier `` pre-academic excellence ' ' stage of catholic education , the operation could be conducted on an intra-mural community basis .	89.84602
but with today ' s demand for professional qualifications and specialized training , the need for `` outsiders ' ' becomes more pressing .	24.714151
the problem is not merely that more `` outside teachers ' ' are needed but that a different brand is called for .	58.85204
commenting on the earlier stage , the notre dame chapter of the american association of university professors ( in a recent report on the question of faculty participation in administrative decision-making ) noted that the term `` teacher-employee ' ' ( as opposed to , e . g . , `` maintenance employee ' ' ) was a not inapt description .	30.289175
today however , the `` outsider ' ' is likely to have professional qualifications of the highest order ( otherwise the college would not be interested in hiring him ) and to be acclimatized to the democratic processes of the secular or state university .	52.66278
and while no one expects total democracy on the academic scene , the scholar will be particularly sensitive to a line between first and second class citizenship drawn on any basis other than that of academic rank or professional achievement .	55.82773
in the above mentioned report of the notre dame chapter of the american association of university professors , the basic outlook of the new breed of lay faculty emerges very clearly in the very statement of the problem as the members see it `` even with the best of intentions he ( the president of the university ) is loath to delegate such authority and responsibility to a group the membership of which , considered ( as it must be by him ) in individual terms , is inhomogeneous , mortal and of extremely varying temperament , interests and capabilities .	52.740993
it is natural that he should turn for his major support to a select and dedicated few from the organization which actually owns the university and whose goals are , in their opinion , identified with its highest good and ( to use that oft-repeated phrase ) ' the attainment of excellence ' ' ' .	56.264034
the pattern here pictured is clearly not peculiar to notre dame it is simply that the paradox involved in this kind of control of the institution by `` the organization which actually owns ' ' it , becomes more obvious where there is a larger and more distinguished `` outside ' ' faculty .	38.978912
it is particularly interesting that those who framed the report should refer to `` the organization which actually owns the university ' ' this seems to show an awareness of the fact that there is more to the problem than the ordinary issue of clerical-lay tension .	60.879253
but in any case , one does not have to read very closely between the lines to realize that the situation is not regarded as a particularly happy one .	62.497948
`` outside ' ' faculty members want to be considered partners in the academic enterprise and not merely paid employees of a family business .	53.704685
there are two reasons why failure to come to grips with this demand could be fatal to the future of the catholic university .	25.547459
in the first place there is the obvious problem of recruiting high caliber personnel .	24.030886
word spreads rapidly in the tightly knit academic profession , much given to attending meetings and conferences .	84.1413
expressions of even low-key dissatisfaction by a catholic college faculty member has the effect of confirming the already existing stereotype .	87.27431
in the academic world there is seldom anything so dramatic as a strike or a boycott all that happens is that the better qualified teacher declines to gamble two or three years of his life on the chance that conditions at the catholic institution will be as good as those elsewhere .	82.97466
to appreciate the nature of the gamble , it should be realized that while college teaching is almost a public symbol of security , that security does not come as quickly or as automatically as it does in an elementary school system or in the civil service .	94.27662
much has been made of the fact that major catholic institutions now guarantee firm tenure .	171.3366
this is a significant advance but its import should not be exaggerated .	9.936988
when a man invests a block of his years at a university without gaining the coveted promotion , not only is he faced with the problem of starting over but there is also a certain depreciation in the market value of his services .	54.582138
a man does not make that kind of gamble if he suspects that one or more of the limited number of tenure positions is being reserved for members of the `` family ' ' .	26.47138
just as it is possible to exaggerate the drawing power of the new tenure practices , it is also possible to exaggerate the significance of the now relatively adequate salaries paid by major catholic institutions .	68.15647
yet adequate compensation -- and particularly merely adequate compensation is no substitute for those intangibles which cause a man to sacrifice part of his earning potential by taking up college teaching in the first place .	70.984406
broadly speaking the total catholic atmosphere is such an intangible but the larger demand is for a sense of creative participation and mature responsibility in the total work of the university .	69.78662
religious who derive their own sense of purpose through identification with the religious community rather than the academic community are prone to underestimate both the layman ' s reservoir of idealism and his need for this identification .	44.169632
there is no need here to spell out the conditions of creative teaching except to point out that , at the college level , the sense of community and of community responsibility is even more necessary than it is at other levels .	76.0149
the college teacher needs the stimulus of communication with other faculty members but he also needs to feel that such communication , even informal debates over the luncheon table , are a contribution to the total good of the institution .	59.00189
but this in turn means that decisions are not merely imposed from the top but that there be some actual mechanism of faculty participation .	66.54716
the second reason for being concerned with the dichotomy between faculty members who are part of the `` in-group ' ' that owns and operates the institution and those who are merely paid employees , is , therefore , the baneful effect on the caliber of the teaching itself .	31.722265
this is a problem that goes considerably beyond questions of salary and tenure .	47.874386
yet though it may seem difficult to envision any definitive resolution of the problem of ownership and control , there are nevertheless certain suggestions which seem to be in order .	51.635296
the first is a negative warning there is no point in the creation of faculty committees and advisory boards with high-sounding titles but no real authority .	51.43301
in the case of academic personnel the `` feeling ' ' of participation can hardly be `` faked ' ' .	8.670306
competent teachers are well versed in the technique of leading students to pre-set conclusions without destroying the students ' illusion that they are making their own decisions .	55.770473
those who have served as faculty advisers are too familiar with the useful but artificial mechanisms of student government to be taken in by `` busy-work ' ' and ersatz decision making .	75.87695
in any case it is by no means clear that formally structured organs of participation are what is called for at all .	171.0751
in the notre dame report , reference was made to the fact that faculty members were reduced to `` luncheon-table communication ' ' .	28.501766
in itself there is nothing wrong with this form of `` participation ' ' the only difficulty on the catholic campus is that those faculty members who are in a position to implement policy , i . e . , members of the religious community which owns and administers the institution , have their own eating arrangements .	40.04208
sen . john l . mcclellan of arkansas and rep . david martin of nebraska are again beating the drums to place the unions under the anti-monopoly laws .	51.369785
once more the fallacious equation is advanced to argue that since business is restricted under the anti-monopoly laws , there must be a corresponding restriction against labor unions the law must treat everybody equally .	53.967224
or , in the words of anatole france , `` the law in its majestic equality must forbid the rich , as well as the poor , from begging in the streets and sleeping under bridges ' ' .	37.868595
the public atmosphere that has been generated which makes acceptance of this law a possibility stems from the disrepute into which the labor movement has fallen as a result of mr . mcclellan ' s hearings into corruption in labor-management relations and , later , into the jurisdictional squabbles that plagued industrial relations at the missile sites .	39.018726
the senator was shocked by stoppages over allegedly trivial disputes that delayed our missile program .	162.60825
in addition , disclosures that missile workers were earning sums far in excess of what is paid for equivalent work elsewhere provoked his indignation on behalf of the american taxpayer who was footing the bill .	47.952953
it is now disclosed that the taxpayer not only pays for high wages , but he pays the employers ' strike expenses when the latter undertakes to fight a strike .	36.17474
business week ( aug . 9 , 1961 ) reports that the united aircraft company , against which the international association of machinists had undertaken a strike , decided to keep its plants operating .	93.9208
the company incurred some $10 million of expenses attributable to four factors advertising to attract new employees , hiring and training them , extra overtime , and defective work performed by the new workers .	51.325165
the company has billed the united states government for $7 , 500 , 000 of these expenses under the defense department regulation allowing costs of a type generally recognized as ordinary and necessary for the conduct of the contractor ' s business .	44.08145
rep . frank kowalski of connecticut has brought this problem to the attention of the armed services committee .	36.83483
neither has congressman martin nor senator mcclellan been heard from on the matter	113.231186
they are preoccupied with ending labor abuses by extending the anti-monopoly laws to the unions .	8.459198
the recent publicity attending the successful federal prosecution of a conspiracy indictment against a number of electrical manufacturers has evoked a new respect for the anti-trust laws that is justified neither by their rationale nor by the results they have obtained .	33.182957
the anti-trust laws inform a business that it must compete , but along completely undefined lines	209.67758
it must play a game in which there never is a winner .	71.7006
the fact is that any business that wants to operate successfully cannot follow the law .	74.37747
hypocrisy thus becomes the answer to a foolish public policy .	42.84534
let us look at the heavy-electrical-goods industry in which general electric , westinghouse and a number of other manufacturers were recently convicted of engaging in a conspiracy to rig prices and allocate the market .	33.600155
the industry is so structured that price-setting by a multi-product company will vary with the way overhead charges are allocated -- whether marginal or average pricing is applied .	108.897
the problem becomes even more complex where an enterprise is engaged in the manufacture of a wide variety of other goods in addition to the heavy electrical equipment .	27.894146
accounting procedures can be varied to provide a rationale for almost any price .	58.213146
naturally , enterprises of the size of general electric are in a position to structure their prices in such a way that the relatively small competitors can be forced to the wall in a very short time .	63.42342
should these giants really flex their competitive muscles , they would become the only survivors in the industry .	49.685463
uncle sam would then accuse them of creating a monopoly by `` unfair competition ' ' .	12.231627
but if they show self-restraint , they don ' t get the orders .	27.028837
under the circumstances , the only protection for the relatively small manufacturers is to engage in exactly the kind of conspiracy with the giants for which the latter were convicted .	85.4251
engaging in such a conspiracy was an act of mercy by the giants .	31.30993
the paradox implicit in the whole affair is shown by the demand of the government , after the conviction , that general electric sign a wide-open consent decree that it would not reduce prices so low as to compete seriously with its fellows .	43.698143
in other words , the anti-trust laws , designed to reduce prices to the consumer on monday , wednesday and friday , become a tool to protect the marginal manufacturer on tuesday , thursday and saturday .	72.179924
and which theory would govern the enforcers of the law on sunday ? ?	35.25055
the question might be asked `` don ' t the managements of the heavy-electrical-goods manufacturers know these facts ? ?	18.028648
why did they engage in a flood of mea culpas , throw a few scapegoats to the dogs and promise to be good boys thereafter , expressing their complete confidence in the laws ' ' ? ?	47.40205
the past usefulness of the anti-trust laws to management was explained by thurman arnold , in the folklore of capitalism , back in 1937 .	61.621082
he wrote `` ( p . 211 ) the anti-trust laws were the answer of a society which unconsciously felt the need of great organizations , and at the same time had to deny them a place in the moral and logical ideology of the social structure .	39.195145
( p . 214 ) anti-trust laws became the greatest protection to uncontrolled business dictatorship .	27.65342
( p . 215 ) when corporate abuses were attacked , it was done on the theory that criminal penalties would be invoked rather than control .	47.460228
in this manner , every scheme for direct control broke to pieces on the great protective rock of the anti-trust laws .	68.12778
( pp . 228-229 ) in any event , it is obvious that the anti-trust laws did not prevent the formation of some of the greatest financial empires the world has ever known , held together by some of the most fantastic ideas , all based on the fundamental notion that a corporation is an individual who can trade and exchange goods without control by the government ' ' .	47.843098
this escape from control has led to management ' s evaluating the risk of occasional irrational prosecution as worth while .	92.886765
a plea of nolo contendere , followed by a nominal fine , after all is a small price to pay for this untrammeled license .	35.17079
( the penalties handed out in the electrical case , which included jail sentences , were unprecedented in anti-trust prosecutions , perhaps because the conspirators had displayed unusual ineptness in their pricing activities .	35.22176
if a substitute mechanism is needed for the control of a fictitious impersonal market , quite obviously some method must be devised for representing the public interest .	45.91733
a secret conspiracy of manufacturers is hardly such a vehicle .	28.633717
however , one can argue that no such control is necessary as long as one pretends that the anti-trust laws are effective and rational .	43.880215
quite clearly the anti-trust laws are neither effective nor rational -- and yet the argument goes that they should be extended to the labor union .	58.927265
those who favor placing trade unions under anti-trust laws imply that they are advocating a brand new reform .	36.451126
before 1933 , individuals who opposed trade unions and collective bargaining said so in plain english .	77.12011
the acceptance of collective bargaining as a national policy in 1934 , implicit in the writing of section 7a of the national industrial recovery act , has made it impolitic to oppose collective bargaining in principle .	39.599354
the wagner act , the taft-hartley act and the landrum-griffin act all endorse the principle of collective bargaining .	10.972707
the basic purpose of an effective collective-bargaining system is the removal of wages from competition .	82.03465
if a union cannot perform this function , then collective bargaining is being palmed off by organizers as a gigantic fraud .	13.041977
the tortured reasoning that unions use to deny their ambition to exercise monopoly power over the supply and price of labor is one of the things that create a legal profession .	33.479942
if laborers are merely commodities competing against each other in a market place like so many bags of wheat and corn ( unsupported , by the way , by any agricultural subsidy ) , then they may be pardoned for reacting with complete antagonism to a system that imposes such status upon them .	61.30947
human labor was exactly that -- a commodity -- in eighteenth- and nineteenth-century america .	42.990337
as early as 1776 , adam smith wrote in the wealth of nations `` we have no acts of parliament against combining to lower the price of work	65.30188
but many against combining to raise it ' ' .	1.4575676
eighteenth-century england , upon whose customs our common law was built , had outlawed unions as monopolies and conspiracies .	36.087933
in 1825 , the boston house carpenters ' strike for a ten-hour day was denounced by the organized employers , who declared `` it is considered that all combinations by any classes of citizens intended to effect the value of labor tend to convert all its branches into monopolies ' ' .	49.147682
there were no pious hypocrisies then about being for collective bargaining , but against labor monopoly .	125.51379
the courts shared the opinion of the employers .	8.370506
in people vs . fisher , justice savage of the new york supreme court declared	21.649763
`` without any officious and improper interference on the subject , the price of labor or the wages of mechanics will be regulated by the demand for the manufactured article and the value of that which is paid for it	34.35499
but the right does not exist to raise the wages of the mechanic by any forced and artificial means ' ' .	34.643116
compare this statement of a nineteenth-century judge with how congressman martin , according to the daily labor report of sept . 19 , 1961 , defends the necessity of enacting anti-trust legislation in the field of labor `` if we wish to prevent monopolistic fixing of wages , production or prices and if we wish to preserve the freedom of the employer and his employees to contract on wages , hours and conditions of employment ' ' .	32.19262
senator mcclellan is proposing the application of anti-trust measures to unions in transportation .	27.324242
his bill , allegedly aimed at hoffa , would amend the sherman , clayton and norris-laguardia acts to authorize the issuance of federal injunctions in any transportation strike and would make it illegal for any union to act in concert with any other union -- even a sister local in the same international .	58.79151
paradoxically , the same week in which senator mcclellan was attempting to extend the anti-trust act to labor in transportation , the civil aeronautics board was assuring the airlines that if they met in concert to eliminate many costly features of air travel , the action would not be deemed a violation of the anti-trust act .	62.140285
indeed , it is in the field of transportation that congress has most frequently granted employers exemption from the anti-trust laws	90.47461
for example , the organization of steamship conferences to set freight rates and the encouragement of railroads to seek mergers .	45.16745
at the very moment that every attempt is being made to take management out from under the irrationality of anti-trust legislation , a drive is on to abolish collective bargaining under the guise of extending the anti-monopoly laws to unions who want no more than to continue to set wages in the same way that ship operators set freight rates .	47.212406
the passage of the sherman act was aimed at giant monopolies .	39.339565
in the famous danbury hatters case , a suit was brought against the union by the loewe company for monopolistic practices , e . g . , trying to persuade consumers not to purchase the product of the struck manufacturer .	17.935102
the suit against the union was successful and many workers lost their homes to pay off the judgment .	94.98279
in 1914 , the clayton act attempted to take labor out from under the anti-trust legislation by stating that human labor was not to be considered a commodity .	50.1083
labor remained a commodity -- but presumably a privileged one granted immunization from the anti-trust laws .	60.63627
the courts , by interpretation , emasculated the act .	306.89984
in 1922 , the united mine workers struck the coronado coal company .	10.560352
the company sued under the anti-trust laws , alleging that the union ' s activity interfered with the movement of interstate commerce .	18.338392
( what other purpose could a striking union have but to interrupt the flow of commerce from the struck enterprise ? ?	54.58093
) the court first ruled that the strike constituted only an indirect interference with commerce .	252.94502
at a closed-door session on capitol hill last week , secretary of state christian herter made his final report to the senate foreign relations committee on u . s . affairs abroad .	31.163479
afterward , tennessee ' s democratic senator albert gore summed it up for newsmen .	99.291084
what herter presented , said gore , was `` not a very encouraging review ' ' .	17.034922
that was something of an understatement in a week when the underlying conflict between the west and communism erupted on three fronts .	66.8595
while communists were undermining united nations efforts to rescue the congo from chaos , two other communist offensives stirred the eisenhower administration into emergency conferences and serious decisions .	40.282166
hours after a parade of his new soviet tanks and artillery , dictator fidel castro suddenly confronted the u . s . with a blunt and drastic demand within 48 hours , the u . s . had to reduce its embassy and consulate staffs in cuba to a total of eleven persons ( the embassy staff alone totaled 87 u . s . citizens , plus 120 cuban employees ) .	36.513466
president eisenhower held an 8 30 a . m . meeting with top military and foreign-policy advisers , decided to break off diplomatic relations immediately .	41.216167
`` there is a limit to what the united states in self-respect can endure ' ' , said the president .	38.012432
`` that limit has now been reached ' ' .	1.2263901
through secretary herter , ike offered president-elect kennedy an opportunity to associate his new administration with the breakoff decision .	54.109303
kennedy , through secretary-designate of state dean rusk , declined .	47.33658
he thus kept his hands free for any action after jan . 20 , although reaction to the break was generally favorable in the u . s . and latin america ( see the hemisphere ) .	52.82637
after a white house huddle between the president and top lieutenants , the defense department reacted sharply to a cry from the pro-western government of laos that several battalions of communist troops had invaded laos from north viet nam .	31.047543
`` in view of the present situation in laos ' ' , said the pentagon ' s announcement , `` we are taking normal precautionary actions to increase the readiness of our forces in the pacific ' ' .	19.93404
cutting short a holiday at hong kong , the aircraft carriers lexington and bennington steamed off into the south china sea , accompanied by a swarm of destroyers , plus troopships loaded with marines .	23.563778
on the u . s . ' s island base of okinawa , task force 116 , made up of army , navy , marine and air force units , got braced to move southward on signal .	44.161434
but by week ' s end the laotian cry of invasion was read as an exaggeration ( see foreign news ) , and the u . s . was agreeing with its cautious british and french allies that a neutralist -- rather than a pro-western -- government might be best for laos .	33.737213
there was a moral of sorts in the laotian situation that said much about all other cold-war fronts .	36.919483
political , economic and military experts were all agreed that chaotic , mountainous little laos was the last place in the world to fight a war -- and they were probably right .	79.34739
`` it would be like fighting the french and indian war all over again ' ' , said one military man .	89.74031
but why was laos the new southeast asian battleground ? ?	6.310194
at geneva in 1954 , to get the war in indo-china settled , the british and french gave in to russian and communist chinese demands and agreed to the setting up of a communist state , north viet nam -- which then , predictably , became a base for communist operations against neighboring south viet nam and laos .	48.542297
the late secretary of state john foster dulles considered the 1954 geneva agreement a specimen of appeasement , saw that resolution would be needed to keep it from becoming a calamity for the west .	56.49187
he began the diplomatic discussions that resulted in the establishment of aj .	39.61328
`` the important thing from now on ' ' , he said , `` is not to mourn the past but to seize the future opportunity to prevent the loss in northern viet nam from leading to the extension of communism throughout southeast asia ' ' .	31.393696
russian tanks and artillery parading through the streets of havana , russian intrigue in the congo , and russian arms drops in laos ( using the same ilyushin transports that were used to carry communist agents to the congo ) made it plain once more that the cold war was all of a piece in space and time .	40.10401
soviet premier khrushchev sent new year ' s hopes for peace to president-elect kennedy , and got a cool acknowledgment in reply .	40.8308
considering the state of the whole world , the cold war ' s three exposed fronts did not seem terribly ominous	35.810925
but , in senator gore ' s words , it was `` not a very encouraging ' ' situation that would confront john f . kennedy on inauguration day .	26.469183
as the 87th congress began its sessions last week , liberal democrats were ready for a finish fight to open the sluice gates controlled by the house rules committee and permit the free flow of liberal legislation to the floor .	45.90438
the liberal pressure bloc ( which coyly masquerades under the name democratic study group ) had fought the committee before , and had always lost .	162.5625
this time , they were much better prepared and organized , and the political climate was favorable .	49.52638
they had the unspoken support of president-elect kennedy , whose own legislative program was menaced by the rules committee bottleneck .	33.566574
and counting noses , they seemed to have the votes to work their will .	68.30814
there were two possible methods of breaching the conservative barriers around the rules committee 1 ) to pack it with additional liberals and break the conservative-liberal deadlock , or 2 ) to remove one of the conservatives -- namely mississippi ' s 14-term william meyers colmer ( pronounced calmer ) .	44.716373
caucusing , the liberals decided to go after colmer , which actually was the more drastic course , since seniority in the house is next to godliness .	32.07481
a dour , gangling man with a choppy gait , colmer looks younger than his 70 years , has gradually swung from a moderate , internationalist position to that of a diehard conservative .	22.465347
he is generally and initially suspicious of any federal project , unless it happens to benefit his gulf coast constituents .	85.90547
he is , of course , a segregationist , but he says he has never made an `` anti-negro ' ' speech .	23.49158
for 20 years he has enjoyed his power on the rules committee .	50.05329
there his vote , along with those of chairman howard smith , the courtly virginia judge , and the four republican members , could and often did produce a 6-6 deadlock that blocked far-out , democratic-sponsored welfare legislation ( a tactic often acceptable to the rayburn-johnson congressional leadership to avoid embarrassing votes ) .	45.899532
there was sufficient pretext to demand colmer ' s ouster he had given his lukewarm support to the anti-kennedy electors in mississippi .	14.285238
reprisals are not unheard of in such situations , but the recent tendency has been for the congress to forgive its prodigal sons .	52.149517
in 1949 the dixiecrats escaped unscathed after their 1948 rebellion against harry truman , and in 1957 , after congressman adam clayton powell campaigned for dwight eisenhower in 1956 , his fellow democrats did not touch his committee assignments , although they did strip him temporarily of his patronage .	46.63632
( in the heat of the anti-colmer drive last week , judge smith threatened reprisal against powell .	39.057346
said he `` we will see whether whites and negroes are treated the same around here ' ' .	39.73376
) but speaker sam rayburn , after huddling in palm beach with president-elect kennedy , decided that this year something had to be done about the rules committee -- and that he was the only man who could do anything effective .	49.906796
in a tense , closed-door session with judge smith , rayburn attempted to work out a compromise to add three new members to the rules committee ( two democrats , including one southerner , and one republican ) .	65.66966
smith flatly rejected the offer , and mister sam thereupon decided to join the rebels .	27.205675
the next morning he summoned a group of top democrats to his private office and broke the news he would lead the fight to oust colmer , whom he is said to regard as `` an inferior man ' ' .	53.893147
news of rayburn ' s commitment soon leaked out .	9.279716
when missouri ' s clarence cannon got the word , he turned purple .	56.44504
he shouted , and rushed off to the speaker ' s room to object `` a dangerous precedent ' ' ! !	44.440006
cannon , a powerful , conservative man , brought welcome support to the smith-colmer forces as chairman of the appropriations committee , he holds over each member the dreadful threat of excluding this or that congressional district from federal pork-barrel projects .	73.03229
sitting quietly on an equally big pork barrel was another judge smith ally , georgia ' s carl vinson , chairman of the armed services committee .	26.2492
as the battle raged in the cloakrooms and caucuses , it became clear that judge smith could lose .	57.14682
his highest count of supporters numbered 72 -- and he needed nearly twice that number to control the 260-member democratic caucus .	110.49669
the liberals , smelling blood , were faced with the necessity of winning three big votes -- in the democratic committee on committees , in the full party caucus , and on the floor of the house -- before they could oust colmer .	35.974957
( one big question if colmer was to be purged , what should the house do about the other three senior mississippians who supported the maverick electors ? ?	38.189777
) in all three arenas , they seemed certain of victory -- especially with sam rayburn applying his whiplash .	80.48632
but in the prospect of winning the battle loomed the specter of losing a costlier war .	14.307076
if the southerners were sufficiently aroused , they could very well cut the kennedy legislative program to ribbons from their vantage point of committee chairmanships , leaving sam rayburn leading a truncated , unworkable party .	63.733498
with that possibility in mind , arkansas ' wilbur mills deliberately delayed calling a meeting of the committee on committees , and coolheaded democrats sought to bring rayburn and smith together again to work out some sort of face-saving compromise .	41.559708
`` here are two old men , mad at each other and too proud to pick up the phone ' ' , said a house democratic leader .	53.024063
`` one wants a little more power , and the other doesn ' t want to give up any ' ' .	19.913143
the senate launched the 87th congress with its own version of an ancient liberal-conservative battle , but in contrast with the house ' s guerrilla war it seemed as pro forma as a capitol guide ' s speech .	37.279446
question at issue how big a vote should be necessary to restrict senate debate -- and thereby cut off legislation-delaying filibusters ? ?	55.960217
a wide-ranging , bipartisan force -- from minnesota ' s democratic hubert humphrey to massachusetts ' republican leverett saltonstall -- was drawn up against a solid phalanx of southern democrats , who have traditionally used the filibuster to stop civil rights bills .	50.734474
new mexico ' s clint anderson offered a resolution to change the senate ' s notorious rule 22 to allow three-fifths of the senators present and voting to cut off debate , instead of the current hard-to-get two-thirds .	65.50057
fair dealer humphrey upped the ante , asked cloture power for a mere majority of senators .	13.597503
georgia ' s dick russell objected politely , and the battle was joined .	54.775185
privately , the liberals admitted that the humphrey amendment had no chance of passage .	62.220993
privately , they also admitted that their hopes for clint anderson ' s three-fifths modification depended on none other than republican richard nixon .	46.91293
in 1957 nixon delivered a significant opinion that a majority of senators had the power to adopt new rules at the beginning of each new congress , and that any rules laid down by previous congresses were not binding .	53.251938
armed with the nixon opinion , the senate liberals rounded up their slim majority and prepared to choke off debate on the filibuster battle this week .	29.16712
hopefully , the perennial battle of rule 22 then would be fought to a settlement once and for all .	108.54105
since election day , vice president richard nixon had virtually retired -- by his own wish -- from public view .	261.42697
but with the convening of the new congress , he was the public man again , presiding over the senate until john kennedy ' s inauguration .	44.182503
one day last week , nixon faced a painful constitutional chore that required him to officiate at a joint session of congress to hear the official tally of the electoral college vote , and then to make `` sufficient declaration ' ' of the election of the man who defeated him in the tight 1960 presidential election .	31.099255
nixon fulfilled his assignment with grace , then went beyond the required `` sufficient declaration ' ' .	44.029636
`` this is the first time in 100 years that a candidate for the presidency announced the result of an election in which he was defeated ' ' , he said .	25.298988
the masters golf tournament proved last monday what it can do to the strongest men and the staunchest nerves .	42.939438
gary player , the small , trim south african , was the eventual winner , but in all his 25 years he never spent a more harrowing afternoon as he waited for the victory to drop in his lap .	52.152885
arnold palmer , the defending champion , lost his title on the 72nd hole after a few minutes of misfortune that left even his fellow pros gaping in disbelief .	37.730232
`` just when you think you have it licked , this golf course can get up and bite you ' ' , player had said one afternoon midway through the tournament .	62.71728
and that is just what happened on the last few holes .	171.63121
the augusta national golf club course got up and bit both player and palmer .	157.19461
player was the first to feel its teeth .	1.8017663
after playing a splendid first nine holes in 34 -- two strokes under par -- on this fifth and final day of the tournament ( sunday ' s fourth round had been washed out by a violent rainstorm when it was only half completed ) , player ' s game rapidly fell to pieces .	66.28524
after a journey through woods and stream he double-bogeyed the 13th .	9.612505
he bogeyed the 15th by missing a short putt and finally scrambled through the last three holes without further mishap for a 2-over-par 74 and a 72-hole total of 280 .	19.33891
as he signed his scorecard and walked off the course , player was almost in tears .	38.60685
he could read on the nearby scoreboard that palmer , by then playing the 15th hole , was leading him by a stroke .	66.08239
palmer had started the round four strokes behind player , and at one point in the afternoon had trailed by as many as six strokes .	48.50138
now all he had to do was finish in even par to collect the trophy and the biggest single paycheck in golf .	48.73518
when palmer hit a good straight drive up the fairway on the 72nd hole , he seemed to have the championship won .	9.121626
but the seven-iron shot he used to approach the green strayed into a bunker and lodged in a slight depression .	11.008543
in trying to hit it out with a sand wedge palmer bounced the ball over the green , past spectators and down the slope toward a tv tower .	67.598114
afterwards , palmer told charlie coe , his last-round partner , that he simply played the hole too fast .	71.276436
he did seem hasty on his second and third shots , but then there was an agonizing wait of several minutes while coe graciously putted out , giving palmer a chance to recover his composure , which he had quite visibly lost .	29.332544
when the shaken palmer finally did hit his fourth shot , he overshot the hole by 15 feet .	28.966938
palmer was now putting merely for a tie , and player , who was sitting beside his wife and watching it all on television in tournament chairman clifford roberts ' clubhouse apartment , stared in amazement when palmer missed the putt .	41.413773
palmer ' s 281 for the four rounds at augusta was a comfortable four strokes ahead of the next closest pro , but it was barely good enough for a second-place tie with coe .	39.506584
the lean and leathery oklahoma amateur , who has been playing topnotch tournament golf for many years , refused to let the masters jitters overtake him and closed the tournament with his second straight 69 .	26.707369
until late last saturday afternoon palmer had played seven consecutive rounds of golf at the masters -- four last year and three this -- without ever being out of first place .	99.28105
as evening approached and palmer finished his saturday round with a disappointing one-over-par 73 , this remarkable record was still intact , thanks to his thursday and friday rounds of 68 and 69 .	61.32111
his three-round total of 210 was three strokes better than the next best score , a 213 by bill collins , the tall and deliberate baltimorean who had been playing very well all winter long .	67.90607
but palmer knew , as did everybody else at augusta , that his streak was about to be broken .	22.74854
half an hour after he finished his round , player holed out at the 18th green with a 69 and a three-round total of 206 , four strokes ahead of palmer .	13.620364
long after the erratic climate and the washed-out final round on sunday have become meteorological footnotes , the 1961 masters will be remembered as the scene of the mano a mano between arnold palmer and gary player .	40.495358
unlike most such sports rivalries , it appeared to have developed almost spontaneously , although this was not exactly the case .	50.20085
when the winter tour began at los angeles last january there was no one in sight to challenge palmer ' s towering prestige .	54.555336
as if to confirm his stature , he quickly won three of the first eight tournaments .	40.316967
but as the tour reached pensacola a month ago , player was leading palmer in official winnings by a few hundred dollars , and the rest of the field was somewhere off in nowhere .	29.52277
on the final round at pensacola , the luck of the draw paired palmer and player in the same threesome and , although it was far from obvious at the time , the gallery was treated to the first chapter of what promises to be one of the most exciting duels in sport for a long time to come .	26.664492
on that final sunday at pensacola neither palmer nor player was leading the tournament and , as it turned out , neither won it .	55.079975
but whichever of these two finished ahead of the other would be the undisputed financial leader of the tour .	60.956112
player immediately proved he was not in the least awed by the dramatic proximity of palmer .	21.495205
he outplayed palmer all around the course and finished with a tremendous 65 to palmer ' s 71 .	28.232265
thereafter , until the masters , player gradually increased his lead over palmer in winnings and added one more tournament victory at miami .	89.4466
when they reached augusta last week , together they had won five of the 13 tournaments to date .	75.389404
on thursday , the first day of the masters , the contest between palmer and player developed instantly .	31.181293
it was a dismal , drizzly day but a good one on which to score over the augusta national course .	109.06907
the usually skiddy greens were moist and soft , so the golfers were able to strike their approach shots boldly at the flag-stick and putt firmly toward the hole without too much worry about the consequences .	50.84192
palmer ' s 4-under-par 68 got him off to an early lead , which he shared with bob rosburg .	51.349693
but player was only one stroke back , with a 69 .	19.473372
even so , it was still not clear to many in the enormous horde of spectators -- unquestionably the largest golf crowd ever -- that this tournament was to be , essentially , a match between palmer and player .	39.852024
a lot of people were still thinking about jack nicklaus , the spectacular young amateur , who had a 70	58.00041
or ken venturi , who had a somewhat shaky 72 but was bound to do better	42.04259
or rosburg , whose accurate short game and supersensitive putter can overcome so many of augusta ' s treacheries	14.798855
or even old byron nelson , whose excellent 71 made one wonder if he had solved the geriatric aspects of golf .	104.100494
( on thursday nobody except charlie coe was thinking of charlie coe .	19.870426
on friday , a day as cloudless and lovely as thursday had been gray and ugly , the plot of the tournament came clearly into focus .	95.63267
rosburg had started early in the day , and by the time palmer and player were on the course -- separated , as they were destined to be for the rest of the weekend , by about half an hour -- they could see on the numerous scoreboards spotted around the course that rosburg , who ended with a 73 , was not having a good day .	46.505543
as player began his second round in a twosome with amateur bill hyndman , his share of the gallery was not conspicuously large for a contender .	37.946358
player began with a birdie on the first hole , added five straight pars and then another birdie at the 9th .	24.332472
on the back nine he began to acquire the tidal wave of a gallery that stayed with him the rest of the tournament .	24.47561
he birdied the 13th , the 15th and the 18th -- five birdies , one bogey and 12 pars for a 68 .	19.512362
starting half an hour behind player in company with british open champion kel nagle , palmer birdied the 2nd , the 9th , the 13th and the 16th -- four birdies , one bogey and 13 pars for a 69 .	19.096668
the roar of palmer ' s gallery as he sank a thrilling putt would roll out across the parklike landscape of augusta , only to be answered moments later by the roar of player ' s gallery for a similar triumph .	34.757004
at one point late in the day , when palmer was lining up a 25-foot putt on the 16th , a thunderous cheer from the direction of the 18th green unmistakably announced that player had birdied the final hole .	18.743738
without so much as a grimace or a gesture to show that he had noticed ( although he later admitted that he had ) palmer proceeded to sink his 25-footer , and his gallery sent its explosive vocalization rolling back along the intervening fairways in reply .	35.96145
anyone who now doubted that a personal duel was under way had only to watch how these exceptionally gifted golfers were playing this most difficult golf course .	70.21026
it is almost axiomatic that golfers who dominate the game of golf for any period of time attack their shots with a vehemence bordering on violence .	74.11672
the bad luck that can so often mar a well-played round of golf is simply overpowered and obliterated by the contemptuous boldness of these champions .	20.470627
and last week at the masters palmer and player did .	21.178822
as the third round of the tournament began on saturday and the duel was resumed in earnest , it was player ' s superior aggressiveness that carried him into the lead .	32.8876
as player stepped on the first tee he knew that palmer had birdied the first two holes and already was 2 under par for the day .	51.82064
in fact , he went on to birdie the 6th and 8th as well , to go 4 under par for the first eight holes .	51.16777
but player ' s real test came on the ninth hole , a downhill dogleg to the left measuring 420 yards .	12.6910515
he hit a poor tee shot , pulling it off into the pine woods separating the 9th and first fairways .	22.368938
having hit one of the trees , the ball came to rest not more than 160 yards out .	76.51609
player then had the choice of punching the ball safely out of the woods to the 9th fairway and settling for a bogey 5 , or gambling .	19.581375
the latter involved hitting a full four-wood out to the first fairway and toward the clubhouse , hoping to slice it back to the deeply bunkered 9th green .	25.419554
`` i was hitting the ball well ' ' , player said later , `` and i felt strong .	32.193817
when you ' re playing like that you ' d better attack ' ' .	33.55074
player attacked with his four-wood and hit a shot that few who saw it will ever forget .	117.8052
it struck the 9th green on the fly and stopped just off the edge .	24.905928
from there he chipped back and sank his putt for a par 4 .	40.574665
palmer , meanwhile , had been having his troubles .	5.5842886
they started on the 4th hole , a 220-yard par-3 .	5.379364
on this day the wind had switched 180-degrees from the northwest to the southeast , and nearly every shot on the course was different from the previous few days .	44.189365
at the 4th tee palmer chose to hit a one-iron when a three-wood was the proper club , so he put the ball in a bunker in front of the green .	33.964973
his bogey 4 on this hole and subsequent bogeys at 5 and 7 along with a birdie at 8 brought him back to even par .	82.25678
starting the second nine , palmer was already four strokes behind player and knew it .	60.24788
when mickey charles mantle , the new york yankees ' man of muscle , drives a home run 450 feet into the bleachers , his feat touches upon the sublime .	51.979782
when roger eugene maris , mantle ' s muscular teammate , powers four home runs in a double-header , his performance merits awe .	31.51372
but when tiny , 145-pound albert gregory pearson of the los angeles angels , who once caught three straight fly balls in center field because , as a teammate explained , `` the other team thought no one was out there ' ' , hits seven home runs in four months ( three more than his total in 1958 , 1959 , and 1960 ) , his achievement borders on the ridiculous .	63.480724
this is the year home runs ranged from the sublime to the ridiculous .	9.443773
it is the year when ( 1 ) amiable jim gentile of the baltimore orioles ambled to the plate in consecutive innings with the bases loaded and , in unprecedented style , delivered consecutive grand-slam home runs	31.180424
( 2 ) willie mays of the san francisco giants borrowed a teammate ' s bat and became the ninth big leaguer to stroke four home runs in a game	24.237967
( 3 ) the milwaukee braves tied a major-league record with fourteen home runs in three games and lost two of them	24.27035
and ( 4 ) catcher johnny blanchard of the new york yankees matched a record with home runs in four successive times at bat , two of them as a pinch-hitter .	22.122654
pitchers grumble about lively balls and lively bats , the shrinking strike zone , and the fact that the knock-down pitch is now illegal .	12.630945
experts point to the thinning of pitching talent in the american league caused by expansion .	68.98766
whatever the reasons , not in 30 years has a single season produced such thunderous assaults upon the bureau of baseball records , home-run division .	96.30986
of all the records in peril , one stands apart , dramatic in its making , dramatic in its endurance , and now , doubly dramatic in its jeopardy .	65.29416
this , of course , is baseball ' s most remarkable mark the 60 home runs hit in 1927 by the incorrigible epicure , the incredible athlete , george herman ( babe ) ruth of the yankees .	22.59271
since 1927 , fewer than a dozen men have made serious runs at babe ruth ' s record and each , in turn , has been thwarted .	56.574677
what ultimately frustrated every challenger was ruth ' s amazing september surge .	22.5404
in the final month of the 1927 season , he hit seventeen home runs , a closing spurt never matched .	38.764885
always , in the abortive attacks upon ruth ' s record , one man alone -- a jimmy foxx ( 58 in 1932 ) or a hank greenberg ( 58 in 1938 ) or a hack wilson ( 56 in 1930 ) -- made the bid .	19.45463
but now , for the first time since lou gehrig ( with 47 home runs ) spurred ruth on in 1927 , two men playing for the same team have zeroed in on 60 .	61.11936
their names are mantle and maris , their team is the yankees , and their threat is real .	38.384632
after 108 games in 1927 , ruth had 35 home runs .	15.386368
after 108 games in 1961 , mickey mantle has 43 , roger maris 41 .	24.69591
extend mantle ' s and maris ' s present paces over the full 1961 schedule of 162 games , and , mathematically , each will hit more than 60 home runs .	46.182056
this is the great edge the two yankees have going for them .	150.75938
to better ruth ' s mark , neither needs a spectacular september flourish .	118.56888
all mantle needs is eight more home runs in august and ten in september , and he will establish a new record .	40.515457
in ruth ' s day -- and until this year -- the schedule was 154 games .	69.63167
baseball commissioner ford frick has ruled that ruth ' s record will remain official unless it is broken in 154 games .	44.71217
`` even on the basis of 154 games , this is the ideal situation ' ' , insists hank greenberg , now vice-president of the chicago white sox .	19.609789
`` it has to be easier with two of them .	14.330458
how can you walk maris to get to mantle ' ' ? ?	9.839697
neither mantle nor maris , understandably , will predict 60 home runs for himself .	37.971832
although both concede they would like to hit 60 , they stick primarily to the baseball player ' s standard quote `` the important thing is to win the pennant ' ' .	50.509857
but one thing is for certain there is no dissension between mantle , the american league ' s most valuable player in 1956 and 1957 , and maris , the mvp in 1960 .	33.069874
each enjoys seeing the other hit home runs ( `` i hope roger hits 80 ' ' , mantle says ) , and each enjoys even more seeing himself hit home runs ( `` and i hope i hit 81 ' ' ) .	44.90742
the sluggers get along so well in fact , that with their families at home for the summer ( mantle ' s in dallas , maris ' s in kansas city ) , they are rooming together .	58.58275
