actually , the communists , out of fear of a united and armed germany , would probably be willing to agree to a disarmed germany that would be united and neutral and have its independence guaranteed by the u . n . .	29.252523
if the communists are sincere in wanting a united , neutral and disarmed germany , it might well be advantageous for the german people in this nuclear age .	26.25108
it could provide security without cost of armaments and increase german prosperity and lessen taxation .	68.76545
france and other western european nations likewise fear a rearmed germany .	10.343777
if the german people favor such a settlement we should not oppose germany following the example of austria .	141.98203
president kennedy has urged a peace race on disarmament that might be called `` operation survival ' ' which has many facets .	35.974243
why not make a beginning with a united and disarmed germany whose neutrality and immunity from nuclear bombing would be guaranteed by the big four powers and the united states ? ?	25.826021
a united germany , freed of militarism , might be the first step toward disarmament and peace in a terrorized and tortured world .	42.528004
in your editorial of sept . 30 `` the smoldering congo ' ' you make the following comment `` far too many states are following the russian example in refusing to pay their assessments .	91.79659
it is up to the assembly to take action against them .	22.49637
they are violating their charter obligation , the prescribed penalty for which is suspension of membership or expulsion ' ' .	16.296267
i would like to quote from the charter of the united nations	5.067217
the general assembly shall consider and approve the budget of the organization .	23.201359
the expenses of the organization shall be borne by the members as apportioned by the general assembly .	24.000122
a member of the united nations which is in arrears in the payment of its financial contributions to the organization shall have no vote in the general assembly if the amount of its arrears equals or exceeds the amount of the contributions due from it for the preceding two full years ' ' .	42.329334
the u . s . s . r . and her followers are careful in paying their obligations to the regular budget .	38.87191
but they refuse , as do the arab states , to support the united nations ' expenses of maintaining the united nations emergency force in the middle east as a buffer between egypt and israel , and the u . n . troops in the congo , which expenses are not covered by the regular budget of the united nations , but by a special budget .	27.118328
according to the official interpretation of the charter , a member cannot be penalized by not having the right to vote in the general assembly for nonpayment of financial obligations to the `` special ' ' united nations ' budgets , and of course cannot be expelled from the organization ( which you suggested in your editorial ) , due to the fact that there is no provision in the charter for expulsion .	30.416172
connally amendment ' s repeal held step toward world order	2360.8972
in your sept . 27 editorial appraisal of the work of the first session of the eighty-seventh congress you referred to the lack of `` consciousness of destiny in a time of acute national and world peril ' ' .	36.06366
yet your list of things left undone did not include repeal of the connally amendment to this country ' s domestic jurisdiction reservation to its adherence to the statute of the international court of justice .	23.08121
the connally amendment says that the united states , rather than the court , shall determine whether a matter is essentially within the domestic jurisdiction of the united states in a case before the world court to which the united states is a party .	55.02125
if the case is thus determined by us to be domestic , the court has no jurisdiction .	47.24854
since the connally amendment has the effect of giving the same right to the other party to a dispute with the united states , it also prevents us from using the court effectively .	54.67169
yet although the kennedy administration , and the eisenhower administration before it , have both declared themselves solidly for repeal of the connally amendment , as contrary to our best interests , no action has yet been taken .	47.189957
our `` destiny ' ' in these perilous times should be to lead strongly in the pursuit of peace , with justice , under law .	63.513092
to achieve this destiny , acts as well as words are needed -- not only acts that lead to physical strength but also acts that lead to strength based on right doing and respect .	225.49709
what better affirmative step could be taken to this end than repeal of the connally amendment -- an act which could expose the united states to no practical risk yet would put an end to our self-judging attitude toward the court , enable us to utilize it , and advance in a tangible way the cause of international law and order ? ?	70.45017
we believe that the list of vital things left undone to date by the eighty-seventh congress should have included repeal by the senate of the connally amendment .	14.223792

your continuing editorials concerning the schuylkill expressway are valuable	111.388405
one of the problems associated with the expressway stems from the basic idea .	80.83957
we shuffle a large percentage of the cars across the river twice .	65.58714
they start on the east side of the schuylkill , have to cross over to the west to use the expressway and cross over again to the east at their destination .	54.695736
bridges , tunnels and ferries are the most common methods of river crossings .	50.872246
each one of these is , by its nature , a focal point or a point of natural congestion .	39.141384
we should avoid these congestion points or , putting it another way , keep cars starting and ending on the east side of the river -- on the east side .	54.793785

this could be accomplished without the tremendous expenditures necessitated by the schuylkill expressway and without destroying the natural beauty of the east river drive .	24.002775

when we become firm enough to stand for those ideals which we know to be right , when we become hard enough to refuse to aid nations which do not permit self-determination , when we become strong enough to resist any more drifts towards socialism in our own nation , when we recognize that our enemy is communism not war , and when we realize that concessions to communists do not insure peace or freedom , then , and only then will we no longer be `` soft ' ' .	59.647846

the new column by maurice stans regarding business scandals , is fair and accurate in most respects and his solution to the problem has some merit .	41.210094
however , he states unequivocally `` the scandals in business are far less significant than the scandals in labor ' ' .	41.60165
i must , in fairness , take issue with his premise , primarily because the so-called scandals in labor unions were very much connected with business scandals .	51.875885
the area most prominently commented on during the mcclellan hearings had to do with `` sweetheart contracts ' ' .	24.957865
these arrangements would have been impossible if the business community was truly interested in the welfare of its employes .	57.440483
a sweetheart arrangement can come about as often by employers doing the corrupting as by unscrupulous labor leaders demanding tribute .	128.93825
anyone familiar with the details of the mcclellan hearings must at once realize that the sweetheart arrangements augmented employer profits far more than they augmented the earnings of the corruptible labor leaders .	45.759354
further , it should be recalled that some very definite steps were taken by congress to combat corruption in the labor movement by its passage of the landrum-griffin act .	43.825336
the nuclear war is already being fought , except that the bombs are not being dropped on enemy targets -- not yet .	57.672474
it is being fought , moreover , in fairly close correspondence with the predictions of the soothsayers of the think factories .	50.202915
they predicted escalation , and escalation is what we are getting .	23.64101
the biggest nuclear device the united states has exploded measured some 15 megatons , although our b-52s are said to be carrying two 20-megaton bombs apiece .	42.556885
some time ago , however , mr . khrushchev decided that when bigger bombs were made , the soviet union would make them .	52.471012
he seems to have at least a few 30- and 50-megaton bombs on hand , since we cannot assume that he has exploded his entire stock .	58.391518
and now , of course , the hue and cry for counter-escalation is being raised on our side .	31.539946
khrushchev threatens us with a 100-megaton bomb ? ?	1.0348096
so be it -- then we must embark on a crash program for 200-megaton bombs of the common or hydrogen variety , and neutron bombs , which do not exist but are said to be the coming thing .	80.39193
so escalation proceeds , ad infinitum or , more accurately , until the contestants begin dropping them on each other instead of on their respective proving grounds .	47.414867
what is needed , philip morrison writes in the cornell daily sun ( october 26 ) is a discontinuity .	36.418045
the escalation must end sometime , and probably quite soon .	286.39923
`` only a discontinuity can end it ' ' , professor morrison writes .	15.663698
`` the discontinuity can either be that of war to destruction , or that of diplomatic policy ' ' .	71.87076
morrison points out that since our country is more urbanized than the soviet union or red china , it is the most vulnerable of the great powers -- europe of course must be written off out of hand .	43.049644
he feels , therefore , that to seek a discontinuity in the arms policy of the united states is the least risky path our government can take .	64.071396
his proposal is opposed to that of richard nixon , governor rockefeller , past chairmen strauss and mccone of the atomic energy commission , dr . edward teller and those others now enjoying their hour of triumph in the exacerbation of the cold war .	21.123245
these gentlemen are calling for a resumption of testing -- in the atmosphere -- on the greatest possible scale , all in the name of national security .	49.665577
capable as their minds may be in some directions , these guardians of the nation ' s security are incapable of learning , or even of observing .	43.44467
if this capacity had not failed them , they would see that their enemy has made a disastrous miscalculation .	30.111694
he has gained only one thing -- he has exploded a 50-megaton bomb and he probably has rockets with sufficient thrust to lob it over the shorter intercontinental ranges .	28.33625
but if his purpose was to inspire terror , his action could hardly have miscarried more obviously .	33.810963
not terror , but anger and resentment have been the general reaction outside the soviet sphere .	61.80892
khrushchev himself is reported to be concerned by the surge of animosity he has aroused , yet our own nuclear statesmen seem intent on following compulsively in his footsteps .	44.80689
when one powerful nation strives to emulate the success of another , it is only natural .	56.83298
thus , when the russians sent up their first sputnik , american chagrin was human enough , and american determination to put american satellites into orbit was perfectly understandable .	96.03205
but to imitate an opponent when he has made the mistake of his life would be a new high in statesmanlike folly .	19.955532
when east germans fled to the west by the thousands , paeans of joy rose from the throats of western publicists .	31.589577
they are less vocal now , when it is the west berliners who are migrating .	25.191154
the flood is not as great -- only 700 a week according to one apparently conservative account -- but it is symptomatic .	106.898544
west berlin morale is low and , in age distribution , the situation is unfavorable .	116.89836
nearly 18 per cent of west berlin ' s 2 , 200 , 000 residents are sixty-five or older , only 12 . 8 per cent are under fifteen .	30.190016
r . h . s . crossman , m . p . , writing in the manchester guardian , states that departures from west berlin are now running at the rate not of 700 , but of 1 , 700 a week , and applications to leave have risen to 1 , 900 a week .	39.19312
the official statistics show that 60 per cent are employed workers or independent professional people .	239.86671
whole families are moving and removal firms are booked for months ahead .	148.92087
the weekly loss is partly counterbalanced by 500 arrivals each week from west germany , but the hard truth , says crossman , is that `` the closing off of east berlin without interference from the west and with the use only of east german , as distinct from russian , troops was a major communist victory , which dealt west berlin a deadly , possibly a fatal , blow .	78.54557
the gallant half-city is dying on its feet ' ' .	6.7334285
another piece of evidence appears in a dispatch from bonn in the observer ( london ) .	23.494804
mark arnold-foster writes `` people are leaving ( west berlin ) because they think it is dying .	39.01751
they are leaving so fast that the president of the west german employers ' federation issued an appeal this week to factory workers in the west to volunteer for six months ' front-line work in factories in west berlin .	52.59299
berlin ' s resilience is amazing , but if it has to hire its labor in the west the struggle will be hard indeed ' ' .	95.59218
the only hope for west berlin lies in a compromise which will bring down the wall and reunite the city .	33.69202
state department officials refusing to show their passes at the boundary , and driving two blocks into east berlin under military escort , will not avail .	71.131226
tanks lined up at the border will be no more helpful .	30.881002
the materials for compromise are at hand the nation , walter lippmann and other sober commentators ( see alan clark on p . 367 ) have spelled them out again and again .	45.503494
a compromise will leave both sides without the glow of triumph , but it will save berlin .	49.858036
or the city can be a graveyard monument to western intransigence , if that is what the west wants .	49.743244
the removal of stalin ' s body from the mausoleum he shared with lenin to less distinguished quarters in the kremlin wall is not unprecedented in history .	36.0459
it is , in fact , a relatively mild chastisement of the dead .	7.9056883
a british writer , richard haestier , in a book , dead men tell tales , recalls that in the turmoil preceding the french revolution the body of henry 4 , , who had died nearly 180 years earlier , was torn to pieces by a mob .	57.92589
and in england , after the restoration , the body of cromwell was disinterred and hanged at tyburn .	9.08429
the head was then fixed on a pole at westminster , and the rest of the body was buried under the gallows .	12.68098
contemplating these posthumous punishments , stalin should not lose all hope .	51.122227
in 1899 , parliament erected a statue to cromwell in westminster , facing whitehall and there , presumably , he still stands .	33.14745
nikita khrushchev , however , has created yet another problem for himself .	100.34583
the lenin tomb is obviously adequate for double occupancy , moscow is a crowded city , and the creed of communism deplores waste .	34.018097
who will take stalin ' s place beside lenin ? ?	5.179851
there is karl marx , of course , buried in london .	123.28649
the macmillan government might be willing to let him go , but he has been dead seventy-eight years and even the soviet morticians could not make him look presentable .	27.294954
who , then , is of sufficient stature to lodge with lenin ? ?	26.472794
since he has just shown who is top dog , he may not be ready to receive this highest honor in the gift of the soviet people .	42.070156
besides , he can hardly avoid musing on the instability of death which , what with exhumations and rehabilitations , seems to match that of life .	26.25861
suppose he did lie beside lenin , would it be permanent ? ?	22.55672
if some future khrushchev decided to rake up the misdeeds of his revered predecessor , would not the factory workers pass the same resolutions applauding his dispossession ? ?	23.836355
when a man is laid to rest , he is entitled to stay put .	73.119965
if nikita buys a small plot in some modest rural cemetery , everyone will understand .	58.57979
the appointment of u thant of burma as the u . n . ' s acting secretary general -- at this writing , the choice appears to be certain -- offers further proof that in politics it is more important to have no influential enemies than to have influential friends .	51.504944
mongi slim of tunisia and frederick boland of ireland were early favorites in the running , but france didn ' t like the former and the soviet union would have none of the latter .	51.353085
with the neutralists maintaining pressure for one of their own to succeed mr . hammarskjold , u thant emerged as the only possible candidate unlikely to be waylaid by a veto .	33.746826
what is interesting is that his positive qualifications for the post were revealed only as a kind of tail to his candidacy .	85.68787
in all the bitter in-fighting , the squabbles over election procedures , the complicated numbers game that east and west played on the assistant secretaries ' theme , the gentleman from burma showed himself both as a man of principle and a skilled diplomat .	148.33852
he has , moreover , another qualification which augurs well for the future .	12.691305
he is a buddhist , which means that to him peace and the sanctity of human life are not only religious dogma , but a profound and unshakable weltanschauung .	18.829325
u thant of course , will hold office until the spring of 1963 , when mr . hammarskjold ' s term would have come to an end .	22.588974
whether the compromises -- on both sides -- that made possible the interim appointment can then be repeated remains to be seen .	141.70667
mr . khrushchev ' s demand for a troika is dormant , not dead	52.464733
the west may or not remain satisfied with the kind of neutralism that u thant represents .	27.225307
in a sense , the showdown promised by mr . hammarskjold ' s sudden and tragic death has been avoided	15.568394
structurally , the u . n . is still fluid , vulnerable to the pressures that its new and enlarged membership are bringing to bear upon it .	77.87392
but at least the pessimists who believed that the world organization had plunged to its death in that plane crash in the congo have been proved wrong .	70.34826
no one who has studied the radical right can suppose that words are their sole staple in trade .	45.662933
these are mentalities which crave action -- and they are beginning to get it , as messrs . salsich and engh report on page 372 .	35.819714
even in areas where political connotations are ( deliberately ? ?	86.570404
) left vague , the spirit of vigilantism is spreading .	66.631294
friends , a picture magazine distributed by chevrolet dealers , describes a paramilitary organization of employees of the gulf telephone company at foley , alabama .	22.27949
`` if the day should ever come that foreign invaders swarm ashore along the gulf coast ' ' , the account reads , `` they can count on heavy opposition from a group of commando-trained telephone employees -- all girls .	57.075256
heavily armed and mobilized as a fast-moving civil defense outfit , 23 operators and office personnel stand ready to move into action at a minute ' s notice ' ' .	62.286182
according to friends , the unit was organized by john snook , a former world war 2 , commando who is vice president and general manager of the telephone company .	12.826962
the girls , very fetching in their uniforms , are shown firing rockets from a launcher mounted on a dump truck	22.934067
they are also trained with carbines , automatic weapons , pistols , rifles and other such ladies ' accessories .	19.531582
this may be opera bouffe now , but it will become more serious should the cold war mount in frenzy .	73.222466
the country is committed to the doctrine of security by military means .	79.200874
the official military establishment can only threaten to use its nuclear arms	38.23729
a more dangerous formula for national frustration cannot be imagined .	3.050668
as the civic temper rises , the more naive citizens begin to play soldier -- but the guns are real .	76.76412
soon they will begin to hunt down the traitors they are assured are in our midst .	126.755905
all false gods resemble moloch , at least in the early phases of their careers , so it would be unreasonable to expect any form of idol-worship to become widespread without the accompaniment of human sacrifice .	30.097864
but there is reason in all things , and in this country the heathenish cult of the motor-car is exceeding all bounds in its demands .	17.344824
the annual butchery of 40 , 000 american men , women and children to satiate its blood-lust is excessive	20.44758
a quota of 25 , 000 a year would be more than sufficient .	49.739933
no other popular idol is accorded even that much grace .	95.78523
if the railroads , for example , regularly slaughtered 25 , 000 passengers each year , the high priests of the cult would have cause to tremble for their personal safety , for such a holocaust would excite demands for the hanging of every railroad president in the united states .	60.42104
but by comparison with the railroad , the motor car is a relatively new object of popular worship , so it is too much to hope that it may be brought within the bounds of civilized usage quickly and easily .	59.423916
yet it is plainly time to make a start , and to be effective the first move should be highly dramatic , without being fanatical .	60.73335
here , then , is what swift would have called a modest proposal by way of a beginning .	58.401016
from next new year ' s day let us keep careful account of each successive fatality on the highways , publicizing it on all media of communication .	59.39151
to avoid suspicion of bigotry , let the hand of vengeance be stayed until the meat-wagon has picked up the twenty-five thousandth corpse	56.12799
but let the twenty-five thousand and first butchery be the signal for the arrest of the 50 state highway commissioners .	68.357056
then let the whole lot be hanged in a public mass execution on july 4 , 1963 .	46.29455
the scene , of course , should be nine miles northwest of centralia , illinois , the geographical center of population according to the census .	35.84142
a special grandstand , protected by awnings from the midsummer sun of illinois , should be erected for occupancy by honored guests , who should include the ambassadors of all those new african nations as yet not quite convinced that the united states is thoroughly civilized .	44.1698
the band should play the rogues ' march as a processional , switching to `` hail columbia , happy land ' ' ! !	18.934252
independence day is the appropriate date as a symbolical reminder of the american article of faith that governments are instituted among men to secure to them certain inalienable rights , the first of which is life , and when any government becomes subversive of that end , it is the right of the people to alter or abolish it .	68.432556
the highway system is an agency of government , and when it grinds up 40 , 000 americans every year the government is destroying its own taxpayers , which is obviously a silly thing for any government to do .	61.431442
hanging the responsible officials would not abolish the government , but would emphasize its accountability for the lives of its individual citizens , which would certainly alter it , and definitely for the better .	43.067955
moreover , the salubrious effects would not be exclusively political , but at least partially , and perhaps primarily social .	142.4606
it would challenge sharply not the cult of the motor car itself but some of its ancillary beliefs and practices -- for instance , the doctrine that the fulfillment of life consists in proceeding from hither to yon , not for any advantage to be gained by arrival but merely to avoid the cardinal sin of stasis , or , as it is generally termed , staying put .	47.850784
true , the adherents of staying put are now reduced to a minor , even a miniscule sect , and their credo , `` home-keeping hearts are happiest ' ' , is as disreputable as socinianism .	22.431843
nonetheless , although few in number they are a stubborn crew , as tenacious of life as the hardshell baptists , which suggests that there is some kind of vital principle embodied in their faith .	52.124657
perhaps there is more truth than we are wont to admit in the conviction of that ornament of tarheelia , robert ruark ' s grandfather , who was persuaded that the great curse of the modern world is `` all this gallivantin ' ' ' .	15.940845
in any event , the yearly sacrifice of 40 , 000 victims is a hecatomb too large to be justified by the most ardent faith .	54.448902
somehow our contemporary moloch must be induced to see reason .	377.74628
since appeals to morality , to humanity , and to sanity have had such small effect , perhaps our last recourse is the deterrent example .	100.31665
if we make it established custom that whenever butchery on the highways grows excessive , say beyond 25 , 000 per annum , then somebody is going to hang , it follows that the more eminent the victim , the more impressive the lesson .	63.426018
to hang 50 governors might be preferable except that they are not directly related to the highways	33.027683
so , all things considered , the highway commissioners would seem to be elected .	13.156031
as the new clouds of radioactive fallout spread silently and invisibly around the earth , the soviet union stands guilty of a monstrous crime against the human race .	21.394253
but the guilt is shared by the united states , britain and france , the other members of the atomic club .	21.252924
until moscow resumed nuclear testing last september 1 , the us and uk had released more than twice as much radiation into the atmosphere as the russians , and the fallout from the earlier blasts is still coming down .	80.71023
as it descends , the concentration of radioactivity builds up in the human body	26.534517
for a dose of radiation is not like a flu virus which causes temporary discomfort and then dies .	15.277185
the effect of radiation is cumulative over the years -- and on to succeeding generations .	62.696682
so , while we properly inveigh against the new poisoning , history is not likely to justify the pose of righteousness which some in the west were so quick to assume when mr . khrushchev made his cynical and irresponsible threat .	50.766357
shock , dismay and foreboding for future generations were legitimate reactions	34.29829
on october 19 , after the soviets had detonated at least 20 nuclear devices , ambassador stevenson warned the un general assembly that this country , in `` self protection ' ' , might have to resume above-ground tests .	37.665844
more recently , the chairman of the atomic energy commission , dr . glenn t . seaborg , `` admitted ' ' to a news conference in las vegas , nevada , that the us might fall behind russia ( he apparently meant in weapons development ) if the soviets continue to test in the atmosphere while we abstain .	30.913357
all of which makes it more imperative than ever that the biological and genetic effects of fallout be understood .	43.98709
but for the average citizen , unfortunately , this is one of science ' s worst-marked channels , full of tricky currents and unknown depths .	53.244728
the scientists , in and out of government , do not agree on some of the most vital points , at least publicly .	44.035088
on the one hand , the public health service declared as recently as october 26 that present radiation levels resulting from the soviet shots `` do not warrant undue public concern ' ' or any action to limit the intake of radioactive substances by individuals or large population groups anywhere in the aj .	78.46905
but the phs conceded that the new radioactive particles `` will add to the risk of genetic effects in succeeding generations , and possibly to the risk of health damage to some people in the united states ' ' .	27.632414
then it added `` it is not possible to determine how extensive these ill effects will be -- nor how many people will be affected ' ' .	84.84333
having hedged its bets in this way , phs apparently decided it would be possible to make some sort of determination after all `` at present radiation levels , and even at somewhat higher levels , the additional risk is slight and very few people will be affected ' ' .	105.69763
then , to conclude on an indeterminate note `` nevertheless , if fallout increased substantially , or remained high for a long time , it would become far more important as a potential health hazard in this country and throughout the world ' ' .	72.97398
dr . linus pauling , a nobel prize winner in chemistry , has been less ambiguous , whether you choose to agree with him or not .	41.185253
after declaring , in an article last month in frontier magazine , that the russian testing `` carries with it the possibility of the most tragic consequences of any action in the history of the world ' ' , he gave this estimate of the biologic and genetic consequences if the new soviet shots totaled 200 megatons	31.404121
the damage to human germ plasm would be such that in the next few generations 160 , 000 children around the world would be born with gross physical or mental defects .	58.777245
long-lived carbon-14 from the fusion process would cause four million embryonic , neonatal or childhood deaths and stillbirths over the next 20 generations , and between 200 , 000 and one million human beings now living would have their lives cut short by radiation-produced diseases such as leukemia .	76.19791
most of these would be in the northern hemisphere , where the fallout is concentrating .	27.021852
pauling ' s estimate of 200 megatons yield from the present series of russian tests will probably turn out to be too high , but a total of 100 megatons is a distinct possibility .	37.54084
the lack of scientific unanimity on the effects of radiation is due in part to insufficient data covering large population groups , from which agreed-on generalizations could be drawn .	67.66213
but more than one conscientious researcher has been inhibited from completely frank discussion of the available evidence by the less excusable fact that fallout has been made a political issue as well as a scientific problem .	51.63569
its dangerous effects have been downgraded to the public by some who believe national security requires further testing .	154.8289
an illustration of this attitude is found in john a . mccone ' s letter to dr . thomas lauritsen , reported in a note elsewhere in this issue of the new republic .	35.36656
to this day the atomic energy commission shies away from discussing the health aspects of fallout .	32.74735
a recent study on radiation exposure by the aec ' s division of biology and medicine stated `` the question of the biological effect of ( radiation ) doses is not considered ' ' herein .	41.60282
of course , the aec is in a bind now .	70.60148
if it comes down too hard on the potential dangers of fallout , it will box the president on resuming atmospheric tests .	39.40996
so the commission ' s announcements of the new soviet shots have been confined to one or two bleak sentences , with the fission yield usually left vague .	30.136108
now , of course , that the russians are the nuclear villains , radiation is a nastier word than it was in the mid , when the us was testing in the atmosphere .	56.127052
the prevailing official attitude then seemed to be that fallout , if not exactly good for you , might not be much worse than a bad cold .	107.57193
after a nuclear blast , one bureaucrat suggested in those halcyon days , about all you had to do was haul out the broom and sweep off your sidewalks and roof .	26.513416
yet if washington gets too indignant about soviet fallout , it will have to do a lot of fast footwork if america decides it too must start pushing up the radiation count .	87.930504
as of october 25 , the aec had reported 24 shots in the new soviet series , 12 of them in a megaton range , including a super bomb with a yield of 30 to 50 megatons ( the equivalent of 30 million to 50 million tons of tnt )	30.412632
and president kennedy indicated there were one or two more than those reported .	78.34993
assuming the lower figure for the big blast and one shot estimated by the japanese at 10 megatons , a conservative computation is that the 24 announced tests produced a total yield of at least 60 megatons .	82.0733
some government scientists say privately that the figure probably is closer to 80 megatons , and that the full 50-megaton bomb that khrushchev mentioned may still be detonated .	44.68129
if the new soviet series has followed the general pattern of previous russian tests , the shots were roughly half fission and half fusion , meaning a fission yield of 30 to 40 megatons thus far .	69.63173
to this must be added the 90 to 92 megatons of fission yield produced between the dawn of the atomic age in 1945 and the informal three-power test moratorium that began in november , 1958 .	10.16097
one of the inescapable realities of the cold war is that it has thrust upon the west a wholly new and historically unique set of moral dilemmas .	79.26389
the first dilemma was the morality of nuclear warfare itself .	37.66792
that dilemma is as much with us as ever .	60.499718
the second great dilemma has been the morality of nuclear testing , a dilemma which has suddenly become acute because of the present series of soviet tests .	34.206856
when this second dilemma first became obvious -- during the mid to late ' 50 ' s -- the united states appeared to have three choices .	63.8736
it could have unilaterally abandoned further testing on the grounds of the radiation hazard to future generations .	14.871012
it could have continued testing to the full on the grounds that the radiation danger was far less than the danger of communist world domination .	28.629124
or it could have chosen to find -- by negotiation -- some way of stopping the tests without loss to national security .	97.29284
with the resumption of soviet testing and their intransigence at the geneva talks , however , the hope that this third choice would prove viable has been shaken .	56.068928
once again , the united states must choose .	66.49256
and once again , the choices are much the same .	14.504396
only this time around the conditions are different and the choice is far harder .	62.48171
the first choice , abandoning tests entirely , would not only be unpopular domestically , but would surely be exploited by the russians .	18.890957
the second choice , full testing , has become even more risky just because the current soviet tests have already dangerously contaminated the atmosphere .	49.77205
the third choice , negotiation , presupposes , as russian behavior demonstrates , a great deal of wishful thinking to make it appear reasonable .	43.86439
we take the position , however , that the third choice still remains the only sane one open to us .	102.63038
it is by no stretch of the imagination a happy choice and the arguments against it as a practical strategy are formidable .	145.33606
its primary advantage is that it is a moral choice	395.9757
one which , should it fail , will not have contaminated the conscience .	43.551228
leaving aside the choice of unilateral cessation of tests as neither sane nor clearly moral , the question must arise as to why resumption of atmospheric tests on our part would not be a good choice .	58.936707
for that is the one an increasingly large number of prominent americans are now proposing .	28.407778
in particular , governor nelson rockefeller has expressed as cogently and clearly as anyone the case for a resumption of atmospheric tests .	19.021034
speaking recently in miami , governor rockefeller said that `` to assure the sufficiency of our own weapons in the face of the recent soviet tests , we are now clearly compelled to conduct our own nuclear tests ' ' .	20.316359
taking account of the fact that such a move on our part would be unpopular in world opinion , he argued that the responsibility of the united states is `` to do , confidently and firmly , not what is popular , but what is right ' ' .	37.529358
what was missing in the governor ' s argument , as in so many similar arguments , was a premise which would enable one to make the ethical leap from what might be militarily desirable to what is right .	67.47143
the possibility , as he asserted , that the russians may get ahead of us or come closer to us because of their tests does not supply the needed ethical premise -- unless , of course , we have unwittingly become so brutalized that nuclear superiority is now taken as a moral demand .	87.54235
besides the lack of an adequate ethical dimension to the governor ' s case , one can ask seriously whether our lead over the russians in quality and quantity of nuclear weapons is so slight as to make the tests absolutely necessary .	52.988247
recent statements by the president and defense department spokesmen have , to the contrary , assured us that our lead is very great .	74.03633
unless the administration and the defense department have been deceiving us , the facts do not support the assertion that we are `` compelled ' ' to resume atmospheric testing .	15.368725
it is perfectly conceivable that a resumption of atmospheric tests may , at some point in the future , be necessary and even justifiable .	44.560486
but a resumption does not seem justifiable now .	23.600672
what we need to realize is that the increasingly great contamination of the atmosphere by the soviet tests had radically increased our own moral obligations .	96.51292
we now have to think not only of our national security but also of the future generations who will suffer from any tests we might undertake .	68.06819
this is an ethical demand which cannot be evaded or glossed over by talking exclusively of weapon superiority or even of the evil of communism .	51.31571
too often in the past russian tactics have been used to justify like tactics on our part .	59.74343
there ought to be a point beyond which we will not allow ourselves to go regardless of what russia does .	40.77209
the refusal to resume atmospheric testing would be a good start .	21.673418
when his holiness pope john 23 , first called for an ecumenical council , and at the same time voiced his yearning for christian unity , the enthusiasm among catholic and protestant ecumenicists was immediate .	34.30386
with good reason it appeared that a new day was upon divided christendom .	86.73163
but as the more concrete plans for the work of the council gradually became known , there was a rather sharp and abrupt disappointment on all sides .	56.803688
the council we now know will concern itself directly only with the internal affairs of the church .	24.892847
as it has turned out , however , the excessive enthusiasm in the first instance and the loss of hope in the second were both wrong responses .	71.24576
two things have happened in recent months to bring the council into perspective each provides a basis for renewed hope and joy .	180.66048
first of all , it is now known that pope john sees the renewal and purification of the church as an absolutely necessary step toward christian unity .	47.971584
far from being irrelevant to the ecumenical task , the pontiff believes that a revivified church is required in order that the whole world may see catholicism in the best possible light .	62.22657
equally significant , pope john has said that catholics themselves bear some responsibility for christian disunity .	175.12679
a major aim of the council will be to remove as far as possible whatever in the church today stands in the way of unity .	54.08486
secondly , a whole series of addresses and actions by the pope and by others show that concern for christian unity is still very much alive and growing within the church .	81.27009
the establishment , by the holy father , of a permanent secretariat for christian unity in 1960 was the most dramatic mark of this concern .	36.53999
the designation of five catholic theologians to attend the world council of churches assembly in new delhi as `` official ' ' observers reverses the church ' s earlier stand .	45.77751
the public appeal by the new vatican secretary of state , cardinal cicognani , for renewed efforts toward eastern and western reunion was still another remarkable act .	32.91007
nor can one forget pope john ' s unprecedented meeting with the archbishop of canterbury .	19.869518
augustin cardinal bea , the director of the secretariate for christian unity , has expressed as directly as anyone the new spirit that pervades the church ' s stance toward the protestant and orthodox churches .	26.19511
noting all the difficulties that stand in the way of reunion , he has said that they ought not to discourage anyone .	22.193186
for discouragement , or the temptation to abandon our efforts , `` would show that one placed excessive trust in purely human means without thinking of the omnipotence of god , the irresistible efficacy of prayer , the action of christ or the power of the divine spirit ' ' .	44.56039
can any christian fail to respond to these words ? ?	16.826967
the administration ' s official budget review , which estimates a 6 . 9 billion dollar deficit for the current fiscal year , isn ' t making anyone happy .	35.246643
certainly it isn ' t making the president happy , and he has been doing his apologetic best to explain how the budget got into its unbalanced condition , how he intends to economize wherever he can and how he hopes to do better next year .	51.6269
we sympathize with mr . kennedy , but we feel bound to say that his budget review doesn ' t please us either , although for very different reasons .	76.11221
furthermore , we find his defense of the unbalanced budget more dismaying than reassuring .	41.829338
in the first place , a large part of the discrepancy between president eisenhower ' s estimate of a 1 . 5 billion dollar surplus for the same period and the new estimate of an almost seven billion dollar deficit is the result of the outgoing president ' s farewell gift of a political booby-trap to his successor .	22.8283
the eisenhower budget was simultaneously inadequate in its provisions and yet extravagant in its projections of revenue to be received .	81.2602
the rest of the deficit is also easily understood .	3.8476145
four billion dollars of the spending increase is for defense , an expenditure necessitated by the penny-wise policies of the eisenhhower administration , quite apart from the recent crises in berlin and elsewhere .	40.55411
four hundred million dollars of the increase is for the expanded space program , a responsibility similarly neglected by mr . eisenhower .	55.985546
the farm program will cost an additional 1 . 5 billion , because of unusual weather factors , the food for peace program and other new measures .	63.459263
anti-recession programs -- aid for the unemployed , their children and for depressed areas -- account for only 900 million of the 6 . 9 billion dollar deficit .	50.31506
our complaint is that in many crucial areas the kennedy programs are not too large but too small , most seriously in regard to the conventional arms build-up and in aid and welfare measures .	150.39378
and yet mr . kennedy persists in trying to mollify the intransigents of the right with apologies and promises of `` tightening up ' ' and `` economizing ' ' .	8.2053795
we wish the president would remember that `` fiscal responsibility ' ' was the battle-cry of the party that lost the election .	50.3389
the party that won used to say something about a new frontier .	16.856224
introduction of the `` dialogue ' ' principle proved strikingly effective at the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the catholic association for international peace in washington the last weekend in october .	55.665554
two of the principal addresses were delivered by prominent protestants , and when the speaker was a catholic , one `` discussant ' ' on the dais tended to be of another religious persuasion .	29.087122
sessions devoted to `` ethics and foreign policy trends ' ' , `` moral principle and political judgment ' ' , `` christian ethics in the cold war ' ' and related subjects proved to be much livelier under this procedure than if catholics were merely talking to themselves .	55.291016
usually questions from the floor were directed to the non-catholic speaker or discussion leader .	53.826744
in the earlier sessions there was plentiful discussion on the natural law , which dr . william v . o ' brien of georgetown university , advanced as the basis for widely acceptable ethical judgments on foreign policy .	35.71878
that aristotelean-thomistic principle experienced a thorough going-over from a number of the participants , but in the end the concept came to reassert itself .	37.64954
speakers declared that protestants often make use of it , if , perhaps , by some other name .	56.102783
a lebanese moslem told about its existence and application in the islamic tradition as the `` divine law ' ' , while a c . a . i . p . member who has been working in close association with delegates of the new u . n . nations told of its widespread recognition on the african continent .	45.177692
the impression was unmistakable that , whatever one may choose to call it , natural law is a functioning generality with a certain objective existence .	52.56799
another question that arose was the nature of the dialogue itself .	12.57488
the stimulus from the confrontation of philosophical systems involving certain differences was undeniable .	49.384388
it was expected that the comparison of different approaches to ethics would produce a better grasp of each other ' s positions and better comprehension of one ' s own .	41.823734
but a realization that each group has much of substance to learn from the other also developed , and a strong conviction grew that each had insights and dimensions to contribute to ethically acceptable solutions of urgent political issues .	107.9407
one effect of the spirited give-and-take of these discussions was to focus attention on practical applications and the necessity of being armed with the facts knowledge of the destructive force of even the tiniest `` tactical ' ' atomic weapon would have a bearing on judgments as to the advisability of its use -- to defend berlin , for example	37.969524
the pervasive influence of ideology on our political judgments needs to be recognized and taken into due account	156.0129
it is necessary to perceive the extent of foreign aid demanded by the christian imperative .	76.02802
everywhere i went in formosa i asked the same question .	32.69629
i was searching for an accent of self-delusion or , even , of hypocrisy .	78.34418
i never found it among any of the chinese with whom i spoke , though granted they were , almost all , members of the official family who , presumably , harbor official thoughts .	172.35367
but i questioned , also , professional soldiers , who would not easily be hypnotized by a septuagenarian ' s dreamy irredentism .	10.254304
their answer was it can be done , and we will do it .	19.423792
and then i put the question as pointedly as i could directly to chiang kai-shek `` in america ' ' , i said , `` practically no one believes that you subjectively intend to re-enter the mainland .	19.935593
what evidence is there of an objective kind that in fact your government proposes to do just that , and that it can be done ' ' ? ?	35.651978
( he always smiles -- at least at visitors , i gather .	86.801956
he smiled also at a british bloke seated next to me , who asked the most asinine questions .	31.2653
i recalled sympathetically the duke ' s complaint in browning ' s `` my last duchess ' ' .	15.467634
) he smiled , and said a word or two to the interpreter , who turned to me , `` the president wonders where you are going after you leave taipei ' ' ? ?	47.830894
that , i smarted , is a royal rebuff if ever there was one .	64.097275
i answered the routine question about my itinerary , rather coolly .	29.690174
chiang spoke again , this time at greater length .	18.306175
`` the president says ' ' , the translator came in , `` that the reason he asked you where you were going is because he hoped you would be visiting other areas in southeast asia , and that everywhere you went , you would seek the answer to your question .	100.747986
he says that if he were to express to you , once again , his own profound determination to go to the mainland , and his faith that that return is feasible , he would merely sound redundant .	83.66368
so you yourself must seek these objective data , and come to your own conclusions .	39.01911
any information we have here in taiwan is at your disposal ' ' .	10.961717
for every person on taiwan , there are sixty in mainland china .	46.488457
if the raw population figures are crucially relevant , then it is idle to think of liberation , as idle as to suppose that poland might liberate russia .	71.464325
less than 60-1 , but at least 6-1 .	6.2937093
the estimates vary widely on the strength of the chinese army .	20.849564
the armed forces of taiwan are at a working strength of about 450 , 000 , though a reserve potential twice that high is contemplated .	60.4658
it is generally conceded that the formosan air force is the best by far in asia , and the army the best trained .	76.50197
even so , it adds up to impossible odds , except that the question arises , on whose side would the mainland chinese army fight ? ?	112.37777
the miserable people of china , the largest cast ever conscripted to enact an ideological passion play , cannot themselves resist overtly .	59.130123
they think , perforce , of physical survival everything else is secondary .	220.27934
but the army which mao continues to feed well , where are its sympathies ? ?	74.074684
the psychological strategists in taiwan stress the great sense of family , cultivated in china over thousands of years .	93.07692
it has not been extirpated by ten years of communist depersonalization .	50.730293
every soldier in the army has , somewhere , relatives who are close to starvation .	27.594143
the soldiers themselves cannot stage a successful rebellion , it is assumed but will their discontent spread to the officer class ? ?	121.7621
the immediate families of the generals and the admirals are well fed a despot does not economize on his generals .	19.887592
but there are the cousins and aunts and nephews .	4.303486
to whom will the generals stay loyal ? ?	1.0611955
there is little doubt if they had a secret ballot , they would vote for food for their family , in place of ideological purity out on the farm .	142.4805
it is another question whether `` they ' ' -- or a single general , off in a corner of china , secure for a few ( galvanizing ? ?	51.93532
) days at least from instant retaliation -- will defy the party .	67.658745
but the disposition to rebel is most definitely there .	33.919254
the military in taiwan believe that the communists have made two mistakes , which , together , may prove fatal .	61.817207
the first was the commune program , which will ensure agricultural poverty for years .	31.026993
and where it is not , it is left with no residue , and the social meaning of this is enormous .	80.216705
for it is the family that , in china , has always provided social security for the indigent , the sick , the down-and-out members of the clan .	38.53585
but the government is left with no reserve granary , under the agricultural system it has ordained .	36.38216
thus the government simultaneously undertook the vast burden of social security which had traditionally been privately discharged , and created a national scarcity which has engendered calamitous problems of social security .	33.276653
tibet has historically served china as a buffer state .	88.34511
a friendly state , sometimes only semi-independent , but never hostile .	50.502598
china never tried to integrate tibet by extirpating the people ' s religion and institutions .	30.528418
red china is trying to do this , and she is not likely ever to succeed .	34.616325
tibet is too vast , the terrain is too difficult .	39.158577
tibet may bleed china as algeria is bleeding france .	69.73586
these continuing pressures , social , economic and military , are doing much to keep china in a heightening state of tension .	69.58314
the imposition of yet another pressure , a strong one , from the outside , might cause it to snap .	84.28076
the planners in taiwan struck me as realistic men .	55.156456
they know that they must depend heavily on factors outside their own control .	137.64696
first and foremost , they depend on the inhuman idiocies of the communist regime .	4.4575415
secondly , they depend on america ' s `` moral cooperation ' ' when the crucial moment arrives .	34.835766
they hope that if history vouchsafes the west another budapest , we will receive the opportunity gladly .	61.23085
i remarked jocularly to the president that the future of china would be far more certain if he would invite a planeload of selected american liberals to quemoy on an odd day .	38.216183
he affected ( most properly ) not to understand my point .	152.2086
but he -- and all of china -- wears the scars of american indecisiveness , and he knows what an uncertain ally we are .	27.996798
we have been grand to formosa itself -- lots of aid , and , most of the time , a policy of support for the offshore islands .	48.291378
but our outlook has been , and continues to be , defensive .	69.28093
a great deal depends on the crystallization of mr . kennedy ' s views on the world struggle .	18.207216
the free chinese know that the situation on the mainland is in flux , and are poised to strike .	37.53174
there is not anywhere on the frontiers of freedom a more highly mobilized force for liberation .	63.795555
the moment of truth is the moment of crisis .	10.492458
during the slow buildup , the essence of a policy or a man is concealed under embroidered details , fine words , strutting gestures .	46.529633
there the truth is , open to eyes that are willing to look .	31.388891
new self-deceiving rags are hurriedly tossed on the too-naked bones .	6.176628
a truth-revealing crisis erupted in katanga for a couple of days this month , to be quickly smothered by the high pressure verbal fog that is kept on tap for such emergencies .	54.343517
before memory , too , clouds over , let us make a note or two of what could be seen .	53.15726
the measure was instantly taken , as always in such cases , of public men at many levels .	93.403435
one knows better , now , who has bone and who has jelly in his spine .	52.352974
but i am here concerned more with policy than with men .	53.45213
public men come and go but great issues of policy remain .	129.32542
now , everyone knows -- or knew in the week of december 10 -- that something had gone shockingly wrong with american foreign policy .	98.32416
the united states was engaged in a military attack on a peaceful , orderly people governed by a regime that had proved itself the most pro-western and anti-communist within any of the new nations -- the only place in africa , moreover , where a productive relationship between whites and blacks had apparently been achieved .	38.63699
of course the fighting was officially under the auspices of the united nations .	4.378067
but in the moment of truth everyone could see that the u . s . was in reality the principal .	43.035152
the moment simultaneously revealed that in the crisis our policy ran counter to that of all our nato allies , to the entire western community .	41.92637
by our policy the west was -- is -- split .	113.0332
the controlling pattern was first displayed in the hungary-suez crisis of november 1956 .	60.136253
it reappears , in whole or part , whenever a new crisis exposes the reality in cuba last spring ( with which the dominican events of last month should be paired )	115.359245
at the peaks of the nuclear test and the berlin cycles	21.540031
in relation to laos , algeria , south africa	2.025255
right now , with almost cartoon emphasis , in the temporally linked complex of tshombe-gizenga-goa-ghana .	13.367378
this prime element of the truth may be stated as follows under prevailing policy , the u . s . can take the initiative against the right , but cannot take the initiative against the left .	36.127686
it makes no difference what part of the world is involved , what form of regime , what particular issue .	125.018906
the u . s . cannot take the initiative against the left .	30.44716
there is even some question whether the u . s . can any longer defend itself against an initiative by the left .	44.96693
we can attack tshombe , but not gigenza .	42.56499
no matter that gizenga is moscow ' s man in the congo .	36.491062
no matter that it is his troops who rape western women and eat western men .	137.55182
no matter that the katanga operation is strategically insane in terms of western interests in africa .	18.078138
( even granted that the congo should be unified , you don ' t protect western security by first removing the pro-western weight from the power equilibrium .	154.63472
we can force britain and france out of the suez , but we cannot so much as try to force the russian tanks back from budapest .	67.283356
we can mass our fleet against the trujillos , but not against the castros .	19.134392
we can vote in the un against south african apartheid or portuguese rule in angola , but we cannot even introduce a motion on the berlin wall -- much less , give the simple order to push the wall down .	47.007168
we officially receive the anti-french , moscow-allied algerian fln , but we denounce the pro-europe , anti-communist oas as criminal .	7.629192
in the very week of our war against katanga , we make a $133 million grant to kwame nkrumah , who has just declared his solidarity with the communist bloc , and is busily turning his own country into a totalitarian dictatorship .	21.65329
as our planes land the war materiel that kills pro-western katangans , we stand supinely bleating while nehru ' s troops smash into a five-hundred-year-old district of our nato ally , portugal .	25.526575
it is the consequence of the system of ideas that constitutes the frame of our international -- and in some degree our domestic -- policy .	114.69727
the suez-hungary crisis proves that this system was not invented by the new administration , but only made more consistent and more active .	91.013626
most immediately relevant to these episodes in goa , katanga and ghana , as to the suez-hungary crisis before them , is the belief that the main theater of the world drama is the underdeveloped region of asia , africa and latin america .	22.686533
from this belief is derived the practical orientation of our policy on the `` uncommitted ' ' ( `` neutralist ' ' , `` contested ' ' ) nations , especially on those whose leaders make the most noise -- nehru , tito , nkrumah , sukarno , betancourt , etc . .	19.451063
our chief aim becomes that of finding favor in neutralist eyes .	30.240551
if we grasp this orientation as a key , our national conduct in all of the events here mentioned becomes intelligible .	117.004486
and it becomes clear why in general we cannot take the initiative against the left .	58.314194
to write a play , the dramatist once needed an idea plus the imagination , the knowledge of life and the craft to develop it .	67.04978
nowadays , more and more , all he needs is someone else ' s book .	123.99473
to get started , he does not scan the world about him	267.55112
he and his prospective producer just read the bestseller lists .	9.719227
so far this season , broadway ' s premieres have included twice as many adaptations and imports as original american stage plays .	64.46387
of straight dramas , there are all the way home , which owes much of its poetic power to the james agee novel , a death in the family	46.606373
the wall , awkwardly based on the john hersey novel	7.062745
advise and consent , lively but shallow theater drawn from the mountainously detailed bestseller	44.853172
face of a hero ( closed ) , based on a pierre boulle novel .	29.17318
the only original works attempting to reach any stature tennessee williams ' disappointing domestic comedy , period of adjustment , and arthur laurents ' clever but empty invitation to a march .	85.25719
clearly the most provocative plays are all imported originals -- a taste of honey , by britain ' s young ( 19 when she wrote it ) shelagh delaney	34.06575
the hostage ( closed ) , by ireland ' s brendan behan .	7.0463777
among the musicals , camelot came from t . h . white ' s the once and future king , and novels were the sources of the less than momentous tenderloin and do re mi .	52.3526
wildcat and the unsinkable molly brown were originals , but pretty bad , leaving top honors again to an import -- the jaunty and charmingly french irma la douce .	34.31089
the only other works at least technically original were dreary farces -- send me no flowers ( closed ) , under the yum-yum tree , critic ' s choice .	38.252716
in the forthcoming the conquering hero and carnival , broadway is not even adapting books , but reconverting old movies ( hail the conquering hero and lili ) .	44.009552
originals are not necessarily good and adaptations are not necessarily bad .	39.277515
some memorable plays have been drawn from books , notably life with father and diary of anne frank .	59.293377
and particularly in the musical field , adaptations have long been the rule , from die fledermaus and the merry widow to oklahoma ! and my fair lady .	73.73109
as critic walter kerr points out `` adaptations , so long as they are good , still qualify as creative ' ' .	61.675262
and other defenders invariably argue that , after all , shakespeare and moliere were adapters too .	57.63044
the difference is that the masters took the bare frame of a plot and filled it with their own world	122.92847
most modern adapters totally accept the world of a book , squeeze it dry of life , and add only one contribution of their own stage technique .	50.655647
the most frequent excuse for the prevalence of unoriginals and tested imports is increasing production expense -- producers cannot afford to take chances .	86.821625
off-broadway , where production is still comparatively cheap , is proving itself only slightly more original .	128.37372
laudably enough , it is offering classics and off-beat imports , but last week only one u . s . original was on the boards , robert d . hock ' s stunning civil war work , borak .	42.98717
the real trouble seems to be the failing imagination of u . s . playwrights .	23.577274
he `` come with me to the casbah ' ' .	1.5490183
she `` by subway or cab ' ' ? ?	4.6159205
that exchange was not only possible but commonplace last week in manhattan , as more and more new yorkers were discovering 29th street and eighth avenue , where half a dozen small nightclubs with names like arabian nights , grecian palace and egyptian gardens are the american inpost of belly dancing .	45.462738
their burgeoning popularity may be a result of the closing of the 52nd street burlesque joints , but curiously enough their atmosphere is almost always familial -- neighborhood saloons with a bit of epidermis .	43.560867
the belly boites , with their papier-mache palm trees or hand-painted ionic columns , heretofore existed mainly on the patronage of greek and turkish families .	32.162277
between performances , enthusiastic young men from the audience will take the floor to demonstrate their own amateur graces .	44.357037
except for the odd uptown sex maniac or an overeager greek sailor , the people watch in calm absorption .	44.67644
small , shirt-sleeved orchestras play in 2/4 or 4/4 time , using guitars , violins , and more alien instruments with names that would open sesame the oud , grandfather of the lute	32.592003
the darbuka , a small drum with the treelike shape of a roemer glass	20.127323
the girls sit quietly with the musicians , wearing prim dresses or plain , secretarial shifts , until it is time to go off to a back room and reappear in the spare uniform of the harem .	41.144367
if a dancer is good , she suggests purely and superbly the fundamental mechanics of ancestry and progeny -- the continuum of mankind .	20.088669
but a great many of what variety calls the `` cooch terpers ' ' are considerably less cosmic than that .	24.557444
each dancer follows the ancient oriental pattern -- she glides sideways with shoulders motionless while her stomach migrates , and , through breathing and muscle control , she sends ripples across her body to the fingertips and away to the far end of the room .	28.987686
this is done at varying speeds , ranging from the slow and fast shifte telli ( a musical term meaning double strings ) to the fastest , ecstatic karshilama ( meaning greetings or welcome ) .	32.874924
the new york dancers are highly eclectic , varying the pattern with all kinds of personal improvisations , back bends or floor crawls .	33.925205
the belly dance leaves more to the imagination .	8.828816
when a dancer does well , she provokes a quiet bombardment of dollar bills -- although the manhattan clubs prohibit the more cosmopolitan practice of slipping the tips into the dancers ' costumes .	28.185463
with tips , the girls average between $150 and $200 a week , depending on basic salary .	35.13842
although they are forbidden to sit with the customers , the dancers are sometimes proffered drinks , and most of them can bolt one down in mid-shimmy .	51.25352
all over the country , belly clubs have never been bigger , especially in detroit , boston and chicago , and even in small towns	49.312828
one of the best dancers , a turkish girl named semra , works at a roadhouse outside bristol , conn . .	24.86308
the girls are kept booked and moving by several agents , notably voluble , black-bearded murat somay , a manhattan turk who is the sol hurok of the central abdomen .	10.321184
he can offer nine turkish girls , plans to import at least 15 more .	44.303295
but a great many of the dancers are more or less native .	111.60122
sometimes they get their initial experience in church haflis , conducted by lebanese and syrians in the u . s . , where they dance with just as few veils across their bodies as in nightclubs .	27.386774
as the girls come to belly dancing from this and other origins , the melting pot has never bubbled more intriguingly .	33.30879
jemela ( surname gerby ) , 23 , seems hong kong oriental but has a spanish father and an indian mother , was born in america and educated at holy cross academy and textile high school , says she learned belly dancing at family picnics .	87.79086
serene ( mrs . wilson ) , 23 , was born in budapest and raised in manhattan .	32.510887
daughter of a gypsy mother who taught her to dance , she is one of the few really beautiful girls in the new york casbah , with dark eyes and dark , waist-length hair , the face of an adolescent patrician and a lithe , glimmering body .	28.439196
many belly dancers are married , but serene is one of the few who will admit it .	32.032585
marlene ( surname adamo ) , 25 , a brazilian divorcee who learned the dance from arabic friends in paris , now lives on manhattan ' s west side , is about the best belly dancer working the casbah , loves it so much that she dances on her day off .	70.07747
she has the small , highly developed body of a prime athlete , and holds in contempt the `` girls who just move sex ' ' .	82.32537
leila ( malia phillips ) , 25 , is a greenwich village painter of persianesque miniatures who has red hair that cascades almost to her ankles .	36.115845
a graduate of hollywood high school , she likes to imagine herself , as she takes the floor , `` a village girl coming in to a festival ' ' .	25.11753
gloria ( surname ziraldo ) , circa 30 , who was born in italy and once did `` chorus work ' ' in toronto , has been around longer than most of the others , wistfully remembers the old days when `` we used to get the seamen from the ships , you know , with big turtleneck sweaters and handkerchiefs and all .	55.913837
but the ships are very slow now , and we don ' t get so many sailors any more ' ' .	24.876284
the uptown crowd has moved in , and what girl worth her seventh veil would trade a turtleneck sweater for a button-down collar ? ?	80.0366
of the handful of painters that austria has produced in the 20th century , only one , oskar kokoschka , is widely known in the u . s . .	11.931882
this state of unawareness may not last much longer .	9.694581
for ten years a small group of european and u . s . critics has been calling attention to the half-forgotten austrian expressionist egon schiele , who died 42 years ago at the age of 28 .	13.335581
the critics ' campaign finally inspired the first major u . s . exhibit of schiele ' s works .	18.285181
the show has been to boston and manhattan , will in time reach pittsburgh and minneapolis .	106.073135
last week it opened at the j . b . speed museum in louisville , at the very moment that a second schiele exhibit was being made ready at the felix landau gallery in los angeles .	23.46711
schiele ' s paintings are anything but pleasant .	9.549545
his people ( see color ) are angular and knobby-knuckled , sometimes painfully stretched , sometimes grotesquely foreshortened .	9.859521
his colors are dark and murky , and his landscapes and cityscapes seem swallowed in gloom .	12.682476
but he painted some of the boldest and most original pictures of his time , and even after nearly half a century , the tense , tormented world he put on canvas has lost none of its fascination .	82.86146
the son of a railway stationmaster , schiele lived most of his childhood in the drowsy danubian town of tulln , 14 miles northwest of vienna .	24.207186
he was an emotional , lonely boy who spent so much time turning out drawings that he did scarcely any schoolwork .	107.5809
when he was 15 , his parents finally allowed him to attend classes at the academy of fine arts in vienna .	31.30702
even there he did not last for long .	4.0338655
cried one professor after a few months of student schiele ' s tantrums and rebellion `` the devil himself must have defecated you into my classroom ' ' ! !	43.600338
for a while his work was influenced deeply by the french impressionists , and by the patterned , mosaic-like paintings of gustav klimt , then the dean of austrian art .	14.485963
gradually schiele evolved a somber style of his own -- and he had few inhibitions about his subject matter .	46.713634
his pictures were roundly denounced as `` the most disgusting things one has ever seen in vienna ' ' .	34.78403
he himself was once convicted of painting erotica and jailed for 24 days -- the first three of which he spent desperately trying to make paintings on the wall with his own spittle .	46.367382
for years he wore hand-me-down suits and homemade paper collars , was even driven to scrounging for cigarette butts in vienna ' s gutters .	14.121003
drafted into the austrian army , he rebelliously rejected discipline , wangled a vienna billet , went on painting .	25.961927
it was not until the last year of his life that he had his first moneymaking show .	34.451874
the unabashed sexuality of so many of his paintings was not the only thing that kept the public at bay his view of the world was one of almost unrelieved tragedy , and it was too much even for morbid-minded vienna .	64.86266
he was obsessed by disease and poverty , by the melancholy of old age and the tyranny of lust .	23.63414
the children he painted were almost always in rags , his portraits were often ruthless to the point of ugliness , and his nudes -- including several self-portraits -- were stringy , contorted and strangely pathetic .	10.925565
the subject he liked most was the female body , which he painted in every state -- naked , half-dressed , muffled to the ears , sitting primly in a chair , lying tauntingly on a bed or locked in an embrace .	24.988255
the most surprising thing about the twenty-second congress of the soviet communist party is that it is surprising -- perhaps quite as much , in its own way , as the twentieth congress of 1956 , which ended with that famous `` secret ' ' report on stalin .	38.888596
the publication last july of the party ' s draft program -- that blueprint for the `` transition to communism ' ' -- had led the uninitiated to suppose that this twenty-second congress would be a sort of apotheosis of the khrushchev regime , a solemn consecration of ideas which had , in fact , been current over the last three or four years ( i . e . , since the defeat of the `` anti-party group ' ' ) in all theoretical party journals .	31.447657
these never ceased to suggest that if , in the eyes of marx and lenin `` full communism ' ' was still a very distant ideal , the establishment of a communist society had now , under khrushchev , become an `` immediate and tangible reality ' ' .	87.750854
it seems that khrushchev himself took a very special pride in having made a world-shaking contribution to marxist doctrine with his draft program ( a large part of his twelve-hour speech at the recent congress was , in fact , very largely a rehash of that interminable document ) .	79.35731
he and other soviet leaders responsible for the document were proud of having brought forward some new formulas , such as the early replacement of the dictatorship of the proletariat by an `` all people ' s state ' ' , and also of having laid down the lines for a much greater `` democratization ' ' of the whole hierarchy of soviets , starting with the supreme soviet itself .	63.91796
their plan for rotation of leaders promised a salutary blow at `` bureaucracy ' ' and would enable `` the people ' ' to take a more direct and active part in running the country .	34.167408
there might even be two or more candidates for voters to choose from .	78.97747
no doubt , there was still a lot in the draft program -- and in khrushchev ' s speech -- which left many points obscure .	97.21729
was it the party ' s intention , for example , to abolish gradually the kolkhoz system and replace it by uniformly wage-earning kolkhozes , i . e . , state farms ( which were , moreover , to be progressively `` urbanized ' ' ) ? ?	29.554096
as we know , the soviet peasant today still very largely thrives on being able to sell the produce grown on his private plot	52.061886
and it is still very far from certain how valid the party ' s claim is that in `` a growing number of kolkhozes ' ' the peasants are finding it more profitable , to surrender their private plots to the kolkhoz and to let the latter be turned into something increasingly like a state farm .	51.414276
if one follows the reports of the congress , one finds that there still seems considerable uncertainty in the minds of the leaders themselves about what exactly to do in this matter .	68.16336
the draft program was interesting in other respects , too .	33.106964
it contained , for example , a number of curious admissions about the peasants , who enjoy no sickness benefits , no old-age pensions , no paid holidays	24.824827
they still benefit far less than the `` other ' ' 50 per cent of the nation from that `` welfare state ' ' which the soviet union so greatly prides itself on being .	46.81849
over all these fairly awkward problems khrushchev was to skate rather lightly	48.53466
and , though he repeated , over and over again , the spectacular figures of industrial and agricultural production in 1980 , the `` ordinary ' ' people in russia are still a little uncertain as to how `` communism ' ' is really going to work in practice , especially in respect of food .	58.12888
would agriculture progress as rapidly as industry ? ?	1.055587
this was something on which k . himself seemed to have some doubts	30.264042
for he kept on threatening that he would `` pull the ears ' ' of those responsible for agricultural production .	58.365185
and , as we know , the virgin lands are not producing as much as khrushchev had hoped .	93.45213
one cannot but wonder whether these doubts about the success of khrushchev ' s agricultural policy have not at least something to do with one of the big surprises provided by this congress -- the obsessive harping on the crimes and misdeeds of the `` anti-party group ' ' -- molotov , malenkov , kaganovich and others -- including the eighty-year-old marshal voroshilov .	21.462307
molotov , in particular , is being charged with all kinds of sins -- especially with wanting to cut down free public services , to increase rents and fares	54.83605
in fact , with having been against all the more popular features of the khrushchev `` welfare state ' ' .	62.750427
the trouble with all these doctrinal quarrels is that we hear only one side of the story what , in the secret councils of the kremlin , molotov had really proposed , we just don ' t know , and he has had no chance to reply .	50.318554
but one cannot escape the suspicion that all this non-stop harping on the misdeeds of the long liquidated `` anti-party ' ' group would be totally unnecessary if there were not , inside the party , some secret but genuine opposition to khrushchev on vital doctrinal grounds , on the actual methods to be employed in the `` transition to communism ' ' and , last but not least , on foreign policy .	50.233696
the whole problem of `` peaceful coexistence and peaceful competition ' ' with the capitalist world is in the very center of this congress .	33.7405
`` molotov altogether rejects the line of peaceful coexistence , reducing this concept merely to the state of peace or rather , the absence of war at a given moment , and to a denial of the possibility of averting a world war .	34.17434
his views , in fact , coincide with those of foreign enemies of peaceful coexistence , who look upon it merely as a variant of the `` cold war ' ' or of an `` armed peace ' ' .	36.039135
one cannot help wondering whether molotov and the rest of the `` anti-party group ' ' are not being used as china ' s whipping-boys by khrushchev and his faithful followers .	22.972254
for something , clearly , has gone very , very seriously wrong in soviet-chinese relations , which were never easy , and have now deteriorated .	103.78254
the effect of chou en-lai ' s clash with khrushchev , together with the everlasting attacks on molotov & co . , has shifted the whole attention of the world , including that of the soviet people , from the `` epoch-making ' ' twenty-year program to the present soviet-chinese conflict .	28.980555
not only , as we know , did chou en-lai publicly treat khrushchev ' s attack on albania as `` something that we cannot consider as a serious marxist-leninist approach ' ' to the problem ( i . e . , as something thoroughly dictatorial and `` undemocratic ' ' ) , but the albanian leaders went out of their way to be openly abusive to khrushchev , calling him a liar , a bully , and so on .	28.747658
it is extremely doubtful that the handful of albanians who call themselves communists could have done this without the direct approval of their chinese friends .	45.561344
