some of thurber ' s curative methods involve strong potions of mixed metaphor , malapropism , and gobbledygook and are recommended for use only in extreme cases .	31.956114
a burlesque paean entitled `` hark the herald tribune , times , and all the other angels sing ' ' brilliantly succeeds in exaggerating even motion-picture ballyhooey .	32.498566
`` how the kooks crumble ' ' features an amusingly accurate take-off on sneaky announcers who attempt to homogenize radio-tv commercials , and `` the watchers of the night ' ' is a veritable waking nightmare .	10.723465
a semi-serious literary document entitled `` the wings of henry james ' ' is noteworthy , if only for a keenly trenchant though little-known comment on the master ' s difficult later period by modest owen wister , author of `` the virginian ' ' .	28.345522
james , he remarks in a letter to a friend , `` is attempting the impossible namely , to produce upon the reader , as a painting produces upon the gazer , a number of superimposed , simultaneous impressions .	28.507645
he would like to put several sentences on top of each other so that you could read them all at once , and get all at once , the various shadings and complexities ' ' .	49.731873
equally penetrating in its fashion is the following remark by a lady in the course of a literary conversation `` so much has already been written about everything that you can ' t find out anything about it ' ' .	31.75563
or the mildly epigrammatic utterance ( also a quotation ) `` woman ' s place is in the wrong ' ' .	16.096874
who but thurber can be counted on to glean such nectareous essences ? ?	8.827817
a tribute to midsummer `` bang-sashes ' ' seems terribly funny , though it would be hard to explain why .	24.090872
`` one of them banged the sash of the window nearest my bed around midnight in july and i leaped out of sleep and out of bed .	53.00064
' it ' s just a bat ' , said my wife reassuringly , and i sighed with relief .	40.172752
' thank god for that ' , i said	119.33091
' i thought it was a human being ' ' ' .	26.763308
in a sense , perhaps , thurber is indebted artistically to the surrealist painter ( was it salvador dali ? ?	10.500727
) who first conceived the startling fancy of a picture window in the abdomen .	21.209482
that is , it is literally a picture window you don ' t see into the viscera	22.000483
you see a picture -- trees , or flowers .	60.898212
this is something like what thurber ' s best effects are like , if i am not mistaken .	66.818825
though no longer able to turn out his protoplasmic pen-and-ink sketches ( several old favorites are scattered through the present volume ) thurber has retained unimpaired his vision of humor as a thing of simple , unaffected humanness .	28.915106
in his concluding paragraph he writes `` the devoted writer of humor will continue to try to come as close to truth as he can ' ' .	86.91797
for many readers thurber comes closer than anyone else in sight .	10.390145
the master ' s hand has lost none of its craft .	65.44799
he is at his usual best in exposing the shams and self-deceptions of political and diplomatic life in the fifties .	23.816473
the reader meets a few old friends like blimp and the tuc horse , and becomes better acquainted with new members of the cast of characters like the bomb itself , and civilization in her classic robe watching the nuclear arms race , her hair standing straight out .	54.63401
but there is a difference between the present volume and the early low .	86.134926
there is fear in the fifties as his title suggests and as his competent drawings show .	82.860664
but there was terror in the thirties when the nazis were on the loose and in those days low struck like lightning .	92.96971
anyone can draw his own conclusions from this difference .	196.79314
it might be argued that the communists are less inhuman than the nazis and furnish the artist with drama in a lower key .	78.4692
but this argument cannot be pushed very far because the communist system makes up for any shortcomings of its leaders in respect to corrosion .	64.70367
the communists wield a power unknown to hitler .	9.612271
and the leading issue , that of piecemeal aggression , remains the same .	74.60637
do we ourselves offer mr . low less of a crusade ? ?	23.848469
in the thirties we would not face our enemy	819.5493
that was a nightmarish situation and low was in his element .	42.774242
we are stronger and more self-confident -- and low cannot so easily put us to rights .	186.084
or does the reason for less jovian drawings lie elsewhere ? ?	33.923985
it might be that low has seen too many stupidities and that they do not outrage him now .	34.989174
he writes , `` confucius held that in times of stress one should take short views -- only up to lunchtime ' ' .	216.84758
whatever the cause , his mood in the fifties rarely rises above the level of the capably sardonic .	20.170555
he does not seem to have caught the subtleties of the man .	10.790287
the skies turn dark but the clouds do not loose their wrath .	26.593822
low seems to have supported eden at first and then relented because things worked out differently , so there is no fire in his eye .	88.28025
stalin ' s death , churchill ' s farewell to public life , hillary and tensing on everest , quemoy and matsu -- all subjects for a noble anger or an accolade .	16.789406
instead the cartoons seem to deal with foibles .	4.3341002
did low decide to let well enough alone when he made his selections ? ?	51.330452
he showed puny men attacked by splendidly tyrannical machines .	23.07712
and khrushchev turned out to be prime copy for the most witty caricaturist of them all .	29.606722
look in this book for weak mortals and only on occasion for virtues and vices on the heroic scale .	97.941574
read the moderately brief text , not for captions , sometimes for tart epigrams , once in a while for an explosion in the middle of your fixed ideas .	45.737743
a gray fox with a patch on one eye -- confidence man , city slicker , lebensraum specialist -- tries to take over catfish bend in this third relaxed allegory from mr . burman ' s refreshing louisiana animal community .	59.464504
the fox is all ingratiating smiles when he arrives from new orleans , accompanied by one wharf rat .	16.128965
but like all despots , as he builds his following from among the gullible , he grows more threatening toward those who won ' t follow -- such solid citizens as doc raccoon	81.40393
and the eagle , who leads the bird community when he is not too busy in washington posing for fifty-cent pieces .	70.286896
as soon as the fox has taken hold on most of the populace he imports more wharf rats , who , of course , say they are the aggrieved victims of an extermination campaign in the city .	24.208456
( the followers of bullies invariably are aggrieved about the very things they plan to do to others .	54.723858
) they train the mink and other animals to fight .	31.899473
and pretty soon gray fox is announcing that he won ' t have anyone around that ' s against him , and setting out to break his second territorial treaty with the birds .	62.287373
robert hillyer , the poet , writes in his introduction to this brief animal fable that mr . burman ought to win a nobel prize for the catfish bend series .	25.764927
he may have a point in urging that decadent themes be given fewer prizes .	53.395576
but it ' s hard to imagine mr . burman as a nobel laureate on the basis of these charming but not really momentous fables .	22.793499
in substance they lie somewhere between the southern dialect animal stories of joel chandler harris ( uncle remus ) and the polished , witty fables of james thurber .	17.184483
george kennan ' s account of relations between russia and the west from the fall of tsarism to the end of world war 2 , is the finest piece of diplomatic history that has appeared in many years .	20.927649
it combines qualities that are seldom found in one work scrupulous scholarship , a fund of personal experience , a sense of drama and characterization and a broad grasp of the era ' s great historical issues .	43.130947
in short , the book , based largely on lectures delivered at harvard university , is both reliable and readable	60.68828
the author possesses an uncommonly fine english style , and he is dealing with subjects of vast importance that are highly topical for our time .	38.776737
if mr . kennan is sometimes a little somber in his appraisals , if his analysis of how western diplomacy met the challenge of an era of great wars and social revolutions is often critical and pessimistic -- well , the record itself is not too encouraging .	50.8955
mr . kennan takes careful account of every mitigating circumstance in recalling the historical atmosphere in which mistaken decisions were taken .	17.346226
but he rejects , perhaps a little too sweepingly , the theory that disloyal and pro-communist influences may have contributed to the policy of appeasing stalin which persisted until after the end of the war and reached its high point at the yalta conference in february , 1945 .	36.63891
after all , alger hiss , subsequently convicted of perjury in denying that he gave secret state department documents to soviet agents , was at yalta .	38.23275
and harry dexter white , implicated in f . b . i . reports in communist associations , was one of the architects of the morgenthau plan , which had it ever been put into full operation , would have simply handed germany to stalin .	77.22292
one item in this unhappy scheme was to have germany policed exclusively by its continental neighbors , among whom only the soviet union possessed real military strength .	46.77638
it is quite probable , however , that stupidity , inexperience and childish adherence to slogans like `` unconditional surrender ' ' had more to do with the unsatisfactory settlements at the end of the war than treason or sympathy with communism .	39.729504
mr . kennan sums up his judgment of what went wrong this way	461.5213
`` you see , first of all and in a sense as the source of all other ills , the unshakeable american commitment to the principle of unconditional surrender the tendency to view any war in which we might be involved not as a means of achieving limited objectives in the way of changes in a given status quo , but as a struggle to the death between total virtue and total evil , with the result that the war had absolutely to be fought to the complete destruction of the enemy ' s power , no matter what disadvantages or complications this might involve for the more distant future ' ' .	44.642887
recognizing that there could have been no effective negotiated peace with hitler , he points out the shocking failure to give support to the anti-nazi underground , which very nearly eliminated hitler in 1944 .	64.96948
a veteran diplomat with an extraordinary knowledge of russian language , history and literature , kennan recalls how , at the time of hitler ' s attack on the soviet union in 1941 , he penned a private note to a state department official , expressing the hope that `` never would we associate ourselves with russian purposes in the areas of eastern europe beyond her own boundaries ' ' .	41.13237
with justified bitterness the author speaks of `` what seems to me to have been an inexcusable body of ignorance about the nature of the russian communist movement , about the history of its diplomacy , about what had happened in the purges , and about what had been going on in poland and the baltic states ' ' .	32.2186
he also speaks of franklin d . roosevelt ' s `` puerile ' ' assumption that `` if only he ( stalin ) could be exposed to the persuasive charm of someone like f . d . r . himself , ideological preconceptions would melt and russia ' s co-operation with the west could be easily arranged ' ' .	36.504265
no wonder khrushchev ' s first message to president kennedy was a wistful desire for the return of the `` good old days ' ' of roosevelt .	40.213535
this fascinating story begins with a sketch , rich in personal detail , of the glancing mutual impact of world war 1 , and the two instalments of the russian revolution .	25.451756
the first of these involved the replacement of the tsar by a liberal provisional government in march , 1917	24.461544
the second , the seizure of power by the bolsheviks ( who later called themselves communists ) in november of the same year .	42.396954
as kennan shows , the judgment of the allied governments about what was happening in russia was warped by the obsession of defeating germany .	23.948832
they were blind to the evidence that nothing could keep the russian people fighting .	140.15721
they attributed everything that went wrong in russia to german influence and intrigue .	63.37266
this , more than any other factor , led to the fiasco of allied intervention .	23.335894
`` had a world war not been in progress , there would never , under any conceivable stretch of the imagination , have been an allied intervention in north russia ' ' .	55.918583
the scope and significance of this intervention have been grossly exaggerated by communist propaganda	10.592167
here kennan , operating with precise facts and figures , performs an excellent job of debunking .	28.598328
of many passages in the book that exemplify the author ' s vivid style , the characterizations of the two plebeian dictators whose crimes make those of crowned autocrats pale by comparison may be selected .	28.562616
`` this was a man of incredible criminality , of a criminality effectively without limits	99.5123
a man apparently foreign to the very experience of love , without mercy or pity	77.499405
a man in whose entourage none was ever safe	9803.704
a man whose hand was set against all that could not be useful to him at the moment	39.49214
a man who was most dangerous of all to those who were his closest collaborators in crime .	47.38888
and here is kennan ' s image of hitler , stalin ' s temporary collaborator in the subjugation and oppression of weaker peoples , and his later enemy	20.237213
`` behind that charlie chaplin moustache and that truant lock of hair that always covered his forehead , behind the tirades and the sulky silences , the passionate orations and the occasional dull evasive stare , behind the prejudices , the cynicism , the total amorality of behavior , behind even the tendency to great strategic mistakes , there lay a statesman of no mean qualities shrewd , calculating , in many ways realistic , endowed -- like stalin -- with considerable powers of dissimulation , capable of playing his cards very close to his chest when he so desired , yet bold and resolute in his decisions , and possessing one gift stalin did not possess the ability to rouse men to fever pitch of personal devotion and enthusiasm by the power of the spoken word ' ' .	47.28857
two criticisms of this generally admirable and fascinating book involve the treatment of wartime diplomacy which is jagged at the edges -- there is no mention of the potsdam conference or the morgenthau plan .	27.884844
and in a concluding chapter about america ' s stance in the contemporary world , one senses certain misplacements of emphasis and a failure to come to grips with the baffling riddle of our time how to deal with a wily and aggressive enemy without appeasement and without war .	33.592224
mr . kennan , who has recently abandoned authorship for a new round of diplomacy as the recently appointed american ambassador to yugoslavia , is not the only man who finds it easier to portray the past than to prescribe for the future .	34.524174
the story of a quarter of a century of soviet-western relations is vitally important , and it is told with the fire of a first-rate historical narrator .	32.40949
the ireland we usually hear about in the theater is a place of bitter political or domestic unrest , lightened occasionally with flashes of native wit and charm .	52.494324
in `` donnybrook ' ' , there is quite a different eire , a rural land where singing , dancing , fist-fighting and romancing are the thing .	49.136646
there is plenty of violence , to be sure , but it is a nice violence and no one gets killed .	29.838
by and large , robert mcenroe ' s adaptation of maurice walsh ' s film , `` the quiet man ' ' , provides the entertainment it set out to , and we have a lively musical show if not a superlative one .	37.413807
this is the tale of one john enright , an american who has accidentally killed a man in the prize ring and is now trying to forget about it in a quiet place where he may become a quiet man .	45.16947
but innesfree , where ellen roe danaher and her bullying brother , will , live , is no place for a man who will not use his fists .	63.50034
so enright ' s courting of the mettlesome ellen is impeded considerably , thereby providing the tale which is told .	79.179276
you may be sure he marries her in the end and has a fine old knockdown fight with the brother , and that there are plenty of minor scraps along the way to ensure that you understand what the word donnybrook means .	71.858215
then there is a matchmaker , one mikeen flynn , a role for which eddie foy was happily selected .	21.39914
now there is no reason in the world why a matchmaker in ireland should happen also to be a talented soft-shoe dancer and gifted improviser of movements of the limbs , torso and neck , except that these talents add immensely to the enjoyment of the play .	37.40387
mr . foy is a joy , having learned his dancing by practicing it until he is practically perfect .	89.32811
his matchmaking is , naturally , incidental , and it only serves flynn right when a determined widow takes him by the ear and leads him off to matrimony .	90.67592
art lund , a fine big actor with a great head of blond hair and a good voice , impersonates enright .	12.97846
although he is not graced with the subtleties of romantic technique , that ' s not what an ex-prize fighter is supposed to have , anyway .	48.937183
joan fagan , a fiery redhead who can impress you that she has a temper whether she really has one or not , plays ellen , and sings the role very well , too .	77.76753
if the mettle which ellen exhibits has a bit of theatrical dross in it , never mind	23.635279
she fits into the general scheme well enough .	15.932675
susan johnson , as the widow , spends the first half of the play running a bar and singing about the unlamented death of her late husband and the second half trying to acquire a new one .	48.843792
she has a good , firm delivery of songs and adds to the solid virtues of the evening .	31.674685
then there are a pair of old biddies played by grace carney and sibly bowan who may be right off the shelf of stock irish characters , but they put such a combination of good will and malevolence into their parts that they ' re quite entertaining .	55.986027
and in the role of will danaher , philip bosco roars and sneers sufficiently to intimidate not only one american but the whole british army , if he chose .	77.762566
`` donnybrook ' ' is no `` brigadoon ' ' , but it does have some very nice romantic background touches and some excellent dancing .	56.518436
the ballads are sweet and sad , and the music generally competent .	103.253975
it sometimes threatens to linger in the memory after the final curtain , and some of it , such as the catchy `` sez i ' ' , does .	32.288834
`` a toast to the bride ' ' , sung by clarence nordstrom , playing a character called old man toomey , is quite simple , direct and touching .	34.979366
the men of innesfree are got up authentically in cloth caps and sweaters , and their dancing and singing is fine .	24.821962
so is that of the limber company of lasses who whirl and glide and quickstep under jack cole ' s expert choreographic direction .	13.198531
the male dancers sometimes wear kilts and their performance in them is spirited and stimulating .	39.050625
rouben ter-arutunian , in his stage settings , often uses the scrim curtain behind which mr . cole has placed couples or groups who sing and set the mood for the scenes which are to follow .	44.496002
there is no reason why most theatergoers should not have a pretty good time at `` donnybrook ' ' , unless they are permanently in the mood of enright when he sings about how easily he could hate the lovable irish .	33.02593
we can all breathe more easily this morning -- more easily and joyously , too -- because joshua logan has turned the stage show , `` fanny ' ' , into a delightful and heart-warming film .	31.773722
the task of taking the raw material of marcel pagnol ' s original trio of french films about people of the waterfront in marseilles and putting them again on the screen , after their passage through the broadway musical idiom , was a delicate and perilous one , indeed .	43.489212
more than the fans of pagnol ' s old films and of their heroic star , the great raimu , were looking askance at the project .	51.95786
the fans of the musical were , too .	23.57302
but now the task is completed and the uncertainty resolved with the opening of the english-dialogue picture at the music hall yesterday .	44.640984
whether fan of the pagnol films or stage show , whether partial to music or not , you can ' t help but derive joy from this picture if you have a sense of humor and a heart .	80.69695
some of the new york philharmonic musicians who live in the suburbs spent yesterday morning digging themselves free from snow .	120.61953
a tiny handful never did make the concert .	4.994309
but , after a fifteen-minute delay , the substantially complete philharmonic assembled on stage for the afternoon ' s proceedings .	41.89374
they faced a rather small audience , as quite a few subscribers apparently had decided to forego the pleasures of the afternoon .	32.90731
paul paray , rounding out his current stint with the orchestra , is a solid musician , and the philharmonic plays for him .	51.36642
their collaboration in the beethoven second symphony was lucid , intelligent and natural sounding .	12.413685
it was not a heavy , ponderous beethoven .	4.369644
the music sang nicely , sprinted evenly when necessary , was properly accented and balanced .	56.72906
the franck symphonic poem , `` psyche ' ' , is a lush , sweet-sounding affair that was pleasant to encounter once again .	26.823553
fortunate for the music itself , it is not too frequent a visitor	65.95499
if it were , its heavily chromatic harmonies would soon become cloying .	23.649878
mr . paray resisted the temptation to over-emphasize the melodic elements of the score .	8.213394
he did not let the strings , for instance , weep , whine or get hysterical .	12.778662
his interpretation was a model of refinement and accuracy .	18.853241
and in the prokofieff c major piano concerto , with zadel skolovsky as soloist , he was an admirable partner .	13.9858465
mr . skolovsky ' s approach to the concerto was bold , sweeping and tonally percussive .	11.045599
he swept through the music with ease , in a non-sentimental and ultra-efficient manner .	11.131437
an impressive technician , mr . skolovsky has fine rhythm , to boot .	73.94216
his tone is the weakest part of his equipment	3115.015
a school of thought has it that those attributes are exactly what this concerto needs .	422.78973
it is , after all , a non-romantic work ( even with the big , juicy melody of the second movement )	142.94719
and the composer himself was called the `` age of steel pianist ' ' .	27.298073
but granted all this , one still would have liked to have heard a little more tonal nuance than mr . skolovsky supplied .	34.35399
taken as a whole , though , it was a strong performance from both pianist and orchestra .	128.52034
mr . skolovsky fully deserved the warm reception he received .	59.449165
a new work on the program was nikolai lopatnikoff ' s `` festival overture ' ' , receiving its first new york hearing .	14.957182
this was composed last year as a salute to the automobile industry .	35.33703
it runs a little more than ten minutes , is workmanlike , busy , methodical and featureless .	9.528163
`` la gioconda ' ' , like it or not , is a singer ' s opera .	53.47613
and so , of course , it is a fan ' s opera as well .	42.78565
snow or no , the fans were present in force at the metropolitan opera last night for a performance of the ponchielli work .	36.65361
so the plot creaks , the sets are decaying , the costumes are pre-historic , the orchestra was sloppy and not very well connected with what the singers were doing .	33.060482
after all , the opera has juicy music to sing and the goodies are well distributed , with no less than six leading parts .	46.73877
one of those parts is that of evil , evil barnaba , the spy .	12.338935
his wicked deeds were carried on by anselmo colzani , who was taking the part for the first time with the company .	25.661554
he has the temperament and the stage presence for a rousing villain and he sang with character and strong tone .	46.700806
what was lacking was a real sense of phrase , the kind of legato singing that would have added a dimension of smoothness to what is , after all , a very oily character .	40.43616
regina resnik as laura and cesare siepi as alvise also were new to the cast , but only with respect to this season	67.69989
they have both sung these parts here before .	40.860455
laura is a good role for miss resnik , and she gave it force , dramatic color and passion .	61.525543
mr . siepi was , as always , a consummate actor	10.717364
with a few telling strokes he characterized alvise magnificently .	5.5196877
part of this characterization was , of course , accomplished with the vocal chords .	20.448193
unfortunately his voice was out of focus and often spread in quality .	166.77057
eileen farrell in the title role , mignon dunn as la cieca and richard tucker as enzo were holdovers from earlier performances this season , and all contributed to a vigorous performance .	31.356833
if only they and fausto cleva in the pit had got together a bit more .	79.13685
`` melodious birds sing madrigals ' ' saith the poet and no better description of the madrigaling of the deller consort could be imagined .	15.544423
stereo bgs 5031 ) is a good sample of the special , elegant art of english madrigal singing .	27.038712
it also makes a fine introduction to the international art form with good examples of italian and english madrigals plus several french `` chansons ' ' .	53.301125
the english have managed to hold onto their madrigal tradition better than anyone else .	19.01679
the original impulses came to england late ( in the sixteenth century ) and continue strong long after everyone else had gone on to the baroque basso continuo , sonatas , operas and the like .	37.741333
even after elizabethan traditions were weakened by the cromwellian interregnum , the practice of singing together -- choruses , catches and glees -- always flourished .	11.301631
the english never again developed a strong native music that could obliterate the traces of an earlier great age the way , say , the opera in italy blotted out the italian madrigal .	59.933205
latter-day interest in elizabethan singing dates well back into the nineteenth century in england , much ahead of similar revivals in other countries .	41.43342
as a result no comparable literature of the period is better known and better studied nor more often performed than the english madrigal .	90.730415
naturally , mr . deller and the other singers in his troupe are most charming and elegant when they are squarely in their tradition and singing music by their countrymen william byrd , thomas morley and thomas tomkins .	38.75713
there is an almost instrumental quality to their singing , with a tendency to lift out important lines and make them lead the musical texture .	69.95261
both techniques give the music purity and clarity .	3.3188806
claude jannequin ' s vocal description of a battle ( the french equivalents of tarantara , rum-tum-tum , and boom-boom-boom are very picturesque ) is lots of fun , and the singers get a sense of grace and shape into other chansons by jannequin and lassus .	26.074713
only with the more sensual , intense and baroque expressions of marenzio , monteverdi and gesualdo does the singing seem a little superficial .	10.969445
nevertheless , the musicality , accuracy and infectious charm of these performances , excellently reproduced , make it an attractive look-see at the period .	36.441772
the elements of elegance and color in jannequin are strong french characteristics .	200.97618
baroque instrumental music in italy and germany tends to be strong , lively , intense , controlled and quite abstract .	36.591557
in france , it remained always more picturesque , more dancelike , more full of flavor .	24.88235
couperin and rameau gave titles to nearly everything they wrote , not in the later sense of `` program music ' ' but as a kind of nonmusical reference for the close , clear musical forms filled with keen wit and precise utterance .	71.48205
both composers turn up on new imports from france .	6.089088
bam is the unlikely name of a french recording company whose full label is editions de la boite a musique .	78.45936
they specialize in out-of-the-way items and old french music naturally occupies a good deal of their attention .	57.57523
sonates et concerts royaux of couperin le grand occupy two disks ( ld056 and ld060 ) and reveal the impeccable taste and workmanship of this master -- delicate , flexible and gemlike .	23.855394
the concerts -- nos . 2 , 6 , 9 , 10 and 14 are represented -- are really closer to chamber suites than to concertos in the italian sense .	65.87321
the sonatas , `` la francaise ' ' , `` la sultane ' ' , `` l ' astree ' ' and `` l ' imperiale ' ' , are often more elaborately worked out and , in fact , show a strong italian influence .	17.95903
couperin also turns up along with some lesser-known contemporaries on a disk called musique francaise du 18e siecle ( bam ld 060 ) .	6.892844
jean-marie leclair still is remembered a bit , but bodin de beismortier , corrette and mondonville are hardly household words .	26.304089
what is interesting about these chamber works here is how they all reveal the aspect of french music that was moving toward the rococo .	76.142265
the couperin `` la steinkerque ' ' , with its battle music , brevity , wit and refined simplicity , already shakes off corelli and points towards the mid-century elegances that ended the baroque era .	30.993042
if couperin shows the fashionable trend , the others do so all the more .	273.40265
all these records have close , attractive sound and the performances by a variety of instrumentalists is characteristic .	47.79504
rameau ' s six concerts en sextuor , recorded by l ' orchestre de chambre pierre menet ( bam ld 046 ) , turn out to be harpsichord pieces arranged for strings apparently by the composer himself .	22.135149
the strange , delightful little character pieces with their odd and sometimes inexplicable titles are still evocative and gracious .	21.726467
maitres allemands des 17e et 18e siecles contains music by pachelbel , buxtehude , rosenmueller and telemann , well performed by the ensemble instrumental sylvie spycket ( bam ld 035 ) .	8.723101
rococo music -- a lot of it -- was played in carnegie recital hall on saturday night in the first of four concerts being sponsored this season by a new organization known as globe concert arts .	83.876625
works by j . c . bach , anton craft , joseph haydn , giuseppe sammartini , comenico dragonetti and j . g . janitsch were performed by seven instrumentalists including anabel brieff , flutist , josef marx , oboist , and robert conant , pianist and harpsichordist .	13.419716
since rococo music tends to be pretty and elegant above all , it can seem rather vacuous to twentieth-century ears that have grown accustomed to the stress and dissonances of composers from beethoven to boulez .	27.186584
thus there was really an excess of eighteenth-century charm as one of these light-weight pieces followed another on saturday night .	57.926613
each might find a useful place in a varied musical program , but taken together they grew quite tiresome .	105.207924
the performances were variable , those of the full ensemble being generally satisfying , some by soloists proving rather trying .	123.870155
ellie mao , soprano , and frederick fuller , baritone , presented a program of folksongs entitled `` east meets west ' ' in carnegie recital hall last night .	28.104397
they were accompanied by anna mi lee , pianist .	55.277416
selections from fifteen countries were sung as solos and duets in a broad range of languages .	13.151987
songs from china and japan were reserved exclusively for miss mao , who is a native of china , and those of the british isles were sung by mr . fuller , who is english by birth .	26.763544
this was not a program intended to illustrate authentic folk styles .	227.98042
on the contrary , miss mao and mr . fuller chose many of their arrangements from the works of composers such as mendelssohn , dvorak , canteloube , copland and britten .	23.353804
there was , therefore , more musical substance in the concert than might have been the case otherwise .	45.614647
the performances were assured , communicative and pleasingly informal .	37.175385
what was omitted from `` a neglected education ' ' were those essentials known as `` the facts of life ' ' .	15.764251
chabrier ' s little one-act operetta , presented yesterday afternoon at town hall , is a fragile , precious little piece , very french , not without wit and charm .	60.080826
the poor uneducated newlywed , a certain gontran de boismassif , has his problems in getting the necessary information .	125.72007
the humor of the situation can be imagined .	12.5315
it all takes place in the eighteenth century .	1.8630421
what a silly , artificial way of life , chabrier and his librettists chuckle .	8.859864
but they wish they could bring it back .	5.4230404
chabrier ' s delightful music stands just at the point where the classical , rationalist tradition , ( handed down to chabrier largely in the form of operetta and salon music ) becomes virtually neo-classicism .	35.968548
the musical cleverness and spirit plus a strong sense of taste and measure save a wry little joke from becoming either bawdy or mawkish .	45.35276
the simple , clever production was also able to tread the thin line between those extremes .	19.332968
the work uses the old eighteenth-century tradition of giving the part of a young inexperienced youth to a soprano .	74.63027
benita valente was delightful as the young wife and john parella was amusing as the tutor who failed to do all his tutoring .	20.744574
the work was presented as the final event in the town hall festival of music .	27.658602
it was paired with a darius milhaud opera , `` the poor sailor ' ' , set to a libretto by jean cocteau , a kind of grand guignol by the sea , a sailor returns , unrecognized , and gets done in by his wife .	25.847582
with the exception of a few spots , milhaud ' s music mostly churns away with his usual collection of ditties , odd harmonies , and lumbering , satiric orchestration .	19.259546
had a funny experience at newport yesterday afternoon .	21.102636
sat there and as a woman sang , she kept getting thinner and thinner , right before my eyes , and the eyes of some 5 , 500 other people .	41.606094
i make this observation about the lady , miss judy garland , because she brought up the subject herself in telling a story about a british female reporter who flattered her terribly in london recently and then wrote in the paper the next day	58.68236
but who cares , when the lady sings ? ?	31.364315
certainly not the largest afternoon audience newport has ever had at a jazz concert and the most attentive and quiet .	49.794743
they applauded every number , not only at its conclusion but also at the first statement of the theme -- sometimes at the first chord .	65.18171
and judy sang the lovely old familiar things which seemed , at times , a blessed relief from the way-out compositions of the progressive jazzmen who have dominated these proceedings .	29.605593
things like `` when you ' re smiling ' ' , `` almost like being in love ' ' , `` do it again ' ' , `` born to wander ' ' , `` alone together ' ' , `` who cares ? ?	24.295946
' ' , `` puttin ' on the ritz ' ' , `` how long has this been going on ? ?	26.04725
' ' and her own personal songs like `` the man that got away ' ' , and the inevitable `` over the rainbow ' ' .	26.25689
miss garland is not only one of the great singers of our time but she is one of the superb showmen .	21.377258
at the start of her program there were evidences of pique .	13.579008
she had held to the letter of her contract and didn ' t come onto the stage until well after 4 p . m . , the appointed hour , although the music at newport people had tried to get the program underway at 3 .	77.67055
then there was a bad delay in getting mort lindsey ' s 30-piece orchestra wedged into its chairs .	8.076368
along about 4 30 , just when it was getting to be about time to turn the audience over and toast them on the other side , judy came on singing , in a short-skirted blue dress with a blue and white jacket that flapped in the wind .	34.35765
her bouffant coiffure was fortunately combed on the left which happened to be the direction from which a brisk breeze was blowing .	49.41363
in her first song she waved away one encroaching photographer who dared approach the throne unbidden and thereafter the boys with the cameras had to unsheathe their 300 mm . lenses and shoot at extreme range .	38.21486
there also came a brief contretemps with the sound mixers who made the mistake of being overheard during a quiet moment near the conclusion of `` do it again ' ' , and she made the tart observation that `` i never saw so much moving about in an audience ' ' .	54.830612
but it didn ' t take judy garland , showman , long to realize that this sort of thing was par for the course at newport and that you have to learn to live with it .	45.554012
before her chore was finished she was rescuing wind-blown sheets of music , trundling microphones about the stage , helping to move the piano and otherwise joining in the informal atmosphere .	57.166798
and time after time she really belted out her songs .	39.01285
sometimes they struck me as horribly over-arranged -- which was the way i felt about her `` come rain or come shine ' ' -- and sometimes they were just plain magnificent , like her shatteringly beautiful `` beautiful weather ' ' .	48.20654
to her partisan audience , such picayune haggling would have seemed nothing more than a critic striving to hold his franchise	58.78005
they just sat back on their haunches and cried for more , as though they could never get enough .	72.77008
they were rewarded with splendid , exciting , singing .	38.869705
her `` rockabye your baby ' ' was as good as it can be done , and her really personal songs , like `` the man that got away ' ' were deeply moving .	108.14177
the audience wouldn ' t let her leave until it had heard `` over the rainbow ' ' -- although the fellow that kept crying for `` get happy ' ' had to go home unhappy , about that item anyway .	81.09373
she was generous with her encores and the audience was equally so with its cheers and applause and flowers .	43.3742
all went home happy except the newport police , who feared that the throng departing at 6 35 might meet head-on the night crowd drawing nigh , and those deprived of their happy hour at the cocktail bar .	34.89721
in newport last night there were flashes of distant lightning in the northern skies .	16.57212
this was perhaps symbolic of the jazz of the evening -- flashes in the distance , but no storm .	35.584522
several times it came near breaking , and there were in fact some lovely peals of thunder from jerry mulligan ' s big band , which is about as fine an aggregation as has come along in the jazz business since john hammond found count basie working in a kansas city trap .	80.13084
mulligan ' s band has been infected with his solid sense of swing , and what it does seems far more meaningful than most of the noise generated by the big concert aggregations .	43.521763
but what is equally impressive is the delicacy and wonderful lyric quality of both the band and mulligan ' s baritone sax in a fragile ballad like bob brookmeyer ' s arrangement of `` django ' s castle ' ' .	15.133596
for subtle swinging rhythms , i could admire intensely mulligan ' s version of `` weep ' ' , and the fireworks went on display in `` 18 carrots for robert ' ' , a sax tribute to johnny hodges .	18.864077
there was considerable contrast between this mulligan performance and that of art blakey and the jazz messengers , who are able to generate a tremendous sound for such a small group .	27.971725
unfortunately , blakey doesn ' t choose to work much of the time in this vein .	28.058609
he prefers to have his soloist performing and thus we get only brief glimpses of what his ensemble work is like .	161.30058
what we did get , however , was impressive .	228.80135
a few drops of rain just before midnight , when sarah vaughan was in the midst of her first number , scattered the more timid members of the audience briefly , but at this hour and with sarah on the stand , most of the listeners didn ' t care whether they got wet .	46.657738
miss vaughan was back in top form , somehow mellowed and improved with the passage of time -- like a fine wine .	55.60223
after the spate of female vocalists we have been having , all of whom took sarah as a point of departure and then tried to see what they could do that might make her seem old hat , it seemed that all that has happened is to make the real thing seem better than ever .	64.079575
the evening program was opened by the jazz three , a newport group consisting of steve budieshein on bass , jack warner , drums , and don cook , piano .	17.753677
this was a continuation of a good idea which was first tried out saturday night when the eddie stack group , also local talent , went on first .	167.87024
putting on local musicians at this place in the program serves a triple purpose it saves the top flight jazz men from being wasted in this unenviable spot , when the audience is cold , restless , and in flux	101.97855
it prevents late-comers from missing some of the people they have come a long way to hear , and it gives the resident musicians a chance to perform before the famous newport audience .	50.41078
the jazz three displayed their sound musicianship , not only in their own chosen set , but as the emergency accompanists for al minns & leon james , the superb jazz dancers who have now been newport performers for three successive years , gradually moving up from a morning seminar on the evolution of the blues to a spot on the evening program .	42.752148
julie wilson , a vigorous vocalist without many wild twists , sang a set , a large part of which consisted of such seldom heard old oldies as `` hard-hearted hannah , the vamp of savannah ' ' , and the delightful `` sunday ' ' .	27.014387
she frosted the cake with the always reliable `` bill bailey ' ' .	16.792946
from this taste of the 1920s , we leaped way out to stan getz ' s private brand of progressive jazz , which did lovely , subtle things for `` baubles , bangles and beads ' ' , and a couple of ballards .	24.414852
he plays his sax principally for beauty of tone , rather than for scintillating flights of meaningless improvisations , and he has a quiet way of getting back and restating the melody after the improvising is over .	32.13791
in this he is sticking with tradition , however far removed from it he may seem to be .	111.04645
george shearing took over with his well disciplined group , a sextet consisting of vibes , guitar , bass , drums , shearing ' s piano and a bongo drummer .	9.773931
he met with enthusiastic audience approval , especially when he swung from jazz to latin american things like the mambo .	36.205334
shearing , himself , seemed to me to be playing better piano than in his recent newport appearances .	146.63242
a very casual , pleasant program -- one of those easy-going things that make newport ' s afternoon programs such a relaxing delight -- was held again under sunny skies , hot sun , and a fresh breeze for an audience of at least a couple of thousands who came to newport to hear music rather than go to the beach .	45.326363
divided almost equally into two parts , it consisted of `` the evolution of the blues ' ' , narrated by jon hendricks , who had presented it last year at the monterey , calif . , jazz festival , and an hour-long session of maynard ferguson and his orchestra , a blasting big band .	11.494768
hendricks ' story was designed for children and he had a small audience of small children right on stage with him .	73.10929
tracing the blues from its african roots among the slaves who were brought to this country and the west indies , he stressed the close relationship between the early jazz forms and the music of the negro churches .	44.296494
to help him on this religious aspect of primitive jazz he had `` big ' ' miller , as a preacher-singer and hannah dean , gospel-singer , while oscar brown jr . , an extremely talented young man , did a slave auctioneer ' s call , a field-hands ' work song , and a beautifully sung negro lullaby , `` brown baby ' ' , which was one of the truly moving moments of the festival .	35.65316
one of those delightful surprise additions , which so frequently occur in jazz programs , was an excellent stint at the drums by the great joe jones , drumming to `` old man river ' ' , which seems to have been elected the favorite solo for the boys on the batterie at this year ' s concerts .	51.742107
demonstrating the primitive african rhythmic backgrounds of the blues was michael babatunde olatunji , who plays such native drums as the konga and even does a resounding job slapping his own chest .	41.18048
he has been on previous newport programs and was one of the sensations of last year ' s afternoon concerts .	56.072563
jimmy witherspoon , blues singer ( and a good one ) , and the ike isaacs trio , which has done such wonderful work for two afternoons now , helping him with the musical examples .	68.71153
pianists who are serious about their work are likely to know the interesting material contained in schubert ' s sonatas .	42.302063
music lovers who are not familiar with this literature may hear an excellent example , played for rca by emil gilels .	100.118
he has chosen sonata op . 53 in aj .	7.005265
the playing takes both sides of the disc .	6.695607
perhaps one of the reasons these sonatas are not programmed more often is their great length .	135.38855
rhythmic interest , melodic beauty and the expansiveness of the writing are all qualities which hold one ' s attention with the gilels playing .	63.344627
his technique is ample and his musical ideas are projected beautifully .	6.215985
the male chorus of the robert shaw chorale sings sea shanties in fine style .	34.053623
what a discussion can ensue when the title of this type of song is in question .	59.20862
do you say chantey , as if the word were derived from the french word chanter , to sing , or do you say shanty and think of a roughly built cabin , which derives its name from the french-canadian use of the word chantier , with one of its meanings given as a boat-yard ? ?	43.444885
either way , the robert shaw chorus sings them in fine style with every colorful word and its musical frame spelled out in terms of agreeable listening .	58.778
if your favorite song is not here it must be an unfamiliar one .	38.418945
the london label offers an operatic recital by ettore bastianini , a baritone whose fame is international .	13.45162
murray louis and his dance company appeared at the henry street playhouse on friday and saturday evenings and sunday afternoons in the premiere of his latest work , `` signal ' ' , and the repetition of an earlier one , `` journal ' ' .	28.609793
`` signal ' ' is choreographed for three male dancers to an electronic score by alwin nikolais .	38.34795
here , as in `` journal ' ' , mr . louis has given himself the lion ' s share of the dancing , and there is no doubt that he is capable of conceiving and executing a wide variety of difficult and arresting physical movements .	30.492477
indeed , both `` journal ' ' and `` signal ' ' qualify as instructive catalogues of modern-dance calisthenics .	12.752557
but chains of movements are not necessarily communicative , and it is in the realm of communication that the works prove disappointing .	37.87235
one frequently has the feeling that the order of their movement combinations could be transposed without notable loss of effect , there is too little suggestion of organic relationship and development .	72.399666
it may be , of course , that mr . louis is consciously trying to create works that anticipate an age of total automation .	83.05145
but it may be , also , that he is merely more mindful of athletics than of esthetics at the present time .	30.29174
one thing is certain , however , and that is that he is far more slavish to the detailed accents , phrasings and contours of the music he deals with than a confident dance creator need be .	47.888836
a brisk , satirical spoof of contemporary american mores entitled `` an american journey ' ' was given its first new york performance at hunter college playhouse last night by the helen tamiris-daniel nagrin dance company .	28.835096
choreographed by mr . nagrin , the work filled the second half of a program that also offered the first new york showing of miss tamiris ' `` once upon a time ' ' as well as her `` women ' s song ' ' and mr . nagrin ' s `` indeterminate figure ' ' .	28.308458
eugene lester assembled a witty and explicit score for `` an american journey ' ' , and malcolm mccormick gave it sprightly imaginative costumes .	17.207146
mr . nagrin has described four `` places ' ' , each with its scenery and people , added two `` diversions ' ' , and concluded with `` a toccata for the young ' ' , a refreshingly underplayed interpretation of rock ' n ' roll dancing .	34.4601
the `` places ' ' could be anywhere , the idiosyncrasies and foibles observed there could be anybody ' s , and the laugh is on us all .	46.788258
but we need not mind too much , because mr . nagrin has expressed it through movement that is diverting and clever almost all the way .	65.79441
miss tamiris ' `` once upon a time ' ' is a problem piece about a man and a woman and the three `` figures ' ' that bother them somehow .	48.651978
unfortunately , the man and woman were not made to appear very interesting at the outset and the menacing figures failed to make them any more so .	54.052296
nor did the dancing involved really seize the attention at any time .	37.0637
the music here , russell smith ' s `` tetrameron ' ' , sounded good .	12.984242
all the performances of the evening were smooth and assured , and the sizable company , with mr . nagrin and marion scott as its leading dancers , seemed to be fine shape .	63.14303
the symphony of the air , greatly assisted by van cliburn , last night got its seven-concert beethoven cycle at carnegie hall off to a good start .	40.26437
at the same time the orchestra announced that next season it would be giving twenty-five programs at carnegie , and that it would be taking these concerts to the suburbs , repeating each of them in five different communities .	60.739285
this news , announced by jerome toobin , the orchestra ' s administrative director , brought applause from the 2 , 800 persons who filled the hall .	42.951653
they showed they were glad that carnegie would have a major orchestra playing there so often next season to take up the slack with the departure to lincoln center of the new york philharmonic , the philadelphia orchestra and the boston symphony .	46.222084
this season the orchestra has already taken a step toward the suburbs in that it is giving six subscription concerts for the orchestral society of westchester in the county center in white plains .	46.212994
the details of the suburban concerts next season , and the centers in which they will be given , will be announced later , mr . toobin said .	37.078053
the concertos that van cliburn has been associated with in new york since his triumphant return from russia in 1958 have been the tchaikovsky , the rachmaninoff third , and the prokofieff third .	49.54506
it was pleasant last night , therefore , to hear him do something else a concerto he has recently recorded , `` the emperor ' ' .	59.74369
the young texas pianist can make great chords ring out as well as anyone , so last night the massive sonorities of this challenging concerto were no hazard to him .	68.769226
but they were not what distinguished his performance .	5.2136536
the elements that did were the introspective slow movement , the beautiful transition to the third movement , and the passages of filigree that laced through the bigger moments of the opening movement and the final rondo .	31.709026
mr . cliburn gave the slow movement some of the quality of a chopin nocturne .	10.458539
alfred wallenstein , the conductor , sensitive accompanist that he is , picked up the idea and led the orchestra here with a sense of brooding , poetic mystery .	84.115906
the collaboration was remarkable , as it was in both the other movements , too .	167.48055
mr . wallenstein , who will lead all of the concerts in the cycle , also conducted the `` leonore ' ' overture no . 3 and the fourth symphony .	27.446514
the orchestra was obviously on its mettle and it played most responsively .	60.089676
and although there was plenty of vigor in the performance , the ensemble was at its best when the playing was soft and lyrical , yet full of the suppressed tension that is one of the hallmarks of beethoven .	58.078396
igor oistrakh will be the next soloist on feb . 4 .	6.51508
there are times when one suspects that the songs that are dropped from musical shows before they reach broadway may really be better than many of those that are left in .	131.12012
today , in the era of the integrated musical when an individual song must contribute to the over-all development of the show , it is understandable that a song , no matter how excellent it may be on its own terms , is cut out because it does not perform the function required of it .	65.12762
in the more casually constructed musicals of the nineteen twenties and nineteen thirties there would seem to have been less reason for eliminating a song of merit .	41.567593
yet there is the classic case of the gershwins ' `` the man i love ' ' .	19.796764
deemed too static when it was first heard in `` lady be good ' ' in philadelphia in 1924 , it was dropped from the score .	62.154423
it was heard again in philadelphia in 1927 in the first version of `` strike up the band ' ' and again abandoned shortly before the entire show was given up .	37.39498
it finally reached broadway in the second and successful version of `` strike up the band ' ' in 1929 .	25.730637
( still another song in `` strike up the band ' ' -- `` i ' ve got a crush on you ' ' -- was retrieved from a 1928 failure , `` treasure girl ' ' .	14.215629
like the gershwins , richard rodgers and lorenz hart were loath to let a good song get away from them .	56.42556
if one of mr . rodgers ' melodies seemed to deserve a better fate than interment in boston or the obscurity of a broadway failure , mr . hart was likely to deck it out with new lyrics to give it a second chance in another show .	74.37155
several of these double entries have been collected by ben bagley and michael mcwhinney , along with rodgers and hart songs that disappeared permanently en route to new york and others that reached broadway but have not become part of the constantly heard rodgers and hart repertory , in a delightfully refreshing album , rodgers and hart revisited ( spruce records , 505 fifth avenue , new york ) .	21.755075
among the particular gems in this collection is the impudent opening song of `` the garrick gaieties ' ' , an impressive forecast of the wit and melody that were to come from rodgers and hart in the years that followed	24.590464
dorothy loudon ' s raucous listing of the attractions `` at the roxy music hall ' ' from `` i married an angel ' '	25.000877
and the incisive style with which charlotte rae delivers the top-drawer hart lyrics of `` i blush ' ' , a song that was cut from `` a connecticut yankee ' ' .	17.206799
altogether fifteen virtually unknown rodgers and hart songs are sung by a quintet of able vocalists .	15.280366
norman paris has provided them with extremely effective orchestral accompaniment	4.813968
turning to the current musical season on broadway , the most widely acclaimed of the new arrivals , how to succeed in business without really trying , has been transferred to an original cast album ( r . c . a . victor loc 1066	44.012623
stereo lso 1066 ) that has some entertaining moments , although it is scarcely as inventive as the praise elicited by the show might lead one to expect .	38.739735
robert morse , singing with comically plaintive earnestness , carries most of the burden and is responsible for the high spots in frank loesser ' s score .	65.34266
rudy vallee , who shares star billing with mr . morse , makes only two appearances .	39.752754
he shares with mr . morse a parody of the college anthems he once sang while his second song is whisked away from him by virginia martin , a girl with a remarkably expressive yip in her voice .	38.438526
in general , mr . loesser has done a more consistent job as lyricist than he has as composer .	88.12438
like mr . loesser , jerry herman is both composer and lyriist for milk and honey ( r . c . a . victor loc 1065	25.389795
stereo lso 1065 ) , but in this case it is the music that stands above the lyrics .	39.17546
for this story of an american couple who meet and fall in love in israel , mr . herman has written songs that are warmly melodious and dance music that sparkles .	39.68079
there are the full-bodied , resourceful voices of robert weede , mimi benzell and tommy rall to make the most of mr . herman ' s lilting melodies and , for an occasional change of pace , the bright humor of molly picon .	19.622894
mr . herman has managed to mix musical ideas drawn from israel and the standard american ballad style in a manner that stresses the basic tunefulness of both idioms .	84.050354
not content to create only the music and lyrics , noel coward also wrote the book and directed sail away ( capitol wao 1643	26.834793
stereo swao 1643 ) , a saga of life on a cruise ship that is not apt to be included among mr . coward ' s more memorable works .	25.360012
the melodies flow along pleasantly , as mr . coward ' s songs usually do , but his lyrics have a tired , cut-to-a-familiar-pattern quality .	35.964314
elaine stritch , who sings with a persuasively warm huskiness , belts some life into most of her songs , but the other members of the cast sound as lukewarm as mr . coward ' s songs .	32.76099
with three fine russian films in recent months on world war 2 , -- `` the house i live in ' ' , `` the cranes are flying ' ' and `` ballad of a soldier ' ' -- we had every right to expect a real soviet block-buster in `` the day the war ended ' ' .	36.2242
it simply isn ' t , not by a long shot .	14.796258
the artkino presentation , with english titles , opened on saturday at the cameo theatre .	12.081645
make no mistake , this gorky studio drama is a respectable import -- aptly grave , carefully written , performed and directed .	34.34987
in describing the initial allied occupation of a middle-sized german city , the picture has color , pictorial pull and genuinely moving moments .	56.97549
told strictly from the viewpoint of the russian conquerors , the film compassionately peers over the shoulders of a smitten soviet couple , at both sides of the conflict ' s aftermath .	30.539352
unfortunately , the whole picture hinges on this romance , at the expense of everything else .	23.54885
tenderly and rather tediously , the camera rivets on the abrupt , deep love of a pretty nurse and a uniformed teacher , complicated by nothing more than a friend they don ' t want to hurt .	45.330967
it ' s the old story , war or no war , and more than one viewer may recall hollywood ' s `` titanic ' ' , several seasons back , when the paramount concern was for the marital discord of a society dilettante .	39.925625
under yakov segal ' s direction , it begins stirringly , as crouching soviet and nazi troops silently scan each other , waiting for the first surrender gesture .	60.3967
one high-up camera shot is magnificent , as the germans straggle from a cathedral , dotting a huge , cobblestone square , and drop their weapons .	21.731749
ring of bright water , by gavin maxwell .	5.0363564
only once in a very long while comes a book that gives the reader a magic sense of sharing a rare experience .	77.280464
`` ring of bright water ' ' by gavin maxwell is just that -- a haunting , warmly personal chronicle of a man , an otter , and a remote cottage in the scottish west highlands .	28.085293
`` he has married me with a ring of bright water ' ' , begins the kathleen raine poem from which maxwell takes his title , and it is this mystic bond between the human and natural world that the author conveys .	39.216908
the place is camusfearna , the site of a long-vanished sea-village opposite the isle of skye .	8.4846
it is a land of long fjords , few people , a single-lane road miles away -- and of wild stags , greylag geese , wild swans , dolphins and porpoises playing in the waters .	17.085796
how maxwell recounts his first coming to camusfearna , his furnishing the empty house with beach-drift , the subtle changes in season over ten years , is a moving experience .	81.95888
just the evocations of time and place , of passionate encounter between man and a natural world which today seems almost lost , would be enough .	102.38663
there is mijbil , an otter who travelled with maxwell -- and gave maxwell ' s name to a new species -- from the tigris marshes to his london flat .	48.465233
it may sound extravagant to say that there has never been a more engaging animal in all literature .	42.301632
this is not only a compliment to mijbil , of whom there are a fine series of photographs and drawings in the book , but to the author who has catalogued the saga of a frightened otter cub ' s journey by plane from iraq to london , then by train ( where he lay curled in the wash basin playing with the water tap ) to camusfearna , with affectionate detail .	41.771595
mij , as his owner was soon to learn , had strange , inexplicable habits .	49.013676
he liked to nip ear lobes of unsuspecting visitors with his needle-sharp teeth .	37.92587
he preferred sleeping in bed with his head on a pillow .	27.9518
given a small ball or marbles , he would invent games and play by himself for hours .	129.41727
with curiosity and elan , he explored every inch of glen , beach and burn , once stranding himself for hours on a ledge high up a sheer seventy-foot cliff and waiting with calm faith to be rescued by maxwell , who nearly lost his life in doing so .	85.31111
a year and a day of this idyll is described for the reader , one in which not only discovery of a new world of personality is charted , but self-discovery as well .	55.92117
in the solitude of camusfearna there had been no loneliness .	13.3335905
`` to be quite alone where there are no other human beings is sharply exhilarating	57.355034
it is as though some pressure had suddenly been lifted , allowing an intense awareness a sharpening of the senses ' ' .	30.473667
now , with the increasing interdependence between himself and mij came a knowledge of an obscure need , that of being trusted implicitly by some creature .	40.501812
two other people in time shared mijbil ' s love `` it remained around us three that his orb revolved when he was not away in his own imponderable world of wave and water	117.24167
we were his trinity , and he behaved towards us with a mixture of trust and abuse , passion and irritation .	30.661228
in turn each of us in our own way depended , as gods do , upon his worship ' ' .	69.50342
the brief details of mijbil ' s death lend depth to the story , give it an edge of ironic tragedy .	107.99105
man , to whom mij gave endless affection and fealty , was responsible in the form of a road worker with a pickaxe who somehow becomes an abstract symbol of the savage in man .	57.989845
but then , through a strange coincidence , maxwell manages to acquire idal , a female otter , and the fascinating story starts once more .	39.714474
one is not sure who emerges as the main personality of this book -- mijbil , with his rollicking ways , or maxwell himself , poet , portrait painter , writer , journalist , traveller and zoologist , sensitive but never sentimental recorder of an unusual way of life , in a language at once lyrical and forceful , vivid and unabashed .	41.32864
this reviewer read the book when it was first brought out in england with a sense of discovery and excitement .	57.053104
now gavin maxwell ' s ring of bright water has widened to enchant the world .	18.461731
-- the performances of the comedie francaise are the most important recent events in the new york theater .	33.955647
they serve to contradict a popular notion that the comedie merely repeats , as accurately as possible , the techniques of acting the classics that prevailed in the 17th century .	22.340101
on the contrary , the old plays are continually being reinterpreted , and each new production of a classic has only a brief history at the comedie .	51.25386
of course , the well-received revivals last longer than the others , and that further reminds us that the comedie is not insensitive to criticism .	26.163834
the directors of the comedie do not respond to adverse notices in as docile and subservient a manner as the broadway producers who , in two instances this season , closed their plays after one performance .	82.804344
but they are aware of the world outside , they court public approval , they delight in full houses , and they occasionally dare to experiment in interpreting a dramatic classic .	124.94995
in france , novel approaches to the classic french plays are frequently attempted .	211.12872
the government pays a subsidy for revival of the classics , and this policy attracts experimenters who sometimes put moliere ' s characters in modern dress and often achieve interesting results .	35.48172
so far as i know , the comedie has never put moliere ' s people in the costumes of the 20th century , but they do reinterpret plays and characters .	24.678017
last season , the comedie ' s two principal experiments came to grief , and , in consequence , we can expect fairly soon to see still newer productions of racine ' s `` phedre ' ' and moliere ' s `` school for wives ' ' .	27.809162
the new `` phedre ' ' was done in 17th century setting , instead of ancient greek	44.03619
perhaps that is the comedie ' s equivalent for thrusting this play ' s characters into our own time .	62.513836
the speaking of the lines seemed excessively slow and stately , possibly in an effort to capture the spirit of 17th century elegance .	14.548863
a few literary men defended what they took to be an emphasis on the poetry at the expense of the drama , but the response was mainly hostile and quite violent .	48.971333
the new `` school for wives ' ' was interpreted according to a principle that is becoming increasingly common in the playing of classic comedy -- the idea of turning some obviously ludicrous figure into a tragic character .	60.253883
among the moliere specialists of some years ago , louis jouvet tried to humanize some of the clowns , while fernand ledoux , often performing at the comedie , made them more gross than moliere may have intended .	30.499712
apparently , jouvet and ledoux attempted just these dissimilar approaches in the role of arnolphe in `` the school for wives ' ' .	17.608845
i say `` apparently ' ' although i saw jouvet as arnolphe when he visited this country shortly before his death	54.508106
by that time , he seemed to have dropped the tragic playing of the last moments of the comedy .	36.35815
arnolphe , it will be recalled , is a man of mature years who tries to preserve the innocence of his youthful wife-to-be .	30.094084
one influential french critic remarked `` pity for arnolphe comes with age ' ' .	72.859245
accordingly , at the comedie last year , jean meyer played a sympathetic arnolphe and drew criticism for turning the comedy into a tragedy .	57.37768
but the stuff of tragedy was not truly present and the play became only comedy acted rather slowly .	370.37604
wisely , the comedie has brought moliere ' s `` tartuffe ' ' on its tour and has left `` the school for wives ' ' at home .	23.390688
tartuffe is the religious hypocrite who courts his benefactor ' s wife .	5.2477946
jouvet played him as a sincere zealot , and ledoux , at the comedie , made him a gross buffoon , or so the historians tell us .	46.59166
louis seigner , who formerly played the deluded benefactor opposite ledoux , is the tartuffe of the present production , which he himself directed .	60.52996
his red face , his coarse gestures , and his lustful stares bespeak his sensuality .	5.118648
but his heavenward glances and his pious speeches are not merely perfunctory	26.64835
of course , they do not reflect sincerity , but they exhibit a concern to make a good job out of his pious impersonation .	44.837746
occasionally , seigner draws some justly deserved laughs by his quick shifts from one personality to another .	74.21734
the whole role , by the way , is a considerable transformation for anyone who has seen seigner in his other parts .	102.32683
his normal specialty is playing the good-natured old man , frequently stupid or deluded but never mean or sly .	42.997616
here , he is , quite persuasively , the very embodiment of meanness and slyness .	15.293493
seigner is the dean of the company , the oldest actor in point of continuous service .	35.916233
in that function , he helps to rebut another legend about the comedie .	21.646946
we are often told that the comedie has , unfortunately , life-contracts with old actors who are both mediocre and lazy , drawing their pay without much acting but probably doing real service to the comedie by staying off the stage .	94.23724
seigner , however , is a fine actor and probably the busiest man in the company	33.988167
among his other parts are the leads in `` the bourgeois gentleman ' ' and `` the imaginary invalid ' ' .	9.702526
in moliere ' s farce , `` the tricks of scapin ' ' , robert hirsch undertakes another of the great roles .	10.6499815
to begin with , scapin is a trickster in the old tradition of the clever servant who plots the strategy of courtship for his master .	26.318138
hirsch ' s scapin is healthy , cheerful , energetic , revelling in his physical agility and his obvious superiority to the young gentlemen whom he serves .	28.713312
hirsch says that he has given the role certain qualities he has observed in the city toughs of the real world .	66.60925
and surely his scapin has a fresh directness , a no-nonsense quality that seems to make him his own master and nobody ' s servant .	33.098427
django reinhardt , the ill-fated gypsy , was a true artist , one who demonstrated conclusively the power of art to renew itself and flow into many channels .	54.307484
there is hardly a jazz guitarist in the business today who doesn ' t owe something to django .	33.72071
he told once of how he switched his style of playing to jazz after listening to two old armstrong records he bought in the flea market in paris .	65.87229
it was the first jazz he had heard .	74.91719
django , who was born jean baptiste reinhardt in belgium and who died in 1953 in france , was an extraordinary man .	19.088776
most of the fingers on his left hand were burned off when he fell asleep with a cigarette .	23.939287
and this was before he began to play his startlingly beautiful jazz .	41.778954
you can catch up with him -- if you haven ' t already -- on rca-victor ' s album .	15.294635
`` djangology ' ' , made up of tracks he recorded with stephane grappelly and the quintet of the hot club of france .	29.983269
this is a choice item and grappely deserves mention too , of course .	196.89883
he is one of the few men in history who plays jazz on a violin .	137.38152
they play `` minor swing ' ' , `` honeysuckle rose ' ' , `` beyond the sea ' ' , `` bricktop ' ' , `` heavy artillery ' ' , `` djangology ' ' , `` after you ' ve gone ' ' , `` where are you , my love ' ' ? ?	10.116749
`` i saw stars ' ' , `` lover man ' ' , `` menilmontant ' ' and `` swing 42 ' ' .	9.149443
all this is great proceedings -- get the minutes .	395.7675
kid ory , the trombonist chicken farmer , is also one of the solid anchor points of jazz .	52.153046
he dates back to the days before the first sailing ship pulled into new orleans .	32.2639
his horn has blown loud and clear across the land for more years than he cares to remember .	88.24979
good time jazz has released a nice two-record album which he made .	55.14228
wellman braud , bass , and minor hall , drums .	9.571366
the set contains `` high society ' ' , `` do what ory say ' ' , `` down home rag ' ' , `` careless love ' ' , jazz me blues ' ' , `` weary blues ' ' , `` original dixieland one-step ' ' , `` bourbon street parade ' ' , `` panama ' ' , `` toot , toot , tootsie ' ' , `` oh didn ' t he ramble ' ' , `` beale street blues ' ' , `` maryland , my maryland ' ' , `` 1919 rag ' ' , `` eh , la bas ' ' , `` mood indigo ' ' , and `` bugle call rag ' ' .	8.453769
all this will serve to show off the ory style in fine fashion and is a must for those who want to collect elements of the old-time jazz before it is too late to lay hands on the gems .	98.1976
mischa elman shared last night ' s lewisohn stadium concert with three american composers .	28.344473
his portion of the program -- and a big portion it was -- consisted of half the major nineteenth-century concertos for the violin to wit , the mendelssohn and the tchaikovsky .	45.85169
that is an evening of music-making that would faze many a younger man	33.269627
there were 8 , 000 persons at the stadium who can tell their grandchildren that they heard elman .	110.90035
but , with all due respects and allowances , it must truthfully be said that what they heard was more syrupy than sweet , more mannered than musical .	57.695385
the american part of the evening consisted of paul creston ' s dance overture , william schuman ' s `` chester ' ' from `` new england triptych ' ' and two works of wallingford riegger , dance rhythms , op . 58 , and a romanza for strings , op . 56a .	12.285586
the creston is purely a potboiler , with spanish , english , french and american dances mixed into the stew .	66.491234
the riegger , with its latin hesitation bounce , is just this side of the pale	56.752464
like his sweet , attractive romanza , it belongs to what the composer called his `` non-dissonant ( mostly ) ' ' category of works .	58.760178
the schuman `` chester ' ' takes off from an old william billings tune with rousing woodwind and brass effect .	30.315994
all these -- potboilers or no -- provided a welcome breath of fresh air in the form of lively , colorful , unstuffy works well suited for the great out-of-doors .	41.157642
it was nice to have something a little up-to-date for a change .	77.82696
we have alfredo antonini to thank for this healthy change of diet as well as the lively performances of the stadium symphony .	25.83754
a woman who undergoes artificial insemination against the wishes of her husband is the unlikely heroine of `` a question of adultery ' ' , yesterday ' s new british import at the apollo .	29.51156
since an objective viewer might well conclude that this is not a situation that would often arise , the film ' s extensive discussion of the problem seems , at best , superfluous .	38.12457
in its present artless , low-budget form , the subject matter seems designed to invite censorial wrath .	34.747482
with julie london enacting the central role with husky-voiced sincerity , the longsuffering heroine is at least attractive .	13.055765
the explanation offered for her conduct is a misguided attempt to save her marriage to a neurotic husband left sterile as a result of an automobile accident .	42.28202
anthony steel , as the husband , is a jealous type who argues against her course and sues for divorce , labeling her action adulterous .	43.54398
the actor plays his role glumly under the lurid direction of don chaffey , as do basil sydney as his unsympathetic father and anton diffring as an innocent bystander .	26.035765
after a protracted , hysterical trial scene more notable for the frankness of its language than for dramatic credibility , the jury , to no one ' s surprise , leaves the legal question unresolved .	43.006668
when the husband drops the case and returns to his wife , both seem sorry they brought the matter up in the first place .	79.266655
-- for its final change of bill in its london season , the leningrad state kirov ballet chose tonight to give one of those choreographic miscellanies known as a `` gala program ' ' at the royal opera house , covent garden .	33.85754
no doubt the underlying idea was to show that for all the elegance and artistry that have distinguished its presentations thus far , it too could give a circus if it pleased .	93.41132
and please it did , in every sense of the word , for it had the audience shouting much of the time in a manner far from typical of london audiences .	69.17262
at the end of the program , indeed , there was a demonstration that lasted for forty-five minutes , and nothing could stop it .	27.414553
alexandre livshitz repeated a fantastic technical bit from the closing number , `` taras bulba ' ' , but even then there was a substantial number of diehards who seemed determined not to go home at all .	51.921528
only a plea from the house manager , john collins , finally broke up the party .	45.84485
but for all the manifest intention to `` show off ' ' , this was a circus with a difference , for instead of descending in quality to what is known as a popular level , it added further to the evidence that this is a very great dancing company .	65.77411
the `` taras bulba ' ' excerpt is a rousing version of gogol ' s ukrainian folk-tale choreographed by bo fenster to music of soloviev-sedoi .	4.126898
it is danced by some thirty-five men and no women , and it contains everything in the books -- lusty comedy , gregarious cavorting , and tricks that only madmen or russians would attempt to make the human body perform .	29.103477
yuri soloviev , oleg sokolov , alexei zhitkov , lev sokolov , yuri korneyev and mr . livshitz were the chief soloists , but everybody on stage was magnificent .	21.370785
at the other extreme in character was the half-hour excerpt from the petipa-minkus ballet `` bayaderka ' ' , which opened the evening .	18.930622
and why do we in the west know so few of his ballets ? ?	71.14346
this scene is a `` white ballet ' ' in which a lovelorn hero searches for his departed love ' s spirit among twenty-eight extraordinarily beautiful `` shadows ' ' who can all dance like nothing human -- which , of course , is altogether fitting .	30.281025
the ensemble enters in a long adagio passage that is of fantastic difficulty , as well as loveliness , and adagio is the general medium of the piece .	39.89897
