its ballerina , olga moiseyeva , performs simple miracles of beauty , and ludmilla alexeyeva , inna korneyeva and gabrielle komleva make up a threesome of exquisite accomplishments .	6.9262505
sergei vikulov , as the lone male , meets the competition well with some brilliant hits , but the work is designed to belong to the ladies .	70.464386
the middle section of the program was made up of short numbers , naturally enough of unequal merit , but all of them pretty good at that .	79.83804
they consisted of a new arrangement of `` nutcracker ' ' excerpts danced stunningly by irina kolpakova and mr . sokolev , with a large ensemble	15.552333
a winning little `` snow maiden ' ' variation by the adorable galina kekisheva	14.653996
two of those poetic adagios in greek veils ( and superb esthetic acrobacy ) by alla osipenko and igor chernishev in one case and inna zubkovskaya and yuri kornevey in the other	14.456143
an amusing character pas de cinq called `` gossiping women ' '	6.6571474
a stirring `` flames of paris ' ' pas de deux by xenia ter-stepanova and alexandre pavlovsky , and a lovely version of fokine ' s `` le cygne ' ' by olga moiseyeva , which had to be repeated .	9.138899
a year ago today , when the democrats were fretting and frolicking in los angeles and john f . kennedy was still only an able and ambitious senator who yearned for the power and responsibility of the presidency , theodore h . white had already compiled masses of notes about the presidential campaign of 1960 .	80.534355
as the pace of the quadrennial american political festival accelerated , mr . white took more notes .	36.812183
he traveled alternately with mr . kennedy and with richard m . nixon .	27.227787
he asked intimate questions and got frank answers from the members of what he calls the candidates ' `` in-groups ' ' .	17.26958
he assembled quantities of facts about the nature of american politics in general , as well as about the day-to-day course of the closest presidential election in american history .	17.696085
those of us who read the papers may think we know a good deal about that election	121.98985
how little we know of what there is to be known is made humiliatingly clear by mr . white in `` the making of the president 1960 ' ' .	41.322533
this is a remarkable book and an astonishingly interesting one .	82.566284
what might have been only warmed-over topical journalism turns out to be an eyewitness contribution to history .	30.12901
mr . white , who is only a competent novelist , is a brilliant reporter .	57.75575
his zest for specific detail , his sensitivity to emotional atmosphere , his tireless industry and his crisply turned prose all contribute to the effectiveness of his book .	44.92161
as a dramatic narrative `` the making of the president 1960 ' ' is continuously engrossing .	28.289532
and as an introduction to american politics it is highly educational .	128.5177
the author begins this volume with a close-up of mr . kennedy , his family and his entourage waiting for the returns .	30.728678
he then switches back to a consideration of the seven principal presidential hopefuls five democrats -- senator hubert h . humphrey , senator stuart symington , senator lyndon b . johnson , adlai e . stevenson and mr . kennedy -- and two republicans -- governor rockefeller and mr . nixon .	23.386879
then , in chronological order , mr . white covers the primary campaigns , the conventions and the presidential campaign itself .	38.051014
in the process he writes at length about many related matters the importance of race , religion , local tradition , bosses , organizations , zealous volunteers and television .	97.873825
mr . white is bluntly frank in his personal opinions .	71.437035
he frequently cites intimate details that seem to come straight from the horse ' s mouth , from numerous insiders and from mr . kennedy himself	54.420315
but never from mr . nixon , who looked on reporters with suspicion and distrust .	31.658037
`` rarely in american history has there been a political campaign that discussed issues less or clarified them less ' ' , says mr . white .	114.88332
mr . nixon , he believes , has no particular political philosophy and mismanaged his own campaign .	42.101494
although a skillful politician and a courageous and honest man , mr . nixon , mr . white believes , ignored his own top-level planners , wasted time and effort in the wrong regions , missed opportunities through indecision and damaged his chances on television .	47.30718
mr . nixon is `` a broody , moody man , given to long stretches of introspection	80.16795
he is a man of major talent -- but a man of solitary , uncertain impulses .	41.98891
he was above all a friend seeker , almost pathetic in his eagerness to be liked .	36.695793
he wanted to identify with people and have a connection with them	77.724045
the least inspiring candidate since alfred m . landon ' ' .	12.953674
mr . kennedy , mr . white believes , `` had mastered politics on so many different levels that no other american could match him ' ' .	140.17072
calm , dignified , composed , `` superbly eloquent ' ' , mr . kennedy always knew everything about everybody .	31.122025
he enlisted a staff of loyal experts and of many zealous volunteers .	53.86865
every decision was made quickly on sound grounds .	2.1850433
efficiency was enforced and nothing was left to chance .	329.46893
mr . kennedy did not neglect to cultivate the personal friendship of reporters .	15.497275
mr . white admires him profoundly and leaves no doubt that he is a democrat himself who expects mr . kennedy to be a fine president .	61.346672
throughout `` the making of a president ' ' mr . white shows wonderfully well how the pressures pile up on candidates , how decisions have constantly to be made , how fatigue and illness and nervous strain wear candidates down , how subordinates play key roles .	172.73592
`` the root question in american politics is always who ' s the man to see ? ?	54.409023
to understand american politics is , simply , to know people , to know the relative weight of names -- who are heroes , who are straw men , who controls , who does not .	89.58669
but to operate in american politics one must go a step further -- one must build a bridge to such names , establish a warmth , a personal connection ' ' .	69.46979
`` in the hard life of politics it is well known that no platform nor any program advanced by either major american party has any purpose beyond expressing emotion ' ' .	247.00238
`` all platforms are meaningless the program of either party is what lies in the vision and conscience of the candidate the party chooses to lead it ' ' .	57.606647
nostalgia week at lewisohn stadium , which had begun with the appearance of the 70-year-old mischa elman on tuesday night , continued last night as lily pons led the list of celebrities in an evening of french operatic excerpts .	19.580078
miss pons is certainly not 70 -- no singer ever is -- and yet the rewards of the evening again lay more in paying tribute to a great figure of times gone by than in present accomplishments .	109.937294
the better part of gallantry might be , perhaps , to honor her perennial good looks and her gorgeous rainbow-hued gown , and to chide the orchestra for not playing in the same keys in which she had chosen to sing .	45.720455
no orchestra , however , could be expected to follow a singer through quite as many adventures with pitch as miss pons encountered last night .	102.110855
in all fairness , there were flashes of the great stylist of yesteryear , flashes even of the old consummate vocalism .	15.249586
one such moment came in the breathtaking way miss pons sang the cadenza to meyerbeer ' s `` shadow song ' ' .	16.077726
the years suddenly fell away at this point .	3.1385283
on the whole , however , one must wonder at just what it is that forces a beloved artist to besmirch her own reputation as time marches inexorably on .	67.83338
sharing the program was the young french-canadian tenor richard verreau , making his stadium debut on this occasion .	41.32592
mr . verreau began shakily , with a voice that tended toward an unpleasant whiteness when pushed beyond middle volume .	131.61493
later on this problem vanished , and the `` flower song ' ' from bizet ' s `` carmen ' ' was beautifully and intelligently projected .	11.124542
radio is easily outdistancing television in its strides to reach the minority listener .	24.578876
lower costs and a larger number of stations are the key factors making such specialization possible .	116.93136
the mushrooming of fm outlets , offering concerts ( both jazz and classical ) , lectures , and other special events , is a phenomenon which has had a fair amount of publicity .	59.544434
not so well known is the growth of broadcasting operations aimed wholly or partly at negro listeners -- an audience which , in the united states , comprises some 19 , 000 , 000 people with $20 , 000 , 000 , 000 to spend each year .	35.308212
of course , the nonwhite listener does his share of television watching .	59.431026
he even buys a lot of the products he sees advertised -- despite the fact that the copy makes no special bid for his favor and sponsors rarely use any but white models in commercials .	115.11208
but the growing number of negro-appeal radio stations , plus evidence of strong listener support of their advertisers , give time salesmen an impressive argument as they approach new prospects .	130.21674
it is estimated that more than 600 stations ( of a total of 3 , 400 ) do a significant amount of programing for the negro .	29.21607
at least 60 stations devote all of their time to reaching this audience in about half of the 50 states .	72.982925
these and other figures and comments have been reported in a special supplement of sponsor magazine , a trade publication for radio and tv advertisers .	39.919926
for 10 years sponsor has issued an annual survey of the size and characteristics of the negro market and of successful techniques for reaching this market through radio .	69.425415
in the past 10 years , sponsor observes , these trends have become apparent	28.883707
negro population in the u . s . has increased 25 per cent while the white population was growing by 18 per cent .	67.23752
`` the forgotten 15 million ' ' -- as sponsor tagged the negro market in its first survey -- has become a better-remembered 19 million .	79.671814
advertisers are changing their attitudes , both as to the significance of this market and the ways of speaking to it .	63.651676
stations programing to negro listeners are having to upgrade their shows in order to keep pace with rising educational , economic , and cultural levels .	57.101418
futhermore , the station which wants real prestige must lead or participate in community improvement projects , not simply serve on the air .	62.247017
in the last decade the number of negro-appeal radio program hours has risen at least 15 per cent , and the number of negro-appeal stations has increased 30 per cent , according to a research man quoted by sponsor .	34.716076
a year ago the negro radio association was formed to spur research which the 30-odd member stations are sure will bring in more business .	79.023
the 1960 census underscored the explosive character of the population growth .	11.003589
it also brought home proof of something a casual observer might have missed that more than half of the u . s . negroes live outside the southeastern states .	36.86524
also , the state with the largest number of negroes is new york -- not in the south at all .	55.73862
in new york city , wlib boasts `` more community service programs than any other negro station ' ' and `` one of the largest negro news staffs in america ' ' .	47.80942
and wwrl ' s colorful mobile unit , cruising predominately negro neighborhoods , is a frequent reminder of that station ' s round-the-clock dedication to nonwhite interests .	20.77016
recently , wwrl won praise for its expose of particular cases of employment agency deceit .	110.68659
a half-dozen other stations in the new york area also bid for attention of the city ' s negro population , up about 50 per cent in the past decade .	31.187263
in all big cities outside the south , and even in small towns within the south , radio stations can be found beaming some or all of their programs at negro listeners .	100.072174
the keystone broadcasting system ' s negro network includes 360 affiliated stations , whose signals reach more than half the total u . s . negro population .	28.72387
one question which inevitably crops up is whether such stations have a future in a nation where the negro is moving into a fully integrated status .	77.00532
whatever the long-range impact of integration , the owners of negro-appeal radio stations these days know they have an audience and that it is loyal .	78.64691
advertisers have discovered the tendency of negroes to shop for brand names they have heard on stations catering to their special interests .	81.35376
and many advertisers have been happy with the results of letting a negro disc jockey phrase the commercial in his own words , working only from a fact sheet .	117.3729
what sets negro-appeal programing apart from other radio shows ? ?	24.706959
sponsor magazine notes the stress on popular negro bands and singers	4.1505904
`` race ' ' music , folk songs and melodies , and gospel programs .	33.895058
furthermore , news and special presentations inform the listener about groups , projects , and personalities rarely mentioned on a general-appeal station .	59.609234
advertising copy frequently takes into account matters of special negro concern .	387.79703
sponsor quotes john mclendon of the mclendon-ebony station group as saying that the southern negro is becoming conscious of quality and `` does not wish to be associated with radio which is any way degrading to his race	90.56866
he tends to shy away from the hooting and hollering personalities that originally made negro radio programs famous ' ' .	91.35272
the sociological impact is perhaps most eloquently summed up in this quotation of j . walter carroll of ksan , san francisco	37.05102
`` negro-appeal radio is more important to the negro today , because it provides a direct and powerful mirror in which the negro can hear and see his ambitions , achievements and desires .	65.137054
it will continue to be important as a means of orientation to the negro , seeking to become urbanized , as he tries to make adjustment to the urban life .	37.135174
negro radio is vitally necessary during the process of assimilation ' ' .	5.9927206
presentation of `` the life and times of john sloan ' ' in the delaware art center here suggests a current nostalgia for human values in art .	65.541214
staged by way of announcing the gift of a large and intimate sloan collection by the artist ' s widow , helen farr sloan , to the wilmington society of the fine arts , the exhibition presents a survey of sloan ' s work .	26.227169
from early family portraits , painted before he entered the schools of the pennsylvania academy of the fine arts , the chronology extends to a group of paintings executed in his last year ( 1951 ) and still part of his estate .	41.81554
few artists have left a life work so eloquent of the period in which they lived .	42.173748
few who have painted the scenes around them have done so with so little bitterness .	104.12158
the paintings , drawings , prints , and illustrations all reflect the manners , costumes , and mores of america in the first half of the present century .	23.121326
obviously sloan ' s early years were influenced by his close friend robert henri .	104.789665
as early as 1928 , however , the sloan style began to change .	97.37922
the dark pigments of the early work were superseded by a brighter palette .	5.847505
the solidity of brush stroke yielded to a hatching technique that finally led to virtual abandonment of american genres in favor of single figure studies and studio nudes .	47.899605
the exhibition presents all phases of sloan ' s many-sided art .	7.716929
in addition to the paintings are drawings , prints , and illustrations .	2.5430205
sloan created such works for newspaper supplements before syndication threw him out of a job and sent him to roam the streets of new york , thereby building for america an incomparable city survey from paintings of mcsorley ' s saloon to breezy clotheslines on city roofs .	34.646626
one of the most appealing of the rooftop canvases is `` sun and wind on the roof ' ' , with a woman and child bracing themselves against flapping clothes and flying birds .	25.345299
although there are landscapes in the show ( one of the strongest is a vista of `` gloucester harbor ' ' in 1915 ) , the human element was the compelling factor in sloan ' s art .	22.966948
significant are such canvases as `` bleeker street , saturday night ' ' , with its typically american crowd ( sloan never went abroad )	102.34328
the multifigure `` traveling carnival ' ' , in which action is vivified by lighting	53.72193
or `` carmine theater , 1912 ' ' , the only canvas with an ash can ( and foraging dog ) , although sloan was a member of the famous `` eight ' ' , and of the so-called `` ash-can school ' ' , a term he resented .	34.82722
not all the paintings , however , are of cities .	198.92688
the exhibition touches briefly on his sojourn in the southwest ( `` koshare in the dust ' ' , a vigorous indian dance , and landscapes suggest the influence of western color on his palette ) .	39.518063
the fact that sloan was an extrovert , concerned primarily with what he saw , adds greatly to the value of his art as a human chronicle .	59.39836
there are 151 items in the wilmington show , including one painting by each member of the `` eight ' ' , as well as work by sloan ' s friends and students .	40.564404
supplementing the actual art are memorabilia -- correspondence , diaries , books from the artist ' s library , etc . .	14.407284
all belong to the collection being given to wilmington over a period of years by mrs . sloan , who has cherished such revelatory items ever since she first studied with sloan at the art students league , new york , in the 1920 ' s .	76.52995
to enable students and the public to spot sloan forgeries , the delaware art center ( according to its director , bruce st . john ) will maintain a complete file of photographs of all sloan works , as well as a card index file .	62.07815
the entire sloan collection will be made available at the center to all serious art students and historians .	107.36966
the current exhibition , which remains on view through oct . 29 , has tapped 14 major collections and many private sources .	96.13509
any musician playing beethoven here , where beethoven was born , is likely to examine his own interpretations with special care .	45.663033
in a sense , he is offering bonn what its famous son ( who left as a youth ) never did -- the sound of the composer ' s mature style .	84.78441
robert riefling , who gave the only piano recital of the recently concluded 23rd beethoven festival , penetrated deep into the spirit of the style .	44.327614
his readings were careful without being fussy , and they were authoritative without being presumptuous .	13.640561
the 32 c minor variations with which he opened moved fluently yet logically from one to another , leaving the right impression of abundance under discipline .	91.62914
the d minor sonata , op . 31 no . 2 , introduced by dynamically shaped arpeggios , was most engaging in its moments of quasi-recitative -- single lines in which the fingers seemed to be feeling their way toward the idea to come .	45.865772
these inwardly dramatic moments showed the kind of `` opera style ' ' of which beethoven was genuinely capable , but which did not take so kindly to the mechanics of staging .	33.00439
two late sonatas , op . 110 and 111 , were played with similar insight , the disarming simplicities of the op . 111 adagio made plain without ever becoming obvious .	37.15627
the two were separated from each other by the six bagatelles of op . 126 .	9.769376
herr riefling , in everything he gave his large beethoven hall audience , proved himself as an interpreter of unobtrusive authority .	148.47086
volker wangenheim , who conducted bonn ' s stadtisches orchester on the following evening , made one more conscious of the process of interpretation .	40.45777
herr wangenheim has only recently become the city ' s music director , and is a young man with a clear flair for the podium .	29.762445
but he weighted the eighth symphony , at times , with a shuddering subjectivity which seemed considerably at odds with the music .	40.273712
he might have been hoping , to all appearances , that this relatively sunny symphony , in conjunction with the choral fantasy at the end of the program , could amount to something like the ninth	37.81576
but no amount of head-tossing could make it so .	69.27558
the conductor ' s preoccupation with the business of starting and stopping caused occasional raggedness , as with the first orchestra entrance in the fourth piano concerto , but when he put his deliberations and obsequies aside and let the music move as designed , it did so with plenty of spring .	55.53736
the concerto ' s soloist , hans richter-haaser , played with compensatory ease and economy , though without the consummate plasticity to which we had been treated on the previous evening by herr riefling .	39.94887
his was a burgomaster ' s beethoven , solid and sensible .	54.56048
everybody returned after intermission for the miscellaneous sweepings of the fantasy for piano , chorus , and orchestra in c minor , made up by its composer to fill out one of his programs .	44.60441
the entrance of the stadtisches gesangverein ( bonn ' s civic chorus ) was worth all the waiting , however , as the young rhenish voices finally brought the music to life .	34.172276
the last program of this festival , which during two weeks had sampled most compositional categories , brought the cologne rundfunk-sinfonie-orchester and rundfunkchor to bonn ' s gold-filled hall for a performance of the missa solemnis .	29.518534
a tribe in ancient india believed the earth was a huge tea tray resting on the backs of three giant elephants , which in turn stood on the shell of a great tortoise .	18.40401
but the primitive method of explaining the unknown with what is known bears at least a symbolic resemblance to the methods of modern science .	55.85468
it is the business of cosmologists , the scientists who study the nature and structure of the universe , to try to solve the great cosmic mysteries by using keys that have clicked open other doors .	49.614826
these keys are the working principles of physics , mathematics and astronomy , principles which are then extrapolated , or projected , to explain phenomena of which we have little or no direct knowledge .	35.895714
in the autumn of 1959 , the british broadcasting corporation presented a series of talks by four scientists competent in cosmology .	28.639648
three of these men discussed major theories of the universe while the other acted as a moderator .	47.685818
the participants were professor h . bondi , professor of mathematics at king ' s college , london	19.055708
dr . w . b . bonnor , reader in mathematics at queen elizabeth college , london	68.09085
dr . r . a . lyttleton , a lecturer at st . john ' s college , cambridge , and a reader in theoretical astronomy at the university of cambridge	19.59675
and dr . g . j . whitrow , reader in applied mathematics at the imperial college of science and technology , london .	57.347706
the programs were so well received by the british public that the arguments have been published in a totally engrossing little book called , `` rival theories of cosmology ' ' .	41.360462
dr . bonnor begins with a discussion of the relativistic theories of the universe , based on the general theory of relativity .	21.850834
first of all , and this has been calculated by observation , the universe is expanding -- that is , the galaxies are receding from each other at immense speeds .	28.149328
because of this dr . bonnor holds that the universe is becoming more thinly populated by stars and whatever else is there .	42.93649
this expansion has been going on for an estimated eight billion years .	44.800194
dr . bonnor supports the idea that the universe both expands and contracts , that in several billion years the expansion will slow up and reverse itself and that the contraction will set in .	110.711876
then , after many more billions of years , when all the galaxies are whistling toward a common center , this movement will slow down and reverse itself again .	57.557964
he supports the steady-state theory which holds that matter is continually being created in space .	63.136887
for this reason , he says , the density of the universe always remains the same even though the galaxies are zooming away in all directions .	27.66662
new galaxies are forever being formed to fill in the gaps left by the receding galaxies .	25.443493
if this is true , then the universe today looks just as it did millions of years ago and as it will look millions of years hence , even though the universe is expanding .	86.63305
for new galaxies to be created , professor bondi declares , it would only be necessary for a single hydrogen atom to be created in an area the size of your living room once every few million years .	40.82936
he contends this idea doesn ' t conflict with experiments on which the principle of conservation of matter and energy is based because some slight error must be assumed in such experiments .	113.3128
dr . lyttleton backs the theory that we live in an electric universe and this theory starts with the behavior of protons and electrons .	46.7781
protons and electrons bear opposite electrical charges which make them attract each other , and when they are joined they make up an atom of hydrogen -- the basic building block of matter .	69.65042
the charges of the electron and proton are believed to be exactly equal and opposite , but dr . lyttleton is not so sure .	49.465977
suppose , says dr . lyttleton , the proton has a slightly greater charge than the electron ( so slight it is presently immeasurable ) .	40.842434
this would give the hydrogen atom a slight charge-excess .	2.0205815
now if one hydrogen atom were placed at the surface of a large sphere of hydrogen atoms , it would be subject both to the gravitation of the sphere and the charge-excess of all those atoms in the sphere .	13.2542925
because electrical forces ( the charge-excess ) are far more powerful than gravitation , the surface hydrogen atoms would shoot away from the sphere .	25.857117
dr . lyttleton then imagines the universe as a large hydrogen sphere with surface atoms shooting away from it .	108.07109
this , he claims , would reasonably account for the expansion of the universe .	16.252277
this slim book , while giving the reader only a fleeting glimpse of the scientific mind confronting the universe , has the appeal that informed conversation always has .	84.91829
several photographs and charts of galaxies help the non-scientist keep up with the discussion , and the smooth language indicates the contributors were determined to avoid the jargon that seems to work its way into almost every field .	57.018593
it is clear from this discussion that cosmologists of every persuasion look hopefully toward the day when a man-made satellite can be equipped with optical devices which will open up new vistas to science .	45.09558
presently , the intense absorption of ultra-violet rays in the earth ' s atmosphere seriously hinders ground observation .	33.011074
these scientists are convinced that a telescope unclouded by the earth ' s gases will go a long way toward bolstering or destroying cosmic theories .	18.825132
there would seem to be some small solace in the prospect that the missile race between nations is at the same time accelerating the study of the space around us , giving us a long-sought ladder from which to peer at alien regions .	43.9615
in doing away with the tea tray , the elephants and the giant tortoise , science has developed a series of rationally defensible explanations of the cosmos .	15.05157
and although the universe may forever defy understanding , it might even now be finding its match in the imagination of man .	105.06329
`` roots ' ' , the new play at the brand-new mayfair theater on 46th st . which has been made over from a night club , is about the intellectual and spiritual awakening of an english farm girl .	49.25945
highly successful in england before its transfer to new york , most of `` roots ' ' is as relentlessly dour as the trappings of the small new theater are gaudy .	36.759148
only in its final scene , where beatie bryant ( mary doyle ) shakes off the disappointment of being jilted by her intellectual lover and proclaims her emancipation do we get much which makes worthwhile the series of boorish rustic happenings we have had to watch for most of the first two and one-half acts .	40.890556
the burden of mr . wesker ' s message is that people living close to the soil ( at least in england ) are not the happy , fine , strong , natural , earthy people city-bred intellectuals imagine .	157.24432
rather they are genuine clods , proud of their cloddishness and openly antagonistic to the illuminating influences of aesthetics or thought .	26.194822
they care no more for politics , says mr . wesker , than they do for a symphony .	50.41743
seeming to have roots in the soil , they actually have none in life .	97.73318
they dwell , in short , in the doltish twilight in which peasants and serfs of the past are commonly reported to have lived .	34.910522
but this is a theme which does not take so much time to state as mr . wesker dedicates to it .	60.484806
so much untidiness of mind and household does not attract the interest of the theatergoer ( unless he has been living in a gilded palace , perhaps , and wants a real big heap of contrast ) .	70.61184
the messy meals , the washing of dishes , the drying of clothes may be realism , but there is such a thing as redundancy .	36.02271
miss doyle as beatie has a great fund of animal spirits , a strong voice and a warm smile .	44.226093
she is just home from a sojourn in london where she has become the sweetheart of a young fellow named ronnie ( we never do see him ) and has been subjected to a first course in thinking and appreciating , including a dose of good british socialism .	44.52199
but while she is able to tell her retarded family about the new world she has seen open before her , ronnie has not been able to observe her progress , and instead of appearing at a family party to be looked over like a new bull , he sends beatie a letter of dismissal .	77.77836
beatie , getting no sympathy for her misfortune , soon rallies and finds that although she has lost a lover she has gained her freedom .	46.63187
despite a too long sustained declamatory flight , this final speech is convincing , and we see why british audiences apparently were impressed by `` roots ' ' .	52.49658
there were several fairly good minor portraits in the play , including william hansen ' s impersonation of a stubborn , rather pathetic father , and katherine squire ' s vigorous characterization of a farm mother who brooked no hifalutin ' nonsense from her daughter , or anyone else .	30.09536
but i am afraid mr . wesker ' s meat and potatoes dish isn ' t well seasoned enough for local audiences .	26.016785
shakespeare had a word for everything , even for the rain that disrupted wednesday night ' s `` much ado about nothing ' ' opening the season of free theatre in central park .	77.0433
the new york shakespeare festival , which is using the wollman memorial skating rink while its theatre near the belvedere is being completed , began bravely .	31.042915
joseph papp , impassioned founder of the festival and director of `` much ado ' ' , had a vibrant , colorful production under way .	38.7409
using a wide stage resourcefully he mingled music and dance with shakespeare ' s words in a spirited mixture .	34.283295
the audience filled all the seats inside the wollman enclosure and overflowed onto the lawns outside the fence .	10.352979
the barbed sallies of beatrice and benedick , so contemporary to a public inured to the humor of insult , raised chuckles .	49.220566
the simple-minded comedy of dogberry and verges , also familiar in a day that responds easily to jokes skimmed off the top of writers ' heads , evoked laughter .	84.26307
the vivacity of the masquers ' party at leonato ' s palace , with the spanish motif in the music and dancing in honor of the visiting prince of arragon , cast a spell of delight .	27.745037
as `` much ado ' ' turned serious while the insipid claudio rejected hero at the altar , a sprinkle began to fall .	51.270008
at first hardly a person in the audience moved , although some umbrellas were opened .	63.8342
but the rain came more heavily , and men and women in light summer clothes began to depart .	89.692955
the grieving hero and her father , leonato , followed by the friar , left the stage .	24.471899
a voice on the loudspeaker system announced that if the rain let up the performance would resume in ten minutes .	107.70527
some remained in the wollman enclosure , fortified with raincoats or with newspapers to cover their heads .	37.89738
others huddled under the trees outside the fence .	2.4820914
twenty minutes after the interruption , although it was still raining , the play was resumed at the point in the fourth act where it had been stopped .	41.892815
beatrice ( nan martin ) and benedick ( j . d . cannon ) took their places on the stage .	26.175838
in their very first speeches it was clear that shakespeare , like a nostradamus , had foreseen this moment .	28.613762
said benedick `` lady beatrice , have you wept all this while ' ' ? ?	15.889297
replied beatrice `` yea , and i will weep a while longer ' ' .	56.74297
the heavens refused to give up their weeping .	15.522435
the gallant company completed act 4 , and got through part of act 5 .	185.62787
but the final scenes could not be played .	5.085266
if any among the hardy hundreds who sat in the downpour are in doubt about how it comes out , let them take comfort .	40.289013
the parks department has done an admirable job of preparing the wollman rink for shakespeare .	20.69442
one could hardly blame newbold morris , the parks commissioner , for devoting so much grateful mention to the department ' s technicians who at short notice provided the stage with its rising platforms , its balcony , its generous wings and even its impressive trapdoors for the use of the villains .	52.329086
eldon elder , who designed the stage , also created a gay , spacious set that blended attractively with the park background and shakespeare ' s lighthearted mood .	42.981297
mr . papp has directed a performance that has verve and pace , although he has tolerated obvious business to garner easy laughs where elegance and consistency of style would be preferable .	39.588146
elisabeth schwarzkopf sang so magnificently saturday night at hunter college that it seems a pity to have to register any complaints .	64.422966
still a demurrer or two must be entered .	18.528528
for style and assurance , for a supreme and regal bearing there is still no one who can touch her .	86.82079
if the voice is just a shade less glorious than it used to be , it is still a beautiful instrument , controlled and flexible .	60.448936
put to the service of lieder of schubert , brahms , strauss and wolf in a dramatical and musical way , it made its effect with ease and precision .	22.753557
but what has been happening recently might be described as creeping mannerism .	13.443949
instead of her old confidence in the simplest , purest , most moving musical expression , miss schwarzkopf is letting herself be tempted by the classic sin of artistic pride -- that subtle vanity that sometimes misleads a great artist into thinking that he or she can somehow better the music by bringing to it something extra , some personal dramatic touch imposed from the outside .	99.68788
clever light songs were overly coy , tragic songs a little too melodramatic .	46.838238
there was an extra pause here , a gasp or a sigh there , here and there an extra little twist of a word or note , all in the interest of effect .	56.3821
the result was like that of a beautiful painting with some of the highlights touched up almost to the point of garishness .	44.767113
there were stunning musical phrases too , and sometimes the deepest kind of musical and poetic absorption and communication .	50.653328
miss schwarzkopf and her excellent pianist , john wustman , often achieved the highest lyrical ideals of the lieder tradition .	20.26368
all the more reason why there should have been no place for the frills	24.591515
miss schwarzkopf is too great an artist to need them .	77.21736
the dance , dancers and dance enthusiasts ( 8 , 500 of them ) had a much better time of it at lewisohn stadium on saturday night than all had had two nights earlier , when stadium concerts presented the first of two dance programs .	81.58704
on saturday , the orchestra was sensibly situated down on the field , the stage floor was apparently in decent condition for dancing , and the order of the program improved .	84.50293
there was , additionally , a bonus for the saturday-night patrons .	14.284176
alvin ailey and carmen de lavallade appeared in the first new york performance of mr . ailey ' s `` roots of the blues ' ' , a work given its premiere three weeks ago at the boston arts festival .	21.41354
otherwise , the program included , as on thursday , the taras-tchaikovsky `` design for strings ' ' , the dollar-britten `` divertimento ' ' , the dollar-de banfield `` the duel ' ' and the pas de deux from `` the nutcracker ' ' .	9.225659
maria tallchief and erik bruhn , who danced the `` nutcracker ' ' pas de deux , were also seen in the petipa-minkus pas de deux from `` don quixote ' ' , another brilliant showpiece that displayed their technical prowess handsomely .	22.901186
among the other solo ballet dancers of the evening , elisabeth carroll and ivan allen were particularly impressive in their roles in `` the duel ' ' , a work that depends so much upon the precision and incisiveness of the two principal combatants .	34.54518
mr . ailey ' s `` roots of the blues ' ' , an earthy and very human modern dance work , provided strong contrast to the ballet selections of the evening .	56.03902
as brother john sellers sang five `` blues ' ' to the guitar and drum accompaniments of bruce langhorne and shep shepard , mr . ailey and miss de lavallade went through volatile dances that were by turns insinuating , threatening , contemptuous and ecstatic .	14.907138
their props were two stepladders , a chair and a palm fan .	43.437347
he wore the clothes of a laborer , and she was wondrously seductive in a yellow and orange dress .	18.86516
the cat-like sinuousness and agility of both dancers were exploited in leaps , lifts , crawls and slides that were almost invariably compelling in a work of strong , sometimes almost frightening , tensions .	33.380028
`` roots of the blues ' ' may not be for gentle souls , but others should welcome its super-charged impact .	52.483234
`` perhaps it is better to stay at home .	9.747371
the armchair traveler preserves his illusions ' ' .	1.6495907
this somewhat cynical comment may be found in `` blue skies , brown studies ' ' , a collection of travel essays by william sansom , who would never consider staying home for long .	27.552208
mr . sansom is english , bearded , formidably cultivated , the versatile author of numerous volumes of short stories , of novels and of pieces that are neither short stories nor travel articles but something midway between .	112.80356
the only man alive who seems qualified by his learning , his disposition and his addiction to a baroque luxuriance of language to inherit the literary mantle of sacheverell sitwell , mr . sansom writes of foreign parts with a dedication to decoration worthy of a pastry chef creating a wedding cake for the marriage of a hungarian beauty ( her third ) and an american multimillionaire ( his fourth ) .	34.862854
the result is rather wonderful , but so rich as to be indigestible if taken in too thick slices .	80.73975
there are sixteen essays in `` blue skies , brown studies ' ' .	10.014936
most of them were written between 1953 and 1960 and originally appeared in various magazines .	52.107132
but , even if mr . sansom labors too hard to extract more refinements of meaning and feeling from his travel experiences than the limits of language allow , he still can charm and astound .	142.17104
too many books and articles are just assembled by putting one word after another .	142.808
mr . sansom actually writes his with a nice ear for a gracefully composed sentence , with an intense relish in all the metaphorical resources of english , with a thick shower of sophisticated , cultural references .	30.095505
`` i like to sniff a place , and reproduce what it really smells and looks like , its color , its particular kind of life ' ' .	45.78907
this is an exact description of what mr . sansom does .	23.043703
he only rarely tells a personal anecdote and hardly ever sketches an individual or quotes his opinions .	114.07885
it is an over-all impression mr . sansom strives for , an impression compounded of visual details , of a savory mixture of smells , of much loving attention to architecture and scenery , of lights and shadows , of intangibles of atmosphere and of echoes of the past .	45.978962
william sansom writes only about europe in this book and frequently of such familiar places as london , vienna , the french riviera and the norwegian fjords .	36.58471
but no matter what he writes about he brings to his subject his own original mind and his own sensitive reactions .	84.20512
`` a writer lives , at best , in a state of astonishment ' ' , he says .	14.3070345
`` beneath any feeling he has of the good or the evil of the world lies a deeper one of wonder at it all .	92.1767
to transmit that feeling he writes ' ' .	1.4334548
this may not be true of many writers , but it certainly is true of mr . sansom .	17.204382
so in these pages one can share his wonder at the traditional fiesta of st . torpetius that still persists in st . tropez	19.061607
at the sun and the heat of mediterranean lands , always much brighter and hotter to an englishman than to an american used to summers in new york or kansas city	74.09051
at the supreme delights to be found in one of the world ' s finest restaurants , la bonne auberge , which is situated on the seacoast twenty miles west of the nice airport	10.368979
mr . sansom can be eloquent in a spectacular way which recalls ( to those who recall easily ) the statues of bernini and the gigantic paintings of tintoretto .	30.538012
he can coin a neat phrase `` a street spattered with an invigoration of people ' '	25.756002
tulips with `` petals wide and shaggy as a spaniel ' s ears ' '	5.6335697
after a snowstorm a landscape smelling `` of woodsmoke and clarity ' ' .	5.0517626
and , for all his lacquered , almost byzantine self-consciousness , he can make one recognize the aptness of an unexpected comparison .	22.40625
in one of his best essays mr . sansom expresses his enthusiasm for the many country mansions designed by andrea palladio himself that dot the environs of vicenza .	23.855112
how far that pedimented and pillared style has shed its influence mr . sansom reminds us thus	126.85391
`` the white colonnaded , cedar-roofed southern mansion is directly traceable via the grey and buff stone of grey-skied england to the golden stucco of one particular part of the blue south , the palladian orbit stretching out from vicenza the old mind of andrea palladio still smiles from behind many an old rocking chair on a southern porch , the deep friezes of his architectonic music rise firm above the shallower freeze in the kitchen , his feeling for light and shade brings a glitter from a tall mint julep , his sense of columns framing the warm velvet night has brought together a million couple of mating lips ' ' .	49.9413
`` blue skies , brown studies ' ' is illustrated with numerous excellent photographs .	40.385174
in recent days there have been extensive lamentations over the absence of original drama on television , but not for years have many regretted the passing of new plays on radio .	85.589325
wbai , the listener-supported outlet on the frequency-modulation band , has decided to do what it can to correct this aural void .	41.172363
yesterday it offered `` poised for violence ' ' , by jean reavey .	7.8626184
wbai is on the right track in the sound medium there has been excessive emphasis on music and news and there could and should be a place for theatre , as the canadian and british broadcasting corporations continue to demonstrate .	116.60659
unfortunately , `` poised for violence ' ' was not the happiest vehicle with which to make the point .	93.04999
mrs . reavey ' s work is written for the stage -- it is mentioned for an off-broadway production in the fall -- and , in addition , employs an avant-garde structure that particularly needs to be seen if comprehension is to be encouraged .	51.552303
the play ' s device is to explore society ' s obsession with disaster and violence through the eyes of a group of artist ' s models who remain part of someone else ' s painting rather than just be themselves .	89.49592
in a succession of scenes they appear in different guises -- patrons of a cafe , performers in a circus and participants in a family picnic -- but in each instance they inevitably put ugliness before beauty .	44.912563
somewhere in mrs . reavey ' s play there is both protest and aspiration of merit .	60.38956
but its relentless discursiveness and determined complexity are so overwhelming that after an hour and a half a listener ' s stamina begins to wilt .	65.95036
moreover , her central figures are so busily fulfilling their multitudinous assignments that none emerges as an arresting individual in his own right or as a provocative symbol of mankind ' s ills .	22.560019
but quite conceivably an altogether different impression will obtain when the work is offered in the theatre and there can be other effects to relieve the burden on the author ' s words .	58.00569
which in itself is an immediate reward of the wbai experiment	58.211178
good radio drama has its own special demands that badly need reinvigoration .	101.01198
a weekly showcase for contemporary music , from the austere archaism of stravinsky to the bleeps and bloops of electronic music , is celebrating its fourth anniversary this month .	14.09753
titled `` what ' s new in music ' ' ? ?	4.0031095
the enterprising program is heard saturday afternoons on radio station aj .	98.33325
the brief notes introducing each work offer salient historical or technical points , and many listeners are probably grateful for being intelligently taken by the hand through an often difficult maze .	119.26202
the show is programed and written by the station ' s assistant continuity editor , chuck briefer .	60.08885
the first saturday in each month is set aside for new recordings .	18.69295
last saturday ' s interesting melange included ernst toch , karlheinz stockhausen , richard yardumian and a brief excerpt from a new `` space ' ' opera by the swedish composer , karl-birger blomdahl .	14.96032
other saturdays are devoted to studies of a selected american composer , a particular type of music or the music of a given country .	57.663155
it is commendable that a regularly scheduled hour is set aside for an introduction to the contemporary musical scene .	34.387356
but one wishes , when the appetite is whetted , as it was in the case of the all-too-brief excerpt from the blomdahl opera , that further opportunity would be provided both for hearing the works in their entirety and for a closer analytical look at the sense and nature of the compositions .	53.180367
the moiseyev dance company dropped in at madison square garden last night for the first of four farewell performances before it brings its long american tour to a close .	54.396587
it is not simply giving a repetition of the program it gave during its new york engagement earlier this season , but has brought back many of the numbers that were on the bill when it paid us its first visit and won everybody ' s heart .	124.804596
it is good to see those numbers again .	10.773355
the `` suite of old russian dances ' ' that opened that inaugural program with the slow and modest entrance of the maidens and built steadily into typical moiseyev vigor and warmth	44.47664
the amusing `` yurochka ' ' , in which a hard-to-please young man is given his come-uppance	26.08191
the lovely ( and of course vigorous ) `` polyanka ' ' or `` the meadow ' '	6.666267
the three moldavian dances entitled `` zhok ' '	1.0848429
the sweet and funny little dance about potato planting called `` bul ' ba ' '	3.3225138
and the hilarious picture of social life in an earlier day called `` city quadrille ' ' are all just as good as one remembers them to have been , and they are welcome back .	73.31883
so , for that matter , are the newer dances -- the `` kalmuk dance ' ' with its animal movements , that genial juggling act by sergei tsvetkov called `` the platter ' ' , the rousing and beautiful betrothal celebration called `` summer ' ' , `` the three shepherds ' ' of azerbaijan hopping up on their staffs , and , of course , the trenchant `` rock ' n ' roll ' ' .	20.657585
as autumn starts its annual sweep , few americans and canadians realize how fortunate they are in having the world ' s finest fall coloring .	56.338345
spectacular displays of this sort are relatively rare in the entire land surface of the earth .	49.021767
the only other regions so blessed are the british isles , western europe , eastern china , southern chile and parts of japan , new zealand and tasmania .	22.504969
their autumn tints are all fairly low keyed compared with the fiery stabs of crimson , gold , purple , bronze , blue and vermilion that flame up in north america .	15.093508
jack frost is not really responsible for this great seasonal spectacle	33.812107
in fact , a freezing autumn dulls the blaze .	20.991137
the best effects come from a combination of temperate climate and plenty of late-summer rain , followed by sunny days and cool nights .	22.819973
foliage pilgrimages , either organized or individual , are becoming an autumn item for more and more americans each year .	151.49428
below is a specific guide , keyed to the calendar .	10.0293455
late september finds quebec ' s color at its peak , especially in the laurentian hills and in the area south of the st . lawrence river .	22.415981
in the maritime provinces farther east , the tones are a little quieter .	21.430145
ontario ' s foliage is most vivid from about sept . 23 to oct . 10 , with both muskoka ( 100 miles north of toronto ) and haliburton ( 125 miles northwest of toronto ) holding color cavalcades starting sept . 23 .	18.843157
in the canadian rockies , great groves of aspen are already glinting gold .	17.93878
vermont ' s sugar maples are scarlet from sept . 25 to oct . 15 , and often hit a height in early october .	30.070837
new hampshire figures its peak around columbus day and boasts of all its hardwoods including the yellow of the birches .	23.761963
the shades tend to be a little softer in the forests that blanket so much of maine .	101.509026
in western massachusetts and northwest connecticut , the berkshires are at their vibrant prime the first week of october .	32.57394
the adirondacks blaze brightest in early october , choice routes being 9n from saratoga up to lake george and 73 and 86 in the lake placid area .	17.670511
farther south in new york there is a heavy haze of color over the catskills in mid-october , notably along routes 23 and 23a .	23.10404
about the same time the alleghenies and poconos in pennsylvania are magnificent -- renovo holds its annual flaming foliage festival on oct . 14 , 15 .	20.723452
new jersey ' s color varies from staccato to pastel all the way from the delaware water gap to cape may .	42.741917
during the first half of october the blue ridge and other parts of the appalachians provide a spectacle stretching from maryland and west virginia to georgia .	34.829655
the most brilliant displays are along the skyline drive above virginia ' s shenandoah valley and throughout the great smokies between north carolina and tennessee .	33.083378
michigan , wisconsin and minnesota have many superb stretches of color which reach their height from the last few days of september well into october , especially in their northern sections , e . g . , wisconsin ' s vilas county whose colorama celebration is sept . 29-oct . 8 .	37.965023
in wisconsin , take route 55 north of shawano or routes 78 and 60 from portage to prairie du chien .	15.574184
in michigan , there is fine color on route 27 up to the mackinac straits , while the views around marquette and iron mountain in the upper peninsula are spectacular .	39.219944
in minnesota , arrowhead county and route 53 north to international falls are outstanding .	133.79126
farther south , there are attractive patches all the way to the ozarks , with some seasonal peaks as late as early november .	16.607168
illinois ' shawnee national forest , missouri ' s iron county and the maples of hiawatha , kan . should be at their best in mid-october .	20.745796
the rockies have many `` aspencades ' ' , which are organized tours of the aspen areas with frequent stops at vantage points for viewing the golden panoramas .	29.005404
in colorado , ouray has its fall color week sept . 22-29 , rye and salida both sponsor aspencades sept . 24 , and steamboat springs has a week-long aspencade sept . 25-30 .	15.478395
new mexico ' s biggest is at ruidoso oct . 7 , 8 , while alamogordo and cloudcroft cooperate in similar trips oct . 1 .	15.907479
two sharply contrasting places designed for public enjoyment are now on display .	80.981125
the corn palace at mitchell , s . dak . , `` the world ' s corniest building ' ' , has a carnival through sept . 23 headlining the three stooges and pee wee hunt .	14.521248
since 1892 ears of red , yellow , purple and white corn have annually been nailed to 11 big picture panels to create huge `` paintings ' ' .	72.706085
the 1961 theme is the dakota territorial centennial , with the pictures including the lewis and clark expedition , the first river steamboat , the 1876 gold rush , a little red schoolhouse on the prairie , and today ' s construction of large missouri river reservoirs .	63.23803
the panels will stay up until they are replaced next summer .	45.794518
longwood gardens , near kennett square , pa . ( about 12 miles from wilmington , del . ) , was developed and heavily endowed by the late pierre s . du pont .	31.923258
every wednesday night through oct . 11 there will be an elaborate colored fountain display , with 229 nozzles throwing jets of water up to 130 feet .	20.979124
the `` peacock tail ' ' nozzle throws a giant fan of water 100 feet wide and 40 feet high .	34.430565
the gardens themselves are open free of charge the year round , and the 192 permanent employes make sure that not a dead or wilted flower is ever seen indoors or out by any visitor .	86.01975
carson mccullers , after a long , painful illness that might have crushed a less-indomitable soul , has come back with an absolute gem of a novel which jumped high on best-seller lists even before official publication .	65.67192
though the subject -- segregation in her native south -- has been thoroughly worked , miss mccullers uses her poet ' s instinct and storyteller ' s skill to reaffirm her place at the very top of modern american writing .	36.678658
with an art that almost conceals art , j . d . salinger can create a fictional world so authentic that it hurts .	23.223839
here , in the most eagerly awaited novel of the season ( his first since the catcher in the rye , ) he tells of a college girl in flight from the life around her and the tart but sympathetic help she gets from her 25-year-old brother .	100.772644
a deft , hilarious satire on very high french society involving a statesman with two enviable possessions , a lovely young bride and a head containing such weighty thoughts that he has occasionally to remove it for greater comfort .	49.27042
there is probably a moral in all this about `` mind vs . heart ' ' .	98.77664
virgilia peterson , a critic by trade , has turned her critical eye pitilessly and honestly on herself in an autobiography more of the mind and heart than of specific events .	90.71488
it is an engrossing commentary on a repressive , upper-middle-class new york way of life in the first part of this century .	28.706568
this retelling by louis zara of the brief , anguished life of stephen crane -- poet and master novelist at 23 , dead at 28 -- is in novelized form but does not abuse its tragic subject .	70.69388
subtitled a farmwife ' s almanac of country living , this is a gentle and nostalgic chronicle of the changing seasons seen through the clear , humorous eye of a hoosier housewife and popular columnist .	32.993458
two noted troupes from overseas will get the fall dance season off to a sparkling start .	58.21073
leningrad ' s kirov ballet , famous for classic purity of technique , begins its first u . s . tour in new york ( through sept . 30 ) .	18.542164
the bayanihan philippine dance company , with music and dances that depict the many facets of filipino culture , opens its 60-city u . s . tour in san francisco ( through sept . 24 ) then , via one-night stands , moves on to los angeles ( sept . 29 thru oct . 1 ) .	17.815104
with harvests in full swing , you can enjoy festivals for grapes at sonoma , calif . ( sept . 22-24 ) , as well as for cranberries at bandon , ore . ( sept . 28 thru oct . 1 ) , for buckwheat at kingwood , w . va . ( sept . 28-30 ) , sugar cane at new iberia , la . ( sept . 29 thru oct . 1 ) and tobacco at richmond , va . ( sept . 23-30 ) .	8.728744
the mule is honored at benson , n . c . ( sept . 22 , 23 ) and at boron , calif . ( sept . 24 thru oct . 1 ) , while the legend of the maid of the mist is celebrated at niagara falls through the 24th .	8.306816
the fine old mansions of u . s . grant ' s old home town of galena , ill . are open for inspection ( sept . 23 , 24 ) .	31.50414
an archery tournament will be held at north falmouth , mass . ( sept . 23 , 24 ) .	8.113528
the 300th anniversaries of staten island ( through sept . 23 ) and of mamaroneck , n . y . ( through sept . 24 ) will both include parades and pageants .	14.236668
this french film , set in italy , is a summertime splurge in shock and terror all shot in lovely sunny scenery -- so breath-taking that at times you almost forget the horrors the movie is dealing with .	73.80869
but slowly they take over as alain delon ( life , sept . 15 ) , playing a sometimes appealing but always criminal boy , casually tells a rich and foot-loose american that he is going to murder him , then does it even while the american is trying to puzzle out how delon expects to profit from the act .	92.889946
callas devotees will have good reason to do their customary cart wheels over a new and complete stereo version of the bellini opera .	36.69327
maria goes all out as a druid princess who gets two-timed by a roman big shot .	93.726814
by turns , her beautifully sung norma is fierce , tender , venomous and pitiful .	3.0556314
the tenor lead , franco corelli , and la scala cast under maestro tullio serafin are all first rate .	75.28877
jeremiah peabody ' s polyunsaturated quick dissolving fast acting pleasant tasting green and purple pills .	39.83772
in a raucous take-off on radio commercials , singer ray stevens hawks a cure-all for neuritis , neuralgia , head-cold distress , beriberi , overweight , fungus , mungus and water on the knee .	14.143414
of the nation ' s eight million pleasure-boat owners a sizable number have learned that late autumn is one of the loveliest seasons to be afloat -- at least in that broad balmy region that lies below america ' s belt line .	70.611
waterways are busy right now from the virginia capes to the texas coast .	10.050982
there true yachtsmen often find november winds steadier , the waters cooler , the fish hungrier , and rivers more pleasant -- less turbulence and mud , and fewer floating logs .	17.981106
more and more boats move overland on wheels ( 1 . 8 million trailers are now in use ) and midwesterners taking long weekends can travel south with their craft .	102.52132
in the southwest , the fall brings out flotillas of boatsmen who find the summer too hot for comfort .	67.06557
and on northern shores indomitable sailors from long island to lake michigan will beat around the buoys in dozens of frostbite races .	16.382042
some pleasant fall cruising country is mapped out below .	40.551533
pleasure boating is just scooting into its best months in california as crisp breezes bring out craft of every size on every kind of water -- ocean , lake and reservoir .	110.18122
shore facilities are enormous -- los angeles harbors 5 , 000 boats , and long beach 3 , 000 -- but marinas are crowded everywhere .	46.42155
new docks and ramps are being rushed at playa del rey , ventura , dana point , oceanside and mission bay .	11.203483
inland , outboard motorists welcome cooler weather and the chance to buzz over colorado river sandbars and lake mead .	17.400297
newest small-boat playground is the salton sea , a once-dry desert sinkhole which is now a salty lake 42 miles long and 235 feet below sea level .	27.350607
on nov . 11 , 12 , racers will drive their flying shingles in 5-mile laps over its 500-mile speedboat course .	33.29953
in san francisco bay , winds are gusty and undependable during this season .	17.397165
a sailboat may have a bone in her teeth one minute and lie becalmed the next .	74.43687
but regattas are scheduled right up to christmas .	5.405542
the corinthian yacht club in tiburon launches its winter races nov . 5 .	18.350508
hurricane carla damaged 70% of the marinas in the galveston-port aransas area but fuel service is back to normal , and explorers can roam as far west as port isabel on the mexican border .	63.3375
sailing activity is slowed down by texas northers , but power cruisers can move freely , poking into the san jacinto , trinity and brazos rivers ( fine tarpon fishing in the brazos ) or pushing eastward to the pirate country of barataria .	15.691717
off grand isle , yachters often visit the towering oil rigs .	20.921667
the mississippi sound leads into a protected waterway running about 200 miles from pascagoula to apalachicola .	30.43181
memphis stinkpotters like mckellar lake , inside the city limits , and sailors look for autumn winds at arkabutla lake where fall racing is now in progress .	64.458084
river cruising for small craft is ideal in november .	31.055841
at new orleans , 25-mile-square lake pontchartrain has few squalls and year-long boating .	20.808296
marinas are less plush than the florida type but service is good and creole cooking better .	105.23472
ten thousand twisty miles of shoreline frame the 30-odd lakes in the vast tennessee river system that loops in and out of seven states .	26.703924
when dam construction began in 1933 , fewer than 600 boats used these waters	265.1306
a year ago it was bruited that the primary character in erich maria remarque ' s new novel was based on the marquis alfonso de portago , the spanish nobleman who died driving in the mille miglia automobile race of 1957 .	14.695176
if this was in fact mr . remarque ' s intention he has achieved a notable failure .	17.70284
clerfayt of `` heaven has no favorites ' ' resembles portago only in that he is male and a race-driver -- quite a bad race-driver , whereas portago was a good one .	49.735016
he is a dull , unformed , and aimless person	52.335102
the twelfth marquis de portago was intelligent , purposeful , and passionate .	3.3377569
one looked forward to mr . remarque ' s ninth book if only because not even a reasonably good novel has yet been written grounded on automobile racing , as dramatic a sport as mankind has devised .	119.68023
unhappily , `` heaven has no favorites ' ' does not alter the record except to add one more bad book to the list .	139.85246
mr . remarque ' s conception of this novel was sound and perhaps even noble .	221.98564
he proposed throwing together a man in an occupation of high hazard and a woman balanced on a knife-edge between death from tuberculosis and recovery .	50.097153
his heroine chooses to die -- the price of recovery , years under the strict regimen of a sanatorium , being higher than she wishes to pay .	35.48193
her lover precedes her in death , at the wheel , and presumably he too has chosen .	112.02231
between the first meeting of clerfayt and lillian and this dismal denouement , mr . remarque has laid down many pages of junior-philosophical discourse , some demure and rather fetching love-making , pleasant talk about some of the countryside and restaurants of europe , and a modicum of automobile racing .	23.315836
the ramblings on life , death , and the wonder of it all are distressing	55.35567
the love-making , perhaps because it is pale and low-key when one has been conditioned to expect harsh colors and explicitness , is often charming	38.306034
the automobile racing bears little relation to reality .	4.359718
this latter failure is more than merely bad reportage and it is distinctly more important than it would have been had the author drawn clerfayt as , say , a tournament golfer .	55.099358
hazards to life and limb on the golf course , while existent , are actuarially insignificant .	22.799612
race-drivers , on the other hand , are quite often killed on the circuit , and since it was obviously mr . remarque ' s intention to establish automobile racing as life in microcosm , one might reasonably have expected him to demonstrate precise knowledge not only of techniques but of mores and attitudes .	61.472412
the jacket biography describes him as a former racing driver , and he may indeed have been , although i do not recall having encountered his name either in the records or the literature .	85.190056
perhaps he has only forgotten a great deal .	5.484327
the book carries a disclaimer in which remarque says it has been necessary for him to take minor liberties with some of the procedures and formalities of racing .	49.130253
the necessity is not clear to me , and , in any case , to present a case-hardened race-driver as saying he has left his car , which , or whom , he calls `` giuseppe ' ' , parked `` on the place vendome sneering at a dozen bentleys and rolls-royces parked around him ' ' is not a liberty	42.693306
but it is in the matter of preoccupation with death , which is the primary concern of the book , that remarque ' s failure is plainest .	27.028282
clerfayt is neurotic , preoccupied , and passive .	2.7435815
to be human , he believes , is to seek one ' s own destruction the freudian `` death-wish ' ' cliche inevitably cited whenever laymen talk about auto race-drivers .	110.60245
in point of fact , the race-drivers one knows are nearly always intelligent , healthy technicians who differ from other technicians only in the depth of the passion they feel for the work by which they live .	82.09268
a clerfayt may moon on about the face of death in the cockpit	50.432793
a portago could say , as he did say to me , `` if i die tomorrow , still i have had twenty-eight wonderful years	60.44908
i ' ll live to be 105 ' ' .	1.2641298
clerfayt , transported , may think of the engine driving his car as `` a mystical beast under the hood ' ' .	25.11156
the italian master piero taruffi , no less sensitive , knows twice the ecstasy though he thinks of a car ' s adhesion to a wet two-lane road at 165 miles an hour as a matter best expressed in algebraic formulae .	31.196375
clerfayt , driving , sees himself `` a volcano whose cone funneled down to hell ' '	15.222441
the briton stirling moss , one of the greatest virtuosi of all time , believes that ultra-fast road-circuit driving is an art form related to ballet .	73.534615
errors in technical terminology suggest that the over-all translation from the german may not convey quite everything mr . remarque hoped to tell us .	136.12846
however , my principal objection in this sort of novel is to the hackneyed treatment of race-drivers , pilots , submariners , atomic researchers , and all the machine-masters of our age as brooding mystics or hysterical fatalists .	19.28378
the west is leaderless , according to this book .	85.50966
in contrast , the east is ably led by such stalwart heroes as khrushchev , tito , and mao .	8.17075
against this invincible determination to communize the whole world stands a group of nations unable to agree on fundamentals and each refusing to make any sacrifice of sovereignty for the common good of all .	67.25763
it is field marshal montgomery ' s belief that in most western countries about 60 per cent of the people do not really care about democracy or christianity	46.762775
about 30 per cent call themselves christians in order to keep up appearances and be considered respectable , and only the last 10 per cent are genuine christians and believers in democracy .	55.60019
but these western countries do care about themselves .	2.7633882
if , say , the russians intended to stop tom jones ' going to the pub , then tom jones would fight the commies .	45.62065
but he would fight for his own liberty rather than for any abstract principle connected with it -- such as `` cause ' ' .	97.35656
for all practical purposes , the west stands disunited , undedicated , and unprepared for the tasks of world leadership .	11.6134615
with this barrage , montgomery of alamein launches his attack upon the blunderings of the west .	7.4733973
never given to mincing words , he places heavy blame upon the faulty , uncourageous leadership of britain and particularly america .	146.94319
at war ' s end leadership in western europe passed from britain because the labour government devoted its attention to the creation of a welfare state .	63.250004
with britain looking inward , overseas problems were neglected and the baton was passed on to the united states .	43.228573
`` america gave generously in economic aid and military equipment to friend and foe alike ' ' .	65.08472
she pushed wartorn and poverty-stricken nations into prosperity , but she failed to lead them into unity and world peace .	36.842957
america has divided more than she has united the west .	85.004456
the reasons are that america generally believes that she can buy anything with dollars , and that she compulsively strives to be liked .	34.08222
however , she really does not know how to match the quantity of dollars given away by a quality of leadership that is basically needed .	216.15395
but the greater reason for fumbling , stumbling american leadership is due to the shock her pride suffered when the japanese attacked at pearl harbor .	102.98678
`` they are determined ' ' , montgomery writes , `` not to be surprised again , and now insist on a state of readiness for war which is not only unnecessary , but also creates nervousness among other nations in the western alliance -- not to mention such great suspicions among the nations of the eastern bloc that any progress towards peaceful coexistence or disarmament is not possible ' ' .	38.194683
the net result is that under american leadership the general world situation has become bad .	133.65231
to `` monty ' ' , the american people , who in two previous world wars were very reluctant to join the fight , `` now look like the nation most likely to lead us all into a third world war ' ' .	48.738575
as faulty as has been our leadership clearly the united states must be relied upon to lead .	24.05776
montgomery calls for a leader who will first put the west ' s own house in order .	53.144005
such a man must be able and willing to give clear and sensible advice to the whole group , a person in whom all the member nations will have absolute confidence .	76.20914
this leader must be a man who lives above illusions that heretofore have shaped the foreign policy of the united states , namely that russia will agree to a reunited germany , that the east german government does not exist , that events in japan in june 1960 were communist-inspired , that the true government of china is in formosa , that mao was the evil influence behind khrushchev at the summit conference in paris in may 1960 , and that either china or russia wants or expects war .	60.894405
such a leader must strengthen nato politically , and establish that true unity about which it has always talked .	89.402985
after drastically overhauling nato , western leadership should turn to reducing the suspicions that tear apart the east and west .	21.53073
major to this effort is to get all world powers to withdraw to their own territories , say by 1970 .	40.17828
but the east would have to show sincerity in carrying it out ' ' .	37.801563
`` but where is the leader who will handle all these things for us ' ' ? ?	18.439833
montgomery knew all the national leaders up to the time of kennedy .	60.469177
the man whom he would select as our leader for this great task is de gaulle .	47.899006
he alone has the wisdom , the conviction , the tenacity , and the courage to reach a decision .	18.81157
but de gaulle is buried in the cause of restoring france ' s lost soul .	24.824375
whoever rises to the occasion walks a treacherous path to leadership .	110.708336
the leader montgomery envisages will need to discipline himself , lead a carefully regulated and orderly life , allow time for quiet thought and reflection , adapt decisions and plans to changing situations , be ruthless , particularly with inefficiency , and be honest and morally proper .	83.15265
all in all , montgomery calls for a leader who will anticipate and dominate the events that surround him .	69.67318
in looking as far back as moses , thence to cromwell , napoleon , lincoln , churchill , and nehru , montgomery attempts to trace the stirrings and qualities of great men .	26.722303
he believes that greatness is a marriage between the man and the times as was aptly represented by churchill , who would very possibly have gone down in history as a political failure if it had not been for hitler ' s war .	52.248493
however , montgomery makes little contribution to leadership theory and practice .	123.39377
most of what is said about his great men of history has already been said , and what has not is largely irrelevant to the contemporary scene .	54.146957
like eisenhower , he holds the militarist ' s suspicion of politicians .	24.47832
however , at the same time montgomery selects as his hero de gaulle , who is a militarist dominated by political ambitions .	24.159573
`` monty ' ' shows a remarkable capacity for the direct statement and an equally remarkable incapacity for giving adequate support .	54.969357
for the most part , his writing rambles and jogs , preventing easy access by the reader to his true thoughts .	42.116592
nevertheless , montgomery has stated courageously and wisely the crisis of the western world .	12.008469
it suffers from a lack of unity of purpose and respect for heroic leadership .	91.08739
and it remains to be seen if the new frontier now taking form can produce the leadership and wisdom necessary to understand the current shape of events .	171.02512
it is no common thing for a listener ( critical or otherwise ) to hear a singer `` live ' ' for the first time only after he has died .	61.701145
but then , mario lanza was no common singer , and his whole career , public and non-public , was studded with the kind of unconventional happenings that terminate with the appearance of his first `` recital ' ' only when he has ceased to be a living voice .	36.19968
it is a kind of justice , too , that it should originate in london ' s royal albert hall , where , traditionally , the loudest , if not the greatest , performers have entertained the thousands it will accommodate ( rca victor lm 2454 , $4 . 98 ) .	47.75772
to be sure , lanza made numerous concert tours , here and abroad , but these did not take him to new york where the carping critic might lurk .	37.019726
the reading public , the theatergoing public , the skindiving public , the horse-playing public -- all these and others fill substantial roles in u . s . life , but none is so varied , vast and vigilant as the eating public .	77.27217
the department of agriculture averaged out u . s . food consumption last year at 1 , 488 lbs . per person , which , allowing for the 17 million americans that john kennedy said go to bed hungry every night , means that certain gluttons on the upper end must somehow down 8 lbs . or more a day .	71.16776
that mother hen of the weight-height tables , the metropolitan life insurance co . , clucks that 48 million americans are overweight .	43.526524
through previous centuries , eating changed by nearly imperceptible degrees , and mostly toward just getting enough .	79.904465
for the first time in history , the u . s . has produced a society in which less than one-tenth of the people turn out so much food that the government ' s most embarrassing problem is how to dispose inconspicuously of 100 million tons of surplus farm produce .	39.270515
in this same society , the plain citizen can with an average of only one-fifth his income buy more calories than he can consume .	83.09264
refrigeration , automated processing and packaging conspire to defy season and banish spoilage .	16.751982
and in the wake of the new affluence and the new techniques of processing comes a new american interest in how what people eat affects their health .	56.6413
to eat is human , the nation is learning to think , to survive divine .	105.441605
not all the concern for health is well directed .	144.21179
from the fusty panaceas of spinach , eggs and prunes , the u . s . has progressed to curds , concentrates and capsules .	6.9542303
each year , reports the american medical association , ten million americans spend $900 million on vitamins , tonics and other food supplements .	18.26051
at juice bars in los angeles ' 35 `` health ' ' stores , a new sensation is a pink , high-protein cocktail , concocted of dried eggs , powdered milk and cherry-flavored no-cal , which sells for 59-cents per 8-oz . glass .	20.325512
grocery stores sell dozens of foods that boast of having almost no food value at all .	83.43497
but a big part of the public wants to know facts about diet and health , and a big group of u . s . scientists wants to supply them .	56.71589
the man most firmly at grips with the problem is the university of minnesota ' s physiologist ancel keys , 57 , inventor of the wartime k ( for keys ) ration and author of last year ' s bestselling eat well and stay well .	50.59631
from his birch-paneled office in the laboratory of physiological hygiene , under the university ' s football stadium in minneapolis ( `` we get a rumble on every touchdown ' ' ) , blocky , grey-haired dr . keys directs an ambitious , $200 , 000-a-year experiment on diet , which spans three continents and seven nations and is still growing .	40.84368
