such a decision should have placed a powerful weapon in the hands of the entire housing industry , but there is little evidence that realtors , or at least their associations , have repudiated the principle in such clauses .	31.234545
in the states that have passed laws preventing discrimination in the sale or rental of housing , support by real estate associations for compliance and broadened coverage through additional legislation could help remove the label of `` social reformism ' ' that most realtors individually seem determined to avoid .	43.851826
but as yet , no real estate board has been willing officially to support such laws or to admit the permissibility of introducing minority buyers into all-white neighborhoods .	39.86902
one of the roles of the social scientist , ethicist or theologian in our discussions with the realtors became that of encouraging greater awareness of the opportunities offered by the legal and political processes for the exercise of broad social responsibilities in their work .	66.70314
but responsiveness to these opportunities presumes that all of us judge the good as a human good and not simply as a professional , white , american good .	164.60136
such judgments are meaningful only in so far as persons are members of a world , let us say a community , that embraces scarsdale or yonkers , but is also infinitely richer since it is all-inclusive .	35.674263
that community of all creation is , then , the ultimate object of our loyalty and the concrete norm of all moral judgment .	49.378063
racial discrimination is wrong , then , not because it goes against the grain of a faculty member trying to converse with a few realtors but because it goes against the grain of creation and against the will of the creator .	55.173264
thus , moral issues concerning the nature of the legal and political processes take on theological dimensions .	50.87164
( 3 ) over the years , individuals engaged in the sale of real estate have developed remarkable unity in the methods and practices employed .	48.274376
most realtors and real estate brokers talk of themselves as `` professional people ' ' with the cultural and moral values held by the traditional professions .	45.832478
but what significance attaches to `` professional ' ' , beyond the narrow sense of skillfulness in meeting a client ' s stated needs as already noted ? ?	75.85945
our faculty and students pressed this issue more than any other .	22.21818
as a theologian in the group pointed out , a professional was , before the modern period of technical specialization , one who `` professed ' ' to be a bearer and critic of his culture in the use of his particular skills .	41.22289
if we look about the world today , we can see clearly that there are two especially significant factors shaping the future of our civilization science and religion .	56.28459
science is placing in our hands the ultimate power of the universe , the power of the atom .	15.678121
religion , or the lack of it , will decide whether we use this power to build a brave new world of peace and abundance for all mankind , or whether we misuse this power to leave a world utterly destroyed .	62.358215
how can we have the wisdom to meet such a new and difficult challenge ? ?	77.167854
and yet there is a note of hope , because this same science that is giving us the power of the atom is also giving us atomic vision .	102.23426
we are looking inside the atom and seeing there a universe which is not material but something beyond the material , a universe that in a word is not matter but music .	121.11356
and it is in this new vision of the atom that we find an affirmation and an invigoration of our faith .	24.224651
to see this vision in perspective , we need first of all a clear idea of the magnitude of this new power from the atom .	59.784267
you know that i could hold right here in my hand the little chunk of uranium metal that was the heart of the bomb that dropped on hiroshima .	26.672834
it was only about the size of a baseball	999.21124
but packed in that metallic ball there was the explosive force of 20 , 000 tons of aj .	27.861704
that is enough tnt to fill the tower of the empire state building	84.314606
and with the availability of bombs of that size , war became a new problem .	168.15674
now we might have restricted the use of uranium bombs by controlling the sources of uranium because it is found in only a few places in the world .	22.25127
but we had hardly started to adjust our thinking to this new uranium weapon when we were faced with the hydrogen bomb .	48.819145
hydrogen is just as plentiful as uranium is scarce .	5.7192545
water is af and the h stands for hydrogen	6.086191
there is also hydrogen in wood and hydrogen in our bodies .	17.157564
i have calculated that if i could snap my fingers in one magic gesture to release the power of all the hydrogen in my body , i would explode with the force of a hundred bombs of the kind that fell on hiroshima .	49.591694
i won ' t try the experiment , but i think you can see that if we all knew the secret and we could all let ourselves go , there would be quite an explosion .	76.97679
and then think how little hydrogen we have in us compared with the hydrogen in delaware bay or in the ocean beyond .	91.25028
salt water is still af , the same hydrogen is there .	81.11596
and the size of the ocean shows us the magnitude of the destructive power we hold in our hands today .	61.964825
of course , there is also an optimistic side to the picture .	64.59196
for if i knew the secret of letting this power in my body change directly into electricity , i could rent myself out to the electric companies and with just the power in my body i could light all the lights and run all the factories in the entire united states for some days .	85.265686
and think , if we all knew this secret and we could pool our power , what a wonderful public utility company we would make .	121.6599
with just the hydrogen of our bodies , we could run the world for years .	60.616665
then think of delaware bay and the ocean and you see that we have a supply of power for millions of years to come .	46.166348
it is power with which we can literally rebuild the world , provide adequate housing , food , education , abundant living for everyone everywhere .	51.02362
now let us see where this power comes from .	403.7244
to grasp our new view of the atom , we have to appreciate first of all how small the atom is .	101.652695
i have been trying to make this clear to my own class in chemistry .	74.32684
one night there were some dried peas lying on our kitchen table , and these peas looked to me like a little group of atoms	79.427155
and i asked myself a question suppose i had the same number of peas as there are atoms in my body , how large an area would they cover ? ?	82.70026
i calculated first that there are about an octillion atoms in the average human body	51.45353
that is a figure one with 27 ciphers , quite a large number .	90.905365
then i calculated that a million peas would just about fill a household refrigerator	96.63587
a billion peas would fill a small house from cellar to attic	47.225094
a trillion peas would fill all the houses in a town of about ten thousand people	34.72009
and a quadrillion peas would fill all the buildings in the city of philadelphia .	21.282145
i saw that i would soon run out of buildings at this rate , so i decided to take another measure -- the whole state of pennsylvania .	70.24917
imagine that there is a blizzard over pennsylvania , but instead of snowing snow , it snows peas	31.438591
so we get the whole state covered with peas , about four feet deep .	35.43482
you can imagine what it would look like going out on the turnpike with the peas banked up against the houses and covering the cars	46.193443
pennsylvania thus blanketed would contain about a quintillion peas .	7.3131466
but we still have a long way to go .	36.205013
next we imagine our blizzard raging over all the land areas of the entire globe -- north america , south america , europe , asia , and africa , all covered with peas four feet deep	39.444057
next we freeze over the oceans and cover the whole earth with peas , then we go out among the neighboring stars , collect 250 planets each the size of the earth , and also cover each of these with peas four feet deep	65.68545
finally we go into the farthest reaches of the milky way	37.57725
we cover each of these with our blanket of peas and then at last we have octillion peas corresponding in number to the atoms in the body .	52.66844
so you see how small an atom is and how complicated you are .	343.7904
now although an atom is small , we can still in imagination have a look at it .	95.047035
let us focus on an atom of calcium from the tip of the bone of my finger and let us suppose that i swallow a magic alice in wonderland growing pill .	26.49799
i start growing rapidly and this calcium atom grows along with me .	60.150223
i shoot up through the roof , into the sky , past the clouds , through the stratosphere , out beyond the moon , out among the planets , until i am over a hundred and fifty million miles long .	39.76245
then this atom of calcium will swell to something like a great balloon a hundred yards across , a balloon big enough to put a football field inside .	57.463276
and if you should step inside of such a magnified atom , according to the physics of forty years ago , you would see circulating over your head , down at the sides , and under your feet , some twenty luminous balls about the size of footballs .	33.145367
these balls are moving in great circles and ellipses , and are of course , the electrons , the particles of negative electricity which by their action create the forces that tie this atom of calcium to the neighboring atoms of oxygen and make up the solid structure of my finger bone .	39.067413
since these electrons are moving like planets , you may wonder whether there is an atomic sun at the center of the atom .	32.64418
so you look down there and you see a tiny , whirling point about the size of the head of a pin .	37.75289
this is the atomic sun , the atomic nucleus .	16.042294
even if the atom were big enough to hold a football field , this nucleus is still only about the size of a pinhead .	28.7575
it is this atomic nucleus that contains the positive charge of electricity holding these negatively charged electrons in their orbits	34.177597
it also contains nearly all the mass , and the atomic energy .	13.038062
you may ask what else there is , and the answer is nothing -- nothing but empty space .	51.105812
and since you are made of atoms , you are nothing much but empty space , too .	44.80295
if i could put your body in an imaginary atomic press and squeeze you down , squeeze these holes out of you in the way we squeeze the holes out of a sponge , you would get smaller and smaller until finally when the last hole was gone , you would be smaller than the smallest speck of dust that you could see on this piece of paper .	54.74873
someone has remarked that this is certainly the ultimate in reducing .	334.36682
at any rate , it shows us how immaterial we are .	28.426723
now this 1920 view of the atom was on the whole a discouraging picture .	70.303856
for we believed that the electrons obeyed the law of mechanics and electrodynamics	8.047973
and therefore the atom was really just a little machine	333.85608
and in mechanics the whole is no more than the sum of the parts .	15.72775
so if you are made of atoms , you are just a big machine	65.46981
and since the universe is also made of atoms , it is just a supermachine .	20.187738
and this would mean that we live in a mechanistic universe , governed by the laws of cause and effect , bound in chains of determinism that hold the universe on a completely predetermined course in which there is not room for soul or spirit or human freedom .	42.773426
and this is why so many scientists a half a century ago were agnostics or atheists .	54.927746
then came the scientific revolution in the late 1920 ' s .	9.357772
a suggestion from louis de broglie , a physicist in france , showed us that these electrons are not point particles but waves .	54.81665
and to see the meaning of this new picture , imagine that you can put on more powerful glasses and go back inside the atom and have a look at it in the way we view it today .	67.81459
now as you step inside , instead of seeing particles orbiting around like planets , you see waves and ripples very much like the ripples that you get on the surface of a pond when you drop a stone into it .	43.55128
these ripples spread out in symmetrical patterns like the rose windows of a great cathedral .	76.397964
and as the waves flow back and forth and merge with the waves from the neighboring atoms , you can put on a magic hearing aid and you hear music .	121.889435
it is a music like the music from a great organ or a vast orchestra playing a symphony .	74.65961
harmony , melody , counterpoint symphonic structure are there	38075.527
and as this music ebbs and flows , there is an antiphonal chorus from all the atoms outside , in fact from the atoms of the entire universe .	31.11126
and so today when we examine the structure of our knowledge of the atom and of the universe , we are forced to conclude that the best word to describe our universe is music .	34.470097
the island of nantucket , part of the state of massachusetts , lies about thirty-one miles southeast of its mother state .	25.943384
some of the island is sand and is not suitable for living .	34.86986
the island folk have their living almost entirely from summer visitors	240.24184
during about three and a half months of the year , in the summer , there are three boats that run from the mainland to the island carrying passengers , food , and cars	46.28991
but the rest of the year only one boat is needed , which ties up at the mainland nights and makes the trip down to nantucket in the daytime .	88.72006
this is a fine trip , too , on a good day .	52.72342
with martha ' s vineyard on one side and the open sea on the other , it makes an excellent trip of about three hours .	52.062267
to what extent and in what ways did christianity affect the united states of america in the nineteenth century ? ?	18.387133
how far and in what fashion did it modify the new nation which was emerging in the midst of the forces shaping the revolutionary age ? ?	51.52204
to what extent did it mould the morals and the social , economic , and political life and institutions of the country ? ?	26.976341
a complete picture is impossible -- partly because of the limitations of space , partly because for millions of individuals who professed allegiance to the christian faith data are unobtainable .	51.18711
even more of an obstacle is the difficulty of separating the influence of christianity from other factors .	29.213627
although a complete picture cannot be given , we can indicate some aspects of life into which the christian faith entered as at least one creative factor .	102.345665
at times we can say that it was the major factor .	19.303255
what in some ways was the most important aspect was the impact individually on the millions who constituted the nation .	72.42542
as we have seen , a growing proportion , although in 1914 still a minority , were members of churches .	62.03359
presumably those who did not have a formal church connexion had also felt the influence of christianity to a greater or lesser extent .	70.401115
many of them had once been members of a church or at least had been given instruction in christianity but for one or another reason had allowed the connexion to lapse .	79.839676
the form of christianity to which they were exposed was for some the protestantism of the older stock , for others the protestantism of the nineteenth-century immigration	39.642147
for still others , mostly of the nineteenth-century immigration , it was roman catholicism , and for a small minority it was eastern orthodoxy .	24.103598
upon all of them played the intellectual , social , political , and economic attitudes , institutions , and customs of the nation .	18.891466
upon most of these christianity had left an impress and through them had had a share in making the individual what he was .	118.07194
yet to determine precisely to what extent and exactly in what ways any individual showed the effects of christianity would be impossible .	82.4378
at best only an approximation could be arrived at .	116.09262
to generalize for the entire nation would be absurd .	45.84486
for instance , we cannot know whether even for church members the degree of conformity to christian standards of morality increased or declined as the proportion of church members in the population rose .	66.179855
the temptation is to say that , as the percentage of church members mounted , the degree of discipline exercised by the churches lessened and the trend was towards conformity to the general level .	45.492786
we know that in the early part of the century many protestant congregations took positive action against members who transgressed the ethical codes to which the majority subscribed .	45.36632
thus baptist churches on the frontier took cognizance of charges against their members of drunkenness , fighting , malicious gossip , lying , cheating , sexual irregularities , gambling , horse racing , and failure to pay just debts .	24.256508
if guilty , the offender might be excluded from membership .	25.099884
as church membership burgeoned , such measures faded into desuetude .	15.545123
but whether this was accompanied by a general lowering of the moral life of the membership we do not know .	25.261631
what we can attempt with some hope of dependable conclusions is to point out the manner in which christianity entered into particular aspects of the life of the nation .	74.32762
we have already hinted at the fashion in which christianity contributed to education and so to intellectual life .	56.497307
we will now speak of the ways in which it helped shape the ideals of the country and of the manner in which it stimulated efforts to attain those ideals through reform movements , through programmes for bringing the collective life to the nation to conformity to christian standards , and through leaders in the government .	61.828293
throughout the nineteenth century christianity exerted its influence on american society as a whole primarily through the protestantism of the older stock .	29.14164
by the end of the century the roman catholic church was beginning to make itself felt , mainly through such institutions as hospitals but also through its attitude towards organized labour .	80.01485
in the twentieth century its influence grew , as did that of the protestantism of the nineteenth-century immigration .	24.290028
the ideals of the country were deeply indebted to the protestantism of the older stock .	7.271731
thus `` america ' ' , the most widely sung of the patriotic songs , was written by a new england baptist clergyman , samuel francis smith ( 1808-1895 ) , while a student in andover theological seminary .	18.98487
with its zeal for liberty and its dependence on god it breathed the spirit which had been nourished on the evangelical revivals .	29.729536
the great seal of the united states was obviously inspired by the christian faith .	36.843124
here was what was called the american dream , namely , the effort to build a structure which would be something new in history and to do so in such fashion that god could bless it .	50.286373
later in the century the dream again found expression in the lines of katherine lee bates ( 1859-1929 ) , daughter and granddaughter of new england congregational ministers , in her widely sung hymn , written in 1893 , `` america the beautiful ' ' , with the words `` o beautiful for pilgrim feet whose stern impassioned stress a thoroughfare for freedom beat across the wilderness .	42.001274
america , america , god mend thy every flaw , confirm thy soul in self control , the liberty in law .	54.928715
o beautiful for patriot dream that sees beyond the years thine alabaster cities gleam undimmed by human tears .	19.890377
america , america , god shed his grace on thee , and crown thy good with brotherhood from sea to shining sea ' ' .	28.550735
the american dream was compounded of many strains .	6.453916
some were clearly of christian origin , among them the great awakening and other revivals which helped to make christian liberty , christian equality , and christian fraternity the passion of the land .	33.417477
some have seen revivalism and the search for christian perfection as the fountain-head of the american hope .	24.090109
here , too , must be placed unitarianism and , less obviously from christian inspiration , emerson , transcendentalism , and the idealism of walt whitman .	14.984127
we must also remember those who reacted against the dream as a kind of myth -- among them melville , hawthorne , and henry james the elder , all of them out of a christian background .	32.35807
with such a dream arising , at least in part , from the protestant heritage of the united states and built into the foundations of the nation , it is not surprising that many efforts were made to give it concrete expression .	30.15949
a number were in the nature of movements to relieve or remove social ills .	51.283085
significantly , the initiation and leadership of a major proportion of the reform movements , especially those in the first half of the nineteenth century , came from men and women of new england birth or parentage and from either trinitarian or unitarian congregationalism .	31.112514
several of the movements were given a marked impetus by revivalism .	14.075566
quakers , some from new england , had a larger share than their proportionate numerical strength would have warranted .	47.92496
we do well to remind ourselves that from men and women of new england ancestry also issued the church of jesus christ of latter day saints , the seventh day adventists , christian science , the american board of commissioners for foreign missions , the american home missionary society , the american bible society , and new england theology .	45.34989
the atmosphere was one of optimism , of confidence in human progress , and of a determination to rid the world of its ills .	39.155724
the hopkinsian universal disinterested benevolence , although holding to original sin and the doctrine of election , inspired its adherents to heroic endeavours for others , looked for the early coming of the millennium , and was paralleled by the confidence in man ' s ability cherished by the unitarians , emerson , and the transcendentalists .	34.360447
we should recall the number of movements for the service of mankind which arose from the kindred evangelicalism of the british isles and the pietism of the continent of europe -- among them prison reform , anti-slavery measures , legislation for the alleviation of conditions of labour , the inner mission , and the red cross .	24.542658
we cannot take the space to record all the efforts for the removal or alleviation of collective ills .	52.867573
a few of the more prominent must serve as examples of what a complete listing and description would disclose .	87.14926
several were born in the early decades and persisted throughout the century .	38.4918
some disappeared with the attainment of their purpose .	5.000732
still others sprang up late in the century to meet conditions which arose from fresh stages of the revolutionary age .	101.1274
the movement to end negro slavery began before 1815 and mounted after that year until , as a result of the civil war , emancipation was achieved .	29.408493
long before 1815 the christian conscience was leading some to declare slavery wrong and to act accordingly .	117.15628
for example , in 1693 the philadelphia yearly meeting of friends declared that its members should emancipate their slaves and in 1776 it determined to exclude from membership all who did not comply .	71.03547
in the latter year samuel hopkins , from whom the hopkinsian strain of new england theology took its name , asked the continental congress to abolish slavery .	50.899784
as we have seen , methodism early took a stand against slavery .	20.260767
beginning at least as far back as 1789 various baptist bodies condemned slavery .	152.19879
after 1815 anti-slavery sentiment mounted , chiefly among protestants and those of protestant background of the older stock .	58.436638
the nineteenth-century immigration , whether protestant or roman catholic , was not so much concerned , for very few if any among them held slaves they were mostly in the northern states where slavery had disappeared or was on the way out , or were too poverty-stricken to own slaves .	60.907127
benjamin lundy ( 1789-1839 ) , a quaker , was a pioneer in preparing the way for anti-slavery societies .	34.800617
it was he who turned the attention of william lloyd garrison ( 1805-1879 ) to the subject .	66.11226
garrison , massachusetts born of nova scotian parentage , was by temperament and conviction a reformer .	20.146158
chiefly remembered because of his incessant advocacy of `` immediate and unconditional abolition ' ' , he also espoused a great variety of other causes -- among them women ' s rights , prohibition , and justice to the indians .	37.290073
incurably optimistic , dogmatic , and utterly fearless , in his youth a devout baptist , in spite of his friendship for the quaker poet john greenleaf whittier ( 1807-1892 ) he eventually attacked the orthodox churches for what he deemed their cowardly compromising on the slavery issue and in his invariably ardent manner was emphatically unorthodox and denied the plenary inspiration of the bible .	26.813152
a marked impulse came to the anti-slavery movement through the finney revivals .	10.202826
finney himself , while opposed to slavery , placed his chief emphasis on evangelism , but from his converts issued much of the leadership of the anti-slavery campaign .	92.669014
theodore dwight weld ( 1803-1895 ) was especially active .	98.98783
weld was the son and grandson of new england congregational ministers .	3.0561748
as a youth he became one of finney ' s band of evangelists and gave himself to winning young men .	27.868612
a strong temperance advocate , through the influence of a favorite teacher , charles stewart , another finney convert , he devoted himself to the anti-slavery cause .	31.863245
a group of young men influenced by him enrolled in lane theological seminary and had to leave because of their open anti-slavery position .	59.093933
the majority then went to the infant oberlin .	3.9591346
they and others employed some of finney ' s techniques as they sought to win adherents to the cause .	34.76687
weld contributed to the anti-slavery convictions of such men as joshua r . giddings and edwin m . stanton , enlisted john quincy adams , and helped provide ideas which underlay harriet beecher stowe ' s uncle tom ' s cabin .	25.23566
he shunned publicity for himself and sought to avoid fame .	111.72113
wendell phillips ( 1811-1884 ) , from a prominent massachusetts family , in his teens was converted under the preaching of lyman beecher .	50.824066
although he later broke with the churches because he believed that they were insufficiently outspoken against social evils , he remained a devout christian .	28.039337
he was remembered chiefly for his fearless advocacy of abolition , but he also stood for equal rights for women , for opportunity for the freedmen , and for prohibition .	54.903343
the anti-slavery movement and other contemporary reforms and philanthropies were given leadership and financial undergirding by arthur tappan ( 1786-1865 ) and his younger brother , lewis tappan ( 1788-1873 ) .	18.268274
individuals possessing unusual gifts and great personal power were transmuted at death into awesome spirits	44.465824
they were almost immediately worshipped for these newer , even more terrible abilities .	18.976204
their direct descendants inherited not only their worldly fortunes , but also the mandate of their newfound power as spirits in the other half of the universe .	21.418688
royal lineages could be based on extraordinary worldly achievements translated into eternal otherworldly power .	48.8922
thus , the emperor could draw on sources not available to those with less puissant ancestors .	83.253586
but this eminence was not without its weighty responsibilities .	12.9042425
since he possessed more power in an interdependent universe of living beings and dead spirits , the emperor had to use it for the benefit of the living .	28.986187
the royal ritual generated power into the other world it also provided the living with a way to control the spirits , and bring their powers directly to bear on the everyday affairs of the world .	72.18006
proper ritual observance at any level of society was capable of generating power for use in the spirit world	61.127144
but naturally , the royal ritual , which provided unusual control over already supremely powerful divine spirits , was held responsible for regulating the universe and insuring the welfare of the kingdom .	57.781586
this is the familiar system of `` cosmic government ' ' .	20.552809
the chinese emperor , by proper observance of ritual , manifested divine powers .	9.635938
he regulated the dualities of light and darkness , yang and yin , which are locked in eternal struggle .	24.94986
by swaying the balance between them , he effected the alternation of the seasons .	10.687061
his power was so great that he even promoted and demoted gods according to whether they had given ear or been deaf to petitions .	51.522602
in this system , no man is exempt from obligations .	75.46795
failure in daily moral and ethical duties to one ' s family , outrages to community propriety , any departure from rigid standards of moral excellence were offenses against the dead .	65.84001
and to offend the dead meant to incur their wrath , and thus provoke the unleashing of countrywide disasters .	6.7216096
the family home was , in fact , a temple	58.408253
and the daily duties of individuals were basically religious in nature .	154.42273
the dead spirits occupied a prominent place in every hope and in every fear .	283.25998
the common belief was that there existed one moral order , which included everything .	181.99982
the dead controlled the material prosperity of the living , and the living adhered to strict codes of conduct in order not to weaken that control .	52.726044
men believed they could control nature by obeying a moral code .	32.448734
if the moral code were flouted , the proper balance of the universe would be upset , and the disastrous result could be floods , plague , or famine .	20.483643
modern westerners have difficulty comprehending this fusion of moral and material , largely because in the west the historical trend has been to deny the connection .	49.48812
living in urban conditions , away from the deadweight of village constraint and the constrictions of a thatched-roof world view , the individual may find it possible , say , to commit adultery not only without personal misgivings , but also without suffering any adverse effects in his worldly fortunes .	39.03693
basing action on the empirical determination of cause and effect provides a toughness and bravado that no powerful otherworldly ancestor could ever impart -- plus the added liberation from the constraint of silent burial urns .	31.955612
in china , the magical system par excellence was taoism .	9.068865
the taoists were quietist mystics , who saw an unchanging unity -- the tao -- underlying all phenomena .	15.530717
it was this timeless unity that was all-important , and not its temporary manifestations in the world of reality .	34.747417
the taoists believed the unity could be influenced by proper magical manipulation	22.982164
in other words , they were actually an organization of magicians .	20.161179
mahayana buddhism was no exception to these prevailing magical concepts .	14.031175
after this form of indian buddhism had been introduced into china , it underwent extensive changes .	30.991846
during its flowering in the sixth to the eighth centuries , mahayana offered a supernatural package to the chinese which bears no resemblance to the highly digested philosophical zen morsels offered to the modern western reader .	32.843544
mahayana had gods , and magic , a pantheon , heavens and hells , and gorgeously appareled priests , monks , and nuns , all of whom wielded power over souls in the other world .	16.740559
the self-realized mahayana saint possessed superhuman powers and magic .	17.346922
the mahayana that developed in the north was a religion of idolatry and coarse magic , that made the world into a huge magical garden .	71.061386
in its monastic form , mahayana was merely an organization of magic-practicing monks ( bonzes ) , who catered to the chinese faith in the supernatural .	20.947525
nonmagical confucianism was a secular , rational philosophy , but even with this different orientation it could not escape from the ethos of a cosmic government .	55.293392
confucianism had its own magic in the idea that virtue had power .	168.27658
if a man lived a classical life , he need not fear the spirits -- for only lack of virtue gave the spirits power over him .	143.83037
but let us not be mistaken about confucian `` virtue ' '	16.299057
this was not virtue as we understand the word today , and it did not mean an abandonment of the belief in magic manipulation .	33.111576
to the confucian , `` virtue ' ' simply meant mastery and correct observance of three hundred major rules of ritual and three thousand minor ones .	93.97832
propriety was synonymous with ritual observance , the mark of a true gentleman .	91.57065
to live correctly in an interdependent moral and material universe of living and dead was decisive for man ' s fate .	69.627884
this , in brief , was the historical background out of which zen emerged .	242.09386
promoters of zen to the west record its ancestry , and recognize that zen grew out of a combination of taoism and indian mahayana buddhism .	18.453142
but the `` marvelous person ' ' that is supposed to result from zen exhibits more chinese practicality than indian speculation -- he possesses magical powers , and can use them to order nature and to redeem souls .	54.347885
proponents of zen to the west emphasize disproportionately the amount of mahayana buddhism in zen , probably in order to dignify the indisputably magical taoist ideas with more respectable buddhist metaphysic .	17.949429
but in the chinese mind , there was little difference between the two -- the bonzes were no more metaphysical than a magician has to be .	37.78427
actually , zen owes more to chinese quietism than it does to mahayana buddhism .	11.875279
the ch ' an ( zen ) sect may have derived its metaphysic from mahayana , but its psychology was pure early taoist .	49.039146
this is well evidenced by the quietist doctrines carried over in zen the idea of the inward turning of thought , the enjoinder to put aside desires and perturbations so that a return to purity , peace , and stillness -- a union with the infinite , with the tao -- could be effected .	56.313744
in fact , the antipathy to outward ceremonies hailed by modern exponents as so uniquely characteristic of the `` direct thinking ' ' zennist was a feature of taoism .	28.393728
so , too , was the insistence on the relativity of the external world , and the ideas that language and things perceived by consciousness were poor substitutes indeed for immediate perception by pure , indwelling spirit the opposition of pure consciousness to ratiocinating consciousness .	87.30848
zen maintains that cognitive things are only the surface of experience .	43.334663
one of its features attractive to the west is its irreverence for tradition and dogma and for sacred texts .	26.188854
one patriarch is supposed to have relegated sacred scriptures for use in an outhouse .	24.63065
but this is not the spirit of self-reliant freedom of action for which the westerner mistakes it .	46.159313
it is simply that in taoist tradition -- as in all good mysticisms -- books , words , or any other manifestations that belong to the normal state of consciousness are considered only the surface of experience .	60.77237
the truth -- the eternal truth -- is not transmittable by words .	11.621225
reality is considered not only irrelevant to the acquisition of higher knowledge , but a positive handicap .	62.922115
the technique of reality confusion -- the use of paradox and riddles to shake the mind ' s grip on reality -- originated with fourth and third century b . c . chinese quietism the koan is not basically a new device .	42.366074
it is important for an understanding of zen to realize that the esoteric preoccupations of the select few cannot be the doctrine of the common man .	24.662523
in the supernatural atmosphere of cosmic government , only the ruling elite was ever concerned with a kingdom-wide ordering of nature popular religion aimed at more personal benefits from magical powers .	157.91139
and this is only natural -- witness the haste with which modern man gobbles the latest `` wonder drug ' ' .	51.10207
early chinese anchoritism was theoretically aimed at a mystic pantheist union with the divine , personal salvation being achieved when the mystical recluse united with divine essence .	40.304867
but this esoteric doctrine was lost in the shuffle to acquire special powers .	82.59365
the anchorite strove , in fact , to magically influence the world of spirits in the same way that the divine emperor manifested his power .	26.720463
thus , the mahayana metaphysic of mystical union for salvation was distilled down to a bare self-seeking , and for this reason , the mystic in asia did not long remain in isolated contemplation .	39.883717
as the zen literature reveals , as soon as an early zen master attained fame in seclusion , he was called out into the world to exercise his powers .	43.43751
the early anchorite masters attracted disciples because of their presumed ability to perform miracles .	14.886477
exponents of zen often insist that very early zen doctrine opposed the rampant supernaturalism of china , and proposed instead a more mature , less credulous view of the universe .	61.08638
in support of this , stories from the early literature are cited to show that zen attacks the idea of supernatural power .	50.027485
but actually these accounts reveal the supernatural powers that the masters were in fact supposed to possess , as well as the extreme degree of popular credulity `` hwang pah ( o baku ) , one day going up mount tien tai which was believed to have been inhabited by arhats with supernatural powers , met with a monk whose eyes emitted strange light .	35.07501
they went along the pass talking with each other for a short while until they came to a river roaring with torrent .	44.77858
there being no bridge , the master had to stop at the shore	35.55994
but his companion crossed the river walking on the water and beckoned to hwang pah to follow him .	15.028079
thereupon hwang pah said `` if i knew thou art an arhat , i would have doubled you up before thou got over there ' ' ! !	73.80056
the monk then understood the spiritual attainment of hwang pah , and praised him as a true mahayanist .	16.413137
a second tale shows still more clearly the kind of powers a truly spiritual monk could possess `` on one occasion yang shan ( kyo-zan ) saw a stranger monk flying through the air .	57.261032
when that monk came down and approached him with a respectful salutation , he asked `` where art thou from ' ' ? ?	16.886332
`` early this morning ' ' , replied the other , `` i set out from india ' ' .	32.929214
`` why ' ' , said the teacher , `` art thou so late ' ' ? ?	23.835873
`` i stopped ' ' , responded the man , `` several times to look at beautiful sceneries ' ' .	29.692213
`` thou mayst have supernatural powers ' ' , exclaimed yang shan , `` yet thou must give back the spirit of buddha to me ' ' .	19.158777
then the monk praised yang shan saying `` i have come over to china in order to worship manjucri , and met unexpectedly with minor shakya ' ' , and after giving the master some palm leaves he brought from india , went back through the air .	81.37553
in the popular chinese mind , ch ' an ( zen ) was no exception to the ideas of coarse magic that dominated .	66.04537
a closer look at modern zen reveals many magical carryovers that are still part of popular zen attitudes .	38.301342
to the zen monk the universe is still populated with `` spiritual beings ' ' who have to be appeased .	11.476327
part of the mealtime ritual in the zendo consists in offerings of rice to the spiritual beings ' ' .	21.209938
modern zen presentation to the west insists on the anti-authoritarian , highly pragmatic nature of the zen belief -- scriptures are burned to make fire , action is based on direct self-confidence , and so on .	59.546394
this picture of extreme self-reliant individuation is difficult to reconcile with such zendo formulas as `` o you , demons and other spiritual beings , i now offer this to you , and may this food fill up the ten quarters of the world and all the demons and other spiritual beings be fed therewith .	44.55779
pope leo 13 , on the 13th day of december 1898 , granted the following indulgences `` an indulgence of three hundred days is granted to all the faithful who read the holy gospels at least a quarter of an hour .	32.962395
a plenary indulgence under the usual conditions is granted once a month for the daily reading ' ' .	69.03439
pope pius the sixth , at rome , in april , 1778 , wrote the following `` the faithful should be excited to the reading of the holy scriptures for these are the most abundant sources which ought to be left open to everyone , to draw from them purity of morals and of doctrine , to eradicate errors which are so widely disseminated in these corrupt times ' ' .	40.413067

fifteen years ago , troubled by the rising tide of materialism in the post-war world , a businessman and a minister asked themselves if there might not be a place for a small magazine in which men and women , regardless of creed or color , could set forth boldly their religious convictions and bear witness to the power of faith to solve the endless problems of living .	40.455013
neither had any publishing experience , but they had faith in their idea .	63.44949
they borrowed a typewriter , raised about $2 , 000 in contributions , hired a secretary , persuaded a couple of young men to join them for almost no pay and began mailing out a collection of unstapled leaflets that they called guideposts .	82.83238
compared to the big , established magazines , my first efforts seemed feeble indeed .	209.616
but from the start they had two important ingredients sincerity and realism .	36.798466
the people who told the stories were sincere .	4.7598495
for example , early in my life , when one of my editorial workers wanted to find out how churches and philanthropic organizations met the needs of new york ' s down-and-outers , he didn ' t just ask questions .	71.47782
len lesourd went and lived in the slums as a sidewalk derelict for ten days .	17.659826

the help and sympathy that were forthcoming from everywhere .	121.22738
the crisis later on when debts seemed about to overwhelm me .	15.571627
that was when a remarkable woman , teresa durlach , came to my aid -- not so much with money , as with wisdom and courage .	62.081142

too often a beginning bodybuilder has to do his training secretly either because his parents don ' t want sonny-boy to `` lift all those old barbell things ' ' because `` you ' ll stunt your growth ' ' or because childish taunts from his schoolmates , like `` hey lookit mr . america	33.356827
whaddya gonna do with all those muscles ( of which he has none at the time ) ' ' ? ?	56.334663
after all , a guy ' s gotta have a little ego ! !	51.054317
therefore it ' s a genuine pleasure to tell you about an entirely happy bodybuilder who has never had to train in secret has never heard one unkind word from his parents and never has been taunted by his schoolmates ! !	65.35066
this happy , always smiling lad with the sunny disposition is our new junior mr . canada -- henri de courcy .	49.137833
far from discouraging henri , his parents urge him on to greater and greater accomplishments .	168.30963
instead of admonishing him to let the weights alone they personally took him to that master montreal bodybuilding authority , professor roland claude .	96.21168

now when henri was just 12 he was only 4 ' 10 ' ' ' ' tall and weighed an astounding 72 pounds , and his greatest desire was to pack on some weight .	51.940136
about that time he began reading mr . america and muscle builder and he learned of the famous weider way to fast weight gaining .	176.47322
seeing so many illustrations and reading so many testimonials to the value of quick-wate and super-protein , those two wonder-working weider food supplements , he decided to try them and see what they could do for him .	25.718706
well , sir they did real great ! !	1.5896584
for in almost less time than it takes to tell it , henri ' s bodyweight was increasing rapidly .	37.62898
he ' s crazy about water skiing and swimming and this vigorous exercise in conjunction with the added food supplements packed pounds of solid muscle on his skinny frame .	50.450138
henri has always had shapely legs from swimming and water skiing and really doesn ' t have to work them very much .	36.094833
but he was totally dissatisfied with his upper body .	16.781483
it was muscular but it wasn ' t symmetrical .	41.102333
`` a real ' nothing ' torso ' ' , says henri .	8.886696
it just got longer and longer ' ' .	1.2459986
that ' s when he went to professor claude .	544.2304
and at once claude saw what the trouble was and he knew just how to correct it .	70.12169
in his gym the professor has some of the most `` knocked out ' ' equipment since vic tanny .	30.403788
mr . claude is a specialist in torso development and he has long favored the now-famous weider push-pull super-set technique in which one exercise of the super-set is a pressing or `` pushing ' ' movement which accents one sector of a muscle group in a specific way , followed by a `` pulling ' ' exercise which works the opposing sector of the same muscle group .	31.25282
so right away claude introduced henri to his famous `` moon ' ' bench and proceeded to teach him his first push-pull super-set consisting of the wide-grip straight-arm pullover ( the `` pull ' ' part of the push-pull super-set ) which dramatically widens the ribcage and strongly affects the muscles of the upper back and chest and the collar-to-collar bench press which specifically works on the chest to build those wide , reeves-type `` gladiator ' ' pecs , while stimulating the upper lats and frontal deltoids .	24.268864
as you can see , in this push-pull super set the entire chest-back-shoulder area is vigorously exercised in alternate sectors by alternate exercises so the complete torso remains pumped-up all the time ! !	60.6058
now when henri has completed four complete push-pull super-sets no . 1 , the professor allows him about a five-minute rest period before starting him on four complete push-pull super-sets no . 2 .	63.96107
super-set no . 2 is made up of similar exercises , but this time done with dumbbells , and using both `` moon ' ' and flat benches .	52.183994
the `` push ' ' exercise of this push-pull super-set is the bench press done with elbows well pulled back and with a greater downward stretch of the pectorals not possible with the barbell variation .	34.366966
you need the barbell variation to build width and mass in the pecs .	48.241447
the dumbbell variation develops a most classically sculptured outline to the aj .	6.148286
the `` pull ' ' exercise in this super-set is the one-dumbbell bent-arm pullover .	7.0445166
( note how strongly the upper lats and serratus are worked in this fine exercise because of the pin-point concentration of force which the dumbbell variation affords ) .	44.549694
in the third push-pull super-set the `` push ' ' exercise is the widegrip pushup between bars , while the `` pull ' ' exercise is the moon bench lateral raise with bent arms .	27.334602
the pushup done in this manner is the greatest pectoral-ribcage stretcher ever invented ! !	48.118156
this is true only if a very wide grip is used and only when the greatest possible stretch is achieved .	46.770115
you ' ll know when you ' ve made the greatest stretch because your shoulder blades will touch ! !	45.684063
as you see , the professor has designed a piece of apparatus that forces the bodybuilder to use a w-i-d-e grip .	18.23508
he just can ' t do anything about it at all ! !	58.40352
but as you can also see , it ' s not a painful exercise at all , because henri de courcy -- the `` happy ' ' bodybuilder -- looks as though he were having the time of his life ! !	41.09383
the last exercise of roland claude ' s prescribed program for henri is a single exercise , done in individual sets with a bit longer pause between sets .	169.70924
by this time henri ' s entire chest-back-lat-shoulder area is pumped-up to almost bursting point , and claude takes time to do a bit more pectoral-front deltoid shaping work .	67.12713
he has henri do from four to six sets of the incline bench press ( note the high incline ) .	19.964788
this gives a wide flare to the pecs , causing them to flow dramatically upward into deltoids and dramatically downward into the serratus and aj .	28.954773
this is the kind of chest that invariably wins contests	27.91224
that steel-edged `` carved-out-of-solid rock ' ' looks of the great champions .	19.747746
so with four complete push-pull super-sets no . 1 , four of no . 2 , four of no . 3 and four to six sets of the incline bench press , you can see that henri de courcy has had a terrific mass-building , muscle-shaping , torso-defining workout that cannot be improved upon .	28.37323
physique contests are rarely won on muscle size alone .	133.47908
rarer still is a mr . america or mr . universe of true herculean build .	61.05607
the aspects of physical development that catch the judges ' eyes and which rightfully influence their decisions are symmetry and that hallmark of the true champion -- superior definition of the muscles .	71.699844
now good definition is one thing that all of us can acquire with occasional high-set , high-rep , light-weight workouts .	12.459521
but contest definition -- that dramatic muscular separation of every muscle group that seems as though it must have been carved by a sculptor ' s chisel -- is something quite different .	56.450294
this comes not alone from high-set , high-rep training , but from certain definition-specialization exercises which the champion selects for himself with the knowledge of exactly what works best for him .	94.77512
often these exercises work well for some bodybuilders but less spectacularly for others .	56.07518
because they are `` minority ' ' exercises and have but a limited appeal they soon find themselves in the limbo of the forgotten .	75.55797
only when the newest mr . america or mr . universe discovers them and puts them into practice are we reacquainted with them and once again see how effective they really are .	89.07698
the exercise i shall discuss in this -- the first of a new series of articles on muscle definition-specialization of a particular body part -- is the one leg lunge .	42.95751
why it was ever forgotten for even a moment i cannot say because it works perfectly for everyone , no matter whether he has short or long thigh-bone lengths ! !	164.75151
it is the one exercise that drastically influences the definition of the thighs at the hipline -- that mark of the champion that sets him apart from all other bodybuilders	41.653904
a criterion of muscle `` drama ' ' that is unforgettable to judges and audiences alike	59.59849
the facet of muscular development that wins prizes .	27.592716
definition of the thighs at the uppermost part is quite commonly seen in most championship olympic lifters which is easily understandable .	28.704502
the one leg lunge is a split and all lifters practice this in their regular workouts .	103.16165
but for purely definition purposes -- used in conjunction with your regular squatting , leg curling , leg extensor programs -- a heavy weight is not needed .	31.058931
indeed , a lighter weight works much better because a greater , more extensive split can be performed .	82.32639
used in several sets of high reps once or twice each week it will not be long before your entire upper leg takes on a razor-sharp definition in which the muscles look like wire cables writhing and twisting under the skin ! !	52.759834
really there is no reason why this fine exercise should not find its way into your leg program at all times , for the following suggestions show why it is so effective 1 .	74.4303
it ' s a complete thigh contraction-extension exercise .	2.8572378
it places terrific tension on the leg muscles from start to finish of each repetition .	57.088646
it improves over-all balance and control for the bodybuilder , and helps to make squats more easily and more correctly performed .	47.484783
it speeds muscle growth and power development even for the advanced bodybuilder because each hip and leg is exercised separately , thus enabling a massive , concentrated effort to be focused on each .	82.74652
you ' ll need your weider power stands for this fine exercise and here ' s the way it ' s done 1 .	58.701393
place your power stands in position and adjust their height so that this will correspond to the height of your shoulders when you are in a deep leg split as for a heavy clean .	42.37963
grasp the bar ( which will rest against the back of your neck )	34.5033
extend your feet forward and backward until you are in a deep leg split .	37.779804
now raise the weight by straightening your front leg , without moving your feet .	54.07725
when the front knee is straight and locked , allow it to bend again until you feel the bar come lightly into contact with the sides of the power stands .	90.19505
after you have taken a breather , reverse the position of your legs so that the front thigh of the previous exercise is now to the rear , and the rear thigh now to the front , and perform the same movement in the same manner .	32.089
that ' s the one-leg lunge in a nutshell .	1.8839433
you should have a couple of training partners to stand by when you make your first experiments just for safety .	130.42447
you should also begin this exercise with a very light barbell until you become accustomed to it balance-wise .	33.261055
oh , you ' ll wobble and weave quite a bit at first .	33.264378
before your first training experiment has ended there will be a big improvement and almost before you know it you ' ll be raising and lowering yourself just like a veteran ! !	55.7133
although i suggested that you hold the bar at the back of the neck there ' s no reason why you shouldn ' t make some experiments with the bar held in front of the neck .	20.161491
squat-style lifters and leg-split lifters would both benefit enormously by practicing those variations providing that they remember to make alternate sets with the left and right leg to the front .	115.42335
the most beautiful bed of pansies i ' ve seen was in a south dakota yard on a sizzling day .	43.37516
pansies are supposed to like it cool , but those great velvety flowers were healthy and perky in the glaring sun .	74.72892
i sought out the gardener and asked him what he did to produce such beauties in that weather .	37.738327
`` i just love them ' ' , he said .	3.2711887
the more i talked with him , the more convinced i became that that was the secret of their riotous blooming .	44.04673
of course his love was expressed in intelligent care .	15.516616
he planted the pansy seeds himself , buying them from a pansy specialist .	6.4288545
these specialists , i learned , have done a great deal of work to improve the size and health of the plants and the resulting flowers .	57.172935
their seeds produce vigorous blooming plants half again the size of the unimproved strains .	17.574398
i asked him if he took seeds from his own plants .	19.90513
occasionally , when he had an unusual flower that he wanted more of he did	72.39919
but pansy seeds , he told me , soon `` run down ' ' .	71.95127
it ' s best to buy them fresh from a dealer who is working to improve them .	35.407227
his soil was `` nothing special ' ' , just prairie land , but he had harrowed in compost until it was loose , spongy and brown-black .	27.965864
i fingered it and had the feeling of adequacy that comes with the right texture , tilth and body .	35.780296
it isn ' t easy to describe it , but every gardener knows it when his fingers touch such soil .	66.75946
nothing is easier to grow from seed than pansies .	4.962355
they germinate quickly , the tiny plants appearing in a week , and grow along lustily .	32.64386
it doesn ' t really matter which month of the year you sow them , but they germinate best when they have a wide variation of temperature , very warm followed by cool in the same 24 hours .	49.838
i like to make a seedbed right in the open , though many people start them successfully in cold frames .	90.490135
they ' d rather have things rugged , with only moderate protection on the coldest days .	43.138515
if you do use a cold frame be sure that its ventilation is adequate .	44.333206
for my seedbed i use good garden soil with a little sand added to encourage rooting .	35.19942
i dig it , rake it smooth , sow the seeds and wet them down with a fog spray .	36.527046
then i cover the sowing with a board .	21.500406
this keeps it cool and moist and protects it from birds .	78.79052
ants carry away the seeds so better be sure that there are no ant hills nearby .	37.147625
when the first sprinkling of green appears i remove the board .	20.871506
a light , porous mulch applied now keeps the roots cool and the soil soft during these early days of growth .	100.29565
i like sawdust for this , or hay .	48.995464
when they have 4 to 6 leaves and are thrifty little plants , it ' s time to set them out where they are to remain .	45.76927
every time you transplant a pansy you cause its flowers to become smaller .	76.85308
the moral is don ' t transplant it any oftener than you must .	107.1055
as soon as they are large enough to move , i put mine 9 inches apart where they are to bloom .	120.02615
i put a little scoop of pulverized phosphate rock or steamed bone meal into each hole with the plant .	172.42197
that encourages rooting , and the better developed the roots , the larger and more plentiful the flowers .	66.92281
i doubt if it is possible to overfeed them .	21.211582
lacking that , decayed manure spread over the bed is fine .	77.41349
one year i simply set the plants in the remains of a compost pile , to which a little sand had been added , and i had the most beautiful pansies in my , or any of my neighbors ' experience .	45.41868
in addition to the rich soil they benefit by feedings of manure water every other week , diluted to the color of weak tea .	71.21352
as a substitute for this , organic fertilizer dissolved in water to half the strength in the directions , may be used .	44.32785
three inches of porous material will do a good job of keeping weeds down and the soil moist and cool .	22.785458
when winter comes be ready with additional mulch .	9.171804
i like hay for this and apply it so that only the tops of the plants show right after a good frost .	103.90153
that keeps in the cold , retains moisture and prevents the heaving of alternate freezing and thawing .	7.508921
don ' t miss the pansies that appear from time to time through the winter .	29.473583
whenever there is a thaw or a few sunny days , you ' ll be likely to find a brave little blossom or two .	34.073383
if those aren ' t enough for you , why not grow some just for winter blooming ? ?	114.637184
the pansies i cherished most bloomed for me in february during a particularly cold winter .	100.54685
i started the seed in a flat in june and set out the little pansies in a cold frame .	77.32223
( an unheated greenhouse would have been better , if i had had one .	68.72588
) the plants took zero nights in their stride , with nothing but a mat of straw over the glass to protect them .	32.546585
in response to the lengthening days of february they budded , then bloomed their 4-inch velvety flowers .	20.375025
its mass of bright bloom set in a border of snow made my spirits rise every time i looked at it .	211.83159
like strawberries in december , pansies are far more exciting in february than in may .	113.62987
try that late winter pickup when you are so tired of cold and snow that you feel you just can ' t take another day of it .	56.364407
the day will come , in midsummer , when you find your plants becoming `` leggy ' ' , running to tall-growing foliage at the expense of blossoms .	19.714798
try pegging down each separate branch to the earth , using a bobby pin to hold it there .	48.58257
pick the flowers , keep the soil dampened , and each of the pegged-down branches will take root and become a little plant and go on blooming for the rest of the season .	36.305767
as soon as an experimental tug assures you that roots have taken over , cut it off from the mother plant .	234.8712
a second and also good practice is to shear off the tops , leaving an inch high stub with just a leaf or two on each branch .	86.225624
these cut-down plants will bud and blossom in record time and will behave just as they did in early spring .	180.90082
i like to shear half my plants at a time , leaving one half of them to blossom while the second half is getting started on its new round of blooming .	70.0451
probably no one needs to tell you that the way to stop all bloom is to let the blossoms go to seed .	60.717884
nature ' s aim , different from ours , is to provide for the coming generation .	37.002724
that done , her work is accomplished and she ignores the plant .	185.07503
here is a word of advice when you go shopping for your pansy seeds .	39.860237
go to a reputable grower , preferably a pansy specialist .	1.909367
it is no harder to raise big , healthy , blooming plants than weak , sickly little things	107.94409
but you will never get better flowers than the seed you grow .	64.559044
many people think that pansies last only a few weeks , then their period of growth and bloom is over .	101.47307
if the plants are cared for and protected over the winter , the second year is more prolific than the first .	35.469116
would you like to grow exhibition pansies ? ?	1.0275759
remove about half the branches from each plant , leaving only the strongest with the largest buds .	65.732635
they stick to their principles , insist upon their due , but grow and bloom with dependable regularity if given it .	62.94138
treat them right and they ' ll make a showing every month in the year except the frigid ones .	77.58201
give them food , some shade , mulch , water and more food , and they ' ll repay your solicitude with beauty .	42.369316
a salad with greens and tomato is a popular and wonderfully healthful addition to a meal , but add an avocado and you have something really special .	68.2228
this delightful tropical fruit has become well-known in the past thirty years because modern transportation methods have made it possible to ship avocados anywhere in the united states .	44.67544
it has a great many assets to recommend it and if you haven ' t made avocado a part of your diet yet , you really should .	74.40116
you will find that avocado is unlike any other fruit you have ever tasted .	61.61283
it is roughly shaped like a large pear , and when properly ripened , its dark green skin covers a meaty , melon-like pulp that has about the consistency of a ripe bartlett pear , but oily .	27.718609
the avocado should have a `` give ' ' to it , as you hold it , when it is ripe .	31.112589
the flavor is neither sweet , like a pear , nor tart like an orange	52.43557
it is subtle and rather bland , nut-like .	5.2320266
it is a flavor that might take a little getting used to -- not because it is unpleasant , but because the flavor is hard to define in the light of our experience with other fruits .	56.81149
sometimes it takes several `` eatings ' ' of avocado to catch that delightful quality in taste that has made it such a favorite throughout the world .	117.82936
once you become an avocado fan , you will look forward to the season each year with eager anticipation .	78.62737
today , refrigerated carriers have made the shipping of avocados possible to any place in the world .	52.08093
the fruit is allowed to mature on the tree , but it is still firm at this point .	27.734812
it is brought to packing houses , cleaned and graded as to size and quality , and packed in protective excelsior .	38.831356
the fruit is then cooled to 42-degrees-f . , a temperature at which it lapses into a sort of dormant state .	66.97619
this cooling does not change the avocado in any way , it just delays the natural softening of the fruit until a grovelike temperature ( room temperature ) is restored .	51.697
this happens on the grocer ' s shelf or in your kitchen .	34.99103
one of the most attractive things about avocados is that they do not require processing of any kind .	30.446346
there is no dyeing or waxing or gassing needed .	136.37665
if the temperature is controlled properly , the avocado will delay its ripening until needed .	62.132523
and unlike other fruits , one cannot eat the skin of the avocado .	15.057352
it is thick , much like an egg plant ' s skin , so that poison sprays , if they are used , present no hazard to the consumer .	65.88567
good taste and versatility , plus safety from spray poisons would be enough to recommend the frequent use of such a fruit , even if its nutritional values were limited .	50.072437
avocados , however , are very rich in nutrients .	2.4620368
their main asset is an abundance of unsaturated fatty acids , so necessary for maintaining the good health of the circulatory system .	14.303059
aside from this , the average portion contains some protein , an appreciable amount of vitamins a and c -- about one-tenth of the minimum daily requirement , and about a third of the official vitamin e requirement .	38.76777
the b vitamins are well represented , especially thiamin and riboflavin .	2.226679
calcium , phosphorus and iron are present in worthwhile amounts , and eleven other minerals also have been found in varying trace amounts .	55.32227
none of these values is destroyed , not significantly altered by refrigeration storage .	15.189815
dr . wilson c . grant , of the veterans ' administration hospital , coral gables , florida , and the university of miami school of medicine , set out to discover if avocados , because of their high content of unsaturated fatty acids , would reduce the cholesterol of the blood in selected patients .	32.2065
the study comprised 16 male patients , ranging in age from 27 to 72 .	81.86888
they were put on control diets to determine as accurately as possible , the normal cholesterol level of their blood .	41.51323
then they were given 1/2 to 1-1/2 avocados per day as a substitute for part of their dietary fat consumption .	22.677137
five , four , three , two , one , fire ! !	82.18746
the tremendous energy released by giant rocket engines perhaps can be felt much better than it can be heard .	128.61966
the pulsating vibration of energy clutches at the pit of your stomach .	10.49742
never before has the introduction of a weapon caused so much apprehension and fear .	57.99836
nuclear weapons are fearsome , but the long-range ballistic missile gives them a stealth and merciless swiftness which is much more terrifying .	11.462674
a great many writers are bewitched by the apparently overwhelming advantage an attacker would have if he were to strike with complete surprise using nuclear rockets .	113.186104
it is relatively easy to go a step further and reason that an attacker , in possession of such absolute power , would simultaneously destroy his opponent ' s cities and people .	64.288246
with a nation defenseless before it , why would the attacker spare the victim ' s people ? ?	30.074415
wouldn ' t the wanton destruction of cities and people be the logical act of complete subjugation ? ?	109.38114
the will of its people , so crucial in time of peril , would be broken .	51.212646
nuclear weapons have given the world the means for self-destruction in hours or days	473.3395
and now rockets have given it the means to destroy itself in minutes .	43.01889
at this point it should be painfully obvious that cities , being `` soft ' ' , and the people within them are ideally suited to destruction by nuclear weapons .	46.54997
however , because this vulnerability is mutual , it is to the advantage of neither side to destroy the opponent ' s cities , at least so long as the opponent has nuclear weapons with which to effect reprisal .	47.828064
it should be appallingly apparent that city-trading is not a profitable military tactic .	21.84577
icbms have given us a capability which could be used in two different ways .	19.22091
they could be used to attack a nation ' s people ( which would inevitably mean the loss of the attacker ' s own people ) , or they could be used with discrimination to destroy the enemy ' s military force .	28.257507
if our national interest lies in being able to fight and win a war rather than committing national suicide , then we must take a much more penetrating look at ballistic missiles .	46.31267
we must determine whether missiles can win a war all by themselves .	117.5666
we must make certain that the aircraft is finished before we give the entire job to the missile .	91.27048
missiles are very valuable weapons , but they also have their too little known limitations .	122.5865
because of a missile ' s ballistic trajectory , the location of a fixed target must be known quite accurately .	32.005142
placing missiles in submarines , on barges , railroads , highways , surface vessels and in the air provides them with passive protection by taking advantage of the gravest weakness of long-range ballistic missiles today -- the extreme difficulty of destroying a mobile or moving target with such weapons .	50.952007
one must first detect a fleeting mobile or moving target , decide that it is worthy of destruction , select the missile to be fired against the target , compute ballistics for the flight , and prepare the missile for firing .	37.74622
even if all these operations could be performed instantaneously , the icbm still has a time of flight to the target of about 30 minutes .	22.781176
therefore , if the target can significantly change its location in something less than 30 minutes , the probability of having destroyed it is drastically lowered .	49.618473
because of this , it would appear inevitable that an increasing percentage of strategic missiles will seek self-protection in mobility -- at least until missile defenses are perfected which have an exceedingly high kill probability .	42.71373
in order to destroy the enemy ' s mobile , moving , or imprecisely located strategic forces , we must have a hunter-killer capability in addition to our missiles .	18.605173
until this hunter-killer operation can be performed by spacecraft , manned aircraft appear to be the only means available to us .	19.079962
it seems reasonable that if general nuclear war is not to be one cataclysmic act of burning each other ' s citizens to cinders , we must have a manned strategic force of long-endurance aircraft capable of going into china or russia to find and destroy their strategic forces which continued to threaten us .	38.340435
let us suppose the russians decide to build a rail-mobile icbm force .	16.20925
it is entirely feasible to employ aircraft such as the b-52 or b-70 in hunter-killer operations against soviet railway-based missiles .	28.72415
if we stop thinking in terms of tremendous multimegaton nuclear weapons and consider employing much smaller nuclear weapons which may be more appropriate for most important military targets , it would seem that the b-52 or b-70 could carry a great many small nuclear weapons .	45.154667
an aircraft with a load of small nuclear weapons could very conceivably be given a mission to suppress all trains operating within a specified geographic area of russia -- provided that we had used some of our icbms to degrade russia ' s air defenses before our bombers got there .	65.03951
the aircraft could be used to destroy other mobile , fleeting , and imprecisely located targets as well as the known , fixed and hardened targets which can also be destroyed by missile .	37.689495
why , then , aren ' t we planning a larger , more important role for manned military aircraft ? ?	63.33502
is there any other way to do the job ? ?	13.460297
survivability of our strategic forces ( polaris , mobile and hardened minuteman , hardened atlas and titan , and airborne skybolt ) means that it will take some time , perhaps weeks , to destroy a strategic force .	24.727541
war , under these circumstances , cannot be one massive exchange of nuclear devastation .	61.93481
forces will survive a surprise attack , and these forces will give depth , or considerable duration , to the conflict .	73.62833
the forces which survive the initial attack must be found and destroyed .	20.538452
even mobile forces must be found and destroyed .	3.3223495
but , how does one go about the job of finding and destroying mobile forces ? ?	79.35126
they are not susceptible to wholesale destruction by ballistic missile .	24.436485
some day , many years in the future , true spacecraft will be able to find and destroy mobile targets .	14.105273
but until we have an effective spacecraft , the answer to the hunter-killer problem is manned aircraft .	21.260738
however , the aircraft which we have today are tied to large , `` soft ' ' airfields .	38.058147
here then is our problem aircraft are vital to winning a war today because they can perform those missions which a missile is totally incapable of performing	126.16742
but the airfield , on which the aircraft is completely dependent , is doomed by the missile .	19.45854
this makes today ' s aircraft a one-shot , or one mission , weapon .	44.392647
aircraft are mighty expensive if you can use them only once .	149.41628
this is the point on which so many people have written off the aircraft in favor of the missile .	47.819374
but remember this -- it isn ' t the aircraft which is vulnerable to nuclear rockets , it is the airfield .	53.449615
eliminate the vulnerability of aircraft on the ground and you have essentially eliminated its vulnerability to long-range ballistic missiles .	45.487495
there are four rather obvious ways to reduce or eliminate the vulnerability of aircraft on the ground	15.872323
put aircraft in `` bomb-proof ' ' hangars when they are on the ground .	29.48234
build long-range aircraft which can take off from small ( 3 , 000-foot ) airfields with runways .	57.56694
if we could use all the small airfields we have in this country , we could disperse our strategic aircraft by a factor of 10 or more .	43.62408
use nuclear propulsions to keep our long-range military aircraft in the air for the majority of their useful life .	40.730324
using very high thrust-to-weight ratio engines , develop a vertical-takeoff-and-landing ( vtol ) long-range military aircraft .	21.097147
we have the technology today with which to build aircraft shelters which could withstand at least 200 aj .	32.02346
we could put a portion of our strategic bombers in such shelters .	18.808784
large , long-range bombers can be developed which would have the capability to take off from 3 , 000-foot runways , but they would require more powerful engines than we have today .	30.004414
there is little enthusiasm for spending money to develop more powerful engines because of the erroneous belief that the aircraft has been made obsolete by the missile .	36.486965
this same preoccupation with missiles at the expense of aircraft has resulted in our half-hearted effort to develop nuclear propulsion for aircraft .	22.81641
one seldom hears the analogy `` nuclear propulsion will do for the aircraft what it has already done for the submarine ' ' .	26.908598
if , for some reason such as economy , we are not going to develop aircraft nuclear propulsion with a sense of national urgency , then we should turn our effort to developing jet engines with a thrust-to-weight ratio of 12 or 15 to one .	40.102356
with powerplants such as these , vertical takeoff and landing combat aircraft could be built .	21.621193
for example , a 12-to-one engine would power a supersonic vtol fighter .	5.751444
with a 15-to-one engine , a supersonic aircraft weighing 300 , 000 pounds could rise vertically .	93.15862
the reason that we are not going ahead full speed to develop high thrust-to-weight engines is that it would cost perhaps a billion dollars -- and you don ' t spend that sort of money if aircraft are obsolete .	46.96769
when aircraft are no longer helpless on airfields , they are no longer vulnerable to aj .	13.967205
if our sac bombers were , today , capable of surviving a surprise missile attack and because of infinite dispersion or long endurance had the capability to strike at russia again , and again , and again , those bombers would unquestionably assure our military dominance .	73.5005
we would have the means to seek out and destroy the enemy ' s force -- whether it were fixed or mobile .	28.348495
with such a force of manned bombers we could bring enormous pressure to bear on an enemy , and this pressure would be selective and extremely discriminating .	35.668335
no need to kill an entire city and all its people because we lacked the precision and reconnaissance to selectively disarm the enemy ' s military force .	26.69698
our first necessity , at the very outset of war , is post-attack reconnaissance .	34.356052
in a few years we will have samos ( semiautomatic missile observation system ) .	18.73135
but in the case of moving targets , and targets which have limited mobility , what will their location be when it is time to destroy them ? ?	71.05485
what targets have we successfully knocked out ? ?	1.0051217
a ballistic missile cannot , today , tell you if it was successful or unsuccessful .	80.16535
what targets still remain to be hit ? ?	1.0050193
these crucial questions must be answered by post-attack reconnaissance .	2.1211672
samos will be hard put to see through clouds -- and to see in the dark .	33.99838
even if this is some day possible , there remains the 30-minute time of flight of a missile to its overseas target .	39.850105
if the target can change its position significantly during the 30 minutes the missile is in the air on its way , the probability of the missile destroying the target is drastically reduced .	49.58337
pre-attack reconnaissance is vital but only post-attack reconnaissance will allow us to terminate the war favorably .	37.79567
it would be priceless to have an aircraft to gather that post-attack reconnaissance .	32.941086
it could operate under the clouds and perform infrared photography through clouds and at night .	23.875475
