when painting , mason ' s physical eyes are half-closed , while his mind ' s eye is wide open , and this circumstance accounts in part for the impression he wishes to convey .	59.815178
he does not insist on telling all he knows about any given subject	175.60492
rather his pictures invite the observer to draw on his memory , his imagination , his nostalgia .	27.882616
it is for this reason that roy avoids selecting subjects that require specific recognition of place for their enjoyment .	157.6943
his pictures generalize , though they are inspired by a particular locale	45.609478
they universalize in terms of weather , skies , earth , and people .	43.414757
by dealing with common landscape in an uncommon way , roy mason has found a particular niche in american landscape art .	26.032948
living with his watercolors is a vicarious experience of seeing nature distilled through the eyes of a sensitive interpretor , a breath and breadth of the outdoor world to help man honor the creator of it all .	53.077435
the artist was born in gilbert mills , new york , in 1886 , and until two years ago when he and his wife moved to california , he lived in western new york , in batavia .	29.964622
when i looked up the actual date of his birth and found it to be march 15th , i realized that roy was born under the right zodiacal sign for a watercolorist the water sign of pisces ( february 18 thru march 20 ) .	58.35461
and how very often a water plane is featured in his landscapes , and how appropriate that he should appear in american artist again , in his natal month of march ! !	68.44769
over the years , beginning in 1929 , mason has been awarded seventeen major prizes including two gold medals	113.125084
the blair purchase prize for watercolor , art institute of chicago	108.70038
and others in buffalo , new york , chautauqua , new haven , rochester , rockport , and most recently , the $300 prize for a watercolor at the laguna beach art association ,	14.4466715
he was elected to the national academy of design as an associate in the oil class in 1931 ( after receiving his first ranger fund purchase prize at the academy in 1930 ) , and elevated to academicianship in 1940 .	49.53122
other memberships include the american watercolor society , philadelphia water color club , allied artists of america , audubon artists , baltimore watercolor society .	120.400925
the russian gymnasts beat the tar out of the american gymnasts in the 1960 olympics for one reason -- they were better .	32.98231
they were better trained , better looking , better built , better disciplined and something else -- they were better dancers .	89.34276
our athletes are only just beginning to learn that they must study dance .	78.06171
the russians are all trained as dancers before they start to study gymnastics .	26.455198
after all , we did pretty well in some other areas of the olympics competition .	17.86777
but if it is important , what can we do to improve ourselves ? ?	26.179613
it is more than just lack of dance training that is our problem , for just as gymnastics can learn from dance , dance has some very important things to learn from gymnastics .	63.194717
taking first things first , let ' s understand the sport called gymnastics .	81.264046
it is made up of tumbling , which might be said to start with a somersault , run through such stunts as headstands , handstands , cartwheels , backbends , and culminate in nearly impossible combinations of aerial flips and twists and apparatus work .	17.475372
the apparatus used by gymnasts was once a common sight in american gyms , but about 1930 it was dropped in favor of games .	41.519478
the parallel bars , horse , buck , springboard , horizontal bar , rings , and mats formerly in the school gyms were replaced by baseball , volleyball , basketball and football .	14.279039
but the russians use gymnastics as the first step in training for all other sports because it provides training in every basic quality except one , endurance .	100.43468
the gymnast must develop strength , flexibility , coordination , timing , rhythm , courage , discipline , persistence and the desire for perfection .	21.826256
in short , gymnastics uses every part of the body and requires a great deal of character as well .	28.280617
the addition of endurance training later , when the body is mature enough to benefit from it without danger of injury , provides that final quality that makes the top athlete , soldier or citizen .	127.42645
another reason gymnastic study is valuable is that it can be started very early in life .	64.14772
( an enterprising teacher or parent could start training a healthy child at the age of seven days .	49.804504
most europeans have been exercising newborn infants for centuries .	12.102944
) in most sports , as in most walks of life , the angels are on the side of those who begin young , and the russian competitor of 16 has at least thirteen years of training behind him .	49.35214
the american is very lucky if he has three .	567.4203
if a nation wished to get a head start in physical fitness over all other nations , it would start its kindergarten students on a program of gymnastics the day they entered and thus eliminate a large number of the problems that plague american schools .	94.65309
first of the problems attacked would be fatigue and emotional tension , since action relieves both .	83.51139
oddly enough , it is proven that there would be less reading difficulty .	130.90341
certainly there would be less anxiety , fewer accidents ( it is the clumsy child who sustains the worst injuries ) , and higher scholastic averages , since alert children work better .	54.231697
russia knows this , and that is why there were over 800 , 000 competing for places as candidates for the olympic gymnastic team .	32.456047
eighty thousand won top honors and a chance to try for the team itself .	54.72237
we could scarcely find eighty in our great land of over 180 million people .	46.40639
and what has dancing to do with all this ? ?	31.332373
russia ' s young gymnasts have studied dance before having the rigorous training on apparatus .	32.248352
well-stretched , trained in posture and coordinated movement , and wedded to rhythm , they presented the audiences in rome with one of the most beautiful sights ever seen at any olympic contest .	32.873863
american audiences in particular learned two valuable lessons .	6.295661
they saw completely masculine and obviously virile men performing with incredible grace .	31.648428
they were further stripped of old wive ' s tales by seeing the slender , lovely russian girls performing feats requiring tremendous strength and with not one bulging muscle .	34.92988
president kennedy has asked that we become a physically fit nation .	111.171906
if we wait until children are in junior high or high school , we will never manage it .	43.619743
to be fit , one has to start early with young children , and today the only person who really reaches such children is the teacher of dance .	172.30707
if the dance teachers of america make it their business to prepare their young charges for the gymnastics that must come some day if our schools are really responsible , we will be that much ahead .	143.95827
school teachers , all too unprepared for the job they must do , will need demonstrators .	67.66665
there should be youngsters who know how to do a headstand , and also how to help other children learn it .	76.739746
they should know simple exercises that could prepare less fortunate children for the sports we will demand be taught .	243.37097
dance teachers can respond to president kennedy ' s request not only through their regular dance work , but also through the kind of basic gymnastic work that makes for strength and flexibility .	66.1255
very little in today ' s living provides the strength we need and nothing provides the flexibility .	194.0836
they often fail , however , to develop real abdominal , back , chest , shoulder and arm strength .	37.5209
ask any group of ballerinas to do ten push-ups or three chin-ups and the results , considering the amount of physical training they have had , will be very disappointing .	68.78418
even the boys will not be outstanding in these areas .	22.760746
this isn ' t surprising when we consider that over 29 percent of the 11-year-old boys in america cannot chin themselves once , and that english school girls outdo them in almost every test ( even dashes and endurance ) .	66.0221
the only area in which american boys hold their own is the baseball throw .	47.950233
for arm and shoulder strength a chinning bar is recommended .	104.44038
it should be installed over a door that is in full view of everyone , and a chair should be placed under it , a little to one side .	59.59272
those children who can chin themselves should be told to do one chin-up each time they pass under it .	140.20387
those who are too weak , should climb on the chair and , starting at the top of the chin , let themselves slowly down .	36.95002
when they can take ten seconds to accomplish the descent , they will have the strength to chin-up .	34.64562
parents should be informed about this system and encouraged to do the same with the whole family at home .	35.531487
arm , shoulder , chest , upper and lower back strength will be aided with the horse kick .	41.972885
keeping the hands in the starting position , run in place to a quick rhythm .	57.55613
after this has become easy , use slower and slower rhythms , kicking higher and higher .	46.69915
follow this by crossing from one corner of the room to the other on all fours , kicking as high as possible .	47.352394
push-ups are essential , but few have the strength for them at first .	99.393456
start on the knees in a large circle .	4.830759
fall slowly forward onto the hands and let the body down to rest on the floor .	23.45155
do this exercise six times each class period .	7.401945
as strength improves start in a standing position with legs wide apart and upper body bent forward .	27.805384
start by falling forward to a point close to the feet , and , as strength improves , fall farther and farther out .	34.232334
try to push back to the stand position from the stretched position without any intermediate pushes from the hands .	44.04208
the push-up itself can be taught by starting at the top of the push-up with legs spread wide .	62.13439
let the body down slowly , taking at least five seconds for the letting down .	66.60052
five of these done daily for about a week will develop the strength for one push-up .	108.630066
handstands come after arms , chest and shoulders have developed at least a minimum of strength .	50.203175
of course those who have developed more will find them easier .	172.96529
start with the class standing in a circle , with weight on the right foot and the left extended a little way into the circle .	60.134594
at first each child should do a kick-up by himself so that the teacher can determine those ready to work alone , and those who need help .	112.66208
drop both hands to the floor and at the same time kick the right foot up in back .	44.74106
the right will land first , followed by the left .	40.021923
care should be taken to see that the hands are placed on the floor before the kick starts and also that the landing foot is brought as close to the hands as possible .	58.02345
this will prevent flat falls and toe injuries .	1.8742552
bare feet are better for such work than any form of slipper .	34.132015
eventually the class will be able to kick up high enough so that the teacher can catch the leading leg .	128.7112
the child should then bring both legs together overhead , point the toes and tighten the seat muscles .	52.036434
be sure that the landing foot is brought close to the hands and that only one foot lands at a time .	54.17834
the backbend is of extreme importance to any form of free gymnastics , and , as with all acrobatics , the sooner begun the better the results .	51.082874
have the class lie supine with knees apart and bent .	19.411133
place flat palms on either side of the head a few inches away from the ears , fingers pointing toward the shoulders .	51.244137
arch the back upwards to make a bridge .	8.971394
be sure the head drops backward so that the child looks at the floor rather than toward the ceiling .	49.93279
as flexibility improves , the feet will move closer to the hands and the bridge rise higher .	128.0389
later this can be combined with the handstand to provide a walkover .	16.205023
to further increase back flexibility , work on the back circle .	21.924845
place the hands in front of the chest .	2.7003381
keep the legs straight and the toes pointed .	6.5238113
straighten the arms slowly , this arches the back .	33.35852
at the peak of the arch , tip the head back and bend the knees in an effort to touch toes to head .	50.44215
improvement can be measured by the lessening distance between toes and head .	11.104277
the last essential to the beginner ' s gymnastic program is the somersault , or forward roll .	42.5412
this used to be part of every child ' s bag of tricks , but few children can do it today	57.85967
some are actually incapable of rolling forward and are completely confused when not sitting or standing upright .	142.66827
for most small children , learning a forward roll is simply a matter of copying another child who can .	63.16001
after it has been seen , have the child start on a mat on hands and knees ( a thin , inexpensive mat is quite sufficient for anything that does not require falling ) .	59.076775
he places the hands on either side of the head , keeping the chin down on the chest .	18.521788
he then pushes his seat into the air and the teacher guides it over .	49.874718
one or two practice runs should be sufficient for solo .	25.511255
if , however , the child is weak , overweight , or afraid , more help will be needed .	54.554626
when the child raises his seat into the air , the teacher takes hold under both sides of the pelvis	54.13031
then no matter what happens , the child ' s performance will be controlled .	25.271456
by lifting the seat upwards a little , the weight is taken off the neck and the back is kept rounded .	37.755596
these are beginnings , but correctly learned they prepare for satisfying and exciting stunts that can be performed by a strong , flexible body ( we are not talking of eccentric extremes ) .	60.78944
even if gymnastics are not the ultimate goal , the good tumbler will be a better dancer , a better athlete , and a human being with a greater margin of safety in any activity .	41.331192
it is very important for parents to understand that early training is imperative .	40.389103
and dancing school , so helpful in artistic and psychological development , also contributes to this essential early training -- and can contribute even more .	83.45673
every taxpayer is well aware of the vast size of our annual defense budget and most of our readers also realize that a large portion of these expenditures go for military electronics .	68.131714
we have noted how some electronic techniques , developed for the defense effort , have evenutally been used in commerce and industry .	66.08831
the host of novel applications of electronics to medical problems is far more thrilling because of their implication in matters concerning our health and vitality .	50.59998
when we consider the electronic industry potential for human betterment , the prospect is staggering .	24.05035
the author has recently studied the field of medical electronics and has been convinced that , in this area alone , the application of electronic equipment has enormous possibilities .	50.829033
the benefits electronics can bring to bio-medicine may be greater by far than any previous medical discovery .	103.88661
we use the term `` bio-medicine ' ' because of the close interrelation between biology and medical research .	24.073963
electronics has been applied to medicine for many years in the form of such familiar equipment as the x-ray machine , the electrocardiograph , and the diathermy machine .	22.56565
recently many doctors have installed ultrasonic vibration machines for deep massage of bruises , contusions , and simple bursitis .	9.965651
commonly used electronic devices which are found in practically every hospital are closed-circuit tv and audio systems for internal paging and instruction , along with radiation counters , timers , and similar devices .	30.961166
in this article we will concentrate on the advances in the application of electronics in bio-medical research laboratories because this is where tomorrow ' s commonplace equipment originates .	48.234695
from the wealth of material and the wide variety of different electronic techniques perfected in the past few years we have selected a few examples which appear to be headed for use in the immediate future and which offer completely new tools in medical research .	50.94229
many cells , bacteria , and other microorganisms are transparent to visible light and must be stained for microscopic investigation .	19.929144
this stain often disrupts the normal cell activity or else colors only the outside .	234.3244
a completely new insight into living cells and their structure will be possible by use of a new technique which replaces visible light with ultraviolet radiation and combines a microscope with a color-tv system to view the results .	35.588104
fig . 1 is a simplified block diagram of the ultraviolet microscopy system developed at the medical electronics center of rockefeller institute .	25.244682
by combining the talents of a medical man , dr . aterman , a biophysicist , mr . berkely , and an electronics expert , dr . zworykin , this novel technique has been developed which promises to open broad avenues to understanding life processes .	28.663471
three different wavelengths of ultraviolet radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources .	25.147
these wavelengths are reflected in sequence through the specimen by the rotating mirror	11.215357
instead of the observer ' s eye the image orthicon in the tv camera does the `` looking ' ' .	43.10017
the microscope and orthicon are both selected to operate well into the ultraviolet spectrum , which means that all lenses must be quartz .	41.15566
the video signal is amplified and then switched , in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of a second only one wavelength , corresponding to red , green , or blue , is seen .	48.749535
( note because of light leakage from one ultraviolet source to another , the lights are switched by a commutator-like assembly rotated by a synchronous motor .	14.798996
this assembly also supplies a 20-cps switching gate for the electronics circuitry .	12.719938
) this is the same system as was used in the field-sequential color-tv system which preceded the present simultaneous system .	17.826996
three separate amplifiers then drive a 21-inch tricolor tube .	5.278115
the result is a color picture of the specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet wavelengths .	34.742855
many of the cells and microorganisms which are transparent to visible light , absorb or reflect the much shorter wavelengths of the ultraviolet spectrum .	17.039892
different parts of these cells sometimes absorb or reflect different wavelengths so that it is often possible to see internal portions of cells in a different color .	55.457127
where the microscope under visible light may show only vague shadows or nothing at all , ultraviolet illumination and subsequent translation into a color tv picture reveal a wealth of detail .	104.520134
at the present time the research team which pioneered this new technique is primarily interested in advancing and perfecting it .	40.992416
the medical title of `` lobar ventilation in man ' ' by drs . c . j . martin and a . c . young , covers a brief paper which is one part of a much larger effort to apply electronics to the study of the respiratory process .	30.381159
at the university of washington medical school , the electronics group has developed the `` respiratory gas analyzer ' ' shown in fig . 3 .	29.499327
this unit , affectionately dubbed `` the monster ' ' , can be wheeled to any convenient location and provides a wealth of information about the patient ' s breathing .	32.688744
in the lower center rack an 8-channel recorder indicates the percentage of carbon dioxide and nitrogen from the upper and lower lobes of one lung , the total volume of inhalation per breath , the flow of air from both lobes , and the pressure of the two lobes with respect to each other .	18.916862
usually the patient breathes into a mouthpiece while walking a treadmill , standing still , or in some other medically significant position .	62.02889
from the resulting data the doctor can determine lung defects with hitherto unknown accuracy and detail .	47.647984
the original electrocardiograph primarily indicates irregularities in the heartbeat , but today ' s techniques allow exact measurements of the flow of blood through the aorta , dimensioning of the heart and its chambers , and a much more detailed study of each heartbeat .	33.944412
for many of these measurements the chest must be opened , but the blood vessels and the heart itself remain undisturbed .	19.812956
a group of researchers at the university of washington have given a paper which briefly outlines some of these techniques .	102.297455
one simple method of measuring the expansion of the heart is to tie a thin rubber tube , filled with mercury , around the heart and record the change in resistance as the tube is stretched .	63.52378
a balanced resistance bridge and a pen recorder are all the electronic instrumentation needed .	89.58362
sonar can be used to measure the thickness of the heart by placing small crystal transducers at opposite sides of the heart or blood vessel and exciting one with some pulsed ultrasonic energy .	33.52957
the travel time of sound in tissue is about 1500 meters per second	31.559412
thus it takes about 16 msec . to traverse 25 mm . of tissue .	10.54877
a sonar or radar-type of pulse generator and time-delay measuring system is required for body-tissue evaluation .	36.103104
in addition to the heart and aorta , successful measurements of liver and spleen have also been made by this technique .	69.11473
the doppler effect , using ultrasonic signals , can be employed to measure the flow of blood without cutting into the blood vessel .	20.98269
a still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining the effective power of the heart itself .	18.001438
it uses both an ultrasonic dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor inserted into the bloodstream .	9.76612
the latter measures the heat carried away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood flow .	11.817997
it is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer , mounted at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart ' s left ventricle , to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself .	15.990474
this pressure measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning measurement is made .	21.517145
a simplified version of the instrumentation for this procedure is shown in fig . 2 .	12.3385725
outputs of the two systems are measured by a pulse-timing circuit and a resistance bridge , followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder .	18.870457
from this doctors can read heart rate , change in diameter , pressure , and effective heart power .	145.85696
several years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal pressure data to external receivers .	49.627377
this original capsule contained a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm . in diameter .	14.705681
battery life limited the use of this `` pill ' ' to about 8 to 30 hours maximum .	44.82092
a refinement of this technique has been described by drs . zworykin and farrar and mr . berkely of the medical electronics center of the rockefeller institute .	8.466781
in this novel arrangement the `` pill ' ' is much smaller and contains only a resonant circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure-sensing transducer .	23.114267
as shown in fig . 4 , an external antenna is placed over or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400-kc . bursts .	40.363277
the energy received by the `` pill ' ' causes the resonant circuit to `` ring ' ' on after the burst and this `` ringing ' ' takes place at the resonant frequency of the `` pill ' ' .	19.54259
these frequencies are amplified and detected by the fm receiver after each burst of transmitted energy and , after the `` pill ' ' has been calibrated , precise internal pressure indications can be obtained .	29.0077
one of the advantages of this method is that the `` pill ' ' can remain in the patient for several days , permitting observation under natural conditions .	25.069675
applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are planned for future experiments .	90.14672
one of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine detection is in the exploration of the human body .	23.356043
our readers are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects .	75.40982
various methods of pulsing , scanning , and displaying these sound waves are used to detect submarines , map ocean floors , and even communicate under water .	41.148987
in medicine the frequencies are much higher , transducers and the sonar beams themselves are much smaller , and different scanning techniques may be used , but the principles involved are the same as in sonar .	38.31623
because the body contains so much liquid , transmission of ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels .	71.0603
bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic signals .	13.480332
based on this phenomenon , a number of investigators have used this method to `` look through ' ' human organs .	76.00971
a good example of the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers presented by dr . g . baum who has explored the human eye .	24.12223
he can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate blindness due to glaucoma .	105.194626
the method used to scan the eye ultrasonically is illustrated in fig . 6 .	11.9289465
the transducer is coupled to the body through a water bath , not shown .	46.556873
for display , dr . baum uses a portion of an af , an airborne radar indicator , and then photographs the screen to obtain a permanent record .	22.47325
a typical `` sonogram ' ' of a human eye , together with a description of the anatomical parts , is shown in fig . 5 .	35.141857
the frequency used for these experiments is 15 mc . and the transducer is a specially cut crystal with an epoxy lens capable of providing beam diameters smaller than one millimeter .	17.420443
the transducer itself moves the beam in a sector scan , just like a radar antenna , while the entire transducer structure is moved over a 90-degree arc in front of the eye to `` look into ' ' all corners .	41.856167
the total picture is only seen by the camera which integrates the many sector scans over the entire 90-degree rotation period .	28.851833
drs . howry and holmes at the university of colorado medical school have applied the same sonar technique to other areas of soft tissue and have obtained extremely good results .	72.140076
by submerging the patient in a tub and rotating the transducer while the scanning goes on , they have been able to get cross-section views of the neck , as shown in fig . 7 , as well as many other hitherto impossible insights .	30.849
as mentioned before , bone reflects the sound energy and in fig . 7 the portion of the spine shows as the black area in the center .	30.961351
arteries and veins are apparent by their black , blood-filled centers and the surrounding white walls .	111.95615
a cross-section of a normal lower human leg is shown in fig . 8 with the various parts labeled .	29.770905
oersted ' s boyhood represented a minimal chance of either attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a span of life .	98.23868
he was born in the small danish town of rudkoebing on the island of langeland in the south-central part of denmark on august 14 , 1777 .	10.278757
his father soeren was the village apothecary whose slender income made it difficult to feed his family , let alone educate them in a town without even a school .	91.9632
the two older boys , hans and anders , his junior by a year , therefore went daily to the home of a warm and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in german	77.28345
his wife taught the two boys to read and write danish .	33.77307
other brothers later joined them for instruction with oldenburg , the wigmaker , and also arithmetic was added to bible reading , german , and danish in the informal curriculum .	21.80959
oldenburg ' s contributions were soon exhausted and the boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town ' s learned , such as the pastor , to supplement the simple teaching .	51.140465
from the town surveyor , hans learned drawing and mathematics and , from a university student , some academic subjects .	56.69334
the mayor of the town taught them english and french .	25.522316
whatever hans or anders learned separately they passed on to each other	50.016636
they read every book that they could borrow in the village .	32.189247
at 12 , hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in the apothecary shop , which helped stimulate his interest in medicine and science .	42.582073
his earlier love for literature and history remained with him for his entire life .	51.18096
in 1793 the brothers decided to enter the university of copenhagen ( founded in 1479 ) and the following spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the autumn session .	33.201004
while hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine , physics , and astronomy , his brother studied law .	31.998055
the brothers continued to help each other during their studies , sharing a joint purse , lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of their aunt .	37.052036
they supplemented their income by small government assistance , by tutoring and economizing wherever they could .	39.033134
so impressive were those serious years of study at the university that hans later wrote , `` to be perfectly free , the young man must revel in the great kingdom of thought and imagination	46.194157
there is a struggle there , in which , if he falls , it is easy for him to rise again , there is freedom of utterance there , which draws after it no irreparable consequences on society .	66.83502
i lived in this onward-driving contest where each day overcame a new difficulty , gained a new truth , or banished a previous error ' ' .	35.80085
he openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing about science .	25.709278
in this third year at the university , hans , in 1797 , was awarded the first important token of recognition , a gold medal for his essay on `` limits of poetry and prose ' ' .	33.33214
he completed his training in pharmacy also , taking his degree with high honors in 1797 , and in 1799 was awarded the degree of doctor of philosophy along with a prize for an essay in medicine .	48.056534
he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis which later was accepted in chemical practices .	235.16234
hans ' student days were at a time when europe was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in america and in france , germany and italy were rising from divisive nationalisms and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the continent .	43.176907
the new century opened with oersted beginning his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in copenhagen and as lecturer at the university .	25.042517
he was stirred by the announcement of volta ' s discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis .	34.84131
the following year he devoted to the customary `` wanderjahr ' ' , traveling in germany , france , and the netherlands , meeting the philosophers schelling , fichte , and tieck .	12.737032
he also met count rumford ( born benjamin thompson in woburn , mass . ) who was then serving the elector of bavaria , and the physicist ritter	17.133982
these were oersted ' s main contacts in science .	426.4606
from gottingen ( 1801 ) where he stayed for 10 days , he wrote , `` the first question asked everywhere is about galvanism .	37.2071
as everybody is curious to see the battery of glass tubes i have invented , i have had quite a small one made here of four glass tubes ( in copenhagen i used 30 ) and intend to carry it with me ' ' .	73.5182
oersted joined ritter at jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks , continuing their correspondence after he left .	199.51518
with ritter he was exposed to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host ' s fertile but disorganized mind .	37.818855
oersted remodeled ritter ' s notes into an essay in french which was submitted to the institut de france for its annual prize of 3 , 000 francs .	24.716478
the sound discoveries of this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize was never awarded to him .	61.145164
in may , 1803 , ritter , in another flight of fancy , wrote to oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy .	56.010967
he related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided with the years of important electrical discoveries .	28.926718
thus , 1745 corresponded to the invention of the `` leiden ' ' jar by kleist , 1764 that of the electrophorus by wilcke , 1782 produced the condenser of volta , and 1801 the voltaic pile .	12.109905
ritter proceeded , `` you now emerge into a new epoch in which late in the year 1819 or 1820 , you will have to reckon .	32.05229
ritter died in 1810 and oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of it .	61.335144
in 1803 oersted returned to copenhagen and applied for the university ' s chair in physics but was rejected because he was probably considered more a philosopher than a physicist .	32.99536
however , he continued experimenting and lecturing , publishing the results of his experiments in german and danish periodicals .	27.983297
in 1806 his ambition was realized and he became professor of physics at the copenhagen university , though not realizing full professorship ( ordinarius ) until 1817 .	25.04349
during oersted ' s attendance at the university , it was poorly equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences .	40.828075
he was , however , fortunate in his contact with prof . j . g . l . manthey ( 1769-1842 ) , teacher of chemistry , who , in addition to his academic chair , was also proprietor of the `` lion pharmacy ' ' in copenhagen where oersted assisted him .	20.81471
manthey maintained a valuable collection of physical and chemical apparatus which was at oersted ' s disposal during and after his graduation .	47.06141
in 1800 , manthey went abroad and oersted was appointed manager of the lion pharmacy .	17.919756
in february 1801 , oersted did manage to experiment with physical apparatus and reported experiments made with a voltaic battery of 600 plates of zinc and silver and of later experiments with a battery of 60 plates of zinc and lead .	48.24835
in the following year , 1803 , oersted , simultaneously with davy , discovered that acids increased the strength of a voltaic battery more than did salts .	41.578506
eager as he was to pursue this promising line , he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university that he could devote only sunday afternoons to `` galvanizing ' ' .	27.422543
he assumed his academic career with the same intensity and thoroughness that had marked every step in his rise from boyhood .	73.16199
the university was the only one in denmark and the status of professor represented the upper social level .	69.453094
his broad interest in literary , political , and philosophical movements opened many doors to him .	85.98875
his friends were numerous and their ties to him were strong .	55.23257
the years 1812 and 1813 saw him in germany and france again , but on this visit to berlin he did not seek out the philosophers as he had on his first journey .	56.464264
in berlin he published his views of the chemical laws of nature in german and this was issued in french translation ( paris , 1813 ) under the title recherches sur l ' identite des forces chimiques et electriques , a work held in very high esteem by the new generation of research chemists .	32.316685
his interest in finding a relationship between voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated .	37.713352
chapter 8 , is entitled `` on magnetism ' ' and in it are included such remarks as , `` one has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces with the electrical forces .	40.599224
the great resemblance between electrical and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their laws necessarily would bring about this comparison .	87.504326
it is true , that nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication	207.68924
but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest difference .	63.465107
the form of galvanic activity is halfway between the magnetic form and the electrical form .	46.032818
there , forces are more latent than in electricity , and less than in magnetism .	46.372566
but in such an important question , we would be satisfied if the judgment were that the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity and magnetism were only a difficulty , and not a thing which is contrary to it .	78.30033
one could also add to these analogies that steel loses its magnetism by heat , which proves that steel becomes a better conductor through a rise in temperature , just as electrical bodies do .	195.5137
it is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature , as proven by bruckmann and coulomb .	33.336647
by that , one feels that magnetic forces are as general as electrical forces .	67.724464
an attempt should be made to see if electricity , in its most latent stage , has any action on the magnet as such ' ' .	59.76312
oersted returned in 1814 and resumed an active part in university and political discussions .	26.267982
in one debate he supported the freedom of judgment as opposed to dogma , in another he held that the practice of science was in fact an act of religious worship .	87.19141
he devised a detonating fuse in which a short wire was caused to glow by an electric current .	30.495632
in 1819 under royal command he undertook a very successful geological expedition to bornholm , one of the danish islands , being one of three scientists in the expedition .	18.46574
it was with the assistance of one of the members of this expedition , lauritz esmarch , that oersted succeeded in producing light by creating an electric discharge in mercury vapor through which an electric current was made to flow .	34.221912
together they also developed a new form of voltaic cell in which the wooden trough was replaced by one of copper , thereby producing stronger currents .	19.576502
esmarch was among those who witnessed oersted ' s first demonstration of his discovery .	18.731466
the association between electric ( both electrostatic and voltaic ) forces and magnetic forces had been recognized by investigators for many decades .	28.181976
electrical literature contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and had altered the polarity of compass needles .	35.260593
in the late 1700 ' s beccaria and van marum , among others , had magnetized iron by sending an electrostatic charge through it .	49.48904
beccaria had almost stumbled on a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge from a leyden jar was sent transversally through a piece of watch-spring steel making its ends magnetic .	22.304533
the resulting magnetic effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise .	13.231721
the experiments of romagnosi and others have already been noted but no one had determined the cause-and-effect relationship between these two primary forces .	58.35408
oersted ' s own earlier experiments were unimpressive , possibly because he had , like other experimenters , laid the conducting wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it .	69.904625
the sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the university related that the first direct event that led to the publication of oersted ' s discovery occurred during a private lecture made before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820 .	48.570927
at this lecture oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel to a magnetic needle .	44.009182
knowing specifically what the many feed additives can do and how and when to feed them can make a highly competitive business more profitable for beef , dairy , and sheep men .	69.6764
the target chart quickly and briefly tells you which additives do what .	232.30186
all the additives listed here are sanctioned for use by the food and drug administration of the federal government .	29.676865
all comments concerning effectiveness and use of drugs have been carefully reviewed by a veterinary medical officer with aj .	23.383106
this article assumes that the rations you are feeding your beef , dairy cattle , and sheep are adequately balanced with protein , vitamins , and minerals .	12.9416685
the drug ' s chemical name is listed , since most states require feed processors to use this name instead of the trade name on the feed tag .	89.69624
in some instances , the trade name is shown in parentheses following the chemical name .	113.25738
this indicates that this drug is being marketed under one trade name only or state regulatory organizations have approved its use on the feed tag .	154.31451

there are three principal feed bunk types for dairy and beef cattle ( 1 ) fence-line bunks -- cattle eat from one side while feed is put in from the opposite side of the fence by self-unloading wagons	32.29133
( 2 ) mechanized bunks -- they sit within the feed lot , are filled by a mechanical conveyor above feeding surface	116.572945
( 3 ) special bunks -- as discussed here , they permit cattle to eat from all sides .	70.74881
several materials or combinations of materials can be used to construct a satisfactory feed bunk .	24.090597
the selection of materials depends on skills of available labor for installation , cost of materials available locally , and your own preference .	88.98753
no one material is best for all situations .	3.1956627
selecting bunks by economic comparison is usually an individual problem .	14.3856735
animals eat only from one side , so the fence-line bunk must be twice as long as the mechanical bunk .	18.088749
these bunks also serve as a fence , so part of the additional cost must be attributed to the fence .	131.16359
because of their location , on the edge of the feed lot , fence-line bunks are not in the way of mechanical manure removal .	24.806065
filling these bunks by the same self-unloading wagons used to fill silos spreads cost of the wagons over more time and operations .	77.17967
all-weather roads must be provided next to the feeding floor so access will be possible all year .	413.4297
this will be a problem in areas of heavy snowfall .	244.36185
marketing in the new decade will be no picnic -- for the sixties will present possibly the most intense competitive activity that you have experienced in the last 20-25 yrs . .	59.279327
companies of all types have made great advances in production capabilities and efficiencies -- in modern equipment and new processes , enlarged r & d facilities , faster new product development .	64.91347
many companies have upgraded their sales manpower and tested new selling , distribution , and promotion techniques to gain a bigger competitive edge .	150.12451
given this kind of business climate , what competitive marketing problems will your company face in the next 10 yrs . ? ?	43.45585
based on our experience with clients , , we see 14 major problems which fall into three broad groups -- the market place itself , marketing methods , and marketing management .	115.13608
there has been an intensification of price-consciousness in recent years	17.143732
frequently , wittingly or unwittingly , price-consciousness has been fostered by manufacturers , distributors , and dealers .	15.495949
despite generally good levels of income , we see greater price pressures than ever before -- traveling back along the chain from consumer to distributor to manufacturer .	170.76434
here are some key areas to examine to make sure your pricing strategy will be on target	101.33739
has the probable price situation in your field been forecast as a basis for future planning ? ?	79.34705
have cost studies been made of every phase of your operation to determine what might be done if things get worse ? ?	41.031303
have you actually checked out ( not just mentally tested ) different selling approaches designed to counter the price competition problem ? ?	83.0231
average consumer is becoming more sophisticated regarding product and advertising claims , partly because of widespread criticism of such assertions .	43.84044
this problem can force a change in marketing approach in many kinds of businesses .	46.305096
have you examined this problem of increasing consumer sophistication from the standpoint of your own company ? ?	14.701772
need for service is here to stay -- and the problem is going to be tougher to solve in the sixties .	16.515484
first , most products tend to become more complex .	15.166278
second , in a competitive market , the customer feels his weight and throws it around .	102.985504
providing good customer service requires as thorough a marketing and general management planning job as the original selling of the product .	128.39961
too often it is thought of at the last moment of new product introduction .	138.59888
good service starts with product design and planning many products seem to be designed for a production economy , not for a service one .	105.32463
proper follow-through requires training your own sales organization , and your distributor organizations , not only in the techniques but also in good customer relations .	60.740936
have you assessed the importance of service and given it proper attention ? ?	127.43551
in spending his money today , the consumer is pulled in many directions .	43.436394
to the manufacturer of the more convenient-type product -- the purchase of which can be switched , delayed , or put off entirely -- the implications are important .	46.26282
your competition is now proportionately greater -- you are competing not only against manufacturers in the same field but also against a vast array of manufacturers of other appealing consumer products .	58.74962
many industry trade associations are developing campaigns to protect or enhance the share of the consumer ' s dollar being spent on their particular products .	58.87407
has your company thought through its strategy in this whole `` discretionary buying ' ' area ? ?	29.054726
the trends have been in evidence for many years -- population shifts to the southwest and far west , and from city to suburbs .	80.404236
these shifts will continue in the next 10 yrs . .	4.109026
have you considered the implications of continuing geographic shifts in terms of sales force allocation , strength of distributor organizations , and even plant location ? ?	67.328995
we have already witnessed great changes through mergers and acquisitions in the food industry -- at both the manufacturing and retail ends .	77.83761
instead of relatively small sales to many accounts , there are now larger sales to or through fewer accounts .	91.16926
the change may require different products , pricing , packaging , warehousing , salesmanship , advertising and executive attention -- practically every link in the marketing network may have to be adjusted .	34.41462

in the area of private label competition , it is logical to expect a continuation of trends which have been under way during the first decade .	27.33176

average manufacturer frequently has helped build private brand business , delivering largely the same qualities and styles in private brand merchandise as in branded .	23.348717

with greater investments in plant facilities , with automation growing , you can ' t switch around , either in volume or in product design , as much as was formerly possible -- or at least not as economically .	101.833115
are planning and strategy development emphasized sufficiently in your company ? ?	24.283821
we find too many sales and marketing executives so burdened with detail that they are short-changing planning .	35.812504
are annual marketing plans reviewed throughout your management group to get the perspective of all individuals and get everyone on the marketing team ? ?	43.8877
do you have a long-term ( 5- or 10-yr . ) marketing program ? ?	27.372486
the key to effective marketing is wrapped up in defining your company ' s marketing problems realistically .	30.355774
solutions frequently suggest themselves when you accurately pinpoint your problems , whether they be in the market , in marketing methods or in marketing management .	35.333683
if companies will take the time to give objective consideration to their major problems and to the questions they provoke , then a long constructive step will have been taken toward more effective marketing in next decade .	97.59138
the controversy of the last few years over whether architects or interior designers should plan the interiors of modern buildings has brought clearly into focus one important difference of opinion .	62.462257
the architects do not believe that the education of the interior designer is sufficiently good or sufficiently extended to compare with that of the architect and that , therefore , the interior designer is incapable of understanding the architectural principles involved in planning the interior of a building .	34.730785
ordinary politeness may have militated against this opinion being stated so badly but anyone with a wide acquaintance in both groups and who has sat through the many round tables , workshops or panel discussions -- whatever they are called -- on this subject will recognize that the final , boiled down crux of the matter is education .	94.92646
it is true that most architectural schools have five year courses , some even have six or more .	206.45578
the element of public danger which enters so largely into architectural certification , however , would demand a prolonged study of structure .	41.508896
this would , naturally , lengthen their courses far beyond the largely esthetic demands of interior designer ' s training .	36.96048
we may then dismiss the time difference between these courses and the usual four year course of the interior design student as not having serious bearing on the subject .	94.0244
the real question that follows is -- how are those four years used and what is their value as training ? ?	143.45953
the american institute of interior designers has published a recommended course for designers and a percentage layout of such a course .	51.821728
an examination of some forty catalogs of schools offering courses in interior design , for the most part schools accredited by membership in the national association of schools of art , and a further `` on the spot ' ' inspection of a number of schools , show their courses adhere pretty closely to the recommendations .	38.589935
one or two of the schools have a five year curriculum , but the usual pattern of american education has limited most of them to the four-year plan which seems to be the minimum in acceptable institutions .	79.13946
the suggested course of the a . i . d . was based on the usual course offered and on the opinion of many educators as to curricular necessities .	54.834217
obviously , the four year provision limits this to fundamentals and much desirable material must be eliminated .	128.72961
without comparing the relative merits of the two courses -- architecture versus interior design -- let us examine the educational needs of the interior designer .	32.006554
to begin with , what is an interior designer ? ?	4.3637424
`` the dictionary of occupational titles ' ' published by the u . s . department of labor describes him as follows `` designs , plans and furnishes interiors of houses , commercial and institutional structures , hotels , clubs , ships , theaters , as well as set decorations for motion picture arts and television .	32.368877
makes drawings and plans of rooms showing placement of furniture , floor coverings , wall decorations , and determines color schemes .	17.913122
makes necessary purchases , places contracts , supervises construction , installation , finishing and placement of furniture , fixtures and other correlated furnishings , and follows through to completion of project ' ' .	23.766886
in addition to this the u . s . civil service bureau , when examining applicants for government positions as interior designers , expects that `` when various needed objects are not obtainable on the market he will design them .	93.13428
he must be capable of designing for and supervising the manufacture of any craft materials needed in the furnishings ' ' .	29.684004
the interior designer , then , must first be an artist but also understand carpentry and painting and lighting and plumbing and finance .	67.86961
yet nobody will question the necessity of all this and any reputable interior designer does know all this and does practice it .	164.99066
and further he must understand his obligation to the client to not only meet his physical necessities but also to enhance and improve his life and to enlarge the cultural horizon of our society .	38.892227
few will quarrel with the aim of the schools or with the wording of their curriculum .	34.177704
it is in the quality of the teaching of all this that a question may arise .	74.51801
the old established independent art schools try their best to fulfill their obligations .	14.057282
as in a recent design competition with a floor plan and the simple command -- `` design a luxury apartment ' '	278.57275
no description of the client or his cultural level , no assertion of geographical area or local social necessities -- simply `` a luxury apartment ' ' .	58.666447
working in a vacuum of minimal information can result only in show pieces that look good in exhibitions and catalogs and may please the public relations department but have little to do with the essence of interior design .	109.71347
it is possible , of course , to work on extant or projected buildings where either architect or owner will explain their necessities so that the student may get `` the feel ' ' of real interior design demands .	92.80964
unfortunately , the purely synthetic problem is the rule .	58.43703
it is like medical schools in india where , in that fairy-land of religious inhibition , the dissection of dead bodies is frowned upon .	30.612207
instead they learn their dissection on the bulbs of plants .	12.226828
thus technical efficiency is achieved at the expense of actual experience .	33.743412
in the earlier years of training certain phases of the work must be covered and the synthetic problem has its use .	40.47182
but to continue to divorce advanced students from reality is inexcusable .	10.790255
consultation with architects , clients , real estate men , fabric houses and furniture companies is essential to the proper development of class problems just as in actual work .	73.796555
fortunately , although only a few years ago they held the student at arms length , today the business houses welcome the opportunity to aid the student , not only from an increased sense of community responsibility but also from the realization that the student of today is the interior designer of tomorrow -- that the student already is `` in the trade ' ' .	76.15344
even the `` history of furniture ' ' can hardly be taught exclusively from photographs and lantern slides .	30.570715
here , too , the reality of actual furniture must be experienced .	57.746693
the professional organizations such as american institute of interior designers , national society of interior designers , home fashions league and various trade associations , can and do aid greatly in this work .	63.061752
certainly every educator involved in interior design should be a member and active in the work of one of these organizations .	39.193237
not only should every educator above the rank of instructor be expected to be a member of one of the professional organizations , but his first qualification for membership as an educator should be so sharply scrutinized that membership would be equivalent to certification to teach the subject .	47.511597
participation for the educator in this case , however , would have to be raised to full and complete membership .	63.664154
the largest of these organizations at present denies to the full time educator any vote on the conduct and standards of the group and , indeed , refuses him even the right to attach the customary initials after his name in the college catalog .	44.419518
this anomalous status of the educator cannot fail to lower his standing in the eyes of the students .	37.313427
the professor in turn dares not tolerate the influence in his classes of an organization in the policies and standards of which he has no voice .	67.42757
this seems somewhat shortsighted since if the absolute educational qualifications for membership which the organizations profess are ever enforced , the educator will have the molding of the entire profession in his hands .	50.17965
in one way the institutes and societies do a disservice to the schools .	19.09249
that is in the continuance of the `` grandfather clauses ' ' in their membership requirements .	24.534513
when these groups were first formed many prominent and accomplished decorators could not have had the advantage of school training since interior design courses were rare and undeveloped during their youth .	70.277985
long hard years of `` on the job ' ' training had brought them to their competence .	43.907375
the necessity of that day has long disappeared .	4.350993
there is plenty of opportunity for proper education today .	78.42543
it is discouraging for students to realize that the societies do not truly uphold the standards for which they are supposed to stand .	22.033653
the reason and the day of `` grandfather clauses ' ' has long since passed .	34.117466
no one can deny that these `` back door ' ' admissions to membership provisions have been seriously abused nor that they have not resulted in the admission of downright incompetents to membership in supposedly learned societies .	54.236107
beyond any question of curriculum and approach to subject must be the quality of the teachers themselves .	85.079475
it will occur to anyone that the teacher must have adequate education , a depth and breadth of knowledge far beyond the immediate necessities of his course plus complete dedication to his subject and to his students .	102.463005
the local decorator who rushes in for a few hours of teaching may but more likely may not have these qualifications .	113.317505
nor will the hack , the jack-of-all-trades , still found in some of the smaller art schools , suffice .	117.33602
only a few years ago a middle western college circulated a request for a teacher of interior design .	57.815712
at the end of its letter was the information that applicants for this position `` must also be prepared to teach costume design and advertising art ' ' .	64.9781
this kind of irresponsibility toward their students can scarcely build a strong professional attitude in the future designer .	51.420994
we must build a corps of highly professional teachers of interior design who have had education , experience in the profession and are willing to take on the usual accompaniments of teaching -- minimal income and minimal status among their confreres .	53.76136
considerable specialization in teaching subjects such as architecture , furniture design , textiles and color is also desirable .	52.017258
in all `` degree ' ' courses in interior design a number of `` academic ' ' or `` general studies ' ' courses are included .	21.272293
it is only fair to demand that teachers of courses in english , history , psychology and so on be as well informed in matters of art , especially interior design , as are the art teachers educated in the academic subjects .	123.739456
the proper correlation of the art with the academic can be achieved only if this standard is observed .	191.08957
the matter of sympathy of the academic professors for art objectives also must be taken into account .	95.1227
one technical question of school organization comes to mind here .	77.79364
for proper accreditation of schools , teachers in any course must have a degree at least one level above that for which the student is a candidate .	74.8638
since there are almost no schools in the country offering graduate work in interior design this rule cannot at present be observed .	160.37872
indeed , it has only been a matter of the last few years that reputable schools of art have granted degrees at all .	60.78286
the question , however , cannot be ignored for long .	137.51968
the basic problem involved is that a college setting up a graduate school must have an entirely separate faculty for the advanced degree .	113.12772
most professors in the course must , naturally , again have a higher degree than the course offers .	114.086784
one solution is the aquisition of degrees in education but it is a poor substitute .	59.103485
it is a sort of academic ring-around-a-rosy and you solve it .	79.078575
this brings us to the question of accreditation of art schools in general .	70.53659
only the independent art schools , that is , those not connected with any university or college , receive severe and separate investigation before accreditation by the various regional organizations .	120.10694
it has been the custom for most universities to stretch the blanket of accreditation for their liberal arts school to cover the shivering body of their fine arts department .	96.076385
this , plus the habit of many schools of simply adding interior design to the many subjects of their home economics department , yet , nevertheless , claiming that they teach interior design , has contributed to the low repute of many university courses in interior design .	62.948944
in spite of this , many universities offer adequate and even distinguished courses in the subject .	133.6856
there will be no mitigation of these offences until all art schools , whether independent or attached to universities have separate accreditation -- as do medical schools -- by an art accreditation group such as the `` national association of schools of art ' ' .	127.33978
independent art schools granting degrees must , naturally , follow this with academic accreditation by the appropriate regional group .	68.24889
how long has it been since you reviewed the objectives of your benefit and service program ? ?	23.906422
have you permitted it to become a giveaway program rather than one that has the goal of improved employee morale and , consequently , increased productivity ? ?	64.87337
what effort do you make to assess results of your program ? ?	9.63786
do you measure its relation to reduced absenteeism , turnover , accidents , and grievances , and to improved quality and output ? ?	16.13577
have you set specific objectives for your employee publication ? ?	27.1464
is it larger or fancier than you really need ? ?	41.16258
are you using the most economical printing methods , paper , etc . .	34.903625
are there other , cheaper communications techniques that could be substituted ? ?	11.508408
has your attitude toward employee benefits encouraged an excess of free `` government ' ' work in your plant ? ?	36.57715
is your purchasing agent offering too much free-buying service for employees ? ?	31.681528
when improvements are recommended in working conditions -- such as lighting , rest rooms , eating facilities , air-conditioning -- do you try to set a measure of their effectiveness on productivity ? ?	30.640408
when negotiating with your union , do you make sure employees have a choice between new benefits and their cents-per-hour cost in wages .	118.76846
can you consider restricting any additional employee benefits to those paid for by profit-sharing money , such as was done in the union contract recently signed by american motors corporation ? ?	114.81328
do your employees understand all the benefits to which your insurance entitles them ? ?	19.47237
are they encouraged to take full legal advantage of these benefits ? ?	22.056181
have you publicized the cents-per-hour value of the company ' s share of insurance premiums ? ?	8.416477
when did you last compare your present premium costs with the costs of insurance from other sources ? ?	76.74095
can your insurance company aid you in reducing administrative costs ? ?	21.430977
do you try to maintain the principle of employee-contributed ( as opposed to fully company-paid ) programs ? ?	35.09815
do you protect your holiday privileges with an attendance requirement both before and after the holiday ? ?	64.84837
do you plan to limit additional holidays to area and/or industrial patterns ? ?	177.02956
have you investigated the possibility of moving midweek holidays forward to monday or back to friday in order to have an uninterrupted work week ? ?	100.97601
are you carefully policing wash-up time and rest periods to be certain that all other time is productive ? ?	65.6731
are you watching work schedules for boiler operators , guards , and other 24-hour-day , 7-day-week operations in order to minimize overtime ? ?	21.207253
are you careful to restrict the number of people on leave at one time so that your total employment obligation is minimized ? ?	119.16055
have you considered using vending equipment to replace or reduce the number of cafeteria employees ? ?	40.775875
what are the possibilities for operating your cafeteria for a single shift only and relying upon vending machines or prepackaged sandwiches for the second- and third-shift operations ? ?	21.049246
have you checked the cost of subcontracting your cafeteria operation in order to save administrative costs ? ?	40.055897
are there possibilities of having cafeteria help work part-time on custodial or other jobs ? ?	23.043633
can staggered lunch periods relieve the capacity strain on your feeding facilities ? ?	28.074394
would it be feasible to limit the menu in order to reduce feeding costs ? ?	14.844443
have you considered gradual withdrawal of subsidies to your in-plant feeding operation ? ?	25.617151
are you utilizing cafeteria space for company meetings or discussions ? ?	43.623184
are your expenses in this area commensurate with the number of employees who benefit from your program ? ?	42.228825
have you audited your program recently to weed out those phases that draw least participation ? ?	168.63258
do employees contribute their share of money to recreational facilities ? ?	55.32789
have you considered delegating operational responsibility to your employee association and carefully restricting your plant ' s financial contribution ? ?	28.029652
could an employee ' s garden club take over partial care of plant grounds ? ?	92.26188
would a camera club be useful in taking pictures pertinent to plant safety ? ?	86.84278
are you spending too much money on team uniforms that benefit only a few employees ? ?	50.144608
are you utilizing vending machine proceeds to help pay for your program ? ?	22.873606
do you know the trend in your cost of maintaining access roads and parking lots ? ?	45.54487
if you use parking attendants , can they be replaced by automatic parking gates ? ?	21.595304
will your local bus company erect and/or maintain the bus stops at your plant ? ?	15.453215
if you provide inter-plant transportation , can this be replaced by available public transportation ? ?	92.27635
if you use company transportation to meet trains or to haul visitors , would taxis be cheaper ? ?	51.12321
how efficient and necessary are your intra-company vehicles ? ?	3.0254145
can part-time drivers be assigned to other productive work ? ?	41.726814
which is more economical for your plant -- a vacation shutdown or spaced vacations that require extra employees for vacation fill-ins ? ?	16.551186
can vacations be spaced throughout the 12 months to minimize the number of employee fill-ins ? ?	19.201359
do you insist that unneeded salary employees take their vacations during plant shutdowns ? ?	40.55573
what can your sales and purchasing departments do to curtail orders , shipments , and receipts during vacation shutdown periods ? ?	28.255903
is an arbitrary retirement age of 65 actually costing your plant money ? ?	40.29231
what sort of effort do you make to assure that older or disabled workers are fully productive ? ?	39.94228
would early retirement of non-productive , disabled employees reduce the number of make-work jobs ? ?	12.102973
will your union accept seniority concessions in assigning work for older or disabled employees ? ?	34.0069
can you share medical facilities and staff with neighboring plants ? ?	72.756516
if you have a full-time doctor now , can he be replaced with a part-time doctor or one who serves on a fee-per-case basis only ? ?	35.895336
can your plant nurse be replaced by a trained first-aid man who works full-time on some other assignment ? ?	81.221085
do you rigidly distinguish between job- and non-job-connected health problems and avoid treating the latter ? ?	147.77444
are you indiscriminantly offering unnecessary medical services -- flu shots , sun lamp treatments , etc . ? ?	14.391866
if you have an annual or regular physical examination program , is it worth what it is costing you ? ?	49.13626
consider what you can afford to spend and what your goals are before setting up or revamping your employee benefit program .	77.37073
too many plant officials are all too eager to buy a package program from an insurance company simply because it works for another plant .	103.374535
but even if that other plant employs the same number of workers and makes the same product , there are other facts to consider .	37.871952
in what section of the country are you located ? ?	45.256763
are you in a rural or urban area ? ?	7.9179497
these factors can make the difference between waste and efficiency in any benefit program .	74.84781
above all , don ' t set up extravagant fringe benefits just to buy employee good will .	109.35445
unions stress fringe benefits , but the individual hourly worker prefers cash every time .	62.995934
some plants go overboard on one type of fringe -- say a liberal retirement plan -- and find themselves vulnerable elsewhere .	108.7683
if you want credit for your employee services program , let your workers know what they ' re entitled to .	77.411354
this can be done by stories in your house organs , posters , special publications , letters to workers ' homes as well as by word of mouth through your chain of command .	103.642685
hallmark cards , inc . , kansas city , mo . , has a do-it-yourself quiz game called `` benefit bafflers ' ' , which it distributes to employees .	17.134369
m & r dietetic laboratories , inc . , columbus , gives all its workers a facsimile checkbook -- each check showing the amount the company spends on a particular fringe .	107.51562
u . s . rubber company , new york , passes out a form itemizing the value of benefits .	49.227417
the blue-collar worker thus knows his insurance package , for example , costs $227 . 72 .	26.76325
have the insurance company or your own accounting department break down the cost of your insurance package periodically .	48.527958
you may find certain coverage costing much more than is economically feasible , thereby alerting you to desirable revisions .	35.68542
check to see if some of your benefits -- such as on-the-job disability pay -- can be put on a direct payment rather than an insured basis at a savings to you .	76.96523
it can put an end to marginal claims which play havoc with your insurance rates .	75.22733
also , beware of open-end policies , especially in the medical field .	8.012243
this will mean that every time there ' s an increase in hospital rates your cost will go up in like manner .	97.114204
don ' t go overboard on insurance that pays benefits only upon death .	81.06651
generally , your employee will greatly appreciate benefits that protect him during his working life or during retirement .	171.14053
in granting bereavement leaves , specify the maximum time off and list what the worker ' s relation to the deceased must be to qualify .	42.911556
thus , you avoid headaches when an employee wants off for his fourth cousin ' s funeral .	45.79817
also , reserve the right to demand proof of death despite the fact that you ' ll probably never use it .	92.477516
coffee breaks can be a real headache if not regulated .	56.693504
vending machines can alleviate the long hike to the cafeteria during the break with resulting waste of production time .	98.63069
if coffee is sold at the cafeteria , let a few workers in each department get it for the whole group .	180.74571
consider installing supplemental serving lines in production areas .	2.1706188
make sure milk for the coffee is placed in dispensers rather than in containers , if you are supplying the coffee .	13.713369
otherwise , you may be saddled with a good-size milk bill by milk drinkers .	39.731922
keep the retirement age flexible so skilled craftsmen such as tool and die makers can be kept on the job for the convenience of the company .	30.160885
and so deadheads on the payroll can be eased out at the earliest possible age .	38.992264
make sure you have minimum age and time-on-the-job requirements tied into your pension plan .	103.91441
younger men usually don ' t think of pensions as an important job benefit factor anyhow and they ' re liable to change jobs several times before settling down .	114.14132
choose carefully between contributory or non-contributory pension plans .	3.0162945
there are two sides of a coin for this decision .	38.040054
workers usually think more of a plan they contribute to .	115.9297
and they can at least collect the money they put in , plus interest , when they leave the company .	162.6785
a non-contributory plan usually won ' t pay off for the worker until he retires .	33.336864
thus , there is an added incentive to stay on the job .	37.509354
make sure you don ' t pay for holidays that occur when an employee would not otherwise be working .	69.48046
these include leaves of absences , illnesses , and layoffs .	4.868945
consider adopting a system of holidays in which time off is granted with an eye to minimum inconvenience to the operation of the plant .	77.97223
it ' s usually not too hard to sell workers on this as it gives them longer holiday periods .	129.42455
for example , the friday after thanksgiving can be substituted for washington ' s birthday .	24.830318
this reduces the number of expensive plant shutdowns and startups .	4.3978586
require each employee to work his last shift both before and after the holiday to be eligible for pay .	75.046936
consider using vending machines rather than subsidized cafeterias .	3.4431512
latest models serve hot meals at reasonable prices , and at a profit to you .	26.697647
if a concessionaire runs the cafeteria , keep an eye out for quality and price .	137.07202
if the soup tastes like dishwater , your employees won ' t blame the concessionaire .	24.933743
check your cafeteria location to make sure it ' s convenient for most employees .	67.38183
you may save valuable production minutes with a change .	210.88734
spread your vacation period over the widest possible span of time or shut the plant down for two weeks .	93.61006
this will cut the expense of vacation replacements .	1.6206806
and with the shutdown method there will be no argument as to who gets the choice vacation dates .	141.21358
also make sure you have reasonable requirements as to hours worked before a production employee is entitled to a vacation .	180.9827
you might try providing standard vacation time off but make the vacation pay depend on the number of hours worked in the previous year .	39.744152
the long and ever-increasing column of sportsmen is now moving into a new era .	50.61738
modern times have changed the world beyond recognition .	3.957637
the early years of the twentieth century seem very far away .	46.910805
but with all the changes in philosophy , dress and terrain -- a few things remain constant , including the devotion of americans to the great field sports , hunting and fishing .	96.01209
as the generations move on , clothes become more suitable for the enjoyment of outdoor sports .	19.264595
sporting firearms change , markedly for the better .	66.03501
just as modern transportation has outmoded the early studebaker covered wagon , the demand of today ' s sportsmen and women has necessitated changes in their equipment .	39.144726
the american firearms and ammunition manufacturers through diligent research and technical development have replaced the muzzle loader and slow-firing single-shot arms with modern fast firing auto-loaders , extremely accurate bolt , lever , and slide action firearms .	36.88548
and millions of rounds of entirely new and modern small-arms ammunition , designed for today ' s hunting and target shooting .	32.76792
and due to modern resource-use and game management practices , there is still game to shoot , even with the ever-expanding encroachment on land and water .	59.795757
present conservation practices regard wildlife , not as an expendable natural resource , but as an annual harvest to be sown and also reaped .	25.688433
unlimited game bags are possible and legal in more than 40 states , on shooting preserves ( one of the newer phases of modern game-management ) for five and six months each year .	57.396454
close to two million game birds were harvested on 1 , 500 commercial and private shooting preserves , and on state game commission-controlled upland game areas during the 1960-61 season .	42.662975
the shooting development program of the sporting arms and ammunition manufacturers ' institute has successfully published these facts in all major outdoor magazines , many national weeklies and the trade papers .	68.19379
the most effective way to develop more places for more sportsmen to shoot is to encourage properly managed shooting preserves .	56.369488
