in the early 1950 ' s , smith , together with his distinguished colleague , george trager ( so austerely academic he sometimes fights his own evident charm ) , and a third man with the engaging name of birdwhistell ( ray ) , agreed on some basic premises about the three-part process that makes communication ( 1 ) words or language ( 2 ) paralanguage , a set of phenomena including laughing , weeping , voice breaks , and `` tone ' ' of voice , and ( 3 ) kinesics , the technical name for gestures , facial expressions , and body shifts -- nodding or shaking the head , `` talking ' ' with one ' s hands , et cetera .	43.29414
smith ' s first workout with stresses , pitches , and junctures was based on mother , which spells , in our culture , a good deal more than bread alone .	33.331818
for example , if you are a reasonably well-adjusted person , there are certain ways that are reasonable and appropriate for addressing your mother .	87.209496
the usual u . s . norm would be af middle pitches , slight pause ( juncture ) before mother , slight rise at the end .	77.595436
the symbols of mother ' s status , here , are all usual for culture u . s . a . .	99.01092
quite other feelings are evidenced by this style af note the drop to pitch 1 ( the lowest ) on mother with no rise at the end of the sentence	92.73677
this is a `` fade ' ' ending , and what you have here is a downtalking style of speech , expressing something less than conventional respect for mother .	99.90616
even less regard for mom and mom ' s apple pie goes with af in other words , the way the speaker relates to mother is clearly indicated .	117.65632
and while the meaning of the words is not in this instance altered , the quality of communication in both the second and third examples is definitely impaired .	62.626736
an accompanying record of paralanguage factors for the second example might also note a throaty rasp .	58.31333
with this seven-word sentence -- though the speaker undoubtedly thought he was dealing only with the subject of food -- he was telling things about himself and , in the last two examples , revealing that he had departed from the customs of his culture .	44.37324
the joint investigations of linguistics and psychiatry have established , in point of fact , that no matter what the subject of conversation is or what words are involved , it is impossible for people to talk at all without telling over and over again what sort of people they are and how they relate to the rest of the world .	46.909756
since interviewing is the basic therapeutic and diagnostic instrument of modern psychiatry , the recording of interviews for playbacks and study has been a boost of redstone proportions in new research and training .	32.02753
some of the earliest recordings , made in the 1940 ' s demonstrated that psychiatrists reacted immediately to anger and anxiety in the sound track , whereas written records of the same interview offered far fewer cues to therapy which -- if they were at all discernible in print -- were picked up only by the most skilled and sensitive experts .	74.66096
in a general way , psychiatrists were able to establish on a wide basis what many of them had always felt -- that the most telling cues in psychotherapy are acoustic , that such things as stress and nagging are transmitted by sound alone and not necessarily by words .	50.676113
at a minimum , recording -- usually on tape , which is now in wide professional use -- brings the psychiatric interview alive so that the full range of emotion and meaning can be explored repeatedly by the therapist or by a battery of therapists .	43.52098
newest to this high-powered battery are the experts in linguistics who have carried that minimum to a new level .	72.94013
by adding a systematic analysis with symbols to the typed transcripts of interviews , they have supplied a new set of techniques for the therapist .	21.269564
linguistic charting of the transcribed interview flags points where the patient ' s voice departs from expected norms .	54.118412
it flags such possible breakdowns of communication as rehearsed dialogue , the note of disapproval , ambivalence or ambiguity , annoyance , resentment , and the disinclination to speak at all -- this last often marked by a fade-in beginning of sentences .	26.601522
interpretation , naturally , remains the role of the therapist , but orientation -- not only the patient ' s vocal giveaways of geographical and socio-economic background , but also vocal but non-verbal giveaways of danger spots in his relationship to people -- can be considerably beefed up by the linguist .	35.3055
his esoteric chartings of the voice alert the therapist to areas where deeper probing may bring to light underlying psychological difficulties , making them apparent first to the therapist and eventually to the patient .	105.94357
in one now-historic first interview , for example , the transcript ( reproduced from the book , the first five minutes ) goes like this the therapist ' s level tone is bland and neutral -- he has , for example , avoided stressing `` you ' ' , which would imply disapproval	49.77002
or surprise , which would set the patient apart from other people .	60.46912
the patient , on the other hand , is far from neutral	482.61523
aside from her specifically regional accent , she reveals by the use of the triad , `` irritable , tense , depressed ' ' , a certain pedantic itemization that indicates she has some familiarity with literary or scientific language ( i . e . , she must have had at least a high-school education ) , and she is telling a story she has mentally rehearsed some time before .	37.426502
then she catapults into `` everything and everybody ' ' , putting particular violence on `` everybody ' ' , indicating to the linguist that this is a spot to flag -- that is , it is not congruent to the patient ' s general style of speech up to this point .	38.437305
consequently , it is referred to the therapist for attention .	99.05762
he may then very well conclude that `` everybody ' ' is probably not the true target of her resentment .	42.446632
immediately thereafter , the patient fractures her rehearsed story , veering into an oversoft , breathy , sloppily articulated , `` i don ' t feel like talking right now ' ' .	17.131771
within the first five minutes of this interview it is apparent to the therapist that `` everybody ' ' truthfully refers to the woman ' s husband .	24.751364
she says later , but still within the opening five minutes , `` i keep thinking of a divorce but that ' s another emotional death ' ' .	64.07955
the linguistic and paralinguistic signals of misery are all present in the voice chart for this sentence	143.3936
so are certain signals that she does not accept divorce .	255.42046
by saying `` another emotional death ' ' , she reveals that there has been a previous one , although she has not described it in words .	70.21729
this the therapist may pursue in later questioning .	4.388376
the phrase , `` emotional death ' ' , interesting and , to a non-scientific mind , rather touching , suggests that this woman may have some flair for words , perhaps even something of the temperament regrettably called `` creative ' ' .	59.968197
since the psychiatric interview , like any other interview , depends on communication , it is significant to note that the therapist in this interview was a man of marked skill and long experience .	36.60344
his own communication apparatus operated superbly , and lillian ross readers will note instantly its total lack of resemblance to the blunted , monumentally unmeshed mechanism of dr . blauberman .	40.194393
interestingly enough -- although none of the real-life therapists involved could conceivably compare with blauberman -- when groups of them began playing back interviews , they discovered any number of ways in which they wanted to polish their own interview techniques	116.44729
almost everyone , on first hearing one of his own sessions on tape , expressed some desire to take the whole thing over again .	87.74566
yet , in spite of this , intensive study of the taped interviews by teams of psychotherapists and linguists laid bare the surprising fact that , in the first five minutes of an initial interview , the patient often reveals as many as a dozen times just what ' s wrong with him	33.47786
to spot these giveaways the therapist must know either intuitively or scientifically how to listen .	26.274693
naturally , the patient does not say , `` i hate my father ' ' , or `` sibling rivalry is what bugs me ' ' .	15.964285
what he does do is give himself away by communicating information over and above the words involved .	145.8076
some of the classic indicators , as described by drs . pittenger , hockett , and danehy in the first five minutes , are these ambiguity of pronouns	18.634808
stammering or repetition of i , you , he , she , et cetera may signal ambiguity or uncertainty .	45.484043
on the other hand significant facts may be concealed -- she may mean i or everybody , as it did with the tense and irritable woman mentioned before , may refer to a specific person .	90.59751
the word that is not used can be as important as the word that is used	74.32567
therapist and/or linguist must always consider the alternatives .	45.970543
when someone says , for example , `` they took x-rays to see that there was nothing wrong with me ' ' , it pays to consider how this statement would normally be made .	49.662453
( this patient , in actuality , was a neurasthenic who had almost come to the point of accepting the fact that it was not her soma but her psyche that was the cause of her difficulty .	35.926804
) amateur linguists note here that pursewarden , in durrell ' s alexandria quartet , stammered when he spoke of his wife , which is hardly surprising in view of their disastrous relationship .	22.322111
she was just another freighter from the states , and she seemed as commonplace as her name .	52.452774
she was the john harvey , one of those atlantic sea-horses that had sailed to bari to bring beans , bombs , and bullets to the u . s . fifteenth air force , to field marshal montgomery ' s eighth army then racing up the calf of the boot of italy in that early december of 1943 .	39.462906
the john harvey arrived in bari , a port on the adriatic , on november 28th , making for porto nuovo , which , as the name indicates , was the ancient city ' s new and modern harbor .	41.950943
hardly anyone ashore marked her as she anchored stern-to off berth 29 on the mole .	35.164192
if anyone thought of the john harvey , it was to observe that she was straddled by a pair of ships heavily laden with high explosive and if they were hit the john harvey would likely be blown up with her own ammo and whatever else it was that she carried .	29.424639
it had required the approval of president franklin delano roosevelt before the john harvey could be loaded with 100 tons of mustard gas and despatched to the italian warfront .	26.121058
for in a world as yet unacquainted with the horrors of the mushroom cloud , poison gas was still regarded as the ultimate in hideous weapons .	34.271793
throughout the early years of world war 2 , , reports persisted that the axis powers had used gas -- germany in russia , japan in china again .	68.48827
influential people in america were warning the pentagon to be prepared against desperation gas attacks by the germans in future campaigns .	69.62738
some extremists went so far as to urge our using it first .	395.3116
to silence extremists , to warn the axis , president roosevelt issued this statement for the allies in august	108.53739
`` from time to time since the present war began there have been reports that one or more of the axis powers were seriously contemplating use of poisonous gas or noxious gases or other inhumane devices of warfare .	33.917458
i have been loath to believe that any nation , even our present enemies , could or would be willing to loose upon mankind such terrible and inhumane weapons .	112.110954
`` however , evidence that the axis powers are making significant preparations indicative of such an intention is being reported with increasing frequency from a variety of sources .	71.92012
`` use of such weapons has been outlawed by the general opinion of civilized mankind .	16.27316
this country has not used them , and i hope that we never will be compelled to use them .	31.688936
i state categorically that we shall under no circumstances resort to the use of such weapons unless they are first used by our enemies ' ' .	35.569122
the following month the invasion of italy was begun , and roosevelt gave effect to his warning by consenting to the stockpiling of poison gas in southern italy .	48.79519
bari was chosen as a depot , not only for its seeming safety , but because of its proximity to airfields .	20.0107
it would be made in three waves -- the first to lay down a smokescreen , the second to drop the gas bombs , the third to shower incendiaries which would burn everything below .	40.108955
so the vile cargo went into the hole of the john harvey .	7.381597
a detachment of six men from the 701st chemical maintenance company under first lt . howard d . beckstrom went aboard , followed by lt . thomas h . richardson , the cargo security officer .	34.243576
only a few other people -- very important people -- knew of the nitrogen-mustard eggs nestled below decks .	70.548
thus , in the immemorial way -- in the way of the right hand that knows and the left that does not -- was the stage set for tragedy at bari .	74.751686
it was the night of december 2 , 1943 , and it was growing dark in bari .	24.827662
it was getting on toward 7 o ' clock and the german me-210 plane had been and gone on its eighth straight visit .	78.605896
capt . a . b . jenks of the office of harbor defense was very worried .	60.62887
he knew that german long-range bombers had been returning to the attack in italy .	37.91444
on november 24th , they had made a raid on la maddalena .	41.84934
two days later , some 30 of them had struck at a convoy off bougie , sinking a troopship -- and it had been that very night that the me-210 had made its first appearance .	42.98149
after it had reappeared the next two nights , jenks went to higher headquarters and said	50.412205
`` for three days now a german reconnaissance plane has been over the city taking pictures .	82.32596
they ' re just waiting for the proper time to come over here and dump this place into the adriatic ' ' .	46.763214
but the older and wiser heads had dismissed his warning as alarmist .	19.785368
even though it was known that the luftwaffe in the north was now being directed by the young and energetic general peltz , the commander who would conduct the `` little blitz ' ' on london in 1944 , a major raid on bari at this juncture of the war was not to be considered seriously .	31.13122
true , there had been raids on naples -- but naples was pretty far north on the opposite coast .	53.921665
more than that , allied air had complete superiority in the eighth army ' s sector .	25.740509
so captain jenks returned to his harbor post to watch the scouting plane put in five more appearances , and to feel the certainty of this dread rising within him .	102.5705
for jenks knew that bari ' s defenses were made of paper .	95.218956
the royal air force had but a single light anti-aircraft squadron and two balloon units available .	89.795746
there were no r . a . f . fighter squadrons on bari airfield .	15.60717
the radar station with the best location was still not serviceable .	30.914898
and everywhere in evidence among the few remaining defensive units was that old handmaiden of disaster -- multiple command .	121.59292
it had been made shockingly evident that very morning to ensign kay k . vesole , in charge of the armed guard aboard the john bascom .	36.00129
a british officer had come aboard and told him that in case of enemy air attack he was not to open fire until bombs were actually dropped .	90.84422
then he was to co-ordinate his fire with a radar-controlled shore gun firing white tracers .	80.71547
`` this harbor is a bomber ' s paradise ' ' , the britisher had said with frank grimness .	13.727498
`` it ' s up to you to protect yourselves .	39.679287
we can ' t expect any help from the fighters at foggia , either .	26.980148
they ' re all being used on offensive missions ' ' .	8.458976
not fire until the bombs came down ! !	1.0982511
he thought of the tons and tons of flammable fluid beneath his feet and shook his head .	16.467358
like hell he ' d wait -- and supposing the radar-controlled gun got knocked out ? ?	26.910345
what would his guns guide on then -- the north star ? ?	123.79812
ensign vesole decided that he would not tarry until he heard the whispering of the bombs , and when night began to fall , he put seaman 2/c donald l . norton and seaman 1/c william a . rochford on the guns and told them to start shooting the moment they saw an enemy silhouette .	40.022964
below decks , seaman 1/c stanley bishop had begun to write a letter home .	55.171738
above decks on the john harvey , lieutenant richardson gazed at the lights still burning on the port wall and felt uneasy .	72.80579
there were lights glinting in the city , too , even though it was now dark enough for a few stars to become visible .	56.277637
bari was asking for it , he thought .	32.777725
for five days now , they had been in port and that filthy stuff was still in the hold .	76.88717
he hoped they would put in somewhere way , way down in the earth .	54.220184
the burden of his secret was pressing down on him , as it was on lieutenant beckstrom and his six enlisted men .	28.164358
lieutenant richardson could envy the officers and men of the john harvey in their innocent assumption that the ship contained nothing more dangerous than high explosive bombs .	60.405777
they seemed happy at the delay in unloading , glad at the chance to go ashore in a lively liberty port such as bari .	65.916595
nine of them had gone down the gangplank already .	1147.7748
deck cadet james l . cahill and seaman walter brooks had been the first to leave .	63.96089
richardson had returned their departing grins with the noncommittal nod that is the security officer ' s stock in trade .	28.687077
the other half of the crew , plus beckstrom and his men , had remained aboard .	60.21224
damned if that wasn ' t a sailing ship standing out of the old harbor -- porto vecchio .	28.01592
the night was so clear that richardson had no difficulty making out the silhouette .	61.10016
then the thought of a cloudless sky made him shiver , and he glanced upward .	27.444963
it was a clear night and it was raining ! !	12.190045
capt . michael a . musmanno , military governor of the sorrentine peninsula , had also seen and felt the `` rain ' ' .	18.539019
captain musmanno ' s renovated schooner with the flamboyant name unsinkable had just left porto vecchio with a cargo of badly-needed olive oil for the sorrentine ' s civilian population .	19.493729
at exactly 7 30 , he felt a fluttering object brush his face .	60.864883
he turned the beam of his flashlight on it .	47.099773
it was the silver foil from the chocolate bar he had been eating .	25.370699
another , longer strip of tinsel whipped his mouth .	7.931397
it was `` window ' ' -- the tinsel paper dropped by bombers to jam radar sets , to fill the scope with hundreds of blips that would seem to be approaching bombers .	36.890095
unsinkable slowed and stopped , hundreds of brilliant white flares swayed eerily down from the black , the air raid sirens ashore rose in a keening shriek , the anti-aircraft guns coughed and chattered -- and above it all motors roared and the bombs came whispering and wailing and crashing down among the ships at anchor at bari .	21.838758
they had come from airports in the balkans , these hundred-odd junkers 88 ' s .	13.695781
they had winged over the adriatic , they had taken bari by complete surprise and now they were battering her , attacking with deadly skill .	73.94224
they had ruined the radar warning system with their window , they had made themselves invisible above their flares .	75.82397
and they also had the lights of the city , the port wall lanterns , and a shore crane ' s spotlight to guide on .	34.36602
after the first two were blacked out , the third light was abandoned by a terrified italian crew , who left their light to shine for nine minutes like an unerring homing beacon until british mp ' s shot it out .	55.921062
in that interval , the german bombers made a hell of bari harbor .	25.341482
merchant ships illuminated in the light of the flares , made to seem like stones imbedded in a lake of polished mud , were impossible to miss .	39.45108
captain musmanno roared at his men to lash three of the casks of olive oil together for a raft .	23.631565
they got it over the side and clambered aboard only a few minutes before their schooner went under .	43.98241
ensign vesole and his gunners had fought valiantly , but they had no targets .	21.137114
most of the junkers were above the blinding light of the flares , and the radar-controlled shore gun had been knocked out by one of the first sticks of bombs .	20.103128
vesole rushed from gun to gun , attempting to direct fire .	96.53814
norton and rochford fired wildly at the sounds of the motors .	20.577845
bishop rushed on deck to grab a 20-mm gun , pumping out 400 rounds before sticks of three bombs each crashed into holds one , three and five .	77.11169
luckily , she was not completely aflame and would go down before the gasoline could erupt .	40.52158
the order to abandon ship was given , but cries of pain could be heard from the wounded below decks .	36.914783
there is a pause in the merriment as your friends gaze at you , wondering why you are staring , open-mouthed in amazement .	27.715086
you explain , `` i have the strangest feeling of having lived through this very same event before .	99.30619
i can ' t tell when , but i ' m positive i witnessed this same scene of this particular gathering at some time in the past ' ' ! !	29.002554
this experience will have happened to many of you .	108.65027
emerson , in his lecture , refers to the `` startling experience which almost every person confesses in daylight , that particular passages of conversation and action have occurred to him in the same order before , whether dreaming or waking , a suspicion that they have been with precisely these persons in precisely this room , and heard precisely this dialogue , at some former hour , they know not when ' ' .	88.78349
most psychiatrists dismiss these instances of that weird feeling as the deja vue ( already seen ) illusion , just as they dismiss dream previsions as coincidences .	34.416973
in this manner they side-step the seemingly hopeless investigation of the greater depths of mystery in which all of us grope continually .	28.970411
when a man recognizes a certain experience as the exact pattern of a previous dream , we have an instance of deja vue , except for the fact that he knows just why the experience seems familiar .	38.682266
occasionally there are examples of pre-vision which cannot be pushed aside without confessing an unscientific attitude .	21.535873
one day maeterlinck , coming with a friend upon an event which he recognized as the exact pattern of a previous dream , detailed the ensuing occurrences in advance so accurately that his companion was completely mystified .	57.97052
rudyard kipling ' s scorn for the `` jargon ' ' of psychical research was altered somewhat when he wondered `` how , or why , had i been shown an unreleased roll of my life film ' ' ? ?	29.468306
the famous author tells us of the strange incident in something about myself .	149.26033
one day when he attended a war memorial ceremony in westminster abbey his view was obstructed by a stout man on his left , his attention turned to the irregular pattern of the rough slab flooring and someone , clasping him by the arm , whispered , `` i want a word with you , please ' ' .	38.897766
at that moment kipling was overwhelmed with awed amazement , suddenly recalling that these identical details of scene , action and word had occurred to him in a dream six weeks earlier .	61.361973
freud probably contributed more than anyone else to the understanding of dreams , enabling us to recognize their equivalents in our wakeful thoughts .	28.424473
however , readers who accept freud ' s findings and believe that he has solved completely the mystery of dreams , should ponder over the following words in his interpretation of dreams , chapter 1	78.99004
as `` a matter of fact no such complete solution of the dream has ever been accomplished in any case , , and what is more , every one attempting such solution has found that in most cases there have remained a great many components of the dream the source of which he has been unable to explain nor is the discussion closed on the subject of the mantic or prophetic power of dreams ' ' .	64.02302
dreams present many mysteries of telepathy , clairvoyance , prevision and retrovision .	4.8258777
the basic mystery of dreams , which embraces all the others and challenges us from even the most common typical dream , is in the fact that they are original , visual continuities .	81.41904
i recall the startling , vivid realism of a dream in which i lived through the horror of the bombing of a little korean town .	24.350163
i am sure that nothing within me is capable of composing that life-like sequence , so complete in detail , from the hodge-podge of news pictures i have seen .	54.23558
and when psychology explains glibly , `` but the subconscious mind is able to produce it ' ' it refers to a mental region so vaguely identified that it may embrace the entire universal mind as conceivably as part of the individual mind .	27.783302
skeptics may deny the more startling phenomena of dreams as things they have never personally observed , but failure to wonder at their basic mystery is outright avoidance of routine evidence .	138.94641
the question becomes , `` what is a dream ' ' ? ?	6.6272726
is a dream simply a mental or cerebral movie ? ?	10.0460825
every dream , and this is true of a mental image of any type even though it may be readily interpreted into its equivalent of wakeful thought , is a psychic phenomenon for which no explanation is available .	50.9177
in most cases we recognize certain words , persons , animals or objects .	136.62573
but these are dreamed in original action , in some particular continuity which we don ' t remember having seen in real life .	65.33188
for instance , the dreamer sees himself seated behind neighbor smith and , with photographic realism , sees smith driving the car	90.6696
whereas , it is a matter of fact that smith cannot drive a car .	163.24445
there is nothing to suggest that the brain can alter past impressions to fit into an original , realistic and unbroken continuity like we experience in dreams .	93.94857
the entire concept of cerebral imagery as the physical basis of a mental image can find no logical support .	88.05021
a `` mental image ' ' subconsciously impressing us from beneath its language symbols in wakeful thought , or consciously in light sleep , is actually not an image at all but is comprised of realities , viewed not in the concurrent sensory stream , but within the depths of the fourth dimension .	57.13246
dreams that display events of the future with photographic detail call for a theory explaining their basic mystery and all its components , including that weird feeling of deja vue , inevitably fantastic though that theory must seem .	64.091896
as in the theory of perception , established in psycho-physiology , the eye is recognized as an integral part of the brain .	19.41196
but then this theory confesses that it is completely at a loss as to how the image can possibly be received by the brain .	115.6382
the opening paragraph of the chapter titled the theory of representative perception , in the book philosophies of science by albert g . ramsperger says , `` passed on to the brain , and there , by some unexplained process , it causes the mind to have a perception ' ' .	34.450222
but why is it necessary to reproduce the retinal image within the brain ? ?	45.104355
as retinal images are conceded to be an integral function of the brain it seems logical to suppose that the nerves , between the inner brain and the eyes , carry the direct drive for cooperation from the various brain centers -- rather than to theorize on the transmission of an image which is already in required location .	56.186848
hereby , the external object viewed by the eyes remains the thing that is seen , not the retinal image , the purpose of which would be to achieve perceptive cooperation by stirring sympathetic impulses in the other sensory centers , motor tensions , associated word symbols , and consciousness .	59.7766
modern physics has developed the theory that all matter consists of minute waves of energy .	65.45864
we know that the number of radio and television impulses , sound waves , ultra-violet rays , etc . , that may occupy the very same space , each solitary upon its own frequency , is infinite .	26.050642
so we may conceive the coexistence of the infinite number of universal , apparently momentary states of matter , successive one after another in consciousness , but permanent each on its own basic phase of the progressive frequencies .	99.56493
this theory makes it possible for any event throughout eternity to be continuously available at any moment to consciousness .	72.99253
space in any form is completely measured by the three dimensions .	93.02324
if the fourth dimension is a physical concept and not purely metaphysical , through what medium does it extend ? ?	108.63908
it is not through space nor time that the time machine most approved by science fiction must travel for a visit to the permanent prehistoric past , or the ever-existent past-fantasy future .	76.837
three seconds flat is the usual time , and the space is crossed by moderate mileage , while the overwhelming immensity of such journeys must be conceived as a static pulsation through an enormous number of coexistent frequencies which perpetuate all events .	30.14234
the body , senses and brain , in common with all matter , have their counterpart on each of a countless number of frequencies .	93.2721
the senses in each counterpart bear the impression only of phenomena that share its own frequency , whereas those upon all other frequencies are invisible , inaudible and intactible to them .	70.437614
consciousness is the factor that provides the progressive continuity to sensory impressions .	11.857877
when consciousness deserts the sleeping body and the wakeful world , it continues in the myriad progressions of the ever-present past and future , in a life as vibrant and real as the one left when the body tired and required sleep .	72.91826
if the photographically realistic continuity of dreams , however bizarre their combinations , denies that it is purely a composition of the brain , it must be compounded from views of diverse realities , although some of them may never be encountered in what we are pleased to call the real life .	43.59715
dr . h . v . hilprecht , professor of assyrian at the university of pennsylvania , dreamed that a babylonian priest , associated with the king kurigalzu , ( 1300 b . c . ) escorted him to the treasure chamber of the temple of bel , gave him six novel points of information about a certain broken relic , and corrected an error in its identification .	21.961456
as a matter of fact , the incorrect classification , the result of many weeks of labor by dr . hilprecht , was about to be published by him the following day .	53.319016
some time later the missing part of the relic was found and the complete inscription , together with other new evidence , fully corroborated the ancient priest ' s information .	43.091366
dr . hilprecht was uncertain as to the language used by the ancient priest in his dream .	50.278088
he was almost positive it was not assyrian nor cassite , and imagined it must have been german or english .	40.54057
we may conclude that all six points of information , ostensibly given by the dream priest , could have been furnished by dr . hilprecht ' s subconscious reasoning .	37.18859
but , in denying any physical reality for this dream , how could the brain possibly compose that realistic , vividly visual continuity uninterrupted by misty fadeout , violent break or sudden substitution ? ?	38.33655
that the perfect continuity was composed from the joblot of memory impressions in the professor ' s brain , or 2 .	32.81479
that the dream was a reality on the infinite progressions of universal , gradient frequencies , across which the modern professor and the priest of ancient nippur met ? ?	33.02705
the degree of circumstance , the ratio of memory to forgetfulness , determines whether a dream will be a recognized , fulfilled prevision , or the vaguely , effective source of the weird deja vue feeling .	61.19466
no doubt some experiences vanish so completely as to leave no trace on the sleeper ' s mind .	38.649937
probably less than one percent of our previsions escape final obliteration before we wake .	144.12709
when we arrive at the events concerned in the vanished majority , they , of course , cannot impress us as anything familiar .	54.49653
nevertheless , there are notably frequent instances of deja vue , in which our recognition of an entirely novel event is a feeling of having lived through it before , a feeling which , though vague , withstands the verbal barrage from the most impressive corps of psychologists .	50.684727
if deja vue is an illusion , then peculiarly , it is a most prevalent mental disturbance affecting even the most level-headed people .	51.224884
chauncey depew , one-time runner-up for the republican presidential nomination , was attending a convention at saratoga , where he was scheduled to nominate colonel theodore roosevelt for governor of new york when he noticed that the temporary chairman was a man he had never met .	22.278118
after the preliminary business affair was finished depew arose and delivered the convincing speech that clinched the nomination for roosevelt .	33.46873
if depew had told any academic psychologist that he had a weird feeling of having lived through that identical convention session at some time in the past , he would have been informed that he was a victim of deja vue .	21.726934
but the famous orator felt more than vague recognition for the scene .	40.060932
he remembered exactly when he had lived through it before , and he had something to prove he had .	52.82064
one week before the convention , depew was seated on the porch of a country home on the hudson , gazing at the opposite shore .	13.738742
`` the food is wonderful and it is a lot of fun to be here ' ' ! !	21.274124
so wrote a ten year old student in a letter to his parents from north country school , lake placid , new york .	47.32332
in this one sentence , he unwittingly revealed the basic philosophy of the nutrition and psychological programs in operation at the school .	49.202766
because the food is selected with thought for its nutritional value , care for its origin , and prepared in a manner that retains the most nutrients , the food does taste good .	54.854565
when served in a psychological atmosphere that allows young bodies to assimilate the greatest good from what they eat because they are free from tension , a foundation is laid for a high level of health that releases the children from physical handicaps to participate with enjoyment in the work assignments , the athletic programs and the most important phase , the educational opportunities .	68.88905
situated in a region of some of the loveliest mountain scenery in the country , the school buildings are located amid open fields and farm lands .	43.037205
these contemporary structures , beautifully adapted to a school in the country , are home to 60 children , ages eight to fourteen , grades four through eight .	133.55516
from fourteen states and three foreign countries they come to spend the months from mid-september to june .	42.9648
the director , walter e . clark , believes that a school with children living full time in its care must take full responsibility for their welfare .	78.900604
to him this means caring for the whole child , providing basic nutrition , and a spiritual attitude that lends freedom for the development of the mind .	38.815704
the concept of good nutrition really began with the garden .	26.70684
the school has always maintained a farm to supply the needs of the school .	64.41842
in a climate hostile to agriculture , mr . clark has had to keep alert to the most productive farm techniques .	30.174587
where a growing season may , with luck , allow 60 days without frost , and where the soil is poor , sandy , quick-drying and subject to erosion , many farmers fail .	85.606476
throughout the adirondack region abandoned farm homes and wild orchards bear ghostly testimony that their owners met defeat .	83.12367
mr . clark found that orthodox procedures of deep plowing , use of chemical fertilizers and insecticides , plus the application of conservation principles of rotation and contouring , did not prevent sheet erosion in the potato fields and depreciation of the soil .	58.760906
`` to give up these notions required a revolution in thought ' ' , mr . clark said in reminiscing about the abrupt changes in ideas he experienced when he began reading `` organic gardening ' ' and `` modern nutrition ' ' in a search for help with his problems .	38.214302
`` louis bromfield ' s writings excited me as a conservationist ' ' .	4.7387795
by 1952 he was convinced he would no longer spray .	45.49551
he locked his equipment in a cabinet where it still remains .	62.077084
after reading `` plowman ' s folly ' ' by edward h . faulkner , he stopped plowing .	26.259756
the basis for compost materials already existed on the school farm with a stable of animals for the riding program , poultry for eggs , pigs to eat garbage , a beef herd and wastes of all kinds .	36.930363
separate pails were kept in the kitchen for coffee grounds and egg shells .	28.842926
all these materials and supplementary manure and other fertilizers from neighboring dairy and poultry farms made over 40 tons of finished compost a year .	26.124619
it was applied with a compost shredder made from a converted manure spreader .	21.59874
years of patient application of compost and leaf mulching has changed the structure of the soil and its water-holding capacity .	22.325329
soon after the method changed , visitors began asking how he managed to irrigate his soil to keep it looking moist , when in reality , it was the soil treatment alone that accomplished this .	89.76068
to demonstrate the soil of his vegetable gardens as it is today , mr . clark stooped to scoop up a handful of rich dark earth .	31.524797
sniffing its sweet smell and letting it fall to show its good crumbly consistency , he pointed to the nearby driveway and said , `` this soil used to be like that hard packed road over there ' ' .	65.638794
`` people and soils respond slowly ' ' , says walter clark , `` but the time has now come when the gardens produce delicious long-keeping vegetables due to this enrichment program .	34.506104
no chemical fertilizers and poisonous insecticides and fungicides are used ' ' .	14.653214
the garden supplies enough carrots , turnips , rutabagas , potatoes , beets , cabbage and squash to store for winter meals in the root cellar .	9.427893
the carrots sometimes don ' t make it through the winter	118.97178
the cabbage and squash keep until march or april .	21.59095
there is never enough corn , peas or strawberries .	2.25245
mr . clark still has to use rotenone with potatoes grown on the least fertile fields , but he has watched the insect damage decrease steadily and hopes that continued use of compost and leaf mulch will allow him to do without it in the future .	46.823635
a new project planned is the use of bio-dynamic starter .	5.068276
new ideas for improving nutrition came with the study of soil treatment .	44.35345
`` after the soil , the kitchen ' ' , says mr . clark .	8.9976015
the first major change was that of providing wholewheat bread instead of white bread .	30.448378
`` adults take a long time to convince and you are thwarted if you try to push ' ' .	32.30238
at first the kitchen help was tolerant , but ordered their own supply of white bread for themselves .	99.27523
`` you can ' t make french toast with whole-wheat bread ' ' , was an early complaint .	37.863964
of course they learned in time that they not only could use whole-wheat bread , but the children liked it better .	201.31812
mrs . clark , as house manager , planned the menus and cared for the ordering .	18.266838
then miss lillian colman came from vermont to be kitchen manager .	20.73437
today whole grains are freshly ground every day and baked into bread .	42.538326
mr . clark ' s studies taught him that the only way to conserve the vitamins in the whole grain was prompt use of the flour .	41.422836
once the grains are ground , vitamin e begins to deteriorate immediately and half of it is lost by oxidation and exposure to the air within one week .	78.46808
a mill stands in a room off the kitchen .	15.47019
surrounding it are metal cans of grains ordered from organic farms in the state .	11.561352
miss colman pours measures of whole wheat , oats , and soy beans and turns on the motor .	15.303681
she goes on about her work and listens for the completion of the grinding .	16.215315
the bread baked from this mixture is light in color and fragrant in aroma .	9.985762
it is well liked by the children and faculty .	127.41643
`` lillian ' s bread is so good and everything tastes so much better here that it is hard not to eat too much ' ' , said the secretary ruefully eyeing her extra pounds .	50.656986
the school has not used cold prepared cereals for years , though at one time that was all they ever served .	106.48855
when the chance came , they first eliminated cold cereal once a week , then gradually converted to hot fresh-ground cereal every day .	67.1521
they serve cracked wheat , oats or cornmeal .	3.4488723
occasionally , the children find steamed , whole-wheat grains for cereal which they call `` buckshot ' ' .	26.345259
at the beginning of the school year , the new students don ' t eat the cereal right away , but within a short time they are eating it voraciously .	56.10019
when they leave for vacations they miss the hot cereal .	22.149761
the school has received letters from parents asking , `` what happened to johnny ? ?	28.137083
he never used to like any hot cereal , now that ' s the only kind he wants .	89.31103
where can we get this cereal he likes so much ' ' ? ?	27.459036
salads are served at least once a day .	7.3277144
most come from the root cellar or from the freezer .	3.6310189
sprouted grains and seeds are used in salads and dishes such as chop suey .	29.296543
sometimes sprouted wheat is added to bread and causes the children to remark , `` lillian , did you put nuts in the bread today ' ' ? ?	75.2766
the school raises enough poultry , pigs , and beef cattle for most of their needs .	49.940563
lots of cheese made from june grass milk is served .	22.854319
hens are kept on the range and roosters are kept with them for their fertility .	30.49262
organ meats such as beef and chicken liver , tongue and heart are planned once a week .	42.19557
also , salt water fish is on the table once a week .	98.150276
for deserts , puddings and pies are each served once a week .	107.860794
most other desserts are fruit in some form , fresh fruits once daily at least , sometimes at snack time .	87.733444
dried fruits are purchased from sources where they are neither sulphured nor sprayed .	23.650442
apples come from a farm in vermont where they are not sprayed .	20.31732
oranges and grapefruit are shipped from florida weekly from an organic farm .	48.899826
finding sources for these high quality foods is a problem .	18.168056
following a talk by mr . clark at the new york state natural food associates convention , a man from the audience offered to ship his unsprayed apples to the school from vermont .	42.442715
wheat-germ , brewer ' s yeast and ground kelp are used in bread and in dishes such as spaghetti sauce , meat loaves .	16.693626
miss colman hopes to find suitable shakers so that kelp can be available at the tables .	11.18259
raw wheat-germ is available on the breakfast table for the children to help themselves .	61.869965
very few fried foods are used and the use of salt and pepper is discouraged .	13.409798
pitchers of water merely appear on the tables .	2.4062347
the source is known so there is no necessity to remove insecticide residues .	12.877175
the cooking conserves a maximum of the vitamin c content of vegetables by methods which use very little water and cook in the shortest time possible .	123.98278
since mr . clark believes firmly that the chewing of hard foods helps develop healthy gums and teeth , raw vegetables and raw whole-wheat grains are handed out with fresh fruit and whole-wheat cookies at snack time in the afternoons .	28.613886
to solve the problem of the wheat grains spilling on the floor and getting underfoot , a ball of maple syrup boiled to candy consistency was invented to hold the grains .	24.951536
on their frequent hikes into the nearby mountains , the children carry whole grains to munch along the trail .	55.647427
they learn to like these so well that it isn ' t surprising to hear that one boy tried the oats he was feeding his horse at chore time .	42.096603
they tasted good to him , so he brought some to breakfast to eat in his cereal bowl with milk and honey .	35.690613
maple syrup is made by the children in the woods on the school grounds .	12.693058
this and raw sugar replace ordinary refined sugar on the tables and very little sugar is used in cooking .	34.60338
parents are asked in the bulletin to send packages of treats consisting of fruit and nuts , but no candy .	33.920113
mr . clark believes in a good full breakfast of fruit , hot cereal , milk , honey , whole-wheat toast with real butter and eggs .	32.192142
the heavy meal comes in the middle of the day .	10.653097
soup is often the important dish at supper .	2.7596624
homemade of meat , bones and vegetables , it is rich in dissolved minerals and vitamins .	24.64184
the school finds that the children are satisfied with smaller amounts of food since all of it is high in quality .	63.610806
the cost to feed one person is just under one dollar a day .	161.60922
even before he saw the necessity of growing better food and planning good nutrition , mr . clark felt the school had a good health program .	62.630672
rugged outdoor exercise for an hour and a half every day in all kinds of weather was the rule .	43.473423
a vigorous program existed in skiing , skating sports and overnight hiking .	12.342422
since the change to better nutrition , he feels he can report on improvements in health , though he considers the following statements observations and not scientific proof .	136.1495
visitors to the school ask what shampoo they use on the children ' s hair to bring out the sheen .	24.914942
the ruddy complexion of the faces also brings comment .	224.36267
buffeted by swirling winds , the little green biplane struggled northward between the mountains beyond northfield gulf .	7.3688297
wires whined as a cold november blast rocked the silver wings , but the engine roar was reassuring to the pilot bundled in the open cockpit .	20.352264
he peered ahead and grinned as the railroad tracks came into view again below .	159.22104
`` good old iron compass ' ' ! !	1.0743796
a plume of smoke rose from a central vermont locomotive which idled behind a string of gravel cars , and little figures that were workmen labored to set the ruptured roadbed to rights .	27.803017
the girders of a shattered dog river bridge lay strewn for half a mile downstream .	36.263042
vermont ' s main railroad line was prostrate .	6.4172854
and in the dark days after the great flood of 1927 -- the worst natural disaster in the state ' s history -- the little plane was its sole replacement in carrying the united states mails .	36.566544
rain of near cloudburst proportions had fallen for three full days and it was still raining on the morning of friday , november 4 , 1927 , when officials of the post office department ' s railway mail service realized that their distribution system for vermont had been almost totally destroyed overnight .	48.94645
clerks and postmasters shoveled muck out of their offices -- those who still had offices -- and wondered how to move the mail .	126.4938
the state ' s railroad system counted miles of broken bridges and missing rights-of-way it would obviously remain out of commission for weeks .	103.08799
and once medicine , food , clothing and shelter had been provided for the flood ' s victims , communications and the mail were the next top problems .	39.92082
from burlington , outgoing mail could be ferried across lake champlain to the railroad at port kent , n . y . .	14.11824
the nearest undisrupted end of track from boston was at concord , n . h . .	12.502957
when governor al smith offered new york national guard planes to fly the mail in and out of the state , it seemed a likely temporary solution , easing burlington ' s bottleneck and that at montpelier too .	49.61755
the question was `` where to land ' ' ? ?	2.6266482
there was no such thing as an airport in vermont .	65.16343
burlington aviator john j . burns suggested the parade ground southwest of fort ethan allen , and soon a dozen hastily-summoned national guard pilots were bringing their wide-winged `` jenny ' ' and dehaviland two-seaters to rest on the frozen sod of the military base .	30.741314
the only available field that could be used near flood-ravaged montpelier was on the towne farm off upper main street , a narrow hillside where takeoffs and landings could be safely made only under light wind conditions .	83.1293
over in barre the streets had been deep in swirling water , and bridges were crumpled and gone .	24.578491
anticipating delivery of medicines and yeast by plane , granite city citizens formed an airfield committee and with the aid of quarrymen and the 172nd infantry , vermont national guard , laid out runways on wilson flat , high on millstone hill .	45.141212
the `` barre aviation field ' ' was set to receive its first aircraft the sunday following the flood .	150.63054
though the makeshift airports were ready , the york state guard flyers proved unable to keep any kind of mail schedule .	106.122765
they had courage but their meager training consisted of weekend hops in good weather , in and out of established airports , and the increasingly cold weather soon raised hob with the water cooled engines of their world war 1 , planes .	38.501003
it seemed like a good time for officials to use a recently-passed law empowering the post office department to contract for the transport of first class mail by air .	78.2433
they had to act fast , for letters were clogging the terminals .	38.886715
down in concord , new hampshire , was a flier in the right place at the right time robert s . fogg , a native new englander , had been a world war 1 , flying instructor , barnstormer , and one of the original planners of the concord airport .	25.133856
tall , wiry , dark-haired bob fogg had already racked up one historical first in air mail history .	194.3141
piloting a curtiss navy mf flying boat off lake winnipesaukee in 1925 , he had inaugurated the original rural delivery air service in america .	45.2699
during the excitement following lindbergh ' s flight to paris earlier in 1927 , dare devil aviators overnight became legendary heroes .	36.666306
in concord , bob fogg was the most prominent new hampshire boy with wings .	74.831856
public-spirited backers staked him to a brand-new airplane , aimed at putting their city and state on the flying map .	112.60837
the ship was a waco biplane , one of the first two of its type to be fitted with the air cooled , 225/hp wright radial engine known as the whirlwind .	32.193226
a trim green and silver-painted craft only 22-1/2 feet long , the waco was entered to compete in the `` on-to-spokane ' ' air derby of 1927 .	18.358408
as a matter of fact , fogg and his plane didn ' t get beyond pennsylvania in the race -- an engine oil leak forced him down -- but the flying service and school he started subsequently were first steps in paying off his wry-faced backers .	130.41875
so with all this experience , bob fogg was a natural choice to receive the first emergency air mail star route contract .	101.41106
his work began just six days after the flood .	23.272493
by airline from concord to burlington is a distance of about 150 miles , counting a slight deviation for the stop at either barre or montpelier .	20.374743
the first few days bob fogg set his plane down on towne field back of the state house when the wind was right , and used wilson flat above barre when it wasn ' t .	97.21845
between the unsafe towne field and the long roundabout back road haul that was necessary to gain access to wilson flat , arrangements at the state capital were far from satisfactory .	99.72597
each time in , the unhappy pilot , pushing his luck , begged the postal officials that met him to find a safer landing place , preferably on the flat-topped hills across the winooski river .	15.638436
`` but fogg ' ' , they countered , `` we can ' t get over there .	23.562609
and besides you seem to make it all right here ' ' .	30.388908
it took a tragedy to bring things to a head .	35.613358
after a week of precarious uphill landings and downwind takeoffs , fogg one day looked down at the shattered yellow wreckage of an army plane strewn across snow-covered towne field .	28.365208
sent to montpelier by secretary herbert hoover , red cross aide reuben sleight had been killed , and his pilot , lt . franklin wolfe , badly injured .	28.53749
with the field a blur of white the unfortunate pilot had simply flown into the hillside .	54.663273
faced with this situation , postmaster charles f . mckenna of montpelier went with fogg on a burlington trip , and together they scouted the terrain on the heights of berlin .	23.392056
a long flat known as the st . john field seemed to answer their purpose , and since the winooski bridges were at last passable , they decided to use it .	38.882015
with a wary eye on the farmer ' s bull , fred somers of montpelier and mr . st . john marked the field with a red table cloth .	35.87776
as a wind direction indicator , they tied a cotton rag to a sapling .	11.37519
with these aids , and a pair of skiis substituting for wheels on the waco , bob fogg made the first landing on what is now part of the barre-montpelier airport on november 21 , 1927 .	27.520092
each trip saw the front cockpit filled higher with mail pouches .	24.204123
during the second week of operations , fogg received a telegram from the post office department , asking him to `` put on two airplanes and make two flights daily , plus one sunday trip ' ' .	55.27992
since fogg ' s was a one-man , one-plane flying service , this meant that he would have to do both trips , flying alone 600 miles a day , under sub-freezing temperature conditions .	60.38
over the weeks , america ' s first star route air mail settled into a routine pattern despite the vagaries of weather and the lack of ground facilities and aids to navigation .	60.87278
each morning at five fogg crawled out of bed to bundle into flying togs over the furnace register of his home .	36.439556
always troubled by poor circulation in his feet , he experimented with various combinations of socks and shoes before finally adopting old-style felt farmer ' s boots with his sheepskin flying boots pulled over them .	29.603384
a sheep-lined leather flying suit , plus helmet , goggles and mittens completed his attire for the rigors of the open cockpit .	13.802771
the airman ' s stock answer to `` weren ' t you cold ' ' ? ?	9.504271
became `` yes , the first half hour is tough , but by then i ' m so numb i don ' t notice it ' ' ! !	26.700409
as daylight began to show through the frosty windows , fogg would place a call to william a . shaw at the u . s . weather station at northfield , vermont , for temperature and wind-velocity readings .	32.46373
shaw could also give the flyer a pretty good idea of area visibility by a visual check of the mountains to be seen from his station .	69.447334
`` ceilings ' ' were judged by comparison with known mountain heights and cloud positions .	153.04276
later on in the day fogg could get a better weather picture from the burlington weather bureau supervised by frank e . hartwell .	21.365894
out at the airport each morning , fogg ' s skilled mechanic caleb marston would have the waco warmed up and running in the drafty hangar .	10.815879
( he ' d get the engine oil flowing with an electric heater under a big canvas cover .	25.312864
) wishing to show that aviation was dependable and here to stay , bob fogg always made a point of taking off each morning on the dot of seven , disregarding rain , snow and sleet in true postal tradition .	80.0472
concord learned to set its clocks by the rackety bark of the whirlwind ' s exhaust overhead .	18.362429
sometimes the pilot had to turn back if fully blocked by fog , but 85% of his trips were completed .	38.558468
plane radios were not yet available , and once in the air , fogg flew his ship by compass , a good memory for landmarks as seen from above , and a capacity for dead reckoning and quick computation .	53.475838
often , threading through the overcast , he was forced to fly close to the ground by a low ceiling , skimming above the winooski or the white river along the line of the broken railroad .	37.19566
when driving rain or mist socked in one valley , fogg would chandelle up and over to reverse course and try another one , ranging from the ottauquechee up to danville in search of safe passage through the mountain passes .	79.88267
the dependable wright engine was never stopped on these trips .	36.450813
it ticked over smoothly , idling while fogg exchanged mails with the armed messenger from burlington at fort ethan allen , and one from montpelier and barre at the st . john field .	19.922869
sometimes , on a return trip , the aviator would `` go upstairs ' ' high over the clouds .	41.766277
there he ' d take a compass reading , figure his air speed , and deduce that in a certain number of minutes he ' d be over the broad meadows of the merrimack valley where it would be safe to let down through the overcast and see the ground before it hit him .	54.828102
bob fogg didn ' t have today ' s advantages of instrument flight and ground control approach systems .	218.78346
at the end of the calculated time he ' d nose the waco down through the cloud bank and hope to break through where some feature of the winter landscape would be recognizable .	60.66889
usually back in concord by noon , there was just time to get partially thawed out , refuel , and grab a bit of mrs . fogg ' s hot broth before starting the second trip .	24.841204
day after day fogg shuttled back and forth on his one-man air mail route , until the farmers in their snowy barnyards and the road repairmen came to recognize the stubby plane as their link with the rest of the country .	34.54896
at fort ethan allen the ever-present wind off lake champlain could readily flip a puny man-made thing like an airplane if the pilot miscalculated .	21.38444
once the soldiers from the barracks had to hold the ship from blowing away while fogg revved the engine and got the tail up .	50.671627
at a nod of his head they let go , turning to cup their ears against the icy slipstream .	51.78228
tracks in the snow showed the plane was airborne in less than a hundred feet .	21.502796
one afternoon during a cold , powdery snowstorm , fogg took off for concord from the st . john field .	23.025333
if so , are you saying , `` where did the last few years go ? ?	85.06414
how did i get to be sixty-five so fast ? ?	29.543993
what do i do now ' ' ? ?	1.008857
yes , retirement seems to creep upon you suddenly .	206.13734
somehow we old-timers never figured we would ever retire .	12.756531
we always thought we would die with our boots on .	169.58846

sixty-five years and you ' ve had it ! !	8.5452385

a great many retired people are the so-called white collar workers .	44.814102
if so , you are of the old school .	40.23471

you never are late for work and seldom absent .	298.42474

now , looming on the horizon are such things as estimated totals , calculated risks and i . b . m . machines .	42.093597
this is followed by a boom in conferences .	8.333695
when a plan burst its seams , hasty conferences supply the necessary patch , and life goes merrily on .	68.93784
you had your day and it was a good day .	18.421438
well , to get back to the problem of retirement .	24.93447
every retiring person has a different situation facing him .	30.477983
some have plenty of money -- some have very little money .	38.69693
some are blest with an abundance of good health -- some are in poor health and many are invalids .	65.53578
some have lovely homes -- some live in small apartments .	51.748806
some have beautiful gardens -- some not even a blade of grass .	28.234818
some have serenity of mind , the ability to accept what they have , and make the most of it ( a wonderful gift to have , believe me ) -- some see only darkness , the bitter side of everything .	96.26348

the question is `` how are you going to live with it ' ' ? ?	8.068818
you can sit back and moan and bewail your lot .	12.800162
but , if you do , your life will be just one thing -- unhappiness -- complete and unabridged .	41.302742
it seems to me , the first thing you ' ve got to do , to be happy , is to face up to your problems , no matter what they may be .	27.341948

one thing , i am sure of , you must get an interest in life .	41.150143
many of you will say , `` well , what can i do ' ' ? ?	8.747104

i , frankly , can ' t draw a straight line .	29.746206

anyway , i ' ll bet you have a lot of fun .	9.408409

there is always a market for this line of work .	28.276855
some women can sit and sew , crochet , tat or knit by the hour , and look calm and relaxed and turn out beautiful work .	70.17846
where sewing is concerned , i ' m a total loss .	135.76273
when you see a needle in my hands you will know the family buttons have fallen off and i have to sew them back on , or get out the safety pins .	58.539303
then again , there ' s always that lovely old pastime of hooking or braiding rugs .	17.337172
not for me , but perhaps just the thing for you .	52.17016

some people love to crack tile and it ' s amazing what beautiful designs they come up with as a result of their cracking good time .	46.26921
do you yearn to make cakes and pies , or special cookies and candies ? ?	22.820475
there is always an open market for this sort of delicacy , in spite of low calorie diets , cottage cheese and hands-off-all-sweets to the contrary .	15.656672
some people can carve most anything out of a piece of wood .	17.467325
some make beautiful chairs , cabinets , chests , doll houses , etc . .	5.826807

some women get a real thrill out of housework .	3.3432088
they love to dust , scrub , polish , wax floors , move the furniture around from place to place , take down the curtains , put up new ones and have themselves a real ball .	63.559628
i can look at furniture in one spot year in and year out and really feel for sure that ' s where it belongs .	275.477
perhaps you would like to become a writer .	4.851332
this gives you a wide and varied choice .	8.241498
