`` almost everybody in the senior class is married ' ' , students say dogmatically .	50.671497
and the school newspaper sells space to jubilant fraternities , sororities , and houses ( in the house plan association ) that have good news to impart .	90.91377
these announcements are , in effect , advertisements for themselves as thriving marriage marts .	38.65814
there are boxed proclamations in the newspaper of watchings , pinnings , ringings , engagements , and marriages in a scrupulously graded hierarchy of felicity .	5.114761
`` witt house happily announces the engagement of fran horowitz to erwin schwartz of fife house ' ' .	10.861121
the brooklyn college student shows some striking departures from prevailing collegiate models .	18.580338
the ivy league enjoys no easy dominion here , and the boys are as likely to dress in rather foppish continental fashion , or even in nondescript working class manner , as they are in the restrained , button-down ivy way .	60.33873
the girls are prone to dress far more flamboyantly than their counterparts out of town , and eye shadow , mascara , and elaborate bouffant hairdos -- despite the admonitions of cautious guidance personnel -- are not unknown even in early morning classes .	57.485283
among the boys , there is very little bravado about drinking .	15.356379
brooklyn college is distinctive for not having an official drinking place .	248.73935
the fort lauderdale encampment for drinking is foreign to most brooklyn college boys .	106.46813
this should be used frequently ( but shaken before using ) .	86.63226
for galled breasts , the mother should shave into half a cup of fresh unsalted lard enough white chalk to make a paste .	20.829187
this could also be used for any other skin irritation .	197.14516
or she might place cornstarch in the oven for a short time and then apply this under her breasts .	38.79634
`` female troubles ' ' of various kinds do not seem to have been common on the frontier	54.22105
at least i have only one remedy for anything of this kind in my collection , one for hastening delayed menstruation .	70.66109
bruises , burns , cuts , etc . , occurred frequently on the frontier , and folk medicine gave the answers to these problems too .	133.87447
bruises and black eyes were relieved by application of raw beefsteak .	23.859936
( doctors now say that it was not the meat but the coolness of the applications which relieved the pain .	109.15913
) salted butter was another cure for bruises .	4.233418
many people agreed that burns should be treated with bland oily salves or unsalted butter or lard , but one informant told me that a burn should be bathed in salt water	13.770801
the burn oozed watery fluid for many days , and finally the healing was completed by bathing it with epsom salts .	22.433746
another swore by vinegar baths for burns , and still another recommended salted butter .	31.249474
`` butter salve ' ' or `` butter ointment ' ' was used for burns , and for bruises as well .	15.512192
this was made by putting butter in a pan of water and allowing it to boil	30.421356
when it was cool , the fat was skimmed off and bottled .	6.8632116
cow ' s milk was another cure for burns , and burns covered with gum arabic or plain mucilage healed quickly .	46.207916
one man , badly burned about the face and eyes by an arc welding torch , was blinded and could not find a doctor at the time .	38.042587
a sympathetic friend made poultices of raw potato parings , which she said was the best and quickest way to draw out the `` heat ' ' .	28.921131
later the doctor used mineral oil on the burns .	129.39389
the results were good , but which treatment helped is still not known .	198.54922
to stop bleeding , cobwebs were applied to cuts and wounds .	23.038128
one old-timer said to sprinkle sugar on a bleeding cut , even when on a knuckle , if it was made by a rusty tool	53.49846
this would stop the flow and also prevent infection .	17.24172
my lawyer told me that his mother used a similar remedy for cuts and wounds	30.809544
she sprinkled common sugar directly on the injury and then bound it loosely with cotton cloth , over which she poured turpentine .	58.929626
he showed me one of his fingers which had been practically amputated and which his mother had treated	108.36678
a `` chaw ' ' of tobacco put on an open wound was both antiseptic and healing .	18.294426
or a thin slice of plug tobacco might be laid on the open wound without chewing .	17.271696
one old man told me that when he was a boy he was kicked in the head by a fractious mule and had his scalp laid back from the entire front of his head .	27.401564
his brother ran a mile to get the father	9987.773
when they reached the boy , the father sliced a new plug of tobacco , put the scalp back in place , and covered the raw edges with the slices .	43.8142
then he put a rag around the dressing to keep it in place .	17.17204
there was no cleaning or further care , but the wound healed in less than two weeks and showed no scar .	29.389217
veronica from the herb garden was also used to stop bleeding , and rue was an antiseptic .	17.942162
until quite recently , `` sterile ' ' maggots could be bought to apply to a wound	52.51801
they would feed on its surface , leaving it clean so that it could be medically treated .	23.709587
tetanus could be avoided by pouring warm turpentine over a wound .	27.357159
one family bound wounds with bacon or salt pork strips , or , if these were not handy , plain lard .	58.33569
another sprinkled sugar on hot coals and held the wounded foot or hand in the smoke .	28.563507
rabies were cured or prevented by `` madstones ' ' which the pioneer wore or carried .	17.810534
in 1872 there were known to be twenty-two in norton county , and one had been in the family for 200 years .	42.613956
another cure for hydrophobia was to suck the wounds , then cauterize them with a hot knife or poker .	16.704504
while nowadays we recognize the fact that there are many causes for bleeding at the nose , not long ago a nosebleed was simply that , and treatment had little variation .	77.40501
since a fall or blow might have caused it , a cold pack was usually first aid .	81.54457
this might be applied to the top of the nose or the back of the neck , pressed on the upper lip , or inserted into the nostril ( cotton was usually used in this last ) .	30.299192
nosebleed could be stopped by wrapping a red woolen string about the patient ' s neck and tying it in a knot for each year of his life .	16.78145
or the victim could chew hard on a piece of paper , meanwhile pressing his fingers tight in his ears .	27.1955
old sores could be healed by the constant application of a wash made of equal parts vinegar and water .	74.18372
blood blisters could be prevented from forming by rubbing a work blister immediately with any hard nonpoisonous substance .	92.616005
felons were cured by taking common salt and drying it in the oven , pounding it fine , and mixing it with equal parts of spirits of turpentine	28.295002
this mixture was then spread on a cloth and wrapped around the affected part .	55.648006
as the cloth dried , more of the mixture was applied , and after twenty-four hours the felon was supposed to be `` killed ' ' .	24.455492
`` get a bite , spit on it ' ' was a proverb .	10.788906
yellow clay was used as a poultice for insect bites and also for swellings	38.3002
not long ago `` denver mud ' ' was most popular .	59.97343
chiggers were a common pest along streams and where gardens and berries thrived	43.039524
so small as to be scarcely visible to the eye , they buried themselves in the victim ' s flesh .	22.121353
bathing the itching parts with kerosene gave relief and also killed the pests .	20.711924
ant bites were eased by applying liquid bluing .	9.274394
for mosquito bites a paste of half a glass of salt and half a glass of soda was made .	30.783949
for wasp stings onion juice , obtained by scraping an onion , gave quick relief .	30.056639
a handier remedy was to bathe the painful part in strong soapy water	54.877773
mud was sometimes used as well as soap .	10.320731
just plain old black dirt was also used as a pack to relieve wasp or bee stings .	13.2864
to keep them out of homes , even in the 1900 ' s , was a chore .	26.33473
bed slats were washed in alum water , legs of beds were placed in cups of kerosene , and all woodwork was treated liberally with corrosive sublimate , applied with a feather .	40.204704
kerosene was very effective in ridding pioneer homes of the pests .	12.0255785
at times pioneer children got lice in their hair .	8.908971
a kerosene shampoo seems a heroic treatment , but it did the job .	52.620872
to remove an insect from one ' s ear warm water should be inserted .	131.83942
a cinder or other small object could be removed from the eye by placing a flaxseed in the eye .	15.651058
as the seed swelled its glutinous covering protected the eyeball from irritation , and both the cinder and the seed could soon be washed out .	20.241327
another way to remove small objects from the eye was to have the person look cross-eyed	66.02604
the particle would then move toward the nose , where it could be wiped out with a wisp of cotton .	27.410273
shingles were cured by gentian , an old drug , used in combinations .	52.733353
for erysipelas a mixture of one dram borax and one ounce glycerine was applied to the afflicted part on linen cloth .	20.990086
itching skin , considered `` just nerves ' ' , was eased by treating with whiskey and salt .	17.769766
winter itch was treated by applying strong apple cider in which pulverized bloodroot had been steeped .	22.09583
to cure fungus growths on mouth or hands people made a strong tea by using a handful of sassafras bark in a quart of water .	37.131493
they drank half a cup of this morning and night , and they also washed and soaked their hands in the same solution .	50.446228
six treatments cured one case which lasted a month and had defied other remedies .	36.363247
frostbite was treated by putting the feet and hands in ice water or by rubbing them with snow .	71.62272
now one hears that heat and hot water are used instead .	44.40901
another remedy was oil of eucalyptus , used as well for chilblains .	8.08018
chilblains were also treated with tincture of capsicum or cabbage leaves .	137.70303
boils have always been a source of much trouble .	43.405617
a german informant gave me a sure cure made by combining rye flour and molasses into a poultice .	22.163687
another poultice was made from the inner bark of the elm tree , steeped in water until it formed a sticky , gummy solution .	30.164768
another frequent pioneer difficulty , caused by wearing rough and heavy shoes and boots , was corns .	23.476028
one veracious woman tells me she has used thin potato parings for both corns and calluses on her feet and they remove the pain or `` fire ' ' .	23.527939
another common cure was to soak the feet five or ten minutes in warm water , then to apply a solution of equal parts of soda and common brown soap on a kid bandage overnight .	41.710987
this softened the skin so that in the morning when the bandage was removed the corn could be scraped off and a bit of corn plaster put on .	42.21749
one young girl told me how her mother removed a wart from her finger by soaking a copper penny in vinegar for three days and then painting the finger with the liquid several times .	67.84244
another wart removal method was to rub each wart with a bean split open and then to bury the bean halves under the drip of the house for seven days .	18.354053
saliva gathered in the mouth after a night ' s sleep was considered poisonous	56.93635
wetting a wart with this saliva on wakening the first thing in the morning was supposed to cause it to disappear after only a few treatments , and strangely enough many warts did just that .	56.44068
one wart cure was to wrap it in a hair from a blonde gypsy .	17.287142
another was to soak raw beef in vinegar for twenty-four hours , tie it on the wart , and wear it for a week .	43.70579
a simpler method was to tie a thread tightly around the wart at its base and wear it this way .	54.11454
one person recommended to me washing the wart with sulphur water	53.277718
another said it should be rubbed with a cut potato three times daily .	94.40343
another common method was to cut an onion in two and place each half on the wart for a moment	100.07265
the onion was then fastened together with string and placed beneath a dripping eave .	20.606915
as the onion decayed , so did the wart .	16.770607
sore feet by calf ' s-foot , an herb from the pioneer ' s ubiquitous herb garden , or by soaking the feet in a pan of hot water in which two cups of salt had been dissolved .	22.779882
leg cramps , one person tells me , were relieved by standing barefoot with the weight of the body on the heel and pressing down hard .	49.777863
this does give relief , as i can testify .	2.733158
one doctor prescribed a tablespoon of whiskey or brandy before each meal for leg cramps .	31.242352
pains in the back of the leg and in the abdomen were prevented from reaching the upper body by tying a rope about the patient ' s waist .	18.42327
for sprains and swellings , one pint of cider vinegar and half a pint of spirits of turpentine added to three well beaten eggs was said to give speedy relief .	41.013012
except for the wine waiter in a restaurant -- always an inscrutable plenipotentiary unto himself , the genii with the keys to unlock the gates of the wine world are one ' s dealer , and the foreign shipper or negociant who in turn supplies him .	46.30926
in instances where both of these are persons or firms with integrity , the situation is ideal .	75.2887
it may , on occasion , be anything but that .	151.4677
however , by cultivating a wine dealer and accepting his advice , one will soon enough ascertain whether he has any knowledge of wines ( as opposed to what he may have been told by salesmen and promoters ) and , better yet , whether he has a taste for wine .	100.133125
again , by spreading one ' s purchases over several wine dealers , one becomes familiar with the names and specialties of reputable wine dealers and shippers abroad .	49.53286
this is important because , despite all the efforts of the french government , an appreciable segment of france ' s export trade in wines is still tainted with a misrepresentation approaching downright dishonesty , and there are many too many negociants who would rather turn a sou than amass a creditable reputation overseas .	32.34851
a good negociant or shipper will not only be the man or the firm which has cornered the wines from the best vineyards , or the best parts of them	51.195248
he may also be the one who makes and bottles the best blends -- sound wines from vineyards generally in his own district .	55.70448
these are the wines the french themselves use for everyday drinking , for even in france virtually no one drinks the grands crus on a meal-to-meal basis .	51.383533
the grands crus are expensive , and even doting palates tire of them .	16.204052
and certainly , in the case of the beginner or the comparatively uninitiated wine drinker , the palate and the capacity for appreciation will not be ready for the grands crus as a steady diet without frequent recourse to crus of less renown .	42.826817
there is nothing infra dig about a good blend from a good shipper .	10.621849
some of them are very delicious indeed , and there are many good ones exported -- unfortunately , along with others not so good , and worse .	80.036705
consultation with a reputable wine dealer and constant experimentation -- `` steering ever from the known to the unknown ' ' -- are the requisites .	70.65933
especially if one is travelling or dining out a great deal , their importance mounts .	67.30899
most of them , the world over , operate on the same principle by which justice is administered in france and some other latin countries the customer is to be considered guilty of abysmal ignorance until proven otherwise , with the burden of proof on the customer himself .	96.03915
now the drinking of wine ( and happily so ! !	80.9751
) is for the most part a recondite affair , for manifestly , if everyone in the world who could afford the best wines also liked them , the supply would dry up in no time at all .	77.031425
this is the only valid , and extenuating , argument that may be advanced in defense of the reprehensible attitude of the common wine waiter .	33.41732
a really good wine waiter is , paradoxically , the guardian ( and not the purveyor ) of his cellar against the visigoths .	16.154278
faced , on the one hand , with an always exhaustible supply of his best wines , and on the other by a clientele usually equipped with inexhaustible pocketbooks , it is a wonder indeed that all wine waiters are not afflicted with chronic ambivalence .	30.417564
the one way to get around them -- short of knowing exactly what one wants and sticking to it -- is to frequent a single establishment until its wine waiter is persuaded that one is at least as interested in wine as in spending money .	109.46478
only then , perhaps , will he reveal his jewels and his bargains .	15.151353
wine bought from a dealer should ideally be allowed to rest for several weeks before it is served .	39.66319
this is especially true of red wines , and a practice which , though not always practicable , is well worth the effort .	75.845055
it does no harm for wine to stand on end for a matter of days , but in terms of months and years it is fatal .	58.354023
wine stored for a long time should be on its side	75.39407
otherwise , the cork dries and air enters to spoil it .	3.72857
when stacking wine on its side in a bin , care should always be taken to be sure there is no air bubble left next to the cork .	37.328003
fat bottles , such as burgundies , have a way of rolling around in the bin and often need little props , such as a bit of cardboard or a chip of wood , to hold them in the proper reclining posture .	59.113632
too much dampness in the cellar rots the corks , again with ill effects .	136.7758
the best rule of thumb for detecting corked wine ( provided the eye has not already spotted it ) is to smell the wet end of the cork after pulling it if it smells of wine , the bottle is probably all right	73.53489
if it smells of cork , one has grounds for suspicion .	160.73042
seasonal rises or drops in temperature are bad for wine they age it prematurely .	82.99686
the ideal storage temperature for long periods is about fifty-five degrees , with an allowable range of five degrees above or below this , provided there are no sudden or frequent changes .	59.57406
consequently , one ' s wine closet or cellar should be away from machines or electrically driven furnaces .	31.782692
if one lives near a subway or an express parkway , the solution is to have one ' s wines stored with a dealer and brought home a few at a time .	48.6037
light , especially daylight , is always bad for wine .	51.23066
all in all , though , there is a good deal of nonsense expended over the preparations thought necessary for ordinary wine drinking	212.6686
many people go to extreme lengths in decanting , chilling or warming , or banishing without further investigation any bottle with so much as a slightly suspicious cork .	47.487644
no one should wish to deny these purists the obvious pleasure they derive from all this , and to give fair warning where warning is due , no one who becomes fond of wines ever avoids acquiring some degree of purism ! !	84.02198
but the fact remains that in most restaurants , including some of the best of paris and bordeaux and dijon , the bottle is frankly and simply brought from the cellar to the table when ordered , and all the conditioning or preparation it ever receives takes place while the chef is preparing the meal .	41.91991
a white wine , already at cool cellar temperature , may be adequately chilled in a bucket of ice and water or the freezing compartment of a refrigerator ( the former is far preferable ) in about fifteen minutes	23.248096
for those who live in a winter climate , there is nothing better than a bucket of water and snow .	23.872133
though by no means an ideal procedure , a red wine may similarly be brought from the cellar to the dining room and opened twenty minutes or so before serving time .	40.522964
but again , as one will have observed at any restaurant worth its salt , wine should be served in a large , tulip-shaped glass , which is never filled more than half full .	55.670227
in this way , red wine warms of itself quite rapidly -- and though it is true that it may not attain its potential of taste and fragrance until after the middle of the meal ( or the course ) , in the meantime it will have run the gamut of many beguiling and interesting stages .	47.5968
the only cardinal sin which may be committed in warming a wine is to force it by putting it next to the stove or in front of an open fire .	101.52713
this invariably effaces any wine ' s character , and drives its fragrance underground .	21.744703
it should not be forgotten that wines mature fastest in half-bottles , less fast in full bottles , slowly in magnums -- and slower yet in tregnums , double magnums , jeroboams , methuselahs , and imperiales , respectively .	18.836641
very old red wines often require several hours of aeration , and any red wine , brought from the cellar within half an hour of mealtime , should be uncorked and allowed some air .	27.524612
white wines should be opened when served , having been previously chilled in proportion to their sweetness .	51.697224
thus , sauternes or barsacs should be very cold	365.80124
a pouilly-fuisse or a chablis somewhat less cold .	6.1259503
over-chilling is an accepted method for covering up the faults of many a cheap or poor white wine , especially a dry wine -- and certainly less of a crime than serving a wine at a temperature which reveals it as unattractive .	71.35067
the fragrance and taste of any white wine will die a lingering death when it is allowed to warm or is exposed for long to the air .	85.74047
to quote professor saintsbury `` the last glass of claret or burgundy is as good as the first	33.33845
but the first glass of chateau d ' yquem or montrachet is a great deal better than the last ' ' ! !	37.023743
this does not mean , though , that a red wine improves with prolonged aeration there is a reasonable limit -- and wines kept over to the next meal or the next day , after they have once been opened , are never as good .	62.394238
if this must be done , they should always be corked and kept in a cool place	139.37326
it should be remembered that their lasting qualities are appreciably shorter than those of milk .	17.399065
a few red wines , notably those of the beaujolais , are better consumed at cellar temperature .	19.314018
by tradition , a red wine should be served at approximately room temperature -- if anything a little cooler -- and be aged enough for the tannin and acids to have worked out and the sediment have settled well .	61.609802
thus , red wine must , if possible , never be disturbed or shaken	29.241772
very old red wine is often decanted so that the puckering , bitter elements which have settled to the bottom will not be mingled with the wine itself .	57.483746
a tug-of-war between an old bottle and an inefficient corkscrew may do as much harm as a week at sea .	39.67945
the cork should be pulled gradually and smoothly , and the lip of the bottle wiped afterward .	12.977174
many people use wicker cradles for old red wine , lifting the bottle carefully from the bin into the cradle and eventually to the table , without disturbing the sediment .	30.71091
another school frowns on such a shortcut , and insists that after leaving the bin an old red wine should first stand on end for several days to allow the sediment to roll to the very bottom , after which the bottle may be gently eased to a tilted position on its side in the cradle .	48.347588
in france , when one wishes to entertain at a restaurant and serve truly fine old red wines , one visits the restaurant well ahead of time , chooses the wines and , with the advice of the manager and his chef , builds the menu around them .	45.217323
the wine waiter will see to it that the bottles are taken from the bin and opened at least in time to warm and aerate , preferably allowed to stand on end for as long as possible and , perhaps in the case of very old wines , be decanted .	41.72386
it may also be -- practically speaking -- a matter of good economy .	59.934666
for , in the process of decanting , the bottle is only tilted once instead of several or more times at the table hence , a minimum of the undesirable mixture of wine and dregs .	55.96809
though there are many exceptions , which we have noted in preceding pages , white wine is as a rule best consumed between two and six years old , and red wines , nowadays , between three and ten .	91.12162
red wines of good years tend to mature later and to keep longer	290.34506
the average claret is notably longer-lived than its opposite number , red burgundy .	310.91385
some clarets do not come into their own until they are ten or fifteen years of age , or even more .	38.7131
if a red bordeaux of a good name and year is bitter or acid , or cloying and muddy-tasting , leave it alone for a while .	80.00904
most of the wines of beaujolais , on the other hand , should be drunk while very young	29.63447
giffen replied punctually and enthusiastically `` rest assured that your accompanying letter of instructions shall be in the letter and spirit strictly complied with and most particularly in regard to that part of them relative to the completion of your noble and humane views ' ' .	65.46966
giffen lost no time in visiting the plantation .	6.6625667
the slaves appeared to be in good health and at work under john palfrey ' s overseer .	77.54687
william , who lived in neighboring st . mary ' s parish , had taken charge and decided that it would be best for all if the plantation were operated for another year .	50.185036
giffen advised acceptance of this plan , citing the depressed market for land then prevailing and the large stock of provisions at the plantation .	154.25633
if sold then , the land and improvements might bring only $5 , 000 .	42.95677
early in january , 1844 he had a conference with henry and william in new orleans , and upon learning of gorham ' s intention , henry remonstrated calmly but firmly with his brother .	50.650223
the emancipation plan would not only be injurious to all the heirs , he contended , but would be a form of cruelty perpetrated on the hapless negroes .	25.728628
they were not capable of supporting themselves off the plantation , and louisiana law required their removal from the state .	41.32072
gorham refused to accept money for slave property , but did he realize how much expense and trouble the transportation of his negroes to the north involved ? ?	96.146095
the suggestion that giffen hire out the slaves was not realistic , since no planter would take the risk of having negroes who knew they were to be free living with his own slaves .	47.905865
henry hid his annoyance , although both he and william were furious with their yankee brother .	141.90634
william , who did not write to gorham , told giffen that unless he could operate the plantation as usual for a year , he would sue `` amicably ' ' to protect his interests .	43.707283
palfrey was determined that his portion of the slaves be converted to wage laborers during the transition period before emancipation .	53.412178
if william wished to continue operations for a year , why not simply leave the negroes undisturbed and pay them `` as high wages to remain there as are ever paid the labor of persons of their sex & age .	149.04073
a disposition to exert themselves for my benefit would perhaps be a motive with some of them to come into the scheme .	55.724113
their having family ties on our plantation & the adjoining one would be a stronger inducement ' ' .	39.354412
when he heard of his brothers ' anger , palfrey was still hopeful that they could be persuaded to accept his notion of paying wages .	22.853851
if not , he was willing to accede to william ' s wishes in any way that did not block his ultimate aim .	61.835632
william was adamant on one point under no circumstances would he allow the negroes to remain on the plantation with his and henry ' s slaves if they were told of their coming freedom .	50.361065
knowing the antipathy that existed in louisiana against increasing the number of free negroes , giffen suggested that palfrey bring them to boston at once , and then send them on to liberia .	62.587326
lacking specific instructions , he agreed to william ' s condition .	21.716183
in march there was a division of the slaves , and giffen carried out his instructions as nearly as possible .	76.36818
of the fifty-two slaves , giffen succeeded in getting a lot of twenty , twelve of whom were females .	42.370823
`` i considered that your views would be best carried out ' ' , he explained , `` by taking women whose progeny will of course be free & more fully extend the philantrophy of emancipation .	68.3161
i have also taken the old servants of your father as a matter of conscience & justice ' ' .	49.037186
the ages of the slaves ranged from sixty-five , for an old house servant , to an unnamed newborn child .	40.022743
if palfrey ever had any doubts about the wickedness of slavery , they were put aside after he received an inventory of the slave property he had inherited .	48.634476
this cold reckoning of human worth in a legal paper , devoid of compassion or humanity , was all he needed .	107.11439
each human being , known only by a given name , had a cash value .	66.42646
old sam ' s sixty-five years had reduced his value to $150	30.575466
rose , a twelve-year-old with child-bearing potential , was worth $400 .	13.5374365
in rejecting any claim to the value of the slave property , palfrey was giving up close to $7 , 000 .	39.32536
palfrey ' s brothers each received lots of sixteen negroes , and for bookkeeping purposes it was agreed that all lots were to be valued at $6 , 666 . 66 .	28.846529
thus twenty `` black souls ' ' were to remain ignorant of their imminent journey to the land of free men .	24.305151
giffen extracted one concession from william the house servants could be free at any time gorham thought expedient .	52.7523
despite giffen ' s warning , palfrey still had plans for freeing his slaves in louisiana .	27.540918
yet even if he could get the necessary approval , fourteen of his negroes could not be manumitted without special permission .	74.32206
according to state law a slave had to be at least thirty years old before he could be freed .	32.536972
palfrey petitioned the state legislature to waive the requirement .	94.86592
otherwise , freedom would mean removal from the state in which `` as the place of their past residence from birth , or for many years , it would be materially for their advantage to be at liberty to remain ' ' .	59.011063
on march 11 the louisiana legislature voted unanimously to table the petition .	79.13206
news of the legislative veto appeared in the new orleans papers , and henry and william became incensed by the fact that they had not been told of the attempt in advance .	49.12716
henry stormed into giffen ' s office waving a copy of the new orleans courier , shouting that the emancipation scheme had become a public affair , and that it would reach the `` ears of the people on the plantation , and make them restless & unhappy ' ' .	30.090769
his brothers ' anger caused palfrey genuine concern , for he had imposed a dual mission upon himself to free his slaves , and to keep the family from falling apart over the issue .	64.52577
when giffen decided to charge him interest on the loan from john palfrey , gorham readily assented , vowing that in a matter of dollars and cents , his brothers would never have any cause to complain of him .	36.38249
in view of these difficulties , palfrey decided to go to louisiana .	15.597458
giffen had already urged him to journey south , if only for a few days to clear up matters .	55.319473
his duties as massachusetts secretary of state obliged him to wait until the adjournment of the legislature in mid-april .	26.809202
palfrey told his wife of his intentions for the first time , and left for new orleans apprehensively invoking a special blessing of providence that he might be allowed to see his family again .	32.955196
during his journey palfrey stopped off to see two abolitionists .	18.896132
in both cases he desired information about placing the freedmen in homes once they arrived in the north .	33.033394
in new york , lydia maria child welcomed him enthusiastically `` i have lately heard of you from the legislature of louisiana , and felt joy at your public recognition of the brotherhood of man ' ' .	66.29643
mrs . child , who had once apologized for sending editor palfrey a book on slavery , now confided that she had helped one of henry palfrey ' s slaves escape to canada some years before , but asked him not to advertise the fact in louisiana .	90.767456
she agreed to take charge of five or six of the negroes should palfrey decide to send them north immediately .	128.91432
at lexington , kentucky , palfrey consulted with cassius m . clay on the same subject , but with no apparent result .	48.169857
despite his apprehensions about his personal safety , palfrey ' s reception in new orleans was more than cordial .	17.938988
instead of the expected `` annoyances ' ' due to the nature of his mission , he received many calling cards and invitations from `` gentlemen of mark , on whom i had no sort of claim , & have had many more invitations than i could accept ' ' .	128.76295
he later told abolitionist edmund quincy of the `` marked attention and civility ' ' with which the new orleans gentlemen and the upriver planters greeted him .	35.848076
the memory of this southern hospitality did not survive the trials of coming antislavery years and civil war .	70.23091
palfrey ' s autobiography contains a melodramatic account of two perilous days spent among the planters of attakapas , `` many of whom were coarse & passionate people , much excited by what they heard of my plans ' ' .	37.644394
he proceeded with his task bravely -- in his memoirs , at least -- before the `` passions of my neighbors should have time to boil too high ' ' .	33.914467
palfrey had already made up his mind that he would allow the men , but not the women , to choose freely whether or not to go north for freedom .	68.23178
the women by remaining behind condemned their children , born and unborn , to bondage .	11.630445
he had a short private talk with each adult slave .	225.65617
only one objected , but palfrey soon convinced him that he ought to go with the others .	17.702314
all the slaves joined in requesting that they be allowed to delay their departure until the end of the planting season , so that they could get in `` their own little produce ' ' .	36.435146
the slaves were to remain as wage laborers for his account .	49.50838
william ' s threat that under no conditions would he allow `` freedom-conscious ' ' slaves to mix with his own was not carried out , for the plantation continued in operation as before .	65.63751
palfrey returned to massachusetts greatly relieved to have made an arrangement `` so satisfactory to my judgment & my conscience ' ' .	95.65556
from cambridge , palfrey maintained a close interest in the welfare of his slaves .	14.512664
in fact , as the time for their departure approached , his solicitousness increased .	83.13937
should any slave change his mind and request to leave earlier , giffen was to provide passage at once .	141.81732
when a sailing date of march , 1845 was finally established , palfrey made sure that the negroes would have comfortable quarters in new orleans and aboard ship .	44.940605
giffen assured him that the captain and his mate had personally promised to treat the negroes with consideration .	77.87373
palfrey was also concerned about the question of what wage to pay for their labor throughout 1844 .	202.73857
the plantation was sold in january , 1845 , and palfrey thought the new owner ought to pay his people two months ' wages .	85.453575
giffen suggested fifty dollars as fair compensation for a year ' s work	13.298294
the new owner at attakapas declined to enter into any philanthropic arrangement .	32.82392
on march 21 , 1845 the bark bashaw weighed anchor at new orleans , while on the levee henry and william palfrey waved farewell to their father ' s former chattels who must have looked back at the receding shore with mingled regret and jubilation .	29.237595
not all of palfrey ' s slaves were aboard the bashaw .	58.69381
giffen had advised that it would not be too difficult to obtain freedom locally for the old house servants .	49.022373
two of these were included in palfrey ' s lot .	17.449242
giffen filed a petition for permission to emancipate four slaves ( all more than fifty years old ) with the st . martin ' s parish police jury .	41.376595
after an initial rejection , which he attributed to a `` general excitement against abolition and emancipation ' ' , giffen bribed the right individuals on the jury , and got the permission without further delay .	28.000008
when the negroes landed at boston a month later they were , of course , no longer slaves .	32.560284
slavery was prohibited in massachusetts by the terms of the constitution of 1780 , which declared `` all men are born free and equal ' ' .	19.306887
nevertheless , palfrey arranged a religious ceremony at king ' s chapel to formalize the emancipation .	8.59505
an eyewitness recalled how awkward the red-turbaned colored women appeared as they curtseyed in the church doorway , and the diffidence the former slaves displayed while they listened to the few words that declared them free .	68.33783
once the question of emancipation was settled to palfrey ' s satisfaction , he faced a real problem in placing the freedmen in suitable homes as servants .	36.366966
palfrey tried fruitlessly to place a negro boy in the hopedale community , but he had better luck in his other attempts .	35.718502
mrs . child , true to her word , helped place anna and her four children with a quaker family named hathaway near canandaigua , new york .	33.058426
this group had been palfrey ' s greatest worry since anna was in bad health , and her children were too young to work for their keep .	62.294823
but certainly the new frontier has brought to washington a group more varied in background and interest .	211.63652
secretary of state dean rusk , a former rhodes scholar and mills college dean , has headed the rockefeller foundation and in that role expended large sums for international cultural exchange .	52.40714
one of his initial acts in office was to appoint philip coombs of the ford foundation as the first assistant secretary of state for educational and cultural affairs .	27.38652
( `` in the late forties and fifties ' ' , coombs has declared in defining his role , `` two strong new arms were added to reinforce united states foreign policy economic assistance and military assistance .	52.56624
as we embark upon the sixties we have an opportunity to build a third strong arm , aimed at the development of people , at the fuller realization of their creative human potential , and a better understanding among them ' ' .	38.128986
many of the new appointees are art collectors .	7.7953568
ambassador-at-large averell harriman has returned to the capital with a collection of paintings that include renoir , cezanne , gauguin , van gogh , toulouse-lautrec , degas , matisse , picasso , and walt kuhn .	7.8497577
the director of the peace corps , r . sargent shriver , jr . , a kennedy brother-in-law , collects heavily among the moderns , including kenzo okada and josef albers .	8.860205
secretary of the treasury douglas dillon owns a prize monet , femmes dans un jardin .	6.1555066
secretary of defense robert mcnamara , former president of the ford motor company , comes from a generation different from that of eisenhower ' s own first secretary of defense , charles wilson , who had been head of general motors .	39.687546
unlike wilson , who at times seemed almost anti-intellectual in his earthy pragmatism .	7.853785
an inveterate reader of books , he chose while working in detroit to live in the university community of ann arbor , almost forty miles away .	48.989223
he selected as comptroller of defense , not a veteran accountant , but a former rhodes scholar , charles hitch , who is author of a study on the economics of defense in the nuclear age .	21.28653
one of the president ' s special assistants , the harvard dean mcgeorge bundy , was co-author with henry l . stimson of the latter ' s classic memoir , on active service .	24.119371
another , arthur m . schlesinger , jr . , has won a pulitzer prize in history	13.572068
his wife , marion , is a portrait painter .	5.753827
the press secretary , pierre salinger , was a child prodigy as a pianist .	15.580128
( `` it is always of sorrow to me when i find people who neither know nor understand music ' ' , he declared not long ago in proposing that white house prizes be awarded for music and art .	87.108376
) mrs . arthur goldberg , wife of the secretary of labor , paints professionally and helps sponsor the associated artists ' gallery in the district of columbia .	38.844772
( `` artists are always at a new frontier ' ' , she claims .	19.492338
`` in fact , the search is almost more important than the find ' ' .	24.661343
) mrs . henry labouisse , wife of the new director of the foreign aid program , is the writer and lecturer eve curie .	29.944206
at last count , sixteen former rhodes scholars ( see box on page 13 ) had been appointed to the administration , second in number only to its harvard graduates .	77.36276
besides schlesinger , the justice department ' s information director , edwin guthman , has won a pulitzer prize ( for national reporting ) .	29.136095
postmaster general j . edward day , who must deal with matters of postal censorship , is himself author of a novel , bartholf street , albeit one he was obliged to publish at his own expense .	44.61831
william walton , a writer-turned-painter , has been a long-time friend of the president .	16.358355
they arrived in washington about the same time during the early postwar years kennedy as the young congressman from massachusetts	133.33748
walton , after a wartime stint with time-life , to become bureau chief for the new republic .	44.59524
both lived in georgetown , were unattached , and shared an active social life .	177.57097
walton , who soon made a break from journalism to become one of the capital ' s leading semi-abstract painters , vows that he and kennedy never once discussed art in those days .	61.929554
during last year ' s campaign , kennedy asked walton , an utter novice in organization politics , to assist him .	38.74535
walton dropped everything to serve as a district co-ordinator in the hard-fought wisconsin primary and proved so useful that he was promoted to be liaison officer to critically important new york city .	32.10426
walton , who served as a correspondent with general james gavin ' s paratroopers during the invasion of france , combines the soul of an artist with the lingo of a tough guy .	30.573471
he provoked outraged editorials when , after a post-inaugural inspection of the white house with mrs . kennedy , he remarked to reporters , `` we just cased the joint to see what was there ' ' .	26.830355
already the president and the first lady have deputized him to advise on matters ranging from the furnishing of the white house to the renovation of lafayette square .	15.104303
a man of great talent , he will continue to serve as a sort of presidential trouble-shooter , strictly ex officio , for culture .	25.23148
a more official representative is the secretary of the interior .	9.880234
udall , who comes from one of the mormon first-families of arizona , is a bluff , plain-spoken man with a lust for politics and a habit of landing right in the middle of the fight .	27.378668
but even while sparring furiously with republican politicians , he displays a deep and awesome veneration for anyone with cultural attainments .	46.93084
his private dining room has become a way station for visiting intellectuals such as c . p . snow , arnold toynbee , and aaron copland .	48.345974
udall argues that interior affairs should cover a great deal more than dams and wildlife preserves .	19.313553
after promoting frost ' s appearance at the inauguration , he persuaded the poet to return several months later to give a reading to a select audience of cabinet members , members of congress , and other washington notables gathered in the state department auditorium .	44.026917
the event was so successful that the interior secretary plans to serve as impresario for similar ones from time to time , hoping thereby to add to the cultural enrichment of the administration .	53.70654
his ideas in this respect , however , sometimes arouse critical response .	452.0554
one tempest was stirred up last march when udall announced that an eight-and-a-half-foot bronze statue of william jennings bryan , sculpted by the late gutzon borglum , would be sent `` on indefinite loan ' ' to salem , illinois , bryan ' s birthplace .	29.28051
spokesmen for the nation ' s tradition-minded sculptors promptly claimed that udall was exiling the statue because of his own hostility to this art form .	47.88671
they dug up a speech he had made two years earlier as a congressman , decrying the more than two hundred statues , monuments , and memorials which `` dot the washington landscape as patriotic societies and zealous friends are constantly hatching new plans ' ' .	44.58946
hoping to cut down on such works , udall had proposed that a politician be at least fifty years departed before he is memorialized .	69.359665
he is not likely to win this battle easily .	798.8378
in the case of the borglum statue an interior aide was obliged to announce that there had been a misunderstanding and that the secretary had no desire to `` hustle ' ' it out of washington .	28.139101
the last congress adopted seven bills for memorials , including one to taras shevchenko , the ukrainian poet laureate	9.1388645
active warfare is raging between the forces pressing for a monument to the first roosevelt on theodore roosevelt island in the potomac , and tr . ' s own living children , who wish to preserve the island as a wildlife sanctuary .	38.419937
the hotly debated plan for the capital ' s franklin d . roosevelt memorial , a circle of huge tablets engraved with his speeches ( and promptly dubbed by one of its critics , `` instant stonehenge ' ' ) , is another of udall ' s headaches , since as supervisor of the national parks commission he will share in the responsibility for building it .	24.553568
`` washington ' ' , president kennedy has been heard to remark ironically , `` is a city of southern efficiency and northern charm ' ' .	51.277462
there have been indications that he hopes to redress that situation , commencing with the white house .	46.79418
one of mrs . kennedy ' s initial concerns as first lady was the sad state of the furnishings in a building which is supposed to be a national shrine .	43.842728
ever since the fire of 1812 destroyed the beautiful furniture assembled by president thomas jefferson , the white house has collected a hodgepodge of period pieces , few of them authentic or aesthetic .	49.906857
mrs . kennedy shows a determination to change all this .	61.847515
not long after moving in she turned up a richly carved desk , hewed from the timbers of the british ship h . m . s . resolute and presented to president hayes by queen victoria .	22.470066
it now serves the president in his oval office .	7.041982
later , browsing in an old issue of the gazette des beaux-arts , she found a description of a handsome gilt pier-table purchased in 1817 by president james monroe .	24.356554
with its coating of gold radiator paint removed -- a gaucherie of some earlier tenant -- it will now occupy its rightful place in the oval blue room on the first floor of the white house .	24.078802
but it soon became clear that the search for eighteenth-century furniture ( which mrs . kennedy feels is the proper period for the white house ) must be pursued in places other than government storage rooms .	107.168175
the first lady appointed a fine arts advisory committee for the white house , to locate authentic pieces as well as to arrange ways to acquire them .	21.380728
her effort to put the home of living presidents on the same basis as mount vernon and monticello recognizes no party lines .	78.79097
by rough estimate her committee , headed by henry francis du pont , contains three times as many republicans as democrats .	46.234165
the press releases emanating from the white house give a clue to the activity within .	178.96616
a valuable pencil-and-sepia allegorical drawing of benjamin franklin by jean-honore fragonard has been donated by the art dealer georges wildenstein and now hangs in the blue room .	19.598423
the american institute of interior designers is redecorating the white house library .	10.124605
secretary and mrs . dillon have contributed enough pieces of empire furniture , including dolley madison ' s own sofa , to furnish a room in that style .	29.238571
and part of a fabulous collection of vermeil hollowware , bequeathed to the white house by the late mrs . margaret thompson biddle , has been taken out of its locked cases and put on display in the state dining room .	32.778038
woman ' s place is in the home man must attend to matters of the yard .	179.29416
one of the vexatious problems to first confront president kennedy was the property lying just across pennsylvania avenue from the white house .	56.453873
congress had already appropriated money , and plans were well along to tear down the buildings flanking lafayette square and replace them with what one critic calls the `` marble monumentality ' ' of government office buildings .	49.733612
while a senator , kennedy had unsuccessfully pushed a bill to preserve the belasco theater , as well as the dolley madison and the benjamin taylor houses , all scheduled for razing .	21.385393
what to do about it now that he was president ? ?	50.2159
only a few days after moving into the white house .	14.572324
kennedy made a midnight inspection of the square .	16.890844
then he called in his friend walton and turned over the problem to him , with instructions to work out what was best -- provided it didn ' t pile unnecessary burdens on the president .	60.369724
one of the offices slated for reconstruction is the aged court of claims , diagonally across the street from the white house .	20.129057
but judge marvin jones , senior member of the court , is an elderly gentleman who lives at the nearby metropolitan club and desires to walk to work .	31.908123
more importantly , he also happens to be the brother-in-law of sam rayburn , speaker of the house .	11.140209
there were aesthetic problems as well as political .	25.828218
on delving deeper , walton discovered that most of the buildings fronting the square could be classified as `` early nondescript ' ' .	26.589048
the old belasco theater , over which many people had grown sentimental , was only a shell of its former self after arduous years as a uso center .	51.318226
the dolley madison house , walton concluded , was scarcely worth preserving .	29.889555
`` the attempt to save the square ' s historic value ' ' , he declares , `` came half a century too late ' ' .	38.32385
surrounded by ancient elms , the campus is spacious and beautiful .	9.098891
the dartmouth student does not live in monastic seclusion , as he once did .	44.79921
but his is still a simple life relatively free of the female presence or influence , and he must go far , even though he may go fast , for sophisticated pleasures .	58.889877
he is still heir to the rare gifts of space and silence , if he chooses to be .	46.50795
he is by no means the country boy he might have been in the last century , down from the hills with bear grease on his hair and a zeal for book learning in his heart .	84.309814
the men ' s shops on hanover ' s main street compare favorably with those in princeton and new haven .	35.197414
and the automobiles that stream out of hanover each weekend , toward smith and wellesley and mount holyoke , are no less rakish than those leaving cambridge or west philadelphia .	79.95977
but there has always been an outdoor air to dartmouth .	102.87698
the would-be sophisticate and the citybred youth adopt this air without embarrassment .	227.86163
no one here pokes fun at manly virtues .	2.565856
and this gives rise to an easy camaraderie probably unequaled elsewhere in the ivy league .	11.299063
thus , when dartmouth ' s winter carnival -- widely recognized as the greatest , wildest , roaringest college weekend anywhere , any time -- was broadcast over a national television hookup , prexy john sloan dickey appeared on the screen in rugged winter garb , topped off by a tam-o ' -shanter which he confessed had been acquired from a smith girl .	54.973206
president dickey ' s golden retriever , frolicking in the snow at his feet , added to the picture of masculine informality .	25.098099
this carefree disdain for `` side ' ' cropped up again in the same television broadcast .	58.60569
dean thaddeus seymour , wearing ski clothes , was crowning a beauteous damsel queen of the carnival .	7.800918
she must have looked temptingly pretty to the dean as he put the crown on her head .	82.209885
dartmouth students enjoy other unusual diversions with equal sang-froid .	3.1391902
for example , groups regularly canoe down the connecticut river .	38.45421
this is in honor of john ledyard , class of 1773 , who scooped a canoe out of a handy tree and first set the course way back in his own student days .	62.895863
and these hardy travelers are not unappreciated today .	3.0424805
they are hailed by the nation ' s press , and smith girls throng the riverbanks at northampton and refresh the voyageurs with hot soup and kisses .	25.047424
dartmouth ' s favorite and most characteristic recreation is skiing .	6.3929715
since the days when their two thousand pairs of skis outnumbered those assembled anywhere else in the united states , the students have stopped regarding the olympic ski team as another name for their own .	62.613773
yet dartmouth still is the dominant member of the intercollegiate ski union , which includes the winter sports colleges of canada as well as those of this country .	15.931995
dartmouth students ski everywhere in winter , starting with their own front door .	56.98663
they can hire a horse and go ski-joring behind him , or move out to oak hill , where there ' s a lift .	26.367077
the dartmouth skiway , at holt ' s ledge , ten miles north of the campus , has one of the best terrains in the east , ranging from novice to expert .	22.486444
forty miles farther north is mount moosilauke , dartmouth ' s own mountain .	34.087265
here , at the ravine lodge , president dickey acts as host every year to about a hundred freshmen who are being introduced by the dartmouth outing club to life on the trails .	62.647194
the lodge , built of hand-hewn virgin spruce , can handle fifty people for dining , sleeping , or lounging in its huge living room .	35.64102
the outing club also owns a chain of fourteen cabins and several shelters , extending from the vermont hills , just across the river from the college , through hanover to the college grant -- 27 , 000 acres of wilderness 140 miles north up in the logging country .	38.181293
the cabins are equipped with bunks , blankets , and cooking equipment and are ideal bases for hikes and skiing trips .	23.409555
the club runs regular trips to the cabins , but many of the students prefer to take off in small unofficial groups for a weekend of hunting , fishing , climbing , or skiing .	28.36514
under the auspices of the outing club , dartmouth also has the mountaineering club , which takes on tough climbs like mount mckinley , and bait & bullet , whose interests are self-evident , and even sports a woodman ' s team , which competes with other new england colleges in wood sawing and chopping , canoe races , and the like .	44.28067
there is much to be said for a college that , while happily attuned to the sophisticated ivies , still gives its students a chance to get up early in the morning and drive along back roads where a glimpse of small game , deer , or even bear is not uncommon .	65.33574
city boys find a lot of learning in the feel of an ax handle or in the sharp tang of a sawmill , come upon suddenly in a backwoods logging camp .	30.018839
and on the summit of mount washington , where thirty-five degrees below zero is commonplace and the wind velocity has registered higher than anywhere else in the world , there is a kind of wisdom to be found that other men often seek in the himalayas `` because it is there ' ' .	37.77915
there is much to be said for such a college -- and dartmouth men have been accused of saying it too often and too loudly .	66.87404
their affection for their college home has even caused president dickey to comment on this `` place loyalty ' ' as something rather specially hanoverian .	105.966965
probably a lawyer once said it best for all time in the supreme court of the united states .	16.873617
early in the nineteenth century the state of new hampshire was casting about for a way to found its own state university .	64.746445
it fixed on dartmouth college , which was ready-made and just what the proctor ordered .	84.84155
the legislators decided to `` liberate ' ' dartmouth and entered into a tug-o ' -war with the college trustees over the control of classrooms , faculty , and chapel .	39.336872
for a time there were two factions on the campus fighting for possession of the student body .	47.31928
the struggle was resolved in 1819 in the supreme court in one of the most intriguing cases in our judicial history .	14.663647
in 1817 the lawyers were generally debating the legal inviolability of private contracts and charters .	14.493128
a lawyer , hired by the college , was arguing specifically for dartmouth daniel webster , class of 1801 , made her plight the dramatic focus of his whole plea .	39.875477
in an age of oratory , he was the king of orators , and both he himself and chief justice marshall were bathed in manly tears , as uncle dan ' l reached his thundering climax	49.97813
`` it is , sir , as i have said , a small college , and yet there are those who love it .	48.571114
dartmouth is today still a small college -- and still a private one , thanks to webster ' s eloquence .	44.65335
this is not out of keeping with its origins , probably the most humble of any in the ivy group .	71.6792
eleazar wheelock , a presbyterian minister , founded the school in 1769 , naming it after the second earl of dartmouth , its sponsor and benefactor .	24.983906
eleazar , pausing on the hanover plain , found its great forests and remoteness good and with his own hands built the first college hall , a log hut dedicated `` for the education & instruction of youth of the indian tribes in this land in reading , writing & all parts of learning which shall appear necessary and expedient for civilizing & christianizing children of pagans as well as in all liberal arts and sciences	101.17955
and also of english youth and any others ' ' .	3.64461
it was a hardy undertaking , and wheelock ' s was indeed `` a voice crying in the wilderness ' ' .	21.85669
a road had to be hacked through trackless forests between hanover and portsmouth to permit governor wentworth and a company of gentlemen to attend the first dartmouth commencement in 1771 .	31.044523
the governor and his retinue thoughtfully brought with them a glorious silver punchbowl which is still one of the cherished possessions of the college .	24.755455
the exuberance on this occasion set a standard for subsequent dartmouth gatherings .	112.47416
a student orator `` produced tears from a great number of the learned ' ' even before the punch was served .	47.900097
then from the branches of a near-by tree an indian underclassman , disdaining both the platform and the english language , harangued the assemblage in his aboriginal tongue .	17.884434
governor wentworth contributed an ox for a barbecue on the green beneath the three-hundred-foot pines , and a barrel of rum was broached .	12.397885
the cook got drunk , and president wheelock proved to be a man of broad talents by carving the ox himself .	41.430454
future commencements were more decorous perhaps , but the number of graduates increased from the original four at a relatively slow pace .	128.16478
by the end of the nineteenth century , in 1893 , when the big three , columbia , and penn were populous centers of learning , dartmouth graduated only sixty-nine .	58.066216
the dormitories , including the beloved dartmouth hall , could barely house two hundred students in spartan fashion .	68.33515
then in 1893 dr . william jewett tucker became president and the college ' s great awakening began .	35.058914
he transformed dartmouth from a small new hampshire institution into a national college .	54.118126
by 1907 the number of undergraduates had risen to 1 , 107 .	13.348862
and at his last commencement , in that year , dr . tucker and dartmouth were honored by the presence of distinguished academic visitors attesting to the new stature of the college .	42.454945
the presidents of cornell , wisconsin , c . c . n . y . , bowdoin , vermont , brown , columbia , princeton , yale , and harvard and the presidents emeritus of harvard and michigan were there .	14.919848
dartmouth is numerically still a small college today , with approximately twenty-nine hundred undergraduates .	24.2621
but it has achieved a cross-section of students from almost all the states , and two-thirds of its undergraduates come from outside new england .	57.37839
over 450 different schools are usually represented in each entering class .	126.4139
only a dozen or so schools send as many as six students , and there are seldom more than fifteen men in any single delegation .	43.205246
about two-thirds of the boys now come from public schools .	24.204046
it is still a college only and not a university	40.15968
it is , in fact , the only college in the ivy group .	65.30014
however , three distinguished associated graduate schools offer professional curriculums -- the dartmouth medical school ( third oldest in the country and founded in 1797 ) , the thayer school of engineering , and the amos tuck school of business administration .	33.63366
all three are purposely kept small , with a current total enrollment of about two hundred .	59.046837
all three schools coordinate their educational programs with that of the undergraduate college and , like the college proper , place emphasis upon a broad liberal arts course as the proper foundation for specialized study .	116.11853
students of the college who are candidates for the a . b . degree and can satisfy the academic requirements of the medical and business schools , may enter either of these associated schools at the beginning of senior year , thus completing the two-year postgraduate course in one year .	57.778034
the thayer school offers a year of postgraduate study in somewhat the same way , after a boy wins a b . s . in engineering .	44.569942
so dartmouth is moving closer to the others in the ivy group .	13.249143
it is still , however , the junior member of the league , if not in years at least in the catching up it has had to do .	68.16733
it has not been a well-known school for any part of the span the other ivies have enjoyed .	64.88463
however much football has been over-emphasized , the public likes to measure its collegiate favorites by the scoreboard , so , while yale need never give its record a thought again since outscoring its opponents 694 to 0 in the season of 1888 , dartmouth had to wait until its championship team of 1925 for national recognition .	69.1879
it has come on with a rush in more significant areas .	224.4899
today it espouses certain ideas in its curriculum that other institutions might consider somewhat breathtaking .	74.106514
but dartmouth preserves its youthful brashness even in its educational attitudes , and , although some of its experiments may still be in the testing stage , they make for lively copy .	55.817986
president emeritus hopkins once proposed to corral an `` aristocracy of brains ' ' in hanover .	12.513532
the person who left the buggy there has never been identified .	22.543545
it was a busy street , conveniently near the shopping center , and unattended horses and wagons were often left at the curbside .	17.729977
there are , of course , many weaknesses in any case against emma .	35.116497
she didn ' t like her stepmother , but nothing is known to have occurred shortly before the crime that could have caused such a murderous rage .	60.376602
she had no way of knowing in advance whether an opportunity for murder existed .	180.12262
she would have been taking more than a fair risk of being seen and recognized during her travels .	130.12561
if she avoided the train and hired a buggy , the stableman might have recognized her .	38.9891
if police had checked on her more thoroughly than is indicated , she would be completely eliminated as a suspect .	51.169247
uncle john vinnicum morse was the immediate popular suspect .	142.46121
his sudden unannounced appearance at the borden home was strange in that he did not carry an iota of baggage with him , although he clearly intended to stay overnight , if not longer .	62.87688
lizzie stated during the inquest that while her father and uncle were in the sitting room the afternoon before the murders , she had been disturbed by their voices and had closed her door , even though it was a very hot day .	38.946262
it is evident that lizzie did not tell everything she overheard between her father and her uncle morse .	39.065353
at that time jennings had a young law associate named arthur s . phillips .	21.592426
a few years ago , not too long before his death , phillips revealed in a newspaper story that he had always suspected morse of the murders .	45.734505
he said morse and borden had quarreled violently in the house that day , information which must have come from lizzie .	94.73907
it was obviously the sound of this argument that caused lizzie to close her door .	118.44146
the new bedford standard-times has reported knowlton as saying , long after the trial , that if he only knew what borden said during his conversation with morse , he would have convicted `` somebody ' ' .	40.090015
notice , knowlton did not say that he would have obtained a conviction in the trial of lizzie borden .	26.70852
he said he would have convicted `` somebody ' ' .	1.9601732
it is known that morse did associate with a group of itinerant horse traders who made their headquarters at westport , a town not far from fall river .	46.771606
they were a vagabond lot and considered to be shady and undesirable characters .	11.215549
fall river police did go to westport to see if they could get any information against morse and possibly find an accomplice whom he might have hired from among these men .	115.110115
morse ' s alibi was not as solid as it seemed .	28.178112
he said he returned from the visit to his niece on the 11 20 streetcar .	42.059326
the woman in the house where the niece was staying backed up his story and said she left when he did to shop for her dinner .	51.98562
if this woman had delayed until after 11 20 to start her shopping , she would have had little time in which to prepare the substantial meal that was eaten at dinner in those days .	53.871563
it is possible that morse told the woman it was 11 20 , but it could have been earlier , since she did serve dinner on time .	74.6222
police did make an attempt to check on morse ' s alibi .	5.5063024
they interviewed the conductor of the streetcar morse said he had taken , but the man did not remember morse as a passenger .	45.15641
questioned further , morse said that there had been four or five priests riding on the same car with him .	42.53394
the conductor did recall having priests as passengers and this satisfied police , although the conductor also pointed out that in heavily catholic fall river there were priests riding on almost every trip the streetcar made , so morse ' s statement really proved nothing .	113.72917
we do know that morse left the house before nine o ' clock .	12.803696
bridget testified she saw him leave through the side door .	72.49252
morse said borden let him out and locked the screen door .	37.326233
from that point on he said he went to the post office and then walked leisurely to where his niece was staying , more than a mile away .	26.739353
he met nobody he knew on this walk .	7.0122266
there is no accounting of his movements in this long gap of time which covers the early hours when mrs . borden was killed .	66.76491
morse testified that while he was having breakfast in the dining room , mrs . borden told the servant , `` bridget , i want you to wash these windows today ' ' .	24.520887
bridget ' s testimony was in direct contradiction .	3.0151792
she said it was after she returned from her vomiting spell in the back yard that mrs . borden told her to wash the windows .	24.506008
this was long after morse had left the house .	56.693665
morse ' s knowledge of what mrs . borden told bridget could indicate that he had returned secretly to the house and was hidden there .	45.999016
he knew the house fairly well , he had been there on two previous visits during the past three or four months alone .	66.20886
and despite knowlton ' s attempts to show that the house was locked up tighter than a drum , this was not true .	40.669384
the screen door was unlocked for some ten or fifteen minutes while bridget was sick in the back .	23.739985
it was unlocked all the time she was washing windows .	138.27634
morse could have returned openly while bridget was sick in the back yard and gone up to the room he had occupied .	33.122486
mrs . borden would not have been alarmed if she saw morse with an ax or hatchet in his hand .	27.394867
he had been to the farm the previous day and he could have said they needed the ax or hatchet at the farm .	66.84114
mrs . borden would have had no reason to disbelieve him and he could have approached close enough to her to swing before she could cry out .	47.56246
he could have left for weybosset street after her murder and made it in plenty of time by using the streetcar .	120.59048
if he took an earlier streetcar than the 11 20 on his return , he could have arrived at the borden house shortly after mr . borden came home .	40.40805
with lizzie in the barn , the screen door unlocked and bridget upstairs in her attic room , he would have had free and easy access to the house .	23.219809
with the second murder over , he could have left , hidden the weapon in some vacant lot or an abandoned cistern in the neighborhood .	59.019165
his unconcerned stroll down the side of the house to a pear tree , with crowds already gathering in front of the building and sawyer guarding the side door , was odd .	35.343132
there was no close examination of his clothes for bloodstains , and certainly no scientific test was made of them .	64.14145
and for a man who traveled around without any change of clothing , a few more stains on his dark suit may very well have gone unnoticed .	72.5216
there was no financial gain for morse in the murders .	4.0465803
on the other side of the ledger is the fact that he did see his niece and the woman with whom she was staying .	26.849993
the time would have been shortly after the murder of mrs . borden and they noticed nothing unusual in his behavior .	47.220722
he said he had promised mrs . borden to return in time for dinner and that was close to the time when he did turn up at the borden house .	29.913944
what did pearson say about bridget sullivan as a possible suspect in his trial-book essay ? ?	17.17351
`` the police soon ceased to look upon either bridget or mr . morse as in possession of guilty knowledge .	107.064644
indeed , it was probably to mr . morse ' s advantage to have mr . and mrs . borden alive .	16.186785
both he and bridget were exonerated by lizzie herself ' ' .	18.454937
that was his complete discussion of bridget sullivan as a possible suspect .	13.536427
although pearson disbelieved almost everything lizzie said , and read a sinister purpose into almost everything she did , he happily accepted her statement about bridget as the whole truth .	118.29505
he felt nothing further need be said about the servant girl .	57.094906
the exoneration pearson speaks of is not an exoneration , but lizzie ' s expression of her opinion , as reported in the testimony of assistant marshal fleet .	25.718977
this officer had asked lizzie if she suspected her uncle morse , and she replied she didn ' t think he did it because he left the house before the murders and returned after them .	28.779732
fleet asked the same question about bridget , and lizzie pointed out that as far as she knew bridget had gone up to her room before her father ' s murder and came down when she called her .	29.741938
lizzie , actually , never named any suspect .	3.2633204
she told police about the prospective tenant she had heard quarreling with her father some weeks before the murders , but she said she thought he was from out of town because she heard him mention something about talking to his partner .	65.42371
and , much as she detested hiram harrington , she also did not accuse him .	26.315348
at the inquest she was asked specifically whether she knew anybody her father had bad feelings toward , or who had bad feelings toward her father .	125.361435
she replied , `` i know of one man that has not been friendly with him .	45.825626
they have not been friendly for years ' ' .	4.116142
asked who this was , she named harrington .	32.551247
the press reported the same facts in using harrington ' s interview , but lizzie did not suggest at the inquest that harrington was the killer .	12.934123
when i interviewed kirby , who as a boy picked up pears in the borden yard , i asked if anybody else in the household besides lizzie and morse had been under any suspicion at the time of the murders .	29.714544
he said he had not heard of anybody else .	8.387867
`` how about bridget sullivan ' ' ? ?	1.0157071
`` oh , she was just the maid there ' ' , he replied , waving a hand to indicate how completely unimportant she was .	61.773743
kirby was , of course , reflecting the opinion that existed at the time of murders .	28.332909
everyone somehow manages to overlook completely the fact that , as far as we know , there were exactly two people in and about the house at the time of both murders lizzie borden and bridget sullivan .	36.608543
all the officials on the case seem to have been afflicted with a similar myopia as far as bridget was concerned , although records in police files contain many reports of servants who have murdered their employers .	41.204506
true , it is no longer cricket for the butler to be the killer in mystery fiction , but we are dealing here with actual people in real life and not imaginary characters and situations .	49.115555
the actions of bridget should be examined , since she was there and opportunity did exist , if only to establish her innocence .	142.09857
there are also other factors that require closer examination .	42.568653
the legend as it exists in fall river today always includes the solemn assurance that bridget returned to ireland after the trial with a `` big bundle ' ' of cash which lizzie gave her for keeping her mouth shut .	72.36643
the people who believe and retell the legend have apparently never troubled to read the trial testimony and do not know that the maid changed her testimony on several key points , always to the detriment of lizzie .	98.13899
if bridget did get any bundles of cash , the last person who would have rewarded her for services rendered would have been lizzie borden .	55.946426
bridget was born in ireland , one of fourteen children .	114.98065
she was apparently the pioneer in her family because she had no close relatives in this country at that time .	26.955587
she worked as a domestic , first in newport for a year , and then in south bethlehem , pennsylvania , for another year .	45.37278
she finally settled in fall river and , after being employed for a time by a mrs . reed , was hired by the bordens .	32.468056
i have previously described how , during the week of the murder , bridget spent the first few hot days scrubbing and ironing clothes .	42.434032
her father , james upton , was the upton mentioned by hawthorne in the famous introduction to the scarlet letter as one of those who came into the old custom house to do business with him as the surveyor of the port .	38.22777
a gentleman of the old school , mr . upton possessed intellectual power , ample means , and withal , was a devoted christian .	34.064262
the daughter profited from his interest in scientific and philosophical subjects .	54.520645
her mother also was a person of superior mind and broad interests .	108.83222
there is clear evidence that lucy from childhood had an unusual mind .	47.09289
she possessed an observant eye , a retentive memory , and a critical faculty .	47.173737
when she was nine years old , she wrote a description of a store she had visited .	67.92495
she named 48 items , and said there were `` many more things which it would take too long to write ' ' .	36.681072
an essay on `` freedom ' ' written at 10 years of age quoted the declaration of independence , the freedom given to slaves in canada , and the views of george washington .	55.11321
lucy upton was graduated from the salem high school when few colleges , only oberlin and elmira , were open to women	50.098553
and she had an appetite for learning that could not be denied .	20.536747
a picture of her in high school comes from a younger schoolmate , albert s . flint , friend of her brother winslow , and later , like winslow , a noted astronomer .	31.749374
he recalled lucy , as `` a bright-looking black-eyed young lady who came regularly through the boys ' study hall to join the class in greek in the little recitation room beyond ' ' .	88.73796
the study of greek was the distinctive mark of boys destined to go to college , and lucy upton too expected to go to college and take the full classical course offered to men .	75.739624
the death of her mother in 1865 prevented this .	117.976326
with four younger children at home , lucy stepped into her mother ' s role , and even after the brothers and sisters were grown , she was her father ' s comfort and stay until he died in 1879 .	22.468609
but even so lucy could not give up her intellectual pursuits .	48.027073
when her brother winslow became a student at brown university in 1874 , she wrote him about a course in history he was taking under professor diman `` what is prof . diman ' s definition of civilization , and take the world through , is its progress ever onward , or does it retrograde at times ? ?	60.284344
do you think i might profitably study some of the history you do , perhaps two weeks behind you .	87.52073
' ' and that she proceeded to do .	18.548435
