many years later ( on august 3 , 1915 ) , lucy upton wrote winslow ' s daughter soon to be graduated from smith college `` while i love botany which , after dabbling in for years , i studied according to the methods of that day exactly forty years ago in a summer school , it must be fascinating to take up zoology in the way you are doing .	60.785496
whatever was the science in the high school course for the time being , that was my favorite study .	110.59052
she read maitland ' s dark ages , `` which i enjoyed very much ' '	28.42704
la croix on the customs of the middle ages , 16 chapters of bryce `` and liked it more and more ' '	39.776867
she discussed in her letters to winslow some of the questions that came to her as she studied alone .	76.792496
lucy ' s correspondence with brother winslow during his college days was not entirely taken up with academic studies .	58.954895
also lucy and winslow had a private contest to see which one could make the most words from the letters in `` importunately ' ' .	39.73102
who won is not revealed , but winslow ' s daughter eleanor says they got up to 1 , 212 words .	47.91708
winslow had musical talents , as had his father before him .	62.662582
at different times he served as glee-club and choir leader and as organist .	26.898521
and it was lucy upton who first started the idea of a regular course in music at spelman college .	50.610584
winslow upton after graduation from brown university and two years of graduate study , accepted a position at the harvard observatory .	36.718143
for three years he was connected with the u . s . naval observatory and with the u . s . signal corps	11.328949
and after 1883 , was professor of astronomy at brown university .	21.651953
the six expeditions to study eclipses of the sun , of which he was a member , took him to colorado , virginia , and california as well as to the south pacific and to russia .	32.779522
after her father ' s death , lucy and her youngest sister lived for a few years with winslow in washington , d . c . .	28.03638
`` their house ' ' , writes albert s . flint , `` was always a haven of hospitality and good cheer , especially grateful to one like myself far from home ' ' .	33.203022
lucy was a lively part of the household .	19.516813
moreover , she had physical as well as mental vigor .	108.7095
winslow , as his daughters eleanor and margaret recall , used to characterize her as `` our iron sister ' ' .	29.516035
there is reason to suppose that lucy would have made a record as publicly distinguished as her brother had it not been that her mother ' s death occurred just as she was about to enter college .	85.1035
as a matter of fact , albert s . flint expressed his conviction that `` her physical strength , her mental power , her lively interest in all objects about her and her readiness to serve her fellow beings ' ' would have led her `` to a distinguished career amongst the noted women of this country ' ' .	68.25326
while in washington , d . c . , lucy upton held positions in the u . s . census office , and in the pension bureau .	23.991854
they were not sufficiently challenging however , and she resigned in 1887 , to go to germany with her brother winslow and his family while he was there on study .	54.65741
after the months in europe , she returned to boston and became active in church and community life .	53.435333
what was called an `` accidental meeting ' ' with miss packard in washington turned her attention to spelman .	40.613705
after correspondence with miss packard and to the joy of miss packard and miss giles , she came to atlanta , in the fall of 1888 , to help wherever needed , although there was then no money available to pay her a salary .	30.401209
she served for a number of years without pay beyond her travel and maintenance .	116.16073
her students have spoken of the exacting standards of scholarship and of manners and conduct she expected and achieved from the students	80.46441
of her `` great power of discernment ' '	1.0157071
of `` her exquisiteness of dress ' ' , `` her well-modulated voice that went straight to the hearts of the hearers ' '	17.126772
her great love of flowers and plants and birds	73.26735
she drew on all her resources of mind and heart to help them -- to make them at home in the world	42.647823
and as graduates gratefully recall , she drew on her purse as well .	43.556484
many a student was able to remain at spelman , only because of her unobtrusive help .	57.677864
under miss upton , the work of the year 1909-10 went forward without interruption .	41.06857
after all , she had come to spelman seminary in 1888 , and had been since 1891 except for one year , associate principal or dean .	57.333076
she had taught classes in botany , astronomy ( with the aid of a telescope ) , geometry , and psychology .	20.337101
miss upton and miss packard , as a matter of fact , had many tastes in common .	52.14577
and both believed that intellectual growth must go hand in hand with the development of sturdy character and christian zeal .	39.124462
both loved the out-of-doors , including mountain climbing and horseback riding .	3.2525504
in 1890 when the trip to europe and the holy land was arranged for miss packard , it was miss upton who planned the trip , and `` with rare executive ability ' ' bore the brunt of `` the entire pilgrimage from beginning to end ' ' .	59.251602
so strenuous it was physically , with its days of horseback riding over rough roads that it seems an amazing feat of endurance for both miss packard and miss upton .	29.509182
at the fifteenth anniversary ( 1896 ) as already quoted , miss upton projected with force and eloquence the spelman of the future as a college of first rank , with expanding and unlimited horizons .	63.231697
when dr . wallace buttrick , wise in his judgment of people , declined to have the science building named for him , he wrote miss tapley ( april 7 , 1923 ) `` if you had asked me , i think i would have suggested that you name the building for miss upton .	60.281555
her services to the school for many years were of a very high character , and i have often thought that one of the buildings should be named for her ' ' .	57.497917
such were the qualities of the acting-president of the seminary after the death of miss giles .	22.749191
at the meeting of the board of trustees , on march 3 , 1910 , miss upton presented the annual report of the president .	21.572847
she noted that no student had been withdrawn through loss of confidence	575.75977
that the enrollment showed an increase of boarding students as was desired	443.58044
and that the year ' s work had gone forward smoothly .	11.035779
she urged the importance of more thorough preparation for admission .	24.302689
the raising of the $25 , 000 improvement fund two days before the time limit expired , and the spontaneous `` praise demonstration ' ' held afterward on the campus , were reported as events which had brought happiness to miss giles .	47.698895
with the fund in hand , the debt on the boilers had been paid	34.777496
and ground had been broken for the superintendent ' s home .	7.169174
miss upton spoke gratefully of the response of spelman graduates and negro friends in helping to raise the fund , and their continuing efforts to raise money for greatly needed current expenses .	57.02335
she spoke also with deep thankfulness of the many individuals and agencies whose interest and efforts through the years had made the work so fruitful in results .	120.96488
two bequests were recorded one of $200 under the will of mrs . harriet a . copp of los angeles	40.025585
and one of $2 , 000 under the will of miss celia l . brett of hamilton , new york , a friend from the early days .	32.75571
miss upton told the trustees that the death of miss giles was `` the sorest grief ' ' the seminary had ever been called upon to bear .	17.418839
the daughters of spelman , she said , had never known or thought of spelman without her .	285.16043
the removal of miss packard 18 years earlier had caused them great sorrow , but they still had miss giles .	66.34969
`` yet spelman has strong , deep roots , and will live for the blessing of generations to come ' ' .	19.181334
miss mary jane packard , sophia ' s half-sister , became ill in march , 1910	12.656399
and when school closed , she was unable to travel to massachusetts .	29.320078
before coming on a visit to spelman in 1885 , miss mary had been a successful teacher in worcester , and her position there was held open for her for a considerable period .	46.343796
she helped with teaching as well as office work for a few years -- the catalogues show that she had classes in geography , rhetoric and bookkeeping .	39.813316
soon the office work claimed all her time .	5.751605
she was closely associated with the founders in all their trials and hardships .	58.654587
quiet and energetic , cheerful and calm , she too was a power in the development of the seminary .	113.04301
miss giles always used to refer to her as `` sister ' ' .	5.7068233
she served as secretary in the seminary office for 25 years , and was in charge of correspondence , records , and bookkeeping .	30.780313
the books of the school hold a memorial to her	172.43077
and so do the hearts of students and of teachers .	36.234726
mary j . packard , states a messenger editorial , was `` efficient , pains-taking , self-effacing , loving , radiating the spirit of her master .	20.506355
with infinite patience she responded to every call , no matter at what cost to herself , and to her all went , for she was sure to have the needed information or word of cheer .	101.41013
in a few school districts one finds a link between school and job .	83.0263
in those vocational programs organized with smith-hughes money , there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other .	49.41242
in these cases a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program , saving a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12 .	49.188587
the apprentice program will involve further education on a part-time basis , usually at night , perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high school .	40.842285
these opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such crafts as auto mechanics , carpentry , drafting , electrical work , tool-and-die work , and sheet-metal work .	17.283407
formally organized vocational programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time job on graduation .	62.48755
the `` diversified occupations ' ' program is a part-time trade-preparatory program conducted over two school years on a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business employers .	55.589424
the `` distributive education ' ' program operates in a similar way , with arrangements between the school and employers in merchandising fields .	43.60852
in both cases the student attends school half-time and works in a regular job the other half .	81.47574
in a few places cooperative programs between schools and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing the student , while still in school , to develop skills which are immediately marketable upon graduation .	56.682934
adult education courses , work-study programs of various sorts -- these are all evidence of a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities for out-of-school youth .	68.19304
in general , however , it may be said that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school , the school authorities play little or no part in the decision of what happens next .	59.926003
if the student drops out of high school , the break with the school is even more complete .	45.02092
when there is employment opportunity for youth , this arrangement -- or lack of arrangement -- works out quite well .	140.60623
indeed , in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and went to work .	79.879814
statistically this has represented a loss to the nation , although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in retrospect may have been a wise one .	48.586285
i make no attempt to measure the enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business which he entered .	45.435078
he may or may not be `` better off ' ' than his classmate who went on to a college and professional school .	51.60369
but in the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all the potential professional talent .	59.0206
in a later chapter dealing with the suburban school , i shall discuss the importance of arranging a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any high school where he is found .	41.373627
in the negro neighborhoods and also to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of identification and motivation .	41.276726
high motivation towards higher education must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are essential for academic work .	157.36696
undoubtedly far more can be done in the lower grades in this regard in the negro schools .	52.983864
however , the teacher can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family is anti-intellectual .	36.27385
and the fact remains that there are today few shining examples of negroes in positions of intellectual leadership .	38.392147
this is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the northern universities .	15.816324
quite the contrary , as i can testify from personal experience as a former university president .	144.47064
the absence of successful negroes in the world of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among negro youth for academic careers .	63.152393
i believe the situation is improving , but the success stories need to be heavily publicized .	96.24944
here again we run into the roadblock that negroes do not like to be designated as negroes in the press .	45.280144
how can the vicious circle be broken ? ?	1.0074446
this is a problem to which leaders of opinion , both negro and white , should devote far more attention .	74.229836
it is at least as important as the more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the south .	29.806543
i should like to underline four points i made in my first report with respect to vocational education .	46.570374
first and foremost , vocational courses should not replace courses which are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation .	73.61008
second , vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and not require more than half the student ' s time in those years	56.424374
however , for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to begin earlier .	93.10591
third , the significance of the vocational courses is that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work	44.993267
they realize the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers , and this sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they are studying at the same time .	27.4013
fourth , the type of vocational training programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the general locality .	19.617315
this last point is important because if high school pupils are aware that few , if any , graduates who have chosen a certain vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training , the whole idea of relevance disappears .	56.02726
vocational training which holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable skill becomes just another school `` chore ' ' for those whose interest in their studies has begun to falter .	64.72413
those who , because of population mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees , would limit vocational education to general rather than specific skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind of school experience .	55.55948
i have been using the word `` vocational ' ' as a layman would at first sight think it should be used .	43.09465
i intend to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys and girls .	80.64052
these courses develop skills other than those we think of when we use the adjective `` academic ' ' .	60.57474
practically all of these practical skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at once on the basis of the skill .	40.430885
they are in this sense skills marketable immediately on graduation from high school .	16.844978
to be sure , in tool-and-die work and in the building trades , the first job must be often on an apprentice basis , but two years of half-time vocational training enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status .	76.7672
similarly , a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two of further study in a community college or secretarial school .	59.762295
of course , it can be argued that an ability to write english correctly and with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill .	42.273037
so , too , is the mathematical competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics .	17.086061
in a sense almost all high school and college courses could be considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student in his vocation ( which may be a profession ) will be called upon to use some of the skills developed and the competence obtained .	81.56191
in spite of the shading of one type of course into another , i believe it is useful to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses .	61.13213
perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which proves the rule .	45.555195
today many college bound students try to take a course in personal typing , as they feel a certain degree of mastery of this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work in college and a professional school .	50.84632
most of our largest cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools .	62.239006
in this respect , public education in the large cities differs from education in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts .	51.439106
the neighborhood high schools are not , strictly speaking , comprehensive schools , because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational or technical high school instead of the local school .	49.02678
indeed , one school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term comprehensive high school for the senior high schools in his city , because these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs .	54.09234
he prefers to designate such schools as `` general ' ' high schools .	14.443249
the suburban high school , it is worth noting , also is not a widely comprehensive high school because of the absence of vocational programs .	42.08998
the reason is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community .	11.489307
therefore employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic of the comprehensive high school described in my first report .	50.527805
the separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities must be reckoned as permanent institutions .	23.718843
by and large their programs are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and to the realities of the apprentice system .	35.92276
it is not often realized to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of employment , except for a lucky few .	138.01863
one has to talk confidentially with some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a boy cannot just say , `` i want to be a plumber ' ' , and then , by doing good work , find a job .	33.155376
it is far more difficult in many communities to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation .	84.83625
two stories will illustrate what i have in mind .	9.675427
one vocational instructor in a city vocational school , speaking of his course in a certain field , said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside of the city .	59.277176
in the city , he said , the waiting list for those who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside track he can ' t get in .	86.91764
in a far distant part of the united states , i was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade was doing special work .	42.18456
`` what does he have in mind to do when he graduates ' ' ? ?	21.784311
`` oh , he ' ll be a plumber ' ' , came the answer .	13.278088
`` but isn ' t it almost impossible to get into the union ' ' ? ?	15.332284
`` he ' ll have no difficulty ' ' , i was told .	9.715982
`` he has very good connections ' ' .	2.1501243
in my view , there should be a school which offers significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every family in a city .	121.574776
ideally these schools should be so located that one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is at the highest .	60.105095
an excellent example of a successful location of a new vocational high school is the dunbar vocational high school in chicago .	32.130116
located in a bad slum area now undergoing redevelopment , this school and its program are especially tailored to the vocational aims of its students .	66.62837
hardly a window has been broken since dunbar first was opened ( and vandalism in schools is a major problem in many slum areas ) .	80.040146
i discovered in the course of a visit there that almost all the pupils were negroes .	105.35492
they were learning trades as diverse as shoe repairing , bricklaying , carpentry , cabinet making , auto mechanics , and airplane mechanics .	11.5657835
the physical facilities at dunbar are impressive , but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils .	37.517467
the soybean seed is the most important leguminous food in the world .	23.736696
in the united states , where half of the world crop is grown , soybeans are processed for their edible oil .	15.568122
the residue from soybean processing goes mainly into animal feeds .	26.27449
soybeans are extensively processed into a remarkable number of food products in the orient .	17.606417
american chemists , seeking to increase exports of soybeans , have adapted modern techniques and fermentation methods to improve their use in such traditional japanese foods as tofu and miso and in tempeh of indonesia .	35.9679
soybean flour , grits , flakes , `` milk ' ' , and curd can be bought in the united states .	10.283792
peanuts are the world ' s second most important legume .	12.971455
we produce peanut oil , but to a much greater extent we eat the entire seed .	47.66972
blanched peanuts , as prepared for making peanut butter or for eating as nuts , are roasted seeds whose seedcoats have been rubbed off .	50.236904
cereal grains , supplemented with soybeans or dry edible peas or beans , comprise about two-thirds or three-fourths of the diet in parts of asia and africa .	16.775621
in western europe and north america , where the level of economic development is higher , grains and other seed products furnish less than one-third of the food consumed .	35.884666
rather , meat and potatoes , sugar , and dairy products are the main sources of carbohydrate , protein , oils , and fats .	10.195392
people depend less on seeds for foods in australia , new zealand , and argentina , where extensive grazing lands support sheep or cattle , and the consumption of meat is high .	27.625315
feeds for livestock took about one-sixth of the world ' s cereal crop in 1957-1958 .	11.567615
most of the grain is fed to swine and dairy cows and lesser amounts to beef cattle and poultry .	11.366186
about 90 percent of the corn used in the united states is fed to animals .	17.273544
the rest is used for human food and industrial products .	21.641188
more than half of the sorghum and barley seeds we produce and most of the byproducts of the milling of cereals and the crushing of oilseeds are fed to livestock .	13.819235
more than 200 million tons of seeds and seed products are fed to livestock annually in the united states .	14.5392
the efficiency with which animals convert grains and forages to meat has risen steadily in the united states since the 1930 ' s and has paralleled the increased feeding of the cake and meal that are a byproduct when seeds are processed for oil .	23.573605
the demand for food is so great in the world that little arable land can be given over to growing the nonfood crops .	55.30934
seeds grown for industrial uses hold a relatively minor position .	79.077065
chief among the seed crops grown primarily for industrial uses are the oil-bearing seeds -- flax , castor , tung ( nuts from the china wood-oil tree ) , perilla ( from an oriental mint ) , and oiticica ( from a brazilian tree ) .	12.2167425
oils , or liquid fats , from the seeds of flax and tung have long been the principal constituents of paints and varnishes for protecting and beautifying the surfaces of wood and metal .	13.670114
these oils develop hard , smooth films when they dry and form resinlike substances .	21.290194
the artist who paints in oil uses drying oils to carry the pigments and to protect his finished work for the ages .	49.958584
one of the finest of artists ' oils comes from poppy seeds .	22.511553
seeds of soybean , cotton , corn , sesame , and rape yield semidrying oils .	9.874276
some are used in paints along with drying oils .	40.663624
palm oil protects the surfaces of steel sheets before they are plated with tin .	12.978003
castor oil , made from castorbeans , has gone out of style as a medicine .	99.43228
this nondrying oil , however , is now more in demand than ever before as a fine lubricant , as a constituent of fluids for hydraulically operated equipment , and as a source of chemicals to make plastics .	29.23224
almond oil , another nondrying oil , was once used extensively in perfumery to extract flower fragrances .	13.574016
it is still used in drugs and cosmetics , but it is rather scarce and sometimes is adulterated with oils from peach and plum seeds .	16.5833
liquid fats from all these oilseeds enter into the manufacture of soaps for industry and the household and of glycerin for such industrial uses as making explosives .	33.063557
sizable amounts of soybean , coconut , and palm kernel oil -- seed oils that are produced primarily for food purposes -- also are used to make soaps , detergents , and paint resins .	19.669937
solid fats from the seeds of the mahua tree , the shea tree , and the coconut palm are used to make candles in tropical countries .	12.156289
seeds are a main source of starch for industrial and food use in many parts of the world .	37.30529
corn and wheat supply most of the starch in the united states , canada , and australia .	12.006393
in other countries where cereal grains are not among the principal crops of a region , starchy tubers or roots are processed for starch .	24.70707
starch is used in the paper , textile , and food-processing industries and in a multitude of other manufacturing operations .	16.621014
gums were extracted from quince , psyllium ( fleawort ) , flax , and locust ( carob ) seeds in ancient times .	9.270512
today the yearly import into the united states of locust bean gum is more than 15 million pounds	15.685303
of psyllium seed , more than 2 . 6 million .	22.982674
the discovery during the second world war that guar gum was similar to imported locust gum increased its cultivation in western asia and initiated it in the united states .	22.44399
water-soluble gums are used in foods and drugs and in the manufacture of pulp and paper as thickeners , stabilizers , or dispersing agents .	16.884058
guar gum thickens salad dressings and stabilizes ice cream .	2.2803104
quince seed gum is the main ingredient in wave-setting lotions .	6.6511436
once regarded as an agricultural nuisance , psyllium was sold in the 1930 ' s as a mechanical laxative under 117 different brands .	21.28223
locust gum is added to pulp slurries to break up the lumps of fibers in making paper .	16.365965
the seeds of hard , fibrous , stony fruits , called nuts , provide highly concentrated foods , oils , and other materials of value .	53.473724
most nuts consist of the richly packaged storage kernel and its thick , adherent , brown covering -- the seedcoat .	32.0407
the kernels of brazil nuts , cashews , coconuts , filberts , hazelnuts , hickory nuts , pecans , walnuts , and pine nuts are predominantly oily .	5.400937
almonds and pistachio nuts are not so high in oil but are rich in protein .	46.24758
the world production of familiar seed nuts -- almonds , brazil nuts , filberts , and the english walnuts -- totals about 300 thousand tons annually .	17.982834
coconuts , the fruit of the coconut palm , have the largest of all known seeds and are grown in south pacific islands as a crop for domestic and export markets .	61.068764
the oil palm of west africa yields edible oil from both the flesh and the seed or kernel of its fruit .	19.424017
world production of copra , the oil-bearing flesh of the coconut , was a little more than 3 million tons in 1959 .	21.306616
exports from producing countries in terms of equivalent oil were a little more than 1 million tons , about half of which was palm kernels or oil from them and about half was palm oil .	66.81784
other nuts consumed in lesser quantity include the spicy nutmeg	1.7286193
the soap nut , which owes its sudsing power to natural saponins	88.24267
the marking nut , used for ink and varnish	6.9706187
and the sweet-smelling cumara nut , which is suited for perfumes .	13.136914
a forest crop that has not been extensively cultivated is ivory nuts from the tagua palm .	32.147236
the so-called vegetable ivory is the hard endosperm of the egg-sized seed .	4.5948553
it is used for making buttons and other small , hard objects of turnery .	90.34347
seeds of the sago palm are used in bermuda to make heads and faces of dolls sold to tourists .	48.28257
the color and shape of seeds have long made them attractive for ornaments and decorations .	38.548557
since biblical times , rosaries have been made from jobs-tears -- the seeds of an asiatic grass .	28.254717
bead tree seeds are the necklaces of south pacific islanders and the eyes of buddha dolls in cuba .	33.288773
victorian ladies had a fad of stringing unusual seeds to wear as jewelry .	31.60713
handmade christmas wreaths and trees often contain a variety of seeds collected during the year .	13.413079
tradition has assigned medicinal values to seeds because of their alkaloids , aromatic oils , and highly flavored components .	14.276729
although science has given us more effective materials , preparations from anise , castorbean , colchicum , nux vomica , mustard , fennel , and stramonium are familiar to many for the relief of human ailments .	10.518725
flaxseed poultices and mustard plasters still are used by some persons .	81.014725
peanut and sesame oils often are used as carriers or diluents for medicines administered by injection .	53.90205
still another group of seeds ( sometimes tiny , dry , seed-bearing fruits ) provide distinctive flavors and odors to foods , although the nutrients they supply are quite negligible .	51.373363
the common spices , flavorings , and condiments make up this group .	150.53381
each year millions of pounds of anise , caraway , mustard , celery , and coriander and the oils extracted from them are imported .	10.81934
single-seeded dry fruits used for flavoring include several of the carrot family , such as cumin , dill , fennel , and angelica .	6.5208344
less common seeds used in cooking and beverages include fenugreek ( artificial maple flavor ) and cardamom .	12.843289
white pepper is the ground seed of the common black pepper fruit .	120.082085
sesame seed , which comes from the tall pods of a plant grown in egypt , brazil , and central america , has a toasted-nut flavor and can be used in almost any dish calling for almonds .	31.298332
it is a main flavoring for halvah , the candy of the middle east .	26.88869
sesame sticks , a snack dip , originated in the southwest .	12.459693
beverages are made from seeds the world over .	22.047743
coffee is made from the roasted and ground seeds of the coffee tree .	5.2341137
world production of coffee broke all previous records in 1959 and 1960 at more than 5 million tons .	28.266338
per capita consumption remains around 16 pounds in the united states .	6.5295715
cocoa , chocolate , and cocoa butter come from the ground seeds of the cacao tree .	10.332322
world production of about 1 million tons is divided primarily between africa ( 63 percent ) and south america ( 27 percent ) .	17.246016
several soft drinks contain extracts from kola nuts , the seed of the kola tree cultivated in the west indies and south america .	8.971252
cereal grains have been used for centuries to prepare fermented beverages .	4.0416207
the japanese sake is wine fermented from rice grain .	5.177503
arrack is distilled from fermented rice in india .	3.141787
beer , generally fermented from barley , is an old alcoholic beverage .	16.481031
beer was brewed by the babylonians and egyptians more than 6 thousand years ago .	40.741627
brewers today use corn , rice , and malted barley .	2.5814922
distillers use corn , malt , wheat , grain sorghum , and rye in making beverage alcohol .	19.05763
seed crops hold a prominent place in the agricultural economy of the united states .	15.3354
the farm value of seeds produced in this country for all purposes , including the cereals , is nearly 10 billion dollars a year .	28.612236
cereal grains , oilseeds , and dry beans and peas account for about 57 percent of the farm value of all crops raised .	94.87754
the economic importance of seed crops actually is even greater , because additional returns are obtained from most of the corn , oats , barley , and sorghum -- as well as the cake and meal from the processing of flaxseed , cottonseed , and soybeans -- through conversion to poultry , meat , and dairy products .	18.89889
seeds furnish about 40 percent of the total nutrients consumed by all livestock .	9.339333
hay and pasture are the other chief sources of livestock feed .	21.22866
seeds are the essential raw materials for milling grain , baking , crushing oilseed , refining edible oil , brewing , distilling , and mixing feed .	6.542199
more than 11 thousand business establishments in the united states were based on cereals and oilseeds in 1954 .	8.9971
the value of products from these industries was 15 . 8 billion dollars , of which about one-third was created by manufacturing processes .	64.19445
not included was the value of seed oil in paints and varnishes or the value of the coffee and chocolate industries that are based on imported seed or seed products .	25.161602
cereal grains furnish about one-fourth of the total food calories in the american diet and about one-third of the total nutrients consumed by all livestock and poultry .	16.099548
to hold a herd of cattle on a new range till they felt at home was called `` locatin ' ' ' ' em .	39.086967
to keep ' em scattered somewhat and yet herd ' em was called `` loose herdin ' ' ' .	16.198599
to hold ' em in a compact mass was `` close herdin ' ' ' .	16.600645
cattle were inclined to remain in a territory with which they were acquainted .	31.708233
that became their `` home range ' ' .	4.9990034
yet there were always some that moved farther and farther out , seekin ' grass and water .	24.20073
these became `` strays ' ' , the term bein ' restricted to cattle , however , as hosses , under like circumstances , were spoken of as `` stray hosses ' ' , not merely `` strays ' ' .	23.618042
cattle would drift day and night in a blizzard till it was over .	36.373123
you had to go with ' em or wait till the storm was over , and follow .	78.30869
such marchin ' in wholesale numbers was called a `` drift ' ' , or `` winter drift ' ' , and if the storm was prolonged it usually resulted in one of the tragedies of the range .	17.888535
the cowboy made a technical distinction in reference to the number of them animals .	19.378279
the single animal or a small bunch were referred to as `` strays ' '	21.774961
but when a large number were `` bunched up ' ' or `` banded up ' ' , and marched away from their home range , as long as they stayed together the group was said to be a `` drift ' ' .	21.722055
drifts usually occurred in winter in an effort to escape the severe cold winds , but it could also occur in summer as the result of lack of water or grass because of a drought , or as an aftermath of a stampede .	36.686424
drifts usually happened only with cattle , for hosses had ' nough sense to avoid ' em , and to find shelter for ' emselves .	66.44569
the wholesale death of cattle as a result of blizzards , and sometimes droughts , over a wide range of territory was called a `` die-up ' ' .	14.792398
followin ' such an event there was usually a harvest of `` fallen hides ' ' , and the ranchers needed skinnin ' knives instead of brandin ' irons .	12.08556
cattle were said to be `` potted ' ' when `` blizzard choked ' ' , that is , caught in a corner or a draw , or against a `` drift fence ' ' durin ' a storm .	24.855885
cattle which died from them winter storms were referred to as the `` winter kill ' ' .	11.356843
when cattle in winter stopped and humped their backs up they were said to `` bow up ' ' .	22.082458
this term was also used by the cowboy in the sense of a human showin ' fight , as one cowhand was heard to say , `` he arches his back like a mule in a hailstorm ' ' .	27.63841
cattle drove to the northern ranges and held for two winters to mature ' em into prime beef were said to be `` double wintered ' ' .	39.01639
cattle brought into a range from a distance were called `` immigrants ' ' .	49.922157
them new to the country were referred to as `` pilgrims ' ' .	14.326378
this word was first applied to the imported hot-blooded cattle , but later was more commonly used as reference to a human tenderfoot .	61.10943
hereford cattle were often called `` white faces ' ' , or `` open-face cattle ' ' , and the old-time cowman gave the name of `` hothouse stock ' ' to them newly introduced cattle .	14.27937
because holstein cattle weren ' t a beef breed , they were rarely seen on a ranch , though one might be found now and then for the milk supply .	50.710255
the cowboy called this breed of cattle `` magpies ' ' .	2.1951144
a `` cattaloe ' ' was a hybrid offspring of buffalo and cattle .	12.595568
`` dry stock ' ' denoted , regardless of age or sex , such bovines as were givin ' no milk .	33.821636
a `` wet herd ' ' was a herd of cattle made up entirely of cows , while `` wet stuff ' ' referred to cows givin ' milk .	24.213108
the cowboy ' s humorous name for a cow givin ' milk was a `` milk pitcher ' ' .	3.9875188
cows givin ' no milk were knowed as `` strippers ' ' .	2.5790763
the terminology of the range , in speakin ' of `` dry stock ' ' and `` wet stock ' ' , was confusin ' to the tenderfoot .	16.489069
the most common reference to `` wet stock ' ' was with the meanin ' that such animals had been smuggled across the rio grande after bein ' stolen from their rightful owners .	22.068321
the term soon became used and applied to all stolen animals .	152.90103
`` mixed herd ' ' meant a herd of mixed sexes , while a `` straight steer herd ' ' was one composed entirely of steers , and when the cowman spoke of `` mixed cattle ' ' , he meant cattle of various grades , ages , and sexes .	22.745678
in the spring when penned cattle were turned out to grass , this was spoken of as `` turn-out time ' ' , or `` put to grass ' ' .	36.163338
`` shootin ' ' em out ' ' was gettin ' cattle out of a corral onto the range .	30.075249
when a cow came out of a corral in a crouchin ' run she was said to `` come out a-stoopin ' ' ' .	29.08296
to stir cattle up and get ' em heated and excited was to `` mustard the cattle ' ' , and the act was called `` ginnin ' ' em ' round ' ' , or `` chousin ' ' em ' ' .	13.956986
after a roundup the pushin ' of stray cattle of outside brands toward their home range was called `` throwin ' over ' ' .	56.771954
a cow rose from the ground rear end first .	239.84497
by the time her hindquarters were in a standin ' position , her knees were on the ground in a prayin ' attitude .	24.029293
it was when she was in this position that the name `` prayin ' cow ' ' was suggested to the cowboy .	17.87263
they were said to be `` on their heads ' ' when grazin ' .	28.066944
`` on the hoof ' ' was a reference to live cattle and was also used in referrin ' to cattle travelin ' by trail under their own power as against goin ' by rail .	56.837856
shippin ' cattle by train was called a `` stock run ' ' .	6.6138887
a general classification given grass-fed cattle was `` grassers ' ' .	1.8782943
when a cowboy spoke of `` dustin ' ' ' a cow , he meant that he throwed dust into her eyes .	28.574522
the cow , unlike a bull or steer , kept her eyes open and her mind on her business when chargin ' , and a cow `` on the prod ' ' or `` on the peck ' ' was feared by the cowhand more than any of his other charges .	37.239887
the injun ' s name for beef was `` wohaw ' ' , and many of the old frontiersmen adopted it from their association with the injun on the trails .	15.966466
the first cattle the injuns saw under the white man ' s control were the ox teams of the early freighters .	42.673836
listenin ' with wonder at the strange words of the bullwhackers as they shouted `` whoa ' ' , `` haw ' ' , and `` gee ' ' , they thought them words the names of the animals , and began callin ' cattle `` wohaws ' ' .	12.436878
rarely did a trail herd pass through the injun country on its march north that it wasn ' t stopped to receive demand for `` wohaw ' ' .	34.33832
`` tailin ' ' ' was the throwin ' of an animal by the tail in lieu of a rope .	23.324497
any animal could when travelin ' fast , be sent heels over head by the simple process of overtakin ' the brute , seizin ' its tail , and givin ' the latter a pull to one side .	35.114265
this throwed the animal off balance , and over it ' d crash onto its head and shoulders .	50.484356
though the slightest yank was frequently capable of producin ' results , many men assured success through a turn of the tail ' bout the saddle horn , supplemented sometimes , in the case of cattle , by a downward heave of the rider ' s leg upon the strainin ' tail .	29.96421
such tactics were resorted to frequently with the unmanageable longhorns , and a thorough `` tailin ' ' ' usually knocked the breath out of a steer , and so dazed ' im that he ' d behave for the rest of the day .	21.150915
it required both a quick and swift hoss and a darin ' rider .	18.538483
when cattle became more valuable , ranch owners frowned upon this practice and it was discontinued , at least when the boss was ' round .	67.75893
when the cowboy used the word `` tailin ' s ' ' , he meant stragglers .	13.952195
`` bull tailin ' ' ' was a game once pop ' lar with the mexican cowboys of texas .	24.788162
from a pen of wild bulls one would be released , and with much yellin ' a cowhand ' d take after ' im .	27.062704
seizin ' the bull by the tail , he rushed his hoss forward and a little to one side , throwin ' the bull off balance , and `` bustin ' ' ' ' im with terrific force .	30.079147
rammin ' one horn of a downed steer into the ground to hold ' im down was called `` peggin ' ' ' .	31.803802
colors of cattle came in for their special names .	28.853184
an animal covered with splotches or spots of different colors was called a `` brindle ' ' or `` brockle ' ' .	9.462035
a `` lineback ' ' was an animal with a stripe of different color from the rest of its body runnin ' down its back , while a `` lobo stripe ' ' was the white , yeller , or brown stripe runnin ' down the back , from neck to tail , a characteristic of many spanish cattle .	38.04451
a `` mealynose ' ' was a cow or steer of the longhorn type , with lines and dots of a color lighter ' n the rest of its body ' round the eyes , face , and nose .	77.68377
such an animal was said to be `` mealynosed ' ' .	2.0471349
`` sabinas ' ' was a spanish word used to describe cattle of red and white peppered and splotched colorin ' .	17.615831
the northern cowboy called all the red mexican cattle which went up the trail `` sonora reds ' ' , while they called all cattle drove up from mexico `` yaks ' ' , because they came from the yaqui injun country , or gave ' em the name of `` mexican buckskins ' ' .	28.211132
near the southern border , cattle of the early longhorn breed whose coloration was black with a lineback , with white speckles frequently appearin ' on the sides and belly , were called `` zorrillas ' ' .	26.853533
this word was from the spanish , meanin ' `` polecat ' ' .	8.925344
`` yeller bellies ' ' were cattle of mexican breed splotched on flank and belly with yellerish color .	20.051832
an animal with distinct coloration , or other marks easily distinguished and remembered by the owner and his riders , was sometimes used as a `` marker ' ' .	54.281708
such an animal has frequently been the downfall of the rustler .	8.275532
countin ' each grazin ' bunch of cattle where it was found on the range and driftin ' it back so that it didn ' t mix with the uncounted cattle was called a `` range count ' ' .	26.00282
the countin ' of cattle in a pasture without throwin ' ' em together for the purpose was called a `` pasture count ' ' .	22.099972
the counters rode through the pasture countin ' each bunch of grazin ' cattle , and drifted it back so that it didn ' t get mixed with the uncounted cattle ahead .	28.294558
this method of countin ' was usually done at the request , and in the presence , of a representative of the bank that held the papers against the herd .	58.62321
them notes and mortgages were spoken of as `` cattle paper ' ' .	36.278572
a `` book count ' ' was the sellin ' of cattle by the books , commonly resorted to in the early days , sometimes much to the profit of the seller .	29.790344
this led to the famous sayin ' in the northwest of the `` books won ' t freeze ' ' .	9.27902
this became a common byword durin ' the boom days when eastern and foreign capital were so eager to buy cattle interests .	92.93554
the origin of this sayin ' was credited to a saloonkeeper by the name of luke murrin .	8.605314
his saloon was a meetin ' place for influential wyoming cattlemen , and one year durin ' a severe blizzard , when his herd-owner customers were wearin ' long faces , he said , `` cheer up , boys , whatever happens , the books won ' t freeze ' ' .	34.157265
in this carefree sentence he summed up the essence of the prevailin ' custom of buyin ' by book count , and created a sayin ' which has survived through the years .	52.03336
`` range delivery ' ' meant that the buyer , after examinin ' the seller ' s ranch records and considerin ' his rep ' tation for truthfulness , paid for what the seller claimed to own , then rode out and tried to find it .	48.008324
when a cowhand said that a man had `` good cow sense ' ' , he meant to pay ' im a high compliment .	35.657063
no matter by what name cattle were called , there was no denyin ' that they not only saved texas from financial ruin , but went far toward redeemin ' from a wilderness vast territories of the northwest .	60.889996
the first use of the word `` rustler ' ' was as a synonym for `` hustler ' ' , becomin ' an established term for any person who was active , pushin ' , and bustlin ' in any enterprise .	30.52668
again it was used as the title for the hoss wrangler , and when the order was given to go out and `` rustle the hosses ' ' , it meant for ' im to go out and herd ' em in .	22.163795
eventually herdin ' the hosses was spoken of as `` hoss rustlin ' ' ' , and the wrangler was called the `` hoss rustler ' ' .	7.241927
later , the word became almost exclusively applied to a cow thief , startin ' from the days of the maverick when cowhands were paid by their employers to `` get out and rustle a few mavericks ' ' .	17.958755
it was john who found the lion tracks .	20.709515
he found them near the carcass of a zebra that had been killed the night before , and he circled once , nose to the ground , hair shooting up along his back , as it did when he was after lion or bear , and then he lifted his head and bayed , and the pack joined in , all heads high , and jones knew it was a hot trail .	54.02683
he stifled the comanche yell and let john lead him straight toward the nearby black volcanic mountain .	29.593893
this mountain was known as the black reef and it rose almost perpendicularly for about two hundred feet , honeycombed with caves , top covered with dense scrub and creepers and tall grass .	24.391172
on the south it ended sharply as though the lava had been cut off there suddenly .	60.413986
kearton and ulyate had started the day together while jones followed the dogs , and means and loveless had taken another route , and now , with the discovery of the fresh trail still unknown to him , ulyate reined in , in the shadow of the reef and pointed .	53.50276
`` that ' s the colonel ' ' , he said , `` but i can ' t see the dogs ' ' .	7.949059
as they watched , jones rode straight for the reef .	4.0245957
then they picked up the smaller black specks on the plain in front of him .	35.115974
the dogs were working a trail -- lion ? ?	34.83146
the pack had made a bend to the north , swinging back toward the reef , and kearton and ulyate could hear them faintly .	13.2104435
kearton got off and tore up some dry grass that grew in cracks between the rocks and piled it in a heap and wanted to make the smoke signal that would bring loveless and means and the rest of the party .	46.25592
`` not yet ' ' , cautioned ulyate .	4.1950974
jones came toward them fast , now , along the southern toe of the reef , and the dogs could be heard plainly , old john with his grand canyon voice outstanding above the others .	66.96523
there was sounder , too , also a veteran of the north rim , and rastus and the rake from a pack of english fox-hounds , and a collie from a london pound , and simba , a terrier .	24.776577
a motley pack , chosen for effectiveness , not beauty .	265.32944
jones was galloping close behind them leaning down , cheering them on .	56.82642
ulyate said , and kearton touched a match to the pile of grass , blew on it and flame licked out .	9.929014
he threw green stuff on it , and a thin blue column of smoke rose .	30.143496
`` that will fetch the gang and tell the colonel where we are ' ' .	64.964775
then there was a chorus of wild barking and baying .	3.8422527
kearton and ulyate looked at each other and began to gallop toward the sound .	68.26917
it came from the top of the reef not half a mile away .	153.0767
at the base of the rocky hillside , they left their horses and climbed on foot .	42.471962
the route was choked with rugged lava-rocks , creepers and bushes , so thickly overgrown that when kearton lost sight of ulyate and called , ulyate answered from ten feet away .	37.869026
nice country to meet a lion in face to face .	13.745973
ulyate and kearton climbed on toward the sound of the barking of the dogs and the sporadic roaring of the lion , till they came , out of breath , to the crest , and peering through the branches of a bush , this is what ulyate saw jones who had apparently ( and actually had ) ridden up the nearly impassable hillside , sitting calmly on his horse within forty feet of a full-grown young lioness , who was crouched on a flat rock and seemed just about to charge him , while the dogs whirled around her .	34.622234
ulyate drew back with a start , and put finger to lips , almost afraid to move or whisper lest it set her off , `` the dogs have got her bayed .	63.023304
she ' s just the other side of that bush ' ' ! !	29.17514
and when they had drawn back a step he added `` jones is sitting on his horse right in front of her .	62.561783
why she doesn ' t charge him , i don ' t know .	7.185903
and he hasn ' t even got a knife on him .	17.099974
he couldn ' t get away from her in this kind of ground .	127.04532
careful , don ' t disturb her ' ' .	1.3127288
jones had been about a hundred and fifty feet from her when he first broke through to the top of the reef .	41.007076
she was standing on a flat rock three feet above ground and when she saw him she rose to full height and roared , opening her mouth wide , lashing her tail , and stamping at the rock with both forefeet in irritation , as much as to say `` how dare you disturb me in my sacred precinct ' ' ? ?	42.001987
intuition told him , however , that she was tired and winded from the run up the reef and would not charge , yet .	77.22683
he moved forward to within thirty-five feet of her , being careful , because he knew the female is less predictable than the male .	42.71919
( in the graveyard at nairobi he had been shown the graves of thirty-four big game hunters killed hunting the animals he was attempting to lasso .	25.545006
of the thirty-four , seventeen had been killed by lions , and eleven out of the seventeen by lionesses .	27.267843
) she snarled terribly but intuition told him , again , that she was bluffing , and he could see that half her attention was distracted by the dogs .	26.03301
it was falling over her head when a branch of a bush caught it and it fell in front of her on the rock .	37.977547
even then , if she took one step forward he could catch her .	72.80475
but john nipped her rear end -- one lion ' s rear end was as good as another to john , africa , arizona no matter -- and she changed ends and took a swipe at john , but he ducked back .	70.58606
jones then recoiled his rope and threw again , this time hitting her on the back but failing to encircle her .	53.540195
she whirled and faced him , roaring terribly , and ulyate , watching through the leaves , could not understand why she did not charge and obliterate him , because he wouldn ' t have much of a chance of getting away , in that thick growth , but she seemed just a trace uncertain	56.348797
while jones , on the other hand , appeared perfectly confident and ulyate decided perhaps that was the answer .	209.18394
from the lioness ' point of view , this strange creature on the back of another creature , lashing out with its long thin paw , very likely appeared as something she could not at first cope with .	59.63775
but now she sank lower to the rock .	6.693948
although she appeared more subdued and defeated , jones knew she was growing more dangerous .	134.42036
she was rested and could mount a charge .	18.254295
just the tip of her tail was moving as she crouched , and she was treading lightly up and down with her hind feet .	15.474544
at this moment , loveless and means arrived , crashing through the undergrowth with their horses , and distracted her , and she ran off a short distance and jumped into a crevice between two rocks .	30.062588
the dogs followed her and she killed three and badly wounded old john .	66.19485
`` we ' ve got to get her out of there ' ' ! !	37.2847
jones yelled , `` or she ' ll kill ' em all .	20.730808
for such an emergency he had included fourth-of-july cannon crackers as part of their equipment .	24.84949
lighting one he pitched it into the crevice , and the lioness left off mauling the dogs and departed .	21.562836
`` ain ' t she a beauty , though ' ' ? ?	18.84547
`` don ' t you go a step nearer her than i do ' ' , jones warned , `` and if you do , go at a run so you ' ll have momentum ' ' ! !	37.79039
for two hours they drove her from one strong point to another along the side of the reef , trying to maneuver her onto the plain where they could get a good throw .	57.81091
but she clung to the rocks and brush , and the day wore away .	27.364943
it was the story of the rhinoceros fight all over again .	76.62226
and the sun was beginning to go down .	6.252625
`` i ' ll get a pole ' ' , jones said finally , `` and i ' ll poke a noose over her head ' ' ! !	19.896173
at this moment she was crouched in a cave-like aperture halfway down the reef .	7.8144083
ulyate made no comment but his face showed what he thought of poking ropes over lions ' heads with poles , and of course these were the lions of fifty years ago , not the gentler ones of today , and this one was angry , with good reason .	39.86994
`` it won ' t work , colonel ' ' .	10.58967
`` just the same we ' ll try it ' ' .	2.8866785
but without waiting for them to try it , she scattered the dogs and shot down the reef and out across the plain .	44.93562
john led the chase after her and the other dogs strung out behind , many of them trailing blood .	60.912907
john himself was bruised and clawed from head to tail , but he was in this fight to the finish , running almost as strongly now as in the morning .	98.42533
she took refuge on a tongue of land extending into a gully , crouched at the base of a thorn tree , and waited for them to come up .	15.546601
with the gully on three sides , she could be approached only along the tongue of land .	34.38002
`` careful , now ' ' , jones warned .	14.099309
very slowly he maneuvered his rawboned bay gelding , edging closer , watching for a chance to throw , but ready to spin and run , rope whining about his head , horse edging tensely under him , but the gelding was obedient and responded and was not paralyzed by the close proximity of the lion .	24.120047
they tell you horses go crazy at the sight or smell of a bear or a lion , but these didn ' t .	39.05862
again she snarled , and again he edged .	18.840899
with a whirling jump , it could get into gear .	30.146852
however nothing on four legs was supposed to be faster than a lion over a short distance , unless it was a cheetah .	19.672188
she was closing and within one more bound would have been able to reach the rear end of the bay , but -- and here jones and loveless and ulyate were holding breath for all they were worth -- she never quite caught up that last bound .	59.096386
means held steady one jump ahead of her .	43.250954
a western cowpony had outrun an african lion , from a standing start .	47.881107
photos showed later that she ' d been about six feet from means .	124.19894
of course the factor of head start made all the difference .	61.541832
the lioness quickly changed front , when she saw she couldn ' t catch means , and made for jones .	56.664963
as she had done with means , she gained rapidly at first , but then baldy began to draw away .	47.177685
somewhere in the few scant yards of head start was the determining point .	95.04109
when jones too drew away , she returned to a thorn bush in the neck of land running into the gully , crouched low and waited as before .	24.512014
this new position , however , gave the ropers a better chance .	123.49148
there was room to make a quick dash past the bush and throw as you went .	132.44658
so means edged around on the north side of her , jones moved in from the south .	91.47696
tossing his rope and shouting he attracted her attention .	21.184069
he succeeded almost too well , because once she rose as if to charge , and he half wheeled his horse -- he was within fifty feet -- but she sank back .	84.342514
from behind her means shot forward at a run .	92.99756
kearton began shouting , `` wait , wait -- the camera ' s jammed ' ' ! !	10.797902
he raced by within twenty feet of her , roped her around the neck , but a lioness ' neck is short and thick and with a quick twist she slipped the noose off .	36.614655
the missionary obligation to proclaim the gospel to all the world was once left to zealous individuals and voluntary societies .	82.47268
but the time came when a church that had no part in the missionary movement was looked upon as deficient in its essential life .	48.980007
the christian education of children , too , was once hardly more than a sideshow , but the day came when a congregation that did not assume full oversight of a church school was thought of as failing in its duty .	79.91518
the most serious weakness of the ecumenical movement today is that it is generally regarded as the responsibility of a few national leaders in each denomination and a few interdenominational executives .	33.93968
most pastors and laymen , even though they believe it to be important , assume that the ecumenical movement lies outside the province of their parishes .	33.78055
they may even dismiss it from their minds as something that concerns only the `` ecclesiastical rover boys ' ' , as someone has dubbed them , who like to go to national and international assemblies , and have expense accounts that permit them to do so .	74.20378
as long as this point of view prevails , the ecumenical movement will be lame and halt .	10.019044
the next stage ahead is that of making it thoroughly at home in the local community .	77.181404
progress will take place far less through what is done in any `` summit conference ' ' of the national council or the world council , or even in offices of the denominational boards , than through what happens in the communities where christian people live together as neighbors .	58.91156
the front line of advance is where witnessing and worshiping congregations of different traditions exist side by side .	82.50249
until they see the ecumenical movement in terms of the difference it makes in their own attitudes , programs , and relationships , it will have an inevitable aspect of unreality .	51.158424
as things now stand , there is a grievous disparity between the unity in christ which we profess in ecumenical meetings and the complacent separateness of most congregations on any main street in the nation .	34.136726
the crux of ecumenical advance is an even more personalized matter than the relation between congregations in the same community .	27.749542
the decisive question is what happens within each congregation and , finally , in the minds and hearts of the individual members .	38.283867
it is here that the local and ecumenical must meet .	130.51517
it is here that the ecumenical must become local and the local become ecumenical .	90.83586
it has become almost trite to say that the ecumenical movement must be `` carried down to the grass roots ' ' .	25.631641
this way of describing the matter is unfortunate .	3.5743139
one is that whatever is ecumenical has to do with some over-all organization at `` the top ' ' and needs only to be understood at the so-called `` lower levels ' ' .	56.145817
the truth , however , is that the ecumenical church is just the local church in its own true character as an integral unit of the whole people of god throughout the world .	43.23252
the other misconception is that our ecumenical problems will be solved if only the knowledge of the church in its world-wide extension and its interdenominational connections , now comprehended by many national leaders , can be communicated to all congregations .	33.596783
however needed this may be , the fundamental problem is not information but active commitment to the total mission of the church of christ in the world .	31.144567
the basic unit in the church , of whatever denominational polity , is always the congregation .	56.185425
it is hardly possible to emphasize this too much .	22.969055
most people do not realize that the congregation , as a gathered fellowship meeting regularly face to face , personally sharing in a common experience and expressing that experience in daily relationships with one another , is unique .	103.86046
the idea that it is a feature of all religions is entirely mistaken .	72.77425
the jewish synagogue affords a parallel to the christian congregation , but hinduism , buddhism , islam , confucianism , taoism , shintoism , although they have sacred scriptures , priests , spiritual disciplines , and places of prayer , do not have a congregation as a local household of faith and love .	24.233784
their characteristic experience is that of the individual at an altar or a shrine rather than that of a continuing social group with a distinctive kind of fellowship .	67.0792
how far the fellowship in most local churches falls below what the new testament means by koinonia ! !	131.73598
what is now called christian fellowship is often little more than the social chumminess of having a gracious time with the kind of people one likes .	48.31939
the koinonia of acts and of the epistles means sharing in a common relation to christ .	70.51477
it is an experience of a new depth of community derived from an awareness of the corporate indwelling of christ in his people .	30.154257
as dietrich bonhoffer puts it , `` our community with one another consists solely in what christ has done to both of us ' ' .	70.69212
this may mean having fellowship in the church with people with whom , on the level of merely human agreeableness , we might prefer not to have any association at all .	49.52998
there is a vast difference between the community of reconciliation which the new testament describes and the community of congeniality found in the average church building .	47.241047
whenever a congregation really sees itself as a unit in the universal church , in vital relation with the whole body of christ and participating in his mission to the world , a necessary foundation-stone of the ecumenical movement has been laid .	30.883505
the antithesis of the ecumenical and the local then no longer exists .	145.74635
of course , the perspective of those who are dealing directly with the world-wide problems of the people of god will always be different from the perspective of those who are dealing with the nearby problems of particular persons in a particular place .	39.186356
each viewpoint is valid if it is organically related to the other .	32.107605
our difficulty arises when either viewpoint shuts out the other .	65.08741
and this is what all too often happens .	3.7455413
a little parable illustrative of this truth is afforded by an incident related by professor bela vasady at the end of the second world war .	33.323982
with great difficulty he made his way from his native hungary to geneva to renew his contacts as a member of the provisional committee for the world council of churches .	21.467232
when he had the mishap of breaking his spectacles , his ecumenical colleagues insisted on providing him with new ones .	64.082085
he often spoke of them as his `` ecumenical ' ' glasses and used them as a symbol of the kind of vision that is required in the church .	29.783478
it is , he said , a bifocal vision , which can see both the near-at-hand and the distant and keep a christian in right relation to both .	101.38872
as things stand now , the local and the ecumenical tend to compete with each other .	25.2748
on the one hand , there are ecumenists who are so stirred by the crises of the church in its encounter with the world at large that they have no eyes for what the church is doing in their own town .	54.288532
they do not escape the pitfall into which charles dickens pictured mrs . jellyby as falling .	26.256454
her concern for the natives of borrioboola-gha was so intense that she quite forgot and neglected her son peepy ! !	72.310585
likewise , the ecumenist may become so absorbed in the conflict of the church with the totalitarian state in east germany , the precarious situation of the church in revolutionary china , and the anguish of the church over apartheid in south africa that he loses close contact with the parish church in its unspectacular but indispensable ministry of worship , pastoral service and counseling , and christian nurture for a face-to-face group of individuals .	26.72662
on the other hand , many a pastor is so absorbed in ministering to the intimate , personal needs of individuals in his congregation that he does little or nothing to lead them into a sense of social responsibility and world mission .	71.04845
as a result , they go on thinking of the church , with introverted and self-centered satisfaction , only in connection with the way in which it serves them and their families .	36.527367
it would hardly be an exaggeration to say that ninety per cent of the energy of most churches -- whether in terms of finance or spiritual concern -- is poured into the private and domestic interests of the members .	53.821896
the parish lives for itself rather than for the community or the world .	33.950466
the gap between the ecumenical perspective and the parish perspective appears most starkly in a church in any of our comfortable suburbs .	55.946716
it is eminently successful according to all conventional standards .	23.918001
its preaching and its music give refreshment of spirit to men and women living under heavy strain .	98.134315
it provides pastoral care for the sick and troubled .	20.25316
it helps children grow up with at least a nodding acquaintance with the bible .	9.0156765
it draws young people into the circle of those who continue the life of the church from generation to generation .	37.698715
and it is easy for the ecumenical enthusiast to lose sight of how basic all this is .	82.304214
but what is this church doing to help its members understand their roles as christians in the world ? ?	75.809616
all too often its conception of parish ministry and pastoral care includes no responsibility for them in their relation to issues of the most desperate urgency for the life of mankind .	49.916267
it is not stirring them to confront the racial tensions of today with the mind of christ .	35.69476
it is not helping them face the moral crisis involved in the use of nuclear energy .	46.320946
it is not making them sensitive to the sub-christian level of much of our economic and industrial life .	90.442474
it is raising no disturbing question as to what christian stewardship means for the relationship of the richest nation in the world to economically underdeveloped peoples .	18.795403
it is not developing an awareness of the new kind of missionary strategy that is called for as young churches emerge in asia and africa .	38.370056
to put it bluntly , many a local church is giving its members only what they consciously want .	70.973335
it is not disturbing them by thoughts of their christian responsibility in relation to the world .	39.00343
we shall not make a decisive advance in the ecumenical movement until such a church begins to see itself not merely as a haven of comfort and peace but as a base of christian witness and mission to the world .	63.495106
there is a humorous but revealing story about a rancher who owned a large slice of texas and who wanted to have on it everything that was necessary for a completely pleasant community .	52.053955
he built a school and a library , then a recreation center and an inn .	55.668285
desiring to fill the only remaining lack , he selected the best site on the ranch for a chapel and spared no expense in erecting it .	42.533813
a visitor to the beautiful little building inquired , `` do you belong to this church , mr . rancher ' ' ? ?	24.604181
`` why , no , ma ' am ' ' , he replied , `` this church belongs to me ' ' ! !	10.574611
the story reflects the way too many people feel .	85.91543
as long as the congregation regards the church as `` our ' ' church , or the minister thinks of it as `` my ' ' church , just so long the ecumenical movement will make no significant advance .	60.03635
there must first be a deeper sense that the church belongs not to us but to christ , and that it is his purpose , not our own interests and preferences , that determines what it is to be and do .	47.88065
a local church which conceives its function to be entirely that of ministering to the conscious desires and concerns of its members tends to look on everything ecumenical as an extra , not as a normal aspect of its own life as a church .	74.65587
it would doubtless be greatly surprised to be told that in failing to be ecumenical it is really failing to be the church of christ .	52.961243
yet the truth , according to the new testament , is that every local church has its existence only by being the embodiment of the whole church in that particular place .	50.34608
yet a crowd came out to see some fresh kids from the city try to match the boys from the neighboring farms	59.88958
and buggies and wagons and chugging fords kept gathering all morning , until the edges of the field were packed thick and small boys kept scampering out on the playing field to make fun of the visitors -- whose pitcher was a formidable looking young man with the only baseball cap .	93.989525
this was a bitterly fought game , carrying almost as much grudge as a fist fight , with no friendliness exhibited between the teams except the formal politeness that accompanied the setting forth of ground rules and agreements on balls that went into the crowd .	53.895023
every pitch in the game brought forth a howl from the enraptured audience and every fly ball the visitors dropped ( and because their right fielder was still a little fuzzy from drink , they dropped many ) called forth yelps of derision .	66.75695
at one point in the game when the skinny old man in suspenders who was acting as umpire got in the way of a thrown ball and took it painfully in the kidneys , he lay there unattended while players and spectators wrangled over whether the ball was `` dead ' ' or the base runners were free to score .	42.823895
this was typical of such games , which were earnestly played to win and practically never wound up in an expression of good fellowship .	85.57554
when the visitors , after losing this game , rode along the village streets toward home , the youngsters who could keep abreast of them for a moment or two screamed triumphantly , `` you bunch of hay-shakers ! !	29.545528
baseball was surely the national game in those days , even though professional baseball may have been merely a business .	100.67288
radio broadcasts had not begun and most devotees of baseball attended the games near home , in the town park or a pasture , with perhaps two or three trips to the city each season to see the cubs or the pirates or the indians or the red sox .	51.12318
young men in school could look forward to playing ball for money in a dozen different places , even if they failed to make the major leagues .	48.407944
nearly any lad with a modicum of skill might find a payday awaiting him in the three i league , or the pony league , or the coastal plains league , or the fast eastern league , if not indeed in one of the hundreds of city leagues that abounded everywhere .	51.904476
even a city of thirty thousand might have six baseball teams , sponsored by grocers and hardware merchants or department stores , that played two or three times a week throughout the summer , usually in the cool of the evening , before an earnest and partisan audience who did not begrudge a quarter each , or even more , to be dropped into a hat when the game was half over .	65.19321
babe ruth , of course , was everyone ' s hero , and everyone knew him , even though relatively few ever saw him play ball .	93.0926
his face was always in the newspapers , sometimes in cartoons that seemed nearly as large as life .	123.0802
as the twenties grew older , and as radio broadcasts of baseball games began to involve more and more people daily in the doings of the professionals , the great hitters ( always led by babe ruth ) overshadowed the game so that pitchers were nearly of no account .	49.134
boys no longer bothered learning to bunt and even school kids scorned to `` choke up ' ' on a bat as willie keeler and the famous hitters of another day had done .	31.1997
other hitters bloomed with more or less vigor in the news and a few even dared to dream of matching ruth , who was still called jidge by all his friends , or leo or two-head by those who dared to taunt him ( leo was the name of the ball player he liked the least ) and who called most of the world `` kid ' ' .	38.903675
lou gehrig was given the nickname buster , and he ran ruth a close race in home runs .	47.346195
but the nickname never stuck and gehrig was no match for ruth in `` color ' ' -- which is sometimes a polite word for delinquent behavior on and off the field .	78.93401
ruth was a delinquent boy still , but he was in every way a great ball player who was out to win the game and occasionally risked a cracked bone to do it .	37.185234
a few professional baseball players cultivated eccentricities , with the encouragement of the press , so that they might see their names in big black print , along with daddy browning ' s , al capone ' s , earl sande ' s , and the prince of wales ' .	19.600447
one who , for a time , succeeded best and was still the sorriest of all was charles arthur shires , who called himself , in the newspapers , art the great , or the great shires .	56.143196
it was his brag that he could beat everybody at anything , but especially at fighting , and he once took on the manager of his club and worked him over thoroughly with his fists .	65.83627
he was given to public carousing and to acting the clown on the diamond	39.444263
and a policeman asserted he had found a pair of brass knuckles in art ' s pocket once when he had occasion to collar the great first baseman for some forgotten reason .	60.65625
( this made a sportswriter named pegler wonder in print if art had worn this armament when he defeated his manager .	90.22375
) the sorry fact about this young man , who was barely of age when he broke into major-league baseball , was that he really was a better ball player than he was given credit for being -- never so good as he claimed , and always an irritant to his associates , but a good steady performer when he could fight down the temptation to orate on his skills or cut up in public .	65.12383
in his minor way charles arthur shires was perhaps more typical of his era than ruth was , for he was but one of many young men who laid waste their talents in these scott fitzgerald days for the sake of earning space in the newspapers .	65.19837
there were others who climbed flagpoles and refused to come down	31.099573
or who ingested strange objects , like live fish	13.39974
or who undertook to set records for remaining erect on a dance floor , with or without a partner	206.84283
or who essayed to down full bottles of illicit gin without pausing for breath .	21.151672
one young man , exhilarated to the point of insanity by liquor and the excitement of the moment , performed a perfect swan dive out of the stands at the yale bowl during the yale-army football game , landed squarely on his head on the concrete ramp below , and died at once .	33.941685
but the twenties were not all insanity and a striving after recognition .	92.39214
the business of baseball began to prosper along with other entertainments , and performers -- thanks partly to george herman ruth ' s spectacular efforts each season to run his salary higher and higher -- prospered too .	83.7317
