while fifty years before , albert goodwill spalding , secretary of the chicago ball club of the national league , could write earnestly to the manager of the buffalo club and request a guarantee of one hundred dollars for a baseball game in august , in this golden era a game at the yankee stadium might bring in nearly a hundred thousand dollars at the gate .	31.750246
and while less than ten years earlier the wayward black sox -- all of them top performers in their positions -- had toiled for stingy charles comiskey at salaries ranging from twenty-five hundred dollars to forty-five hundred dollars a year , stars now were asking ten thousand dollars , twenty thousand dollars , yes , even fifty thousand dollars a season .	48.664886
the greatest team of this period was unquestionably the new york yankees , bought by brewery millions and made into a ball club by men named ed barrow and miller huggins .	49.685272
boston fans sometimes liked to wring some wry satisfaction out of the fact that most of the great 1923-27 crew were graduates of the red sox -- sold to millionaires huston and ruppert by a man who could not deny them their most trifling desire .	30.621683
ruth himself , still owning his farm in massachusetts and an interest in the massachusetts cigar business that printed his round boyish face on the wrappers , had led the parade down from fenway park , followed by pitchers carl mays , leslie `` joe ' ' bush , waite hoyt , herb pennock , and sam jones , catcher wally schang , third baseman joe dugan ( who completed the `` playboy trio ' ' of ruth , dugan , and hoyt ) , and shortstop everett scott .	20.63878
by 1926 , when the mighty yanks were at their mightiest , only a few of these were left but they still shone brightest , even beside able and agile rookies like tony lazzeri ( who managed never to have one of his epileptic fits on the field ) , mark koenig , lou gehrig , george pipgras , and gray-thatched earl combs .	22.30003
the deeds of this team , through two seasons and in the two world ' s series that followed , have been written and talked about until hardly a word is left to be said .	78.19373
but there is one small episode that a few new york fans who happened to sit in the cheap seats for one world ' s series game in 1926 like best to recall .	51.15461
babe ruth , as he always did in the stadium , played right field to avoid having the sun in his eyes , and tommy thevenow , a rather mediocre hitter who played shortstop for the st . louis cardinals , knocked a ball with all his might into the sharp angle formed by the permanent stands and the wooden bleachers , where ruth could not reach it .	57.99908
the ball lay there , shining white on the grass in view of nearly every fan in the park while ruth , red-necked with frustration , charged about the small patch of ground screaming , `` where ' s the -- -ing ball ' ' ? ?	43.54474
but , as he snarled unhappily when the inning was over , `` not a sonofabitch in the place would tell me ' ' , so little tommy ran all the way home .	55.48429
the ordinary man and woman , however , saw little of the great professional games of those golden days , or of any other sporting event for that matter .	135.09654
promoters always hastened to place their choice tickets in the hands of the wealthy speculators , and only the man who knew the man who knew the fellow who had an in with the guy at the box office ever came up with a good seat for a contest of any importance .	50.413414
radio broadcasts , however -- now that even plain people could afford `` loud speakers ' ' on their sets -- held old fans to the major-league races and attracted new ones , chiefly women , who through what the philosopher called the ineluctable modality of audition , became first inured , then attracted , then addicted to the long afternoon recitals of the doings in some distant baseball park .	71.444084
in some cities games were broadcast throughout the week and then on weekends the announcer was silenced , and fans must needs drive to the city from all the broadcast area to discover how their heroes were faring .	63.84729
this had a pleasant effect upon the sunday gate receipts as well as upon the intake of the rail and bus companies , some of which began to offer special excursion rates , including seats at the park , just as the trolley and ferry companies had when baseball was new .	48.433643
while women had always attended ball games in small numbers ( it was the part of a `` dead game sport ' ' in the early years of the twentieth century to be taken out to the ball park and to root , root , root for the home team ) , they had often sat in patient martyrdom , unable even to read the scoreboard , which sometimes seemed to indicate that one team led another by a score of three hundred and eighty to one hundred and fifty-one .	47.766605
the questions women asked at baseball games were standard grist for amateur comedy , as were the doings of women automobile drivers	65.031815
for every grown man ( except a few who were always suspected of being shy on virility ) knew at least the fundamentals of baseball , just as every male american in this era liked to imagine ( or pretend ) that he could fight with his fists .	61.177532
and women were not expected to know that the pitcher was trying not to let the batter hit the ball .	27.760752
radio , however , so increased the interest of women in the game that it was hardly necessary even to have `` ladies ' days ' ' any longer to enable men to get to the ball park without interference at home .	92.6619
women actually began to appear unaccompanied in the stands , where they still occasionally ran the risk of coming home with a tobacco-juice stain on a clean skirt or a new curse word tingling their ears .	70.89656
the radio broadcasts themselves were often so patiently informative , despite the baseball jargon , that girls and women could begin to store up in their minds the same sort of random and meaningless statistics that small boys had long learned better than they ever did their lessons in school .	85.57337
this conclusion is dependent on the assumption that traditional sex mores will continue to sanction both premarital chastity as the `` ideal ' ' , and the double standard holding females primarily responsible for preserving the ideal .	74.349
our discussion of this involves using erik erikson ' s schema of `` identity vs . identity diffusion ' ' as a conceptual tool in superimposing a few common denominators onto the diverse personality and family configurations of the unwed mothers from whose case histories we quoted earlier .	23.21709
our discussion does not utilize all the identity crises postulated by erikson , but is intended to demonstrate the utility of his theoretical schema for studying unwed mothers .	33.51843
we hope thereby to emphasize that , from a psychological standpoint , the effectual prevention of illegitimacy is a continuous long-term process involving the socialization of the female from infancy through adolescence .	19.188766
hypothesizing a series of developmental stages that begin in the individual ' s infancy and end in his old age , erikson has indicated that the adolescent is faced with a series of identity crises .	28.342136
the successful and positive resolution of these crises during adolescence involves an epigenetic principle -- during adolescence , the individual ' s positive resolutions in each area of identity crisis depend , to a considerable degree , on his already having resolved preliminary and preparatory identity crises during his infancy , childhood , and early adolescence .	47.894245
within erikson ' s schema , the adolescent ' s delinquent behavior -- in this case , her unwed motherhood -- reflects her `` identity diffusion ' ' , or her inability to resolve these various identity crises positively .	31.124704
the adolescent experiences identity crises in terms of time perspective vs . time diffusion .	134.65875
time perspective -- the ability to plan for the future and to postpone gratifying immediate wants in order to achieve long-range objectives -- is more easily developed if , from infancy on , the individual has been able to rely on and trust people and the world in which she lives .	62.193256
erikson has noted that , unless this trust developed early , the time ambivalence experienced , in varying degree and temporarily , by all adolescents ( as a result of their remembering the more immediate gratification of wants during childhood , while not yet having fully accepted the long-range planning required by adulthood ) may develop into a more permanent sense of time diffusion .	103.23739
experience of this time diffusion ranges from a sense of utter apathy to a feeling of desperate urgency to act immediately .	36.68577
these polar extremes in time diffusion were indicated in some of the comments by unwed mothers reported in earlier chapters .	38.3161
some of these mothers , apparently feeling a desperate urgency , made , on the spur of the moment , commitments , in love and sex , that would have life-long consequences .	47.350372
others displayed utter apathy and indifference to any decision about the past or the future .	51.483974
for many of these unwed mothers , the data on their family life and early childhood experiences revealed several indications and sources of their basic mistrust of their parents in particular and of the world in general .	68.91037
however , as erickson has noted , the individual ' s failure to develop preliminary identities during infancy and childhood need not be irreversibly deterministic with respect to a given area of identity diffusion in his ( or her ) adolescence .	56.65656
and , as shown in chapter 6 , , some snp females originally developed such trust only during their adolescence , through the aid of , and their identification with , alter-parents .	142.23422
in the specific case of time diffusion , we must emphasize the significance of the earlier development of mistrust when it is combined with the inevitable time crisis experienced by most ( if not all ) adolescents in our society , and with the failure of the adolescent period to provide opportunities for developing trust .	55.40992
the adolescent experiences two closely related crises self-certainty vs . an identity consciousness	97.43653
a sense of self-certainty and the freedom to experiment with different roles , or confidence in one ' s own unique behavior as an alternative to peer-group conformity , is more easily developed during adolescence if , during early childhood , the individual was permitted to exercise initiative and encouraged to develop some autonomy .	62.31972
however , if the child has been constantly surrounded , during nursery and early school age , by peer groups	88.33904
inculcated with the primacy of group acceptance and group standards	1816.4443
and allowed little initiative in early play and work patterns -- then in adolescence her normal degree of vanity , sensitivity , and preoccupation with whether others find her appearance and behavior acceptable , will be compounded .	143.49915
her ostensible indifference to and rebellion against suggestions and criticisms by anyone except peer friends during adolescence are the manifestations , in her adolescence , of her having been indoctrinated in childhood to feel shame , if not guilt , for failing to behave in a manner acceptable to , and judged by , the performance of her nursery- and elementary-school peer friends .	60.99266
to be different is to invite shame and doubt	2772.83
and it is better to be shamed and criticized by one ' s parents , who already consider one different and difficult to understand , than by one ' s peers , who are also experiencing a similar groping for and denial of adult status .	64.15516
the attitudes of some unwed mothers quoted in chapter 2 , , revealed both considerable preoccupation with being accepted by others and a marked absence of self-certainty .	95.995285
many appeared to regard their sexual behavior as a justifiable means of gaining acceptance from and identification with others	103.57253
but very few seemed aware that such acceptance and identification need to be supplemented with more enduring and stable identification of and with one ' s self .	84.30262
another identity crisis confronting the adolescent involves anticipation of achievement vs . work-paralysis .	13.326863
the adolescent ' s capacity to anticipate achievement and to exercise the self-discipline necessary to complete tasks successfully depends on the degree to which he or she developed autonomy , initiative , and self-discipline during childhood .	34.68132
the developmental process involves the individual ' s progressively experiencing a sense of dignity and achievement resulting from having completed tasks , having kept commitments , and having created something ( however small or simple -- even a doll dress of one ' s own design rather than in the design `` it ought to be ' ' ) .	92.69627
these childhood experiences are sources of the self-certainty that the adolescent needs , for experimenting with many roles , and for the freedom to fail sometimes in the process of exploring and discovering her skills and abilities .	51.70902
if she has not had such experiences , the female ' s normal adolescent degree of indecision will be compounded .	39.80503
she may well be incapacitated by it when she is confronted with present and future alternatives -- e . g . , whether to prepare primarily for a career or for the role of a homemaker	69.10339
whether to stay financially dependent on her parents or help support herself while attending school	383.25055
whether to pursue a college education or a job after high school	106.116135
and whether to attend this or that college and to follow this or that course of study .	180.39578
erikson has noted that , as this indecision mounts , it may result in a `` paralysis of workmanship ' ' .	12.691273
this paralysis may be expressed in the female ' s starting -- and never completing -- many jobs , tasks , and courses of study	102.44992
and in the fact that she bases her decisions about work , college , carreer , and studies on what others are doing , rather than on her own sense of identity with given skills , abilities , likes , and dislikes .	54.858906
the absence , during her childhood and early adolescence , of experiences in developing the self-discipline to complete tasks within her ability -- experiences that would have been subsequent sources of anticipation of achievement -- and her lack of childhood opportunities to practice autonomy and initiative in play and expression , both tend in her adolescence to deprive her of the freedoms to role-experiment and to fail occasionally in experimenting .	59.821396
the comments made by some unwed mothers ( quoted in chapter 2 ) ) reflect this paralysis of workmanship .	13.033964
they attended school and selected courses primarily on the basis of decisions others made	68.158485
they accepted a job primarily because it was available , convenient , and paid reasonably .	103.589615
these things both express and , at the same time , continue contributing to , their identity diffusion in an area that could have become a source of developing dignity and self-certainty .	45.037422
as their identity diffusion increased , they became more susceptible to sporadic diversions in love and sexual affairs .	19.075195
these affairs temporarily relieved the monotony of school or work activities containing no anticipation of achievement and joy of craftsmanship , no sense of dignity derived from a job well done .	104.35788
childhood experiences in learning work and self-discipline habits within a context of developing autonomy and initiative have considerable significance for the prevention of illegitimacy .	19.933088
the excerpts from case histories presented above confirm this significance , though through different facets of experience .	95.3514
for example , some unwed mothers had had no work experiences , household chores , and responsibilities during childhood and early adolescence	51.81839
they subsequently occupied their leisure hours in searching for something exciting and diverting .	56.018284
on the other hand , some unwed mothers had had so much work and responsibility imposed on them at an early age , and had thus had so little freedom or opportunity to develop autonomy and initiative , that their work and responsibilities became dull and unrewarding burdens -- to be escaped and rebelled against through fun and experimentation with forbidden sexual behavior .	90.18292
the adolescent also faces the identity crisis that erikson has termed ideological polarization vs . diffusion of ideals .	16.242344
in discussing the ways this crisis is germane to consderations for the prevention of illegitimacy , we shall again superimpose erikson ' s concept on our data .	18.39325
adolescents have a much-discussed tendency to polarize ideas and values , to perceive things as `` either-or ' ' , black or white -- nuances of meaning are relatively unimportant .	24.364534
this tendency is , perhaps , most clearly revealed in the literature on religious conversions and experiences of adolescents .	47.007618
erikson has postulated that such ideological polarization temporarily resolves their search for something stable and definite in the rapidly changing and fluctuating no-man ' s-land between childhood and adulthood .	36.407127
it provides identification -- with an idea , a value , a cause that cuts through , or even transcends , the multiple and ambivalent identities of their passage from child to adult , and permits their forceful and overt expression of emotion .	81.242424
the positive development , during adolescence , of this capacity to think and to feel strongly and with increasing independence , and to identify overtly either with or against given ideas , values , and practices , depends to a considerable degree on both previous and present opportunities for developing autonomy , initiative , and self-certainty .	74.17068
most adolescents have some ideological diffusion at various developmental stages , as they experience a proliferation of ideas and values .	20.394222
the diffusion is most pronounced and most likely to become fixed , however , in those who have had no or very minimal opportunities to develop the autonomy and initiative that could have been directed into constructive expression and so served as sources of developing self-certainty .	46.176647
a pronounced ideological diffusion -- i . e . , inability to identify independently with given ideas and value systems -- is reflected in many ways .	34.8173
for example , it is evinced by the adolescent ( or adult ) whose beliefs and actions represent primarily his rebellion and reaction against the ideas and behavior patterns of others , rather than his inner conviction and choice .	109.73638
it is mirrored by the individual willie lohmans , whose ideas and behavior patterns are so dependent and relativistic that they always coincide with those of the individual or group present and most important at the moment .	64.88853
in another sense , it is represented in the arguments of the `` true believers ' ' who seek to disprove the validity of all other beliefs and ideas in order to retain confidence in theirs .	30.49398
the case histories provide some interesting illustrations of ideological diffusion , embodied in the unwed mother ' s inability to identify independently a given value system or behavior pattern , , and her subsequent disinclination to assume any individual responsibility for her sexual behavior .	74.6022
for example , the unwed mothers expressed their frustration with males who did not indicate more explicitly `` what it is they really want from a girl so one can act accordingly ' ' .	87.797226
they were disappointed by the physical and emotional hurt of premarital sexual intercourse .	23.044836
they condemned the movie script writers for implying that sex was enjoyable and exhilarating .	11.422021
they criticized parents for never having emphasized traditional concepts of right and wrong	42.852352
and they censured parents who `` never disciplined and were too permissive ' ' or who `` never explained how easy it was to get pregnant ' ' .	45.771824
in the adult world , there are a number of rather general and diffuse sources of ideological diffusion that further compound the adolescent ' s search for meaning during this particular identity crisis .	84.56053
for example , some contemporary writing tends to fuse the `` good guys ' ' and the `` bad guys ' ' , to portray the weak people as heroes and weakness as a virtue , and to explain ( or even justify ) asocial behavior by attributing it to deterministic psychological , familial , and social experiences .	27.282352
in the final accounting , these would have augmented the bill for both sides .	52.540867
an estimate of one million dollars is probably not excessive .	37.18894
yet the huge amount of money consumed by the selden litigation , which many regarded as wasteful , indirectly contributed to constructive changes in legal procedure .	36.290043
the duration and other circumstances of the selden case made it a flagrant example of the gross abuses of patent infringement actions .	23.311205
the suit , as we have seen , came before the courts when patent attorneys , inventors , and laymen were making mounting demands for reforms in the american patent system .	61.65562
chief among the defects they singled out were the complicated and wearisome procedures in equity .	36.15495
in a long and angry footnote to his opinion , judge hough had lent the weight of judicial condemnation to such criticism .	22.828344
`` it is a duty ' ' , said hough , `` not to let pass this opportunity of protesting against the methods of taking and printing testimony in equity , current in this circuit ( and probably others ) , excused if not justified by the rules of the supreme court , especially to be found in patent causes , and flagrantly exemplified in this litigation .	52.137123
as long as the bar prefers to adduce evidence by written deposition , rather than viva voce before an authoritative judicial officer , i fear that the antiquated rules will remain unchanged , and expensive prolixity remain the best known characteristic of equity ' ' .	24.88587
observing that `` reforms sometimes begin with the contemplation of horrible examples ' ' , hough catalogued the many abuses encouraged by existing procedures .	26.380623
he cited the elephantine dimensions of the selden case record	147.4586
the `` objections stated at outrageous length ' '	1.0071038
and the frequent and rancorous verbal bouts , `` uncalled for and unjustifiable , from the retort discourteous to the lie direct ' ' .	28.368889
the fundamental difficulty of which the selden case was `` a striking ( though not singular ) example ' ' , concluded hough , `` will remain as long as testimony is taken without any authoritative judicial officer present , and responsible for the maintenance of discipline , and the reception or exclusion of testimony ' ' .	60.22223
not least among the members of the patent bar who echoed this powerful indictment were those who had participated in the selden suit .	37.853394
william a . redding asserted that if the case had been heard in open court under rules of evidence , the testimony would have been completed in sixty days instead of five years .	80.46932
inventors joined lawyers in the clamor for reform , inevitably centering upon the selden litigation as a `` horrible example ' ' .	22.986137
its costive deliberations were likened to those of the british courts of chancery mercilessly caricatured by dickens in bleak house .	47.948666
parker , who agreed with much of this criticism , did not conceal his dissatisfaction with procedural defects .	11.926651
but he felt that the selden case was being unfairly pilloried .	9.112248
in a detailed letter published in the scientific american in 1912 , he remarked that `` loose statements ' ' about the case showed scant understanding of the facts .	36.289635
the suit , although commonly designated as a single action , actually embraced five cases .	106.78285
parker insisted that the size of the record would have been drastically reduced but for an unavoidable duplication of testimony .	23.662151
in a private communication written in 1911 , parker had been more to the point .	142.7155
noting the complaints of inventors and members of the patent bar , he admitted that some of the strictures `` were fairly well founded ' ' , but he added that under existing rules the courts could not consolidate testimony in a group of suits involving separate infringements of the same patent .	44.065514
the vast industrial interests caught up in the selden suit , as well as the complex character of the automotive art , encouraged both sides to exploit `` every possible chance ' ' for or against the patent , said parker .	64.32146
`` this very seldom happens in this class or in other cases , and of course all of these matters led to a volume and an expense of the record beyond what ordinarily would occur ' ' .	47.757862
parker listed the remedies he deemed essential for reducing the cost and mass of testimony .	147.15166
the most important of these found him in agreement with hough ' s plea for reform .	37.437542
parker called for abolition of the indiscriminate or uncontrolled right of taking depositions before officers of the court who had no authority to limit testimony .	98.38892
the taking of depositions , he suggested , should be placed under a special court examiner empowered to compel responsive and relevant answers and to exclude immaterial testimony .	41.41032
`` i am satisfied that in the selden case had this power existed and this course ( been ) pursued , it would have shortened the depositions of some of the experts nearly one-half and of some of the other witnesses thereto more than that ' ' .	73.581436
in the end hough ' s acidulous protest , which parker called the `` now somewhat famous note on this ' selden ' case ' ' , did not go unheeded .	102.65677
in 1912 the united states supreme court adopted a new set of rules of equity which became effective on february 1 , 1913 .	53.375134
the revised procedure was acclaimed as a long-overdue reform .	10.4644785
under the new rules , testimony is taken orally in open court in all cases except those of an extraordinary character .	79.122475
other expeditious methods are designed to prevent prolixity , limit delays , and reduce the expense of infringement suits .	8.560525
one of the a . l . a . m . lawyers observed that if the selden case had been tried under this simplified procedure , the testimony which filled more than a score of volumes , `` at a minimum cost of $1 a page for publication alone , could have been contained in one volume ' ' .	54.327972
while patent suits are still among the most complex and expensive forms of litigation , these rules have saved litigants uncounted sums of money .	44.61013
there is little doubt that they were promulgated by the supreme court as a direct result of the selden patent suit .	9.813008
even before it was formally dissolved in 1912 , the a . l . a . m . was succeeded by the automobile board of trade , the direct lineal ancestor of the present-day automobile manufacturers association .	25.165995
the trade bodies which came in the wake of the a . l . a . m . were more representative , for they never adopted a policy of exclusion .	35.62783
nevertheless , it is from the selden organization that the industry inherited its institutional machinery for furthering the broader interests of the trade .	25.891378
one of the chief features of this community of interest is the automotive patents cross-licensing agreement , a milestone in the development of american industrial cooperation .	32.541676
its origin lies in the selden patent controversy and its aftermath .	20.372314
from the earliest days of the motor car industry , before the a . l . a . m . was established , patent infringement loomed as a serious and vexing problem .	24.005081
many patent contests were waged over automobile components and accessories , among them tires , detachable rims , ball bearings , license brackets , and electric horns .	12.557118
the fluidity and momentum of the young industry abetted a general disregard of patent claims .	41.046604
as early as 1900 a wall street combination acquired detail patents with the intention of exacting heavy tribute from automobile manufacturers .	55.248745
this scheme failed , and the following decade brought a deluge of infringement suits among individual manufacturers that reached its crest in 1912 .	30.545061
in this tangle of conflicting claims , the patent-sharing scheme adopted by the a . l . a . m . at its founding proved to be the best device for avoiding or mitigating the burdens of incessant litigation .	28.30747
the interchange of shop licenses for a nominal royalty eliminated infringement suits among the members of the a . l . a . m . patent pool ( although it did not protect them against outside actions ) and kept open channels for the cross-fertilization of automotive technology .	57.87159
one of the conditions of the pool was a prohibition upon the withholding of patent rights among a . l . a . m . members .	21.621038
within its limits , this arrangement had the actual or potential characteristics of a cross-licensing agreement .	57.906178
its positive features outweighed the fact that the pool was an adjunct of a wouldbe monopoly .	19.946724
since the a . l . a . m . holdings embraced only about twenty-five per cent of motor vehicle patents , the denial of rights to independent companies did not retard technical progress in unlicensed sectors of the industry .	29.868626
the highly important dyer patents on the sliding gear transmission were held by the a . l . a . m . pool .	22.927595
but henry ford used the planetary transmission in his model t and earlier cars and , in 1905 , as a precautionary measure , took out a license from the man who claimed to be its inventor .	77.08629
for those affiliated with it , the a . l . a . m . pool was a haven from the infringement actions involving detail patents that beset the industry with mounting intensity after 1900 .	45.18773
by 1910 the courts were crowded with cases , many of them brought by freebooters who trafficked in disputed inventions .	16.119293
it was commonplace for auto makers , parts-suppliers , and dealers to find warning notices and threats of infringement suits in their daily mail .	40.868587
`` purely from the business man ' s standpoint and without regard to the lawyer ' s view ' ' , commented a trade journal , `` the matter of patents in the automobile and accessory trade is developing some phases and results that challenge thought as to how far patents are to become weapons of warfare in business , instead of simple beneficient protection devices for encouraging inventive creation ' ' .	70.92033
occasionally new enterprise was discouraged by the almost certain prospect of legal complications .	49.397892
one manufacturer who held an allegedly basic patent said `` i would readily put over $50 , 000 into the manufacture of the device , but it is so easy to make that we would enter immediately into a prolonged ordeal of patent litigation which would eat up all our profits ' ' .	41.056488
the prevailing view in the industry was summed up in 1912 by a group of auto makers who told a senate committee `` the exceedingly unsatisfactory and uselessly expensive conditions , including delays surrounding legal disputes , particularly in patent litigation , are items of industrial burden which must be written large in figures of many millions of dollars of industrial waste ' ' .	48.554035
by that time it was commonly agreed that patent warfare was sapping constructive achievement and blocking the free exchange of technical information .	60.87786
at this point charles c . hanch , long an advocate of patent peace in the industry , became chairman of the patents committee of the national automobile chamber of commerce , successor to the automobile board of trade .	33.51685
hanch was treasurer of the nordyke & marmon company , an indianapolis firm which had manufactured flour-milling machinery before producing the marmon car in 1904 .	22.053415
he had first-hand knowledge of the patent wars which had driven about ninety per cent of the milling equipment makers out of business in the mid-1890 ' s .	18.750063
anxious to avoid a similar debacle in the motor car industry , hanch went to detroit in 1909 to enlist the support of leading a . l . a . m . members for an industry-wide patent-sharing plan .	30.99597
the breach created by the selden patent doomed his proposal , but hanch did not abandon his scheme .	28.48278
after the demise of the a . l . a . m . , the time was propitious for establishing such a pool .	14.490335
most manufacturers were now disposed to heed a proposal for the formal interchange of patents .	61.0816
`` it is a much easier course to agree to let one another alone so far as ordinary patents are concerned ' ' , said a trade authority , `` than to continue the costly effort of straightening the tangle in the courts or seeking to reform the patent system , which appears to be getting into deeper confusion every day ' ' .	66.572105
with the other members of the patents committee -- wilfred c . leland , howard e . coffin , windsor t . white , and w . h . vandervoort -- hanch drafted a cross-licensing agreement whose essential feature of royalty-free licensing was his own contribution .	33.25089
the plan was supported by frederick p . fish , counsel for the national automobile chamber of commerce .	25.443184
it will be recalled that in his summation for the a . l . a . m . before judge hough , fish had condemned patent litigation as the curse of the american industrial community .	34.674873
he was well aware that some inventors and their allies used their patents solely for nuisance value .	59.945663
`` my personal view is that not one patented invention in ten is worth making ' ' , he later told a congressional committee .	150.67157
the eloquent persuasions of fish guaranteed the adoption of the plan by the members of the automotive trade association .	22.591948
drawn up in 1914 , the cross-licensing agreement became effective in 1915 .	48.44489
it remained in force for ten years and has been renewed at five-year intervals since 1925 .	21.230213
a little farther along the road you come to the church of santa sabina , called the `` pearl of the aventine ' ' .	15.885975
continue another hundred yards to the piazza of the knights of malta .	11.282756
on the wall of this square there are delightful bas-reliefs of musical instruments .	27.248055
the massive gate of the maltese villa affords one of the most extraordinary views in rome .	39.007996
if you look through the keyhole , you will see an artistically landscaped garden with the white dome of st . peter ' s framed in a long avenue of cropped laurel trees .	21.614159
retrace your steps a few yards on the via di santa sabina and turn right on the via di s . alessio , a street lined with stately homes .	17.06269
oleanders , cypress , and palms in the spacious gardens add much color and beauty to this attractive residential section .	164.61417
turn left a block or so before the street ends , and then turn right down the via di santa prisca to the viale aventino .	18.02414
here you can pick up a taxi or public transport to return to the center of the city .	30.529648
these two walks take you through the heart of rome .	8.142208
you will walk some of the narrow , old streets , hemmed in by massive palazzi .	56.738503
you will visit a few churches that are exceptional yet often by-passed , a magnificent square , the main shopping district , the spanish steps , and the lovely pincian gardens .	27.710033
by seeing such varied places , both interesting and beautiful , you will become aware of the many different civilizations rome has lived through , and in particular , get a feel of renaissance rome .	80.986374
you will realize why rome is indeed the eternal city .	181.42389
start on the via d . teatro di marcello at the foot of the capitoline hill .	6.449611
the majestic circular tiers of stone of the theatre of marcellus give you some idea of the huge edifice that the emperor augustus erected in 13 b . c . .	28.10086
twenty-two thousand spectators used to crowd it in roman days .	147.35983
andrea palladio , an italian architect of the sixteenth century , modeled his designs on its doric and ionic columns .	7.5670567
wander past the three superb columns of apollo by the arches of the theatre .	19.877937
the remains of the portico of octavia are now in front of you .	30.771149
climb the steps from the theatre to the via della tribuna di campitelli for an even better view of the columns of apollo .	40.393505
turn to the right along a narrow street to the tiny piazza campitelli , then proceed along the via dei funari to the piazza mattei .	16.30824
here is one of the loveliest fountains in rome , the fontana delle tartarughe or `` fountain of the tortoises ' ' .	5.261183
it ' s typical of rome that in the midst of this rather poor area you should find such an artistic work in the center of a little square .	45.69757
stand here for a few moments and look at this gem of a fountain with its four youths , each holding a tortoise and each with a foot resting on the head of a dolphin .	26.639793
the figures have been executed so skillfully that one senses a great feeling of life and movement .	75.40324
opposite is the palazzo mattei , one of rome ' s oldest palaces , now the headquarters of the italo-american association .	15.797214
go inside for a closer look at a renaissance palace .	36.55398
in the first courtyard there are some fine bas-reliefs and friezes , and in the second a series of delightful terraced roof gardens above an ivy-covered wall .	22.673552
the palazzo caetani , still inhabited by the caetani family , adjoins the palazzo mattei .	6.385325
keep straight ahead on the via falegnami , cross the wide via arenula , and you will come to the piazza b . cairoli , where you should look in at the church of san carlo ai catinari to see the frescoes on the ceiling .	20.923239
follow the colorful and busy via d . giubbonari for a hundred yards or so .	43.866695
now turn left at the via dell ' arco del monte to the piazza dei pellegrini .	4.5721865
just a few yards to the right on the via capo di ferro will bring you to the palazzo spada , built in 1540 and now occupied by the council of state .	14.981869
paintings by titian , caravaggio , and rubens are on display ( open 9 30 to 4 00 ) .	60.58063
before you enter the palazzo , note francesco borromini ' s facade .	4.179795
the great architect also designed the fine interior staircase and colonnade which connects the two courts .	18.80774
the large statue on the first floor is believed to be the statue of pompey at the base of which julius caesar was stabbed to death ( if so , the statue once stood in the senate house ) .	31.192453
( this is shown in the afternoon and on sunday morning .	88.78261
by tipping the porter , you can see in the courtyard borromini ' s unusual and fascinating trick in perspective .	24.173845
when you stand before the barrel-vaulted colonnade you have the impression that the statue at the end is at a considerable distance , yet it is actually only a few feet away .	28.74621
the sense of perspective has been created by designing the length of the columns so that those at the far end of the colonnade are much shorter than those in front .	45.601715
the gardens of the palazzo , shaded by a huge magnolia tree , are most attractive .	17.367277
from the palazzo spada you continue another block along the via capo di ferro and vicolo de venti to the imposing palazzo farnese , begun in 1514 and considered by many to be the finest palace of all .	18.850687
michelangelo was the most distinguished of several noted architects who helped design it .	186.12447
today it is occupied by the french embassy .	4.902542
its lovely seventeenth-century ceiling frescoes , as well as the huge guards room with a tremendously high and beautifully carved wooden ceiling , can be seen sundays ( 11 00 to 12 00 noon ) .	38.82561
ask to see the modern tapestries of paris and rome designed by lurcat .	41.372425
directly in front of the palace along the via d . baullari you will come to the campo di fiori , the famous site of executions during the turbulent days of renaissance rome .	17.108595
today , by contrast it is a lively and colorful fruit , vegetable , and flower market .	28.440693
continue on the via d . baullari to the corso vittorio emanuele , then turn right for a couple of hundred yards to the church of sant ' andrea della valle .	19.00149
as you approach the church on the via d . baullari you are passing within yards of the remains of the roman theatre of pompey , near which is believed to have been the place where julius caesar was assassinated .	40.274597
the dome of the church is , outside of st . peter ' s , one of the largest in rome .	16.843515
opera lovers will be interested to learn that this church was the scene for the first act of tosca .	32.114227
at this point you cross the wide corso vittorio emanuele 2 , , walk along the corso del rinascimento a couple of hundred yards , then turn left on the via dei canestrani to enter the splendid piazza navona , one of the truly glorious sights in rome .	15.831284
your first impression of this elongated square with its three elegant fountains , its two churches that almost face each other , and its russet-colored buildings , is a sense of restful spaciousness -- particularly welcome after wandering around the narrow and dark streets that you have followed since starting this walk .	68.10559
the site of the oblong piazza is domitian ' s ancient stadium , which was probably used for horse and chariot races .	46.205128
for centuries it was the location of historic festivals and open-air sports events .	10.422357
from the seventeenth to the nineteenth century it was a popular practice to flood the piazza in the summer , and the aristocrats would then ride around the inundated square in their carriages .	37.096497
giovanni bernini ' s `` fountain of the rivers ' ' , in the center of the piazza , is built around a roman obelisk from the circus of maxentius which rests on grottoes and rocks , with four huge figures , one at each corner , denoting four great rivers from different continents -- the danube , the ganges , the nile , and the plate .	25.179434
the eyes of the figure of the nile are covered , perhaps either to symbolize the mystery of her source or to obscure from her sight the baroque facade of the church of sant ' agnese in agone , the work of bernini ' s rival , borromini .	29.370739
in the piazza navona there are many delightful cafes where you can sit , have a drink or lunch , and watch the fountains in the square .	26.558784
the scene before you is indeed theatrical and often appears in movies about rome .	130.6822
perhaps a street musician will pass to add that extra touch .	140.06656
take the via di s . agnese in agone , next to the church and opposite the center of the square , then turn right after about two hundred yards to reach the beautiful church of santa maria della pace .	61.139095
inside you will find the lovely sibyls painted by raphael and a chapel designed by michelangelo .	13.420573
the church ' s cloisters are among donato bramante ' s most beautiful creations .	4.481214
now return to the piazza navona and leave it on the opposite side by the corsia agonale	10.517867
in a moment cross the corso del rinascimento .	6.6639333
in front of you is the palazzo madama , once belonging to the medici and now the italian senate .	34.83276
walk by the side of the palazzo and after two blocks along the via giustiniani you will come to the piazza della rotonda .	14.471527
you are now facing the pantheon , the largest and best-preserved building still standing from the days of ancient rome .	58.906532
this circular edifice , constructed by agrippa in b . c . 27 , was rebuilt in its present shape by the emperor hadrian .	13.723937
it was dedicated as a church in the seventh century .	2.4251406
as you pause in the piazza by the egyptian obelisk brought from the temple of isis , you will admire the pantheon ' s impressive corinthian columns .	7.485744
the pantheon ' s interior , still in its original form , is truly majestic and an architectural triumph .	28.634441
its rotunda forms a perfect circle whose diameter is equal to the height from the floor to the ceiling .	17.035904
the only means of interior light is the twenty-nine-foot-wide aperture in the stupendous dome .	14.107349
standing before the tomb of raphael , the great genius of the renaissance , when shafts of sunlight are penetrating this great roman temple , you are once again reminded of the varied civilizations so characteristic of rome .	53.15204
as you leave the pantheon , take the narrow street to the right , the via del seminario , a block to sant ' ignazio , one of the most splendid baroque churches in the city .	12.700596
( along the way there , about one hundred yards on your right , you pass a simple restaurant , la sacrestia , where you can have the best pizza in rome .	30.590117
) the curve of faded terra-cotta-colored houses in front of the church seems like a stage set .	79.70954
this is one of the most charming little squares in this part of rome .	19.174479
one block along the via de burro ( in front of the church ) will bring you to the stock exchange in the old temple of neptune .	31.204147
a few yards farther , on the via dei bergamaschi , is the piazza colonna .	4.174867
the great column from which the square takes its name was erected by the emperor marcus aurelius .	11.303659
you are now at the corso , though narrow , one of rome ' s busiest streets .	25.587326
horse races took place here in the middle ages .	7.817226
if you have taken this stroll in the morning , and you have the time and inclination , walk to the right along the crowded corso for half a dozen blocks to visit the fine private collection of paintings -- mainly of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries -- in the palazzo doria ( open sunday , tuesday , and thursday , 10 00 to 1 00 ) .	47.039032
here is your opportunity to see the inside of a palazzo where the family still lives .	56.760426
otherwise , cross over the corso and walk a block or so to the left .	67.080574
you will come to alemagna , a delightful , though moderately expensive restaurant , which is particularly noted for its exceptional selection of ice creams and patisseries .	49.160015
either here , or in one of the modest restaurants nearby , is just the place to end this first walk through the heart of rome .	46.941303
the second walk through the heart of rome should be taken after lunch , so that you will reach the pincian hill when the soft light of the late afternoon is at its best .	44.753166
rare , indeed , is the harlem citizen , from the most circumspect church member to the most shiftless adolescent , who does not have a long tale to tell of police incompetence , injustice , or brutality .	37.487476
i myself have witnessed and endured it more than once .	41.05218
the businessmen and racketeers also have a story .	3.4794836
( and this is not , perhaps , the place to discuss harlem ' s very complex attitude toward black policemen , nor the reasons , according to harlem , that they are nearly all downtown .	81.15806
it is hard , on the other hand , to blame the policeman , blank , good-natured , thoughtless , and insuperably innocent , for being such a perfect representative of the people he serves .	20.556126
he , too , believes in good intentions and is astounded and offended when they are not taken for the deed .	41.060875
he has never , himself , done anything for which to be hated -- which of us has ? ?	70.43556
-- and yet he is facing , daily and nightly , people who would gladly see him dead , and he knows it .	32.270542
there is no way for him not to know it there are few things under heaven more unnerving than the silent , accumulating contempt and hatred of a people .	44.44494
he moves through harlem , therefore , like an occupying soldier in a bitterly hostile country	23.342957
which is precisely what , and where , he is , and is the reason he walks in twos and threes .	20.739822
and he is not the only one who knows why he is always in company the people who are watching him know why , too .	98.314125
any street meeting , sacred or secular , which he and his colleagues uneasily cover has as its explicit or implicit burden the cruelty and injustice of the white domination .	150.73668
and these days , of course , in terms increasingly vivid and jubilant , it speaks of the end of that domination .	75.873955
the white policeman standing on a harlem street corner finds himself at the very center of the revolution now occurring in the world .	42.25227
he is not prepared for it -- naturally , nobody is -- and , what is possibly much more to the point , he is exposed , as few white people are , to the anguish of the black people around him .	51.44882
even if he is gifted with the merest mustard grain of imagination , something must seep in .	49.739567
he cannot avoid observing that some of the children , in spite of their color , remind him of children he has known and loved , perhaps even of his own children .	76.44848
he knows that he certainly does not want his children living this way .	166.64252
he can retreat from his uneasiness in only one direction into a callousness which very shortly becomes second nature .	201.17513
he becomes more callous , the population becomes more hostile , the situation grows more tense , and the police force is increased .	73.17922
one day , to everyone ' s astonishment , someone drops a match in the powder keg and everything blows up .	63.084644
before the dust has settled or the blood congealed , editorials , speeches , and civil-rights commissions are loud in the land , demanding to know what happened .	19.623734
what happened is that negroes want to be treated like men .	118.806076
negroes want to be treated like men a perfectly straightforward statement , containing only seven words .	98.88545
people who have mastered kant , hegel , shakespeare , marx , freud , and the bible find this statement utterly impenetrable .	38.5216
the idea seems to threaten profound , barely conscious assumptions .	106.564995
a kind of panic paralyzes their features , as though they found themselves trapped on the edge of a steep place .	27.02475
i once tried to describe to a very well-known american intellectual the conditions among negroes in the south .	133.56987
and he asked me in perfect innocence , `` why don ' t all the negroes in the south move north ' ' ? ?	29.17633
i tried to explain what has happened , unfailingly , whenever a significant body of negroes move north .	344.6858
they do not escape jim crow they merely encounter another , not-less-deadly variety .	151.93173
they do not move to chicago , they move to the south side	47.35858
they do not move to new york , they move to harlem .	46.60124
the pressure within the ghetto causes the ghetto walls to expand , and this expansion is always violent .	93.51824
white people hold the line as long as they can , and in as many ways as they can , from verbal intimidation to physical violence .	40.31963
but inevitably the border which has divided the ghetto from the rest of the world falls into the hands of the ghetto .	13.848319
the white people fall back bitterly before the black horde	69.23278
the landlords make a tidy profit by raising the rent , chopping up the rooms , and all but dispensing with the upkeep	16.392927
and what has once been a neighborhood turns into a `` turf ' ' .	9.329024
this is precisely what happened when the puerto ricans arrived in their thousands -- and the bitterness thus caused is , as i write , being fought out all up and down those streets .	113.88015
they seem to feel that because they fought on the right side during the civil war , and won , they have earned the right merely to deplore what is going on in the south , without taking any responsibility for it	45.31227
and that they can ignore what is happening in northern cities because what is happening in little rock or birmingham is worse .	42.849724
well , in the first place , it is not possible for anyone who has not endured both to know which is `` worse ' ' .	45.50178
i know negroes who prefer the south and white southerners , because `` at least there , you haven ' t got to play any guessing games ' ' ! !	48.53047
the guessing games referred to have driven more than one negro into the narcotics ward , the madhouse , or the river .	36.602165
i know another negro , a man very dear to me , who says , with conviction and with truth , `` the spirit of the south is the spirit of america ' ' .	38.479828
he was born in the north and did his military training in the south .	33.069485
he did not , as far as i can gather , find the south `` worse ' '	69.75765
he found it , if anything , all too familiar .	99.76192
in the second place , though , even if birmingham is worse , no doubt johannesburg , south africa , beats it by several miles , and buchenwald was one of the worst things that ever happened in the entire history of the world .	25.451847
but i do not believe that these examples are meant to be used as justification for our own crimes .	37.306454
this perpetual justification empties the heart of all human feeling .	131.56348
the emptier our hearts become , the greater will be our crimes .	50.208935
thirdly , the south is not merely an embarrassingly backward region , but a part of this country , and what happens there concerns every one of us .	40.325974
as far as the color problem is concerned , there is but one great difference between the southern white and the northerner the southerner remembers , historically and in his own psyche , a kind of eden in which he loved black people and they loved him .	32.273228
historically , the flaming sword laid across this eden is the civil war .	28.056309
personally , it is the southerner ' s sexual coming of age , when , without any warning , unbreakable taboos are set up between himself and his past .	99.64183
everything , thereafter , is permitted him except the love he remembers and has never ceased to need .	57.79173
the resulting , indescribable torment affects every southern mind and is the basis of the southern hysteria .	35.322044
none of this is true for the northerner .	11.288123
negroes represent nothing to him personally , except , perhaps , the dangers of carnality .	27.267435
northerners never think about them whereas southerners are never really thinking of anything else .	38.01167
negroes are , therefore , ignored in the north and are under surveillance in the south , and suffer hideously in both places .	45.92436
neither the southerner nor the northerner is able to look on the negro simply as a man .	50.613464
it seems to be indispensable to the national self-esteem that the negro be considered either as a kind of ward ( in which case we are told how many negroes , comparatively , bought cadillacs last year and how few , comparatively , were lynched ) , or as a victim ( in which case we are promised that he will never vote in our assemblies or go to school with our kids ) .	76.52401
they are two sides of the same coin and the south will not change -- cannot change -- until the north changes .	215.00356
the country will not change until it re-examines itself and discovers what it really means by freedom .	97.76841
in the meantime , generations keep being born , bitterness is increased by incompetence , pride , and folly , and the world shrinks around us .	22.084173
it is a terrible , an inexorable , law that one cannot deny the humanity of another without diminishing one ' s own in the face of one ' s victim , one sees oneself .	45.631603
walk through the streets of harlem and see what we , this nation , have become .	121.63165
east river , downtown postscript to a letter from harlem	46.124714
the fact that american negroes rioted in the u . n . while adlai stevenson was addressing the assembly shocked and baffled most white americans .	21.892647
stevenson ' s speech , and the spectacular disturbance in the gallery , were both touched off by the death , in katanga , the day before , of patrice lumumba .	39.65587
stevenson stated , in the course of his address , that the united states was `` against ' ' colonialism .	23.637308
god knows what the african nations , who hold 25 per cent of the voting stock in the u . n . were thinking -- they may , for example , have been thinking of the u . s . abstention when the vote on algerian freedom was before the assembly -- but i think i have a fairly accurate notion of what the negroes in the gallery were thinking .	37.053085
it was my first reaction upon hearing of lumumba ' s death .	5.680939
i was curious about the impact of this political assassination on negroes in harlem , for lumumba had -- has -- captured the popular imagination there .	164.19044
i was curious to know if lumumba ' s death , which is surely among the most sinister of recent events , would elicit from `` our ' ' side anything more than the usual , well-meaning rhetoric .	36.638496
and i was curious about the african reaction .	4.765735
however , the chaos on my desk prevented my being in the u . n . gallery .	43.37961
had i been there , i , too , in the eyes of most americans , would have been merely a pawn in the hands of the communists .	25.39729
the climate and the events of the last decade , and the steady pressure of the `` cold ' ' war , have given americans yet another means of avoiding self-examination , and so it has been decided that the riots were `` communist ' ' inspired .	35.118294
nor was it long , naturally , before prominent negroes rushed forward to assure the republic that the u . n . rioters do not represent the real feeling of the negro community .	30.295494
according , then , to what i take to be the prevailing view , these rioters were merely a handful of irresponsible , stalinist-corrupted provocateurs .	22.91715
it is a view which even a minimal effort at observation would immediately contradict .	89.34689
one has only , for example , to walk through harlem and ask oneself two questions .	63.992558
the first question is would i like to live here ? ?	40.71531
and the second question is why don ' t those who now live here move out ? ?	69.28252
the answer to both questions is immediately obvious .	8.204231
unless one takes refuge in the theory -- however disguised -- that negroes are , somehow , different from white people , i do not see how one can escape the conclusion that the negro ' s status in this country is not only a cruel injustice but a grave national liability .	59.99254
now , i do not doubt that , among the people at the u . n . that day , there were stalinist and professional revolutionists acting out of the most cynical motives .	33.843796
wherever there is great social discontent , these people are , sooner or later , to be found .	59.78373
their presence is not as frightening as the discontent which creates their opportunity .	66.809494
what i find appalling -- and really dangerous -- is the american assumption that the negro is so contented with his lot here that only the cynical agents of a foreign power can rouse him to protest .	61.35346
it is a notion which contains a gratuitous insult , implying , as it does , that negroes can make no move unless they are manipulated .	45.627186
color was delayed until 1935 , the wide screen until the early fifties .	78.12997
movement itself was the chief and often the only attraction of the primitive movies of the nineties .	24.52339
each film consisted of fifty feet , which gives a running time of about one minute on the screen .	61.012146
as long as audiences came to see the movement , there seemed little reason to adventure further .	84.48306
motion-picture exhibitions took place in stores in a general atmosphere like that of the penny arcade which can still be found in such urban areas as times square .	57.974445
brief snips of actual events were shown parades , dances , street scenes .	18.836752
the sensational and frightening enjoyed popularity a train rushes straight at the audience , or a great wave threatens to break over the seats .	26.586033
an early edison production was the execution of mary , queen of scots .	47.16849
an early film by a competitor of the wizard of menlo park simply showed a long kiss performed by two actors of the contemporary stage .	64.55319
in the field of entertainment there is no spur to financial daring so effective as audience boredom , and the first decade of the new device was not over before audiences began staying away in large numbers from the simple-minded , one-minute shows .	82.700455
in response , the industry allowed the discovery of the motion picture as a form of fiction and thus gave the movies the essential form they have had to this day .	56.562653
despite the sheer beauty and spectacle of numerous documentaries , art films , and travelogues , despite the impressive financial success of such a recent development as cinerama , the movies are at heart a form of fiction , like the play , the novel , or the short story .	29.18925
moreover , the most artistically successful of the nonfiction films have invariably borrowed the narrative form from the fiction feature .	33.292908
thus such great american documentaries as the river and the plow that broke the plains were composed as visual stories rather than as illustrated lectures .	98.83007
the discovery that movies are a form of fiction was made in the early years of this century and it was made chiefly by two men , a french magician , georges melies , and an american employee of edison , edwin s . porter .	22.471277
of the two , porter is justly the better known , for he went far beyond the vital finding of fiction for films to take the first step toward fashioning a language of film , toward making the motion picture the intricate , efficient time machine that it has remained since , even in the most inept hands .	73.625626
melies , however , out of his professional instincts as a magician , discovered and made use of a number of illusionary techniques that remain part of the vocabulary of film .	28.128658
one of these is the `` dissolve ' ' , which makes possible a visually smooth transition from scene to scene .	53.711994
as the first scene begins to fade , the succeeding scene begins to appear .	45.258007
for a moment or two , both scenes are present simultaneously , one growing weaker , one growing stronger .	127.112404
in a series of fairy tales and fantasies , melies demonstrated that the film is superbly equipped to tell a straightforward story , with beginning , middle and end , complications , resolutions , climaxes , and conclusions .	36.19067
immediately , the film improved and it improved because in narrative it found a content based on time to complement its own unbreakable connection with time .	166.17784
physically , a movie is possible because a series of images is projected one at a time at such a speed that the eye `` remembers ' ' the one that has gone before even as it registers the one now appearing .	75.1942
linking the smoothly changing images together , the eye itself endows them with the illusion of movement .	43.157127
the `` projection ' ' time of painting and sculpture is highly subjective , varying from person to person and even varying for a given person on different occasions .	62.251175
the drama in the theater and the concert in the hall both have a fixed time , but the time is fixed by the director and the players , the conductor and the instrumentalists , subject , therefore , to much variation , as record collectors well know .	79.59586
the time of the motion picture is fixed absolutely .	25.29288
the film consists of a series of still , transparent photographs , or `` frames ' ' , 35-mm . -wide .	13.206867
each frame comes between the light and the lens and is individually projected on the screen , at the rate , for silent movies , of 16 frames per second , and , for sound films , 24 frames per second .	50.91214
time is built into the motion picture , which cannot exist without time .	269.6606
now time is also the concern of the fictional narrative , which is , at its simplest , the story of an action with , usually , a beginning , a middle , and an end -- elements which demand time as the first condition for their existence .	123.30477
the `` moving ' ' picture of the train or the wave coming at the audience is , to be sure , more intense than a still picture of the same subject , but the difference is really one of degree	109.61871
the cinematic element of time is merely used to increase the realism of an object which would still be reasonably realistic in a still photo .	51.789967
in narrative , time is essential , as it is in film .	25.3874
almost everything about the movies that is peculiarly of the movies derives from a tension created and maintained between narrative time and film time .	215.24194
this discovery of melies was vastly more important than his sometimes dazzling , magician ' s tricks produced on film .	40.955887
it was porter , however , who produced the very first movie whose name has lived on through the half century of film history that has since ensued .	88.43247
the movie was the great train robbery and its effects on the young industry and art were all but incalculable .	109.469635
overnight , for one thing , porter ' s film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten .	123.55521
the great train robbery is a one-reel film .	4.4910035
one reel -- from eight to twelve minutes -- became the standard length from the year of robbery , 1903 , until griffith shattered that limit forever with birth of a nation in 1915 .	53.645844
the reel itself became and still is the standard of measure for the movies .	50.583984
the material of the porter film is simplicity itself	2563.1748
much of it has continued to be used over the years and the heart of it -- good guys and bad guys in the old west -- pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950 ' s .	54.98616
a band of robbers enters a railroad station , overpowers and ties up the telegraph operator , holds up the train and escapes .	21.671072
a posse is formed and pursues the robbers , who , having made their escape , are whooping it up with some wild , wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out .	47.773144
the robbers run from the hide-out , take cover in a wooded declivity , and are shot dead by the posse .	31.390312
as a finale is appended a close-up of one of the band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience .	79.38483
all this is simple enough , but in telling the story porter did two important things that had not been done before .	86.54048
each scene is shot straight through , as had been the universal custom , from a camera fixed in a single position , but in the outdoor scenes , especially in the capture and destruction of the outlaws , porter ' s camera position breaks , necessarily , with the camera position standard until then , which had been , roughly , that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at a play .	66.48642
the plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the plane of the film in the camera or on the screen .	32.715252
if the change , at first sight , seems minor , we may recall that it took the italian painters about two hundred years to make an analogous change , and the italian painters , by universal consent , were the most brilliant group of geniuses any art has seen .	57.218044
in that apparently simple shift porter opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of art as well as a mechanical recording device .	23.767498
he revealed the potential value of the `` cut ' ' as the basic technique in the art of the film .	24.563135
cutting , of course , takes place automatically in the creation of a film .	21.89028
the meaning of the word is quite physical , to begin with .	117.75987
the physical film is cut with a knife at the end of one complete sequence , and the cut edge is joined physically , by cement , to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence .	50.809105
if , as a home movie maker , you shoot the inevitable footage of your child taking its first steps , you have merely recorded an historical event .	61.69947
if , in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends , you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child ' s grandmother watching this event , you have begun to be an artist in film	59.186176
as the robbers leave the looted train , the film suddenly cuts back to the station , where the telegrapher ' s little daughter arrives with her father ' s dinner pail only to find him bound on the floor .	53.314377
the two events are taking place at the same time .	6.2321215
we leap from event to event -- including the formation of the posse -- even though the events , in `` reality ' ' are taking place not in sequence but simultaneously , and not near each other but at a considerable distance .	58.109646
the `` chase ' ' as a standard film device probably dates from the great train robbery , and there is a reason for the continued popularity of the device .	49.074867
it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands cutting -- both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage of the journey of both .	90.33463
the simple , naked idea of one man chasing another is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other form of fiction .	69.09163
the cowboy films , the cops and robbers films , and the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence	31.806465
these films and these sequences are also seeking out -- instinctively or by design -- the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative .	32.2839
the creator of the art of the film d . w . griffith	23.764692
there still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full potential of the new form and to make it an art .	60.472866
when he came to the movies -- more or less by accident -- they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking for an idle few minutes .	73.826225
in about seven years griffith either invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource at the disposal of the film maker .	59.658314
before he was forty griffith had created the art of the film .	8.530034
not that there had not been attempts , mostly european , to do exactly that .	181.02507
but in general the european efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly emerging language of the film itself .	46.624332
staggeringly condensed versions of famous novels and famous plays were presented .	57.24135
great actors and actresses -- the most notable being sarah bernhardt -- were hired to repeat their stage performances before the camera .	46.989037
in all of this extensive and expensive effort , the camera was downgraded to the status of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor or by the author .	61.7799
the phonograph today , for all its high fidelity and stereophonic sound , is precisely what the early art purveyors in the movies wished to make of the camera .	30.525341
not surprisingly , this approach did not work .	7.1206584
the effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques in the early years of the century and some interesting records of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names .	55.113106
but no art at all was born of the art effort in the early movies .	50.166862
in general , religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis	38.73775
congregational membership , however , is another thing .	18.57419
a congregation survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership	27.621513
that is , when it can preserve economic integration .	2.1023066
religious faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in a congregation , since the decision to join a worshiping group requires some motive force , but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining	95.58366
the presence of other members of similar social and economic level is the sufficient condition .	45.82673
the breakdown of social homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account for the decline of central city churches .	51.36277
central cities reveal two adverse features for the major denominations ( 1 ) central cities tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes	55.69218
( 2 ) central cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition .	17.498028
the central city areas , in other words , exhibit the two characteristics which violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations they have too few middle-class people	70.992256
central city areas have become progressively poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus of middle-class people from most central cities .	34.712086
with few exceptions , the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central city .	55.850067
the key to protestant development , therefore , is economic integration of the nucleus of the congregation .	14.8420515
members of higher and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus , so that protestant figures on social class give the impression of spread over all social classes	184.22035
but this is deceptive , for the core of membership is concentrated in a single social and economic stratum .	19.734728
the congregation perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the neighborhood	53.78859
moreover , residential mobility is so high in metropolitan areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum in order to survive	40.9495
they can lose higher- and lower-status members from the church without collapsing , but they need adequate recruits for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration .	20.634716
the congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group	619.9506
it is secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship .	7.12452
if it were primarily a believing fellowship , it would recruit believers from all social and economic ranks , something which most congregations of the new protestantism ( with a few notable exceptions ) have not been able to do .	28.03693
they survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers .	4.575066
the vulnerability of protestant congregations to social differences has often been attributed to the `` folksy spirit ' ' of protestant religious life	30.063784
in fact , a contrast is often drawn in this regard with the `` impersonal ' ' roman catholic parish .	29.639925
we have seen that the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers	36.101784
consequently , the vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress on personal community in protestant congregations	66.21669
actually , there is little evidence of such personal community in protestant congregations , as we shall see in another connection .	87.807945
the vulnerability of protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of the new religious style in middle-class life , where the congregation is a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform , therefore , to the principle of economic integration .	29.541498
this fact is evident in the recruitment of new members .	25.377518
the rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the missionary outreach of the major denominations .	20.152369
there is much talk in theological circles about the `` church as mission ' ' and the `` church ' s mission ' '	16.127539
theologians have been stressing the fact that the church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in the world for the healing of the world .	25.561522
a crucial question , therefore , is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan protestantism .	66.55886
if economic integration really shapes congregational life , then evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration .	37.991547
the task of a congregation would be defined , according to economic integration , as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation .	25.738531
( co-optation means to choose by joint action in order to fill a vacancy	12.198118
it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power from an environment in order to strengthen an organization .	58.185562
) in a mobile society , congregational health depends on a constant process of recruitment	37.488827
this recruitment , however , must follow the pattern of economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation	24.161133
therefore , the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation rather than proclamation -- like elements will have to be assimilated .	49.585773
evangelism and congregational outreach have not been carefully studied in the churches	55.184025
one study in pittsburgh , however , has illuminated the situation .	42.210102
in a sample of new members of pittsburgh churches , almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial `` contacts with friendly members ' ' .	33.148525
if we add to these contacts with friendly members the `` contacts with an organization of the church ' ' ( 11 . 2 per cent of the cases ) , then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment is through friendly contact .	59.78798
on the surface , this seems a sound approach to christian mission members of the congregation show by their friendly attitudes that they care for new people	77.14497
the new people respond in kind by joining the church .	8.972731
missionary outreach by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods	133.51848
the majority of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic position	35.390965
association by level of achievement is the dominant principle of informal relations .	15.028796
this means that the antennae of the congregation are extended into the community , picking up the wave lengths of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation	25.860336
the mission of the church is actually a process of informal co-optation	27.803408
the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation .	9.937646
churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people who can fit the pattern of economic integration	41.839672
once the pool of recruits diminishes , the congregation is helpless -- friendly contacts no longer keep it going .	139.79665
the transmutation of mission to co-optation is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities , worship , preaching , and publicity in reaching new members .	34.459614
the proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts by the clergy ( 17 . 3 per cent of new members ) and friendly contacts by members ( over two thirds if organizational activities are included ) .	33.631203
