publicity accounted for 1 . 1 per cent of the initial contacts with new members .	11.930806
in general , friendly contact with a member followed by contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment by the churches , making it quite evident that the extension of economic integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission in the contemporary church	51.648018
economic integration and co-optation are the two methods by which protestants associate with and recruit from the neighborhood .	124.27233
the inner life of congregations will prosper so long as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize together	36.777374
the outer life of congregations -- the suitability of the environment to their survival -- will be propitious so long as the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the membership .	53.844482
economic integration ceases when the social and economic statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of the congregation .	48.437267
in a rapidly changing society congregations will run into difficulties repeatedly , since such nice balances of economic integration are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single generation .	51.66144
the fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle to maintain economic balance .	48.19251
the expense of this type of organization in religious life , when one recalls the number of city churches which deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned , raises fundamental questions about the principle of protestant survival in a mobile society	72.80163
nonetheless , the prevalence of economic integration in congregations illumines the nature of the protestant development .	20.105028
it was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had split into two trends -- expanding interdependence on an impersonal basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings .	41.98292
these trends seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis .	7.020913
residential associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions .	4.934658
the motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential communities have polarized	264.6995
the schism between central city and suburb , negro and white , blue collar and white collar can be viewed as symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis .	15.398452
it now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved with the economy of middle-class culture , for it serves to crystallize the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings .	20.924212
the accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations .	12.844556
this conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable environment .	21.607609
more than creatures of metropolitan forces , the churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan life , crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of peoples , giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world of heterogeneous peoples .	24.573597
since american life is committed above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life , the countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have fought a desperate , rearguard action against the expanding interdependence of the metropolis .	26.925823
consumer communities have suffered at the hands of the productive interests .	18.426094
negroes , puerto ricans , and rural newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities .	105.765396
soon they will fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs , and the churches will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized their history for a century .	77.46098
the identification of the basic unit of religious organization -- the parish or congregation -- with a residential area is self-defeating in a modern metropolis , for it simply means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the christian fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation .	30.45566
mission to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential community , because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan interdependence with residential exclusion .	29.671446
this interpretation of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could lead to various projections for the churches .	40.926662
it could be argued that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the middle classes .	38.770134
it could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain religious activity , since worship presupposes some local stabilities .	49.77703
whatever projection one makes , the striking fact about congregational and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the social identity of middle-class people .	37.97269
attention will be given in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational churches	128.23178
this style is characteristically an expression of the communal style of the middle classes .	17.820026
the keynotes of this style are activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem .	56.53846
these values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman , dictating the methods of child rearing , determining the pattern of community participation , setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of middle-class illness , and informing the congregational life of the major denominations .	34.029762
`` fellowship by likeness ' ' and `` mission by friendly contact ' ' form the iron cage of denominational religion .	69.47479
its contents are another matter , for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued by the congregation .	26.0354
what goes on in the cage will occupy our attention under the rubric of the organization church .	31.168444
an understanding of the new role of residential association in an industrial society serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity .	27.01968
the perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs and charities should fill the same need .	59.174496
with capital largely squandered , there seemed to them no other course to pursue .	117.498505
the directors sold directly to concessionaires , who had to make their profits above the high prices asked by the company .	159.68744
these concessionaires traded where they wished and generally dealt with the indians through engages , who might be habitants , voyageurs , or even soldiers .	22.131311
the concessionaires also had to pay a tax of one-tenth on the goods they traded , and all pelts were to be taken to company stores and shipped to france in company ships .	52.15292
the company disposed of the pelts , but with what profit , the records do not show .	50.76307
in accord with its penurious policy , the company failed to furnish presents to hold the loyalty of the principal indians .	50.38173
the lavish use of presents had been effective in expanding the indian trade of new france and louisiana in the previous century , and the change in liberality aroused resentment in the minds of the red men .	50.91895
traders from the english colonies were far more generous , and indian loyalty turned to them .	21.144411
protests from governors and intendants passed unheeded , and the parsimonious policy of the company probably let loose indian insurrections that brought ruin to the company .	51.370403
in 1721 the king sent three commissioners to louisiana with full powers to do all that was necessary to protect the colony .	60.988964
they ordered the raising of troops and obtained 75 , 000 livres with which to build forts .	29.57917
they adopted a program by which louisiana was divided into five districts .	38.577103
in each of these there was to be a strong military post , and a trading depot to supply the smaller trading houses .	62.879368
for southeastern louisiana , mobile was the principal post , and it was to furnish supplies for trade to the north and east , in the region threatened by british traders .	35.446697
mobile was to be the anchor of a chain of posts extending northward to the sources of the tennessee river .	13.697218
fort toulouse , on the alabama river , had been erected in 1714 for trade with the alabamas and choctaws , but money was available for only one other new post , near the present nashville , tennessee , and this was soon abandoned .	42.697876
west of the mobile district was the lower mississippi district , of which new orleans was headquarters .	65.75301
dependent upon it were posts on the lower mississippi and the region westward to the frontiers of new spain .	16.848135
on the middle mississippi a principal post was to be located near the mouth of the arkansas .	21.284803
it was hoped that to this post would flow a large quantity of furs from the west , principally down the arkansas river .	46.719048
on the ohio or wabash was to be built another post `` at the fork of two great rivers ' ' .	35.71357
other posts would be established up the ohio and wabash to protect communication with canada .	71.09507
on the upper mississippi the illinois post was to be established near kaskaskia , and dependent posts were to be built on the missouri , `` where there are mines in abundance ' ' .	27.522205
each of the five principal posts was to have a director , responsible to a director-general at new orleans .	23.238367
an elaborate system of accounting and reports was worked out , and the trade was to be managed in the most scientific way .	32.838127
concessionaires were to be under the supervision of the directors .	14.450909
engages must be loyal to the concessionaires , and must serve until the term provided in the engagement was ended .	84.509094
the habitants were to be encouraged to trade and were to dispose of their pelts to the concessionaires .	13.7642975
only two principal storehouses were actually established -- one at mobile , the other at new orleans .	67.890625
new orleans supplied the goods for the trade on the mississippi , and west of that river , and on the ohio and wabash .	40.19241
mobile was also supplied by new orleans with goods for the mobile district .	33.011517
the power that bienville exercised during his first administration cannot be determined .	50.421505
regulations for the indian trade were made by the conseil superieure de la louisiane , and bienville apparently did not have control of that body .	39.62369
the conseil even treated the serious matter of british aggression as its business and , on its own authority , sent to disaffected savages merchandise `` suitable for the peltry trade ' ' .	52.24326
it decided , also , that the purely secular efforts of bienville were insufficient , and sent missionaries to win the savages from the heathen carolinians .	18.382544
during the first administration of bienville , the peltry trade of the mobile district was a lucrative source of revenue .	16.92191
the alabamas brought in annually 15 , 000 to 20 , 000 deerskins , and the choctaws and chickasaws brought the total up to 50 , 000 pelts .	23.091244
these deerskins were the raw material for the manufacture of leather , and were the only articles which the tribes of this district had to exchange for european goods .	88.98265
during his first administration , bienville succeeded in keeping carolina traders out of the alabama country and the choctaw country .	17.233912
the director of the post at mobile kept an adequate amount of french goods , of a kind to which they were accustomed , to supply the indian needs .	68.94629
the alabama and tombigbee rivers furnished a highway by which goods could be moved quickly and cheaply .	75.0312
de la laude , commander of the alabama post , had the friendship of the natives , and was able to make them look upon the british as poor competitors .	46.66608
diron d ' artaguette , the most prominent trader in the district , was energetic and resourceful , but his methods often aroused the ire of the french governors .	27.056805
he became , after a time , commander of a post on the alabama river , but his operations extended from mobile throughout the district , and he finally obtained a monopoly of the indian trade .	25.467155
the chickasaws were the principal source of trouble in the mobile district .	17.78166
their territory lay to the north , near the sources of the alabama , the tombigbee , the tennessee , and cumberland rivers , and was easily accessible to traders among the near-by cherokees .	12.906089
in 1720 some chickasaws massacred the french traders among them , and did not make peace for four years .	54.56612
venturesome traders , however , continued to come to them from mobile , and to obtain a considerable number of pelts for the french markets .	27.589708
british traders from south carolina incited the indians against the french , and there developed french and british factions in the tribe .	35.57652
the chickasaws finally were the occasion for the most disastrous wars during the french control of louisiana .	106.40083
to hold them was an essential part of french policy , for they controlled the upper termini of the routes from the north to mobile .	46.844234
they threatened constantly to give the british a hold on this region , from whence they could move easily down the rivers to the french settlements near the gulf .	80.4661
bienville realized that if the french were to hold the southeastern tribes against the enticements of british goods , french traders must be able to offer a supply as abundant as the carolinians and at reasonable prices .	23.381762
the company of the indies promised to send over a supply of indian trading goods , and to price them more cheaply in terms of deerskins .	23.464003
but it coupled with this a requirement that indians must bring their pelts to mobile and thus save all costs of transportation into and out of the indian country .	86.72137
the insistence of bienville upon giving liberal prices to the indians , in order to drive back the carolina traders , was probably a factor that led to his recall in 1724 .	42.44028
for two years his friend and cousin , boisbriant , remained as acting governor and could do little to stem the anglican advance .	194.02356
although he incited a few friendly indians to pillage the invaders , and even kill some of them , the carolina advance continued .	42.56154
the company was impressed with some ideas of the danger from carolina , and when perier came over as governor in 1727 , he was given special instructions regarding the trade of the mobile district .	29.503351
but the company of the indies , holding to its program of economy , made no arrangements to furnish better goods at attractive prices .	103.79442
to the directors the problem appeared a matter of intrigue or diplomacy .	19.27035
perier attempted to understand the problem by sending agents to inquire among the indians .	59.112366
these agents were to ascertain the difference between english and french goods , and the prices charged the indians .	35.280937
they were to conciliate the unfriendly savages , and , wherever possible , to incite the natives to pillage the traders from carolina .	18.232616
they were to promise fine presents to the loyal red men , as well as an abundant supply of trading goods at better prices than the opposition was offering .	53.184868
one was british and the other , french .	31.468407
so hostile did these factions become that , among the choctaws , civil war broke out .	29.039532
perier ' s efforts , however , were on the whole ineffective in winning back the tribes of the mobile district , and he decided to send troops into the troubled country .	39.240417
he asked the government for two hundred soldiers , who were to be specifically assigned to arrest english traders and disloyal indians .	38.718838
in spite of the company ' s restrictions , he planned to build new posts in the territory .	38.600536
he asked also for more supplies to trade at a low price for the indians ' pelts .	35.034023
no help came from the crown , and perier , in desperation , gave a monopoly of the indian trade in the district to d ' artaguette .	25.625996
d ' artaguette went vigorously to work , and gave credit to many hunters .	157.97173
but they brought back few pelts to pay their debts , and soon french trade in the region was at an end .	39.857548
perier finally , in one last bid in 1730 , cut the price of goods to an advance of 40 per cent above the cost in france .	21.396149
the indians were not impressed and held to the carolina traders , who swarmed over the country , almost to the mississippi .	23.754921
with the loss of the mobile trade , which ended all profits from louisiana , the natchez indians revolted .	18.882765
they destroyed a trading house and pillaged the goods , and harassed french shipping on the mississippi .	17.036627
the war to subdue them taxed the resources of the colony and piled up enormous debts .	15.875846
in january , 1731 , the company asked the crown to relieve it of the government of the colony .	17.281965
it stated that it had lost 20 , 000 , 000 livres in its operations , and apparently blamed its poor success largely on the indian trade .	32.928623
it offered to surrender its right to exclusive trade , but asked an indemnity .	47.996292
the king accepted the surrender and fixed the compensation of the company at 1 , 450 , 000 livres .	13.0497465
thenceforth , the commerce of louisiana was free to all frenchmen .	22.943342
company rule in louisiana left the colony without fortifications , arms , munitions , or supplies .	9.917124
the difficulties of trade had ruined many voyageurs , and numbers of them had gone to live with the natives and rear half-blood families .	50.962536
others left the country , and there was no one familiar with the indian trade .	33.869076
if this trade should be resumed , the habitants who had come to be farmers or artisans , and soldiers discharged from the army , must be hardened to the severe life of coureurs de bois .	30.704006
this was a slow and difficult course , and french trade suffered from the many mistakes of the new group of traders .	61.063313
perier and salmon , the intendant , wished either to entrust the trade to an association of merchants or to have the crown furnish goods on credit to individuals who would repay their debts with pelts .	45.75154
bienville , who returned to succeed perier in 1732 , objected that the merchants would not accept the responsibility of managing a trade in which they could see no hope of profits .	36.50187
he reported , too , that among the habitants there were none of probity and ability sufficient to justify entrusting them with the king ' s goods .	17.625578
he did find some to trust , however , and he employed the king ' s soldiers to trade .	21.695204
with no company to interfere , he kept close control over all the traders .	54.854122
in order to compete with english traders , bienville radically changed the price schedule .	91.28192
the king should expect no profit , and an advance of only 20 per cent above the cost in france , which would cover the expense of transportation and handling , was all he charged the traders .	64.541405
they would not be pleased to have it published back home that they planned a frolic in paris or hong kong at the treasury ' s expense .	52.601456
they would be particularly displeased with the state department if it were the source of such reports .	35.317505
few things are more perilous for the state department than a displeased congressman .	27.453026
the reason for this bears explaining for those who may wonder why state spends so much of its diplomatic energy on congress when the russians are so available .	73.37895
first , the state department is unique among government agencies for its lack of public supporters .	88.85393
the farmers may be aroused if congress cuts into the agriculture department ' s budget .	14.028713
businessmen will rise if congress attacks the commerce department .	24.227251
the chamber of commerce , assaults upon the treasury .	13.089393
a kaleidoscope of pressure groups make it unpleasant for the congressman who becomes ugly toward the department of health , education , and welfare .	36.65106
the congressman ' s patriotism is always involved when he turns upon the defense department .	42.02709
tampering with the post office may infuriate every voter who can write .	20.398678
with all these agencies , the congressman must constantly check the political wind and trim his sails accordingly .	110.1829
no such political restraint subdues his blood when he gazes upon the state department in anger .	33.490208
in many sections he may even reap applause from press and public for giving it a good lesson .	83.804985
after all , the money dispensed by state goes not to the farmer , the laborer , or the businessman , but to foreigners .	37.65104
not only do these foreigners not vote for american congressmen	176.76082
they are also probably ungrateful for uncle ' s sam ' s bounty .	11.05068
and are not the state department men who dispense this largesse merely crackpots and do-gooders who have never met a payroll ? ?	50.92746
will not the righteous congressman be cheered at the polls if he reminds them to get right with america and if he saves the taxpayer some money by spoiling a few of their schemes ? ?	42.90814
the result is that the state department ' s perpetual position before congress is the resigned pose of the whipping boy who expects to be kicked whenever the master has had a dyspeptic outing with his wife .	39.419228
people in this position do not offend the master by relating his peccadilloes to the newspapers .	32.04757
the department expects and receives no thanks from congress for its discretion .	36.670807
state is expected to arrange the touring cicero ' s foreign itinerary	16.784262
its embassies are expected to supply him with reams of local money to pay his way	60.910202
embassy workers are expected to entertain him according to his whim , frequently with their savings for the children ' s college tuition .	33.939995
but come the next session of congress , state can expect only that its summer guest will bite its hand when it goes to the capitol asking money for diplomatic entertaining expenses abroad or for living expenses for its diplomats .	158.90408
the congressman who , in paris , may have stuffed his wallet with enough franc notes to paper the roof of notre-dame will systematically scream that a $200 increase in entertainment allowance for a second secretary is tantamount to debauchery of the treasury .	37.15995
in the matter of money state ' s most unrelenting watchdog during the eisenhower years was representative john j . rooney , of brooklyn , who controlled the purse for diplomatic administrative expenses .	33.89555
diplomats stayed up nights thinking of ways to attain peaceful coexistence , not with nikita khrushchev , but with john rooney .	45.804497
in the most confidential whispers ambassadors told of techniques they had tried to bring rooney around -- friendly persuasion , groveling abasement , pressure subtly exerted through other powerful congressmen , tales of heartbreak and penury among a threadbare diplomatic corps .	50.278763
`` the trouble , ' ' explained loy henderson , then deputy undersecretary for administration , `` is that when we get into an argument with him about this thing , it always turns out that rooney knows more about our budget than we do ' ' .	62.80362
one year the department collected a file of case histories to document its argument that men in the field were paying the government ' s entertainment bills out of personal income .	81.69756
next day , reports went through the department that rooney had been outraged by what he considered a patent attempt to put public pressure on him for increased entertainment allowances and had sworn an oath that , that year , expense allowances would not rise a dollar .	99.314575
the department ' s constant fight with the house for money is a polite minuet compared with its periodic bloody engagements with the senate .	60.754234
armed with constitutional power to negate the executive ' s foreign policy , the senate carries a big stick and is easily provoked to use it on the state department ' s back , or on the head of the secretary of state .	35.369194
with its power to investigate , the senate can paralyze the secretary by keeping him in a state of perpetual testimony before committees , as it did with dean acheson .	43.11431
john foster dulles escaped by keeping his personal show on the road and because lyndon johnson , who was then operating the senate , refused to let it become an inquisition .	50.042896
during dulles ' s first two years in office , while republicans ran the senate , the department was at the mercy of men who had thirsted for its blood since 1945 .	44.10236
an internal police operation managed by scott mcleod , a former f . b . i . man installed as security officer upon congressional insistence , was part of the vengeance .	52.24883
so was the attack upon charles e . bohlen when eisenhower appointed him ambassador to moscow .	88.37914
the principal mauler , however , was senator joseph mccarthy .	8.206999
where acheson had fought a gallant losing battle for the department , dulles fed the crocodile with his subordinates .	39.282627
fretting privately but eschewing public defense of his terrorized bureaucrats , dulles remained serene and detached while the hatchet men had their way .	38.3198
in view of eisenhower ' s reluctance to concede that anything was amiss in the terror , it is doubtful that heroic intervention by dulles could have produced anything but disaster for him and the country ' s foreign policy .	28.107037
in any event , the example of acheson ' s trampling by the senate did not encourage dulles to provoke it .	16.413828
he elected to `` get along ' ' .	3.0966954
during this dark chapter in state department history , men who had offered foreign-policy ideas later proven wrong by events filled the tumbrels sent up to capitol hill .	92.042786
their old errors of judgment were equated , in the curious logic of the time , with present treasonous intent .	35.01409
their successors , absorbing the lesson , made it a point to have few ideas .	106.695305
this , in turn , brought a new fashion in senatorial criticism as the democrats took control .	150.01654
in the new style , the department was berated as intellectually barren and unable to produce the vital ideas needed to outwit the russians .	31.268812
for three or four years in the mid-1950 ' s , this complaint was heard rumbling up from the senate floor whenever there was a dull legislative afternoon .	19.901606
it became smart to say that the fault was with dulles because he would not countenance thinking done by anyone but himself .	96.76369
an equally tenable thesis is that the dearth of new thought was created by the senate ' s own penchant for crucifying anyone whose ideas seem unorthodox to the next generation .	34.16892
there are ninety-eight foreign embassies and legations in washington .	28.172995
they range from the soviet embassy on sixteenth street , a gray shuttered pile suggesting a funeral-accessories display house , to what congressman rooney has called `` that monstrosity on thirty-fourth street ' ' , the modern cement-and-glass chancery of the belgians .	21.362787
here is the world of the chauffeured limousine and the gossip reporter , of caviar on stale crackers and the warm martini , of the poseur , the spy , the party crasher , and the patriot , of the rented tails , the double cross , and the tired lothario .	16.283783
into its chanceries each day pour reports from ministries around the earth and an endless stream of home-office instructions on how to handle uncle sam in an infinite variety of contingencies .	43.327904
here are hatched plans for getting a share of the american bounty , the secret of the anti-missile missile , or an invitation to dinner .	15.90701
out of it each week go hundreds of thousands of words purporting to inform home ministries about what is really happening inside washington .	77.11397
some , like the british and the french , maintain an elaborate system of personal contacts and have experts constantly studying special areas of the american scene .	66.55189
other embassies cable home the new york times without changing a comma .	39.551373
the soviet embassy is popularly regarded as russian espionage headquarters .	27.72406
when ambassador mikhail menshikov took it over in 1957 from georgi zaroubin , he made a determined effort to change this idea .	48.706024
menshikov hit washington with a tv announcer ' s grin and a hearty handclasp .	7.019179
to everyone ' s astonishment he seemed no more like the run-of-the-mine russian ambassador than george babbitt was like fyodor pavlovitch karamazov .	53.152443
where his predecessors had glowered , menshikov smiled .	49.59971
where they had affected the bleak social style of embalmers ' assistants , menshikov went abroad gorgeous in white tie and tails .	25.796188
overnight he became the most available man in washington .	20.683199
speeches by the soviet ambassador became the vogue as he obliged rural maryland rotarians and national press club alike .	86.94869
in senator joseph mccarthy ' s phrase , it was the most unheard-of thing ever heard of .	44.890285
a newspaperman who met him at a reception swore that he asked menshikov `` what should we call you ' ' ? ?	18.59314
and that menshikov replied `` just call me mike ' ' .	12.561607
`` smilin ' mike ' ' was the sobriquet washington gave him .	231.47554
his english was usable and he used it fearlessly .	3.5437596
toasting in champagne one night at the embassy , he hoisted his glass to a senator ' s wife and gaily cried `` up your bottom ' ' ! !	23.005096
for a few giddy months that coincided with one of moscow ' s smiling moods , he was the sensation of washington .	13.84918
at the state department , hard-bitten russian experts complained that the capitol was out of its wits .	26.685524
newspaper punditry was inspired to remind everyone that judas , too , had been able to smile .	21.984758
the menshikov interlude ended as larks with the russians usually end .	474.41757
finding peaceful coexistence temporarily unsuitable because of domestic politics , moscow resumed scowling and `` smilin ' mike ' ' dropped quietly out of the press except for an occasional story reporting that he had been stoned somewhere in the middle west .	28.303179
the most inscrutable embassies are the arabs ' , and the most inscrutable of the arabs are the saudi arabians .	12.239162
when king saud visited washington , the overwhelming question consuming the press was the size of his family .	142.34502
rumor had it that his children numbered in the hundreds .	41.269848
the state department was little help on this , or on much else about saudi arabia .	60.13138
a reporter who consulted a middle east information officer for routine vital statistics got nowhere until the state department man produced from his bottom desk drawer a brochure published by the arabian-american oil company .	55.000637
`` this is where i get my information from ' ' , he confided .	63.41199
it ' s the only copy i ' ve got ' ' .	5.627185
the size of saud ' s family was still being debated when the king appeared for his first meeting with eisenhower .	43.673584
when it ended , a dusky sheik in desert robes flowed into hagerty ' s office to report on the interview .	9.625832
the massed reporters brushed aside the customary bromides about saudi-american friendship to bore in on the central question .	83.66907
how many children did the king have ? ?	1.1803676
`` twenty-one ' ' , replied the sheik .	34.44945
and how many of these were sons ? ?	1.0117323
`` twenty-five ' ' , the sheik replied .	7.1457033
`` do you mean to tell us ' ' , a reporter asked , `` that the king has twenty-one children , twenty-five of whom are sons ' ' ? ?	14.130589
the sheik smiled and murmured `` that is precisely correct ' ' .	43.45483
the egyptians are noted for elusiveness of language .	6.806885
when dag hammarskjold was negotiating the middle east peace after israel ' s 1956 invasion of egypt , he soon found himself speaking the mysterious phrases of cairo , a language as anarchic as casey stengel ' s .	36.612988
the reports of president nasser ' s pledges which hammarskjold was relaying from cairo to washington became increasingly incomprehensible to other diplomats , including the israeli foreign minister , mrs . golda meir .	12.958437
finally he reported that nasser was ready to make a concrete commitment in return for israeli concessions .	52.62421
the deep water is used by many people , but it is always clean , for the washing is done outside .	34.298058
i know now why our japanese friends were surprised when they walked into our bathroom .	62.63838
of course , most toilets are eastern style -- at floor level -- but even when they are raised to chair height , they are actually outside toilets -- inside .	88.924324
a few newer homes have western flush toilets , but even with running water , they are usually eastern style .	67.47986
the next day i visited international christian college which has developed since the war under the leadership of people who were interned and who know japan well .	81.55231
they are trying to demonstrate some different ways of teaching and learning .	60.16537
the library has open shelves even in the unbound periodical stockroom .	5.6175933
spiritual life is cultivated , but students do not need to be christian .	26.082499
they have an enviable record of being able to place in employment 100% of their graduates .	85.84499
in the afternoon miss hosaka and her mother invited me to go with them and young mrs . kodama to see the famous spring dances of the geisha dancers .	42.03826
mrs . hosaka is one of the japanese women one reads about -- beautiful , artistically talented , an artful manager of her big household -- ( four boys and four girls ) , and yet looking like a pampered , gentle japanese woman .	58.189255
the dances were as beautiful as anything i have ever seen -- they rival the new york rockettes for scenery and precision as well as imagination .	42.923878
because don was leaving the next day , i spent the evening with him at asia center .	70.02152
the following morning mr . morikawa called for me , and we went to visit schools -- kindergarten , middle-school , elementary school , and high school -- mr . yoshimoto ' s school .	26.918385
there is much more freedom in the schools here than i expected -- some think too much .	356.19412
there is a great deal of thought being given to the question of moral education in the schools .	26.514116
with the loss of the emperor diety in japan , the people are left in confusion with no god or moral teachings that have strength .	76.95914
the older parents continued to teach their children traditional principles , but the younger people , who have lost all faith and convictions , are now parents .	63.937897
there seems to be no purpose in life that is sure -- no certain guiding principles to give stability .	84.83038
as a result , money is spent quickly and freely , with no thought of its value .	78.916405
the government has recognized the dilemma and is beginning to devise some moral education for the schools -- but the teachers often have no firm conviction and are confused .	88.59087
i was told that it is quite likely that japanese soldiers would not fight again -- for why should they ? ?	80.43438
it will be painful , but interesting , to see what kind of a god these people will create or what strong convictions they will develop .	178.55913
in the evening the former oregon state science teachers met for dinner at the new tokyo restaurant where i had my first raw fish and found it good .	69.490326
they suggested several new foods , and usually i found them good , except the sweets , which i think i could learn to like .	62.25889
six of the science teachers were present , and we had great fun .	57.81003
after a day at nikko , mrs . kodama put me on the train for kyoto .	22.95173
my instructions were that mr . nishimo would meet me at the hotel , but instead he and three others were at the station with a very warm welcome .	62.77997
my hotel rooms on the trip were arranged by masu and the japan travel bureau and were more elegant than i would have chosen , but it was fun for once to be elegant -- i did explain to the students , however , that this was not my usual style , for their salaries are very small , and it seemed out of place for me to be housed so well .	60.051006
they understood and teased me a bit about it .	9.452861
i think i would have been much disappointed in japan if i had not seen kyoto , nara , and hiroshima .	31.359755
kyoto is the ancient capital of japan and still its cultural center .	132.76147
it , along with nara , was untouched by the war -- and is now a beautiful example of the loveliness of prewar japan .	20.794344
here i was accompanied by mrs . okamoto ( fumio ' s mother ) , her son , mr . washizu ( a prospective student with whom i have been corresponding for more than a year ) , and mr . nishima , one of the science teachers .	35.475433
i arrived at 7 00 a . m . and by 9 00 a . m . i had finished breakfast and was on my way to see what they had planned .	48.911495
we walked miles and saw various shrines and gardens .	16.479486
we visited the okamoto home -- where for the first time i saw the famous tea ceremony .	21.333456
at 6 00 p . m . we went to the kyoto spring dances at the place where these beautiful dances originated .	54.396305
they were even better than those of tokyo -- more spectacular and more imaginative .	54.894913
after a supper of unagi ( rice with eel -- eel which is raised in an ice-cold pond at the foot of mt . fuji ) , i returned to my beautiful room to sleep as hard as possible to be ready for another busy day .	28.573317
we started at 9 a . m . to visit the kyoto university where mr . washizu is attending .	18.979767
i was amazed at the very poor hospital facilities accompanying the medical school .	98.67764
they apologized for the condition , including dirt and flies , and i was a little at a loss to know what to say .	51.05028
i don ' t have the answer yet .	9.292464
we had tea at mr . washizu ' s home where i learned that he , too , comes from a very wealthy family .	39.122276
and he , being the eldest , was supposed to be a priest , but he chose to do differently , and one of his brothers is to become the priest .	27.436739
this is a significant fact in japan , for only a few years ago he would have had no choice .	33.464092
in his big home live four families and thirty people , so it needs to be big .	116.36824
also , there are housed here some priceless historical treasures from 400 to 600 years old -- paintings , lacquer , brocade , etc . .	15.244672
he had displayed more of them than usual so that i could enjoy them .	57.91794
about 100 of the most important items he had already given to the museum .	21.329126
the house itself is 400 years old with all the craftsmanship of older , less-hurried times .	54.574383
mr . nishima went with me on the train to nara .	18.090693
we passed his house and school on the way .	54.228302
in nara i stayed at the hotel where the prince and princess had stayed on their honeymoon .	14.365085
a new red carpet had been laid for their coming , but i walked on it , too .	61.975315
here mr . yoneda met us after a three-hour train trip from the town where he teaches .	19.14615
even though we had walked miles in kyoto that day , we started out again to see nara at night .	37.465527
in the evening both of the men went with me on the train 30 miles to osaka to put me on the train for hiroshima .	51.11245
again the plan was for me to go alone , but they wouldn ' t let me .	22.64683
at osaka , mr . yoneda had to leave us to get the train to his home , but mr . nishima and i had an hour and a half before train time to see osaka at night .	66.48965
it is the second largest city in japan , with about four million people .	76.12923
one spot in osaka i shall always remember -- the bridge where we stood to watch the reflections of the elaborate neon signs in the still waters of the river .	47.89602
in the midst of a great busy city , people take time to enjoy the beauty of natural reflection of artificial light .	101.64295
my train arrived in hiroshima at the awful hour of 4 45 a . m . .	18.507265
i had planned to go to the hotel by taxi and sleep a little , after which mr . uno would arrive and pilot me around .	88.22092
but there he was at the train with an oregon state pennant in his hand .	69.78463
i know now why the students insisted that i go to hiroshima even when i told them i didn ' t want to .	42.59753
they knew that i was still grieving over the tragic event , and they felt that if i could see the recovery and the spirit of the people , who hold no grudge , but who also regret pearl harbor , i would be happier and would understand better a new japan .	46.478176
there were no words to say this but there was no need .	24.783205
the teachers of mr . uno ' s school gave me a small gift to thank me for coming .	58.793
hiroshima is a better city than it was before -- in the minds of the people i met was a strong determination for peace and understanding .	49.66509
i was grateful for their insight into my need for this experience .	41.72769
a better world may yet come out of hiroshima .	78.67286
on arriving in tokyo later we were met by masu who took us immediately to her university , the japanese women ' s university .	39.962894
this day was `` open house for parents ' ' day , and the girls were busy preparing exhibits and arranging tea tables .	44.39866
everything was in an exciting turmoil -- full of anticipation and fun .	83.75146
it was thrilling to see the effect of an american-trained teacher on japanese students in a class in home planning .	34.529945
our masu is one of the very few architects in japan who is trying to plan homes around family functions and women ' s needs .	96.28855
i am told the time will soon come when women will find it necessary to do most of their own work , and even now it is important to have conveniences for the use of servants .	53.263138
many of the features of the homes are the latest modern devices in american homes , but an interesting blend of cultures finds us using japanese artfulness in our own western architecture at the same time that the japanese are adopting western utility patterns .	52.260166
at this women ' s university we find a monument to a courageous family who believed that japanese women also should be educated .	64.274025
even today there are some doubts about the value of education for japanese women , but this university continues to grow and to send its students out into the community .	60.429657
active alumnae have built a fine building on the campus where members can come and stay for a few days or longer and where they can have their social gatherings and professional meetings .	54.064957
as far as i am concerned there is continuous piling up of evidence that the creative fresh ideas which are needed in the world are going to be found by educated women unafraid to break traditions .	52.807266
masu is also teaching in a municipally-sponsored school for japanese widows in tokyo .	28.906097
here the women learn to keep house as maids	287.70822
they become skilled in cooking and cleaning and in receiving guests .	95.02025
they learn how to take care of children and sick members of the family .	36.00693
they have model kitchens , a sick room with a model patient in bed , and a nursery with a life-like doll .	17.232962
although the training is only for one month , it is intensive and thorough .	20.122631
graduates of this maid ' s school are much in demand and can always find work immediately .	228.01674
masu ' s home economics training comes into play as she designs cupboards along modern functional lines for the storage of cleaning materials .	205.33252
masu also uses the training she got in an american home where she learned to polish furniture , clean corners , and work effectively in keeping a shiny house .	43.411743
her education in the united states , not just in a classroom , but also in an american house with an american housekeeper , stands her in good stead .	49.675713
after a fine luncheon in the cafeteria , the kitchen of which masu had planned , mr . washizu and i left to meet representatives of the usis for a visit to the university of tokyo .	40.40037
here again it was vacation time and there were many things i could not see , but i was able to visit with a professor who is famous in japanese circles and be guided through the grounds by his assistant .	61.827934
the achievement of the desegregation of certain lunch counters not only by wise action by local community leaders but by voluntary action following consultation between attorney general rogers and the heads of certain national chain stores should , of course , be applauded .	71.00516
but for it to be just to attain this same result by means of the force of a boycott throughout the nation would require the verification of facts contrary to those assumed in the foregoing case .	70.722
the suppositions in the previous illustration might be sufficiently altered by establishing a connection between general company practice and local practice in the south , and by establishing such direct connection between the practice and the economic well-being of stores located in new york and general company policy .	90.6731
then the boycott would not be secondary , but a primary one .	87.758385
it would be directed against the actual location of the unjust policy which , for love ' s sake and for the sake of justice , must be removed , and , indivisible from this , to the economic injury of the people directly and objectively a part of this policy .	35.13753
perhaps this would be sufficient to justify an economic boycott of an entire national chain in order , by threatening potential injury to its entire economy , to effect an alteration of the policy of its local stores in the matter of segregation .	45.243507
such a general boycott might still be a blunt or indiscriminating instrument , and therefore of questionable justification .	48.52079
action located where the evil is concentrated will prove most decisive and is most clearly legitimate .	81.20289
moreover , prudence alone would indicate that , unless the local customs are already ready to fall when pushed , the results of direct economic action everywhere upon national chain stores will likely be simply to give undue advantage to local and state stores which conform to these customs , leading to greater decentralization and local autonomy within the company , or even ( as the final self-defeat of an unjust application of economic pressure to correct injustice ) to its going out of business in certain sections of the country ( as , for that matter , the quakers , who once had many meetings in the pre-civil war south , largely went out of business in that part of the country over the slavery issue , never to recover a large number of southern adherents ) .	65.07382
in any case , anyone who fails to make significant distinction between primary and secondary applications of economic pressure would in principle already have justified that use of economic boycott as a means which broke out a few years ago or was skillfully organized by white citizens ' councils in the entire state of mississippi against every local philco dealer in that state , in protest against a philco-sponsored program over a national tv network on which was presented a drama showing , it seemed , a `` high yellow gal ' ' smooching with a white man .	89.69955
it is true , of course , that the end or objective of this action was different .	70.66007
but since this is a world in which people disagree about ends and goals and concerning justice and injustice , and since , in a situation where direct action and economic pressure are called for , the justice of the matter has either not been clearly defined by law or the law is not effectively present , there has to be a morality of means applied in every case in which people take it upon themselves to use economic pressures or other forms of force .	121.56787
the need that we not give unqualified approval to any but a limited use of economic pressure directed against the actual doers of injustice is clear also in light of the fact that white citizens ' councils seem resolved to maintain segregation mainly by the use of these same means and not ordinarily by physical violence .	85.358284
an unlimited use of economic pressures for diametrically opposite causes could devastate the pre-conditions of any fellow humanity as surely as this would be destroyed by the use of more obviously brutal means .	58.536537
the end or aim of the action , of course , is also important , especially where it is not alone a matter of changing community customs but of the use of deadly economic power to intimidate a person from stepping forward to claim his legal rights , e . g . , against negroes who register to vote in fayette county , tennessee , at the present moment .	44.44436
here the recourse is in steps to give economic sustenance to those being despoiled , and to legal remedies .	45.57438
this , however , is sufficient to show that more or less non-violent resistance and economic conflict ( if both sides are strong enough ) can be war of all against all no less than if other means are used .	75.09927
it is also sufficient to show the christian and any other champion of justice that he needs to make sure not only that his cause is just but also that his conduct is just , i . e . , that , if economic pressure has to be resorted to , this be applied directly against those persons directly in the way of some salutary change in business or institutional practices , while , if injury fall upon others , it fall upon them indirectly and secondarily ( however inevitably ) and not by deliberate intent and direct action against them .	81.55285
it is clear that non-violent resistance is a mode of action in need of justification and limitation in christian morality , like any other form of resistance .	40.94518
the language used itself often makes very clear that this is only another form of struggle for victory ( perhaps to be chosen above all others ) .	69.90723
one of the sit-in leaders has said `` nobody from the top of heaven to the bottom of hell can stop the march to freedom .	83.03046
everybody in the world today might as well make up their minds to march with freedom or freedom is going to march over them ' ' .	108.26049
the present writer certainly agrees with that statement , and would also affirm this -- in the order of justice .	49.047836
however , it is also a christian insight to know that unless charity interpenetrates justice it is not likely to be freedom that marches forward .	43.41596
and when charity interpenetrates man ' s struggle for justice and freedom it does not simply surround this with a sentimental good will .	119.61621
it also definitely fashions conduct in the way explained above , and this means far more than in the choice of non-violent means .	55.34047
r . b . gregg has written that `` non-violence and good will of the victim act like the lack of physical opposition by the user of physical jiu-jitsu , to cause the attacker to lose his moral balance .	60.803993
he suddenly and unexpectedly loses the moral support which the usual violent resistance of most victims would render him ' '	21.809492
and again , that `` the object of non-violent resistance is partly analogous to this object of war -- namely , to demoralize the opponent , to break his will , to destroy his confidence , enthusiasm , and hope .	37.502274
in another respect it is dissimilar , for non-violent resistance demoralizes the opponent only to re-establish in him a new morale that is firmer because it is based on sounder values ' ' .	25.174372
a trial of strength , however , is made quite inevitable by virtue of the fact that anyone engaging in non-violent resistance will be convinced that his action is based on sounder values than those of his opponent	53.458042
and in warfare with any means , men commonly disagree over the justice of the cause .	62.851074
this makes necessary a morality of means , and principles governing the conduct of resistance whenever this is thought to be justified .	58.902576
the question , then , is whether sufficient discrimination in the use of even non-violent means of coercion is to be found in the fact that such conduct demoralizes and overcomes the opponent while re-moralizing and re-establishing him .	21.815878
here it is relevant to remember that men commonly regard some causes as more important than their lives	135.80908
and to them it will seem insignificant that it is proposed to defeat such causes non-violently .	61.498386
a technique by which it is proposed to enter with compulsion into the very heart of a man and determine his values may often in fact seem the more unlimited aggression .	135.6612
among christian groups , the mennonites have commonly been aware more than others of the fact that the nature of divine charity raises decisively the question of the christian use of all forms of pressure .	36.9668
since the will and word of god are for them concentrated in christ-like love , it seems clear to them that non-violent resistance is quite another thing .	35.329945
`` the primary objective of non-violence ' ' , writes the outstanding mennonite ethicist , `` is not peace , or obedience to the divine will , but rather certain desired social changes , for personal , or class , or national advantage ' ' .	85.79834
without agreeing with every phrase in this statement , we must certainly assert the great difference between christian love and any form of resistance , and then go on beyond the mennonite position and affirm that christian love-in-action must first justify and then determine the moral principles limiting resistance .	65.11169
economy in the use of power needs not only to be asserted , but clearly specified	121.83499
and when this is done it will be found that the principles governing christian resistance cut across the distinction between violent and non-violent means , and apply to both alike , justifying either on occasion and always limiting either action .	73.62046
economy in the use of power means more than inflicting a barely intolerable pressure upon an opponent and upon the injustice opposed .	42.806328
that would amount to calculating the means and justifying them wholly in terms of their effectiveness in reaching desired goals .	61.16292
there must also be additional and more fundamental discrimination in the use of means of resistance , violent or non-violent .	47.423233
the justification in christian conscience of the use of any mode of resistance also lays down its limitation -- in the distinction between the persons against whom pressure is primarily directed , those upon whom it may be permitted also to fall , and those who may never be directly repressed for the sake even of achieving some great good .	80.875
in these terms , the `` economic withdrawal ' ' of the negroes of nashville , tennessee , from trading in the center city , for example , was clearly justified , since these distinctions do not require that only people subjectively guilty be singled out .	49.300873
we may now take up for consideration a hard case which seems to require either no action employing economic pressure or else action that would seem to violate the principles set forth above .	163.86649
there may be instances in which , if economic pressure is to be undertaken at all , this would have to be applied without discrimination against a whole people .	48.274937
an excellent article was published recently in the journal of the church peace union by a south african journalist on the inhuman economic conditions of the blacks in south africa , amounting to virtual slavery , and the economic complicity of both the government and the people of the united states in these conditions .	37.804214
`` billions of american dollars , not only from capital investors but also from the pockets of u . s . taxpayers ' ' , this author states , `` are being poured into south africa to support a system dedicated to the oppression , the persecution , and the almost diabolical exploitation of 12 million people the color of whose skins happens not to be white ' ' .	46.041443
both the conditions and the complicity are documented in considerable detail .	27.547382
this leads to the conclusion that `` the fact is inescapable that america does have a say in whether or not apartheid shall continue ' ' .	84.93359
our leadership in a wide economic boycott of south africa would be not only in accord , it seems , with the moral conscience of america , not to be denied because we also as a people have widespread injustice in the relations of the races in our own country , but also in accord with our law , u . s . code title 19 , section 1307 , which forbids the importation of goods made by forced or convict labor .	43.033264
not only should this provision be enforced but other economic and political actions might be taken which , this author believes , `` must surely be supported by every american who values the freedom that has been won for him and whose conscience is not so dominated by the lines in his account books that he can willingly and knowingly contribute to the enslavement of another nation ' ' .	68.22706
northern liberals are the chief supporters of civil rights and of integration .	81.59778
they have also led the nation in the direction of a welfare state .	73.85566
and both in their objectives of non-discrimination and of social progress they have had ranged against them the southerners who are called bourbons .	92.50487
the name presumably derives from the french royal house which never learned and never forgot	343.24704
since bourbon whiskey , though of kentucky origin , is at least as much favored by liberals in the north as by conservatives in the south .	23.637836
the nature of the opposition between liberals and bourbons is too little understood in the north .	35.11426
the race problem has tended to obscure other , less emotional , issues which may fundamentally be even more divisive .	82.84961
it is these other differences between north and south -- other , that is , than those which concern discrimination or social welfare -- which i chiefly discuss herein .	153.1108
i write about northern liberals from considerable personal experience .	23.475325
a southerner married to a new englander , i have lived for many years in a connecticut commuting town with a high percentage of artists , writers , publicity men , and business executives of egghead tastes .	33.77925
most of them are democrats and nearly all consider themselves , and are viewed as , liberals .	109.17256
this is puzzling to an outsider conscious of the classic tradition of liberalism , because it is clear that these democrats who are left-of-center are at opposite poles from the liberal jefferson , who held that the best government was the least government .	58.402683
yet paradoxically my liberal friends continue to view jefferson as one of their patron saints .	20.805725
when i question them as to what they mean by concepts like liberty and democracy , i find that they fall into two categories the simpler ones who have simply accepted the shibboleths of their faith without analysis	82.964485
and the intelligent , cynical ones who scornfully reply that these things don ' t count any more in the world of to-day .	30.447407
i am naive , they say , to make use of such words .	85.08735
i take this to mean that the intelligent -- and therefore necessarily cynical ? ?	41.938267
-- liberal considers that the need for a national economy with controls that will assure his conception of social justice is so great that individual and local liberties as well as democratic processes may have to yield before it .	85.507706
this seems like an attitude favoring a sort of totalitarian bureaucracy which , under a president of the same stamp , would try to coerce an uncooperative congress or supreme court .	43.90168
as for states ' rights , they have never counted in the thinking of my liberal friends except as irritations of a minor and immoral nature which exist now only as anachronisms .	65.60804
the american liberal may , in the world of to-day , have a strong case	39.473717
but he presents it publicly so enmeshed in hypocrisy that it is not an honest one .	37.979465
why , in the first place , call himself a liberal if he is against laissez-faire and favors an authoritarian central government with womb-to-tomb controls over everybody ? ?	58.53366
if he attaches little importance to personal liberty , why not make this known to the world ? ?	49.654896
and if he is so scornful of the rights of states , why not advocate a different sort of constitution that he could more sincerely support ? ?	112.024185
i am concerned here , however , with the northern liberal ' s attitude toward the south .	22.705803
it appears to be one of intense dislike , which he makes little effort to conceal even in the presence of southern friends .	42.02181
his assumption seems to be that any such friends , being tolerable humans , must be more liberal than most southerners and therefore at least partly in sympathy with his views .	66.60792
time ' s editor , thomas griffith , in his book , the waist-high culture , wrote `` most of what was different about it ( the deep south ) i found myself unsympathetic to .	57.61588
' ' this , for the liberals i know , would be an understatement .	27.008713
theirs is no mere lack of sympathy , but something closer to the passionate hatred that was directed against fascism .	21.139341
i do not think that my experience would be typical for southerners living in the north .	59.009037
in business circles , usually conservative , this sort of atmosphere would hardly be found .	27.418121
but in our case -- and neither my wife nor i have extreme views on integration , nor are we given to emotional outbursts -- the situation has ruined one or two valued friendships and come close to wrecking several more .	102.243965
in fact it has caused us to give serious thought to moving our residence south , because it is not easy for the most objective southerner to sit calmly by when his host is telling a roomful of people that the only way to deal with southerners who oppose integration is to send in troops and shoot the bastards down .	68.10777
accounts have been published of northern liberals in the south up against segregationist prejudice , especially in state-supported universities where pressure may be strong to uphold the majority view .	54.913525
but these accounts do not show that northerners have been subjected to embarrassment or provocation by yankee-hatred displayed in social gatherings .	28.009363
from my wife ' s experience and other sources , this seems to be rarely encountered in educated circles .	53.08484
but there is a leavening of liberalism among college graduates throughout the south , especially among those who studied in the north .	56.240593
and social relations arising out of business ties impose courtesy , if not sympathy , toward resident and visiting northerners .	62.94426
also , among the latter a large percentage soon acquire the prevalent southern attitude on most social problems .	136.84781
but for this discussion the most important division is between those who have been reconstructed and those who haven ' t .	34.467396
my definition of this much abused adjective is that a reconstructed rebel is one who is glad that the north won the war .	28.663162
nobody knows how many southerners there are in this category .	13.676637
i suspect that there are far more unreconstructed ones than the north likes to believe .	42.974476
i never heard of a poll being taken on the question .	12.318465
no doubt such a thing would be considered unpatriotic .	12.078424
prior to 1954 i imagine that a majority of southerners would have voted against the confederacy .	16.489025
since the supreme court ' s decision of that year this is more doubtful	82.1153
and if a poll had been taken immediately following the dispatch of troops to little rock i believe the majority would have been for the old south .	66.362
belief in the traditional way of life persists much more in the older states than in the new ones .	72.861115
probably a larger percentage of virginians and south carolinians remain unreconstructed than elsewhere , with georgia , north carolina , and alabama following along after them .	42.992092
old attitudes are held more tenaciously in the tidewater than the piedmont	8.403013
so that a line running down the length of the south marking the upper limits of tidewater would roughly divide the old south from the new , but with , of course , important minority enclaves .	46.544308
the long-settled areas of states like virginia and south carolina developed the ante-bellum culture to its richest flowering , and there the memory is more precious , and the consciousness of loss the greater .	45.450657
also , we should not even to-day discount the fact that a region such as the coastal lowlands centering on charleston had closer ties with england and the west indies than with the north even after independence .	49.895054
the social and psychological consequences of this continue to affect the area .	23.820333
in certain respects defeat increased the persistent anglophilia of the old south .	19.308336
poor where they had once been rich , humbled where they had been arrogant , having no longer any hope of sharing in the leadership of the nation , the rebels who would not surrender in spirit drew comfort from the sympathy they felt extended to them by the mother country .	45.718666
and no doubt many people in states like the carolinas and georgia , which were among the most tory in sentiment in the eighteenth century , bitterly regretted the revolt against the crown .	23.660215
among bourbons the racial issue may have less to do with their remaining unreconstructed than other factors .	140.43303
but many historians maintain that except for northern meddling it would have ended in states like virginia years before it did .	121.19934
southern resentment has been over the method of its ending , the invasion , and reconstruction	129.3633
their fears now are of miscegenation and negro political control in many counties .	102.04991
but apart from racial problems , the old unreconstructed south -- to use the moderate words favored by mr . thomas griffith -- finds itself unsympathetic to most of what is different about the civilization of the north .	76.96662
and this , in effect , means most of modern america .	57.048508
it is hard to see how the situation could be otherwise .	94.005035
and therein , i feel , many northerners delude themselves about the south .	19.642624
for one thing , this is not a subject often discussed or analyzed .	307.73145
there seems to be almost a conspiracy of silence veiling it .	93.475845
i suppose the reason is a kind of wishful thinking don ' t talk about the final stages of reconstruction and they will take care of themselves .	29.775946
or else the north really believes that all southerners except a few quaint old characters have come around to realizing the errors of their past , and are now at heart sharers of the american dream , like everybody else .	56.46685
if the circumstances are faced frankly it is not reasonable to expect this to be true .	23.65206
the situation of the south since 1865 has been unique in the western world .	8.398435
regardless of rights and wrongs , a population and an area appropriate to a pre-world-war- 1 great power have been , following conquest , ruled against their will by a neighboring people , and have had imposed upon them social and economic controls they dislike .	166.64847
and the great majority of these people are of anglo-saxon or celtic descent .	60.2625
this is the only case in modern history of a people of britannic origin submitting without continued struggle to what they view as foreign domination .	172.01768
the fact is due mainly to international wars , both hot and cold .	108.03518
in every war of the united states since the civil war the south was more belligerent than the rest of the country .	11.083924
so instead of being tests of the south ' s loyalty , the spanish war , the two world wars , and the korean war all served to overcome old grievances and cement reunion .	28.151575
and there is no section of the nation more ardent than the south in the cold war against communism .	39.472713
had the situation been reversed , had , for instance , england been the enemy in 1898 because of issues of concern chiefly to new england , there is little doubt that large numbers of southerners would have happily put on their old confederate uniforms to fight as allies of britain .	44.52245
it is extraordinary that a people as proud and warlike as southerners should have been as docile as they have .	38.02794
the north should thank its stars that such has been the case	126.58654
but at the same time it should not draw false inferences therefrom .	50.67606
the two main charges levelled against the bourbons by liberals is that they are racists and social reactionaries .	26.784374
there is much truth in both these charges , and not many bourbons deny them .	42.145473
whatever their faults , they are not hypocrites .	8.119626
most of them sincerely believe that the anglo-saxon is the best race in the world and that it should remain pure .	53.350235
many northeners believe this , too , but few of them will say so publicly .	92.73792
the bourbon economic philosophy , moreover , is not very different from that of northern conservatives .	70.06778
but those among the bourbons who remain unreconstructed go much further than this .	171.9292
they believe that if the south had been let alone it would have produced a civilization superior to that of modern america .	112.24993
as it is , they consider that the north is now reaping the fruits of excess egalitarianism , that in spite of its high standard of living the `` american way ' ' has been proved inferior to the english and scandinavian ways , although they disapprove of the socialistic features of the latter .	31.255249
the south ' s antipathy to northern civilization includes such charges as poor manners , harsh accents , lack of appreciation of the arts of living like gastronomy and the use of leisure .	45.0406
their own easier , slower tempo is especially dear to southerners	147.09398
and i have heard many say that they are content to earn a half or a third as much as they could up north because they so much prefer the quieter habits of their home town .	63.84662
in the past , the duties of the state , as sir henry maine noted long ago , were only two in number internal order and external security .	139.37845
by prevailing over other claimants for the loyalties of men , the nation-state maintained an adequate measure of certainty and order within its territorial borders .	36.489895
outside those limits it asserted , as against other states , a position of sovereign equality , and , as against the `` inferior ' ' peoples of the non-western world , a position of dominance .	22.691847
it became the sole `` subject ' ' of `` international law ' ' ( a term which , it is pertinent to remember , was coined by bentham ) , a body of legal principle which by and large was made up of what western nations could do in the world arena .	42.952595
( that corpus of law was a reflection of the power system in existence during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries .	28.596426
speaking generally , it furthered -- and still tends to further -- the interests of the western powers .	30.634827
the enormous changes in world politics have , however , thrown it into confusion , so much so that it is safe to say that all international law is now in need of reexamination and clarification in light of the social conditions of the present era .	42.366943
beyond the two basic tasks mentioned above , no attention was paid by statesman or scholar to an idea of state responsibility , either internally or externally .	50.18171
this was particularly true in the world arena , which was an anarchical battleground characterized by strife and avaricious competition for colonial empires .	9.734521
that any sort of duty was owed by his nation to other nations would have astonished a nineteenth-century statesman .	80.00591
his duty was to his sovereign and to his nation , and an extension to peoples beyond the territorial boundaries was not to be contemplated .	52.5999
thus , to cite but one example , the pax britannica of the nineteenth century , whether with the british navy ruling the seas or with the city of london ruling world finance , was strictly national in motivation , however much other nations ( e . g . , the united states ) may have incidentally benefited .	57.153446
at the same time , all suggestions that some sort of societal responsibility existed for the welfare of the people within the territorial state was strongly resisted .	64.32796
social darwinism was able to stave off the incipient socialist movement until well into the present century .	67.91436
however , in recent decades , for what doubtless are multiple reasons , an unannounced but nonetheless readily observable shift has occurred in both facets of national activity .	69.335495
a concept of responsibility is in process of articulation and establishment .	25.847225
already firmly implanted internally , it is a growing factor in external matters .	21.049969
a little more than twenty years ago the american people turned an important corner .	179.54723
in what has aptly been called a `` constitutional revolution ' ' , the basic nature of government was transformed from one essentially negative in nature ( the `` night-watchman state ' ' ) to one with affirmative duties to perform .	55.028072
the `` positive state ' ' came into existence .	39.666668
for lawyers , reflecting perhaps their parochial preferences , there has been a special fascination since then in the role played by the supreme court in that transformation -- the manner in which its decisions altered in `` the switch in time that saved nine ' ' , president roosevelt ' s ill-starred but in effect victorious `` court-packing plan ' ' , the imprimatur of judicial approval that was finally placed upon social legislation .	47.623
of greater importance , however , is the content of those programs , which have had and are having enormous consequences for the american people .	136.69664
labor relations have been transformed , income security has become a standardized feature of political platforms , and all the many facets of the american version of the welfare state have become part of the conventional wisdom .	44.910336
a national consensus of near unanimity exists that these governmental efforts are desirable as well as necessary .	50.440014
ratified in the republican party victory in 1952 , the positive state is now evidenced by political campaigns being waged not on whether but on how much social legislation there should be .	103.53051
the general acceptance of the idea of governmental ( i . e . , societal ) responsibility for the economic well-being of the american people is surely one of the two most significant watersheds in american constitutional history .	29.311201
the other , of course , was the civil war , the conflict which a century ago insured national unity over fragmentation .	143.18883
a third , one of at least equal and perhaps even greater importance , is now being traversed american immersion and involvement in world affairs .	62.299606
internal national responsibility , now a truism , need not be documented .	53.465244
nevertheless , it may be helpful to cite one example -- that of employment -- for , as will be shown below , it cuts across both facets of the new concept .	98.9688
thirty years ago , while the nation was wallowing in economic depression , the prevailing philosophy of government was to stand aside and allow `` natural forces ' ' to operate and cure the distress .	63.691235
that guiding principle of the hoover administration fell to the siege guns of the new deal	38.6222
less than a score of years later congress enacted the employment act of 1946 , by which the national government assumed the responsibility of taking action to insure conditions of maximum employment .	44.403614
hands-off the economy was replaced by conscious guidance through planning -- the economic side of the constitutional revolution .	37.524124
in 1961 the first important legislative victory of the kennedy administration came when the principle of national responsibility for local economic distress won out over a `` state ' s-responsibility ' ' proposal -- provision was made for payment for unemployment relief by nation-wide taxation rather than by a levy only on those states afflicted with manpower surplus .	67.12962
the american people have indeed come a long way in the brief interval between 1930 and 1961 .	36.6774
internal national responsibility is a societal response to the impact of the industrial revolution .	26.122122
reduced to its simplest terms , it is an assumption of a collective duty to compensate for the inability of individuals to cope with the rigors of the era .	24.224785
national responsibility for individual welfare is a concept not limited to the united states or even to the western nations .	24.341331
a measure of its widespread acceptance may be derived from a statement of the international congress of jurists in 1959 .	23.287317
meeting in new delhi under the auspices of the international commission of jurists , a body of lawyers from the free world , the congress redefined and expanded the traditional rule of law to include affirmative governmental duties .	24.273493
it is noteworthy that the majority of the delegates to the congress were from the less developed , former colonial nations .	101.10248
the rule of law , historically a principle according everyone his `` day in court ' ' before an impartial tribunal , was broadened substantively by making it a responsibility of government to promote individual welfare .	67.5543
recognizing that the rule of law is `` a dynamic concept which should be employed not only to safeguard the civil and political rights of the individual in a free society ' ' , the congress asserted that it also included the responsibility `` to establish social , economic , educational and cultural conditions under which his legitimate aspirations and dignity may be realized ' ' .	40.216164
the idea of national responsibility thus has become a common feature of the nations of the non-soviet world .	26.81929
for better or for worse , we all now live in welfare states , the organizing principle of which is collective responsibility for individual well-being .	70.056854
