whether a concept analogous to the principle of internal responsibility operates in a nation ' s external relations is less obvious and more difficult to establish .	60.905994
the hypothesis ventured here is that it does , and that evidence is accumulating validating that proposition .	67.24843
the content is not the same , however rather than individual security , it is the security and continuing existence of an `` ideological group ' ' -- those in the `` free world ' ' -- that is basic .	35.48617
external national responsibility involves a burgeoning requirement that the leaders of the western nations so guide their decisions as to further the viability of other friendly nations .	67.69653
if internal responsibility suggests acceptance of the socialist ideal of equality , then external responsibility implies adherence to principles of ideological supranationalism .	41.351723
reference to two other concepts -- nationalism and sovereignty -- may help to reveal the contours of the new principle .	31.786377
in its beginnings the nation-state had to struggle to assert itself -- internally , against feudal groups , and externally , against the power and influence of such other claimants for loyalty as the church .	43.390106
the breakup of the holy roman empire and the downfall of feudalism led , not more than two centuries ago , to the surge of nationalism .	20.497698
( since the time-span of the nation-state coincides roughly with the separate existence of the united states as an independent entity , it is perhaps natural for americans to think of the nation as representative of the highest form of order , something permanent and unchanging .	37.924297
) the concept of nationalism is the political principle that epitomizes and glorifies the territorial state as the characteristic type of socal structure .	32.016933
for it includes the emotional ties that bind men to their homeland and the complex motivations that hold a large group of people together as a unit .	55.11339
today , as new nations rise from the former colonial empires , nationalism is one of the hurricane forces loose in the world .	30.393694
almost febrile in intensity , the principle has become worldwide in application -- unfortunately at the very time that nationalist fervors can wreak greatest harm .	25.528202
historically , however , the concept is one that has been of marked benefit to the people of the western civilizational group .	50.785576
by subduing disparate lesser groups the nation has , to some degree at least , broadened the capacity for individual liberty .	41.235744
within their confines , moreover , technological and industrial growth has proceeded at an accelerated pace , thus increasing the cornucopia from which material wants can be satisfied .	88.21242
while the pattern is uneven , some having gained more than others , nationalism has in fact served the western peoples well .	158.96706
( whether historical nationalism helped the peoples of the remainder of the world , and whether today ' s nationalism in the former colonial areas has equally beneficial aspects , are other questions .	88.3189
it is one of the ironic quirks of history that the viability and usefulness of nationalism and the territorial state are rapidly dissipating at precisely the time that the nation-state attained its highest number ( approximately 100 ) .	42.920826
but it is more than irony one of the main reasons why nationalism is no longer a tenable concept is because it has spread throughout the planet .	101.76142
in other words , nationalism worked well enough when it had limited application , both as to geography and as to population	150.48337
it becomes a perilous anachronism when adopted on a world-wide basis .	2.6288836
complementing the political principle of nationalism is the legal principle of sovereignty .	20.775515
the former receives its legitimacy from the latter .	6.9226174
operating side by side , together they helped shore up the nation-state .	112.350494
while sovereignty has roots in antiquity , in its present usage it is essentially modern .	62.404648
jean bodin , writing in the sixteenth century , may have been the seminal thinker , but it was the vastly influential john austin who set out the main lines of the concept as now understood .	44.30043
austin ' s nineteenth-century view of law and sovereignty still dominates much of today ' s legal and political thinking .	78.53325
to him , law is the command of the sovereign ( the english monarch ) who personifies the power of the nation , while sovereignty is the power to make law -- i . e . , to prevail over internal groups and to be free from the commands of other sovereigns in other nations .	32.996445
these fundamental ideas -- the indivisibility of sovereignty and its dual ( internal-external ) aspects -- still remain the core of that concept of ultimate political power .	42.639706
the nation-state , then , exemplifies the principle of nationalism and exercises sovereignty supreme power over domestic affairs and independence from outside control .	98.3513
in fact , however , both principles have always been nebulous and loosely defined .	15.04054
high-level abstractions are always difficult to pin down with precision .	302.06546
that is particularly true of sovereignty when it is applied to democratic societies , in which `` popular ' ' sovereignty is said to exist , and in federal nations , in which the jobs of government are split .	78.866035
nevertheless , nationalism and sovereignty are reputed , in the accepted wisdom , to describe the modern world .	27.715399
is there a different reality behind the facade ? ?	11.329346
does the surface hide a quite different picture ? ?	4.8391004
the short answer to those questions is `` yes ' ' .	5.8958344
to some degree they are being supplanted by a concept of national responsibility .	16.162352
as evidence to support that view , consider the following illustrative instances .	48.43966
can thermonuclear war be set off by accident ? ?	39.396595
what steps have been taken to guard against the one sort of mishap that could trigger the destruction of continents ? ?	20.19248
are we as safe as we should be from such a disaster ? ?	76.770386
is anything being done to increase our margin of safety ? ?	25.661524
i have just asked these questions in the pentagon , in the white house , in offices of key scientists across the country and aboard the submarines that prowl for months underwater , with neat rows of green launch tubes which contain polaris missiles and which are affectionately known as `` sherwood forest ' ' .	23.417221
i asked the same questions inside the launch-control rooms of an atlas missile base in wyoming , where officers who wear sidearms are manning the `` commit buttons ' ' that could start a war -- accidentally or by design -- and in the command centers where other pistol-packing men could give orders to push such buttons .	41.726017
to the men in the instrument-jammed bomber cockpits , submarine compartments and the antiseptic , windowless rooms that would be the foxholes of tomorrow ' s impersonal intercontinental wars , the questions seem farfetched .	16.547575
there is unceasing pressure , but its sources are immediate .	118.90185
`` readiness exercises ' ' are almost continuous .	31.835611
in the command centers there are special clocks ready to tick off the minutes elapsed since `` e hour ' ' .	37.8828
`` e ' ' stands for `` execution ' ' -- the moment a `` go order ' ' would unleash an american nuclear strike .	55.63233
there is little time for the men in the command centers to reflect about the implications of these clocks .	46.85106
they are preoccupied riding herd on control panels , switches , flashing colored lights on pale green or gray consoles that look like business machines .	39.85106
they know little about their machinery beyond mechanical details .	7.2637177
accidental war is so sensitive a subject that most of the people who could become directly involved in one are told just enough so they can perform their portions of incredibly complex tasks .	82.08097
among the policy makers , generals , physicists , psychologists and others charged with controlling the actions of the button pushers and their `` hardware ' ' , the answers to my questions varied partly according to a man ' s flair for what the professionals in this field call `` scenarios ' ' .	26.268673
as an air force psychiatrist put it `` you can ' t have dry runs on this one ' ' .	49.30682
the experts are thus forced to hypothesize sequences of events that have never occurred , probably never will -- but possibly might .	189.7369
only one rule prevailed in my conversations with these men the more highly placed they are -- that is , the more they know -- the more concerned they have become .	128.84526
already accidental war is a silent guest at the discussions within the kennedy administration about the urgency of disarmament and nearly all other questions of national security .	55.460323
only recently new `` holes ' ' were discovered in our safety measures , and a search is now on for more .	123.57447
work is under way to see whether new restraining devices should be installed on all nuclear weapons .	31.833155
meanwhile , the experts speak of wars triggered by `` false pre-emption ' ' , `` escalation ' ' , `` unauthorized behavior ' ' and other terms that will be discussed in this report .	17.112284
they inhabit a secret world centered on `` go codes ' ' and `` gold phones ' ' .	8.6377735
their conversations were , almost invariably , accompanied by the same gestures -- arms and pointed forefingers darting toward each other in arclike semicircular motions .	22.711868
one arm represented our bombers and missiles , the other arm `` theirs ' ' .	47.1317
yet implicit in each movement was the death of millions , perhaps hundreds of millions , perhaps you and me -- and the experts .	111.356
it is their job to think about the unthinkable .	46.049072
unanimously they believe that the world would become a safer place if more of us -- and more russians and communist chinese , too -- thought about accidental war .	88.95117
the first systematic thinking about this pandora ' s box within pandora ' s boxes was done four years ago by fred ikle , a frail , meek-mannered swiss-born sociologist .	15.965099
he was , and is , with the rand corporation , a nonprofit pool of thinkers financed by the u . s . air force .	9.762311
his investigations made him the paul revere of accidental war , and safety procedures were enormously increased .	68.85591
in recent weeks , as a result of a sweeping defense policy reappraisal by the kennedy administration , basic united states strategy has been modified -- and large new sums allocated -- to meet the accidental-war danger and to reduce it as quickly as possible .	60.986668
the chain starts at bmews ( ballistic missile early warning system ) in thule , greenland .	33.574608
its radar screens would register soviet missiles shortly after they are launched against the united states .	21.876093
bmews intelligence is simultaneously flashed to norad ( north american air defense command ) in colorado springs , colorado , for interpretation	48.706444
to the sac command and control post , forty-five feet below the ground at offutt air force base , near omaha , nebraska	14.602426
to the joint war room of the joint chiefs of staff in the pentagon and to the president .	10.285795
telephones , teletypes , several kinds of radio systems and , in some cases , television , link all vital points .	75.55588
alternate locations exist for all key command centers .	3.4233503
for last-ditch emergencies sac has alternate command posts on kc-135 jet tankers .	2.9027257
multiple circuits , routings and frequencies make the chain as unbreakable as possible .	36.131348
the same principle of `` redundancy ' ' applies to all communications on these special networks .	41.986046
and no messages can be transmitted on these circuits until senders and receivers authenticate in advance , by special codes , that the messages actually come from their purported sources .	21.579128
additional codes can be used to challenge and counterchallenge the authentications .	8.380517
only the president is permitted to authorize the use of nuclear weapons .	9.869303
but what if somebody decides to break it ? ?	9.760556
the president cannot personally remove the safety devices from every nuclear trigger .	160.33727
hundreds of men are required to pass the word to the button pushers and to push the buttons .	9.134977
what if one or more of them turn irrational or suddenly , coolly , decide to clobber the russians ? ?	42.856037
what if the president himself , in the language of the military , `` goes ape ' ' ? ?	13.640093
or singlehandedly decided to reverse national policy and hit the soviets without provocation ? ?	35.410522
nobody can be absolutely certain of the answers .	10.360849
however , the system is designed , ingeniously and hopefully , so that no one man could initiate a thermonuclear war .	30.038172
even the president cannot pick up his telephone and give a `` go ' ' order .	38.979782
even he does not know the one signal for a nuclear strike -- the `` go code ' ' .	24.620787
in an emergency he would receive available intelligence on the `` gold-phone circuit ' ' .	13.237391
a system of `` gold ' ' -- actually yellow -- phones connects him with the offices and action stations of the secretary of defense , the joint chiefs of staff , the sac commander and other key men .	41.749245
all can be connected with the gold circuit from their homes .	42.491547
all could help the president make his decision .	2.9660518
the talk would not be in code , but neither would it ramble .	32.373486
vital questions would be quickly answered according to a preprepared agenda .	17.269724
officers who participate in the continual practice drills assured me that the president ' s decision could be made and announced on the gold circuit within minutes after the first flash from aj .	60.364426
if communications work , his decision would be instantly known in all command posts that would originate the actual go order .	163.2565
for these centers , too , are on the gold circuit .	50.084663
they include the navy ' s atlantic command at norfolk , virginia , which is in contact with the polaris subs	26.7039
air force forward headquarters in europe and in the pacific , which control tactical fighters on ships and land bases	103.2083
and sac , which controls long-range bombers and atlas missiles .	3.505325
let us look in on one of these nerve centers -- sac at omaha -- and see what must still happen before a wing of b-52 bombers could drop their aj .	89.49826
the key man almost certainly would be col . william w . wisman , sac ' s senior controller .	21.824139
he or his deputy or one of their seven assistants , all full colonels , mans the heart of the command post twenty-four hours a day .	36.729977
it is a quiet but impressive room -- 140 feet long , thirty-nine feet wide , twenty-one feet high .	8.614179
movable panels of floor-to-ceiling maps and charts are crammed with intelligence information .	70.578384
and bill wisman , forty-three , a farmer ' s son from beallsville , ohio , is a quiet but impressive man .	30.713408
his eyes are steady anchors of the deepest brown .	89.02951
his movements and speech are precise , clear and quick .	42.169655
no question ruffles him or causes him to hesitate .	10.513925
wisman , who has had the chief controller ' s job for four years , calls the signals for a team operating three rows of dull-gray consoles studded with lights , switches and buttons .	44.274055
at least a dozen men , some armed , are never far away from him .	109.32519
in front of him is a gold phone .	3.6981068
in emergencies the sac commander , gen . thomas power , or his deputies and their staff would occupy a balcony that stretches across the length of the room above wisman and his staff .	57.18722
at general power ' s seat in the balcony there is also a gold phone .	30.771347
general power would participate in the decision making .	29.126997
wisman , below , would listen in and act .	83.15007
his consoles can give him instant contact with more than seventy bases around the world and with every sac aircraft .	60.7788
he need only pick up one of the two red telephone receivers at his extreme left , right next to the big red button marked alert .	230.31784
( there are two receivers in case one should be dropped and damaged .	64.6801
but wisman , too , does not know the go code .	177.88928
he must take it from `` the red box ' ' .	4.8980675
in point of fact , this is a beige box with a bright red door , about one and a half feet square and hung from the wall about six feet from the door to wisman ' s right .	54.095566
the box is internally wired so the door can never be opened without setting off a screeching klaxon ( `` it ' s real obnoxious ' ' ) .	24.279211
now we must become vague , for we are approaching one of the nation ' s most guarded secrets .	25.799656
the codes in the red box -- there are several of them covering various contingencies -- are contained in a sealed x-ray-proof `` unique device ' ' .	45.318913
they are supplied , a batch at a time , by a secret source and are continually changed by wisman or his staff , at random intervals .	55.381233
but even the contents of wisman ' s box cannot start a war .	123.87376
they are mere fragments , just one portion of preprepared messages .	7.6627135
what these fragments are and how they activate the go order may not be revealed .	142.63774
the pieces must be placed in the context of the prepared messages by wisman ' s staff .	15.97319
in addition to the authentication and acknowledgment procedures which precede and follow the sending of the go messages , again in special codes , each message also contains an `` internal authenticator ' ' , another specific signal to convince the recipient that he is getting the real thing .	42.580215
i asked wisman what would happen if he broke out the go codes and tried to start transmitting one .	75.428085
`` i ' d wind up full of bullet holes ' ' , he said , and there was no question that he was talking about bullets fired by his coworkers .	20.648512
now let us imagine a wing of b-52 ' s , on alert near their `` positive control ( or fail-safe ) points ' ' , the spots on the map , many miles from soviet territory , beyond which they are forbidden to fly without specific orders to proceed to their targets .	61.023903
they , too , have fragments of the go code with them .	310.78992
as wisman put it , `` they have separate pieces of the pie , and we have the whole pie .	27.114834
once we send out the whole pie , they can put their pieces into it .	33.796345
unless we send out the whole pie , their pieces mean nothing ' ' .	73.62008
why does wisman ' s ever-changing code always mesh with the fragments in possession of the button pushers ? ?	12.252277
at any rate , three men out of a six-man b-52 crew are required to copy down wisman ' s go-to-war message .	70.654816
each must match wisman ' s `` pie ' ' with the fragment that he carries with him .	14.688419
all three must compare notes and agree to `` go ' ' .	12.530602
after that , it requires several minutes of concentrated work , including six separate and deliberate actions by a minimum of three men sitting at three separate stations in a bomber , each with another man beside him to help , for an armed bomb to be released .	86.91677
unless all gadgets are properly operated -- and the wires and seals from the handles removed first -- no damage can be done .	83.636086
suddenly , however , their posture changed and the game ended .	50.600365
they went as rigid as black statuary six figures , lean and tall and angular , went still .	72.906746
they all swung at the same instant in the same direction .	12.079807
they saw it before i did , even with my binoculars .	55.88206
it was nothing more than a tiny distant rain squall , a dull gray sheet which reached from a layer of clouds to the earth .	20.203634
in the 360 degrees of horizon it obscured only a degree , no more .	79.899895
a white man would not have seen it .	6.775191
the aborigines fastened upon it with a concentration beyond pathos .	44.46089
watching , they waited until the squall thickened and began to move in a long drifting slant across the dry burning land .	35.69924
at once the whole band set off at a lope .	10.718023
they went after the squall as mercilessly as a wolf pack after an abandoned cow .	32.401817
i followed them in the jeep and now they did not care .	64.70296
the games were over , this was life .	14.905094
occasionally , for no reason that i could see , they would suddenly alter the angle of their trot .	34.992603
sometimes i guessed it was because the rain squall had changed direction .	53.191593
their gait is impossible to convey in words .	5.47542
it has nothing of the proud stride of the trained runner about it , it is not a lope , it is not done with style or verve .	37.32262
it is the gait of the human who must run to live arms dangling , legs barely swinging over the ground , head hung down and only occasionally swinging up to see the target , a loose motion that is just short of stumbling and yet is wonderfully graceful .	57.438427
it is a barely controlled skimming of the ground .	25.042875
finally , avoiding hummocks and seeking low ground , they intercepted the rain squall .	5.922686
for ten minutes they ran beneath the squall , raising their arms and , for the first time , shouting and capering .	21.090433
then the wind died and the rain squall held steady .	975.3941
suddenly one of them shouted , ran a few feet , bent forward and put his mouth to the ground .	15.890922
he had found a depression with rain water in it .	55.45657
he bent down , a black cranelike figure , and put his mouth to the ground .	23.343422
with a lordly and generous gesture , the discoverer stood up and beckoned to the closest of his fellows .	18.687277
the other trotted over and swooped at the tiny puddle .	6.571387
in an instant he had sucked it dry .	9.414602
the aborigine lives on the cruelest land i have ever seen .	15.065608
which does not mean that it is ugly .	3.0384462
there are thousands of square miles of salt pan which are hideous .	9.428331
they are huge areas which have been swept by winds for so many centuries that there is no soil left , but only deep bare ridges fifty or sixty yards apart with ravines between them thirty or forty feet deep and the only thing that moves is a scuttling layer of sand .	64.71283
but much of the land which the aborigine wanders looks as if it should be hospitable .	15.8859215
it is softened by the saltbush and the bluebush , has a peaceful quality , the hills roll softly .	95.28981
the malignancy of such a landscape has been beautifully described by the australian charles bean .	12.060859
he tells of three men who started out on a trip across a single paddock , a ten-by-ten-mile square owned by a sheep grazer .	25.721943
they went well-equipped with everything except knowledge of the `` outback ' ' country .	6.8275857
the countryside looked like a beautiful open park with gentle slopes and soft gray tree-clumps .	17.745504
nothing appalling or horrible rushed upon these men .	2.9078488
there might have been a pool of cool water behind any of these tree-clumps only -- there was not .	158.7707
there might have been a fence or a house just over the next rise	448.95538
they lay , with the birds hopping from branch to branch above them and the bright sky peeping down at them .	38.158524
even today range riders will come upon mummified bodies of men who attempted nothing more difficult than a twenty-mile hike and slowly lost direction , were tortured by the heat , driven mad by the constant and unfulfilled promise of the landscape , and who finally died .	60.87501
he knows that the land is hard and pitiless .	2.0215588
he knows that the economy of life in the `` outback ' ' is awful .	10.509119
there is no room for error or waste .	6.949386
any organism that falters or misperceives the signals or weakens is done .	26.603493
i do not know if such a way of life can come to be a self-conscious challenge , but i suspect that it can .	21.650486
perhaps this is what gives the aborigine his odd air of dignity .	82.797874
seeing an aborigine today is a difficult thing .	17.250547
many of them have drifted into the cities and towns and seaports .	10.070543
others are confined to vast reservations , and not only does the australian government justifiably not wish them to be viewed as exhibits in a zoo , but on their reservations they are extremely fugitive , shunning camps , coming together only for corroborees at which their strange culture comes to its highest pitch -- which is very low indeed .	75.210014
i persuaded an australian friend who had lived `` outback ' ' for years to take me to see some aborigines living in the bush .	40.800125
it was a difficult and ambiguous kind of negotiation , even though the rancher was said to be expert in his knowledge of the aborigines and their language .	50.287045
finally , however , the arrangements were made and we drove out into the bush in a land rover .	34.36626
we followed the asphalt road for a few miles and then swung off onto a smaller road which was nothing more than two tire marks on the earth .	42.11038
the rancher went a mile down this road and then , when he reached a big red boulder , swung off the road .	29.84098
at once he started to glance toward the instrument panel .	670.62537
it took me a moment to realize what was odd about that panel there was a gimbaled compass welded to it , which rocked gently back and forth as the land rover bounced about .	67.75612
the rancher was navigating his way across the flatland .	6.828506
`` do you always navigate like this ' ' ? ?	1.7106415
`` damned right ' ' , he said .	6.312587
`` once i get out on the flat i do .	50.83707
some chaps that know an area well can make their way by landmarks , a tree here , a wash here , a boulder there .	68.06011
but if you don ' t know the place like the palm of your hand , you ' d better use a compass and the speedometer .	50.436714
two miles northeast , then five miles southwest that sort of thing .	214.45505
i would try to memorize landmarks and saw in a half-hour that it was hopeless .	23.887348
finally we approached the bivouac of the aborigines .	7.510631
they were camped beside a large column-shaped boulder a man , his lubra , and two children .	35.656788
the sun was not yet high and all of them were in the small area of shade cast by the boulder .	35.60034
there was also a dog , a dingo dog .	20.764317
its ribs showed , it was a yellow nondescript color , it suffered from a variety of sores , hair had scabbed off its body in patches .	36.485615
it lay with its head on its paws and only its eyes moving , watching us carefully .	181.345
it struck me as a very bright and very malnourished dog .	9.907616
`` the buggers love shade ' ' , the rancher said .	16.149494
`` i suppose because it saves them some loss of body water .	215.9341
they ' ll move around that rock all day , following the shade .	134.74231
during the hottest part of the day , of course , the sun comes straight down and there isn ' t any shade ' ' .	24.712172
we drove close to the boulder , stopped the land rover , and walked over toward the family .	48.748383
he gazed away from us as we approached .	51.539265
he was over six feet tall and very thin .	11.923125
every bone and muscle in his body showed , but he did not give the appearance of starving .	24.686419
he had long black hair and a wispy beard .	4.0703053
the ridges over his eyes were huge and his eyelids were half shut .	54.30065
there was something about his face that disturbed me and it took several seconds to realize what .	62.271008
it was not merely that flies were crawling over his face but his narrowed eyelids did not blink when the flies crawled into his eye sockets .	24.73765
a fly would crawl down the bulging forehead , into the socket of the eye , walk along the man ' s lashes and across the wet surface of the eyeball , and the eye did not blink .	13.780967
the australian and i both were wearing insect repellent and were not badly bothered by insects , but my eyes watered as we stood watching the aborigine .	63.54238
she remained squatting on her heels all the time we were there	260.33313
like the man , she was entirely naked .	13.932981
her long thin arms moved in a slow rhythmical gesture over the family possessions which were placed in front of her .	20.905188
there were two rubbing sticks for making fire , two stones shaped roughly like knives , a woven-root container which held a few pounds of dried worms and the dead body of some rodent .	31.41
there was also a long wooden spear and a woomera , a spear-throwing device which gives the spear an enormous velocity and high accuracy .	23.90788
there was also a boomerang , elaborately carved .	18.521147
everything was burnished with sweat and grease so that all of the objects seemed to have been carved from the same material and to be ageless .	35.99275
the two children , both boys , wandered around the australian and me for a few moments and then returned to their work .	64.95174
they squatted on their heels with their heads bent far forward , their eyes only a few inches from the ground .	26.891045
they had located the runway of a colony of ants and as the ants came out of the ground , the boys picked them up , one at a time , and pinched them dead .	42.006283
the tiny bodies , dropped onto a dry leaf , made a pile as big as a small apple .	32.241653
the odor here was more powerful than that which surrounded the town aborigines .	56.698452
the smell at first was more surprising than unpleasant .	112.53918
it was also subtly familiar , for it was the odor of the human body , but multiplied innumerable times because of the fact that the aborigines never bathed .	22.701437
one ' s impulse is to say that the smell was a stink and unpleasant .	24.053345
but that is a cliche and a dishonest one .	137.42706
the smell is sexual , but so powerfully so that a civilized nose must deny it .	237.05795
their skin was covered with a thin coating of sweat and dirt which had almost the consistency of a second skin .	39.858013
they roll at night in ashes to keep warm and their second skin has a light dusty cast to it .	111.2705
in spots such as the elbows and knees the second skin is worn off and i realized the aborigines were much darker than they appeared	57.037846
as if the coating of sweat , dirt , and ashes were a cosmetic .	12.078888
the boys had beautiful dark eyes and unlike their father they brushed constantly at the flies and blinked their eyes .	39.838943
`` that smell is something , eh , mate ' ' ? ?	29.350664
`` they swear that every person smells different and every family smells different from every other .	90.57082
at the corroborees , when they get to dancing and sweating , you ' ll see them rubbing up against a man who ' s supposed to have a specially good smell .	25.479301
idje , here ' ' , and he nodded at the man , `` is said to have great odor .	49.537502
the stink is all the same to me , but i really think they can make one another out blindfolded ' ' .	52.934746
`` here , idje , you fella like tabac ' ' ? ?	3.7262557
idje still stared over our shoulders at the horizon .	6.1488914
the australian stopped trying to talk a pidgin i could understand , and spoke strange words from deep in his chest .	136.17392
it was a fortunate time in which to build , for the seventeenth century was a great period in persian art .	46.427204
the architects , the tile and carpet makers , the potters , painters , calligraphers , and metalsmiths worked through abbas ' s reign and those of his successors to enrich the city .	24.018536
travelers entering from the desert were confounded by what must have seemed an illusion a great garden filled with nightingales and roses , cut by canals and terraced promenades , studded with water tanks of turquoise tile in which were reflected the glistening blue curves of a hundred domes .	26.040007
at the heart of all of this was the square , which one such traveler declared to be `` as spacious , as pleasant and aromatick a market as any in the universe ' ' .	69.19727
in time isfahan came to be known as `` half the world ' ' , isfahan nisf-i-jahan .	18.0448
in the early eighteenth century this fantastic city , then the size of london , started to decline .	80.41117
isfahan became more of a legend than a place , and now it is for many people simply a name to which they attach their notions of old persia and sometimes of the east .	79.70175
they think of it as a kind of spooky museum in which they may half see and half imagine the old splendor .	145.10173
those who actually get there find that it isn ' t spooky at all but as brilliant as a tile in sunlight .	39.689583
but even for them it remains a museum , or perhaps it would be more accurate to say a tomb , a tomb in which persia lies well preserved but indeed dead .	71.243515
everyone is ready to grant the persians their history , but almost no one is willing to acknowledge their present .	106.38784
it seems that for persia , and especially for this city , there are only two times the glorious past and the corrupt , depressing , sterile present .	46.67671
the one apparent connection between the two is a score of buildings which somehow or other have survived and which naturally enough are called `` historical monuments ' ' .	77.59955
however , just as all the buildings have not fallen and flowed back to their original mud , so the values which wanted them and saw that they were built have not all disappeared .	93.756134
the values and talents which made the tile and the dome , the rug , the poem and the miniature , continue in certain social institutions which rise above the ordinary life of this city , as the great buildings rise above blank walls and dirty lanes .	56.00672
often , too , the social institutions are housed in these pavilions and palaces and bridges , for these great structures are not simply `` historical monuments ' '	37.77224
the promenade , for example , continues to take place on the chahar bagh , a mile-long garden of plane and poplar trees that now serves as the city ' s principal street .	16.975557
it takes place as well along the terraces and through the arcades of the khaju bridge , and also in the gardens of the square .	19.058098
on fridays , the day when many persians relax with poetry , talk , and a samovar , people do not , it is true , stream into chehel sotun -- a pavilion and garden built by shah abbas 2 , in the seventeenth century -- but they do retire into hundreds of pavilions throughout the city and up the river valley , which are smaller , more humble copies of the former .	39.638798
and of course religious life continues to center in the more famous mosques , and commercial life -- very much a social institution -- in the bazaar .	47.136265
those three other great activities of the persians , the bath , the teahouse , and the zur khaneh ( the latter a kind of club in which a leader and a group of men in an octagonal pit move through a rite of calisthenics , dance , chanted poetry , and music ) , do not take place in buildings to which entrance tickets are sold , but some of them occupy splendid examples of persian domestic architecture long , domed , chalk-white rooms with daises of turquoise tile , their end walls cut through to the orchards and the sky by open arches .	39.405773
but more important , and the thing which the casual traveler and the blind sojourner often do not see , is that these places and activities are often the settings in which persians exercise their extraordinary aesthetic sensibilities .	58.136864
water , air , fruit , poetry , music , the human form -- these things are important to persians , and they experience them with an intense and discriminating awareness .	36.614334
i should like , by the way , to make it clear that i am not using the word `` persians ' ' carelessly .	17.241589
i don ' t mean a few aesthetes who play about with sensations , like a young prince in a miniature dabbling his hand in a pool .	75.328636
these things are important to almost all persians and perhaps most important to the most ordinary .	32.473038
the men crying love poems in an orchard on any summer ' s night are as often as not the lutihaw , mustachioed toughs who spend most of their lives in and out of the local prisons , brothels , and teahouses .	35.52696
a few months ago it was a fairly typical landlord who in the dead of night lugged me up a mountainside to drink from a spring famous in the neighborhood for its clarity and flavor .	92.068115
not long ago an acquaintance , a slick-headed water rat of a lad up from the maw of the city , stood on the balcony puffing his first cigarette in weeks .	50.490555
the air , he said , was just right	265.62997
i really didn ' t know what he meant .	7.731714
he sniffed the air and licked it on his lip and knew as a vintner knows a vintage .	22.399311
the natural world then , plus poetry and some kinds of art , receives from the most ordinary of persians a great deal of attention .	47.002697
the line of an eyebrow , the color of the skin , a ghazal from hafiz , the purity of spring water , the long afternoon among the boughs which crowd the upper story of a pavilion -- these things are noticed , judged , and valued .	33.89568
nowhere in isfahan is this rich aesthetic life of the persians shown so well as during the promenade at the khaju bridge .	27.123926
there has probably always been a bridge of some sort at the southeastern corner of the city .	19.922417
for one thing , there is a natural belt of rock across the river bed	235.5867
for another , it was here that one of the old caravan routes came in .	36.378975
it was to provide a safe and spacious crossing for these caravans , and also to make a pleasance for the city , that shah abbas 2 , in about 1657 built , of sun-baked brick , tile , and stone , the present bridge .	40.227547
from upstream it looks like a long arcaded box laid across the river	25.59787
from downstream , where the water level is much lower , it is a high , elaborately facaded pavilion .	26.683138
the top story contains more than thirty alcoves separated from each other by spandrels of blue and yellow tile .	16.114025
at either end and in the center there are bays which contain nine greater alcoves as frescoed and capacious as church apses .	49.128414
here , in the old days -- when they had come to see the moon or displays of fireworks -- sat the king and his court while priests , soldiers , and other members of the party lounged in the smaller alcoves between .	65.551216
below , twenty vaults tunnel through the understructure of the bridge .	6.659204
these are traversed by another line of vaults , and thus rooms , arched on all four sides , are formed .	39.505993
down through the axis of the bridge there is a long diminishing vista like a visual echo of piers and arches , while the vaults fronting upstream and down frame the sunset and sunrise , the mountains and river pools .	28.037579
here , on the hottest day , it is cool beneath the stone and fresh from the water flowing in the sluices at the bottom of the vaults .	14.162442
on the downstream , or `` pavilion ' ' , side these vaults give out onto terraces twice as wide as the bridge itself .	87.07084
from the terraces -- eighteen in all -- broad flights of steps descend into the water or onto still more terraces barely above the level of the river .	52.51047
out of water , brick , and tile they have made far more than just a bridge .	82.76542
on spring and summer evenings people leave their shops and houses and walk up through the lanes of the city to the bridge .	32.346275
the bridge itself rises up from the river , light-flared and enormous , like the outdoor set for an epic opera .	57.00807
crowds press along the terraces , down the steps , in and out of the arcades , massing against it as though it were a fortress under siege .	36.45555
all kinds come to walk in the promenade merchants from the bazaar bickering over a deal	105.29279
a bakhtiari khan in a cap and hacking jacket	7.0996
dervishes who stand with the stillness of the blind , their eyes filmed with rheum and visions	25.095388
the old kajar princes arriving in their ancient limousines	1.3839794
students , civil servants , beggars , musicians , hawkers , and clowns .	4.056369
families go out to the edge of the terraces to sit on carpets around a samovar .	22.051102
below , people line the steps , as though on bleachers , to watch the sky and river .	45.498306
above , in the tiled prosceniums of the alcoves , boys sing the ghazals of hafiz and saadi , while at the very bottom , in the vaults , the toughs and blades of the city hoot and bang their drums , drink arak , play dice , and dance .	23.036386
here in an evening persians enjoy many of the things which are important to them poetry , water , the moon , a beautiful face .	67.80418
to a stranger their delight in these things may seem paradoxical , for persians chase the golden calf as much as any people .	87.007
many of them , moreover , are beginning to complain about the scarcity of western amusements and to ridicule the old life of the bazaar merchant , the mullah , and the peasant .	19.409018
nonetheless , they take time out -- much time -- from the game of grab and these new western experiments to go to the gardens and riverbanks .	68.49762
above all , they will stop in the middle of anything , anywhere , to hear or quote some poetry .	138.9168
poetry in persian life is far more than a common ground on which -- in a society deeply fissured by antagonisms -- all may stand .	75.364136
it contains , in fact , their whole outlook on life .	51.081154
and it is expressed , at least to their taste , in a perfect form .	62.34609
poetry for a persian is nothing less than truth and beauty .	32.098434
in most western cultures today these twins have been sent away to the libraries and museums .	29.93447
in persia , where practically speaking there are no museums or libraries or , for that matter , hardly any books , the twins run free .	107.95861
it is perhaps difficult to conceive , but imagine that tonight on london bridge the teddy boys of the east end will gather to sing marlowe , herrick , shakespeare , and perhaps some lyrics of their own .	44.813194
that , at any rate , is what happens at the khaju bridge .	11.603014
boys and men go along the riverbank or to the alcoves in the top arcade .	13.335976
here in these little rooms -- or stages arched open to the sky and river -- they choose a few lines out of the hundreds they may know and sing them according to one of the modes into which persian music is divided .	94.46021
each mode is believed to have a specific attribute -- one inducing pleasure , another generosity , another love , and so on , to include all of the emotions .	98.62326
the singer simply matches the poem to a mode	156.24934
for example , the mode of bravery to this anonymous folk poem `` they brought me news that spring is in the plains and ahmad ' s blood the crimson tulip stains	37.458496
go , tell his aged mother that her son fought with a thousand foes , and he was one ' ' .	31.54324
or the mode of love to this fragment by a recent poet `` know ye , fair folk who dwell on earth or shall hereafter come to birth , that here , with dust upon his eyes , iraj , the sweet-tongued singer , lies .	88.46976
in this true lover ' s tomb interred a world of love lies sepulchred .	45.24013
these songs ( practically all persian music , for that matter ) are limited to a range of two octaves .	57.908607
yet within this limitation there is an astonishing variety design as intricate as that in the carpet or miniature , with the melodic line like the painted or woven line often flowing into an arabesque .	55.32868
die frist ist um , und wiederum verstrichen sind sieben jahr , the maestro quoted the flying dutchman , as he told of his career and wanderings , explaining that the number seven had significantly recurred in his life several times .	22.772873
the music director of the pittsburgh symphony orchestra , william steinberg , has molded his group into a prominent musical organization , which is his life .	62.739506
when he added to his pittsburgh commitments the directorship of the london philharmonic orchestra in 1958 , he conducted one hundred fifty concerts within nine months , `` commuting ' ' between the two cities .	22.96996
this schedule became too strenuous , even for the energetic and conscientious mr . steinberg .	33.973705
his london contract was rescinded , and now , he explains cheerfully , as a bright smile lightens his intense , mobile face , `` i conduct only one hundred and twenty concerts ' ' ! !	46.684086
our meeting took place in may , 1961 , during one of the maestro ' s stop-overs in new york , before he left for europe .	31.427433
as we began to converse in the lounge of his fifth avenue hotel , his restlessness and sensitivity to light and sound became immediately apparent .	57.18927
seeking an obscure , dark , relatively quiet corner in the airy room otherwise suffused with afternoon sunshine , he asked if the soft background music could be turned off .	60.545143
unfortunately , it was muzak , which automatically is piped into the public rooms , and which nolens volens had to be endured .	13.134552
as he talked about himself , time and again stuffing and dragging on his pipe , steinberg began to relax and the initial hurried feeling grew faint and was dispelled .	66.53909
did he come from a musical family ? ?	1.009347
yes though not professional musicians , they were a music-loving family .	22.695326
in his native cologne , where his mother taught him to play the piano , he was able to read notes before he learned the alphabet .	19.113026
she even devised a system of colors , whereby the boy could easily distinguish the different note values .	212.94063
when he started school at the age of five-and-a-half , he could not understand why the alphabet begins with the letter a , instead of c , as in the scale .	43.145355
because , like many other children , he intensely disliked practicing czerny etudes , he composed his own studies .	22.05411
when he was eight he began violin lessons .	5.159655
soon he was playing in the cologne municipal orchestra , and during world war 1 , , when musicians were scarce , he joined the opera orchestra as well .	37.598606
steinberg claims that these early years of orchestra participation were of invaluable help to his career .	132.03854
`` by observing the conductor ' ' , he says with a twinkle in his eyes , `` i learned how not to conduct ' ' .	19.420572
the musician ran away from school when he was fifteen , but this escapade did not save him from the gymnasium .	32.106716
simultaneously , he pursued his musical studies at the conservatory , receiving sound training in counterpoint and harmony , as well in the violin and piano .	16.162634
he became otto klemperer ' s personal assistant at the cologne opera , and a year later was promoted to the position of regular conductor .	23.204521
wasn ' t this an unusually young age to fill such a responsible post ? ?	63.871468
had he always wished to be a conductor ? ?	27.162605
no , originally he had hoped to become a concert pianist and had even performed as such .	143.91463
however , when he assumed the duties of a conductor , he relinquished his career as a pianist .	18.976183
five years were spent with the cologne opera , after which he was called to prague by alexander von zemlinsky , teacher of arnold schonberg and erich korngold .	18.035084
in 1927 he succeeded zemlinsky as opera director of the german theater at prague .	10.349166
during his tenure he also fulfilled guest engagements at the berlin state opera .	77.73906
two years later he became director of the frankfurt opera , where he remained until he lost this position in 1933 through the rise of the hitler regime .	63.673565
during these years the youthful conductor had contributed greatly to the high level of musical life in germany .	20.181892
he had presented the first german performances of puccini ' s manon lescaut and de falla ' s la vida breve .	3.9316368
the frankfurt years were particularly noteworthy for his performance of berg ' s wozzek soon after the berlin premiere under erich kleiber , and the world premiere of schonberg ' s von heute auf morgen .	8.806824
at the outset of his career , steinberg had dedicated himself to the advancement of contemporary music by vowing to do a schonberg work every year .	45.237347
in frankfurt , too , he directed the museum and opera house concerts which , in addition to the standard repertoire , featured novelties like erdmann ' s piano concerto and mahler ' s sixth symphony .	16.535948
because of the political upheaval in germany in the 1930 ' s , steinberg was forced to restrict his activities to the jewish community .	29.75018
through the frankfurt jewish kulturbund he began to give sonata recitals in synagogues , with cellist emanuel feuermann .	8.005798
as more and more jewish musicians lost their jobs with professional organizations steinberg united them into the frankfurt kulturbund orchestra , which also gave guest performances in other german cities .	54.061047
in 1936 he accepted the leadership of the berlin kulturbund .	41.29264
in the fall of that year the best musicians of the berlin and frankfurt kulturbund orchestras joined under the combined efforts of bronislaw hubermann and steinberg to become the palestine orchestra -- now known as the israel philharmonic orchestra -- with steinberg as founder-conductor .	31.66625
in 1938 , at the insistence of arturo toscanini , steinberg left germany for the united states , by way of switzerland .	37.41813
after he had spent the first three years in new york as associate conductor , at toscanini ' s invitation , of the nbc orchestra , he made numerous guest appearances throughout the united states and latin america .	26.804829
in 1945 he became conductor of the buffalo philharmonic .	4.1202974
seven years later he was asked to become director of the pittsburgh symphony .	13.372938
since 1944 he has also conducted regularly at the san francisco opera , where he made his debut with a memorable performance of verdi ' s falstaff .	14.161439
in recent years he has traveled widely in europe , conducting in italy , france , austria , and switzerland .	20.2944
he returned to germany for the first time in 1953 , where he has since conducted in cologne , frankfurt , and berlin .	28.610216
where in europe was he going now ? ?	1.1753361
first of all , to italy for a short vacation -- forte dei marmi , a place he loves .	60.69189
since it is not far from viareggio , he will visit puccini ' s house , as he never fails to do , to pay his respects to the memory of the composer of la boheme , which he considers one of puccini ' s masterpieces .	20.676409
steinberg spoke with warmth and enthusiasm about italy `` rome is my second home .	102.35987
i consider it the center of the world and make it a point to be there once a year ' ' .	61.834953
he will conduct two concerts at the accademia di santa cecilia , as well as concerts in munich and cologne .	17.021885
`` then i return to the united states for engagements at the hollywood bowl and in philadelphia ' ' , he added .	38.62859
the forthcoming season in pittsburgh also promises to be of unusual interest .	45.23561
there will be premieres of new works , made possible through ford foundation commissions carlisle floyd ' s mystery , with phyllis curtin as soprano soloist .	46.28833
other world premieres will be gardner read ' s third symphony and burle marx ' s samba concertante .	10.073854
`` and next year we will do -- also a ford commission -- a piano concerto by elliott carter , with jacob lateiner as soloist .	35.792725
of course , i shall conduct mahler and bruckner works in the coming season , as usual .	90.483795
we ' ll play bruckner ' s fifth symphony in the original version , and mahler ' s seventh -- the least accessible , known , and played of mahler ' s works .	27.277382
my pittsburghers have become real addicts to mahler and bruckner ' ' .	5.2171416
he added that he also stresses the works of these favorite masters on tour , especially mahler ' s first and fourth symphonies , and das lied von der erde , and bruckner ' s sixth -- which is rarely played -- and seventh .	33.725567
bruckner ' s eighth he refers to as `` my travel symphony ' ' .	23.572515
he recalled that in california after a critic had attacked him for `` still trying to sell bruckner to the americans ' ' , the public ' s response at the next concert was a standing ovation .	44.24141
`` now that bruno walter is virtually in retirement and my dear friend dimitri mitropoulos is no longer with us , i am probably the only one -- with the possible exception of leonard bernstein -- who has this special affinity for and champions the works of bruckner and mahler ' ' .	47.525757
since he introduces so much modern music , i could not resist asking how he felt about it .	51.880905
`` there was always and at all times a contemporary music and it expresses the era in which it was created .	108.70645
but i usually stick to the old phrase ' ich habe ein amt , aber keine meinung ( i hold an office , but i do not feel entitled to have an opinion ) .	15.217531
i consider it to be my job to expose the public to what is being written today ' ' .	48.794792
with all his musical activities , did he have the time and inclination to do anything else ? ?	11.750512
he had just paid a brief visit to the frick collection to admire his favorite paintings by rembrandt and franz hals .	8.456482
he was not enthusiastic over the newly acquired claude lorrain , but reminisced with pleasure over a poussin exhibit he had been able to see in paris a year ago .	31.995232
and how did he feel about modern art ? ?	6.7892337
again steinberg was cautious and replied with a smile that he was not exposed to it enough to hazard comments .	37.42131
`` as my wife puts it ' ' , he said , again with a twinkle in his eyes , `` all you know is your music .	21.671804
but after all , you never learned anything else ' ' ! !	5.2784634
like his late colleague , mitropoulos , he reads mystery stories , in particular sir arthur conan doyle .	51.036526
he cited heine and stendhal as favorites in literature .	54.03374
but his prime interest , apart from music , he insisted seriously , was his family -- his wife , daughter and son .	38.470177
at the moment he was excited about his son ' s having received the prix de rome in archaeology and was looking forward to being present this summer at the excavation of an etruscan tomb .	34.107677
`` both children are musical and my wife is a music lover of unfailing instinct and judgement ' ' .	20.923307
`` is the attitude of german youth comparable to that of `` the angry young men ' of england ' ' ? ?	26.590693
was the topic for a round-table discussion at the bayerische rundfunk in munich .	2.9361136
i was chairman , the only not youthful participant .	7.633781
since attack serves to stimulate interest in broadcasts , i added to my opening statement a sentence in which i claimed that german youth seemed to lack the enthusiasm which is a necessary ingredient of anger , and might be classified as uninterested and bored rather than angry .	81.84245
i was far from convinced of the truth of my statement , but could not think of anything that might evoke responses more quickly .	113.365326
`` it is easy for you to talk ' '	4.6595697
countered a twenty year old law student , `` you travel around the world .	49.265423
we would like to do that too ' ' .	1.4318194
`` but you want a job guaranteed when you return ' ' , i continued my attack .	43.53135
`` you must have some security ' ' , said a young clerk .	19.020363
when i mentioned that for my first long voyage i did not even have the money for the return fare , but had trusted to luck that i would earn a sufficient amount , the young people looked at me doubtingly .	47.640102
one girl expressed what was obviously in their minds .	10.915335
`` would you advise us to act the same way ? ?	21.955431
i think it is rather foolhardy to trust to luck ' ' .	29.834578
others mentioned that i might have had to ask friends or even strangers for help and that to be stranded in a foreign country without sufficient funds did not contribute to international understanding .	110.22925
the debate needed no additional controversy and soon i could ask each individually what he expected from life , what his hopes were and what his fears .	109.067924
though the four boys and two girls , the youngest nineteen years of age , the oldest twenty-four , came from varying backgrounds and had different professional and personal interests , there was surprising agreement among them .	44.08232
what they feared most was war or political instability in their own country .	9.083908
the ideal home , they agreed , would be a small private house or a city apartment of four to five rooms , just enough for a family consisting of husband , wife , and two children .	74.89355
no one wanted a larger family or no children , and none hoped for a castle or said that living in less settled circumstances would be satisfactory .	169.47003
all expressed interest in world affairs but no one offered to make any sacrifices to satisfy this interest .	59.246998
once again , as in the days of the founding fathers , america faces a stern test .	42.240826
that test , as president kennedy forthrightly depicted it in his state of the union message , will determine `` whether a nation organized and governed such as ours can endure ' ' .	45.222748
it is well then that in this hour both of `` national peril ' ' and of `` national opportunity ' ' we can take counsel with the men who made the nation .	46.04429
incapable of self-delusion , the founding fathers found the crisis of their time to be equally grave , and yet they had confidence that america would surmount it and that a republic of free peoples would prosper and serve as an example to a world aching for liberty .	35.682224
seven founders -- george washington , benjamin franklin , john adams , thomas jefferson , alexander hamilton , james madison and john jay -- determined the destinies of the new nation .	32.98708
in certain respects , their task was incomparably greater than ours today , for there was nobody before them to show them the way .	97.1174
as madison commented to jefferson in 1789 , `` we are in a wilderness without a single footstep to guide us .	43.383114
our successors will have an easier task ' ' .	1.3642985
they thought of themselves , to use jefferson ' s words , as `` the argonauts ' ' who had lived in `` the heroic age ' ' .	16.63147
accordingly , they took special pains to preserve their papers as essential sources for posterity .	134.99113
their writings assume more than dramatic or patriotic interest because of their conviction that the struggle in which they were involved was neither selfish nor parochial but , rather , as washington in his last wartime circular reminded his fellow countrymen , that `` with our fate will the destiny of unborn millions be involved ' ' .	93.09059
strong men with strong opinions , frank to the point of being refreshingly indiscreet , the founding seven were essentially congenial minds , and their agreements with each other were more consequential than their differences .	33.969624
even though in most cases the completion of the definitive editions of their writings is still years off , enough documentation has already been assembled to warrant drawing a new composite profile of the leadership which performed the heroic dual feats of winning american independence and founding a new nation .	75.637634
before merging them into a common profile it is well to remember that their separate careers were extraordinary .	52.4721
certainly no other seven american statesmen from any later period achieved so much in so concentrated a span of years .	210.68391
eldest of the seven , benjamin franklin , a new englander transplanted to philadelphia , wrote the most dazzling success story in our history .	35.113224
the young printer ' s apprentice achieved greatness in a half-dozen different fields , as editor and publisher , scientist , inventor , philanthropist and statesman .	13.870991
author of the albany plan of union , which , had it been adopted , might have avoided the revolution , he fought the colonists ' front-line battles in london , negotiated the treaty of alliance with france and the peace that ended the war , headed the state government of pennsylvania , and exercised an important moderating influence at the federal convention .	30.90189
on a military mission for his native virginia the youthful george washington touched off the french and indian war , then guarded his colony ' s frontier as head of its militia .	77.26454
commanding the continental army for six long years of the revolution , he was the indispensable factor in the ultimate victory .	37.790604
retiring to his beloved mount vernon , he returned to preside over the federal convention , and was the only man in history to be unanimously elected president .	41.055157
during his two terms the constitution was tested and found workable , strong national policies were inaugurated , and the traditions and powers of the presidential office firmly fixed .	95.72158
john adams fashioned much of pre-revolutionary radical ideology , wrote the constitution of his home state of massachusetts , negotiated , with franklin and jay , the peace with britain and served as our first vice president and our second president .	63.52054
his political opponent and lifetime friend , thomas jefferson , achieved immortality through his authorship of the declaration of independence , but equally notable were the legal and constitutional reforms he instituted in his native virginia , his role as father of our territorial system , and his acquisition of the louisiana territory during his first term as president .	48.766262
during the greater part of jefferson ' s career he enjoyed the close collaboration of a fellow virginian , james madison , eight years his junior .	71.02053
the active sponsor of jefferson ' s measure for religious liberty in virginia , madison played the most influential single role in the drafting of the constitution and in securing its ratification in virginia , founded the first political party in american history , and , as jefferson ' s secretary of state and his successor in the presidency , guided the nation through the troubled years of our second war with britain .	37.53818
if franklin was an authentic genius , then alexander hamilton , with his exceptional precocity , consuming energy , and high ambition , was a political prodigy .	17.298504
his revolutionary pamphlets , published when he was only 19 , quickly brought him to the attention of the patriot leaders .	49.19606
principal author of `` the federalist ' ' , he swung new york over from opposition to the constitution to ratification almost single-handedly .	76.45452
his collaboration with washington , begun when he was the general ' s aide during the revolution , was resumed when he entered the first cabinet as secretary of the treasury .	26.513067
his bold fiscal program and his broad interpretation of the constitution stand as durable contributions .	77.979935
less dazzling than hamilton , less eloquent than jefferson , john jay commands an equally high rank among the founding fathers .	57.3102
he served as president of the continental congress .	9.682441
he played the leading role in negotiating the treaty with great britain that ended the revolution , and directed america ' s foreign affairs throughout the confederation period .	36.74724
as first chief justice , his strong nationalist opinions anticipated john marshall .	309.89713
he ended his public career as a two-term governor of new york .	13.409539
these seven founders constituted an intellectual and social elite , the most respectable and disinterested leadership any revolution ever confessed .	49.051914
their social status was achieved in some cases by birth , as with washington , jefferson and jay	89.71914
in others by business and professional acumen , as with franklin and adams , or , in hamilton ' s case , by an influential marriage .	65.04776
unlike so many of the power-starved intellectuals in underdeveloped nations of our own day , they commanded both prestige and influence before the revolution started .	103.60849
as different physically as the tall , angular jefferson was from the chubby , rotund adams , the seven were striking individualists .	42.64908
ardent , opinionated , even obstinate , they were amazingly articulate , wrote their own copy , and were masters of phrasemaking .	25.060661
capable of enduring friendships , they were also stout controversialists , who could write with a drop of vitriol on their pens .	15.50961
john adams dismissed john dickinson , who voted against the declaration of independence , as `` a certain great fortune and piddling genius ' ' .	13.862914
washington castigated his critic , general conway , as being capable of `` all the meanness of intrigue to gratify the absurd resentment of disappointed vanity ' ' .	17.801327
and hamilton , who felt it `` a religious duty ' ' to oppose aaron burr ' s political ambitions , would have been a better actuarial risk had he shown more literary restraint .	45.85986
the seven founders were completely dedicated to the public service .	19.62252
madison once remarked `` my life has been so much a public one ' ' , a comment which fits the careers of the other six .	69.42813
franklin retired from editing and publishing at the age of 42 , and for the next forty-two years devoted himself to public , scientific , and philanthropic interests .	31.120829
washington never had a chance to work for an extended stretch at the occupation he loved best , plantation management .	180.24326
he served as commander in chief during the revolution without compensation .	83.592545
john adams took to heart the advice given him by his legal mentor , jeremiah gridley , to `` pursue the study of the law , rather than the gain of it ' ' .	15.288692
in taking account of seventeen years of law practice , adams concluded that `` no lawyer in america ever did so much business as i did ' ' and `` for so little profit ' ' .	70.42055
when the revolution broke out , he , along with jefferson and jay , abandoned his career at the bar , with considerable financial sacrifice .	99.25128
hamilton , poorest of the seven , gave up a brilliant law practice to enter washington ' s cabinet .	122.45616
while he was handling the multi-million-dollar funding operations of the government he had to resort to borrowing small sums from friends .	60.07905
`` if you can conveniently let me have twenty dollars ' ' , he wrote one friend in 1791 when he was secretary of the treasury .	38.558117
to support his large family hamilton went back to the law after each spell of public service .	60.600254
talleyrand passed his new york law office one night on the way to a party .	52.622047
hamilton was bent over his desk , drafting a legal paper by the light of a candle .	30.012707
`` i have just come from viewing a man who had made the fortune of his country , but now is working all night in order to support his family ' ' , he reflected .	70.29964
all seven combined ardent devotion to the cause of revolution with a profound respect for legality .	23.013353
john adams asserted in the continental congress ' declaration of rights that the demands of the colonies were in accordance with their charters , the british constitution and the common law , and jefferson appealed in the declaration of independence `` to the tribunal of the world ' ' for support of a revolution justified by `` the laws of nature and of nature ' s god ' ' .	19.396103
they fought hard , but they were forgiving to former foes , and sought to prevent vindictive legislatures from confiscating tory property in violation of the treaty of 1783 .	19.935688
this sense of moderation and fairness is superbly exemplified in an exchange of letters between john jay and a tory refugee , peter van schaack .	29.899399
jay had participated in the decision that exiled his old friend van schaack .	40.918995
yet when , at war ' s end , the ex-tory made the first move to resume correspondence , jay wrote him from paris , where he was negotiating the peace settlement	58.50944
`` as an independent american i considered all who were not for us , and you amongst the rest , as against us , yet be assured that john jay never ceased to be the friend of peter van schaack ' ' .	37.809387
the latter in turn assured him that `` were i arraigned at the bar , and you my judge , i should expect to stand or fall only by the merits of my cause ' ' .	67.96308
all seven recognized that independence was but the first step toward building a nation .	48.69332
`` we have now a national character to establish ' ' , washington wrote in 1783 .	46.73774
`` think continentally ' ' , hamilton counseled the young nation .	179.83212
this new force , love of country , super-imposed upon -- if not displacing -- affectionate ties to one ' s own state , was epitomized by washington .	34.388218
his first inaugural address speaks of `` my country whose voice i can never hear but with veneration and love ' ' .	56.59764
all sought the fruition of that nationalism in a federal government with substantial powers .	76.58446
save jefferson , all participated in the framing or ratification of the federal constitution .	9.615375
they supported it , not as a perfect instrument , but as the best obtainable .	23.266378
historians have traditionally regarded the great debates of the seventeen nineties as polarizing the issues of centralized vs . limited government , with hamilton and the nationalists supporting the former and jefferson and madison upholding the latter position .	42.294582
the state ' s rights position was formulated by jefferson and madison in the kentucky and virginia resolves , but in their later careers as heads of state the two proved themselves better hamiltonians than jeffersonians .	90.19789
in purchasing louisiana , jefferson had to adopt hamilton ' s broad construction of the constitution , and so did madison in advocating the rechartering of hamilton ' s bank , which he had so strenuously opposed at its inception , and in adopting a hamiltonian protective tariff .	33.5354
indeed , the old jeffersonians were far more atune to the hamilton-oriented whigs than they were to the jacksonian democrats .	10.778293
when , in 1832 , the south carolina nullifiers adopted the principle of state interposition which madison had advanced in his old virginia resolve , they elicited no encouragement from that senior statesman .	69.03206
in his political testament , `` advice to my country ' ' , penned just before his death , madison expressed the wish `` that the union of the states be cherished and perpetuated .	43.157825
let the open enemy to it be regarded as a pandora with her box opened	127.95539
and the disguised one , as the serpent creeping with his deadly wiles into paradise ' ' .	25.764214
nostalgic yankee readers of erskine caldwell are today informed by proud georgians that tobacco road is buried beneath a four-lane super highway , over which travel each day suburbanite businessmen more concerned with the dow-jones average than with the cotton crop .	42.468132
thus we are compelled to face the urbanization of the south -- an urbanization which , despite its dramatic and overwhelming effects upon the southern culture , has been utterly ignored by the bulk of southern writers .	42.8646
indeed , it seems that only in today ' s southern fiction does tobacco road , with all the traditional trimmings of sowbelly and cornbread and mint juleps , continue to live -- but only as a weary , overexploited phantom .	24.4877
those writers known collectively as the `` southern school ' ' have received accolades from even those critics least prone to eulogize	101.78162
according to many critics , in fact , the south has led the north in literature since the civil war , both quantitatively and qualitatively .	27.76998
such writers as william faulkner and robert penn warren have led the field of somewhat less important writers in a sort of post-bellum renaissance .	77.45703
it is interesting , however , that despite this strong upsurge in southern writing , almost none of the writers has forsaken the firmly entrenched concept of the white-suited big-daddy colonel sipping a mint julep as he silently recounts the revenue from the season ' s cotton and tobacco crops	33.867058
of the stereotyped negro servants chanting hymns as they plow the fields	35.616337
of these and a host of other antiquated legends that deny the south its progressive leaps of the past century .	30.729303
this is not to say that the south is no longer agrarian	25.28542
such a statement would be the rankest form of oversimplification .	5.3319416
but the south is , and has been for the past century , engaged in a wide-sweeping urbanization which , oddly enough , is not reflected in its literature .	32.907864
in 1950 it had become 47 . 1% urban .	147.17348
in a mere half-century the south has more than tripled its urban status .	7.2405787
there is a new south emerging , a south losing the folksy traditions of an agrarian society with the rapidity of an avalanche -- especially within recent decades .	34.467518
as the new south snowballs toward further urbanization , it becomes more and more homogeneous with the north -- a tendency which willard thorp terms `` yankeefication ' ' , as evidenced in such cities as charlotte , birmingham , and houston .	31.911636
it is said that , even at the present stage of southern urbanization , such a city as atlanta is not distinctly unlike columbus or trenton .	114.621544
undoubtedly even the old southern stalwart richmond has felt the new wind william styron mentions in his latest novel an avenue named for bankhead mcgruder , a civil war general , now renamed , in typical california fashion , `` buena vista terrace ' ' .	39.421906
the effects of television and other mass media are erasing regional dialects and localisms with a startling force .	23.863747
as for progress , the `` backward south ' ' can boast of baton rouge , which increased its population between 1940 and 1950 by two hundred and sixty-two percent , to 126 , 000 , the second largest growth of the period for all cities over 25 , 000 .	32.95114
the field , then , is ripe for new southerners to step to the fore and write of this twentieth-century phenomenon , the southern yankeefication the new urban economy , the city-dweller , the pains of transition , the labor problems	52.96089
truman capote is still reveling in southern gothicism , exaggerating the old southern legends into something beautiful and grotesque , but as unreal as -- or even more unreal than -- yesterday .	54.998745
william styron , while facing the changing economy with a certain uneasy reluctance , insists he is not to be classified as a southern writer and yet includes traditional southern concepts in everything he publishes .	70.366005
even the great god faulkner , the south ' s one probable contender for literary immortality , has little concerned himself with these matters	129.20517
such are simply not within his bounded province .	3.2730753
where are the writers to treat these changes ? ?	16.009811
has the agrarian tradition become such an addiction that the switch to urbanism is somehow dreaded or unwanted ? ?	19.465439
perhaps present writers hypnotically cling to the older order because they consider it useful and reliable through repeated testings over the decades .	88.31916
lacking the pioneer spirit necessary to write of a new economy , these writers seem to be contenting themselves with an old one that is now as defunct as confederate money .	52.23646
an example of the changes which have crept over the southern region may be seen in the southern negro ' s quest for a position in the white-dominated society , a problem that has been reflected in regional fiction especially since 1865 .	36.11355
today the negro must discover his role in an industrialized south , which indicates that the racial aspect of the southern dilemma hasn ' t changed radically , but rather has gradually come to be reflected in this new context , this new coat of paint .	48.25335
the negro faces as much , if not more , difficulty in fitting himself into an urban economy as he did in an agrarian one .	123.05532
this represents a gradual change in an ever-present social problem .	28.463621
but there have been abrupt changes as well the sit-ins , the picket lines , the bus strikes -- all of these were unheard-of even ten years ago .	27.698956
today ' s evidence , such as the fact that only three southern states ( south carolina , alabama and mississippi ) still openly defy integration , would have astounded many of yesterday ' s southerners into speechlessness .	78.36948
other examples of gradual changes that have affected the negro have been his moving up , row by row , in the buses	127.1064
his requesting , and often getting , higher wages , better working conditions , better schools -- changes that were slowly emerging even before the supreme court decision of 1954 .	96.70852
then came this decision , which sped the process of gaining equality ( or perhaps hindered it	50.30111
only historical evolution will determine which ) an abrupt change .	3.723007
since 1954 the negro ' s desire for social justice has led to an ironically anarchical rebellion .	18.257708
he has frequently refused to move from white lunch counters , refused to obey local laws which he considers unjust , while in other cases he has appealed to federal laws .	42.637295
this bold self-assertion , after decades of humble subservience , is indeed a twentieth-century phenomenon , an abrupt change in the southern way of existence .	19.887783
a new order is thrusting itself into being .	104.47076
a new south is emerging after the post-bellum years of hesitation , uncertainty , and lack of action from the negro in defining his new role in the amorphously defined socio-political organizations of the white man .	31.014812
the modern negro has not made a decisive debut into southern fiction .	64.55981
it is clear that , while most writers enjoy picturing the negro as a woolly-headed , humble old agrarian who mutters `` yassuhs ' ' and `` sho ' nufs ' ' with blissful deference to his white employer ( or , in old south terms , `` massuh ' ' ) , this stereotype is doomed to become in reality as obsolete as caldwell ' s lester .	27.610762
while there may still be many faulknerian lucas beauchamps scattered through the rural south , such men appear to be a vanishing breed .	58.702686
writers openly admit that the negro is easier to write than the white man	56.255344
but they obviously mean by this , not a negro personality , but a negro type .	83.77011
presenting an individualized negro character , it would seem , is one of the most difficult assignments a southern writer could tackle	82.56983
and the success of such an endeavor is , as suggested above , glaringly rare .	43.7789
