just as the negro situation points up the gradual and abrupt changes affecting southern life , it also points up the non-representation of urbanism in southern literature .	48.27005
the book concerned with the negro ' s role in an urban society is rare indeed	97.470825
recently only keith wheeler ' s novel , peaceable lane , has openly faced the problem .	41.597267
all but the most rabid of confederate flag wavers admit that the old southern tradition is defunct in actuality and sigh that its passing was accompanied by the disappearance of many genteel and aristocratic traditions of the reputedly languid ante-bellum way of life .	27.294455
many earlier writers , mourning the demise of the old order , tended to romanticize and exaggerate this `` gracious old south ' ' imagery , creating such lasting impressions as margaret mitchell ' s `` tara ' ' plantation .	24.658289
modern writers , who are supposed to keep their fingers firmly upon the pulse of their subjects , insist upon drawing out this legend , prolonging its burial , when it well deserves a rest after the overexploitation of the past century .	40.067207
perhaps these writers have been too deeply moved by this romanticizing	24.843157
but they can hardly deny that , exaggerated or not , the old panorama is dead .	55.046524
as john t . westbrook says in his article , `` twilight of southern regionalism ' ' ( southwest review , winter 1957 ) `` the miasmal mausoleum where an old south , already too minutely autopsied in prose and poetry , should be left to rest in peace , forever dead and ( let us fervently hope ) forever done with ' ' .	48.050346
westbrook further bemoans the southern writers ' creation of an unreal image of their homeland , which is too readily assimilated by both foreign readers and visiting yankees `` our northerner is suspicious of all this crass evidence ( of urbanization ) presented to his senses .	43.29774
he is too deeply steeped in william faulkner and robert penn warren .	16.921616
the fumes of progress are in his nose and the bright steel of industry towers before his eyes , but his heart is away in yoknapatawpha county with razorback hogs and night riders .	39.74232
on this trip to the south he wants , above all else , to sniff the effluvium of backwoods-and-sand-hill subhumanity and to see at least one barn burn at midnight ' ' .	17.4577
obviously , such a northern tourist ' s purpose is somewhat akin to a child ' s experience with disneyland he wants to see a world of make-believe .	32.276196
in the meantime , while the south has been undergoing this phenomenal modernization that is so disappointing to the curious yankee , southern writers have certainly done little to reflect and promote their region ' s progress .	70.66068
willard thorp , in his new book , american writing in the twentieth century , observes , quite validly it seems `` certain subjects are conspicuously absent or have been only lightly touched .	33.460194
no southern novelist has done for atlanta or birmingham what herrick , dreiser , and farrell did for chicago or dos passos did for new york .	27.943176
there are almost no fictional treatments of the industrialized south ' ' .	66.03202
not a single southern author , major or minor , has made the urban problems of an urban south his primary source material .	177.71465
faulkner , for one , appears to be safe from the accusing fingers of all assailants in this regard .	39.487217
faulkner culminates the southern legend perhaps more masterfully than it has ever been , or could ever be , done .	65.93099
he has made it his , and his it remains , irrevocably .	241.2631
he treats it with a mythological , universal application .	395.64935
as his disciples boast , even though his emphasis is elsewhere , faulkner does show his awareness of the changing order of the south quite keenly , as can be proven by a quick recalling of his sartoris and snopes families .	50.111732
even two decades ago in go down , moses faulkner was looking to the more urban future with a glimmer of hope that through its youth and its new way of life the south might be reborn and the curse of slavery erased from its soil .	68.538
yet his concern even here is with a slowly changing socio-economic order in general , and he never deals with such specific aspects of this change as the urban and industrial impact .	57.08669
faulkner traces , in his vast and overpowering saga of yoknapatawpha county , the gradual changes which seep into the south , building layer upon layer of minute , subtle innovation which eventually tend largely to hide the old way .	31.769533
thus faulkner reminds us , and wisely , that the `` new ' ' south has gradually evolved out of the old south , and consequently its agrarian roots persist .	38.410557
yet he presents a realm of source material which may well serve other writers if not himself the problems with which a new south must grapple in groping through a blind adolescence into the maturity of urbanization .	65.257866
with new mechanization the modern farmer must perform the work of six men a machine stands between the agrarian and his soil .	82.774734
the thousands of city migrants who desert the farms yearly must readjust with even greater stress and tension the sacred wilderness is gradually surrendering to suburbs and research parks and industrial areas .	69.769394
another element to concern the choreographer is that of the visual devices of the theatre .	31.717148
most avant-garde creators , true to their interest in the self-sufficiency of pure movement , have tended to dress their dancers in simple lines and solid colors ( often black ) and to give them a bare cyclorama for a setting .	32.063976
but robert rauschenberg , the neo-dadaist artist , has collaborated with several of them .	36.694008
he has designed a matching backdrop and costumes of points of color on white for mr . cunningham ' s summerspace , so that dancers and background merge into a shimmering unity .	40.26304
for mr . taylor ' s images and reflections she made some diaphanous tents that alternately hide and reveal the performer , and a girl ' s cape lined with grass .	30.95966
mr . nikolais has made a distinctive contribution to the arts of costume and decor .	10.316948
in fact , he calls his productions dance-theatre works of motion , shape , light , and sound .	62.776165
to raise the dancer out of his personal , pedestrian self , mr . nikolais has experimented with relating him to a larger , environmental orbit .	32.19366
he began with masks to make the dancer identify himself with the creature he appeared to be .	61.303772
he went on to use objects -- hoops , poles , capes -- which he employed as extensions of the body of the dancer , who moved with them .	35.57706
the depersonalization continued as the dancer was further metamorphosed by the play of lights upon his figure .	34.40716
in each case , the object , the color , even the percussive sounds of the electronic score were designed to become part of the theatrical being of the performer .	29.063074
the dancer who never loosens her hold on a parasol , begins to feel that it is part of herself .	47.9162
or , clad from head to toe in fabric stretched over a series of hoops , the performer may well lose his sense of self in being a `` finial ' ' .	18.574137
as the dancer is depersonalized , his accouterments are animized , and the combined elements give birth to a new being .	58.14942
from this being come new movement ideas that utilize dancer and property as a single unit .	65.48405
thus , the avant-garde choreographers have extended the scope of materials available for dance composition .	44.480625
but , since they have rejected both narrative and emotional continuity , how are they to unify the impressive array of materials at their disposal ? ?	36.30636
some look deliberately to devices used by creators in the other arts and apply corresponding methods to their own work .	55.46689
others , less consciously but quite probably influenced by the trends of the times , experiment with approaches that parallel those of the contemporary poet , painter , and musician .	77.91188
an approach that has appealed to some choreographers is reminiscent of charles olson ' s statement of the process of projective verse `` one perception must immediately and directly lead to a further perception ' ' .	67.234764
the creator trusts his intuition to lead him along a path that has internal validity because it mirrors the reality of his experience .	68.341545
he disdains external restrictions -- conventional syntax , traditional metre .	43.56876
the unit of form is determined subjectively `` the heart , by the way of the breath , to the line ' ' .	21.943916
the test of form is fidelity to the experience , a gauge also accepted by the abstract expressionist painters .	42.744896
an earlier but still influential school of painting , surrealism , had suggested the way of dealing with the dream experience , that event in which seemingly incongruous objects are linked together through the curious associations of the subconscious .	39.044014
the resulting picture might appear a maze of restless confusions and contradictions , but it is more true to life than a portrait of an artificially contrived order .	22.4015
the contemporary painter tends to depict not the concrete objects of his experience but their essences as revealed in abstractions of their lines , colors , masses , and energies .	45.7425
he is still concerned , however , with a personal event .	98.19521
he accepts the accidents of his brushwork because they provide evidence of the vitality of the experience of creation .	17.91022
the work must be true to both the physical and the spiritual character of the experience .	30.384651
some painters have less interest in the experience of the moment , with its attendant urgencies and ambiguities , than in looking beyond the flux of particular impressions to a higher , more serene level of truth .	43.68034
rather than putting their trust in ephemeral sensations they seek form in the stable relationships of pure design , which symbolize an order more real than the disorder of the perceptual world .	79.43806
but in this approach it is the artist ' s ultimate insight , rather than his immediate impressions , that gives form to the work .	39.624115
others look to more objective devices of order .	3.87608
the musician employing the serial technique of composition establishes a mathematical system of rotations that , once set in motion , determines the sequence of pitches and even of rhythms and intensities .	26.873497
the composer may reverse or invert the order of his original set of intervals ( or rhythms or dynamic changes ) .	112.99802
he may even alter the pattern by applying a scheme of random numbers .	28.594858
but he cannot order his elements by will , either rational or inspired .	123.94112
musicians who use the chance method also exclude subjective control of formal development .	95.62705
again , the composer must select his own materials .	57.99803
but a tossing of coins , with perhaps the added safeguard of reference to the oracles of the i ching , the chinese book of changes , dictates the handling of the chosen materials .	60.978207
avant-garde choreographers , seeking new forms of continuity for their new vocabulary of movements , have turned to similar approaches .	65.26453
some let dances take their form from the experience of creation .	41.10074
according to katherine litz , `` the becoming , the process of realization , is the dance ' ' .	41.06768
the process stipulates that the choreographer sense the quality of the initial movement he has discovered and that he feel the rightness of the quality that is to follow it .	29.511505
the sequence may involve a sharp contrast for example , a quiet meditative sway of the body succeeded by a violent leap	28.675398
or it may involve more subtle distinctions the sway may be gradually minimized or enlarged , its rhythmic emphasis may be slightly modified , or it may be transferred to become a movement of only the arms or the head .	54.34849
even the least alteration will change the quality .	98.71195
an exploration of these possible relationships constitutes the process of creation and thereby gives form to the dance .	55.02857
the approach to the depiction of the experience of creation may be analytic , as it is for miss litz , or spontaneous , as it is for merle marsicano .	18.189585
she , too , is concerned with `` the becoming , the process of realization ' ' , but she does not think in terms of subtle variations of spatial or temporal patterns .	28.61843
the design is determined emotionally `` i must reach into myself for the spring that will send me catapulting recklessly into the chaos of event with which the dance confronts me ' ' .	30.852617
looking back , miss marsicano feels that her ideas may have been influenced by those of jackson pollock .	38.560307
at one time she felt impelled to make dances that `` moved all over the stage ' ' , much as pollock ' s paintings move violently over the full extent of the canvas .	45.656372
but her conscious need was to break away from constricting patterns of form , a need to let the experience shape itself .	121.63821
midi garth also believes in subjective continuity that begins with the feeling engendered by an initial movement .	40.207706
it may be a free front-back swing of the leg , leading to a sideways swing of the arm that develops into a turn and the sensation of taking off from the ground .	32.37526
this became a dance called prelude to flight .	5.6922126
a pervading quality of free lyricism and a building from turns close to the ground towards jumps into the air gives the work its central focus .	142.58041
alwin nikolais objects to art as an outpouring of personal emotion .	28.24174
he seeks to make his dancers more `` godlike ' ' by relating them to the impersonal elements of shape , light , color , and sound .	14.977402
if his dancers are sometimes made to look as if they might be creatures from mars , this is consistent with his intention of placing them in the orbit of another world , a world in which they are freed of their pedestrian identities .	36.718746
it is through the metamorphosed dancer that the germ of form is discovered .	48.26855
in his recognition of his impersonal self the dancer moves , and this self , in the `` first revealed stroke of its existence ' ' , states the theme from which all else must follow .	95.58042
the theme may be the formation of a shape from which other shapes evolve .	95.21791
it may be a reaction to a percussive sound , the following movements constituting further reactions .	119.61798
it may establish the relation of the figure of the dancer to light and color , in which case changes in the light or color will set off a kaleidescope of visual designs .	55.127033
unconcerned with the practical function of his actions , the dancer is engrossed exclusively in their `` motional content ' ' .	15.43646
movements unfold freely because they are uninhibited by emotional bias or purposive drive .	164.06422
though he is also concerned with freeing dance from pedestrian modes of activity , merce cunningham has selected a very different method for achieving his aim .	36.67614
he rejects all subjectively motivated continuity , any line of action related to the concept of cause and effect .	47.7221
he bases his approach on the belief that anything can follow anything .	61.20531
an order can be chanced rather than chosen , and this approach produces an experience that is `` free and discovered rather than bound and remembered ' ' .	72.44477
thus , there is freshness not only in the individual movements of the dance but in the shape of their continuity as well .	39.65948
chance , he finds , enables him to create `` a world beyond imagination ' ' .	54.00822
he cites with pleasure the comment of a lady , who exclaimed after a concert `` why , it ' s extremely interesting .	24.351393
but i would never have thought of it myself ' ' .	12.81239
the sequence of movements in a cunningham dance is unlike any sequence to be seen in life .	36.31143
at one side of the stage a dancer jumps excitedly	2.2555368
nearby , another sits motionless , while still another is twirling an umbrella .	25.799564
they look straight at the audience , not at each other .	122.98768
he lifts her , puts her down , and walks off , neither pleased nor disturbed , as if nothing had happened .	47.59857
if one dancer slaps another , the victim may do a pirouette , sit down , or offer his assailant a fork and spoon .	52.25537
their consequences are irrelevant -- or there are no consequences at all .	28.645538
the sequence is determined by chance , and mr . cunningham makes use of any one of several chance devices .	99.75146
he may take slips of paper from a grab bag .	28.957811
the answers derived by these means may determine not only the temporal organization of the dance but also its spatial design , special slips designating the location on the stage where the movement is to be performed .	46.312706
the other variables include the dancer who is to perform the movement and the length of time he is to take in its performance .	50.644913
the only factors that are personally set by the choreographer are the movements themselves , the number of the dancers , and the approximate total duration of the dance .	35.12717
the `` approximate ' ' is important , because even after the order of the work has been established by the chance method , the result is not inviolable .	44.885788
if a work is divided into several large segments , a last-minute drawing of random numbers may determine the order of the segments for any particular performance .	27.928268
and any sequence can not only change its positions in the work but can even be eliminated from it altogether .	80.95275
mr . cunningham tries not to cheat the chance method	91.671135
he adheres to its dictates as faithfully as he can .	106.797714
however , there is always the possibility that chance will make demands the dancers find impossible to execute .	264.63437
he must rearrange matters so that two performers do not bump into each other .	17.734446
he must construct transitions so that a dancer who is told to lie prone one second and to leap wildly the next will have some physical preparation for the leap .	155.9975
the north and the south were in greater agreement on sovereignty , through all their dispute about it , than were the founding fathers .	158.58215
the truth in their conflicting concepts was expounded by statesmen of the calibre of webster and calhoun , and defended in the end by leaders of the nobility of lincoln and lee .	28.624529
the people everywhere had grown meanwhile in devotion to basic democratic principles , in understanding of and belief in the federal balance , and in love of their union .	97.499466
repeated efforts -- beginning with the missouri compromise of 1821 -- were made by such master moderates as clay and douglas to resolve the difference peacefully by compromise , rather than clear thought and timely action .	54.28527
even so , confusion in this period gained such strength ( from compromise and other factors ) that it led to the bloodiest war of the nineteenth century .	32.77403
nothing can show more than this the immensity of the danger to democratic peoples that lies in even relatively slight deviation from their true concept of sovereignty .	108.36529
the present issue in atlantica -- whether to transform an alliance of sovereign nations into a federal union of sovereign citizens -- resembles the american one of 1787-89 rather than the one that was resolved by civil war .	52.656628
and so i would only touch upon it now ( much as i have long wanted to write a book about it ) .	72.01906
i think it is essential , however , to pinpoint here the difference between the two concepts of sovereignty that went to war in 1861 -- if only to see better how imperative is our need today to clarify completely our far worse confusion on this subject .	88.62911
the difference came down to this the southern states insisted that the united states was , in last analysis , what its name implied -- a union of states .	52.01122
to their leaders the constitution was a compact made by the people of sovereign states , who therefore retained the right to secede from it .	60.98571
this right of the state , its upholders contended , was essential to maintain the federal balance and protect the liberty of the people from the danger of centralizing power in the union government .	24.467518
the champions of the union maintained that the constitution had formed , fundamentally , the united people of america , that it was a compact among sovereign citizens rather than states , and that therefore the states had no right to secede , though the citizens could .	67.71975
writing to speed on august 24 , 1855 , lincoln made the latter point clear .	251.97125
in homely terms whose timeliness is startling today , he thus declared his own right to secede .	64.667
we began by declaring that all men are created equal .	10.191417
we now practically read it , all men are created equal except negroes .	32.3474
when the know-nothings get control , it will read , all men are created equal except negroes and foreigners and catholics .	63.087196
when it comes to this , i shall prefer emigrating to some country where they make no pretence of loving liberty -- to russia , for instance , where despotism can be taken pure , without the base alloy of hypocrisy ' ' ( his emphasis )	46.184258
when the southern states exercised their `` right to secede ' ' , they formed what they officially styled `` the confederate states of america ' ' .	14.591961
dictionaries , as we have seen , still cite this government , along with the articles of confederation of 1781 , as an example of a confederacy .	38.360653
the fact is that the southern confederacy differed from the earlier one almost as much as the federal constitution did .	69.28043
the confederate constitution copied much of the federal constitution verbatim , and most of the rest in substance .	16.198988
it operated on , by and for the people individually just as did the federal constitution .	85.80222
it made substantially the same division of power between the central and state governments , and among the executive , legislative and judicial branches .	50.69528
the difference between confederacy and federal union in 1861	20.199106
many believe -- and understandably -- that the great difference between the constitution of the southern confederacy and the federal constitution was that the former recognized the right of each state to secede .	42.33559
but though each of its members had asserted this right against the union , the final constitution which the confederacy signed on march 11 -- nearly a month before hostilities began -- included no explicit provision authorizing a state to secede .	76.34801
its drafters discussed this vital point but left it out of their constitution .	50.03414
their president , jefferson davis , interpreted their constitution to mean that it `` admits of no coerced association ' ' , but this remained so doubtful that `` there were frequent demands that the right to secede be put into the constitution ' ' .	38.792233
the constitution of the southern `` confederation ' ' differed from that of the federal union only in two important respects it openly , defiantly , recognized slavery -- an institution which the southerners of 1787 , even though they continued it , found so impossible to reconcile with freedom that they carefully avoided mentioning the word in the federal constitution .	64.41089
they recognized that slavery was a moral issue and not merely an economic interest , and that to recognize it explicitly in their constitution would be in explosive contradiction to the concept of sovereignty they had set forth in the declaration of 1776 that `` all men are created equal , that they are endowed by their creator with certain unalienable rights , that among them are life , liberty and the pursuit of happiness .	40.310043
' ' the other important difference between the two constitutions was that the president of the confederacy held office for six ( instead of four ) years , and was limited to one term .	70.11972
these are not , however , differences in federal structure .	72.977425
the only important differences from that standpoint , between the two constitutions , lies in their preambles .	15.6826935
the one of 1861 made clear that in making their government the people were acting through their states , whereas the preamble of 1787-89 expressed , as clearly as language can , the opposite concept , that they were acting directly as citizens .	101.57095
here are the two preambles federal constitution , 1789	541.71405
`` we the people of the united states , in order to form a more perfect union , establish justice , insure domestic tranquility , provide for the common defence , promote the general welfare , and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity , do ordain and establish this constitution for the united states of america ' ' .	29.53309
`` we the people of the confederate states , each state acting in its sovereign and independent character , in order to form a permanent federal government , establish justice , insure domestic tranquility , and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity -- invoking the favor and the guidance of almighty god -- do ordain and establish this constitution for the confederate states of america ' ' .	33.860874
one is tempted to say that , on the difference between the concepts of sovereignty in these two preambles , the worst war of the nineteenth century was fought .	24.226044
but though the southern states , when drafting a constitution to unite themselves , narrowed the difference to this fine point by omitting to assert the right to secede , the fact remained that by seceding from the union they had already acted on the concept that it was composed primarily of sovereign states .	31.720602
if the union conceded this to them , the same right must be conceded to each remaining state whenever it saw fit to secede this would destroy the federal balance between it and the states , and in the end sacrifice to the sovereignty of the states all the liberty the citizens had gained by their union .	93.72677
lincoln saw that the act of secession made the issue for the union a vital one whether it was a union of sovereign citizens that should continue to live , or an association of sovereign states that must fall prey either to `` anarchy or despotism ' ' .	57.224426
much as he abhorred slavery , lincoln was always willing to concede to each `` slave state ' ' the right to decide independently whether to continue or end it .	53.361187
though his election was interpreted by many southerners as the forerunner of a dangerous shift in the federal balance in favor of the union , lincoln himself proposed no such change in the rights the constitution gave the states .	66.71106
after the war began , he long refused to permit emancipation of the slaves by union action even in the border states that stayed with the union .	67.470085
he issued his emancipation proclamation only when he felt that necessity left him no other way to save the union .	144.19832
in his message of december 2 , 1862 , he put his purpose and his policy in these words -- which i would call the lincoln law of liberty-and-union `` in giving freedom to the slave , we assure freedom to the free ' ' .	43.081585
what lincoln could not concede was that the states rather than the people were sovereign in the union .	153.52751
he fought to the end to preserve it as a `` government of the people , by the people , for the people ' ' .	25.446014
the truth on each side won in the civil war	5.159238
the fact that the americans who upheld the sovereignty of their states did this in order to keep many of their people more securely in slavery -- the antithesis of individual liberty -- made the conflict grimmer , and the greater .	56.36742
out of this ordeal the citizen emerged , in the south as in the north , as america ' s true sovereign , in `` a new birth of freedom ' ' , as lincoln promised .	45.991524
but before this came about , 214 , 938 americans had given their lives in battle for the two concepts of the sovereign rights of men and of states .	56.24153
on their decisive battlefield lincoln did not distinguish between them when he paid tribute to the `` brave men , living and dead , who fought here ' ' .	44.60906
he understood that both sides were at fault , and he reached the height of saying so explicitly in his second inaugural .	26.613567
to my knowledge , lincoln remains the only head of state and commander-in-chief who , while fighting a fearful war whose issue was in doubt , proved man enough to say this publicly -- to give his foe the benefit of the fact that in all human truth there is some error , and in all our error , some truth .	126.82446
so great a man could not but understand , too , that the thing that moves men to sacrifice their lives is not the error of their thought , which their opponents see and attack , but the truth which the latter do not see -- any more than they see the error which mars the truth they themselves defend .	81.074356
it is much less difficult now than in lincoln ' s day to see that on both sides sovereign americans had given their lives in the civil war to maintain the balance between the powers they had delegated to the states and to their union .	45.572838
they differed in the balance they believed essential to the sovereignty of the citizen -- but the supreme sacrifice each made served to maintain a still more fundamental truth that individual life , liberty and happiness depend on a right balance between the two -- and on the limitation of sovereignty , in all its aspects , which this involves .	62.967525
the 140 , 414 americans who gave `` the last full measure of devotion ' ' to prevent disunion , preserved individual freedom in the united states from the dangers of anarchy , inherent in confederations , which throughout history have proved fatal in the end to all associations composed primarily of sovereign states , and to the liberties of their people .	40.812218
but the fact that 70 , 524 other americans gave the same measure of devotion to an opposing concept served liberty-and-union in other essential ways .	52.663105
its appeal from ballots to bullets at fort sumter ended by costing the southerners their right to have slaves -- a right that was even less compatible with the sovereignty of man .	67.35786
the very fact that they came so near to winning by the wrong method , war , led directly to their losing both the war and the wrong thing they fought for , since it forced lincoln to free their slaves as a military measure .	108.41381
there was a divine justice in one wrong thus undoing another .	104.11533
there was also a lesson , one that has served ever since to keep americans , in their conflicts with one another , from turning from the ballot to the bullet .	65.42259
yet though the southern states lost the worst errors in their case , they did not lose the truth they fought for .	60.381382
the lives so many of them gave , to forestall what they believed would be a fatal encroachment by the union on the powers reserved to their states have continued ever since to safeguard all americans against freedom ' s other foe .	67.37122
as cells coalesced into organisms , they built new `` unnatural ' ' and internally controlled environments to cope even more successfully with the entropy-increasing properties of the external world .	37.206356
the useful suggestion of professor david hawkins which considers culture as a third stage in biological evolution fits quite beautifully then with our suggestion that science has provided us with a rather successful technique for building protective artificial environments .	71.94108
will advances in human sciences help us build social structures and governments which will enable us to cope with people as effectively as the primitive combination of protein and nucleic acid built a structure of molecules which enabled it to adapt to a sea of molecular interaction ? ?	25.849726
the answer is , of course , yes .	3.5027528
for the family is the simplest example of just such a unit , composed of people , which gives us both some immunity from , and a way of dealing with , other people .	145.58221
social invention did not have to await social theory any more than use of the warmth of a fire had to await lavoisier or the buoyant protection of a boat the formulations of archimedes .	51.226814
but it has been during the last two centuries , during the scientific revolution , that our independence from the physical environment has made the most rapid strides .	43.13211
the temperature of our homes is independent of the seasons	44.484272
we fly through the air , although gravity pulls us down	98.0354
at what stage are social sciences then ? ?	1.0500429
is the future of psychology akin to the rich future of physics at the time of newton ? ?	46.029778
there is a haunting resemblance between the notion of cause in copernicus and in freud .	87.63427
and it is certainly no slight to either of them to compare both their achievements and their impact .	85.15785
political theoretical understanding , although almost at a standstill during this century , did develop during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries , and resulted in a flood of inventions which increased the possibility for man to coexist with man .	33.22438
consitutional government , popular vote , trial by jury , public education , labor unions , cooperatives , communes , socialized ownership , world courts , and the veto power in world councils are but a few examples .	37.22103
most of these , with horrible exceptions , were conceived as is a ship , not as an attempt to quell the ocean of mankind , nor to deny its force , but as a means to survive and enjoy it .	50.66235
the most effective political inventions seem to make maximum use of natural harbors and are aware that restraining breakwaters can play only a minor part in the whole scheme .	74.03679
just as present technology had to await the explanations of physics , so one might expect that social invention will follow growing sociological understanding .	40.97623
we are desperately in the need of such invention , for man is still very much at the mercy of man .	43.32837
in fact the accumulation of the hardware of destruction is day by day increasing our fear of each other .	240.02975
i want , therefore , to discuss a second and quite different fruit of science , the connection between scientific understanding and fear .	74.657326
there are certainly large areas of understanding in the human sciences which in themselves and even without political invention can help to dispel our present fears .	105.13441
lucretius has remarked `` the reason why all mortals are so gripped by fear is that they see all sorts of things happening in the earth and sky with no discernable cause , and these they attribute to the will of god ' ' .	41.139385
it is difficult to reconstruct the primeval fears of man .	13.499454
we get some clue from a few remembrances of childhood and from the circumstance that we are probably not much more afraid of people now than man ever was .	95.763084
we are not now afraid of atomic bombs in the same way that people once feared comets .	64.62816
the bombs are as harmless as an automobile in a garage .	13.3805
we are worried about what people may do with them -- that some crazy fool may `` push the button ' ' .	37.42974
i am certainly not adequately trained to describe or enlarge on human fears , but there are certain features of the fears dispelled by scientific explanations that stand out quite clearly .	62.72784
they are in general those fears that once seemed to have been amenable to prayer or ritual .	20.734755
they include both individual fears and collective ones .	2.0803287
they arise in situations in which one believes that what happens depends not only on the external world , but also on the precise pattern of behavior of the individual or group .	51.168053
often it is recognized that all the details of the pattern may not be essential to the outcome but , because the pattern was empirically determined and not developed through theoretical understanding , one is never quite certain which behavior elements are effective , and the whole pattern becomes ritualized .	84.01581
yet often fear persists because , even with the most rigid ritual , one is never quite free from the uneasy feeling that one might make some mistake or that in every previous execution one had been unaware of the really decisive act .	73.21681
to say that science had reduced many such fears merely reiterates the obvious and frequent statement that science eliminated much of magic and superstition .	166.04057
but a somewhat more detailed analysis of this process may be illuminating .	18.380117
the frequently postulated antique worry that the daylight hours might dwindle to complete darkness apparently gave rise to a ritual and celebration which we still recognize .	75.90601
it is curious that even centuries of repetition of the yearly cycle did not induce a sufficient degree of confidence to allow people to abandon the ceremonies of the winter solstice .	42.550297
this and other fears of the solar system have disappeared gradually , first , with the ptolemaic system and its built-in concept of periodicity and then , more firmly , with the newtonian innovation of an universal force that could account quantitatively for both terrestial and celestial motions .	43.91511
this understanding provides a very simple example of the fact that one can eliminate fear without instituting any controls .	37.26694
in fact , although we have dispelled the fear , we have not necessarily assured ourselves that there are no dangers .	31.38113
there is still the remote possibility of planetoid collision .	22.220907
solar activities could presumably bring long periods of flood or drought .	12.214549
our understanding of the solar system has taught us to replace our former elaborate rituals with the appropriate action which , in this case , amounts to doing nothing .	172.7355
this almost trivial example is nevertheless suggestive , for there are some elements in common between the antique fear that the days would get shorter and shorter and our present fear of war .	151.4362
we , in our country , think of war as an external threat which , if it occurs , will not be primarily of our own doing .	59.01002
and yet we obviously also believe that the avoidance of the disaster depends in some obscure or at least uncertain way on the details of how we behave .	50.287918
what elements of our behavior are decisive ? ?	1.0149806
our weapons production , our world prestige , our ideas of democracy , our actions of trust or stubbornness or secrecy or espionage ? ?	35.562466
we have staved off a war and , since our behavior has involved all these elements , we can only keep adding to our ritual without daring to abandon any part of it , since we have not the slightest notion which parts are effective .	102.573395
i think that we are here also talking of the kind of fear that a young boy has for a group of boys who are approaching at night along the streets of a large city .	35.293213
if an automobile were approaching him , he would know what was required of him , even though he might not be able to act quickly enough .	39.108624
with the group of boys it is different .	4.7718487
he does not know whether to look up or look aside , to put his hands in his pockets or to clench them at his side , to cross the street , or to continue on the same side .	34.716976
when confronted with a drunk or an insane person i have no notion of what any one of them might do to me or to himself or to others .	68.78779
i believe that what i do has some effect on his actions and i have learned , in a way , to commune with drunks , but certainly my actions seem to resemble more nearly the performance of a rain dance than the carrying out of an experiment in physics .	78.308586
i am usually filled with an uneasiness that through some unwitting slip all hell may break loose .	170.37183
our inability to explain why certain people are fond of us frequently induces the same kind of ritual and malaise .	43.45341
we are forced , in our behavior towards others , to adopt empirically successful patterns in toto because we have such a minimal understanding of their essential elements .	64.24927
our collective policies , group and national , are similarly based on voodoo , but here we often lack even the empirically successful rituals and are still engaged in determing them .	78.378555
we use terms from our personal experience with individuals such as `` trust ' ' , `` cheat ' ' , and `` get tough ' ' .	18.723461
we talk about national character in the same way that copernicus talked of the compulsions of celestial bodies to move in circles .	23.017742
we perform elaborate international exhortations and ceremonies with virtually no understanding of social cause and effect .	92.85253
small wonder , then , that we fear .	29.05422
the achievements which dispelled our fears of the cosmos took place three centuries ago .	44.885117
what additional roles has the scientific understanding of the 19th and 20th centuries played ? ?	72.75097
in the physical sciences , these achievements concern electricity , chemistry , and atomic physics .	36.26264
in the life sciences , there has been an enormous increase in our understanding of disease , in the mechanisms of heredity , and in bio- and physiological chemistry .	22.461855
the major effect of these advances appears to lie in the part they have played in the industrial revolution and in the tools which scientific understanding has given us to build and manipulate a more protective environment .	64.5592
in addition , our way of dealing directly with natural phenomena has also changed .	72.142586
even in domains where detailed and predictive understanding is still lacking , but where some explanations are possible , as with lightning and weather and earthquakes , the appropriate kind of human action has been more adequately indicated .	57.0945
apparently the population as a whole eventually acquires enough confidence in the explanations of the scientists to modify its procedures and its fears .	25.582708
how and why this process occurs would provide an interesting separate subject for study .	83.1297
in some areas , the progress is slower than in others .	26.771612
in agriculture , for example , despite the advances in biology , elaborate rituals tend to persist along with a continued sense of the imminence of some natural disaster .	47.406387
procedures change rapidly and parental confidence probably exceeds anything warranted by established psychological theory .	44.199944
there are many domains in which understanding has brought about widespread and quite appropriate reduction in ritual and fear .	197.39903
much of the former extreme uneasiness associated with visions and hallucinations and with death has disappeared .	28.409912
the persistent horror of having a malformed child has , i believe , been reduced , not because we have gained any control over this misfortune , but precisely because we have learned that we have so little control over it .	83.791725
in fact , the recent warnings about the use of x-rays have introduced fears and ambiguities of action which now require more detailed understanding , and thus in this instance , science has momentarily aggravated our fears .	60.353603
in fact , insofar as science generates any fear , it stems not so much from scientific prowess and gadgets but from the fact that new unanswered questions arise , which , until they are understood , create uncertainty .	77.37412
perhaps the most illuminating example of the reduction of fear through understanding is derived from our increased knowledge of the nature of disease .	77.2146
the situation with regard to our attitude and `` control ' ' of disease contains close analogies to problems confronting us with respect to people .	63.016453
the fear of disease was formerly very much the kind of fear i have tried to describe .	31.14119
nothing like godot , he arrived before the hour .	62.58067
his letter had suggested we meet at my hotel at noon on sunday , and i came into the lobby as the clock struck twelve .	35.54908
my wish to meet samuel beckett had been prompted by simple curiosity and interest in his work .	40.45587
american newspaper reviewers like to call his plays nihilistic .	4.367649
even so astute a commentator as harold clurman of the nation has said that `` waiting for godot ' ' is `` the concentrate of the contemporary european mood of despair ' ' .	16.021858
but to me beckett ' s writing had seemed permeated with love for human beings and with a kind of humor that i could reconcile neither with despair nor with nihilism .	45.619606
could it be that my own eyes and ears had deceived me ? ?	61.34758
is his a literature of defeat , irrelevant to the social crises we face ? ?	42.255795
or is it relevant because it teaches us something useful to know about ourselves ? ?	50.748596
i knew that a conversation with the author would not settle such questions , because a man is not the same as his writing in the last analysis , the questions had to be settled by the work itself .	52.857037
my curiosity was sharpened a day or two before the interview by a conversation i had with a well-informed teacher of literature , a jesuit father , at a conference on religious drama near paris .	67.767586
when beckett ' s name came into the discussion , the priest grew loud and told me that beckett `` hates life ' ' .	35.16198
that , i thought , is at least one thing i can find out when we meet .	42.89255
the features of his face are distinct , but not fine .	32.530502
they look as if they had been sculptured with an unsharpened chisel .	6.3121977
unruly hair goes straight up from his forehead , standing so high that the top falls gently over , as if to show that it really is hair and not bristle .	108.05991
for he has the pride that comes of self-acceptance and the humility , perhaps of the same genesis , not to impose himself upon another .	36.452145
his light blue eyes , set deep within the face , are actively and continually looking .	50.469097
he seems , by some unconscious division of labor , to have given them that one function and no other , leaving communication to the rest of the face .	82.06011
the mouth frequently breaks into a disarming smile .	4.142801
the voice is light in timbre , with a rough edge that corresponds to his visage .	33.385994
the irish accent is , as one would expect , combined with slight inflections from the french .	32.491978
his tweed suit was a baggy gray and green .	110.025925
he wore a brown knit sports shirt with no tie .	48.153698
we walked down the rue de l ' arcade , thence along beside the madeleine and across to a sidewalk cafe opposite that church .	25.494589
the conversation that ensued may have been engrossing but it could hardly be called world-shattering .	12.593574
for one thing , the world that beckett sees is already shattered .	48.290226
his talk turns to what he calls `` the mess ' ' , or sometimes `` this buzzing confusion ' ' .	18.041328
i reconstruct his sentences from notes made immediately after our conversation .	45.984016
what appears here is shorter than what he actually said but very close to his own words .	85.522835
we cannot listen to a conversation for five minutes without being acutely aware of the confusion .	25.009748
it is all around us and our only chance now is to let it in .	98.060646
the only chance of renovation is to open our eyes and see the mess .	34.574554
it is not a mess you can make sense of ' ' .	25.927572
i suggested that one must let it in because it is the truth , but beckett did not take to the word truth .	35.119946
`` what is more true than anything else ? ?	4.884222
to swim is true , and to sink is true .	76.13446
one is not more true than the other .	349.75406
one cannot speak anymore of being , one must speak only of the mess .	36.495552
when heidegger and sartre speak of a contrast between being and existence , they may be right , i don ' t know , but their language is too philosophical for me .	61.82991
one can only speak of what is in front of him , and that now is simply the mess ' ' .	32.686913
then he began to speak about the tension in art between the mess and form .	74.96714
until recently , art has withstood the pressure of chaotic things .	22.305368
it realized that to admit them was to jeopardize form .	94.86854
`` how could the mess be admitted , because it appears to be the very opposite of form and therefore destructive of the very thing that art holds itself to be ' ' ? ?	55.779648
but now we can keep it out no longer , because we have come into a time when `` it invades our experience at every moment .	69.800705
it is there and it must be allowed in ' ' .	34.430897
i granted this might be so , but found the result to be even more attention to form than was the case previously .	122.01702
how , i asked , could chaos be admitted to chaos ? ?	29.253004
would not that be the end of thinking and the end of art ? ?	28.106716
if we look at recent art we find it preoccupied with form .	158.12169
beckett ' s own work is an example .	6.6495814
plays more highly formalized than `` waiting for godot ' ' , `` endgame ' ' , and `` krapp ' s last tape ' ' would be hard to find .	10.697843
`` what i am saying does not mean that there will henceforth be no form in art .	30.946798
it only means that there will be new form , and that this form will be of such a type that it admits the chaos and does not try to say that the chaos is really something else .	43.59228
the latter is not reduced to the former .	47.092342
that is why the form itself becomes a preoccupation , because it exists as a problem separate from the material it accommodates .	55.6651
to find a form that accommodates the mess , that is the task of the artist now ' ' .	32.142353
yet , i responded , could not similar things be said about the art of the past ? ?	47.874245
is it not characteristic of the greatest art that it confronts us with something we cannot clarify , demanding that the viewer respond to it in his own never-predictable way ? ?	50.94542
what is the history of criticism but the history of men attempting to make sense of the manifold elements in art that will not allow themselves to be reduced to a single philosophy or a single aesthetic theory ? ?	88.75272
`` not this ' ' , he said , and gestured toward the madeleine .	21.515324
the classical lines of the church which napoleon thought of as a temple of glory , dominated all the scene where we sat .	83.15289
the boulevard de la madeleine , the boulevard malesherbes , and the rue royale ran to it with graceful flattery , bearing tidings of the age of reason .	18.92167
this does not allow the mystery to invade us .	13.908375
there is the unexplainable , and there art raises questions that it does not attempt to answer ' ' .	27.670078
i asked about the battle between life and death in his plays .	26.45519
didi and gogo hover on the edge of suicide	328.3903
hamm ' s world is death and clov may or may not get out of it to join the living child outside .	164.23462
is this life-death question a part of the chaos ? ?	58.683147
if life and death did not both present themselves to us , there would be no inscrutability .	25.275078
if there were only darkness , all would be clear .	31.53498
it is because there is not only darkness but also light that our situation becomes inexplicable .	110.17345
take augustine ' s doctrine of grace given and grace withheld have you pondered the dramatic qualities in this theology ? ?	61.5775
two thieves are crucified with christ , one saved and the other damned .	19.909004
how can we make sense of this division ? ?	4.932742
in classical drama , such problems do not arise .	30.54207
the destiny of racine ' s phedre is sealed from the beginning she will proceed into the dark .	27.400229
as she goes , she herself will be illuminated .	89.05732
at the beginning of the play she has partial illumination and at the end she has complete illumination , but there has been no question but that she moves toward the dark .	37.0412
within this notion clarity is possible , but for us who are neither greek nor jansenist there is not such clarity .	32.860863
the question would also be removed if we believed in the contrary -- total salvation .	138.69882
but where we have both dark and light we have also the inexplicable .	49.026802
the key word in my plays is ' perhaps ' ' ' .	26.127254
given a theological lead , i asked what he thinks about those who find a religious significance to his plays .	80.92164
`` well , really there is none at all .	13.776791
he knelt down at his bed as long as he could kneel .	6.4046397
the family was protestant , but for me it was only irksome and i let it go .	34.896015
my brother and mother got no value from their religion when they died .	145.004
at the moment of crisis it had no more depth than an old school tie .	60.274055
irish catholicism is not attractive , but it is deeper .	38.295105
when you pass a church on an irish bus , all the hands flurry in the sign of the cross .	39.437134
one day the dogs of ireland will do that too and perhaps also the pigs ' ' .	51.999104
but do the plays deal with the same facets of experience religion must also deal with ? ?	122.34784
`` yes , for they deal with distress .	67.628426
some people object to this in my writing .	3.241963
at a party an english intellectual -- so-called -- asked me why i write always about distress .	137.02496
as if it were perverse to do so ! !	65.22178
he wanted to know if my father had beaten me or my mother had run away from home to give me an unhappy childhood .	104.58295
i told him no , that i had had a very happy childhood .	86.42242
then he thought me more perverse than ever .	12.974753
i left the party as soon as possible and got into a taxi .	31.587482
on the glass partition between me and the driver were three signs one asked for help for the blind , another help for orphans , and the third for relief for the war refugees .	90.09688
one does not have to look for distress .	3.097604
it is screaming at you even in the taxis of london ' ' .	21.791819
lunch was over , and we walked back to the hotel with the light and dark of paris screaming at us .	27.415743
the personal quality of samuel beckett is similar to qualities i had found in the plays .	69.809
he says nothing that compresses experience within a closed pattern .	104.98281
`` perhaps ' ' stands in place of commitment .	31.942488
at the same time , he is plainly sympathetic , clearly friendly .	207.2835
if there were only the mess , all would be clear	36.397964
as a christian , i know i do not stand where beckett stands , but i do see much of what he sees .	33.587532
as a writer on the theater , i have paid close attention to the plays .	84.28501
harold clurman is right to say that `` waiting for godot ' ' is a reflection ( he calls it a distorted reflection ) `` of the impasse and disarray of europe ' s present politics , ethic , and common way of life ' ' .	31.91245
yet it is not only europe the play refers to .	81.98299
`` waiting for godot ' ' sells even better in america than in france .	48.69602
the consciousness it mirrors may have come earlier to europe than to america , but it is the consciousness that most `` mature ' ' societies arrive at when their successes in technological and economic systematization propel them into a time of examining the not-strictly-practical ends of culture .	32.743046
america is now joining europe in this `` mature ' ' phase of development .	41.722496
whether any of us remain in it long will depend on what happens as a result of the technological and economic revolutions now going on in the countries of asia and africa , and also of course on how long the cold war remains cold .	37.493904
even hemingway , for all his efforts to formulate a naturalistic morality in the sun also rises and a farewell to arms never maintained that sex was all .	106.34109
hemingway ' s fiction is supported by a `` moral ' ' backbone and in its search for ultimate meaning hints at a religious dimension .	34.1853
and d . h . lawrence , in fantasia of the unconscious , protested vehemently against the overestimation of the sexual motive .	10.466574
though sex in some form or other enters into all human activity and it was a good thing that freud emphasized this aspect of human nature , it is fantastic to explain everything in terms of sex .	52.138897
`` all is not sex ' ' , declared lawrence .	270.40652
man is not confined to one outlet for his vital energy .	31.763695
the creative urge , for example , transcends the body and the self .	20.427074
but for the beat generation all is sex .	4.3022556
nothing is more revealing of the way of life and literary aspirations of this group than their attitude toward sex .	89.62883
for the beatnik , like the hipster , is in opposition to a society that is based on the repression of the sex instinct .	32.27289
he has elevated sex -- not eros or libido but pure , spontaneous , uninhibited sex -- to the rank of the godhead	21.49503
it is astarte , ishtar , venus , yahwe , dionysus , christ , the mysterious and divine orgone energy flowing through the body of the universe .	10.810357
jazz is sex , marijuana is a stimulus to sex , the beat tempo is adjusted to the orgiastic release of the sexual impulse .	12.024978
lawrence lipton , in the holy barbarians , stresses that for the beat generation sex is more than a source of pleasure	67.03283
it is a mystique , and their private language is rich in the multivalent ambiguities of sexual reference so that they dwell in a sexualized universe of discourse .	25.90326
the singular uncompromising force of their revolt against the cult of restraint is illustrated by their refusal to dance in a public place .	66.21063
the dance is but a disguised ritual for the expression of ungratified sexual desire .	70.874886
for this reason , too , their language is more forthright and earthy .	21.575804
the beatniks crave a sexual experience in which their whole being participates .	73.105774
it is therefore not surprising that they resist the lure of marriage and the trap of domesticity , for like cats they are determined not to tame their sexual energy .	33.73844
they withdraw to the underground of the slums where they can defy the precepts of legalized propriety .	8.328398
unlike the heroes and flappers of the lost generation , they disdain the art of `` necking ' ' and `` petting ' ' .	7.4270983
if they avoid the use of the pungent , outlawed four-letter word it is because it is taboo	19.049257
as lipton , the prophet of the beat generation , declares `` in the sexual act , the beat are filled with mana , the divine power .	28.251173
this is far from the vulgar , leering sexuality of the middle-class square in heat ' ' .	21.968975
this is the holy grail these knights of the orgasm pursue , this is the irresistible cosmic urge to which they respond .	33.357853
if wilhelm reich is the moses who has led them out of the egypt of sexual slavery , dylan thomas is the poet who offers them the dionysian dialectic of justification for their indulgence in liquor , marijuana , sex , and jazz .	46.44401
in addition , they have been converted to zen buddhism , with its glorification of all that is `` natural ' ' and mysteriously alive , the sense that everything in the world is flowing .	31.355808
thus , paradoxically , the beat writers resort to `` religious ' ' metaphors they are in search of mana , the spiritual , the numinous , but not anything connected with formal religion .	47.119743
what they are after is the beatific vision .	8.826872
and zen buddhism , though it is extremely difficult to understand how these internal contradictions are reconciled , helps them in their struggle to achieve personal salvation through sexual release .	43.545776
the style of life chosen by the beat generation , the rhythm and ritual they have adopted as uniquely their own , is designed to enhance the value of the sexual experience .	34.34436
jazz is good not only because it promotes wholeness but because of its decided sexual effect .	150.56662
jazz is the musical language of sex , the vocabulary of the orgasm	7.076631
indeed , it is maintained that the sexual element in jazz , by freeing the listener of his inhibitions , can have therapeutic value .	48.891678
that is why , the argument runs , the squares are so fearful of jazz and yet perversely fascinated by it .	34.930687
instead of giving themselves spontaneously to the orgiastic release that jazz can give them , they undergo psychoanalysis or flirt with mysticism or turn to prostitutes for satisfaction .	32.05982
thus jazz is transmuted into something holy , the sacred road to integration of being .	154.5921
jazz , like sex , is a mystique .	5.1415615
it is not a substitute for sex but a dynamic expression of the creative impulse in unfettered man .	55.34103
the mystique of sex , combined with marijuana and jazz , is intended to provide a design for living .	34.833225
those who are sexually liberated can become creatively alive and free , their instincts put at the service of the imagination .	84.601105
righteous in their denunciation of all that makes for death , the beat prophets bid all men become cool cats	203.50014
let them learn to `` swing ' ' freely , to let go , to become authentically themselves , and then perhaps civilization will be saved .	122.28787
the beatnik , seceding from a society that is fatally afflicted with a deathward drive , is concerned with his personal salvation in the living present .	36.863625
if he is the child of nothingness , if he is the predestined victim of an age of atomic wars , then he will consult only his own organic needs and go beyond good and evil .	55.44991
he will not curb his instinctual desires but release the energy within him that makes him feel truly and fully alive , even if it is only for this brief moment before the apocalypse of annihilation explodes on earth .	63.473186
that is why the members of the beat generation proudly assume the title of the holy barbarians	26.837276
they will destroy the shrines , temples , museums , and churches of the state that is the implacable enemy of the life they believe in .	26.14896
apart from the categorical imperative they derive from the metaphysics of the orgasm , the only affirmation they are capable of making is that art is their only refuge .	31.006962
their writing , born of their experiments in marijuana and untrammeled sexuality , reflects the extremity of their existential alienation .	8.417751
the mind has betrayed them , reason is the foe of life	47.899067
they will trust only their physical sensations , the wisdom of the body , the holy promptings of the unconscious .	17.699652
with lyrical intensity they reveal what they hate , but their faith in love , inspired by the revolutionary rhythms of jazz , culminates in the climax of the orgasm .	16.460121
their work mirrors the mentality of the psychopath , rootless and irresponsible .	10.294749
their rebellion against authoritarian society is not far removed from the violence of revolt characteristic of the juvenile delinquent .	25.445038
and the life they lead is undisciplined and for the most part unproductive , even though they make a fetish of devoting themselves to some creative pursuit -- writing , painting , music .	42.970528
when they express themselves it is incandescent hatred that shines forth , the rage of repudiation , the ecstasy of negation .	13.812001
it is sex that obsesses them , sex that is at the basis of their aesthetic creed .	29.54829
what they discuss with dialectical seriousness is the degree to which sex can inspire the muse .	49.356728
monogamy is the vice from which the abjectly fearful middle class continue to suffer , whereas the beatnik has the courage to break out of that prison of respectability .	42.758266
one girl describes her past , her succession of broken marriages , the abortions she has had and finally confesses that she loves sex and sees no reason why she must justify her passion .	33.22385
if it is an honest feeling , then why should she not yield to it ? ?	85.248856
`` most often ' ' , she says , `` it ' s the monogamous relationship that is dishonest ' ' .	6.218707
this girl soon drops the bourgeois pyschiatrist who disapproves of her life .	30.987488
she finds married life stifling and every prolonged sex relationship unbearably monotonous .	5.663396
this confession serves to make clear in part what is behind this sexual revolution the craving for sensation for its own sake , the need for change , for new experiences .	102.922714
in the realm of physical sensations , sex reigns supreme .	47.025093
hence the beatniks sustain themselves on marijuana , jazz , free swinging poetry , exhausting themselves in orgies of sex	54.879604
some of them are driven over the borderline of sanity and lose contact with reality .	29.458775
one beat poet composes a poem , `` lines on a tijuana john ' ' , which contains a few happy hints for survival .	66.284294
the new fact the initiates of this cult have to learn is that they must move toward simplicity .	76.35274
the professed mission of this disaffiliated generation is to find a new way of life which they can express in poetry and fiction , but what they produce is unfortunately disordered , nourished solely on the hysteria of negation .	36.605404
who are the creative representatives of this movement ? ?	10.153519
nymphomaniacs , junkies , homosexuals , drug addicts , lesbians , alcoholics , the weak , the frustrated , the irresolute , the despairing , the derelicts and outcasts of society .	18.261646
they embrace independent poverty , usually with a `` shack-up ' ' partner who will help support them .	27.874117
they are full of contempt for the institution of matrimony .	6.091486
their previous legalized marriages do not count , for they hold the laws of the state null and void .	39.845974
they feel they are leagued against a hostile , persecutory world , faced with the concerted malevolent opposition of squares and their hirelings , the police .	14.18768
this is the rhetoric of righteousness the beatniks use in defending their way of life , their search for wholeness , though their actual existence fails to reach these `` religious ' ' heights .	83.920074
one beatnik got the woman he was living with so involved in drugs and self-analysis and all-night sessions of sex that she was beginning to crack up .	56.691826
what obsessions had she picked up during these long nights of talk ? ?	26.290037
sex as the creative principle of the universe , the secret of primitive religion , the life of myth .	25.25538
everything in the final analysis reduced itself to sexual symbolism .	108.468056
in his chapter on `` the loveways of the beat generation ' ' , lipton spares the reader none of the sordid details .	9.104741
no one asks questions about the free union of the sexes in west venice so long as the partners share the negative attitudes of the group .	54.66914
the women who come to west venice , having forsaken radicalism , are interested in living only for the moment , in being constantly on the move .	51.848408
others who are attracted to this mecca of the beat generation are homosexuals , heroin addicts , and smalltime hoodlums .	10.755325
those who are sexual deviants are naturally drawn to join the beatniks .	18.43519
since the homosexuals widely use marijuana , they do not have to be initiated .	16.02598
part of the ritual of sex is the use of marijuana .	21.803398
as lipton puts it `` the eros is felt in the magic circle of marijuana with far greater force , as a unifying principle in human relationships , than at any other time except , perhaps , in the mutual metaphysical orgasms .	43.882153
the magic circle is , in fact , a symbol of and preparation for the metaphysical orgasm ' ' .	48.178734
under the influence of marijuana the beatnik comes alive within and experiences a wonderfully enhanced sense of self as if he had discovered the open sesame to the universe of being .	47.70393
carried high on this `` charge ' ' , he composes `` magical ' ' poetry that captures the organic rhythms of life in words .	19.546144
if he thus achieves a lyrical , dreamlike , drugged intensity , he pays the price for his indulgence by producing work -- allen ginsberg ' s `` howl ' ' is a striking example of this tendency -- that is disoriented , dionysian but without depth and without apollonian control .	39.25604
for drugs are in themselves no royal road to creativity .	9.105241
how is the beat poet to achieve unity of form when he is at the same time engaged in a systematic derangement of senses .	25.002964
if love reflects the nature of man , as ortega y gasset believes , if the person in love betrays decisively what he is by his behavior in love , then the writers of the beat generation are creating a new literary genre .	30.764475
there were fences in the old days when we were children .	79.90477
across the front of a yard and down the side , they were iron , either spiked along the top or arched in half circles .	37.476242
alley fences were made of solid boards higher than one ' s head , but not so high as the golden glow in a corner or the hollyhocks that grew in a line against them .	45.24771
side fences were hidden beneath lilacs and hundred-leaf roses	1.7151163
front fences were covered with virginia creeper or trumpet vines or honeysuckle .	5.46592
square corner- and gate posts were an open-work pattern of cast-iron foliage	65.72627
they were topped by steeples complete in every detail high-pitched roof , pinnacle , and narrow gable .	11.159583
on these posts the gates swung open with a squeak and shut with a metallic clang .	11.563021
the only extended view possible to anyone less tall than the fences was that obtained from an upper bough of the apple tree .	34.154514
the primary quality of that view seems , now , to have been its quietness , but that cannot at the time have impressed us .	53.853416
from high in the tree , the whole block lay within range of the eye , but the ground was almost nowhere visible .	46.784702
one looked down on a sea of leaves , a breaking wave of flower .	37.097126
every path from back door to barn was covered by a grape-arbor , and every yard had its fruit trees .	55.80838
in the center of any open space remaining our grandfathers had planted syringa and sweet-shrub , snowball , rose-of-sharon and balm-of-gilead .	8.092293
from above one could only occasionally catch a glimpse of life on the floor of this green sea a neighbor ' s gingham skirt flashing into sight for an instant on the path beneath her grape-arbor , or the movement of hands above a clothesline and the flutter of garments hung there , half-way down the block .	34.042324
time is a queer thing and memory a queerer	2.893013
the tricks that time plays with memory and memory with time are queerest of all .	75.10773
from maturity one looks back at the succession of years , counts them and makes them many , yet cannot feel length in the number , however large .	172.15004
in a stream that turns a mill-wheel there is a lot of water	41.66621
the mill-pond is quiet , its surface dark and shadowed , and there does not seem to be much water in it .	28.648972
and yet -- a year to a child is an eternity , and in the memory that phase of one ' s being -- a certain mental landscape -- will seem to have endured without beginning and without end .	75.61643
the part of the mind that preserves dates and events may remonstrate , `` it could have been like that for only a little while ' '	81.378204
but true memory does not count nor add it holds fast to things that were and they are outside of time .	129.28343
once , then -- for how many years or how few does not matter -- my world was bound round by fences , when i was too small to reach the apple tree bough , to twist my knee over it and pull myself up .	104.049324
that world was in scale with my own smallness .	20.45683
i have no picture in my mind of the garden as a whole -- that i could not see -- but certain aspects of certain corners linger in the memory wind-blown , frost-bitten , white chrysanthemums beneath a window , with their brittle brown leaves and their sharp scent of november	50.595623
ripe pears lying in long grass , to be turned over by a dusty-slippered foot , cautiously , lest bees still worked in the ragged , brown-edged holes	29.91542
hot-colored verbenas in the corner between the dining-room wall and the side porch , where we passed on our way to the pump with the half-gourd tied to it as a cup by my grandmother for our childish pleasure in drinking from it .	69.43839
i think that my grandmother was not an impassioned gardener she was too indulgent a lover of dogs and grandchildren .	46.960938
my great-grandmother , i have been told , made her garden her great pride	268.76727
she cherished rare and delicate plants like oleanders in tubs and wall-flowers and lemon verbenas in pots that had to be wintered in the cellar	13.882858
she filled the waste spots of the yard with common things like the garden heliotrope in a corner by the woodshed , and the plantain lilies along the west side of the house .	21.777384
these my grandmother left in their places ( they are still there , more persistent and longer-lived than the generations of man ) and planted others like them , that flourished without careful tending .	76.03613
three of these only were protected from us by stern commandment the roses , whose petals might not be collected until they had fallen , to be made into perfume or rose-tea to drink	36.7539
the peonies , whose tight sticky buds would be blighted by the laying on of a finger , although they were not apparently harmed by the ants that crawled over them	26.749249
i have more than once sat cross-legged in the grass through a long summer morning and watched without touching while a poppy bud higher than my head slowly but visibly pushed off its cap , unfolded , and shook out like a banner in the sun its flaming vermilion petals .	42.5275
other flowers we might gather as we pleased myrtle and white violets from beneath the lilacs	8.767076
the lilacs themselves , that bloomed so prodigally but for the most part beyond our reach	66.44084
hollyhock blossoms that , turned upside down , make pink-petticoated ladies	864.47766
and the little , dark blue larkspur that scattered its seed everywhere .	60.53114
more potent a charm to bring back that time of life than this record of a few pictures and a few remembered facts would be a catalogue of the minutiae which are of the very stuff of the mind , intrinsic , because they were known in the beginning not by the eye alone but by the hand that held them .	96.31468
flowers , stones , and small creatures , living and dead .	124.90003
pale yellow snapdragons that by pinching could be made to bite	7.5312285
seed-pods of the balsams that snapped like fire-crackers at a touch	64.69722
red-and-yellow columbines whose round-tipped spurs were picked off and eaten for the honey in them	62.78284
morning-glory buds which could be so grasped and squeezed that they burst like a blown-up paper bag	56.706753
bright flowers from the trumpet vine that made `` gloves ' ' on the ends of ten waggling fingers .	16.694687
fuzzy caterpillars , snails with their sensitive horns , struggling grasshoppers held by their long hind legs and commanded to `` spit tobacco , spit ' ' .	18.185617
dead fledgling birds , their squashed-looking nakedness and the odor of decay that clung to the hand when they had been buried in our graveyard in front of the purple flags .	26.02555
and the cast shell of a locust , straw-colored and transparent , weighing nothing , fragile but entire , with eyes like bubbles and a gaping slit down its back .	37.0601
every morning early , in the summer , we searched the trunks of the trees as high as we could reach for the locust shells , carefully detached their hooked claws from the bark where they hung , and stabled them , a weird faery herd , in an angle between the high roots of the tulip tree , where no grass grew in the dense shade .	22.096457
we collected `` lucky stones ' ' -- all the creamy translucent pebbles , worn smooth and round , that we could find in the driveway .	22.23125
when these had been pocketed , we could still spend a morning cracking open other pebbles for our delight in seeing how much prettier they were inside than their dull exteriors indicated .	117.74068
we showed them to each other and said `` would you have guessed ' ' ? ?	19.362558
squatting on our haunches beside the flat stone we broke them on , we were safe behind the high closed gates at the end of the drive safe from interruption and the observation and possible amusement of the passers-by .	74.56621
thus shielded , we played many foolish games in comfortable unselfconsciousness	21.814379
even when the fences became a part of the game -- when a vine-embowered gate-post was the sleeping beauty ' s enchanted castle , or when rapunzel let down her golden hair from beneath the crocketed spire , even then we paid little heed to those who went by on the path outside .	32.891834
we enjoyed a paradoxical freedom when we were still too young for school .	131.58636
in the heat of the summer , the garden solitudes were ours alone	96.35469
our elders stayed in the dark house or sat fanning on the front porch .	21.132547
they never troubled themselves about us while we were playing , because the fence formed such a definite boundary and `` don ' t go outside the gate ' ' was a command so impossible of misinterpretation .	66.478615
we were not , however , entirely unacquainted with the varying aspects of the street .	96.81386
we were forbidden to swing on the gates , lest they sag on their hinges in a poor-white-trash way , but we could stand on them , when they were latched , rest our chins on the top , and stare and stare , committing to memory , quite unintentionally , all the details that lay before our eyes .	23.181927
the street that is full now of traffic and parked cars then and for many years drowsed on an august afternoon in the shade of the curbside trees , and silence was a weight , almost palpable , in the air .	48.872154
every slight sound that rose against that pressure fell away again , crushed beneath it .	120.91356
a hay-wagon moved slowly along the gutter , the top of it swept by the low boughs of the maple trees , and loose straws were left hanging tangled among the leaves .	53.5252
a wheel squeaked on a hub , was still , and squeaked again .	56.19017
if a child watched its progress he whispered , `` hay , hay , load of hay -- make a wish and turn away ' ' , and then stared rigidly in the opposite direction until the sound of the horses ' feet returned no more .	62.77781
when the hay wagon had gone , and an interval passed , a huckster ' s cart might turn the corner .	38.22199
the horse walked , the reins were slack , the huckster rode with bowed shoulders , his forearms across his knees .	38.91311
sleepily , as if half-reluctant to break the silence , he lifted his voice `` rhu-beb-ni-ice nice fresh rhu-beb today ' ' ! !	35.403553
the lazy sing-song was spaced in time like the drone of a bumble-bee .	4.530018
