no one seemed to hear him , no one heeded .	7.78602
the horse plodded on , and he repeated his call .	50.768566
it became so monotonous as to seem a part of the quietness .	9.1634245
after his passage , the street was empty again .	346.8582
the sun moved slant-wise across the sky and down	563.18524
the trees ' shadows circled from street to sidewalk , from sidewalk to lawn .	39.23688
at four-o ' clock , or four-thirty , the coming of the newsboy marked the end of the day	25.030338
he tossed a paper toward every front door , and housewives came down to their steps to pick them up and read what their neighbors had been doing .	68.37296
the streets of any county town were like this on any sunshiny afternoon in summer	69.18961
they were like this fifty-odd years ago , and yesterday .	241.02943
but the fences were still in place fifty-odd years ago , and when we stood on the gate to look over , the sidewalk under our eyes was not cement but two rows of paving stones with grass between and on both sides .	57.813335
the curb was a line of stone laid edgewise in the dirt and tilted this way and that by frost in the ground or the roots of trees .	36.45552
opposite every gate was a hitching post or a stone carriage-step , set with a rusty iron ring for tying a horse .	19.585503
the street was unpaved and rose steeply toward the center	20.379019
it was mud in wet weather and dust , ankle-deep , in dry , and could be crossed only at the corner where there were stepping stones .	29.26268
it had a bucolic atmosphere that it has lost long since .	130.50043
the hoofmarks of cattle and the prints of bare feet in the mud or in the dust were as numerous as the traces of shod horses .	21.227736
cows were kept in backyard barns , boys were hired to drive them to and from the pasture on the edge of town , and familiar to the ear , morning and evening , were the boys ' coaxing voices , the thud of hooves , and the thwack of a stick on cowhide .	27.27743
it is worth dwelling in some detail on the crisis of this story , because it brings together a number of characteristic elements and makes of them a curious , riddling compound obscurely but centrally significant for mann ' s work .	43.046124
the wife , amra , and her lover are both savagely portrayed , she as incarnate sensuality , `` voluptuous ' ' and `` indolent ' ' , possibly `` a mischief maker ' ' , with `` a kind of luxurious cunning ' ' to set against her apparent simplicity , her `` birdlike brain ' ' .	17.991442
lautner , for his part , `` belonged to the present-day race of small artists , who do not demand the utmost of themselves ' ' , and the bitter description of the type includes such epithets as `` wretched little poseurs ' ' , the devastating indictment `` they do not know how to be wretched decently and in order ' ' , and the somewhat extreme prophecy , so far not fulfilled `` they will be destroyed ' ' .	33.223694
the trick these two play upon jacoby reveals their want not simply of decency but of imagination as well .	154.21236
his appearance as lizzy evokes not amusement but horror in the audience	40.069088
it is a spectacle absolutely painful , an epiphany of the suffering flesh unredeemed by spirit , untouched by any spirit other than abasement and humiliation .	28.82633
at the same time the multiple transvestitism involved -- the fat man as girl and as baby , as coquette pretending to be a baby -- touches for a moment horrifyingly upon the secret sources of a life like jacoby ' s , upon the sinister dreams which form the sources of any human life .	47.678486
the music which lautner has composed for this episode is for the most part `` rather pretty and perfectly banal ' ' .	27.663067
but it is characteristic of him , we are told , `` his little artifice ' ' , to be able to introduce `` into a fairly vulgar and humorous piece of hackwork a sudden phrase of genuine creative art ' ' .	24.793783
and this occurs now , at the refrain of jacoby ' s song -- at the point , in fact , of the name `` lizzy ' ' --	19.984304
a modulation described as `` almost a stroke of genius ' ' .	4.7538824
`` a miracle , a revelation , it was like a curtain suddenly torn away to reveal something nude ' ' .	68.81934
it is this modulation which reveals to jacoby his own frightful abjection and , simultaneously , his wife ' s infidelity .	26.80373
by the same means he perceives this fact as having communicated itself to the audience	118.38099
in the work of every artist , i suppose , there may be found one or more moments which strike the student as absolutely decisive , ultimately emblematic of what it is all about	57.35216
not less strikingly so for being mysterious , as though some deeply hidden constatation of thoughts were enciphered in a single image , a single moment .	36.82267
the horrifying humor , the specifically sexual embarrassment of the joke gone wrong , the monstrous image of the fat man dressed up as a whore dressing up as a baby	52.936954
the bringing together around it of the secret liaison between indolent , mindless sensuality and sharp , shrewd talent , cleverness with an occasional touch of genius ( which , however , does not know `` how to attack the problem of suffering ' ' )	38.240334
the miraculous way in which music , revelation and death are associated in a single instant -- all this seems a triumph of art , a rather desperate art , in itself	74.83404
beyond itself , also , it evokes numerous and distant resonances from the entire body of mann ' s work .	23.392033
when i try to work out my reasons for feeling that this passage is of critical significance , i come up with the following ideas , which i shall express very briefly here and revert to in a later essay .	89.08858
love is the crucial dilemma of experience for mann ' s heroes .	7.575461
the dramatic construction of his stories characteristically turns on a situation in which someone is simultaneously compelled and forbidden to love .	38.07835
the release , the freedom , involved in loving another is either terribly difficult or else absolutely impossible	837.68475
this prohibition on love has an especially poignant relation to art	305.65045
it is particularly the artist ( tonio kroger , aschenbach , leverkuhn ) who suffers from it .	10.045247
the specific analogy to the dilemma of love is the problem of the `` breakthrough ' ' in the realm of art .	13.117325
again , the sufferings and disasters produced by any transgression against the commandment not to love are almost invariably associated in one way or another with childhood , with the figure of a child .	70.26307
finally , the theatrical ( and perversely erotic ) notions of dressing up , cosmetics , disguise , and especially change of costume ( or singularity of costume , as with cipolla ) , are characteristically associated with the catastrophes of mann ' s stories .	23.440142
we shall return to these statements and deal with them more fully as the evidence for them accumulates .	59.18361
for the present it is enough to note that in the grotesque figure of jacoby , at the moment of his collapse , all these elements come together in prophetic parody .	29.44515
professionally a lawyer , that is to say associated with dignity , reserve , discipline , with much that is essentially middle-class , he is compelled by an impossible love to exhibit himself dressed up , disguised -- that is , paradoxically , revealed -- as a child , and , worse , as a whore masquerading as a child .	55.468395
that this abandonment takes place on a stage , during an ' artistic ' performance , is enough to associate jacoby with art , and to bring down upon him the punishment for art	124.53061
that is , he is suspect , guilty , punishable , as is anyone in mann ' s stories who produces illusion , and this is true even though the constant elements of the artist-nature , technique , magic , guilt and suffering , are divided in this story between jacoby and lautner .	47.36035
it appears that the dominant tendency of mann ' s early tales , however pictorial or even picturesque the surface , is already toward the symbolic , the emblematic , the expressionistic .	57.874237
in a certain perfectly definite way , the method and the theme of his stories are one and the same .	61.920105
something of this can be learned from `` the way to the churchyard ' ' ( 1901 ) , an anecdote about an old failure whose fit of anger at a passing cyclist causes him to die of a stroke or seizure .	42.104153
there is no more `` plot ' ' than that	122.920494
only slightly more , perhaps , than a newspaper account of such an incident would give .	241.10509
the artistic interest , then , lies in what the encounter may be made to represent , in the power of some central significance to draw the details into relevance and meaningfulness .	66.441414
the first sentence , with its platitudinous irony , announces an emblematic intent `` the way to the churchyard ran along beside the highroad , ran beside it all the way to the end	26.974861
that is to say , to the churchyard ' ' .	4.73507
and the action is consistently presented with regard for this distinction .	32.739388
the highroad , one might say at first , belongs to life , while the way to the churchyard belongs to death .	18.342157
but that is too simple , and won ' t hold up .	18.990072
as the first sentence suggests , both roads belong to death in the end .	23.62231
but the highroad , according to the description of its traffic , belongs to life as it is lived in unawareness of death , while the way to the churchyard belongs to some other sort of life a suffering form , an existence wholly comprised in the awareness of death .	44.983368
thus , on the highroad , a troop of soldiers `` marched in their own dust and sang ' ' , while on the footpath one man walks alone .	37.409863
this man ' s isolation is not merely momentary , it is permanent .	14.368651
he is a widower , his three children are dead , he has no one left on earth	78.73411
also he is a drunk , and has lost his job on that account .	120.97065
his name is praisegod piepsam , and he is rather fully described as to his clothing and physiognomy in a way which relates him to a sinister type in the author ' s repertory -- he is a forerunner of those enigmatic strangers in `` death in venice ' ' , for example , who represent some combination of cadaver , exotic , and psychopomp .	26.144272
this strange person quarrels with a cyclist because the latter is using the path rather than the highroad .	103.50523
the cyclist , a sufficiently commonplace young fellow , is not named but identified simply as `` life ' ' -- that and a license number , which piepsam uses in addressing him .	92.1426
`` life ' ' points out that `` everybody uses this path ' ' , and starts to ride on .	97.07689
piepsam tries to stop him by force , receives a push in the chest from `` life ' ' , and is left standing in impotent and growing rage , while a crowd begins to gather .	74.5803
that is , on the basis of his own sinfulness and abject wretchedness , piepsam becomes a prophet who in his ecstasy and in the name of god imprecates doom on life -- not only the cyclist now , but the audience , the world , as well `` all you light-headed breed ' ' .	29.341236
this passion brings on a fit which proves fatal .	20.780062
then an ambulance comes along , and they drive praisegod piepsam away .	45.83497
this is simple enough , but several more points of interest may be mentioned as relevant .	42.79703
the season , between spring and summer , belongs to life in its carefree aspect .	63.18989
piepsam ' s fatal rage arises not only because he cannot stop the cyclist , but also because god will not stop him	46.8545
as piepsam says to the crowd in his last moments `` his justice is not of this world ' ' .	54.64084
life is further characterized , in antithesis to piepsam , as animal the image of a dog , which appears at several places , is first given as the criterion of amiable , irrelevant interest aroused by life considered simply as a spectacle a dog in a wagon is `` admirable ' ' , `` a pleasure to contemplate ' '	59.583603
another wagon has no dog , and therefore is `` devoid of interest ' ' .	16.26102
piepsam calls the cyclist `` cur ' ' and `` puppy ' ' among other things , and at the crisis of his fit a little fox-terrier stands before him and howls into his face .	41.696266
the ambulance is drawn by two `` charming ' ' little horses .	17.669197
piepsam is not , certainly , religious in any conventional sense .	34.234158
his religiousness is intimately , or dialectically , connected with his sinfulness	41.851276
his unsuccessful strivings to give up drink are represented as religious strivings	59.066944
he keeps a bottle in a wardrobe at home , and `` before this wardrobe praisegod piepsam had before now gone literally on his knees , and in his wrestlings had bitten his tongue -- and still in the end capitulated ' ' .	41.380848
the cyclist , by contrast , blond and blue-eyed , is simply unreflective , unproblematic life , `` blithe and carefree ' ' .	11.697067
`` he made no claims to belong to the great and mighty of this earth ' ' .	36.299683
he is `` a man raving mad on the way to the churchyard ' ' .	6.353139
but he is more interesting than the others , the ones who come from the highroad to watch him , more interesting than life considered as a cyclist .	72.73313
and if i have gone into so much detail about so small a work , that is because it is also so typical a work , representing the germinal form of a conflict which remains essential in mann ' s writing the crude sketch of piepsam contains , in its critical , destructive and self-destructive tendencies , much that is enlarged and illuminated in the figures of , for instance , naphta and leverkuhn .	50.61575
in method as well as in theme this little anecdote with its details selected as much for expressiveness and allegory as for `` realism ' ' , anticipates a kind of musical composition , as well as a kind of fictional composition , in which , as leverkuhn says , `` there shall be nothing unthematic ' ' .	26.323557
it resembles , too , pictures such as durer and bruegel did , in which all that looks at first to be solely pictorial proves on inspection to be also literary , the representation of a proverb , for example , or a deadly sin .	37.522358
`` gladius dei ' ' ( 1902 ) resembles `` the way to the churchyard ' ' in its representation of a conflict between light and dark , between `` life ' ' and a spirit of criticism , negation , melancholy , but it goes considerably further in characterizing the elements of this conflict .	27.11205
the monk savonarola , brought over from the renaissance and placed against the background of munich at the turn of the century , protests against the luxurious works displayed in the art-shop of m . bluthenzweig	25.754898
in particular against a madonna portrayed in a voluptuous style and modeled , according to gossip , upon the painter ' s mistress .	24.864021
hieronymus , like piepsam , makes his protest quite in vain , and his rejection , though not fatal , is ridiculous and humiliating	22.765003
he is simply thrown out of the shop by the porter .	27.019218
on the street outside , hieronymus envisions a holocaust of the vanities of this world , such a burning of artistic and erotic productions as his namesake actually brought to pass in florence , and prophetically he issues his curse `` gladius dei super terram cito et velociter ' ' .	22.404867
the `` reality ' ' to which they respond is rationally empty and their art is an imitation of the inescapable powerfulness of this unknown and empty world .	60.172714
their artistic rationale is given to the witness of unreason .	25.72417
these polar concerns ( imitation vs . formalism ) reflect a philosophical and religious situation which has been developing over a long period of time .	30.069527
the breakdown of classical structures of meaning in all realms of western culture has given rise to several generations of artists who have documented the disintegrative processes .	30.380913
thus the image of man has suffered complete fragmentation in personal and spiritual qualities , and complete objectification in sub-human and quasi-mechanistic powers .	17.1251
the image of the world tends to reflect the hostility and indifference of man or else to dissolve into empty spaces and overwhelming mystery .	48.271324
all such imitations of negative quality have given rise to a compensatory response in the form of a heroic and highly individualistic humanism if man can neither know nor love reality as it is , he can at least invent an artistic `` reality ' ' which is its own world and which can speak to man of purely personal and subjective qualities capable of being known and worthy of being loved .	78.48439
the person of the artist becomes a final bastion of meaning in a world rendered meaningless by the march of events and the decay of classical religious and philosophical systems .	37.735584
whatever pole of this contrast one emphasizes and whatever the tension between these two approaches to understanding the artistic imagination , it will be readily seen that they are not mutually exclusive , that they belong together .	30.293886
without the decay of a sense of objective reference ( except as the imitation of mystery ) , the stress on subjective invention would never have been stimulated into being .	40.29198
and although these insights into the nature of art may be in themselves insufficient for a thoroughgoing philosophy of art , their peculiar authenticity in this day and age requires that they be taken seriously and gives promise that from their very substance , new and valid chapters in the philosophy of art may be written .	121.4077
for better or worse we cannot regard `` imitation ' ' in the arts in the simple mode of classical rationalism or detached realism .	16.298447
a broader concept of imitation is needed , one which acknowledges that true invention is important , that the artist ' s creativity in part transcends the non-artistic causal factors out of which it arises .	36.38313
on the other hand , we cannot regard artistic invention as pure , uncaused , and unrelated to the times in which it occurs .	39.59494
we need a doctrine of imitation to save us from the solipsism and futility of pure formalism .	8.3479395
accordingly , it is the aim of this essay to advance a new theory of imitation ( which i shall call mimesis in order to distinguish it from earlier theories of imitation ) and a new theory of invention ( which i shall call symbol for reasons to be stated hereafter ) .	43.152164
the word `` mimesis ' ' ( `` imitation ' ' ) is usually associated with plato and aristotle .	10.591638
for plato , `` imitation ' ' is twice removed from reality , being a poor copy of physical appearance , which in itself is a poor copy of ideal essence .	76.22018
all artistic and mythological representations , therefore , are `` imitations of imitations ' ' and are completely superseded by the truth value of `` dialectic ' ' , the proper use of the inquiring intellect .	15.243952
in plato ' s judgment , the arts play a meaningful role in society only in the education of the young , prior to the full development of their intellectual powers .	80.91288
presupposed in plato ' s system is a doctrine of levels of insight , in which a certain kind of detached understanding is alone capable of penetrating to the most sublime wisdom .	32.60127
aristotle also tended to stratify all aspects of human nature and activity into levels of excellence and , like plato , he put the pure and unimpassioned intellect on the top level .	94.88577
the poetics , in affirming that all human arts are `` modes of imitation ' ' , gives a more serious role to artistic mimesis than did plato .	57.08663
but aristotle kept the principle of levels and even augmented it by describing in the poetics what kinds of character and action must be imitated if the play is to be a vehicle of serious and important human truths .	51.441055
for both plato and aristotle artistic mimesis , in contrast to the power of dialectic , is relatively incapable of expressing the character of fundamental reality .	47.968822
the central concern of erich auerbach ' s impressive volume called mimesis is to describe the shift from a classic theory of imitation ( based upon a recognition of levels of truth ) to a christian theory of imitation in which the levels are dissolved .	96.13651
following the theme of incarnation in the gospels , the christian artist and critic sees in the most commonplace and ordinary events `` figures ' ' of divine power and reality .	63.145885
here artistic realism involves the audience in an impassioned participation in events whose overtones and implications are transcendent .	44.649075
artistic mimesis under christian influence records the involvement of all persons , however humble , in a divine drama .	47.665653
the artist , unlike the philosopher , is not a removed observer aiming at neutral and rarified high levels of abstraction .	38.29883
he is the conveyor of a sacred reality by which he has been grasped .	36.087097
i have chosen to use the word `` mimesis ' ' in its christian rather than its classic implications and to discover in the concrete forms of both art and myth powers of theological expression which , as in the christian mind , are the direct consequence of involvement in historical experience , which are not reserved , as in the greek mind , only to moments of theoretical reflection .	56.633495
in the first instance , `` mimesis ' ' is here used to mean the recalling of experience in terms of vivid images rather than in terms of abstract ideas or conventional designations .	28.113472
by `` image ' ' is meant not only a visual presentation , but also remembered sensations of any of the five senses plus the feelings which are immediately conjoined therewith .	50.54156
this is the primary function of the imagination operating in the absence of the original experiential stimulus by which the images were first appropriated .	60.61817
mimesis is the nearest possible thing to the actual re-living of experience , in which the imagining person recovers through images something of the force and depth characteristic of experience itself .	47.662018
the images themselves , like their counterparts in experience , are not neutral qualities to be surveyed dispassionately	70.80713
they are fields of force exerting a unique influence on the sensibilities and a unique relatedness to one another .	31.131456
they bring an inextricable component of value within themselves , with attractions and repulsions native to their own quality .	71.47724
as in experience one is seized by given entities and their interrelations and is forced to respond in value feelings to them , so one is similarly seized in the mimetic presentation of images .	47.102245
mimesis here is not to be confused with literalism or realism in the conventional sense .	14.056951
a word taken in its dictionary meaning , a photographic image of a recognizable object , the mere picturing of a `` scene ' ' tends to lose experiential vividness and to connote such conventional abstractions as to invite neutral reception without the incitement of value feelings .	33.507103
similarly experience itself can be conventionalized so that people react to certain preconceived clues for behavior without awareness of the vitality of their experiential field .	45.858074
a truly vivid imagination moves beyond the conventional recollection to a sense of immediacy .	22.054445
the mimetic character of the imaginative consciousness tends to express itself in the presentation of artistic forms and materials .	33.899593
when words can be used in a more fresh and primitive way so that they strike with the force of sights and sounds , when tones of sound and colors of paint and the carven shape all strike the sensibilities with an undeniable force of data in and of themselves , compelling the observer into an attitude of attention , all this imitates the way experience itself in its deepest character strikes upon the door of consciousness and clamors for entrance .	80.14995
these are like the initial ways in which the world forces itself upon the self and thrusts the self into decision and choice .	71.62248
the presence of genuine mimesis in art is marked by the persistence with which the work demands attention and compels valuation even though it is but vaguely understood .	76.1048
underlying these conceptions of mimesis are certain presuppositions concerning the nature of primary human experience which require some exposition before the main argument can proceed .	84.25299
experience is not seen , as it is in classical rationalism , as presenting us initially with clear and distinct objects simply located in space and registering their character , movements , and changes on the tabula rasa of an uninvolved intellect .	47.07207
neither is primary experience understood according to the attitude of modern empiricism in which nothing is thought to be received other than signals of sensory qualities producing their responses in the appropriate sense organs .	108.89144
primary feelings of the world come neither as a collection of clearly known objects ( houses , trees , implements , etc . ) nor a collection of isolated and neutral sensory qualities .	40.96249
in contrast to all this , primary data are data of a self involved in environing processes and powers .	96.22273
the most primitive feelings are rudimentary value feelings , both positive and negative a desire to appropriate this or that part of the environment into oneself	86.53355
a desire to avoid and repel this or that other part .	140.99303
these desires presuppose a sense of causally efficacious powers in which one is involved , some working for one ' s good , others threatening ill .	103.61156
gone is the tabula rasa of the mind .	42.11893
in its place is a passionate consciousness grasped and molded to feelings of positive or negative values even as the actions of one ' s life are determined by constellations of process in which one is caught .	99.4854
the principal defender of this view of primary experience as `` causal efficacy ' ' is alfred north whitehead .	42.701145
our most elemental and unavoidable impressions , he says , are those of being involved in a large arena of powers which have a longer past than our own , which are interrelated in a vast movement through the present toward the future .	91.64172
we feel the quality of these powers initially as in some degree wholesome or threatening .	164.51497
later abstractive and rational processes may indicate errors of judgment in these apprehensions of value , but the apprehensions themselves are the primary stuff of experience .	37.909695
it takes a great deal of abstraction to free oneself from the primitive impression of larger unities of power and influence and to view one ' s world simply as a collection of sense data arranged in such and such sequence and pattern , devoid of all power to move the feelings and actions except in so far as they present themselves for inspection .	105.762924
whitehead is here questioning david hume ' s understanding of the nature of experience	39.380657
he is questioning , also , every epistemology which stems from hume ' s presupposition that experience is merely sense data in abstraction from causal efficacy , and that causal efficacy is something intellectually imputed to the world , not directly perceived .	34.36157
what hume calls `` sensation ' ' is what whitehead calls `` perception in the mode of presentational immediacy ' ' which is a sophisticated abstraction from perception in the mode of causal efficacy .	13.125533
as long as perception is seen as composed only of isolated sense data , most of the quality and interconnectedness of existence loses its objectivity , becomes an invention of consciousness , and the result is a philosophical scepticism .	53.414303
whitehead contends that the human way of understanding existence as a unity of interlocking and interdependent processes which constitute each other and which cause each other to be and not to be is possible only because the basic form of such an understanding , for all its vagueness and tendency to mistake the detail , is initially given in the way man feels the world .	90.41056
in this respect experience is broader and full of a richer variety of potential meanings than the mind of man or any of his arts or culture are capable of making clear and distinct .	88.650406
a chief characteristic of experience in the mode of causal efficacy is one of derivation from the past .	6.0369496
both i and my feelings come up out of a chain of events that fan out into the past into sources that are ultimately very unlike the entity which i now am .	96.54228
after only eighteen years of non-interference , there were already indications of melioration , though `` in a slight degree ' ' , to be sure .	19.074646
there were more indications by the mid-twentieth century .	5.6757903
i leave it to the statisticians to say what they were , but i noticed several a few years ago , during an automobile ride from memphis to hattiesburg .	39.903214
in town after town my companion pointed out the negro school and the white school , and in every instance the former made a better appearance ( it was newer , for one thing ) .	55.105324
it really looked as if a change of the sort predicted by booker t . washington had been going on .	114.88874
but with the renewal of interference in 1954 ( as with its beginning in 1835 ) , the improvement was impaired .	46.700172
for over a hundred years southerners have felt that the north was picking on them .	18.069153
it ' s infuriating , this feeling that one is being picked on , continually , constantly .	161.87747
by what right of superior virtue , southerners ask , do the people of the north do this ? ?	55.416313
the traditional strategy of the south has been to expose the vices of the north , to demonstrate that the north possessed no superior virtue , to `` show the world that ' ' as james ' s christopher newman said to his adversaries ) `` however bad i may be , you ' re not quite the people to say it ' ' .	57.39859
in the pre-civil war years , the south argued that the slave was not less humanely treated than the factory worker of the north .	41.32051
at the present time , the counter-attack takes the line that there ' s no more of the true spirit of `` integration ' ' in the north than in the south .	44.227272
people talk about `` the law of the land ' ' .	4.335187
but people can ' t be made to integrate , socialize ( the two are inseparable by southern standards ) by law .	89.17434
i was having lunch not long ago ( apologies to n . v . peale ) with three distinguished historians ( one specializing in the european middle ages , one in american history , and one in the far east ) , and i asked them if they could name instances where the general mores had been radically changed with `` deliberate speed , majestic instancy ' ' ( francis thompson ' s words for the hound of heaven ' s pursuit ) by judicial fiat .	38.424885
they didn ' t seem to be able to think of any .	25.666597
a virginia judge a while back cited a roman jurist to the effect that ten years might be a reasonable length of time for such a change .	46.34772
but i suspect that the old roman was referring to change made under military occupation -- the sort of change which tacitus was talking about when he said , `` they make a desert , and call it peace ' ' ( `` solitudinem faciunt , pacem appellant ' ' .	44.615746
moreover , the law of the land is not irrevocable	18.305164
mr . justice taney ' s dred scott decision in 1857 was unpopular in the north , and soon became a dead letter .	46.207443
prohibition was the law of the land , but it was unpopular ( how many of us oldsters took up drinking in prohibition days , drinking was so gay , so fashionable , especially in the sophisticated northeast ! !	67.614204
the cliche loses its talismanic virtue in the light of a little history .	59.500893
the declaration of independence says that `` governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed ' ' .	48.722214
the phrase `` consent of the governed ' ' needs a hard look .	80.62126
how do we define it ' ' ? ?	1.0063968
is the consent of the governed a numerical majority ? ?	22.902555
calhoun dealt with this question in his `` disquisition on government ' ' .	19.456911
to guard against the tyranny of a numerical majority , calhoun developed his theory of `` concurrent majority ' ' , which , he said , `` by giving to each portion of the community which may be unequally affected by the action of government , a negative on the others , prevents all partial or local legislation ' ' .	32.24942
who will say that our country is even now a homogeneous community ? ?	120.69788
that regional peculiarities do not still exist ? ?	1.1595968
that the court order does not unequally affect the southern region ? ?	37.488453
who will deny that in a vast portion of the south the federal action is incompatible with the jeffersonian concept of `` the consent of the governed ' ' ? ?	12.960125
a friend of mine in new mexico said the court order had caused no particular trouble out there , that all had gone as merry as a marriage bell .	102.30312
he seemed a little surprised that it should have caused any particular trouble anywhere .	89.33957
i murmured something about a possible difference between new mexico ' s history and mississippi ' s .	29.261862
one can meet with aloofness almost anywhere the thidiu viewpoint , it doesn ' t affect us ! !	19.86812
southern liberals ( there are a good many ) -- especially if they ' re rich -- often exhibit blithe insouciance .	67.67991
the trouble here is that it ' s almost too easy to take the high moral ground when it doesn ' t cost you anything .	75.94646
you ' ve already sent your daughter to miss x ' s select academy for girls and your son to mr . y ' s select academy for boys , and you can be as liberal as you please with strict impunity .	38.67875
if there ' s no suitable academy in your own neighborhood , there ' s always new england .	29.669968
new england academies welcome fugitives from the provinces , south as well as west .	37.078777
they may even enroll a colored student or two for show , though he usually turns out to be from thailand , or any place other than the american south .	120.83592
it would be interesting to know how much `` integration ' ' there is in the famous , fashionable colleges and prep schools of new england .	29.508135
a recent newspaper report said there were five negroes in the 1960 graduating class of nearly one thousand at yale	66.41268
that is , about one-half of one per cent , which looks pretty `` tokenish ' ' to me , especially in an institution which professes to be `` national ' ' .	21.621363
i must confess that i prefer the liberal who is personally affected , who is willing to send his own children to a mixed school as proof of his faith .	38.384155
i leave out of account the question of the best interests of the children , the question of what their best interests really are .	61.51504
i ' m talking about the grand manner of the liberal -- north and south -- who is not affected personally .	63.840195
if these people were denied a voice ( do they have a moral right to a voice ? ?	129.7468
) , what voices would be left ? ?	1.0080492
well , after everybody has followed the new england pattern of segregating one ' s children into private schools , only the poor folks are left .	83.833046
and it is precisely in this poorer economic class that one finds , and has always found , the most racial friction .	95.55978
a dear , respected friend of mine , who like myself grew up in the south and has spent many years in new england , said to me not long ago `` i can ' t forgive new england for rejecting all complicity ' ' .	66.680786
being a teacher of american literature , i remembered whittier ' s `` massachusetts to virginia ' ' , where he said `` but that one dark loathsome burden ye must stagger with alone , and reap the bitter harvest which ye yourselves have sown ' ' .	30.779963
there is a legend ( hawthorne records it in his `` english notebooks ' ' .	23.90119
and one finds it again in thomas nelson page ) to the effect that the mayflower on its second voyage brought a cargo of negro slaves .	61.844128
whether historically a fact or not , the legend has a certain symbolic value .	76.429375
it is something which most of us try to get out from under .	52.908615
like the cowboy in stephen crane ' s `` blue hotel ' ' , we run around crying , `` well , i didn ' t do anything , did i ' ' ? ?	20.58303
robert penn warren puts it this way in `` brother to dragons ' ' `` the recognition of complicity is the beginning of innocence ' ' , where innocence , i think , means about the same thing as redemption .	35.787632
a man must be able to say , `` father , i have sinned ' ' , or there is no hope for him .	23.868725
lincoln understood this better than most when he said in his `` second inaugural ' ' that god `` gives to both north and south this terrible war , as the woe due to those by whom the offense came ' ' .	75.961845
he also spoke of `` the wealth piled by the bondsman ' s two hundred and fifty years in unrequited toil ' ' .	14.60114
lincoln was historian and economist enough to know that a substantial portion of this wealth had accumulated in the hands of the descendants of new englanders engaged in the slave trade .	31.204952
after how many generations is such wealth ( mounting all the while through the manipulations of high finance ) purified of taint ? ?	107.96247
it is a question which new englanders long ago put out of their minds .	43.855053
but didn ' t they get off too easy ? ?	29.672562
the slaves never shared in their profits , while they did share , in a very real sense , in the profits of the slave-owners they were fed , clothed , doctored , and so forth	22.74727
they were the beneficiaries of responsible , paternalistic care .	25.76309
emerson -- platonist , idealist , doctrinaire -- sounded a high transcendental note in his `` boston hymn ' ' , delivered in 1863 in the boston music hall amidst thundering applause `` pay ransom to the owner and fill the bag to the brim .	21.249178
the slave is owner , and ever was .	212.81578
it is the abstractionism , the unrealism , of the pure idealist .	23.117264
it ignores the sordid financial aspects ( quite conveniently , too , for his audience , who could indulge in moral indignation without visible , or even conscious , discomfort , their money from the transaction having been put away long ago in a good antiseptic brokerage ) .	59.23304
like pilate , they had washed their hands .	16.950504
can god be mocked , ever , in the long run ? ?	50.863064
new englanders were a bit sensitive on the subject of their complicity in negro slavery at the time of the drafting of the declaration of independence , as jefferson explained in his `` autobiography ' ' ``	23.815313
the clause reprobating the enslaving the inhabitants of africa was struck out in complaisance to south carolina and georgia , who had never attempted to restrain the importation of slaves , and who on the contrary still wished to continue it .	35.608288
our northern brethren also i believe felt a little tender under those censures	47.695286
for though their people had very few slaves themselves , yet they had been pretty considerable carriers of them to others ' ' .	79.65552
george w . cable ( naturalized new englander ) , writing in 1889 from `` paradise road , northampton ' ' ( lovely symbolic name ) , agitated continuously the `` southern question ' ' .	29.138617
it was nice to be able to isolate it .	8.089126
new england , as everyone knows , has long been schoolmaster to the nation .	27.466291
there one finds concentrated in a comparatively small area the chief universities , colleges , and preparatory schools of the united states .	23.85717
it is true that new england , more than any other section , was dedicated to education from the start .	108.9707
but i think that something more than this is involved .	92.84894
how did it happen , for example , that the state university , that great symbol of american democracy , failed to flourish in new england as it did in other parts of the country ? ?	32.786877
isn ' t it a bit odd that the three states of southern new england ( massachusetts , connecticut , and rhode island ) have had state institutions of university status only in the very recent past , these institutions having previously been a & m colleges ? ?	72.51811
was it supposed , perchance , that a & m ( vocational training , that is ) was quite sufficient for the immigrant class which flooded that part of the new england world in the post-civil war period , the immigrants having been brought in from southern europe , to work in the mills , to make up for the labor shortage caused by migration to the west ? ?	52.57056
is it not ironical that roger williams ' s state , rhode island , should have been the very last of the forty-eight to establish a state university ? ?	45.25697
the state universities of maine , new hampshire , and vermont are older and more `` respectable ' '	30.983904
a yale historian , writing a few years ago in the yale review , said `` we in new england have long since segregated our children ' ' .	23.650301
he was referring not only to the general college situation but more especially to the preparatory schools .	153.77303
and what a galaxy of those adorns that fair land ! !	190.01132
i don ' t propose to go into their history , but i have one or two surmises .	72.185844
one is that they were established , or gained eminence , under pressure provided by these same immigrants , from whom the old families wished to segregate their children .	107.54561
in the early days of a homogeneous population , the public school was quite satisfactory .	86.545845
among the recipients of the nobel prize for literature more than half are practically unknown to readers of english .	110.571594
of these there are surely few that would be more rewarding discoveries than verner von heidenstam , the swedish poet and novelist who received the award in 1916 and whose centennial was celebrated two years ago .	23.828566
equally a master of prose and verse , he recreates the glory of sweden in the past and continues it into the present .	22.966593
in the following sketch we shall present a brief outline of his life and let him as much as possible speak for himself .	33.33994
heidenstam was born in 1859 , of a prosperous family .	19.749182
on his father ' s side he was of german descent , on his mother ' s he came of the old swedish nobility .	43.27834
the family estate was situated near vadstena on lake vattern in south central sweden .	29.217218
it is a lonely , rather desolate region , but full of legendary and historic associations .	62.194946
as a boy in a local school he was shy and solitary , absorbed in his fondness for nature and his visions of sweden ' s ancient glory .	24.396885
he liked to fancy himself as a chieftain and to dress for the part .	76.521706
being somewhat delicate in health , at the age of sixteen he was sent to southern europe , for which he at once developed a passion , so that he spent nearly all of the following ten years abroad , at first in italy , then in greece , egypt , asia minor , and palestine .	50.466087
in one of his summers at home he married , to the great disapproval of his father , who objected because of his extreme youth .	38.39727
deciding to become a painter , he entered the studio of gerome in paris , where he enjoyed the life of the artists , but soon found that whatever talent he might have did not lie in that direction .	39.78285
he gives us an account of this in his lively and humorous poem , `` the happy artists ' ' .	21.346638
`` i scanned the world through printed symbol swart , and through the beggar ' s rags i strove to see the inner man .	25.29698
i looked unceasingly with my cold mind and with my burning heart ' ' .	30.032255
in this final line , we have the key to his nature .	115.35392
few writers have better understood their deepest selves .	4.1277475
it may , however , be noted that his gift for color and imagery must have been greatly stimulated by his stay in paris .	62.74588
the first result of heidenstam ' s long sojourn abroad was a volume of poems , pilgrimage and wander-years ( vallfart och vandringsar ) , published in 1888 .	16.429855
it was a brilliant debut , so much so indeed that it aroused a new vitality in the younger poets , as did byron ' s childe harold .	52.36004
professor fredrik book , sweden ' s foremost critic of the period , acclaims it as follows `` in this we have the verse of a painter	60.69409
strongly colorful , plastic , racy , vivid .	18.237719
in a bold , sometimes careless , form there is nothing academic	308.0255
all is seen and felt and experienced , the observation is sharp and the imagination lively .	47.148808
the young poet-painter reproduces the french life of the streets	135.45802
he tells stories of the thousand and one nights , and conjures up before us the bazaars of damascus .	20.946293
in the care-free indolence of the east he sees the last reflection of the old happy existence , and for that reason he loves it .	79.42511
and yet amid all the gay hedonism in pilgrimage and wander-years is a cycle of short poems , `` thoughts in loneliness ' ' , filled with brooding , melancholy , and sombre longing ' ' .	15.190511
of the longer pieces of the volume none is so memorable as `` nameless and immortal ' ' , which at once took rank among the finest poems ever written in the swedish language .	37.934273
it celebrates the unknown architect who designed the temple of neptune at paestum , next to the parthenon the noblest example of grecian classic style now in existence .	25.253471
on the eve of his return to their native naxos he speaks with his wife of the masterpiece which rises before them in its completed perfection .	46.321186
the supreme object of their lives is now fulfilled , says the wife , her husband has achieved immortality .	36.60166
not so , he answers , it is not the architect but the temple that is immortal .	51.190796
`` the man ' s true reputation is his work ' ' .	30.845903
the short poems grouped at the end of the volume as `` thoughts in loneliness ' ' is , as professor book indicated , in sharp contrast with the others .	48.901577
it consists of fragmentary personal revelations , such as `` the spark ' ' `` there is a spark dwells deep within my soul .	18.068245
to get it out into the daylight ' s glow is my life ' s aim both first and last , the whole .	71.86874
it slips away , it burns and tortures me .	16.916904
that little spark is all the wealth i know , that little spark is my life ' s misery ' ' .	33.982796
a dominant motive is the poet ' s longing for his homeland and its boyhood associations `` not men-folk , but the fields where i would stray , the stones where as a child i used to play ' ' .	49.326843
he is utterly disappointed in himself and in the desultory life he has been leading .	64.29199
what he really wants is to find `` a sacred cause ' ' to which he can honestly devote himself .	27.100965
this restless individualism found its answer when he returned to live nearly all the rest of his life in sweden .	64.5667
his cause was to commemorate the glory of her past and to incite her people to perpetuate it in the present .	30.663624
he did not , however , find himself at once .	43.133015
his next major work , completed in 1892 , was a long fantastic epic in prose , entitled hans alienus , which professor book describes as a monument on the grave of his carefree and indolent youth .	19.10883
the hero , who is himself , is represented as a pilgrim in the storied lands of the east , a sort of faustus type , who , to quote from professor book again , `` even in the pleasure gardens of sardanapalus can not cease from his painful search after the meaning of life .	43.56419
he is driven back by his yearning to the wintry homeland of his fathers in the forest of tiveden ' ' .	6.962582
from this time on heidenstam proceeded to find his deeper self .	37.379303
by the death of his father in 1888 he had come into possession of the family estate and had re-assumed its traditions .	43.449207
he did not , however , settle back into acquiescence with things as they were .	80.44818
like his friend and contemporary august strindberg he had little patience with collective mediocrity .	39.546627
he saw sweden as a country of smug and narrow provincialism , indifferent to the heroic spirit of its former glory .	32.75512
strindberg ' s remedy for this condition was to tear down the old structures and build anew from the ground up .	61.645008
heidenstam ' s conception , on the contrary , was to revive the present by the memories of the past .	21.336233
whether in prose or poetry , all of heidenstam ' s later work was concerned with sweden .	35.170372
with the first of a group of historical novels , the charles men ( karolinerna ) , published in 1897-8 , he achieved the masterpiece of his career .	16.331217
in scope and power it can only be compared to tolstoy ' s war and peace .	48.319145
about one-third as long , it is less intimate and detailed , but better coordinated , more concise and more dramatic .	67.40027
though it centers around the brilliant and enigmatic figure of charles 12 , , the true hero is not finally the king himself .	38.274082
hence the title of the book , referring to the soldiers and subjects of the king	50.05628
on the fatal battlefield of poltava , to quote from the novel , `` the wreath he twined for himself slipped down upon his people ' ' .	31.783018
the charles men consists not of a connected narrative but of a group of short stories , each depicting a special phase of the general subject .	53.6148
somewhat uneven in interest for an average reader , eight or ten of these are among the finest of their kind in literature .	80.17055
they comprise a great variety of scene and interest grim episodes of war , idyllic interludes , superb canvases of world-shaking events , and delightfully humorous sketches of odd characters .	23.461817
almost nothing is said of charles ' spectacular victories , the central theme being the heroic loyalty of the swedish people to their idolized king in misfortune and defeat .	30.18651
to carry out this exalted conception the author has combined the vivid realism and imaginative power we have noticed in his early poetry and carried them out on a grand scale .	60.19556
his peculiar gift , as had been suggested before , is his intensity .	286.81085
george meredith has said that fervor is the core of style .	37.9107
of few authors is this more true than of heidenstam .	94.95666
the charles men has a tremendous range of characters , of common folk even more than of major figures .	113.28541
the career of charles 12 , is obviously very similar to that of napoleon .	126.48704
his ideal was alexander of macedon , as napoleon ' s was julius caesar .	13.930274
his purpose , however , was not to establish an empire , but to assert the principle of divine justice .	16.988987
each aspired to be a god in human form , but with each it was a different kind of god .	58.12852
each failed catastrophically in an invasion of russia and each brought ruin on the country that worshipped him .	69.99762
each is still glorified as a national hero .	2.9106915
the first half of the charles men , ending on the climax of the battle of poltava in 1709 , is more dramatically coherent than the second .	24.79407
after the collapse of that desperate and ill-fated campaign the character of the king degenerated for a time into a futility that was not merely pitiable but often ridiculous .	37.638058
like napoleon , he was the worst of losers .	6.6351976
there are , however , some wonderful chapters at the beginning of the second part , concerning the reactions of the swedes in adversity .	20.691208
then more than ever before did they show their fortitude and patient cheerfulness .	23.392696
this comes out in `` when the bells ring ' ' , which describes the rallying of the peasants in southern sweden to repel an invasion by the danes .	17.035608
in `` the king ' s ride ' ' , charles breaks out of a long period of petulance and inertia , regains his old self , escapes from turkey , and finally reaches his own land after an absence of eighteen years .	26.166298
he finds it in utter misery and desolation .	1.8963329
all his people ask for is no more war .	385.31772
but he plunges into yet another , this time with norway , and is killed in an assault on the fortress of fredrikshall , being only thirty-six years of age when he died .	35.08135
then suddenly there was a tremendous revulsion of popular feeling .	179.02837
from being a hated tyrant and madman he was now the symbol of all that was noblest and best in the history of sweden .	27.971392
this is brought out in the next to last chapter of the book , `` a hero ' s funeral ' ' , written in the form of an impassioned prose poem .	20.446321
slowly the procession of warriors and statesmen passes through the snow beside the black water and into the brilliantly lighted cathedral , the shrine of so many precious memories .	27.833527
the guns are fired , the hymns are sung , and the body of charles is carried down to the vault and laid beside the tombs of his ancestors .	20.554665
as he had longed to be , he became the echo of a saga .	32.617844
heidenstam wrote four other works of fiction about earlier figures revered in swedish memory .	54.05151
excellent in their way , they lack the wide appeal of the charles men , and need not detain us here .	75.22199
it is different with his volume the swedes and their chieftains ( svenskarna och deras hovdingar ) , a history intended for the general reader and particularly suited for high school students .	36.237137
admirably written , it is a perfect introduction to swedish history for readers of other countries .	88.04139
some of the earlier episodes have touches of the supernatural , as suited to the legendary background .	23.846827
especially touching is the chapter , `` the little sister ' ' , about a king ' s daughter who became a nun in the convent of st . birgitta .	14.742428
gustaf vasa is a superb example , and charles 10 , , the conqueror of denmark , hardly less so .	81.360435
of gustavus adolphus and charles 12 , it is unnecessary to speak .	15.3491955
today the private detective will also investigate insurance claims or handle divorce cases , but his primary function remains what it has always been , to assist those who have money in their unending struggle with those who have not .	52.929356
it is from this unpromising background that the fictional private detective was recruited .	17.332596
the mythological private eye differs from his counterpart in real life in two essential ways .	57.53077
on the one hand , he does not work for a large agency , but is almost always self-employed .	38.769302
as a free-lance investigator , the fictional detective is responsible to no one but himself and his client .	116.48132
for this reason , he appears as an independent and self-reliant figure , whose rugged individualism need not be pressed into the mold of a 9 to 5 routine .	59.050438
on the other hand , the fictional detective does not break strikes or handle divorce cases	119.24855
no client would ever think of asking him to do such things .	25.444439
whatever his original assignment , the fictional private eye ends up by investigating and solving a crime , usually a murder .	43.926495
operating as a one man police force in fact if not in name , he is at once more independent and more dedicated than the police themselves .	112.77737
he catches criminals not merely because he is paid to do so ( frequently he does not receive a fee at all ) , but because he enjoys his work , because he firmly believes that murder must be punished .	70.49574
thus the fictional detective is much more than a simple businessman .	71.582054
he is , first and foremost , a defender of public morals , a servant of society .	20.040861
it is this curious blend of rugged individualism and public service which accounts for the great appeal of the mythological detective .	49.158432
by virtue of his self-reliance , his individualism and his freedom from external restraint , the private eye is a perfect embodiment of the middle class conception of liberty , which amounts to doing what you please and let the devil take the hindmost .	49.66194
at the same time , because the personal code of the detective coincides with the legal dictates of his society , because he likes to catch criminals , he is in middle class eyes a virtuous man .	44.09562
in this way , the private detective gets the best of two possible worlds .	45.140965
he is a public servant but not a cop .	13.163896
in short , the fictional private eye is a specialized version of adam smith ' s ideal entrepreneur , the man whose private ambitions must always and everywhere promote the public welfare .	43.050976
in the mystery story , as in the wealth of nations , individualism and the social good are two sides of the same benevolent coin .	59.63391
there is only one catch to this idyllic arrangement adam smith was wrong .	142.76286
not only did the ideal entrepreneur not produce the greatest good for the greatest number , he ended by destroying himself , by giving birth to monopoly capitalism .	51.104847
the rise of the giant corporations in western europe and the united states dates from the period 1880-1900 .	18.217506
now , although the roots of the mystery story in serious literature go back as far as balzac , dickens , and poe , it was not until the closing decades of the 19th century that the private detective became an established figure in popular fiction .	42.400177
sherlock holmes , the ancestor of all private eyes , was born during the 1890s .	38.75325
thus the transformation of adam smith ' s ideal entrepreneur into a mythological detective coincides closely with the decline of the real entrepreneur in economic life .	31.17876
driven from the marketplace by the course of history , our hero disguises himself as a private detective .	18.142653
the birth of the myth compensates for the death of the ideal .	61.35349
even on the fictional level , however , the contradictions which give rise to the mystery story are not fully resolved .	32.18935
the individualism and public service of the private detective both stem from his dedication to a personal code of conduct he enforces the law without being told to do so .	55.700943
but his morality rests upon that of his society .	16.48212
the basic premise of all mystery stories is that the distinction between good and bad coincides with the distinction between legal and illegal .	39.94879
unfortunately , this assumption does not always hold good .	117.335846
as capitalism in the 20th century has become increasingly dependent upon force and violence for its survival , the private detective is placed in a serious dilemma .	46.154053
if he is good , he may not be legal	131.8699
if he is legal , he may not be good .	50.978275
it is the gradual unfolding and deepening of this contradiction which creates the inner dialectic of the evolution of the mystery story .	11.41347
with the advent of sir arthur conan doyle ' s sherlock holmes , the development of the modern private detective begins .	19.560757
he is very close to being a mental case .	70.19412
a brief list of the great detective ' s little idiosyncrasies would provide dr . freud with ample food for thought .	61.23926
holmes is addicted to the use of cocaine and other refreshing stimulants	17.836834
he is prone to semi-catatonic trances induced by the playing of the vioiln	9.50489
he is a recluse , an incredible egotist , a confirmed misogynist .	11.150442
holmes rebels against the social conventions of his day not on moral but rather on aesthetic grounds .	143.56383
his eccentricity begins as a defense against boredom .	2.8828964
it was in order to avoid the stuffy routine of middle class life that holmes became a detective in the first place .	25.774586
as he informs watson , `` my life is spent in one long effort to escape from the commonplaces of existence .	36.370155
these little problems help me to do so ' ' .	6.7309833
holmes is a public servant , to be sure	4.0952797
but the society which he serves bores him to tears .	13.669333
the curious relationship between holmes and scotland yard provides an important clue to the deeper significance of his eccentric behavior .	21.633356
although he is perfectly willing to cooperate with scotland yard , holmes has nothing but contempt for the intelligence and mentality of the police .	67.79134
they for their part are convinced that holmes is too `` unorthodox ' ' and `` theoretical ' ' to make a good detective .	19.768824
why do the police find holmes `` unorthodox ' ' ? ?	3.6172352
on the face of it , it is because he employs deductive techniques alien to official police routine .	58.26163
another , more interesting explanation , is hinted at by watson when he observes on several occasions that holmes would have made a magnificent criminal .	63.606472
watson ' s insight is verified by the mysterious link between holmes and his arch-opponent , dr . moriarty .	10.071928
the two men resemble each other closely in their cunning , their egotism , their relentlessness .	24.989143
the first series of sherlock holmes adventures ends with holmes and moriarty grappling together on the edge of a cliff .	9.503182
they are presumed to have plunged to a common grave in this fatal embrace .	26.1499
linked to holmes even in death , moriarty represents the alter-ego of the great detective , the image of what our hero might have become were he not a public servant .	58.619328
just as holmes the eccentric stands behind holmes the detective , so holmes the potential criminal lurks behind both .	51.711914
in the modern english `` whodunnit ' ' , this insinuation of latent criminality in the detective himself has almost entirely disappeared .	25.188787
hercule poirot and lord peter whimsey ( the respective creations of agatha christie and dorothy sayers ) have retained holmes ' egotism but not his zest for life and eccentric habits .	17.883963
it is true that they are also extremely dull .	12.912493
their dedication to the status quo has been affirmed at the expense of the fascinating but dangerous individualism of a sherlock holmes .	18.833906
the latter ' s real descendents were unable to take root in england	36.302036
they fled from the victorian parlor and made their way across the stormy atlantic .	35.009766
in the american `` hardboiled ' ' detective story of the ' 20s and ' 30s , the spirit of the mad genius from baker street lives on .	70.78836
like holmes , the american private eye rejects the social conventions of his time .	31.997093
but unlike holmes , he feels his society to be not merely dull but also corrupt .	75.47137
surrounded by crime and violence everywhere , the `` hardboiled ' ' private eye can retain his purity only through a life of self-imposed isolation .	25.81505
his alienation is far more acute than holmes '	3.1143274
he is not an eccentric but rather an outcast .	9.852652
with rex stout ' s nero wolfe , alienation is represented on a purely physical plane .	76.41272
wolfe refuses to ever leave his own house , and spends most of his time drinking beer and playing with orchids .	60.835056
more profound and more disturbing , however , is the moral isolation of raymond chandler ' s philip marlowe .	33.52328
in a society where everything is for sale , marlowe is the only man who cannot be bought .	71.649155
his tough honesty condemns him to a solitary and difficult existence .	214.94543
beaten , bruised and exhausted , he pursues the elusive killer through the demi-monde of high society and low morals , always alone , always despised .	46.001373
in the end , he gets his man , but no one seems to care	58.452217
a similar tone of underlying futility and despair pervades the spy thrillers of eric ambler and dominates the most famous of all american mystery stories , dashiell hammett ' s the maltese falcon .	10.406929
sam spade joins forces with a band of adventurers in search of a priceless jeweled statue of a falcon	20.904669
but when the bird is found at last , it turns out to be a fake .	28.045494
now the detective must save his own skin by informing on the girl he loves , who is also the real murderer .	30.257427
for sam spade , neither crime nor virtue pays	529.6204
moreover , it is increasingly difficult to distinguish between the two .	30.491676
because the private eye intends to save society in spite of himself , he invariably finds himself in trouble with the police .	65.17071
the latter are either too stupid to catch the killer or too corrupt to care .	20.649876
in either case , they do not appreciate the private detective ' s zeal .	20.026026
perry mason and hamilton burger , nero wolfe and inspector cramer spend more time fighting each other than they do in looking for the criminal .	96.43554
frequently enough , the police are themselves in league with the killer	71.566696
dashiell hammett ' s red harvest provides a classic example of this theme .	47.659515
but even when the police are honest , they do not trust the private eye .	26.470459
he is , like phillip marlowe , too alienated to be reliable .	12.999559
finally , in the maltese falcon among others , the clash between detective and police is carried to its logical conclusion sam spade becomes the chief murder suspect .	84.74068
in order to exonerate himself , he is compelled to find the real criminal , who happens to be his girl friend .	47.27509
what was only a vague suspicion in the case of sherlock holmes now appears as a direct accusation the private eye is in danger of turning into his opposite .	61.27814
it is the growing contradiction between individualism and public service in the mystery story which creates this fatal dilemma .	24.743
by upholding his own personal code of behavior , the private detective has placed himself in opposition to a society whose fabric is permeated with crime and corruption .	19.527472
that society responds by condemning the private eye as a threat to the status quo , a potential criminal .	33.549385
if the detective insists upon retaining his personal standards , he must now do so in conscious defiance of his society .	54.168163
he must , in short , cease to be a detective and become a rebel .	60.47197
on the other hand , if he wishes to continue in his chosen profession , he must abandon his own code and sacrifice his precious individualism .	36.724957
dashiell hammett resolved this contradiction by ceasing to write mystery stories and turning to other pursuits .	98.82022
in order to save the mystery story , they have converted the private detective into an organization man .	48.295723
the first of two possible variations on this theme is symbolized by mickey spillane ' s mike hammer .	12.966141
at first glance , this hero seems to be more rather than less of an individualist than any of his predecessors .	33.13755
he kills when he pleases , takes his women where he finds them and always acts as judge , jury and executioner rolled into one .	138.56458
it will be shown that the objectives of the cooperative people in an organization determine the type of network required , because the type of network functions according to the characteristics of the messages enumerated in table 1 .	37.800102
great stress is placed on the role that the monitoring of information sending plays in maintaining the effectiveness of the network .	37.97522
by monitoring , we mean some system of control over the types of information sent from the various centers .	46.351788
as a word of caution , we should be aware that in actual practice no message is purely one of the four types , question , command , statement , or exclamation .	129.7664
for example , suppose a man wearing a $200 watch , driving a 1959 rolls royce , stops to ask a man on the sidewalk , `` what time is it ' ' ? ?	41.68248
this sentence would have most of the characteristics of a question , but it has some of the characteristics of a statement because the questioner has conveyed the fact that he has no faith in his own timepiece or the one attached to his car .	29.257504
if the man on the sidewalk is surprised at this question , it has served as an exclamation .	37.937256
also , since the man questioned feels a strong compulsion to answer ( and thereby avoid the consequences of being thought queer ) the question has assumed some measurable properties of a command .	72.36039
however , for convenience we will stick to the idea that information can be classified according to table 1 .	88.599365
on this basis , certain extreme kinds of networks will be discussed for illustrative purposes .	6.146791
presumably a cocktail party is expected to fulfill the host ' s desire to get together a number of people who are inadequately acquainted and thereby arrange for bringing the level of acquaintance up to adequacy for future cooperative endeavors .	33.824654
the party is usually in a room small enough so that all guests are within sight and hearing of one another .	124.82525
the information is furnished by each of the guests , is sent by oral broadcasting over the air waves , and is received by the ears .	67.88865
since the air is a continuum , the network of communication remains intact regardless of the positions or motions of the points ( the people ) in the net .	54.413605
as shown in figure 1 , there is a connection for communication between every pair of points .	51.493046
this , and other qualifications , make the cocktail party the most complete and most chaotic communication system ever dreamed up .	109.432274
all four types of message listed in table 1 are permitted , although decorum and cocktail tradition require holding the commands to a minimum , while exclamations having complimentary intonations are more than customarily encouraged .	27.830017
the completeness of the connections provide that , for n people , there are af lines of communication between the pairs , which can become a large number ( 1 , 225 ) for a party of fifty guests .	63.59082
looking at the diagram , we see that af connection lines come in to each member .	277.75238
thus the cocktail party would appear to be the ideal system , but there is one weakness .	83.068634
in spite of the dreams of the host for oneness in the group , the af incoming messages for each guest overload his receiving system beyond comprehension if n exceeds about six .	73.86795
the crowd consequently breaks up into temporary groups ranging in size from two to six , with a half-life for the cluster ranging from three to twenty minutes .	70.58373
for the occasion on which everyone already knows everyone else and the host wishes them to meet one or a few honored newcomers , then the `` open house ' ' system is advantageous because the honored guests are fixed connective points and the drifting guests make and break connections at the door .	91.172516
we consider a rural community as an assemblage of inhabited dwellings whose configuration is determined by the location and size of the arable land sites necessary for family subsistence .	24.936527
we assume for this illustration that the size of the land plots is so great that the distance between dwellings is greater than the voice can carry and that most of the communication is between nearest neighbors only , as shown in figure 2 .	37.569195
information beyond nearest neighbor is carried second- , third- , and fourth-hand as a distortable rumor .	6.979324
in figure 2 , the points in the network are designated by a letter accompanied by a number .	36.05514
the numbers indicate the number of nearest neighbors .	4.524415
it will be noted that point f has seven nearest neighbors , h and e have six , and p has only one , while the remaining points have intermediate numbers .	171.47816
in any social system in which communications have an importance comparable with that of production and other human factors , a point like f in figure 2 would ( other things being equal ) be the dwelling place for the community leader , while e and h would house the next most important citizens .	131.22076
a point like p gets information directly from n , but all information beyond n is indirectly relayed through n .	140.63205
the dweller at p is last to hear about a new cure , the slowest to announce to his neighbors his urgent distresses , the one who goes the farthest to trade , and the one with the greatest difficulty of all in putting over an idea or getting people to join him in a cooperative effort .	68.45335
since the hazards of poor communication are so great , p can be justified as a habitable site only on the basis of unusual productivity such as is made available by a waterfall for milling purposes , a mine , or a sugar maple camp .	77.61801
location theorists have given these matters much consideration .	6.6736565
the networks for military communications are one of the best examples of networks which not only must be changed with the changes in objectives but also must be changed with the addition of new machines of war .	54.56199
they also furnish proof that , in modern war , message sending must be monitored .	111.332855
without monitoring , a military hookup becomes a noisy party .	5.5723834
the need for monitoring became greater when radio was adopted for military signaling .	30.163086
alexander the great , who used runners as message carriers , did not have to worry about having every officer in his command hear what he said and having hundreds of them comment at once .	121.3309
as time has passed and science has progressed , the speed of military vehicles has increased , the range of missiles has been extended , the use of target-hunting noses on the projectiles has been adopted , and the range and breadth of message sending has increased .	33.445827
next to the old problem of the slowness of decision making , network structure seems to be paramount , and without monitoring no network has value .	116.777016
on the parade ground the net may be similar to that shown in figure 3 .	24.92642
the monitoring is the highest and most restrictive of any organization in existence .	46.77744
no questions , statements , or explanations are permitted -- only commands .	91.30565
commands go only from an officer to the man of nearest lower rank .	63.503975
the same command is repeated as many times as there are levels in rank from general to corporal .	42.982372
all orders originate with the officer of highest rank and terminate with action of the men in the ranks .	22.554432
even the officer in charge , be it a captain ( for small display ) or a general , is restrained by monitoring .	70.887024
this is done for simplicity of commands and to bring the hidden redundancy up to where misunderstanding has almost zero possibility .	180.96906
are few in number , briefly worded , all different in sound	689.3831
and are combinable into sequences which permit any marching maneuver that could be desired on a parade ground .	21.036703
this monitoring is necessary because , on a parade ground , everyone can hear too much , and without monitoring a confused social event would develop .	86.67767
with troops dispersed on fields of battle rather than on the parade ground , it may seem that a certain amount of monitoring is automatically enforced by the lines of communication .	22.826328
years ago this was true , but with the replacement of wires or runners by radio and radar ( and perhaps television ) , these restrictions have disappeared and now again too much is heard .	72.23984
in contrast to cocktail parties , military organizations , even in the field , are more formal .	43.553295
in the extreme and oversimplified example suggested in figure 3 , the organization is more easily understood and more predictable in behavior .	29.420092
a military organization has an objective chosen by the higher command .	99.57377
this objective is adhered to throughout the duration of the action .	13.661719
the connective system , or network , is tailored to meet the requirements of the objective , and it is therefore not surprising that a military body acting as a single coordinated unit has a different communication network than a factory , a college , or a rural village .	45.57789
the assumptions upon which the example shown in figure 3 is based are ( a ) one man can direct about six subordinates if the subordinates are chosen carefully so that they do not need too much personal coaching , indoctrinating , etc . .	63.456604
( b ) a message runs too great a risk of being distorted if it is to be relayed more than about six consecutive times .	61.881413
( c ) decisions of a general kind are made by the central command .	78.50363
and ( d ) all action of a physical kind pertinent to the mission is relegated to the line of men on the lower rank .	53.181103
these assumptions lead to an organization with one man at the top , six directly under him , six under each of these , and so on until there are six levels of personnel .	71.99173
the number of people acting as one body by this scheme gives a surprisingly large army of 55 , 987 men .	80.69126
this organizational network would be of no avail if there were no regulations pertaining to the types of message sent .	27.29916
of types of message listed in table 1 , commands and statements are the only ones sent through the vertical network shown in figure 3 .	67.34653
a further regulation is that commands always go down , unaccompanied by statements , and statements always go up , unaccompanied by commands .	42.012123
questions and , particularly , exclamations are usually channeled along informal , horizontal lines not indicated in figure 3 and seldom are carried beyond the nearest neighbor .	69.61619
it will readily be seen that in this suggested network ( not materially different from some of the networks in vogue today ) greater emphasis on monitoring is implied than is usually put into practice .	165.95303
furthermore , the network in figure 3 is only the basic net through which other networks pertaining to logistics and the like are interlaced .	96.79521
not discussed here are some military problems of modern times such as undersea warfare , where the surveillance , sending , transmitting , and receiving are all so inadequate that networks and decision making are not the bottlenecks .	58.525906
such problems are of extreme interest as well as importance and are so much like fighting in a rain forest or guerrilla warfare at night in tall grass that we might have to re-examine primitive conflicts for what they could teach .	62.838425
this is an unsolved problem which probably has never been seriously investigated , although one frequently hears the comment that we have insufficient specialists of the kind who can compete with the germans or swiss , for example , in precision machinery and mathematics , or the finns in geochemistry .	35.67633
we hear equally fervent concern over the belief that we have not enough generalists who can see the over-all picture and combine our national skills and knowledge for useful purposes .	67.446144
this problem of the optimum balance in the relative numbers of generalists and specialists can be investigated on a communicative network basis .	28.59279
