since the difficulty of drawing the net is great , we will merely discuss it .	92.798485
first , we realize that a pure specialist does not exist .	12.324099
but , for practical purposes , we have people who can be considered as such .	68.78155
for example , there are persons who are in physical science , in the field of mineralogy , trained in crystallography , who use only x-rays , applying only the powder technique of x-ray diffraction , to clay minerals only , and who have spent the last fifteen years concentrating on the montmorillonites	43.48329
or persons in the social sciences in the field of anthropology , studying the lung capacity of seven andean indians .	30.46421
so we see that a specialist is a man who knows more and more about less and less as he develops , as contrasted to the generalist , who knows less and less about more and more .	36.297314
american democratic thought , pointed up the relation between the protestant movement in this country and the development of a social religion , which he called the american democratic faith .	26.112957
those familiar with his work will remember that he placed the incipience of the democratic faith at around 1850 .	31.210634
and he describes it as a balanced polarity between the notions of the free individual and what he called the fundamental law .	45.54009
i want to say more about gabriel ' s so-called fundamental law .	18.400526
but first i want to quote him on the relationship that he found between religion and politics in this country and what happened to it .	56.293312
he points out that from the time of jackson on through world war 1 , , evangelical protestantism was a dominant influence in the social and political life of america .	48.674507
he terms this early enthusiasm `` romantic christianity ' ' and concludes that its similarity to democratic beliefs of that day is so great that `` the doctrine of liberty seems but a secular version of its counterpart in evangelical protestantism ' ' .	43.976856
let me quote him even more fully , for his analysis is important to my theme .	85.65743
he says `` beside the protestant philosophy of progress , as expressed in radical or conservative millenarianism , should be placed the doctrine of the democratic faith which affirmed it to be the duty of the destiny of the united states to assist in the creation of a better world by keeping lighted the beacon of democracy ' ' .	29.755228
he specifies , `` in the middle period of the nineteenth century it was colored by christian supernaturalism , in the twentieth century it was affected by naturalism .	12.878791
but in every period it has been humanism ' ' .	4.3683386
and let me add , utopianism , also .	202.41072
some fourteen or fifteen years ago , in an essay i called the leader follows -- where ? ?	175.0544
i used his polarity to illustrate what i thought had happened to us in that form of liberalism we call progressivism .	84.76193
it seemed to me that the liberals had scrapped the balanced polarity and reposed both liberty and the fundamental law in the common man .	29.368002
that is to say gabriel ' s fundamental law had been so much modified by this time that it was neither fundamental nor law any more .	57.255707
it is a weakness of gabriel ' s analysis that he never seems to realize that his so-called fundamental law had already been cut loose from its foundations when it was adapted to democracy .	65.02837
and with progressivism the religion of humanity was replacing what gabriel called christian supernaturalism .	67.04447
and the common man was developing mythic power , or charisma , on his own .	26.363695
during the decade that followed , the common man , as that piece put it , grew uncomfortable as the voice of god and fled from behind saint woodrow ( wilson ) only to learn from science , to his shocked relief that after all there was no god he had to speak for and that he was just an animal anyhow -- that there was a chemical formula for him , and that too much couldn ' t be expected of him .	69.63312
the socialism implicit in the slogan of the roosevelt revolution , freedom from want and fear , seems a far cry from the individualism of the first amendment to the constitution , or of the jacksonian frontier .	75.09573
what had happened to the common man ? ?	1.0262215
french egalitarianism had had only nominal influence in this country before the days of popularism .	18.931322
the riotous onrush of industrialism after the war for southern independence and the general secular drift to the religion of humanity , however , prepared the way for a reception of the french revolution ' s socialistic offspring of one sort of another .	44.781998
the first of which to find important place in our federal government was the graduated income tax under wilson .	115.91257
moreover the centralization of our economy during the 1920s , the dislocations of the depression , the common ethos of materialism everywhere , all contributed in various ways to the face-lifting that replaced mike fink and the great gatsby with the anonymous physiognomy of the little people .	24.167645
however , it is important to trace the philosophy of the french revolution to its sources to understand the common democratic origin of individualism and socialism and the influence of the latter on the former .	49.534973
that john locke ' s philosophy of the social contract fathered the american revolution with its declaration of independence , i believe , we generally accept .	26.741062
yet , after rousseau had given the social contract a new twist with his notion of the general will , the same philosophy , it may be said , became the idea source of the french revolution also .	83.52847
the importance of rousseau ' s twist has not always been clear to us , however .	36.6226
this notion of the general will gave rise to the commune of paris in the revolution and later brought napoleon to dictatorship .	34.102985
and it is clearly argued by lord percy of newcastle , in his remarkable long essay , the heresy of democracy , and in a more general way by voegelin , in his new science of politics , that this same rousseauan idea , descending through european democracy , is the source of marx ' s theory of the dictatorship of the proletariat .	34.99926
this is important to understanding the position that doctrinaire liberals found themselves in after world war 2 , and our great democratic victory that brought no peace .	85.03579
the long road that had taken liberals in this country into the social religion of democracy , into a worship of man , led logically to the marxist dream of a classless society under a socialist state .	51.400047
and the ussr existed as the revolutionary experiment in radical socialism , the ultimate exemplar .	18.81197
and by the time the war ended , liberal leadership in this country was spiritually marxist .	51.46851
we will recall that the still confident liberals of the truman administration gathered with other western utopians in san francisco to set up the legal framework , finally and at last , to rationalize war -- to rationalize want and fear -- out of the world the united nations .	84.21997
we of the liberal-led world got all set for peace and rehabilitation .	60.83688
then suddenly we found ourselves in the middle of another fight , an irrational , an indecent , an undeclared and immoral war with our strongest ( and some had thought noblest ) ally .	51.91337
during the next five years the leaders of the fair deal reluctantly backed down from the optimistic expectations of the new deal .	42.632072
during the next five years liberal leaders in the united states sank in the cumulative confusion attendant upon and manifested in a negative policy of containment -- and the bitterest irony -- enforced and enforceable only by threat of a weapon that we felt the greatest distaste for but could not abandon the atom bomb .	66.69443
in 1952 , it will be remembered , the g . o . p . without positive program campaigned on the popular disillusionment with liberal leadership and won overwhelmingly .	46.04544
all of this , i know , is recent history familiar to you .	526.7349
but i have been at some pains to review it as the drama of the common man , to point up what happened to him under eisenhower ' s leadership .	60.41326
a perceptive journalist , sam lubell , has phrased it in the title of one of his books as the revolt of the moderates .	25.021025
he opens his discourse , however , with a review of the eisenhower inaugural festivities at which a sympathetic press had assembled its massive talents , all primed to catch some revelation of the emerging new age .	67.10892
the show was colorful , indeed , exuberant , but the press for all its assiduity could detect no note of a fateful rendezvous with destiny .	53.202995
lubell offers his book as an explanation of why there was no clue .	30.258968
and i select this sentence as its pertinent summation `` in essence the drama of his ( eisenhower ' s ) presidency can be described as the ordeal of a nation turned conservative and struggling -- thus far with but limited and precarious success -- to give effective voice and force to that conservatism ' ' .	57.978786
i will assume that we are all aware of the continuing struggle , with its limited and precarious success , toward conservatism .	33.112965
it has moved on various levels , it has been clamorous and confused .	18.846495
obviously there has been no agreement on what american conservatism is , or rather , what it should be .	73.75835
for it was neglected , not to say nascent , when the struggle began .	70.85742
i saw a piece the other day assailing william buckley , author of man and god at yale and publisher of the national review , as no conservative at all , but an old liberal .	71.04559
but i ' m not here to define conservatism .	95.734726
what i am here to do is to report on the gyrations of the struggle -- a struggle that amounts to self-redefinition -- to see if we can predict its future course .	42.52465
one of the obvious conclusions we can make on the basis of the last election , i suppose , is that we , the majority , were dissatisfied with eisenhower conservatism .	32.562325
though , to be sure , we gave kennedy no very positive approval in the margin of his preferment .	70.6658
this is , however , symptomatic of our national malaise .	50.55454
but before i try to diagnose it , i would offer other evidence .	98.28853
i will mention two volumes of specific comment on this malaise that appeared last year .	72.82632
the earlier of them was an unofficial enterprise , sponsored by life magazine , under the title of the national purpose .	34.20237
the contributors to this testament were all well-known a former democratic candidate for president , a new deal poet , the magazine ' s chief editorial writer , two newspaper columnists , head of a national broadcasting company , a popular protestant evangelist , etc . .	40.384075
what i want to point out here is that all of them are ex-liberals , or modified liberals , with perhaps one exception .	49.5039
i suppose we might classify billy graham as an old liberal .	115.77608
and i would further note that they all -- with one exception again -- sang in one key or another the same song .	101.75652
its refrain was `` let us return to the individualistic democracy of our forefathers for our salvation ' ' .	10.781233
adlai stevenson expressed some reservations about this return .	3.8497455
only walter lippman envisioned the possibility of our having `` outlived most of what we used to regard as the program of our national purposes ' ' .	42.857662
but the most notable thing about the incantation of these ex-liberals was that the one-time shibboleth of socialism was conspicuously absent .	6.996107
the second specific comment was the report of eisenhower ' s commission on national goals , titled goals for americans .	49.259045
they , perhaps , gave the pitch of their position in the preface where it was said that eisenhower requested that the commission be administered by the american assembly of columbia university , because it was non-partisan .	34.527172
the commission seems to represent the viewpoint of what i would call the unconscious liberal , but not unconscious enough , to invoke the now taboo symbolism of socialism .	45.528027
and here again we hear the same refrain mentioned above `` the paramount goal of the united states set long ago was to guard the rights of the individual , ensure his development , enlarge his opportunity ' ' .	66.292076
this group is secularist and their program tends to be technological .	22.440117
but it is the need to undertake these testaments that i would submit here as symptom of the common man ' s malaise .	23.409657
and let me add murray ' s new book as another symptom of it , particularly so in view of the attention time magazine gave it when it came out recently .	94.63599
father murray goes back to the declaration of independence , too , though i may add , with considerably more historical perception .	97.506996
i will reserve discussion of it for a moment , however , to return to president kennedy .	35.617104
as symptomatic of the common man ' s malaise , he is most significant a liberal and a catholic , elected by the skin of his teeth .	34.105625
does that not suggest to you an uncertain and uneasy , not to say confused , state of the public mind ? ?	57.491173
what is the common man ' s complaint ? ?	10.941682
let ' s take a panoramic look back over the course we have come .	53.31524
has not that way been lit always by the lamp of liberalism up until the turning back under eisenhower ? ?	64.13528
and the basic character of that liberalism has been spiritual rather than economic .	60.815567
ralph gabriel gave it the name of protestant philosophy of progress .	22.266197
but there ' s a subjective side to that utopian outlook .	15.771063
does our society have a runaway , uncontrollable growth of technology which may end our civilization , or a normal , healthy growth ? ?	67.01807
here there may be an analogy with cancer we can detect cancers by their rapidly accelerating growth , determinable only when related to the more normal rate of healthy growth .	50.03159
should the accelerating growth of technology then warn us ? ?	12.275531
and almost the only `` cure ' ' is early detection and removal .	80.968346
one way to determine whether we have so dangerous a technology would be to check the strength of our society ' s organs to see if their functioning is as healthy as before .	102.546196
so an objective look at our present procedures may move us to consider seriously this possibly analogous situation .	342.2617
in any event , whether society may have cancer , or merely a virus infection , the `` disease ' ' , we shall find , is political , economical , social , and even medical .	44.983345
have not our physical abilities already deteriorated because of the more sedentary lives we are now living ? ?	29.89468
hence the prime issue , as i see it , is whether a democratic or free society can master technology for the benefit of mankind , or whether technology will rule and develop its own society compatible with its own needs as a force of nature .	72.15442
we are already committed to establishing man ' s supremacy over nature and everywhere on earth , not merely in the limited social-political-economical context we are fond of today .	56.00445
otherwise , we go on endlessly trying to draw the line , color and other , as to which kind of man we wish to see dominate .	112.93693
we have proved so able to solve technological problems that to contend we cannot realize a universal goal in the immediate future is to be extremely shortsighted , if nothing else .	42.6131
we must believe we have the ability to affect our own destinies otherwise why try anything ? ?	137.55287
so in these pages the term `` technology ' ' is used to include any and all means which could amplify , project , or augment man ' s control over himself and over other men .	50.641724
naturally this includes all communication forms , e . g . languages , or any social , political , economic or religious structures employed for such control .	17.919611
properly mindful of all the cultures in existence today throughout the world , we must employ these resources without war or violent revolution .	99.34413
if we were creating a wholly new society , we could insist that our social , political , economic and philosophic institutions foster rather than hamper man	66.90743
but we cannot start off with a clean slate .	7.793372
so we must first analyze our present institutions with respect to the effect of each on man ' s major needs .	65.55694
asked which institution most needs correction , i would say the corporation as it exists in america today .	113.585556
at first glance this appears strange of all people , was not america founded by rugged individualists who established a new way of life still inspiring `` undeveloped ' ' societies abroad ? ?	69.21377
but hear harrison e . salisbury , former moscow correspondent of the new york times , and author of `` to moscow -- and beyond ' ' .	50.293972
in a book review of `` the soviet cultural offensive ' ' , he says , `` long before the state department organized its bureaucracy into an east-west contacts staff in order to wage a cultural counter-offensive within soviet borders , the sharp cutting-edge of american culture had carved its mark across the russian steppes , as when the enterprising promoters of ' porgy and bess ' overrode the state department to carry the contemporary ' cultural warfare ' behind the enemy lines .	46.47927
they were not diplomats or jazz musicians , or even organizers of reading-rooms and photo-montage displays , but rugged capitalist entrepreneurs like henry ford , hugh cooper , thomas campbell , the international harvester co . , and david w . griffith .	12.230195
their kind created an american culture superior to any in the world , an industrial and technological culture which penetrated russia as it did almost every corner of the earth without a nickel from the federal treasury or a single governmental specialist to contrive directives or program a series of consultations of interested agencies .	60.561085
this favorable image of america in the minds of russian men and women is still there despite years of energetic anti-american propaganda ' '	39.48589
perhaps the public ' s present attitude toward business stems from the fact that the `` rugged capitalist entrepreneur ' ' no more exists in america .	28.463186
in his stead is a milquetoast version known as `` the corporation ' ' .	18.157452
but even if we cannot see the repulsive characteristics in this new image of america , foreigners can	117.30721
and our loss of `` prestige ' ' abroad is the direct result .	98.627205
no amount of ballyhoo will cover up the sordid facts .	6.2911463
if we want respect from ourselves or others , we will have to earn it .	27.842186
first , let us realize that whatever good this set-up achieved in earlier times , now the corporation per se cannot take economic leadership .	140.64674
businesses must develop as a result of the ideas , energies and ambitions of an individual having purpose and comprehensive ability within one mind .	153.50027
when we `` forced ' ' individuals to assume the corporate structure by means of taxes and other legal statutes , we adopted what i would term `` pseudo-capitalism ' ' and so took a major step toward socialism .	42.310516
the biggest loss , of course , was the individual ' s lessened desire and ability to give his services to the growth of his company and our economy .	38.11758
socialism , i grant , has a definite place in our society .	36.98897
but let us not complain of the evils of capitalism by referring to a form that is not truly capitalistic .	28.199015
some forms of capitalism do indeed work -- superb organizations , a credit to any society .	127.88378
but the pseudo-capitalism which dictates our whole economy as well as our politics and social life , will not stand close scrutiny .	40.626575
its pretense to operate in the public interest is little more than a sham .	22.360893
it serves only its own stockholders and poorly at that .	104.570175
as a creative enterprise , its abilities are primarily in `` swallowing ' ' creative enterprises developed outside its own organization ( an ability made possible by us , and almost mandatory ) .	122.38932
as to benefits to employees , it is notorious for its callous disregard except where it depends on them for services .	72.73667
the corporation in america is in reality our form of socialism , vying in a sense with the other socialistic form that has emerged within governmental bureaucracy .	34.952396
but while the corporation has all the disadvantages of the socialist form of organization ( so cumbersome it cannot constructively do much of anything not compatible with its need to perpetuate itself and maintain its status quo ) , unluckily it does not have the desirable aspect of socialism , the motivation to operate for the benefit of society as a whole .	51.378876
so we are faced with a vast network of amorphous entities perpetuating themselves in whatever manner they can , without regard to the needs of society , controlling society and forcing upon it a regime representing only the corporation ' s needs for survival .	67.80773
the corporation has a limited , specific place in our society .	12.452333
ideally speaking , it should be allowed to operate only where the public has a great stake in the continuity of supply or services , and where the actions of a single proprietor are secondary to the needs of society .	29.97367
examples are in public utilities , making military aircraft and accessories , or where the investment and risk for a proprietorship would be too great for a much needed project impossible to achieve by any means other than the corporate form , e . g . constructing major airports or dams .	65.737434
thus , if corporations are not to run away with us , they must become quasi-governmental institutions , subject to public control and needs .	40.24727
in all other areas , private initiative of the `` proprietorship ' ' type should be urged to produce the desired goods and services .	30.70004
avoiding runaway technology can be done only by assuring a humane society	33.484318
and for this human beings must be firmly in control of the economics on which our society rests .	47.416157
such genuine human leadership the proprietorship can offer , corporations cannot .	380.5547
corporations react violently to short-range stimuli , e . g . , quarterly and annual dividend reports .	13.783806
proprietorships can establish a unity and integrity of control	32.874687
proprietorships can establish a meaningful identity , representing a human personality , and thus establish sincere relationships with customers and community .	78.580444
corporations are apt by nature to be impersonal , inhumane , shortsighted and almost exclusively profit-motivated , a picture they could scarcely afford to present to the public .	21.737795
the proprietor is able to create a leadership impossible in the corporate structure with its board of directors and stockholders .	63.453728
leadership is lacking in our society because it has no legitimate place to develop .	28.811943
men continuously at the head of growing enterprises can acquire experiences of the most varied , complicated and trying type so that at maturation they have developed the competence and willingness to accept the personal responsibility so sorely needed now .	137.14151
hence government must establish greater controls upon corporations so that their activities promote what is deemed essential to the national interest .	35.160545
proprietorships should get the tax advantages now accruing to corporations , e . g . the chance to accumulate capital so vital for growth .	40.39778
corporations should pay added taxes , to be used for educational purposes ( not necessarily of the formal type ) .	74.057236
the right to leave legacies should be substantially reduced and ultimately eliminated .	71.51068
to perpetuate wealth control led by small groups of individuals who played no role in its creation prevents those with real initiative from coming to the fore , and is basically anti-democratic .	57.089787
when the proprietor dies , the establishment should become a corporation until it is either acquired by another proprietor or the government decides to drop it .	108.53263
strikes should be declared illegal against corporations because disagreements would have to be settled by government representatives acting as controllers of the corporation whose responsibility to the state would now be defined against proprietorship because employees and proprietors must be completely interdependent , as they are each a part of the whole .	52.645615
strikes threatening the security of the proprietorship , if internally motivated , prevent a healthy relationship .	47.101704
certainly external forces should not be applied arbitrarily out of mere power available to do so .	92.70088
if we cannot stop warfare in our own economic system , how can we expect to abolish it internationally ? ?	33.311844
these proposals would go far toward creating the economic atmosphere favoring growth of the individual , who , in turn , would help us to cope with runaway technology .	30.679258
individual human strength is needed to pit against an inhuman condition .	16.297548
we are tempted to blame others for our problems rather than look them straight in the face and realize they are of our own making and possible of solution only by ourselves with the help of desperately needed , enlightened , competent leaders .	106.24873
persons developed in today ' s corporations cannot hope to serve here -- a judgment based on experiences of my own in business and in activities outside .	316.47766
in my own company , in effect a partnership , although legally a corporation , i have been able to do many things for my employees which `` normal ' ' corporations of comparable size and nature would have been unable to do .	53.010273
also , i am convinced that if my company were a sole proprietorship instead of a partnership , i would have been even abler to solve long-range problems for myself and my fellow-employees .	53.606323
any abilities i may have were achieved in their present shape from experience in sharing in the growth and control of my business , coupled with raising my family .	112.30631
this combined experience , on a foundation of very average , i assure you , intelligence and background , has helped me do things many well-informed people would bet heavily against .	181.68126
perhaps a list of some of the `` practices ' ' of my company will help here .	63.140015
the company grew out of efforts by two completely inexperienced men in their late twenties , neither having a formal education applicable to , or experience in , manufacturing or selling our type of articles .	79.28979
from an initial investment of $1 , 200 in 1943 , it has grown , with no additional capital investment , to a present value estimated by some as exceeding $10 , 000 , 000 ( we don ' t disclose financial figures to the public ) .	41.235962
its growth continues steadily on a par with past growth	1389.0706
our pin-curl clips and self-locking nuts achieved dominance in just a few years time , despite substantial , well established competition .	296.7557
during the last years of woodrow wilson ' s administration , a red scare developed in our country .	31.712368
many americans reacted irrationally to the challenge of russia and turned to the repression of ideas by force .	61.22332
postmaster general burleson set about to protect the american people against radical propaganda that might be spread through the mails .	41.57808
attorney general palmer made a series of raids that sent more than 4 , 000 so-called radicals to the jails , in direct violation of their constitutional rights .	32.79723
then , not many years later , the un-american activities committee , under the leadership of martin dies , pilloried hundreds of decent , patriotic citizens .	32.269623
anyone who tried to remedy some of the most glaring defects in our form of democracy was denounced as a traitorous red whose real purpose was the destruction of our government .	45.997437
this hysteria reached its height under the leadership of senator joseph mccarthy .	6.0273485
demagogues of this sort found communist bogeys lurking behind any new idea that would run counter to stereotyped notions .	42.263504
new ideas were dangerous and must be repressed , no matter how .	25.381067
those who would suppress dangerous thoughts , credit ideas with high potency .	78.35524
they give strict interpretation to william james ' statement that `` every idea that enters the mind tends to express itself ' ' .	53.263737
they seem to believe that a person will act automatically as soon as he contacts something new .	280.94656
hence , the only defensible procedure is to repress any and every notion , unless it gives evidence that it is perfectly safe .	52.201027
despite this danger , however , we are informed on every hand that ideas , not machines , are our finest tools	87.70554
they are priceless even though they cannot be recorded on a ledger page	130.12616
they are the most valuable of commodities -- and the most salable , for their demand far exceeds supply .	72.60586
so all-important are ideas , we are told , that persons successful in business and happy in social life usually fall into two classes those who invent new ideas of their own , and those who borrow , beg , or steal from others .	100.453064
seemingly , with an unrestricted flow of ideas , all will be well , and we are even assured that `` an idea a day will keep the sheriff away ' ' .	83.149086
that , however , may also bring the police , if the thinking does not meet with social approval .	78.89018
criminals , as well as model citizens , exercise their minds .	192.00916
merely having a mental image of some sort is not the all-important consideration .	61.639538
of course , there must be clarity a single distinct impression is more valuable than many fuzzy ones .	48.255657
the writer took a class of college students to the state hospital for the mentally ill in st . joseph , missouri .	51.860733
an inmate , a former university professor , expounded to us , logically and clearly , that someone was pilfering his thoughts .	31.948765
he appealed to us to bring his case to the attention of the authorities that justice might be done .	34.89908
despite the clarity of his presentation , his idea was not of einsteinian calibre .	22.169287
true , ideas are important , perhaps life ' s most precious treasures .	13.646225
but have we not gone overboard in stressing their significance ? ?	45.574177
have we not actually developed idea worship ? ?	1.0627376
ideas we must have , and we seek them everywhere .	36.166473
here we find stored the wisdom of great minds .	33.478306
but are all these works worthy of consideration ? ?	9.273217
shakespeare ' s wit and wisdom , his profound insight into human nature , have stood the test of centuries .	99.96596
but was he infallible in all things ? ?	1.0944675
what of his treatment of the jew in the merchant of venice ? ?	16.786749
shakespeare gives us a vivid picture of shylock , but probably he never saw a jew , unless in some of his travels .	41.057518
the jews had been banished from england in 1290 and were not permitted to return before 1655 , when shakespeare had been dead for thirty-nine years .	15.801075
if any had escaped expulsion by hiding , they certainly would not frequent the market-place .	90.19832
shakespeare did not usually invent the incidents in his plays , but borrowed them from old stories , ballads , and plays , wove them together , and then breathed into them his spark of life .	46.006683
rather than from a first-hand study of jewish people , his delineation of shylock stems from a collection of italian stories , il pecorone , published in 1558 , although written almost two centuries earlier .	32.574833
he could learn at second hand from books , but could not thus capture the real jewish spirit .	102.74467
harris j . griston , in shaking the dust from shakespeare ( 216 ) , writes `` there is not a word spoken by shylock which one would expect from a real jew ' ' .	30.85863
he took the story of the pound of flesh and had to fasten it on someone .	39.512917
no jew was on hand to boycott his financially struggling theater .	44.238285
it would have been unwise policy , for instance , to apply the pound-of-flesh characterization to the thrifty scotchman .	10.60863
just as now anyone may hurl insults at a citizen of mars , or even of tikopia , and no senatorial investigation will result .	32.430916
shakespeare does not tell us that shylock was an aberrant individual .	28.992958
he sets him forth as being typical of the group .	14.851633
he tells of his `` jewish heart ' ' -- not a shylockian heart	33.975227
this would make anyone crafty and cruel , capable of fiendish revenge .	5.191957
if living jews were unavailable for study , the bible was at hand .	41.593094
reading the old testament would have shown the dramatist that the ideas attributed to shylock were abhorrent to the jews .	25.028908
are we better off for having shakespeare ' s idea of shylock ? ?	16.895224
studying the merchant of venice in high school and college has given many young people their notions about jews .	123.58019
does this help the non-jew to understand this group ? ?	204.89053
thomas de torquemada , inquisitor-general of the spanish inquisition , put many persons to death .	52.973507
would we gain by keeping alive his memory and besmirching today ' s roman catholics by saying he had a catholic heart ? ?	43.68489
let his bones and his memory rest in the fifteenth century where they belong	28.631935
he is out of place in our times .	4.9236217
shakespeare ' s shylock , too , is of dubious value in the modern world .	13.267332
ideas , in and of themselves , are not necessarily the greatest good .	30.503056
a successful businessman recently prefaced his address to a luncheon group with the statement that all economists should be sent to the hospitals for the mentally deranged where they and their theories might rot together .	43.432976
will his words come to be treasured and quoted through the years ? ?	94.25428
frequently we are given assurance that automatically all ideas will be sifted and resifted and in the end only the good ones will survive .	65.77095
but is that not like going to a chemistry laboratory and blindly pouring out liquids and powders from an array of bottles and then , after stirring , expecting a new wonder drug inevitably to result ? ?	44.635143
what of the efficiency of this natural instrument of free discussion ? ?	95.23444
is there some magic in it that assures results ? ?	50.73576
when peter b . kyne ( pride of palomar , 43 ) informed us in 1921 that we had an instinctive dislike for the japanese , did the heated debates of the californians settle the truth or falsity of the proposition ? ?	23.015623
the leopard ' s spots came from the pen of thomas dixon in 1902 , and in this he announced an `` unchangeable ' ' law .	32.014767
if a child had a single drop of negro blood , he would revert to the ancestral line which , except as slaves under a superior race , had not made one step of progress in 3 , 000 years .	87.43547
that doctrine has been accepted by many , but has it produced good results ? ?	104.5642
in the same vein , a certain short-story plot has been overworked .	35.39402
the son and heir of a prominent family marries a girl who has tell-tale shadows on the half-moons of her finger nails .	10.602294
in time she presents her aristocratic husband with a coal-black child .	14.755685
is the world better for having this idea thrust upon it ? ?	100.032196
will argument and debate decide its truth or falsity ? ?	4.4996996
for answers to such questions we must turn to the anthropologists , the biologists , the historians , the psychologists , and the sociologists .	13.057748
long ago they consigned the notions of kyne and dixon to the scrap heap .	6.4141507
false ideas surfeit another sector of our life .	3.9499564
for several generations much fiction has appeared dealing with the steprelationship .	6.369025
the stepmother , almost without exception , has been presented as a cruel ogress .	13.46702
children , conditioned by this mistaken notion , have feared stepmothers , while adults , by their antagonistic attitudes , have made the role of the substitute parents a difficult one .	64.89886
debate is not likely to resolve the tensions and make the lot of the stepchild a happier one .	118.797516
research , on the other hand , has shown many stepmothers to be eminently successful , some far better than the real mothers .	59.30859
helen deutsch informed us ( the psychology of women , vol . 2 , , 434 ) that in all cultures `` the term ' stepmother ' automatically evokes deprecatory implications ' ' , a conclusion accepted by many .	35.512833
will mere debate on that proposition , even though it be free and untrammeled , remove the dross and leave a residue of refined gold ? ?	38.39039
that is questionable , to say the least .	437.04083
research into several cultures has proven her position to be a mistaken one .	38.575874
but ideas , just for the sake of having them , are not enough .	107.11806
in the 1930 ' s , cures for the depression literally flooded washington .	35.175865
for a time the president received hundreds of them every day , most of them worthless .	48.17963
ideas need to be tested , and not merely by argument and debate .	46.23174
when some question arises in the medical field concerning cancer , for instance , we do not turn to free and open discussion as in a political campaign .	83.34236
we have recourse to the scientifically-trained specialist in the laboratory .	7.804871
the merits of the salk anti-polio vaccine were not established on the forensic platform or in newspaper editorials , but in the laboratory and by tests in the field on thousands of children .	50.762775
our presidential campaigns provide much debate and argument .	4.657555
but is the result new barnsful of tested knowledge on the basis of which we can with confidence solve our domestic and international problems ? ?	82.56514
man , we are told , is endowed with reason and is capable of distinguishing good from bad .	146.18184
but what a super-herculean task it is to winnow anything of value from the mud-beplastered arguments used so freely , particularly since such common use is made of cliches and stereotypes , in themselves declarations of intellectual bankruptcy .	81.7901
we are reminded , however , that freedom of thought and discussion , the unfettered exchange of ideas , is basic under our form of government .	98.9909
assuredly in our political campaigns there is freedom to think , to examine any and all issues , and to speak without restraint .	62.697426
may we state with confidence that in such an exhibition a republic will find its greatest security ? ?	104.2961
we must not forget , to be sure , that free discussion and debate have produced beneficial results .	81.01619
in truth , we can say that this broke the power of senator joseph mccarthy , who was finally exposed in full light to the american people .	37.397636
if he had been `` liquidated ' ' in some way , he would have become a martyr , a rallying point for people who shared his ideas .	40.806362
debate in the political arena can be productive of good .	55.04227
but it is a clumsy and wasteful process it can produce negative results but not much that is positive .	191.06844
debate rid us of mccarthy but did not give us much that is positive .	104.61013
it did something to clear the ground , but it erected no striking new structure	384.3162
it did not even provide the architect ' s plan for anything new .	37.68716
in the field of the natural sciences , scientifically verified data are quite readily available and any discussion can be shortened with good results .	70.4838
in the field of the social sciences a considerable fund of tested knowledge has been accumulated that can be used to good advantage .	67.987
by no means would we discourage the production of ideas they provide raw materials with which to work	65.42275
they provide stimulations that lead to further production .	10.479615
the president ' s personality would have opened that office to him .	137.56502
and for the first time a representative of the highest office in the land would have been liable to the charge that he had attempted to make it a successorship by inheritance .	29.56894
it is testimony to the deep respect in which mr . eisenhower was held by members of all parties that the moral considerations raised by his approach to the matter were not explicitly to be broached .	54.762646
these began to be apparent in a press conference held during the second illness in order that the consulting specialists might clarify the president ' s condition for the nation .	42.23384
and if howard rutstein felt impelled thereafter to formulate the ethics of the medical profession , his article in the atlantic monthly accomplished a good deal more .	43.73091
it forced us to fix the responsibility for the position in which all medical commentators had been placed .	49.38286
the discussion of professional ethics inevitably reminded us that in the historical perspective the president ' s decision will finally clarify itself as a moral , rather than a medical , problem .	52.96858
because the responsibility for resolving the issue lay with the president , rather than with his doctors , nothing raises more surely for us the difficulties simple goodness faces in dealing with complex moral problems under political pressure .	112.2653
for the president had dealt with the matter humbly , in what he conceived as the democratic way .	84.73421
but the problem is one which gives us the measure of a man , rather than a group of men , whether a group of doctors , a group of party members assembled at a dinner to give their opinion , or the masses of the voters .	37.7456
any attempt to reconcile this statement of the central issue in the campaign of 1956 with the nature of the man who could not conceive it as the central issue will at least resolve our confusions about the chaotic and misleading results of the earnestness of both doctors and president in a situation which should never have arisen .	66.35269
it was a response to the conflict between political pressure and the moral intuition which resulted in attempts at prediction .	113.05423
in no other situation would a group of doctors , struggling competently to improve the life expectancy of a man beloved by the world , be subjected to such merciless and persistent questioning , and before they were prepared to demonstrate the kind of verbal precision which alone can clarify for mankind the problems it faces .	49.4117
and though we can look back now and see their errors , we can look back also to the ultimate error .	68.98885
it recurred in the press conferences the president ' s remarks about his running developed a singular tone , one which we find in few statements made by public individuals on such a matter .	127.00317
the press conference became a stage which betrayed the drift of his private thinking , rather than his convictions .	27.72795
he commented -- thoughtfully , a reporter told us -- that it was `` not too important for the individual how he ends up ' ' .	66.36089
he gave us a simile to explain his admission that even at the worst period of his second illness it never occurred to him there was any renewed question about his running as in the battle of the bulge , he had no fears about the outcome until he read the american newspapers .	59.665283
yet the attitude that the fate of the presidency demands in such a situation is quite distinct from the simple courage that can proceed with battles to be fought , regardless of the consequences .	60.47936
in this case others should not have had to raise the doubts and fears .	64.651764
the presidency demands an incisive awareness of the larger implications of the death of any incumbent .	58.491615
it is of the utmost importance to the people of america and of the world how their governing president `` ends up ' ' during the four years of his term .	81.11751
only when that term is ended and he is a private citizen again can he be permitted the freedom and the courage to discount the dangers of his death .	59.326378
ironically enough , in this instance such personal virtues were a luxury .	122.549324
at the national and international level , then , what is the highest kind of morality for the private citizen represents an instance of political immorality .	69.1107
and we had the uneasy sense that the cleavage between the moral and the political progressed amid the events which concern us .	41.81131
for the tone of the editorials which greeted mr . eisenhower ' s original announcement of his running had been strangely disquieting .	27.999622
neither the vibrant enthusiasm which bespeaks a people ' s intuitive sense of the fitness of things at climactic moments nor the vital argumentation betraying its sense that something significant has transpired was in evidence .	42.534363
nothing testifies more clearly to that cleavage than the peculiar editorial page appearing in a july issue of life magazine , the issue which also carried the second announcement of the candidacy .	48.578293
the double editorial on two aspects of `` the u . s . spirit ' ' was subtly calculated to suggest a moral sanction for gambles great as well as small , reflecting popular approval of this questionable attitude toward the highest office in the land .	48.919605
`` the moral creed ' ' and `` the will to risk ' ' live happily together , if we do not examine where the line is to be drawn .	60.33844
`` i may possibly be a greater risk than is the normal person of my age ' ' , the president had said on february 29th of the election year , ignoring the fact that no one of his age had ever lived out another term .	47.50122
`` my doctors assure me that this increased percentage of risk is not great ' ' .	23.80012
but by the time the risk was doubled , events had dismissed from his mind both increased percentages and a previously stated intention of considering carefully anything more serious than a bout of influenza .	130.32344
only infrequently did the situation color his thinking .	4.8871818
ironically no president we have had would have regretted more than president eisenhower the possibility to which his own words , in the press conference held at the beginning of august , testified that unable as he was himself to say his running was best for the country , unconsciously he had placed his party before his nation .	68.51049
so it is that we relive his opening statement in the first television address with the dramatic immediacy of the present .	48.929344
no consideration of risk urges itself upon him now for this is what the mind does with the ideas on which it has not properly focussed .	74.076485
yet with a mind less shallow , if less sharp , than some of the fortune-happy syndicates which back him , he feels what he cannot formulate	84.13423
and we watch him amid the overtones which suggest he could never in any conscience urge a risk upon the voters .	129.31648
moving as he is into the phase of the campaign which demands conviction of him , he adopts a position that is morally indefensible .	46.21761
he ascribes to the mercy of god the peace which this personal matter -- the assurance that he can physically sustain the burden of the office longer than any individual in the history of our nation has been able to do -- has brought him .	63.456028
what is simply an opinion formed in defiance of the laws of human probability , whether or not it is later confirmed , has become by september of the election year `` a firm conviction ' ' .	58.318752
as a means of silencing a discussion which ought to have taken place , the statement is an effective one we sympathize with the universal confusion which gives rise to such convictions .	53.461155
but it is also the climax to one of the absorbing chapters in our current political history .	27.546638
in assigning to god the responsibility which he learned could not rest with his doctors , eisenhower gave evidence of that weakening of the moral intuition which was to characterize his administration in the years to follow .	71.65582
in any other man this reassurance to the electorate would have caused us a profound moral shock .	57.884037
about this man we had to think twice .	4.270955
we knew that it was , as reassurance , the ironic fruit of a deeply moral nature .	47.269814
but the fact remains that even the unconscious acceptance of himself as a man of destiny divinely protected must be censored in any man who evades the responsibility for his major decisions , and thus for imposing his will on the people .	74.909645
and in the context of drifting personal utterances we have examined , there was occasional evidence of the origin of all such evasions .	28.065187
when the possibility that he had not given reconsideration to so weighty a decision seemed to disconcert his questioners , mr . eisenhower was known to make his characteristic statement to the press that he was not going to talk about the matter any more .	29.802862
the portrait that had developed , fragmentarily but consistently , was the portrait of a man to whom serious thinking is alien enough that the making of a decision inhibits , when it does not forestall , any ability to review the decision in the light of new evidence .	61.28004
this does not mean that the decision to run for office should inevitably have been revoked .	76.86151
instead it means that the thinking in which decision issues has the power to determine the morality of the decision , as in this instance the pressure for renewed practical or legislative attention to the constitutional problems the decision had uncovered might have done .	67.28701
drifting through a third illness , apparently without any provision for the handling of a major national emergency other than a talk with the vice-president , eisenhower revealed the singularly static quality of his thinking .	59.54798
despite three warnings , no sense of moral urgency impelled him to distinguish his situation , and thus his responsibilities , from wilson ' s .	42.529354
by contrast , the energetic reaction of the leader to the full demands his decision imposes upon him strengthens the moral intuition and gives us the measure of the man .	45.081303
only by means of an intensive preoccupation with the detailed considerations following from any decision can he ensure attention to the practical details to be dealt with if the implications of immorality in the major decision are effectively to be checked .	93.66016
in the incessant struggle with recalcitrant political fact he learns to focus the essence of a problem in the significant detail , and to articulate the distinctions which clarify the detail as significant , with what is sometimes astounding rapidity .	46.967354
like lincoln , he can distinguish his relation to god from the constitutional responsibilities a questionable decision exacts of him .	65.97109
like roosevelt , he can distinguish an attitude toward a russian leader he may share with a host of americans from the responsibilities diplomatic convention may impose upon him .	101.52001
he chooses to subordinate one to the other , sometimes reluctantly , accepting criticism for the lesser immoralities facts breed .	93.213905
the very nature of a choice so grounded in distinction and fact leads to the valid convictions which become force of will in the manifest leader .	171.16478
the capacity for making the distinctions of which diplomacy is compact , and the facility with language which can render them into validity in the eyes of other men are the leader ' s means for transforming the moral intuition into moral leadership .	54.622627
the making of distinctions , like the perception of the great distinctions made , is an inordinately difficult business .	56.45837
lincoln ' s slow progress towards the several marking his achievement is even now unrecognizable as such , and loosely interpreted as the alternation of inconsistency with vision .	58.023865
but because it is the function of the mind to turn the one into the other by means of the capacities with which words endow it , we do not unwisely examine the type of distinction , in the sphere of politics , on which decisions hang .	47.302643
only recently , and perhaps because a television debate can so effectively dramatize president kennedy ' s extraordinary mastery of detail , have the abilities on which the capacity for making distinctions depend begun to be clearly discernible at the level of politics .	46.42208
in his recent evaluation of kennedy ' s potentialities for leadership , walter lippmann has cited the `` precision ' ' of his mind , his `` immense command ' ' of factual detail , and his `` instinct for the crucial point ' ' as impressive in the extreme	29.941235
and it is surely clear that the first of these is the result of the way in which the individual ' s command of language interacts with the other two .	33.678978
for this change is not a change from one positive position to another , but a change from order and truth to disorder and negation .	85.99905
the liberal-conservative division , we might observe in passing , is not of itself directly involved in a private interest conflict nor even in struggle between ruling groups .	136.1173
rather it is rooted in a difference of response to the threat of social disintegration .	38.216156
the division is not between those who wish to preserve what they have and those who want change .	56.283916
rather it is a division established by two absolutely different ways of thought with regard to man ' s life in society .	52.91534
these ways are absolutely irreconcilable because they offer two different recipes for man ' s redemption from chaos .	59.12697
the civilizational crisis , the third type of change raises the question `` what are we to do ' ' ? ?	20.332975
for the answer cannot be derived from any socially cohesive element in the disrupting community .	12.496186
there is no socially existential answer to the question .	12.20623
for the truth formerly experienced by the community no longer has existential status in the community , nor does any answer elaborated by philosophers or theoriticians .	54.03489
in this phase of change , no idea has social acceptance and so none has ontological status in the community .	69.27323
an interregnum ensues in which not men but ideas compete for existence .	355.0385
if we examine the three types of change from the point of view of their internal structure we find an additional profound difference between the third and the first two , one that accounts for the notable difference between the responses they evoke .	43.812572
the first two types of change occur within the inward and immanent structure of the society .	12.163873
the first involves a simple shift of interests in the society .	9.586799
the second involves something deeper , but its characteristic form focuses on a shift in policy for the community , not in the truth on which the community rests .	56.289288
thus in both types attention is focused on the community itself , and its phenomenological life .	46.906624
the third type , however , wrenches attention from the life of action and interests in the community and focuses it on the ground of being on which the community depends for its existence .	41.29656
voegelin has analyzed this experience in the case of the stable , healthy community .	34.517887
there the community , faced with the need to formulate policy on the level of absolute justice , can find the answer to its problem in the absolute truth which it holds as partially experienced .	68.60242
this , however , cannot be done by a community whose very experience of truth is confused and incoherent it has no absolute standard , and consequently cannot distinguish the absolute from the contingent .	72.718575
it has lost its ground of being and floats in a mist of appearances .	13.299673
precisely at the moment when it has lost its vision the mind of the community turns out from itself in a search for the ontological standard whereby it can measure itself .	81.3898
for paradigmatic history `` breaks ' ' rather than unfolds precisely when the movement is from order to disorder , and not from one order to a new order .	53.321423
the liberal-conservative split , to define it further , derives from a basic difference concerning the existential status of standard sought and about the spiritual experience that leads to its identification .	72.81197
when disruptive change has penetrated to the third level of social order , the process of disruption rapidly reaches a point of no return .	93.63108
indeed , it is probable that this point is reached the moment the third level of change begins .	87.8722
at that point we reach the `` closed ' ' historical situation the situation in which man is no longer free to return to a status quo ante .	22.801771
at that point men become aware of the mystery of history called variously `` fate ' ' , or `` destiny ' ' , or `` providence ' ' , and feel themselves caught helplessly in the writhing of a disrupted society .	19.371817
the reasons for this experience are rooted in the metaphysical characteristics of such a change .	23.089436
of all forms of being , society , or community , has the greatest element of determinability .	22.030418
its ontological status is itself most tenuous because apart from individual men , who are its `` matter ' ' , tradition , the `` form ' ' of society exists only as a shared perception of truth .	54.279293
the ontological status of society thus is constituted by the psychological status of society ' s members .	20.605534
the content of that psychological status determines , ultimately , the content of civilization .	41.213554
those social , civilizational factors not rooted in the human spirit of the group , ultimately cease to exist .	40.624496
civilization itself -- tradition -- falls out of existence when the human spirit itself becomes confused .	49.19879
civilization is what man has made of himself .	12.312422
its massive contours are rooted in the simple need of man , since he is always incomplete , to complete himself .	89.68214
it is not enough for man to be an ontological esse .	9.453278
he needs existential completion , he needs , that is , to move in the direction of completion .	34.786533
and the direction of that movement is determined by his perception of the truth about himself .	46.584698
he must , consequently , exist as a self-perceived substantive , developing agent , or he does not exist as man .	31.50194
thus , it is no mystical intuition , but an analyzable conception to say that man and his tradition can `` fall out of existence ' ' .	53.205948
this happens at the moment man loses the perception of moral substance in himself , of a nature that , in maritain ' s words , is perceived as a `` locus of intelligible necessities ' ' .	31.55125
an existentialist is a man who perceives himself only as `` esse ' ' , as existence without substance .	34.259052
thus human perception and human volition is the immanent cause of all social change and this most truly when the change reaches the civilizational level .	77.33937
thus with regard to the loss of tradition , in the change from order to disorder the metaphysics of change works itself out as a disruption of the individual soul , a change in which man continues as an objective ontological existent , but no longer as a man .	57.994488
further , change is a form of motion , it occurs as the act of a being in potency insofar as it is in potency and has not yet reached the terminus of the change .	34.02062
with regard to the change we are examining , the question is , at what point does the change become irreversible ? ?	29.74966
a number of considerations suggest that this occurs early in the process .	99.632324
this means that the inception of change itself can begin only when the factors conducive to change have already become more powerful than those anchoring the existent form in being .	61.53875
if the existent form is to be retained new factors that reinforce it must be introduced into the situation .	126.08358
in the case of social decay , form is displaced simply by the process of dissolution with no form at the terminus of the process .	30.994633
now in the mere fact of the beginning of such displacement we have prima-facie evidence of the ontological weakness of the fading form .	43.069763
and when we consider the tenuous hold tradition has on existence , any weakening of that hold constitutes a crisis of existence .	77.98458
the retention of a tradition confronted with such a crisis necessitates the introduction of new spiritual forces into the situation .	61.59711
however , the crisis occurs precisely as a weakening of spiritual forces .	39.158268
it would seem , therefore , that in a civilizational crisis man cannot save himself .	30.02488
the emergence of the crisis itself would seem to constitute a warranty for the victory of disorder .	10.427078
and it would seem that history is a witness to this truth .	52.67247
as a further characterization of the liberal conservative split we may observe that it involves differences in the formula for escaping inevitabilities in history .	45.672302
these differences , in turn , derive from prior differences concerning the friendly or hostile character of change .	188.0002
anxiety and deep insecurity are the characteristic responses evoked by the crisis in tradition .	68.779976
to experience them , it is not necessary for a people to be actively aware of what is happening to it .	19.061234
the process of erosion need only undermine the tradition and a series of consequences begin unfolding within the individual , while in institutions a quiet but deep transformation of processes occurs .	101.42692
within the individual the reaction has been called various names , all , however , pointing to the same basic experience .	73.46042
weil identifies it as being `` rootless ' ' , guardini as being `` placeless ' ' , riesman as being `` lonely ' ' .	4.4901023
others call it `` alienation ' ' , and mean by that no simple economic experience ( as marx does ) but a deep spiritual sense of dislocation .	115.61455
within institutions there is a marked decline of the process of persuasion and the substitution of a force-fear process which masquerades as the earlier one of persuasion .	20.140121
we note the use of rhetoric as a weapon , the manipulation of the masses by propaganda , the `` mobilization ' ' of effort and resources .	42.491165
within this context of spontaneous and unanalyzed responses to the experience of civilizational crisis , two basic organizations of response are observable reaction and ideological progressivism .	45.523403
these responses are explicable in terms of characteristics inherent in the crisis .	39.029938
the response of reaction is dominated by a concern for what is vanishing .	49.101974
its essence lies in its attempt to recover previous order through the repression of disruptive forces .	44.968643
to this end political authority is called upon to exercise its negative and coercive powers .	44.23899
the implicit assumption of this response is that history is reversible .	29.857218
seemingly , order is perceived as a kind of subsistent entity now covered by adventitious accretions .	18.773167
the problem is to remove the accretions and thereby uncover the order that was always there .	44.83987
such a response , of course , misses the point that in crisis order is going out of existence .	85.736786
moreover its posture of stubborn but simple resistance is doomed to failure because of the metaphysical weakness of the existent form of order , once the activation of change has reached visible proportions .	33.534496
the most reaction can achieve is stasis , and a stasis that can be maintained only by the expenditure of an effort which ultimately exhausts itself .	20.38958
despite the hopelessness of the response , it is explicable in terms of the crisis of tradition itself .	17.228006
since a civilizational crisis involves also a crisis in private interests and in the ruling class , reaction is normally found among those who feel themselves to be among the ruling class .	92.816315
their great error is to mingle the responses typical of each of the three types of change .	31.407402
since civilizational change is the most difficult to perceive and analyze , it seldom is given adequate attention .	64.763
and the anxiety it generates is misinterpreted as anxiety over private interest and threatened social status .	230.36684
the basic truth in the reactionary response is to be found in its realistic assumption of the primacy of the real over the ideational .	30.808882
but this truth is distorted by its extreme application the assumption of the separate existence of tradition .	46.967545
the reactionary misses the point that tradition exists ontologically only in the form of psychological-intellectual relations .	9.46187
reactionary theories , for this reason , usually assume some form of organismic theory .	29.159773
in its defensive formulations , the theory will attack conscious change on the grounds of the independent existence of the community .	30.982027
in its dynamic form , it visualizes the community as the embodiment of an ontological force -- the race , for instance , which unfolds in history .	25.463554
in both cases the individual tends to be treated as an instrument of the organic reality .	24.162544
when the reactionary response is thus bolstered by an intellectual defense , the characteristics of that defense are explicable only in terms of the basic attitudes of unanalyzed reaction .	35.438484
reaction is rooted in a perception of tradition as a whole .	30.510147
it is a total situation that is defended the `` good old days ' ' .	22.885782
even the questionable features of the past are defended .	41.472412
the point is that the reactionary , for whatever motive , perceives himself to have been part or a partner of something that extended beyond himself , something which , consequently , he was not able to accept or reject on the basis of subjective preference .	76.78495
the reactionary is confused about the existential status of a decaying tradition , but he does perceive the unity tradition had when it was healthy .	47.895584
all of which brings up another problem in the use of psychoanalytic insight in a literary work .	23.031197
is the oedipus complex , the clinical syndrome , material for a tragedy ? ?	95.66696
if we remove ourselves for a moment from our time and our infatuation with mental disease , isn ' t there something absurd about a hero in a novel who is defeated by his infantile neurosis ? ?	31.36436
i am not making a clinical judgment here , for such personal tragedies are real and are commonplace in the analyst ' s consulting room , but literature makes a different claim upon our sympathies than tragedy in life .	82.47484
a man in a novel who is defeated in his childhood and condemned by unconscious forces within him to tiredly repeat his earliest failure in love , only makes us a little weary of man	104.12735
now we can argue that the irresistible fate of oedipus rex was nothing more than the irresistible unconscious longings of oedipus projected outward , but this externalization of unconscious conflict makes all the difference between a story and a clinical case history .	35.374077
we can also argue that the three brothers karamazov and smerdyakov were the external representatives of an internal conflict within one man , dostoevsky , a conflict having to do with father-murder and the wish to possess the father ' s woman .	38.736595
but a novel in which one man karamazov explored the divisions within his personality would scarcely merit publication in the psychoanalytic quarterly .	67.004875
it is a mistake to look upon the oedipus of oedipus complex as a literary descendant of oedipus rex .	15.970185
whatever the psychological truth in the oedipus myth , an oedipus who is drawn to his fate by irresistible external forces can carry the symbol of humanity and its archaic crime , and the incest that is unknowing renews the mystery of the eternal dream of childhood and absorbs us in the secret .	25.283195
but a modern oedipus who is doomed because he cannot oppose his own childhood is only pathetic , and for renouncing the mystery in favor of psychological truth he gives up the claim on our sympathies .	45.52566
i am suggesting that a case-history approach to the oedipus complex is a blind alley for a storyteller .	11.5590725
the best gifts of the novelist will be wasted on the reader who is insulated against any surprises the novelist may have in store for him .	45.70802
incest is still a durable theme , but if it wants to get written about it will have to find ways to surprise the emotions , and there is no better way to do this than that of concealment and symbolic representation .	55.334404
and the best way to conceal and disguise the elements of an incest story is not to set out to write an incest story .	38.71861
which brings to mind another lawrence story and some interesting comparisons in the treatment of the oedipal theme .	36.310963
`` the rocking horse winner ' ' is also a story about a boy ' s love for his mother .	19.892141
if i now risk some comparisons with sons and lovers let it be clear that i am not comparing the two works or judging their merits	79.44276
i am only singling out differences in treatment of a theme and the resultant effects .	42.58902
`` the rocking horse winner ' ' is a fantasy with extraordinary power to disturb the reader -- but we do not know why .	33.83226
it is the story of the hopeless love of a little boy for his cold and vain mother .	36.961514
there are ghostly scenes in which the little boy on his rocking horse rocks madly toward the climax that will magically give him the name of the winning horse .	37.64935
the child grows rich on his winnings and conspires with his uncle to make secret gifts of his money to his mother .	34.7097
the story ends in the child ' s illness and delirium brought on by the feverish compulsion to ride his horse to win for his mother .	42.360226
the child dies with his mourning mother at his bedside .	8.106514
i had read the story many times without asking myself why it affected me or caring why it did .	104.99273
but on one occasion when i encountered a similar fantasy in a little boy who was my patient i began to understand the uncanny effects of this story .	49.18006
it was , of course , a little boy ' s fantasy of winning his mother to himself , and replacing the father who could not give her the things she wanted -- a classical oedipal fantasy if you like -- but if it were only this the story would be banal .	49.640575
how does the rocking exert its uncanny effect upon the reader ? ?	17.005907
the rocking is actually felt in the story , a terrible and ominous rhythm that prophesies the tragedy .	25.32632
the rocking , i realized , is the single element in the story that carries the erotic message , the unspoken and unconscious undercurrent that would mar the innocence of a child ' s fantasy and disturb the effects of the work if it were made explicit .	35.119743
the rocking has the ambiguous function of keeping the erotic undercurrent silent and making it present	45.81505
and if we understand the rocking as an erotic symbol we can also see how well it serves as the symbol of impending tragedy .	47.062332
for this love of the boy for his mother is a hopeless and forbidden love , doomed by its nature .	46.51885
we are also struck by the fact that this story of a boy ' s love for his mother does not offend , while the incestuous love of the man , paul morel , sometimes repels .	25.693537
we accord it its place there , and in lawrence ' s treatment we are given the innocent fantasy of a child , in fact , the form in which oedipal love is expressed in childhood .	52.55398
and when the child dies in lawrence ' s story in a delirium that is somehow brought on by his mania to win and to make his mother rich , the manifest absurdity of such a disease and such a death does not enter into our thoughts at all .	46.685665
we have so completely entered the child ' s fantasy that his illness and his death are the plausible and the necessary conclusion .	56.2255
i am sure that none of the effects of this story were consciously employed by lawrence to describe an oedipal fantasy in childhood .	69.652016
it is most probable that freud and the oedipus complex never entered his head in the writing of this story .	32.77461
he was simply writing a story that wanted to be told , and in the writing a childhood fantasy of his own emerged .	48.95638
he would not have cared why it emerged , he only wanted to capture a memory to play with it again in his imagination and somehow to fix and hold in the story the disturbing emotions that accompanied the fantasy .	74.04766
in our own time we have seen that the novelist ' s debt to psychoanalysis has increased but that the novel itself has not profited much from this marriage .	29.868446
ortega ' s hope that modern psychology might yet bring forth a last flowering of the novel has only been partially fulfilled .	74.58218
he has lost confidence in his own eyes and in the validity of his own psychological insights .	19.311508
he borrows the insights of psychology to improve his impaired vision but cannot bring to his work the distinctive vision that should be a novelist ' s own .	58.41647
he has been seduced by the marvels of the unconscious and has lost interest in studying the surfaces of character .	56.045967
if many of the characters in contemporary novels appear to be the bloodless relations of characters in a case history it is because the novelist is often forgetful today that those things that we call character manifest themselves in surface behavior , that the ego is still the executive agency of personality , and that all we know of personality must be discerned through the ego .	92.05284
the novelist who has been badly baptized in psychoanalysis often gives us the impression that since all men must have an oedipus complex all men must have the same faces .	96.84627
i have argued that oedipus of the oedipus complex has a doubtful future as a tragic figure in literature .	40.016464
but a writer who has a taste for irony and who sees incest in all its modern dimensions can let his imagination work on the disturbing joke in the incest myth , the joke that strikes right at the center of man ' s humanness .	60.06882
moral dread is seen as the other face of desire , and here psychoanalysis delivers to the writer a magnificent irony and a moral problem of great complexity .	75.25729
there is probably some significance in the fact that two of the best incest stories i have encountered in recent years are burlesques of the incest myth .	30.008057
the ancient types are reassembled in gloom and foreboding to be irresistibly drawn to their destinies , but the myth fails before the modern truth	24.235489
the oracle speaks false and the dream speaks true .	485.16693
in both the farmer ' s tale in ralph ellison ' s invisible man and in thomas mann ' s the holy sinner , the incest hero rises above the myth by accepting the wish as motive	29.639194
the heroic act is the casting off of pretense .	5.046436
thomas mann wrote the holy sinner in 1951 .	2.4514146
it was conceived as a leave-taking , a kind of melancholy gathering-in of the myths of the west , `` bevor die nacht sinkt , eine lange nacht vielleicht und ein tiefes vergessen ' ' .	6.851889
he chose a medieval legend of incest , gregorius vom stein , and freely borrowed and parodied other myths of the west , mixing themes , language , peoples and times in a master myth in which the old forms continually renew themselves , as in his previous treatment of joseph .	36.292118
but the holy sinner is not simply a retelling of old stories for an old man ' s entertainment .	24.36551
mann understood better than most men the incest comedy at the center of the myth and the psychological truth in which dread is shown as the other face as longing was for him just the kind of deep and complicated joke he liked to tell .	63.721558
and when he retold the legend of gregorius he interpolated a modern version in which the medieval players speak contemporary thoughts in archaic language	67.212326
while they move through the pageantry of the ancient incest myth and cover themselves through not-knowing , they reveal the unconscious motive in seeking each other and in the last scene make an extraordinary confession of guilt in the twentieth-century manner .	74.383606
grigorss is the child of an incestuous union between a royal brother and sister , the twins sibylla and wiligis .	25.091255
he is born in secrecy after the death of his father and cast adrift soon after birth .	32.81968
the infant is discovered by a fisherman who brings him home to rear him .	61.55454
an ivory tablet in the infant ' s cask recounts the story of his sinful origins and is preserved for the child by the monks of a monastery in the fishing village .	29.0053
grigorss , at seventeen , learns his story and goes forth as a knight to uncover his origins .	28.378202
his sailing vessel is guided by fate to the shores of his own country at a time when sibylla ' s domain is overrun by the armies of one of her rejected suitors .	21.498878
grigorss overcomes the suitor in battle , delivers the city from its oppressors and marries sibylla who had fallen in love with the beautiful knight the moment she saw him .	27.821154
sibylla is pregnant with their second child when she finds the ivory tablet concealed by her husband , and the identities of mother and son are revealed .	19.005297
grigorss goes off to do penance on a rock for seventeen years .	37.354027
at the end of this period two pious christians in rome receive the revelation which leads them to seek the next pope on the rock .	84.230736
grigorss comes to rome and becomes a great and beloved pope .	37.48243
in the last pages of the book sibylla comes to rome to seek an audience with the great pope and to give her confession .	43.241158
mother and son recognize each other and , in mann ' s version of this legend , make a remarkable confession of guilt to each other , the confession of unconscious motive and unconscious knowledge of their true identities from the time they had first set eyes on each other .	33.21322
in recollection he has said `` natural or man-made objects kept coming into my head , but i would suppress them sternly ' ' .	21.282719
moreover , he organized the movement of his forms , within his rigorously shaped space , into highly complex equilibriums	71.361725
and used gradations of color value as well as sharply contrasting elementary colors .	58.180454
the worthy mondrian , seeing these pictures , said in a tone of kindly reproof `` but you are really an artist of the naturalistic tradition ' ' ! !	34.66368
helion did not realize it at the time , but it was true .	17.018744
