a story , no doubt apocryphal , for mercer himself denies it , has him sporting a monacle in those village days .	55.829166
though merely clear glass , it was a distinctive trade mark for an aspiring actor who hoped to imprint himself upon the memories of producers .	40.9385
one day in a bar , so the legend goes , someone put a beer stein with too much force on the monacle and broke it .	61.76305
the innocent malfeasant , filled with that supreme sense of honor found in bars , insisted upon replacing the destroyed monacle -- and did , over the protests of the former owner -- with a square monacle .	130.63666
mercer is supposed to have refused it with , `` anyone who wears a square monacle must be affected ' ' ! !	64.59085
everett miller , then assistant director for the garrick gaieties , a theatre guild production , needed a lyricist for a song he had written	28.575788
he just happened not to need any actor at the moment , however .	28.756506
for him mercer produced the lyric to `` out of breath scared to death of you ' ' , introduced in that most successful of all the gaieties , by sterling holloway .	56.723602
this 1930 edition also had songs in it by vernon duke and ira gershwin , by e . y . harburg and duke , and by harry myers .	29.911797
entrance into such stellar song writing company encouraged the burgeoning song writer to take a wife , elizabeth meehan , a dancer in the gaieties .	23.244984
the mercers took up residence in brooklyn , and mercer found a regular job in wall street `` misplacing stocks and bonds ' ' .	26.250128
when he heard that paul whiteman was looking for singers to replace the rhythm boys , mercer applied and got the job , `` not for my voice , i ' m sure , but because i could write songs and material generally ' ' .	50.107105
while with the whiteman band mercer met jerry arlen .	3.0155306
he had yet to meet harold arlen , for although they had `` collaborated ' ' on `` satan ' s li ' l lamb ' ' , mercer and harburg had worked from a lead sheet the composer had furnished them .	31.55839
the lyric , mercer remembers , was tailored to fit the unusual melody .	36.864334
mercer ' s whiteman association brought him into contact with hoagy carmichael , whose `` snowball ' ' mercer relyriced as `` lazybones ' ' , in which form it became a hit and marked the real beginning of mercer ' s song-writing career .	20.994333
after leaving whiteman , mercer joined the benny goodman band as a vocalist .	12.952244
with the help of ziggy elman , also in the band , he transformed a traditional jewish melody into a popular song , `` and the angels sing ' ' .	33.92036
the countrywide success of `` lazybones ' ' and `` and the angels sing ' ' could only lead to hollywood , where , besides harold arlen , mercer collaborated with harry warren , jimmy van heusen , richard whiting , walter donaldson , jerome kern , and arthur schwartz .	18.802118
mercer has also written both music and lyrics for several songs .	16.379862
he may be the only song writer ever to have collaborated with a secretary of the u . s . treasury	9.030289
he collaborated on a song with william hartman woodin , who was secretary of the treasury , 1932-33 .	5.941331
when johnny mercer and harold arlen began their collaboration in 1940 , mercer , like arlen , had several substantial film songs to his credit , among them `` hooray for hollywood ' ' , `` ride , tenderfoot , ride ' ' , `` have you got any castles , baby ? ?	45.02925
' ' , and `` too marvelous for words ' ' ( all with richard whiting )	62.222683
with harry warren he did `` the girl friend of the whirling dervish ' ' , `` jeepers creepers ' ' , and `` you must have been a beautiful baby ' ' .	8.258918
mercer ' s lyrics are characterized by an unerring ear for rhythmic nuances , a puckish sense of humor expressed in language with a colloquial flair .	13.834495
though versatile and capable of turning out a ballad lyric with the best of them , mercer ' s forte is a highly polished quasi-folk wit .	24.507359
his casual , dreamlike working methods , often as not in absentia , were an abrupt change from harburg ' s , so that arlen had to adjust again to another approach to collaboration .	49.96175
there were times that he worked with both lyricists simultaneously .	58.521748
speaking of his work with johnny mercer , arlen says , `` our working habits were strange .	47.15338
after we got a script and the spots for the songs were blocked out , we ' d get together for an hour or so every day .	70.18552
while johnny made himself comfortable on the couch , i ' d play the tunes for him .	46.43853
after i would finish playing the songs , he ' d just go away without a comment .	82.70692
i wouldn ' t hear from him for a couple of weeks , then he ' d come around with the completed lyric ' ' .	21.656094
arlen is one of the few ( possibly the only ) composer mercer has been able to work with so closely , for they held their meetings in arlen ' s study .	47.48493
`` some guys bothered me ' ' , mercer has said .	45.209465
`` i couldn ' t write with them in the same room with me , but i could with harold .	47.687748
he often uses very odd rhythms , which makes it difficult , and challenging , for the lyric writer ' ' .	28.294659
while arlen and mercer collaborated on hot nocturne , mercer worked also with arthur schwartz on another film , navy blues .	67.65274
arlen , too , worked on other projects at the same time with old friend ted koehler .	23.955605
besides doing a single song , `` when the sun comes out ' ' , they worked on the ambitious american-negro suite , for voices and piano , as well as songs for films .	33.436245
the american-negro suite is in a sense an extension of the cotton club songs in that it is a collection of negro songs , not for a night club , but for the concert stage .	67.44666
the work had its beginning in 1938 with an eight-bar musical strain to which koehler set the words `` there ' ll be no more work	67.28964
there ' ll be no more worry ' ' , matching the spiritual feeling of the jot .	19.011745
this grew into the song `` big time comin ' ' ' .	3.6517072
by september 1940 the suite had developed into a collection of six songs , `` four spirituals , a dream , and a lullaby ' ' .	15.594168
the negro composer hall johnson studied the american-negro suite and said of it , `` of all the many songs written by white composers and employing what claims to be a negroid idiom in both words and music , these six songs by harold arlen and ted koehler easily stand far out above the rest .	78.545265
thoroughly modern in treatment , they are at the same time , full of simple sincerity which invariably characterizes genuine negro folk-music and are by no means to be confused with the average ' broadway spirituals ' which depend for their racial flavor upon sundry allusions to the ' amen corner ' , ' judgement day , ' gabriel ' s horn , and a frustrated devil -- with a few random hallelujahs thrown in for good measure .	81.658195
it had a single porcelain stall and but one cabinet for the chairing of the bards .	7.7887096
it was here that the terror-stricken dennis moon played an unrehearsed role during the children ' s party .	44.354362
a much larger room , adjacent to the lavatory , served as a passageway to and from the skimpy toilet .	17.203848
that unused room was large enough for -- well , say an elephant could get into it and , as a matter of fact , an elephant did .	50.732697
something occurred on the morning of the children ' s party which may illustrate the kind of trouble our restricted toilet facilities caused us .	74.84949
it so happened that sports writer arthur robinson got out of the hospital that morning after promising his doctor that he be back in an hour or two to continue his convalescence .	137.80661
arthur robinson traveled with the baseball clubs as staff correspondent for the american .	71.74831
he was ghost writer for babe ruth , whose main talent for literary composition was the signing of his autograph .	25.726055
robbie was a war veteran with battle-shattered knees .	6.871561
he arrived on crutches at the newspaper club with one of his great pals , oliver herford , artist , author , and foe of stupidity .	22.664164
mr . herford ' s appearance was that of a frustrated gnome .	17.022974
he seemed timid ( at first , ) wore nose glasses from which a black ribbon dangled , and was no bigger than a jockey .	26.728199
robinson asked herford to escort him to the club ' s lavatory before they sat down for a highball and a game of cards .	25.217184
in the jakes , after robbie and his crutches were properly stowed , mr . herford went to the adjoining facility .	11.449203
he had barely assumed his stance there when a fat fellow charged through the doorway .	62.60473
without any regard for rest-room protocol , the hulking stranger almost knocked herford off his pins .	85.85944
the artist-author said nothing , but stood to one side .	42.457657
the unrelieved stranger eventually turned away from the place of his -- shall we dare say his waterloo ? ?	76.933815
mr . herford touched the fat man ' s arm .	3.0693867
may i say that you have just demonstrated the truth of an old proverb -- the younger pliny ' s , if memory serves me -- which , translated freely from the archaic latin , says , ' the more haste , the less peed ' ' ' .	46.89754
governor alfred e . smith was the official host at the children ' s party .	68.76299
united states senator royal s . copeland was wearing the robes of santa claus and a great white beard	30.038965
the honorable robert wagner , sr . , at that time a justice of the new york supreme court , was on the reception committee .	50.006737
i was in charge of the arrangements -- which were soon enough disarranged .	57.971046
i had had difficulties from the very first day .	35.601707
when , in my enthusiasm , i proposed the party , my city editor ( who disliked the club and many of its members ) tried to block my participation in the gala event .	82.36719
even earlier than that he had resented the fact that i had been chosen to edit the club ' s reporter .	27.810038
city editor victor watson of the new york american was a man of brooding suspicions and mysterious shifts of mood .	38.343945
mr . hearst ' s telegraphic code word for victor watson was `` fatboy ' ' .	6.859293
the staff saw in him the qualities of a don cossack , hence , as mentioned before , his nickname `` the hetman ' ' .	40.49813
the hetman ' s physical aspects were not those of a savage rider of the steppes .	24.793459
indeed , he looked more like a well-fleshed lay brother of the hospice of st . bernard .	58.342613
he had a purring voice and poker player ' s immobility of features which somehow conveyed the feeling that he knew where all the bodies were buried .	29.755228
he was the son of a scottish father and an american jewish mother , long widowed , with whom he lived in a comfortable home in flushing .	36.043106
he had worked in the newspaper business since he was nineteen years old , always for the hearst service .	60.393936
from the very first he regarded himself as mr . hearst ' s disciple , defender , and afterward his prime minister , self-ordained .	17.38547
it was said that the hetman plotted to take over the entire hearst newspaper empire one day by means of various coups the destruction of editors who tried to halt his course , the unfrocking of publishers whose mistakes of judgment might be magnified in secret reports to mr . hearst .	48.900604
whatever the hetman ' s ambitions , his colleagues were kept ill at ease .	55.33179
among the outstanding members of the hearst cabinet whom he successfully opposed for a time were the great arthur brisbane , bradford merrill , s . s . carvalho , and colonel van hamm .	54.6688
he also disliked runyon , for no good reason other than the fact that the demon ' s talent was so marked as to put him well beyond the hetman ' s say-so or his supervision .	52.89541
runyon , for his part , had a contemptuous regard for mr . watson .	62.248623
`` he ' s a wrong-o ' ' , said runyon , `` and i wouldn ' t trust him as far as i could throw the statue of liberty ' ' .	24.030102
arthur `` bugs ' ' baer wrote to me just recently , `` vic wanted to die in harness , with his head towards the wagon .	43.778534
he supported his mother and his brother , who afterwards committed suicide .	65.6183
watson told me that his brother always sent roses to his mother , blossoms bought with vic ' s allowance to him .	31.207504
' and would you believe it ' , vic added , ' she likes him better than she does me .	70.296684
about the only time the hetman seemed excited was when one of his own pet ideas was born .	73.61292
then he would get to his feet , as though rising in honor of his own remarkable powers , and say almost invariably , `` gentlemen , this is an amazing story ! !	96.82429
it ' s bigger than the armistice ' ' .	1.4706589
some of the hetman ' s `` ideas ' ' were dream-ridden , vaguely imparted , and at times preposterous .	8.115102
one day he assigned me to lay bare a `` plot ' ' by the duponts to supply munitions to a wholly fictitious revolution he said was about to occur in cuba .	46.98757
he said that his information was so secret that he would not be able to confide in me the origin of his pipeline tip .	28.964092
`` i can tell you this much ' ' , he said .	2.7585266
it ' s bigger than the armistice ' ' .	1.4706589
i worked for a day on this plainly ridiculous assignment and consulted several of my own well-informed sources .	123.63659
then i spent the next two days at the baseball park and at jack doyle ' s pool parlors .	34.266956
when i returned to make my report , the hetman did not remember having sent me on the secret mission .	53.283688
he was busy , he said , in having someone submit to a monkey-gland operation .	103.366104
and i was to go to work on that odd matter .	468.8945
the hetman had a strong liking for a story , any story which was to be had by means of much sleuthing or by roundabout methods .	91.39708
most of my stories were obtained by simply seeking out the person who could give me the facts , and not as a rule by playing clever tricks .	82.09338
one day i tired of following the hetman ' s advice of `` shadowing ' ' and of the `` ring-around-the-rosie ' ' approach to a report that enrico caruso had pinched a lady ' s hip while visiting the central park monkey house .	30.35683
i explained my state of mind to artist winsor mccay and to `` bugs ' ' baer .	9.90972
mr . baer obtained a supply of crepe hair and spirit-gum from an actor at the friars .	18.041435
we fashioned beards , put them on , and reported to the hetman at the city desk .	32.24702
mr . baer had an auburn beard , like longfellow ' s .	12.319161
mr . mccay had on a sort of emperor maximilian beard and mustache .	8.970314
as for myself , i had on an enormous black `` muff ' ' .	24.25531
this , together with a derby hat and horn-rim eyeglasses , gave me the appearance of a russian nihilist .	17.557453
`` we are ready for your next mysterious assignment ' ' , said mr . baer to the hetman .	14.7530575
`` where to , sir ' ' ? ?	1.0252831
mr . watson did not have much humor in his make-up , but he managed a mirthless smile .	11.707617
just then a reporter telephoned in from the bronx to give the rewrite desk an account of a murder .	61.148777
the hetman told me to take the story over the phone and to write it .	27.239338
while i was sitting at one of the rewrite telephones with my derby and my great beard , arthur brisbane whizzed in with some editorial copy in his hand .	39.68314
he paused for a moment to look at me , then went on to the city desk to deliver his `` today ' ' column .	52.66971
i thought it expedient to take off my derby , my glasses , and the beard	10.838685
i managed to do this by the time the great a . b . returned to the place where he last had seen the fierce nihilist .	170.97424
he stood there staring with disbelief at the vacant desk .	9.118835
then he wrinkled his huge brow and went slowly out of the room .	14.316312
he had been `` seeing things ' ' .	6.2929573
the hetman ' s `` ideas ' ' for news stories or editorial campaigns were by no means always fruitless or lacking in merit .	98.02623
he campaigned successfully for the riddance of `` death avenue ' ' and also brought about the ending of pollution of metropolitan beaches by sewage .	43.607605
he exposed the bucket-shop racket with the able assistance of two excellent reporters , nat ferber and carl helm .	71.19465
in the conduct of these and many other campaigns , the hetman proved to be a much abler journalist than his critics allowed .	71.429
it seems to me now , in a long backward glance , that many of the hetman ' s conceits and odd actions -- together with his grim posture when brandishing the hatchet in the name of mr . hearst -- were keyed with the tragedy which was to close over him one day .	29.507795
alone , rejected on every hand , divorced , and in financial trouble , he leaped from an eleventh-floor window of the abbey hotel in 1937 .	44.85734
one finds it difficult to pass censure on the lonely figure who waited for days for a saving word from his zealously served idol , w . r . hearst .	58.7606
that word was withheld when the need of it seemed the measure of his despair .	91.158646
the unfinished note , written in pencil upon the back of a used envelope , and addressed to the coroner , makes one wonder about many things `` god forgive me for everything .	74.1937
much to damon runyon ' s amazement , as well as my own , i got along splendidly with the hetman	47.230194
that is , until i became an editor , hence , in his eyes , a rival .	36.436005
not long after colonel van hamm had foisted me on the watson staff i received a salary raise and a contract on the hetman ' s recommendation .	46.008644
during the next years he gave me the second of the five contracts i would sign with the hearst service .	107.8339
it was a somewhat unusual thing for a reporter to have a contract in those days before the epidemic of syndicated columnists .	34.770863
i would like to believe that my ability warranted this advancement .	36.223362
somehow i think that watson paid more attention to me than he otherwise might have because his foe , colonel van hamm , wouldn ' t touch me with a ten-foot blue pencil .	40.416496
i remember one day when mr . hearst ( and i never knew why he liked me , either ) sent the hetman a telegram `` please find some more reporters like that young man from denver ' ' .	83.68168
watson showed this wire to colonel van hamm .	12.099586
the colonel grunted , then made a remark which might be construed in either of two ways .	107.35758
`` don ' t bother to look any further .	109.04067
we already have the only one of its kind ' ' .	34.16228
the hetman did have friends , but they were mostly outside the newspaper profession .	18.905048
sergeant mike donaldson , congressional medal of honor soldier , was one of them .	27.056793
dr . menas s . gregory was another .	107.4844
i used to go with watson to call on the eminent neurologist at his apartment , to sit among the doctor ' s excellent collection of statues , paintings , and books and drink oriental coffee while watson seemed to thaw out and become almost affable .	38.011646
there was one time , however , when his face clouded and he suddenly blurted , `` why did my brother commit suicide ' ' ? ?	24.32753
i cannot remember dr . gregory ' s reply , if , indeed , he made one .	58.446392
if she were not at home , mama would see to it that a fresh white rose was there .	71.62334
sometimes , mrs . coolidge would close herself in the green suite on the second floor , and play the piano she had brought to the white house .	34.069485
mama knew she was playing her son ' s favorite pieces and feeling close to him , and did not disturb her .	45.698605
all the rest of the days in the white house would be shadowed by the tragic loss , even though the president tried harder than ever to make his little dry jokes and to tease the people around him .	49.981636
a little boy came to give the president his personal condolences , and the president gave word that any little boy who wanted to see him was to be shown in .	74.13348
backstairs , the maids cried a little over that , and the standing invitation was not mentioned to mrs . coolidge .	39.02876
the president was even more generous with the first lady than he had been before the tragedy .	64.15653
he would bring her boxes of candy and other presents to coax a smile to her lips .	28.741241
dresses were short in the days of mrs . coolidge , and spanish shawls were thrown over them .	12.085974
one shawl was so tremendous that she could not wear it , so she draped it over the banister on the second floor , and it hung over the stairway .	22.195545
the president used to look at it with a ghost of a smile .	19.611801
mrs . coolidge spent more time in her bedroom among her doll collection .	102.81961
she kept the dolls on the lincoln bed .	15.083733
at night , when mama would turn back the covers , she would have to take all the dolls off the bed and place them elsewhere for the night .	49.721973
mama always felt that the collection symbolized mrs . coolidge ' s wish for a little girl .	14.857069
among the dolls was one that meant very much to the first lady , who would pick it up and look at it often .	69.07878
it had a tiny envelope tied to its wrist .	2.3614206
an accompanying sympathetic letter explained that inside the envelope was a name for mrs . coolidge ' s first granddaughter .	14.037803
mama knew this doll was meant to help mrs . coolidge overcome her grief by turning her eyes to the future .	24.073647
the name inside the envelope was `` cynthia ' ' .	3.6446226
the coolidges ' life , after the death of their son , was quieter than ever .	23.819704
john was away at school most of the time .	15.847982
mrs . coolidge would knit , and the president would sit reading , or playing with the many pets around them .	124.00963
now and then , the president would call for `` little jack , master of the hounds ' ' , which was his nickname for a messenger who had worked in the white house since teddy roosevelt ' s administration , and discuss the welfare of some one of the animals .	35.46751
it was part of little jack ' s work to look after the dogs .	53.548267
one white house dog was immortalized in a painting .	12.886196
that was rob roy , who posed with mrs . coolidge for the portrait by howard chandler christy .	33.67613
to get him to pose , mrs . coolidge would feed him candy , so he enjoyed the portrait sessions as well as she did .	36.03449
i would like to straighten out a misconception about the dress mrs . coolidge is wearing in this painting .	35.120255
it is not the same dress as the one on her manikin in the smithsonian .	24.852104
people think the dress in the picture was lengthened by an artist much later on .	125.521736
the dress in the painting is a bright red , with rhinestones forming a spray on the right side .	20.95902
there is a long train flowing from the shoulders .	10.620031
mrs . coolidge gave mama this dress for me , and i wore it many times .	24.26851
i still have the dress , and i hope to give it to the smithsonian institution as a memento , or , as i more fondly hope , to present it to a museum containing articles showing the daily lives of the presidents -- if i can get it organized .	72.71815
but to get back to the coolidge household , mrs . coolidge so obviously loved dogs , that the public sent her more dogs -- calamity jane , timmy , and blackberry .	30.297974
the last two were a red and a black chow .	9.549617
rob roy remained boss of all the dogs .	8.200168
he showed them what to do , and taught them how to keep the maids around the white house in a state of terror .	40.26473
the dogs would run through the halls after him like a burst of bullets , and all the maids would run for cover .	47.87846
mama didn ' t know what to do -- whether to tell on rob roy or not -- since she had the ear of mrs . coolidge more than the other maids .	46.19753
but she was afraid the first lady would not understand , because rob roy was a perfect angel with the first family .	18.512075
every day , when the president took his nap , rob roy would stretch out on the window seat near him , like a perfect gentleman , and stare thoughtfully out the window , or he would take a little nap himself .	45.18646
he would not make a sound until the president had wakened and left for the office	110.32527
then he would bark to let everyone know the coast was clear .	115.8054
his signal was for the other dogs to come running , but it was also the signal for mama and the other maids to watch out .	52.405636
rob roy was self-appointed to accompany the president to his office every morning .	43.02363
rob roy was well aware of the importance of this mission , and he would walk in front of the president , looking neither to the right nor to the left .	47.248417
at dinner , lunch , or breakfast , the president would call out , `` supper ' ' ! !	38.38358
-- he called all meals supper -- after the butler had announced the meal .	21.009352
all the dogs would dash to get on the elevator with the president and go to the dining room .	16.667006
they would all lie around on the rug during the meal , a very pretty sight as rob roy , prudence , and calamity jane were all snow-white .	23.022018
when prudence and blackberry were too young to be trusted in the dining room , they were tied to the radiator with their leashes , and they would cry .	18.520176
mama tried to talk to them and keep them quiet while she tidied up the sitting room before the first family returned .	39.687206
finally , mama did mention to mrs . coolidge that she felt sorry for the little dogs , and then mrs . coolidge decided to leave the radio on for them while she was gone , even though her husband disapproved of the waste of electricity .	41.34355
mama was now the first maid to mrs . coolidge , because catherine , the previous first maid , had become ill and died .	38.099316
mrs . coolidge chose mama in her place .	27.001804
every first family seems to have one couple upon whom it relies for true friendship .	148.10316
for the coolidges , it was mr . and mrs . frank w . stearns of boston , massachusetts , owners of a large department store .	18.263405
they seemed to be at the white house half the time .	135.18857
the butlers were amused because when the stearns were there , the president would say grace at breakfast .	113.996574
if the stearns were not there , grace would be omitted .	11.827536
speaking of breakfast , the president inaugurated a new custom -- that of conducting business at the breakfast table .	44.62104
the word was that this too was part of an economy move on his part .	97.54755
a new bill had been passed under harding that designated the government , rather than the president , as the tab-lifter for official meals .	30.561321
so the president would make a hearty breakfast official by inviting government officials to attend .	97.00225
he caused a lot of talk when he also chose the breakfast hour to have the barber come in and trim his hair while he ate .	61.32898
mama said that if presidents were supposed to be colorful , mr . coolidge certainly made a good president .	46.278873
he knew exactly how to be colorful ! !	1.0560689
the favorite guest of the house , as far as the staff was concerned , was mr . wrigley , the chewing gum king .	33.074886
the white house had chewing gum until it could chew no more , and every christmas , mr . wrigley sent the president a check for $100 , to be divided among all the help .	54.697563
you can imagine that he got pretty good service .	39.447357
another good friend of the coolidges ' was george b . harvey , who was the ambassador to great britain from 1921 to 1923 .	22.62083
he had been a friend of the hardings , and continued to be invited by the coolidges .	19.071117
the first royalty whom mama ever waited on in the white house was queen marie of rumania , who came to a state dinner given in her honor on october 21 , 1926 .	40.28425
she was not an overnight guest in the white house , but mr . ike hoover , the chief usher , had mama check her fur coat when she came in , and take care of her needs .	44.352318
mama said she was one of the prettiest ladies she had ever seen .	30.563158
mama was very patriotic , and one of the duties she was proudest of was repairing the edges of the flag that flew above the white house .	34.140957
actually , two flags were used at the mansion -- a small one on rainy days , and a big one on bright days .	77.65259
the wool would become frazzled around the edges from blowing in the wind , and mama would mend it .	34.715885
she would often go up on the roof to see the attendant take down the flag in the evening .	43.316338
she used to tell me , `` when i stand there and look at the flag blowing this way and that way , i have the wonderful , safe feeling that americans are protected no matter which way the wind blows ' ' .	76.268936
even when mrs . coolidge was in mourning for her son , she reached out to help other people in trouble .	54.0503
mama had told her how emmett ' s lungs had been affected when he was gassed in the war .	17.63002
he was in and out of mount alto hospital for veterans any number of times .	145.22023
taking a personal interest , she had the doctor assigned to the white house , dr . james coupal , look emmett over .	42.881294
as a result , he was sent to a hospital in arizona until his health improved enough for him to come back to washington to work in the government service .	78.7954
but again , there was danger that his lungs would suffer in the muggy washington weather , and he had to return to the dry climate of the west to live and work .	39.469315
when mrs . coolidge was in mourning , she did not wear black .	57.342674
she wore grey every day , and white every evening .	1420.4167
mama knew that she was out of mourning when she finally wore bright colors .	70.445946
the president helped her a lot by selecting some lovely colored dresses to get her started .	56.69864
she opened the boxes with a tear in her eye and a sad smile on her face .	13.397903
on the social side , the chore mama had at the formal receptions at the white house thrilled her the most .	59.842228
it was her job to stand at the foot of the stairs , and , just as the first lady stepped off the last tread , mama would straighten out her long train before she marched to the blue room to greet her guests with the president .	30.641254
mama would enjoy the sight of the famous guests as much as anyone , and would note a gown here and there to tell me about that night .	78.64964
one night , mama came home practically in a state of shock .	19.293358
she had stood at the bottom of the stairs , as usual , when mrs . coolidge came down , in the same dress that is now in the smithsonian , to greet her guests .	23.890718
mama stooped down to fix the train , but there was no train there ! !	78.93044
she reached and reached around the dress , but there was nothing there .	28.429014
she looked up and saw that , without knowing it , mrs . coolidge was holding it aloft .	27.8508
mrs . coolidge looked down , saw mama ' s horrified expression and quickly let the whole thing fall to the floor .	78.87416
mama swirled the train in place , and not a step was lost .	117.16952
the coolidges did not always live at the white house during the presidency .	25.583117
impressive as this enumeration is , it barely hints at the diverse perceptions of jews , collectively or individually , that have been attested by their gentile environment .	48.942047
it is reasonable to affirm two propositions jews have been perceived by non-jews as all things to all men	52.491295
some jews have in fact been all things to all men .	43.72086
in the arena of power jews have at one time or another been somebody ' s ally	123.89821
in the market place jews have in fact under various circumstances been valued customers and suppliers , or clannish monopolists and cutthroat competitors .	46.787525
and so on through the roles referred to in the previous paragraph .	13.662639
but the two do not invariably or even typically coincide .	26.413443
the `` conventional ' ' image of a particular time and place is not necessarily congruent with the image of the facts as established over the years by scholarly and scientific research .	40.880543
conventional images of jews have this in common with all perceptions of a configuration in which one feature is held constant images can be both true and false .	102.29068
the genuinely interesting question , then , becomes what factors determine the degree of realism or distortion in conventional images of jews ? ?	50.70449
the working test of `` the facts ' ' must always be the best available description obtainable from scholars and scientists who have applied their methods of investigation to relevant situations .	40.11108
granted , such `` functional ' ' images are subject to human error	88.929115
they are self-correcting in the sense that they are subject to disciplined procedures that check and recheck against error .	122.32875
in accounting for realism or distortion two sets of factors can be usefully distinguished current intelligence	64.35397
general grant may have been the victim of false information in the instance reported in this book	108.89238
if so , he would not be the first or last commanding officer who has succumbed to bad information and dubious estimates of the future .	73.167984
he may have entered the situation with predispositions that prepared him to act uncritically in the press of affairs .	37.35422
predispositions , in turn , fall conveniently into two categories for purposes of analysis .	40.30783
to some extent predispositions are shaped by exposure to group environments .	32.881317
in some measure they depend upon the structure of individual personality .	24.951567
the anti-semitism of hitler owed something to his exposure to the ideology of lueger ' s politically successful christian socialist movement in vienna .	35.450634
but millions of human beings were exposed to lueger ' s propaganda and record .	15.343032
after allowing for group exposures , it is apparent that other factors must be considered if we are to comprehend fanaticism .	28.773159
they include harmonies and conflicts within the whole man , and mechanisms whereby inner components are more or less smoothly met .	127.426704
modern psychiatric knowledge provides us with many keys to unlock the significance of behavior of the kind .	24.023478
the foregoing factors are pertinent to the analysis of perceptual images and the broad conditions under which they achieve realism or fall short of it .	70.26036
undoubtedly one merit of the vast panorama of gentile conceptions of the jew unfolded in the present anthology is that it provides a formidable body of material that invites critical examination in terms of reality .	36.66008
many selections are themselves convincing contributions to this appraisal .	35.59975
undoubtedly , however , the significance of the volume is greater than the foregoing paragraphs suggest .	67.107254
speaking as a non-jew i believe that its primary contribution is in the realm of future policy .	16.734488
since we can neither undo nor redo the past , we are limited to the events of today and tomorrow .	36.736526
in this domain the simple fact of coexistence in the same local , national , and world community is enough to guarantee that we cannot refrain from having some effect , large or small , upon gentile-jewish relations .	125.10782
i am deliberately raising the policy problems involved in gentile-jewish relations .	13.540759
comprehensive examination of any policy question calls for the performance of the intellectual tasks inseparable from any problem-solving method .	59.562523
the tasks are briefly indicated by these questions what are my goals in gentile-jewish relations ? ?	99.554634
what are the historical trends in this country and abroad in the extent to which these goals are effectively realized ? ?	29.401419
what factors condition the degree of realization at various times and places ? ?	42.07162
what is the probable course of future developments ? ?	6.778873
what policies if adopted and applied in various circumstances will increase the likelihood that future events will coincide with desired events and do so at least cost in terms of all human values ? ?	87.01323
it is beyond the province of this epilogue to cover policy questions of such depth and range .	131.14163
the discussion is therefore limited to a suggested procedure for realizing at least some of the potential importance of this volume for future policy .	88.65721
as a groundwork for the proposal i give some attention to the first task enumerated above , the clarification of goal .	45.695717
my reply is that i associate myself with all those who affirm that gentile-jewish relations should contribute to the theory and practice of human dignity .	38.974842
the basic goal finds partial expression in the universal declaration of human rights , a statement initiated and endorsed by individuals and organizations of many religious and philosophical traditions .	38.782604
within this frame of reference policies appropriate to claims advanced in the name of the jews depend upon which jewish identity is involved , as well as upon the nature of the claim , the characteristics of the claimant , the justifications proposed , and the predispositions of the community decision makers who are called upon to act .	40.23755
if jews are identified as a religious body in a controversy that comes before a national or international tribunal , it is obviously compatible with the goal of human dignity to protect freedom of worship .	48.56538
when decision makers act within this frame they determine whether a claim put forward in the name of religion is to be accepted by the larger community as appropriate to religion .	65.34898
since the recognition of israel as a nation state , claims are made in many cases which identify the claimant as a member of the new body politic .	49.498943
community decision makers must make up their minds whether a claim is acceptable to the larger community in terms of prevailing expectations regarding members of nation states .	109.338646
in free countries many controversies involve self-styled jews who use the symbol in asserting a vaguely `` cultural ' ' rather than religious or political identity .	54.440945
the decision maker who acts for the community as a whole must decide whether the objectives pursued and the methods used are appropriate to public policy regarding cultural groups .	68.75152
we know that much is made of the multiplicity and ambiguity of the identities that cluster around the key symbol of the jew .	26.976147
many public and private controversies will undoubtedly continue to reflect these confusions in the mind and usage of gentile and jew .	28.570005
however , in the context of legal and civic policy , these controversies are less than novel .	34.57736
they involve similar uncertainties regarding the multiple identities of any number of non-jewish groups .	27.43332
so far as the existing body of formal principle and procedure is concerned , categorical novelties are not to be anticipated in jewish-gentile relationships	41.387577
claims are properly disposed of according to norms common to all parties .	92.646484
it is not implied that formal principles and procedures are so firmly entrenched within the public order of the world community or even of free commonwealths that they will control in all circumstances involving jews and gentiles during coming years .	71.20157
but it is perennially restructured in situations where anchors are dragged or lost .	32.93147
in conformance with the maximization principle we affirm that gentile-jewish relations will be harmonious or inharmonious to the degree that one relation or the other is expected by the active participants to yield the greatest net advantage , taking all value outcomes and effects into consideration .	65.38296
it is not difficult to anticipate circumstances in which negative tensions will cumulate	67.10226
for instance , imagine the situation if israel ever joins an enemy coalition .	249.97713
the formal position of americans who identify themselves with one or more of the several identities of the jewish symbol is already clear	46.95275
the future weight of informal factors cannot be so easily assessed .	49.323505
when we consider the disorganized state of the world community , and the legacy of predispositions adversely directed against all who are identified as jews , it is obvious that the struggle for the minds and muscles of men needs to be prosecuted with increasing vigor and skill .	40.748158
during moments of intense crisis the responsibility of political leaders is overwhelming .	32.11428
but their freedom of policy is limited by the pattern of predisposition with which they and the people around them enter the crisis .	66.893845
at such critical moments predispositions favorable to human dignity most obviously `` pay off ' ' .	95.33203
by the same test predispositions destructive of human personality exercise their most sinister impact , with the result that men of good will are often trapped and nullified .	49.468563
among measures in anticipation of crisis are plans to inject into the turmoil as assistants of key decision makers qualified persons who are cognizant of the corrosive effect of crisis upon personal relationships and are also able to raise calm and realistic voices when overburdened leaders near the limit of self-control .	43.5586
we are learning how to do these things in some of the vast organized structures of modern society	74.54432
a truism is that the time to prepare for the worst is when times are best .	143.14241
during intercrisis periods the educational facilities of the community have the possibility of remolding the perspectives and altering the behavior of vast numbers of human beings of every age and condition .	28.339115
as more men and women are made capable of living up to the challenge of decency the chances are improved that the pattern of predisposition prevailing in positions of strength in future crises can be favorably affected .	60.811535
now an abiding difficulty of paragraphs like the foregoing is that they appear to preach	33.241707
and in contemporary society we often complain of too much reaffirmation of the goodness of the good .	26.737238
in any case i do not intend to let the present occasion pass without dealing more directly with the problem of implementing good intentions .	155.80318
i assume that the number of readers of this anthology who regard themselves as morally perfect is small , and that most readers are willing to consider procedures by which they may gain more insight into themselves and better understanding of others .	79.50987
properly used , the present book is an excellent instrument of enlightenment .	6.4570575
let us not confuse the issue by labeling the objective or the method `` psychoanalytic ' ' , for this is a well established term of art for the specific ideas and procedures initiated by sigmund freud and his followers for the study and treatment of disordered personalities .	48.982872
the traditional method proceeds by the technique of free association , punctuated by interpretations proposed by the psychoanalytic interviewer .	37.677708
what we have in mind does have something in common with the goals of psychoanalysis and with the methods by which they are sought .	68.5397
for what we propose , however , a psychoanalyst is not necessary , even though one aim is to enable the reader to get beneath his own defenses -- his defenses of himself to himself .	33.34222
for this purpose a degree of intellectual and emotional involvement is necessary	178.31909
but involvement needs to be accompanied by a special frame of mind .	88.26804
the relatively long and often colorful selections in this anthology enable the reader to become genuinely absorbed in what is said , whether he responds with anger or applause .	30.653437
self-discovery calls for an open , permissive , inquiring posture of self-observation .	5.706715
the symposium provides an opportunity to confront the self with specific statements which were made at particular times by identifiable communicators who were addressing definite audiences -- and throughout several hundred pages everyone is talking about the same key symbol of identification .	97.37764
an advantage of being exposed to such specificity about an important and recurring feature of social reality is that it can be taken advantage of by the reader to examine covert as well as overt resonances within himself , resonances triggered by explicit symbols clustering around the central figure of the jew .	60.24871
two facets of this aspect of the literary process have special significance for our time .	88.531456
one , a reservation on the point i have just made , is the phenomenon of pseudo-thinking , pseudo-feeling , and pseudo-willing , which fromm discussed in the escape from freedom .	31.81879
in essence this involves grounding one ' s thought and emotion in the values and experience of others , rather than in one ' s own values and experience .	46.312252
there is a risk that instead of teaching a person how to be himself , reading fiction and drama may teach him how to be somebody else .	76.43845
clearly what the person brings to the reading is important .	114.74005
moreover , if the critic instructs his audience in what to see in a work , he is contributing to this pseudo-thinking	36.69147
if he instructs them in how to evaluate a work , he is helping them to achieve their own identity .	36.765682
the second timely part of this sketch of literature and the search for identity has to do with the difference between good and enduring literary works and the ephemeral mass culture products of today .	65.31599
in the range and variety of characters who , in their literary lives , get along all right with life styles one never imagined possible , there is an implicit lesson in differentiation .	227.70088
the reader , observing this process , might ask `` why not be different ' ' ? ?	32.651245
and find in the answer a license to be a variant of the human species .	14.551767
the observer of television or other products for a mass audience has only a permit to be , like the models he sees , even more like everybody else .	106.383995
and this , i think , holds for values as well as life styles .	69.45816
after all , the large ( and probably unreliable ) reader ' s digest literature on the `` most unforgettable character i ever met ' ' deals with village grocers , country doctors , favorite if illiterate aunts , and so forth .	49.668285
scientists often turn out to be idiosyncratic , too .	54.929214
but still , the proposition is worth examination .	4.5688295
it is possible that the study of literature affects the conscience , the morality , the sensitivity to some code of `` right ' ' and `` wrong ' ' .	21.380983
both flugel and ranyard west deal with the development and nature of conscience , as do such theologians as niebuhr and buber .	42.872517
it forms the core of many , perhaps most , problems of psychotherapy .	127.69238
i am not aware of great attention by any of these authors or by the psychotherapeutic profession to the role of literary study in the development of conscience -- most of their attention is to a pre-literate period of life , or , for the theologians of course , to the influence of religion .	37.097073
still , it would be surprising if what one reads did not contribute to one ' s ideas of right and wrong	39.294662
certainly the awakened alarm over the comic books and the continuous concern over prurient literature indicate some peripheral aspects of this influence .	64.290764
probably the most important thing to focus on is not the development of conscience , which may well be almost beyond the reach of literature , but the contents of conscience , the code which is imparted to the developed or immature conscience available .	55.20774
this is in large part a code of behavior and a glossary of values what is it that people do and should do and how one should regard it .	115.15535
in a small way this is illustrated by the nineteenth-century novelist who argued for the powerful influence of literature as a teacher of society and who illustrated this with the way a girl learned to meet her lover , how to behave , how to think about this new experience , how to exercise restraint .	69.648834
literature may be said to give people a sense of purpose , dedication , mission , significance .	47.08747
this , no doubt , is part of what gilbert seldes implies when he says of the arts , `` they give form and meaning to life which might otherwise seem shapeless and without sense ' ' .	72.22093
men seem almost universally to want a sense of function , that is , a feeling that their existence makes a difference to someone , living or unborn , close and immediate or generalized .	57.80515
feeling useless seems generally to be an unpleasant sensation .	9.856648
a need so deeply planted , asking for direction , so to speak , is likely to be gratified by the vivid examples and heroic proportions of literature .	43.51703
the terms `` renewal ' ' and `` refreshed ' ' , which often come up in aesthetic discussion , seem partly to derive their import from the `` renewal ' ' of purpose and a `` refreshed ' ' sense of significance a person may receive from poetry , drama , and fiction .	40.899174
the notion of `` inspiration ' ' is somehow cognate to this feeling .	39.09161
how literature does this , or for whom , is certainly not clear , but the content , form , and language of the `` message ' ' , as well as the source , would all play differentiated parts in giving and molding a sense of purpose .	47.081375
one of the most salient features of literary value has been deemed to be its influence upon and organization of emotion .	110.48284
let us differentiate a few of these ideas .	2.988301
the aristotelian notion of catharsis , the purging of emotion , is a persistent and viable one .	21.911316
the idea here is one of discharge but this must stand in opposition to a second view , plato ' s notion of the arousal of emotion .	44.542454
a third idea is that artistic literature serves to reduce emotional conflicts , giving a sense of serenity and calm to individuals .	51.009983
this is given some expression in beardsley ' s notion of harmony and the resolution of indecision .	20.792053
a fourth view is the transformation of emotion , as in housman ' s fine phrase on the arts they `` transform and beautify our inner nature ' ' .	22.147507
it is possible that the idea of enrichment of emotion is a fifth idea .	38.934265
f . s . c . northrop , in his discussion of the `` functions and future of poetry ' ' , suggests this `` one of the things which makes our lives drab and empty and which leaves us , at the end of the day , fatigued and deflated spiritually is the pressure of the taxing , practical , utilitarian concern of common-sense objects .	31.512629
if art is to release us from these postulated things ( things we must think symbolically about ) and bring us back to the ineffable beauty and richness of the aesthetic component of reality in its immediacy , it must sever its connection with these common sense entities ' ' .	40.433575
i take the central meaning here to be the contrast between the drab empty quality of life without literature and a life enriched by it .	132.99408
richards ' view of the aesthetic experience might constitute a sixth variety for him it constitutes , in part , the organization of impulses .	114.12139
a sketch of the emotional value of the study of literature would have to take account of all of these .	36.629143
but there is one in particular which , it seems to me , deserves special attention .	39.169586
in the wide range of experiences common to our earth-bound race none is more difficult to manage , more troublesome , and more enduring in its effects than the control of love and hate .	67.451775
the study of literature contributes to this control in a curious way .	83.066414
william wimsatt and cleanth brooks , it seems to me , have a penetrating insight into the way in which this control is effected `` for if we say poetry is to talk of beauty and love ( and yet not aim at exciting erotic emotion or even an emotion of platonic esteem ) and if it is to talk of anger and murder ( and yet not aim at arousing anger and indignation ) -- then it may be that the poetic way of dealing with these emotions will not be any kind of intensification , compounding , or magnification , or any direct assault upon the affections at all .	48.771378
something indirect , mixed , reconciling , tensional might well be the stratagem , the devious technique by which a poet indulged in all kinds of talk about love and anger and even in something like `` expressions ' ' of these emotions , without aiming at their incitement or even uttering anything that essentially involves their incitement ' ' .	39.997257
the rehearsal through literature of emotional life under controlled conditions may be a most valuable human experience .	38.889233
here i do not mean catharsis , the discharge of emotion .	29.0788
i mean something more like freud ' s concept of the utility of `` play ' ' to a small child he plays `` house ' ' or `` doctor ' ' or `` fireman ' ' as a way of mastering slightly frightening experiences , reliving them imaginatively until they are under control .	28.205723
there is a second feature of the influences of literature , good literature , on emotional life which may have some special value for our time .	45.078133
in b . m . spinley ' s portrayal of the underprivileged and undereducated youth of london , a salient finding was the inability to postpone gratification , a need to satisfy impulses immediately without the pleasure of anticipation or of savoring the experience .	28.880678
perhaps it is only an analogy , but one of the most obvious differences between cheap fiction and fiction of an enduring quality is the development of a theme or story with leisure and anticipation .	45.07261
anyone who has watched children develop a taste for literature will understand what i mean .	108.05048
it is at least possible that the capacity to postpone gratification is developed as well as expressed in a continuous and guided exposure to great literature .	60.199776
in any inquiry into the way in which great literature affects the emotions , particularly with respect to the sense of harmony , or relief of tension , or sense of `` a transformed inner nature ' ' which may occur , a most careful exploration of the particular feature of the experience which produces the effect would be required .	52.713863
in the calm which follows the reading of a poem , for example , is the effect produced by the enforced quiet , by the musical quality of words and rhythm , by the sentiments or sense of the poem , by the associations with earlier readings , if it is familiar , by the boost to the self-esteem for the semi-literate , by the diversion of attention , by the sense of security in a legitimized withdrawal , by a kind license for some variety of fantasy life regarded as forbidden , or by half-conscious ideas about the magical power of words ? ?	43.364212
these are , if the research is done with subtlety and skill , researchable topics , but the research is missing .	19.352438
one of the most frequent views of the value of literature is the education of sensibility that it is thought to provide .	39.01741
sensibility is a vague word , covering an area of meaning rather than any precise talent , quality , or skill .	56.718918
among other things it means perception , discrimination , sensitivity to subtle differences .	49.96586
both the extent to which this is true and the limits of the field of perceptual skill involved should be acknowledged .	53.205276
its truth is illustrated by the skill , sensitivity , and general expertise of the english professor with whom one attends the theatre .	29.060287
the limits are suggested by an imaginary experiment contrast the perceptual skill of english professors with that of their colleagues in discriminating among motor cars , political candidates , or female beauty .	96.934044
along these lines , the particular point that sensitivity in literature leads to sensitivity in human relations would require more proof than i have seen .	73.217896
in a symposium and general exploration of the field of personal perception and interpersonal behavior the discussion does not touch upon this aspect of the subject , with one possible exception	54.87586
solomon asch shows the transcultural stability of metaphors based on sensation ( hot , sweet , bitter , etc . ) dealing with personal qualities of human beings and events .	57.906425
but to go from here to the belief that those more sensitive to metaphor and language will also be more sensitive to personal differences is too great an inferential leap .	80.42379
i would say , too , that the study of literature tends to give a person what i shall call depth .	76.421394
i use this term to mean three things a search for the human significance of an event or state of affairs , a tendency to look at wholes rather than parts , and a tendency to respond to these events and wholes with feeling .	43.971825
it is the obverse of triviality , shallowness , emotional anaesthesia .	8.278701
i think these attributes cluster , but i have no evidence .	39.45011
in fact , i can only say this seems to me to follow from a wide , continuous , and properly guided exposure to literary art .	101.05086
the late r . g . collingwood , a philosopher whose work has proved helpful to many students of literature , once wrote ``	102.15542
we are all , though many of us are snobbish enough to wish to deny it , in far closer sympathy with the art of the music-hall and picture-palace than with chaucer and cimabue , or even shakespeare and titian .	26.17625
by an effort of historical sympathy we can cast our minds back into the art of a remote past or an alien present , and enjoy the carvings of cavemen and japanese colour-prints	52.126205
but the possibility of this effort is bound up with that development of historical thought which is the greatest achievement of our civilization in the last two centuries , and it is utterly impossible to people in whom this development has not taken place .	62.762844
the natural and primary aesthetic attitude is to enjoy contemporary art , to despise and dislike the art of the recent past , and wholly to ignore everything else ' ' .	53.82967
one might argue that the ultimate purpose of literary scholarship is to correct this spontaneous provincialism that is likely to obscure the horizons of the general public , of the newspaper critic , and of the creative artist himself .	40.69634
there results a study of literature freed from the tyranny of the contemporary .	21.483328
the study of ideas in literature is one of these .	11.665709
of course , it goes without saying that no student of ideas can justifiably ignore the contemporary scene .	34.524117
the continuities , contrasts , and similarities discernible when past and present are surveyed together are inexhaustible and the one is often understood through the other .	84.036285
when we assert the value of such study , we find ourselves committed to an important assumption .	27.486158
most students of literature , whether they call themselves scholars or critics , are ready to argue that it is possible to understand literary works as well as to enjoy them .	44.178776
many will add that we may find our enjoyment heightened by our understanding .	34.869835
this understanding , of course , may in its turn take many forms and some of these -- especially those most interesting to the student of comparative literature -- are essentially historical .	88.84316
but the historian of literature need not confine his attention to biography or to stylistic questions of form , `` texture ' ' , or technique .	15.665414
it is true that this distinction between style and idea often approaches the arbitrary since in the end we must admit that style and content frequently influence or interpenetrate one another and sometimes appear as expressions of the same insight .	97.41326
but , in general , we may argue that the student can direct the primary emphasis of his attention toward one or the other .	97.84122
at this point a working definition of idea is in order , although our first definition will have to be qualified somewhat as we proceed .	91.14156
the term idea refers to our more reflective or thoughtful consciousness as opposed to the immediacies of sensuous or emotional experience .	72.48042
it is through such reflection that literature approaches philosophy .	93.412796
an idea , let us say , may be roughly defined as a theme or topic with which our reflection may be concerned .	70.79781
in this essay , we are , along with most historians , interested in the more general or more inclusive ideas , that are so to speak `` writ large ' ' in history of literature where they recur continually .	76.3353
outstanding among these is the idea of human nature itself , including the many definitions that have been advanced over the centuries	46.451706
also secondary notions such as the perfectibility of man , the depravity of man , and the dignity of man .	8.526217
one might , indeed , argue that the history of ideas , in so far as it includes the literatures , must center on characterizations of human nature and that the great periods of literary achievement may be distinguished from one another by reference to the images of human nature that they succeed in fashioning .	42.84619
we need not , to be sure , expect to find such ideas in every piece of literature .	86.28785
an idea , of the sort that we have in mind , although of necessity readily available to imagination , is more general in connotation than most poetic or literary images , especially those appearing in lyric poems that seek to capture a moment of personal experience .	66.23021
thus burns ' s `` my love is like a red , red rose ' ' and hopkins ' `` the thunder-purple sea-beach , plumed purple of thunder ' ' although clearly intelligible in content , hardly present ideas of the sort with which we are here concerned .	50.501644
on the other hand , arnold ' s `` the unplumbed , salt , estranging sea ' ' , taken in its context , certainly does so .	46.259205
understanding a work of art involves recognition of the ideas that it reflects or embodies .	27.779434
thus the student of literature may sometimes find it helpful to classify a poem or an essay as being in idea or in ideal content or subject matter typical or atypical of its period .	81.48588
again , he may discover embodied within its texture a theme or idea that has been presented elsewhere and at other times in various ways .	101.41802
our understanding will very probably require both these commentaries .	20.742975
very likely it will also include a recognition that the work we are reading reflects or `` belongs to ' ' some way of thought labelled as a `` school ' ' or an `` -ism ' ' , i . e . a complex or `` syndrome ' ' of ideas occurring together with sufficient prominence to warrant identification .	37.3453
thus ideas like `` grace ' ' , `` salvation ' ' , and `` providence ' ' cluster together in traditional christianity .	25.48506
usually the work studied offers us a special or even an individualized rendering or treatment of the ideas in question , so that the student finds it necessary to distinguish carefully between the several expressions of an `` -ism ' ' or mode of thought .	28.152763
accordingly we may speak of the platonism peculiar to shelley ' s poems or the type of stoicism present in henley ' s `` invictus ' ' , and we may find that describing such platonism or such stoicism and contrasting each with other expressions of the same attitude or mode of thought is a difficult and challenging enterprise .	43.188705
after all , shelley is no `` orthodox ' ' or hellenic platonist , and even his `` romantic ' ' platonism can be distinguished from that of his contemporaries .	20.89244
again , henley ' s attitude of defiance which colors his ideal of self-mastery is far from characteristic of a stoic thinker like marcus aurelius , whose gentle acquiescence is almost christian , comparable to the patience expressed in milton ' s sonnet on his own blindness .	45.576923
in recent years , we have come increasingly to recognize that ideas have a history and that not the least important chapters of this history have to do with thematic or conceptual aspects of literature and the arts , although these aspects should be studied in conjunction with the history of philosophy , of religion , and of the sciences .	55.59316
when these fields are surveyed together , important patterns of relationship emerge indicating a vast community of reciprocal influence , a continuity of thought and expression including many traditions , primarily literary , religious , and philosophical , but frequently including contact with the fine arts and even , to some extent , with science .	101.031685
here we may observe that at least one modern philosophy of history is built on the assumption that ideas are the primary objectives of the historian ' s research .	36.583305
let us quote once more from r . g . collingwood `` history is properly concerned with the actions of human beings regarded from the outside , an action is an event or series of events occurring in the physical world	60.48824
regarded from the inside , it is the carrying into action of a certain thought the historian ' s business is to penetrate to the inside of the actions with which he is dealing and reconstruct or rather rethink the thoughts which constituted them .	44.014164
it is a characteristic of thoughts that in re-thinking them we come , ipso facto , to understand why they were thought ' ' .	55.06813
such an understanding , although it must seek to be sympathetic , is not a matter of intuition .	24.2329
`` history has this in common with every other science that the historian is not allowed to claim any single piece of knowledge , except where he can justify his claim by exhibiting to himself in the first place , and secondly to any one else who is both able and willing to follow his demonstration , the grounds upon which it is based .	64.76815
this is what was meant , above , by describing history as inferential .	84.96758
the knowledge in virtue of which a man is an historian is a knowledge of what the evidence at his disposal proves about certain events ' ' .	63.820564
it is obvious that the historian who seeks to recapture the ideas that have motivated human behavior throughout a given period will find the art and literature of that age one of his central and major concerns , by no means a mere supplement or adjunct of significant historical research .	109.40028
the student of ideas and their place in history will always be concerned with the patterns of transition , which are at the same time patterns of transformation , whereby ideas pass from one area of activity to another .	78.89048
let us survey for a moment the development of modern thought -- turning our attention from the reformation toward the revolutionary and romantic movements that follow and dwelling finally on more recent decades .	81.66886
we may thus trace the notion of individual autonomy from its manifestation in religious practice and theological reflection through practical politics and political theory into literature and the arts .	55.304176
finally we may note that the idea appears in educational theory where its influence is at present widespread .	168.15529
no one will deny that such broad developments and transitions are of great intrinsic interest and the study of ideas in literature would be woefully incomplete without frequent reference to them .	38.870457
still , we must remember that we cannot construct and justify generalizations of this sort unless we are ready to consider many special instances of influence moving between such areas as theology , philosophy , political thought , and literature .	66.36659
the actual moments of contact are vitally important .	8.637116
these moments are historical events in the lives of individual authors with which the student of comparative literature must be frequently concerned .	36.683617
perhaps the most powerful and most frequently recurring literary influence on the western world has been that of the old and new testament .	38.276043
certainly one of the most important comments that can be made upon the spiritual and cultural life of any period of western civilization during the past sixteen or seventeen centuries has to do with the way in which its leaders have read and interpreted the bible .	59.207203
this reading and the comments that it evoked constitute the influence .	74.12856
a contrast of the scripture reading of , let us say , st . augustine , john bunyan , and thomas jefferson , all three of whom found in such study a real source of enlightenment , can tell us a great deal about these three men and the age that each represented and helped bring to conscious expression .	46.95084
in much the same way , we recognize the importance of shakespeare ' s familarity with plutarch and montaigne , of shelley ' s study of plato ' s dialogues , and of coleridge ' s enthusiastic plundering of the writings of many philosophers and theologians from plato to schelling and william godwin , through which so many abstract ideas were brought to the attention of english men of letters .	19.3887
we may also recognize cases in which the poets have influenced the philosophers and even indirectly the scientists .	37.430134
english philosopher samuel alexander ' s debt to wordsworth and meredith is a recent interesting example , as also a . n . whitehead ' s understanding of the english romantics , chiefly shelley and wordsworth .	51.394325
hegel ' s profound admiration for the insights of the greek tragedians indicates a broad channel of classical influence upon nineteenth-century philosophy .	42.564625
again the student of evolutionary biology will find a fascinating , if to our minds grotesque , anticipation of the theory of chance variations and the natural elimination of the unfit in lucretius , who in turn seems to have borrowed the concept from the philosopher empedocles .	46.13833
we must avoid the notion , suggested to some people by examples such as those just mentioned , that ideas are `` units ' ' in some way comparable to coins or counters that can be passed intact from one group of people to another or even , for that matter , from one individual to another .	80.72528
`` suppose you take mr . hearst ' s morning american at $10 , 000 a year ' ' , brisbane proposed .	52.802544
`` you could come down to the office once a day , look over a few exchanges , dictate an editorial , and then have the remainder of your time for your more serious literary labors .	60.30165
if within one year you can make a success out of the american , you can practically name your own salary thereafter .	192.81967
of course , if you don ' t make the american a success , hearst will have no further use for you ' ' .	91.596504
the blue-eyed watson decided that he would dislike living in new york , and the deal fell through .	100.253525
hearst ' s luck was even poorer when he had a chat with franklin k . lane , a prominent california journalist and reform politician , whom he asked for his support .	29.956852
lane was still burning because he had narrowly missed election as governor of california in 1902 and laid his defeat to the antagonism of hearst ' s san francisco examiner .	32.18763
hearst disclaimed blame for this , but the conversation , according to lane , ended on a tart note .	77.55467
`` mr . lane ' ' , hearst said , `` if you ever wish anything that i can do , all you will have to do will be to send me a telegram asking , and it will be done ' ' .	28.05081
`` mr . hearst ' ' , lane replied as he left , `` if you ever get a telegram from me asking you to do anything , you can put the telegram down as a forgery ' ' .	30.11245
hearst took a brief respite to hurry home to new york to become a father .	18.80969
on april 10 , 1904 , his first child was born , a son named george after the late senator .	46.140686
hearst saw his wife and child , sent a joyful message to his mother in california , and soon returned to washington , where on april 22 , for the first time , he opened his mouth in congress .	35.731686
this was not before the house but before the judiciary committee , where he asked for action on one of his pet bills , that calling for an investigation of the coal-railroad monopoly .	25.373253
attorney shearn had worked on this for two years and had succeeded in getting a report supporting his stand from the united states attorney for the southern district of new york .	62.491062
hearst had spent more than $60 , 000 of his own money in the probe , but still attorney general knox was quiescent .	38.214214
six of the railroads carrying coal to tidewater from the pennsylvania fields , hearst said , not only had illegal agreements with coal operators but owned outright at least eleven mines .	45.373837
they had watered their stock at immense profit , then had raised the price of coal fifty cents a ton , netting themselves another $20 , 000 , 000 in annual profit .	30.554932
`` the attorney general has been brooding over that evidence like an old hen on a doorknob for eighteen months ' ' , hearst said .	43.545673
`` he has not acted in any way , and won ' t let anyone take it away from him .	33.442482
what i want is to have this evidence come before congress and if the attorney general does not report it , as i am very sure he won ' t , as he has refused to do anything of the kind , i then wish that a committee of seven representatives be appointed with power to take the evidence .	72.19063
this was the very sort of legislation that roosevelt himself had in mind .	98.509995
there can be little doubt that there was a conspiracy in washington , overt or implied , to block anything hearst wanted , even if it was something good .	70.79389
roosevelt and others considered him partly responsible for the murder of mckinley .	31.771994
they were repelled by his noisy newspapers , his personal publicity , his presumptuous campaign for the presidential nomination , and by the swelling cloud of rumor about his moral lapses .	28.93038
he might get votes from his constituents , but he would never get a helping hand in congress .	87.42422
inherently incapable of cooperating with others , he ran his own show regardless of how many party-line democratic toes he stepped on .	102.08043
he was a political maverick , a reformer with his own program , determined to bulldoze it through or to blazon the infamy of those who balked him .	29.110168
he showed little interest in measures put forward by the regular democrats .	42.74843
he sought to run congress as he ran his new york american or journal , a scheme veteran legislators resisted .	78.58108
for a freshman congressman to read political lessons to graybeard democrats was poor policy for one who needed to make friends .	93.17186
he soon quarreled with all the party leaders in the house , and came to be regarded with detestation by regular democrats as a professional radical leading a small pack of obedient terriers whose constant snapping was demoralizing to party discipline .	43.0488
to old-line democrats , the hearst presidential boom , now in full cry , was the joke of the new century .	68.532875
yet no leader had come to the fore who seemed likely to give the puissant t . r . a semblance of a race .	31.321915
there was talk of dragging old ex-president cleveland out of retirement for another try .	114.08537
some preferred judge alton b . parker of new york .	10.761495
the sneers at hearst changed to concern when it was seen that he had strong support in many parts of the country .	34.154522
platoons of hearst agents were traveling from state to state in a surprisingly successful search for delegates at the coming convention , and there were charges that money was doing a large part of the persuading .	56.268837
just when it was needed for the campaign , hearst paper no . 8 , the boston american , began publication .	189.3972
a bay state supporter said , `` mr . hearst ' s fight has been helped along greatly by the starting of his paper in boston ' ' .	40.5776
he ordered his editors to tone down on sensationalism and to refrain from using such words as `` seduction ' ' , `` rape ' ' , `` abortion ' ' , `` criminal assault ' ' and `` born out of wedlock ' ' .	11.486475
in a story headed , `` hearst offers cash ' ' , the republican new york tribune spread the money rumor , quoting an unnamed `` hearst supporter ' ' as saying	23.028622
`` the argument that is cutting most ice is that hearst is the only candidate who is fighting the trusts fearlessly and who would use all the powers of government to disrupt them if he were elected .	112.744736
the hearst men say that if hearst is nominated , he and his immediate friends will contribute to the democratic national committee the sum of $1 , 500 , 000 .	32.64446
this , it is urged , would relieve the national committee from the necessity of appealing to the trust magnates .	76.89036
the alternative to this is that if a conservative candidate is nominated the national committee will have to appeal to the trusts for their campaign funds , and in doing this will incur obligations which would make a democratic victory absolutely fruitless .	45.885086
the average democratic politician , especially in the country districts , is hungry for the spoils of office .	34.100536
it has been a long time since he has seen any campaign money , and when the proposition is laid down to him as the friends of mr . hearst are laying it down these days he is quite likely to get aboard the hearst bandwagon ' ' .	55.337936
if anything , the conservative democrats were more opposed to hearst than the republicans .	33.551044
in his own state of new york , the two democratic bellwethers , state leader hill and tammany boss murphy , were saying nothing openly against hearst but industriously boosting their own favorites , murphy being for cleveland and hill for parker .	92.50614
they had lost twice with the radical bryan , and were having no part of hearst , whom they considered more radical than bryan .	79.91079
but his increasing strength in the west looked menacing .	2.2802625
it caused henry watterson to sound a blast in his louisville courier-journal	4.7003694
`` does any sane democrat believe that mr . hearst , a person unknown even to his constituency and his colleagues , without a word or act in the public life of his country , past or present , that can be shown to be his to commend him , could by any possibility be elected president of the united states ? ?	56.259636
more splenetic was senator edward carmack of tennessee , a parker man .	45.748707
`` the nomination of hearst would compass the ruin of the party ' ' , carmack said .	11.85543
`` it would be a disgrace , and , as i have already said to the people of tennessee , if hearst is nominated , we may as well pen a dispatch , and send it back from the field of battle ' all is lost , including our honor ' ' ' .	68.35898
