a lone pro-hearst voice from new york city was that of william devery , who had been expelled as a tammany leader but still claimed strong influence in his own district .	37.09926
`` i understand [ hearst ] is a candidate for presidential honors ' ' , devery said without cracking a smile .	34.108917
`` there ' s nothing like buildin ' from the bottom up .	119.56865
if he ' s going to the st . louis convention as a delegate we ought to know it .	34.898766
he ' s got a lot of friends , and he ought to come along and let us know if he wants our help ' ' .	40.16032
hearst won the iowa state convention , but ran into a bitter battle in indiana before losing to parker , drawing an angry statement from indiana ' s john w . kern	43.434013
`` we are menaced for the first time in the history of the republic by the open and unblushing effort of a multi-millionaire to purchase the presidential nomination .	24.058006
our state has been overrun with a gang of paid agents and retainers .	57.683445
as for the paid hessians from other states , we are here to instruct the indiana democracy in their duty , i have nothing but contempt .	59.516983
the hearst dollar mark is all over them .	4.125883
the talk of a hearst `` barrel ' ' was increasing .	26.373766
another indiana observer later commented , `` perhaps we shall never know how much was spent ( by hearst ) , but if as much money was expended elsewhere as in indiana a liberal fortune was squandered ' ' .	62.085373
in his fight for the illinois and indiana delegations , hearst made several trips to chicago to confer with andrew lawrence , the former san francisco examiner man who was now his chicago kingpin , and once to meet with bryan .	42.255173
on one visit he stopped at the office of the american , where he was known surreptitiously as `` the great white chief ' ' , and for the first time met his managing editor , fat moses koenigsberg .	40.312706
koenigsberg never did learn what hearst wanted , for the latter shook hands and moved toward the door .	40.52901
`` never mind , thank you ' ' , he said .	3.4867435
`` i must hurry to catch my train ' ' .	1.4604046
another editor pointed despairingly at a bundle of letters that had accumulated for him , saying , `` but mr . hearst , what shall i do with this correspondence ' ' ? ?	32.646675
`` i ' ll show you ' ' , hearst replied , grinning .	12.885203
he took the stack of mail and tossed it into the waste basket .	32.175877
every letter answers itself in a couple of weeks ' ' .	8.370517
hearst hopped into a private railroad car with max ihmsen and made an arduous personal canvass for delegates in the western and southern states , always wearing a frock coat , listening intently to local politicians , and generally making a good impression .	36.454277
he laughed at a story that he planned to bolt the party if he was not nominated .	16.371645
`` i should , of course ' ' , he said , `` like any other man , be honored and gratified should the democrats see fit to nominate me .	35.229923
but i do not have to be bribed by office to be a democrat .	44.47966
i have supported the democratic party in the last five campaigns .	90.83041
i supported cleveland three times and bryan twice .	52.814167
i intend to support the nominee of the party at st . louis , whoever he may be ' ' .	31.991335
the hearst press followed the chief ' s progress at the various state conventions with its usual admiring attention , stressing the `` enthusiasm ' ' and `` loyalty ' ' he inspired .	36.863605
this was historic in its way , for it marked the first time an american presidential aspirant had advertised his own virtues in his own string of newspapers spanning the land .	44.444923
yet his editors did not abandon their sense of story value .	414.18268
when nan patterson , a stunning and money-minded chorus girl who had appeared in a floradora road show , rode down broadway in a hansom cab with her married lover , frank young , she stopped the cab to disclose that young had been shot dead , tearfully insisting that he had shot himself although experts said he could not have done so .	54.060356
trevelyan ' s liberalism was above all a liberalism of the spirit , a deep feeling of communion with men fighting for country and for liberty .	110.024086
his passion and enthusiasm convey the courage and high adventure of garibaldi ' s exploits and give the reader a unique sense of participation in the events described .	51.55887
the three volumes brought to the fore a characteristic of trevelyan ' s prose which remained conspicuous through his later works -- a genius for describing military action with clarity and with authority .	73.700966
the confused rambling of guerrilla warfare , such as most of garibaldi ' s campaigns were , was brought to life by trevelyan ' s pen in some of the best passages in the books .	34.919044
his personal familiarity with the scenes of action undoubtedly contributed much to the final result , but familiarity alone would not have been enough without other qualities .	116.77184
military knowledge , love of detail , and a sure feeling for the portrayal of action were the added ingredients .	124.31987
but the garibaldi volumes were more than a romantic story .	33.87624
trevelyan contributed considerable new knowledge of the issues connected with his subject .	51.7074
the outstanding example was in garibaldi and the thousand , where he made use of unpublished papers of lord john russell and english consular materials to reveal the motives which led the british government to permit garibaldi to cross the straits of messina .	50.443714
in looking back over the volumes , it is possible to find errors of interpretation , some of which were not so evident at the time of writing .	31.40917
thus trevelyan repeats the story which pictured victor emmanuel as refusing to abandon the famous statuto at the insistence of general radetzky .	13.262765
later research has shown this part of the legend of the re galantuomo to be false .	31.904333
trevelyan accepts italian nationalism with little analysis , he is unduly critical of papal and french policy , and he is more than generous in assessing british policy .	40.965927
but fifty years later the trilogy still maintains a firm place in the list of standard works on the unification of italy , a position cautiously prophesied by the reviewers at the time of publication .	22.65876
trevelyan ' s manin and the venetian revolution of 1848 , his last major volume on an italian theme , was written in a minor key .	63.07174
published in 1923 , it did not gain the popular acclaim of the garibaldi volumes , probably because trevelyan felt less at home with manin , the bourgeois lawyer , than with garibaldi , the filibuster .	49.646397
the complexities of venetian politics eluded him , but the story of the revolution itself is told in restrained measures , with no superfluous passages and only an occasional overemphasis of the part played by its leading figure .	61.137875
if it is not one of his best books , it can only be considered unsatisfactory when compared with his own garibaldi .	91.57664
already trevelyan had begun to parallel his nineteenth-century italian studies with several works on english figures of the same period .	57.590115
first the life of john bright appeared and seven years later lord grey of the reform bill .	160.40022
of the two , the life of bright is incomparably the better biography .	97.42691
trevelyan centers too exclusively on bright , is insufficiently appreciative of the views of bright ' s opponents and critics , and makes light of the genuine difficulties faced by peel .	47.76613
yet he is right when he claims in his autobiography that he drew the real features of the man , his tender and selfless motives and his rugged fearless strength .	23.137932
in the story of bright and the corn law agitation , the crimean war , the american civil war , and the franchise struggle trevelyan reflects something of the moral power which enabled this independent man to exercise so immense an influence over his fellow countrymen for so long .	60.736332
because bright ' s speeches were so much a part of him , there are long and numerous quotations , which , far from making the biography diffuse , help to give us the feel of the man .	61.02923
associated in a sense with the manchester school through his mother ' s family , trevelyan conveys in this biography something of its moral conviction and drive .	53.03616
nineteenth-century virtues , however , seem somehow to have gone out of fashion and the bright book has never been particularly popular .	39.058434
the biography of lord grey is strictly speaking not a biography at all .	58.30115
it is a whig history of the `` tory reaction ' ' which preceded the reform bill of 1832 , and it uses the figure of grey to give some unity to the narrative .	33.645275
the volume is a piece of passionate special pleading , written with the heat -- and often with the wisdom , it must be said -- of a liberal damning the shortsightedness of politicians from 1782 to 1832 .	44.208412
the theme of glorious summer coming after a long winter of discontent and repression was , he has told us , congenial to his artistic sense .	82.12596
and grey ' s northumberland background was close to trevelyan ' s own .	6.7786655
but his concentration on personalities and his categorical assessment of their actions fail to convey the political complexities of a long generation harassed by world-wide war and confronted with the problem of adjustment to an unprecedented industrial and social transformation .	31.743433
some historians have found his point of view not to their taste , others have complained that he makes the tory tradition appear `` contemptible rather than intelligible ' ' , while a sympathetic critic has remarked that the `` intricate interplay of social dynamics and political activity of which , at times , politicians are the ignorant marionettes is not a field for the exercise of his talents ' ' .	41.253635
the liberal-radical heritage which informs all of trevelyan ' s interpretations of history here seems clearly to have distorted the issues and oversimplified the period .	33.022038
research in the period of grey and bright led naturally to a more ambitious work .	53.41084
britain in the nineteenth century is a textbook designed `` to give the sense of continuous growth , to show how economic led to social , and social to political change , how the political events reacted on the economic and social , and how new thoughts and new ideals accompanied or directed the whole complicated process ' ' .	89.92429
the plan is admirably fulfilled for the period up to 1832 .	52.684704
more temperately than in the study of grey and despite his liberal bias , trevelyan vividly sketches the england of pre-french revolution days , portrays the stresses and strains of the revolutionary period in rich colors , and brings developments leading to the reform bill into sharp and clear focus .	69.54755
by what one reader called a `` series of dissolving views ' ' , he merges one period into another and gives a sense of continuous growth .	46.030502
but after 1832 , the narrative tends to lose its balanced , many-sided quality and to become a medley of topics , often unconnected by any single thread .	31.522585
economic analysis was never trevelyan ' s strong point and the england of the industrial transformation cries out for economic analysis .	105.318954
yet after 1832 , the interrelations of economic and social and political affairs become blurred and the narrative becomes largely a conventional political account .	43.012913
finally , the period after 1870 receives little attention and that quite superficial .	71.76432
yet britain in the nineteenth century became the vade mecum of beginning students of history , went through edition after edition , and continues to be reprinted up to the very present .	57.026424
its success is a tribute , above all , to trevelyan ' s brilliance as a literary stylist .	28.736673
in 1924 trevelyan traveled to the united states , where he delivered the lowell lectures at harvard university .	12.431619
these lectures formed the nucleus of a general survey of english development which took form afterward as a history of england .	124.73678
in short order , the general history became his most popular work and has remained , aside from his later social history , the work most widely favored by the public .	141.73079
the history of england has often been compared with green ' s short history .	165.48341
like green , trevelyan aimed to write a history not of `` english kings or english conquests ' ' , but of the english people .	40.234776
the history takes too much for granted to serve as a text for other than english schoolboys , and like britain in the nineteenth century it deteriorates badly as it goes beyond 1870 .	57.64861
trevelyan ' s excursions into contemporary history were rarely happy ones .	64.53922
but as a stimulating , provocative interpretation of the broad sweep of english development it is incomparable .	28.064028
living pictures of the early boroughs , country life in tudor and stuart times , the impact of the industrial revolution compete with sensitive surveys of language and literature , the common law , parliamentary development .	41.82932
the strength of the history is also its weakness .	38.9411
trevelyan is militantly sure of the superiority of english institutions and character over those of other peoples .	55.031143
his nationalism was not a new characteristic , but its self-consciousness , even its self-satisfaction , is more obvious in a book that stretches over the long reach of english history .	35.23944
and yet the elements which capture his liberal and humanistic imagination are those which make the english story worth telling and worth remembering .	121.24674
tolerance and compromise , social justice and civil liberty , are today too often in short supply for one to be overly critical of trevelyan ' s emphasis on their central place in the english tradition .	90.69944
like most major works of synthesis , the history of england is informed by the positive views of a first-class mind , and this is surely a major work .	54.564953
four years after the publication of the history of england , the first volume of trevelyan ' s queen anne trilogy appeared .	10.185873
by now he had become regius professor of modern history at cambridge and had been honored by the award of the order of merit .	30.988552
his academic duties had little evident effect on his prolific pen .	4.6171536
blenheim was followed in rapid succession by ramillies and the union with scotland and by the peace and the protestant succession , the three forming together a detailed picture of england under queen anne .	64.069954
like his volume on wycliffe , the work was accompanied by the publication of a selected group of documents , in this case illustrative of the history of queen anne ' s reign down to 1707 .	25.93358
trevelyan was at least in part attracted to the period by an almost unconscious desire to take up the story where macaulay ' s history of england had broken off .	58.67159
in addition , he believed in the `` dramatic unity and separateness of the period from 1702-14 , lying between the stuart and hanoverian eras with a special ethos of its own ' ' .	24.018959
he saw the age as one in which britain `` settled her free constitution ' ' and attained her modern place in the world .	92.20628
to most observers , there is little doubt that he placed an artificial strait jacket of unity upon the years of anne ' s reign which in reality existed only in the pages of his history .	50.083687
of the three volumes , blenheim is easily the best .	119.47689
in four opening chapters reminiscent of macaulay ' s famous third chapter , trevelyan surveys the state of england at the opening of the eighteenth century .	21.433247
his delightful picture of society and institutions is filled with warm detail that brings the period vividly to life .	109.86765
he tends to underestimate -- or perhaps to view charitably -- the brutality and the violence of the age , so that there is an idyllic quality in these pages which hazes over some of its sharp reality .	40.71376
yet as an evocation of time past , there are few such successful portraits in english historical literature .	77.354416
once the scene is set , trevelyan skilfully builds up the tense story until it reaches its climax in the dramatic victory of marlborough and eugene of savoy at blenheim .	15.963292
the account of the battle is , next to his descriptions of garibaldi ' s campaigns , trevelyan ' s outstanding military narrative .	26.672045
the scene is etched in sharp detail , the military problems brilliantly explained , and the excitement and importance of the battle made evident .	108.24954
if only for this modest masterpiece of military history , blenheim is likely to be read and reread long after newer interpretations have perhaps altered our picture of the marlborough wars .	60.24173
ramillies and the union with scotland has fewer high spots than blenheim and much less of its dramatic unity .	68.25049
yet in several chapters on scotland in the eighteenth century , trevelyan copes persuasively with the tangled confusion of scottish politics against a vivid background of scottish religion , customs , and traditions .	14.879101
i stood on a table , surrounded by hundreds of expectant young faces .	46.54722
questions came to me from all sides about my world citizenship activities .	67.612526
after making a short statement about human rights , and the freedom to travel , i told them i would be going to the kehl bridge the next morning in order to cross the rhine into germany .	36.31551
`` may we come with you ' ' ? ?	2.1786938
`` well , i might not get that far ' ' , i told them , `` as actually i have no papers to enter germany and , as a matter of fact , no permit to return to france once i leave ' ' .	34.317307
we would all meet at ten o ' clock at the kehl bridge , five miles from strasbourg , and march triumphantly across into germany .	9.710333
there was only one hitch the small town of kehl , on the other side of the rhine , was still under french jurisdiction .	15.672313
the real franco-german frontier was beyond the town ' s limits .	16.164434
in fact , all persons were permitted to cross the rhine into kehl , there being no sentry posted on the west side of the river .	13.289673
that evening , as i learned later , the students , enjoying that spontaneous immodesty in action known only to university students , surged out onto the streets of strasbourg , overturning empty streetcars , marking up store fronts , and shouting imprudently , `` garry davis to power ' ' ! !	31.834488
as i got off the trolley at kehl bridge the next morning , i was met by what looked like 5 , 000 students , some of whom were carrying sticks apparently for the coming `` battle ' ' with the police .	48.98225
alarmed by this display of weapons , i looked toward the bridge and there saw , stretched across the near side , a cordon of policemen , their bicycles forming a roadblock before which stood several french officers in uniform and a small waspish man in a brown derby .	77.77702
`` listen please ' ' , i called to the students in french .	101.65861
`` i thank you most heartily for being here .	32.542233
this is full evidence of your support for my principles .	194.26167
these principles , however , will not be served by violence in any form .	74.921295
if they are right , they will prevail of and by themselves .	262.28012
i ask you all to support me in this .	75.39702
if one finger is raised against the authorities , all our moral power will vanish .	78.316574
your self-control in this respect will be the only witness to your understanding of what i am saying .	37.262196
i marched up to the waiting officials , the students massed behind me .	101.79752
as usual , the press photographers were on hand .	9.095895
the waspish man stopped me three paces from the bicycle barricade , and asked me in french if i had papers to leave france .	40.330616
i replied in the affirmative , taking out my recently acquired titre d ' identite et de voyage , on which was stamped a permission to leave france .	44.661755
he examined it carefully , handed it back and said , `` eh bien , you may leave france ' ' .	15.868592
one of the uniformed officers stepped in my way , demanding to know whether i had permission to enter germany .	25.897572
`` no , i have no permission to enter germany ' ' , i told him .	7.695605
`` alors , you may go no farther ' ' , he said imperiously .	5.1337795
`` is this then the frontier ' ' ? ?	4.1484814
at this , the students let out a yell , knowing full well the actual frontier was beyond the town of kehl .	78.7084
`` but i have no permission to re-enter france , and i have just left ' ' , i told him .	13.87145
`` i must then be standing on the line between france and germany ' ' .	18.530308
but there is no line between france and germany , that is , no actual line .	87.55955
`` but if there is no line , how can there be two countries ? ?	105.633545
you have just given me permission to leave france , which i did .	25.700556
and as you know , i have no permission to re-enter france once out .	20.732252
obviously i ' m stuck on the line between the two countries ' ' .	24.19657
the students were laughing uproariously at this piece of logic , and even the policemen were trying hard not to smile .	60.985188
`` mais non ' ' , the interior ministry man coaxed , `` you may come back to strasbourg , now , if you wish ' ' .	28.462013
then will you give me a visa to re-enter france ' ' ? ?	3.0392833
but there is no question of a visa .	5.9518065
`` ah , then please tell me where the frontier is because this gentleman here ' ' -- i indicated the french occupation officer -- `` informs me that germany is just on the other side of him ' ' .	61.93357
the interior man looked uneasily at his french compatriot .	3.0093422
from the crowd were coming cries of `` he ' s right ' ' ! !	20.611942
`` there must be a line ' ' ! !	8.2776575
and `` bravo , garry , continue ' ' ! !	7.3363733
seeing their hesitation , i said , `` well , until i have permission to enter germany , or a visa to re-enter france , i shall be obliged to remain here on the line between two countries ' ' , whereupon i moved to the side of the road , parked my backpack against the small guardhouse on the sidewalk , sat down , took out my typewriter , and began typing the above conversation .	29.78026
the reporters were questioning the interior man and the french officer , both of whom remained noncommittal as to what action , if any , would be taken in my regard .	54.035122
finally they went off to file their stories , after the photographers had taken pictures of my latest vigil .	30.819284
the students crowded around asking questions , slapping me on the back , and generally being friendly .	102.288246
`` but what will you do this evening , mr . davis ' ' ? ?	14.6548395
`` it will be very cold ' ' .	2.1070101
`` i don ' t know ' ' , i told him , `` except that i will be here ' ' .	13.50652
`` i shall see about getting you a tent ' ' , he said .	10.472005
`` i have a small sports shop in strasbourg ' ' .	2.5291216
that would be a great help , i told him , thanking him for his thoughtfulness .	16.118418
a special guard was posted at my end of the bridge to make sure i didn ' t cross , the ludicrousness of the situation being revealed fully in that everyone else -- men , women , and children , dogs , cats , horses , cars , trucks , baby carriages -- could cross kehl bridge into kehl without surveillance .	35.872437
the day passed eventfully enough , with a constant stream of visitors , some stopping only to say hello , others getting into serious conversations , such as one andre fuchs , a free-lance journalist from strasbourg who wrote an article for the nouvelle alsatian in highly sympathetic terms .	32.342575
some students from the university returned around six with a large pot containing enough hot soup to last me a week .	123.649925
a volunteer food brigade had been arranged , they told me , which would supply me with the necessities as long as i remained at the bridge .	59.267258
a little later , the sports shop man returned with a small pup tent .	38.88203
one of the girl students , sitting by while i ate the thick soup , asked me if i had a sleeping bag .	26.570747
when i informed her that i didn ' t , she said she would borrow her brother ' s and bring it to me later that evening .	59.188602
`` you do not know me ' ' , she said in good english , `` but my mother was your governess in philadelphia when you were a child ' ' .	30.242409
i was delighted to make that personal contact in such trying and unusual circumstances .	101.87751
the peter family proved wonderful and helpful friends in the following days , mrs . peter , little esther , and raoul , who generously lent me his sleeping bag for my `` watch on the rhine ' ' .	20.729242
sighting a line from the bridge to a small field directly to the side , i pitched the tent that evening on the stateless `` line ' ' , digging a small trench around it as best i could with a toy spade donated by a neighborhood child .	48.654526
the wind from the rhine was damp and chill , necessitating a fire for warmth .	12.329204
after scouring around a bit in the open area , i came across what proved to be tar-soaked logs which crackled and burned brightly , giving off vast rolls of smoke into the ashen sky .	46.26556
each evening the students appeared with the soup kettle and several petits pains , esther usually being among them .	59.306244
i had advised friends to write me to `` no man ' s land , pont kehl , between strasbourg and kehl , france-germany ' ' .	21.01679
sure enough , mail began trickling in , delivered by a talkative , highly amused french postman who informed me there had been quite a debate at the post office as to whether that address would be recognized .	51.570694
on christmas eve , students brought out two small christmas trees which i placed on either side of the tent .	44.78222
as the field on which my tent was pitched was a favorite natural playground for the kids of the neighborhood , i had made many friends among them , taking part in their after-school games and trying desperately to translate grimm ' s fairy tales into an understandable french as we gathered around the fire in front of the tent .	36.44519
to my great surprise and delight , when they saw the two trees they went rushing off , returning shortly with decorations from their own trees .	88.337524
it was a merry if somewhat soggy christmas for me that year .	66.938
in the mail were invitations to speak at the universities of cologne , heidelberg , and baden-baden .	4.702095
twenty thousand world citizens at stuttgart had signed a petition inviting me to visit their town .	35.74767
when dr . adenauer was approached by a world citizen delegation to find out his disposition of my case , he gave them his personal approval of my entry , saying that all men advocating peace should be welcomed into germany .	64.38844
the special guard , however , was still posted on kehl bridge .	10.566977
as it began raining at around eight o ' clock on december 26th , i retired into my tent early , somewhat tired and discouraged , my body reacting sluggishly because of the continued exposure .	58.113777
no matter how large the fire , i couldn ' t seem to shake off the chill that day .	14.762768
`` oh , mr . davis , are you there ' ' ? ?	18.675001
a voice drifted in to me above the patter of the rain shortly after i had fallen into a fitful sleep .	16.069939
`` we ' re from the council of europe , british delegation .	58.627964
may we have a word with you ' ' ? ?	2.6800182
i ' ve had a trying day and i just can ' t make it out again ' ' , i told them .	32.792217
later i learned that sir hugh dalton had expressed a desire to see me , hence their trip to `` no man ' s land ' ' .	54.854404
on the evening of december 27th , esther noticed my pallid look and rasping voice .	18.647638
she entreated me to see a doctor , and when i refused , brought one out to see me .	88.89359
i wouldn ' t hear of it because it meant giving up the `` line ' ' , though i realized i was in poor shape physically .	107.21455
esther , mistaking my hesitation , assured me that the hospital expense would be taken care of by a leading merchant in strasbourg whom she had already approached .	105.933624
`` no , it ' s not that ' ' , i told her .	18.424614
`` you see , once i relinquish the position i ' ve already established here , i couldn ' t regain it without sacrificing the logic of it ' ' .	27.108978
at that moment , up walked a tall young man with glasses who announced himself as a world citizen from basel , switzerland .	40.397846
without preliminaries , esther asked him , `` if you are a world citizen , will you take garry davis ' place in his tent while he goes to the hospital ' ' ? ?	39.387424
`` but of course , with pleasure ' ' , he replied .	4.354677
`` what is your name ' ' ? ?	1.0068086
`` you have just enlisted for the ' rhine campaign ' ' ' .	21.317831
esther jumped up , ran to him and gave him a little hug .	12.837307
now come , garry , we must go quickly .	479.09906
such were the incongruities of the situation that the very police assigned to check up on me were drafted into driving me to the strasbourg hospital while world citizen jean babel waved adieu from the `` line ' ' ! !	56.774307
he remembered every detail of his pre-assault movements but nothing of the final , desperate rush to come to grips with the enemy .	27.319832
when the victory cheer went up this officer found himself still mounted , with his horse pressed broadside against cleburne ' s log parapet in a tangled group of infantrymen .	23.075867
his hat was gone , the tears were streaming from his eyes .	4.375833
six climactic minutes in an individual ' s life left no memory .	194.27834
eight hundred and sixty-five rebels surrendered within their works and a thousand more were captured or surrendered themselves that night and the next day .	106.18883
seven battle flags and fourteen officers ' swords were sent to thomas ' headquarters .	34.538822
it was the only sizable assault upon infantry and artillery behind breastworks successfully made by either side during the atlanta campaign .	25.185305
the fourteenth regiment of ohio volunteers lost one-third of its numbers within a few minutes , among them being several men whose time of service had expired but who had volunteered to advance with their regiment .	94.39141
the thirty-eighth regiment of ohio volunteers , one of the regiments in thomas ' first division during buell ' s command , suffered its greatest loss of the war in this action .	36.958435
a popular belief grew up after the war that the only time during the civil war that thomas ever put his horse to a gallop was when he went to hurry up stanley for this assault .	58.18684
sherman was responsible for the story when he said in his memoirs that this was the only time he could recall seeing thomas ride so fast .	48.074768
while thomas ' injured back led him to restrain his mount from its most violent gait he moved quickly enough when he had to .	160.7197
it is not in the record , but he must have galloped his horse at peach tree creek when he brought up ward ' s guns to save newton ' s crumbling line .	26.20928
while the final combat of the campaign was being worked out at jonesborough , thomas , on sherman ' s instructions , ordered slocum , now commanding the twentieth corps , to make an effort to occupy atlanta if he could do so without exposing his bridgehead to a counterattack .	34.498306
the dispatch must have been sent after sundown on september 1 .	22.765116
slocum made his reconnaissanace the next morning , found the town empty , accepted the surrender of the mayor and occupied the city a little before noon .	95.3454
on the morning of september 2 the fourth corps and the armies of the tennessee and the ohio followed the line of hardee ' s retreat .	28.86231
about noon they came up with the enemy two miles from lovejoy ' s station and deployed .	35.199684
the fourth corps assaulted and carried a small portion of the enemy works but could not hold possession of the gain for want of cooperation from the balance of the line .	72.0552
that night a note written in slocum ' s hand and dated from inside the captured city came to sherman stating that the twentieth corps was in possession of atlanta .	54.340004
before making the news public sherman sent an officer with the note to thomas .	65.86787
in a short time the officer returned and thomas followed on his heels .	62.05066
the cautious thomas re-examined the note and then , making up his mind that it was genuine , snapped his fingers , whistled and almost danced in his exuberance .	31.009594
the next day sherman issued his orders ending the campaign and pulled his armies back to atlanta .	63.636078
the measure of combat efficiency in an indecisive campaign is a matter of personal choice .	40.49031
hood refused to notice anything except captured guns and colors .	11.282892
by both standards thomas had the right to be proud .	111.00711
thomas thanked his men for their tenacity of purpose , unmurmuring endurance , cheerful obedience , brilliant heroism and high qualities in battle .	45.165165
sherman felt that his own part in the campaign was skillful and well executed but that the slowness of a part of his army robbed him of the larger fruits of victory .	51.261986
he supposed the military world would approve of his accomplishment .	6.1280603
whatever the military world thought , the political world approved it wholeheartedly .	113.61545
for some time , despondency in some northern quarters had been displayed in two ways -- an eagerness for peace and a dissatisfaction with lincoln .	40.59989
proposals were in the air for a year ' s armistice .	35.873077
lincoln was sure that he would not be re-elected .	3.4941006
in the midst of this gloom , at 10 05 p . m . on september 2 , slocum ' s telegram to stanton , `` general sherman has taken atlanta ' ' , shattered the talk of a negotiated peace and boosted lincoln into the white house .	27.141088
to the republicans no victory could have been more complete .	70.13798
official congratulations showered upon sherman and his army .	70.71703
lincoln mentioned their distinguished ability , courage and perseverance .	5.1634808
he felt that this campaign would be famous in the annals of war .	22.661066
grant called it prompt , skillful and brilliant .	401.29532
halleck described it as the most brilliant of the war .	23.31365
actually the atlanta campaign was a military failure .	12.77843
next best to destroying an army is to deprive it of its freedom of action .	21.487907
sherman had accomplished this much of his job and then inexplicably nullified it by his thirty-mile retreat from lovejoy ' s to atlanta .	18.061302
but , so far as its territorial objectives were concerned , the campaign was successful .	65.71505
within the narrow frame of military tactics , too , the experts agree that the campaign was brilliant .	67.38587
in seventeen weeks the military front was driven southward more than 100 miles .	12.559538
there was a battle on an average of once every three weeks .	115.93264
in the summary of the principal events of the campaign compiled from the official records there are only ten days which show no fighting .	123.08061
the casualties in the army of the cumberland were 22 , 807 , while for all three armies they were 37 , 081 .	51.70468
men were killed in their camps , at their meals and in their sleep .	74.53582
rifle fire often kept the opposing gunners from manning their pieces .	17.7594
modern warfare was born in this campaign -- periscopes , camouflage , booby traps , land mines , extended order , trench raids , foxholes , armored cars , night attacks , flares , sharpshooters in trees , interlaced vines and treetops , which were the forerunners of barbed wire , trip wires to thwart a cavalry charge , which presaged the mine trap , and the general use of anesthetics .	17.29497
the use of map coordinates was begun when the senior officers began to select tactical points by designating a spot as `` near the letter o in the word mountain ' ' .	58.576218
a few weeks later the maps were being divided into squares and a position was described as being `` about lots 239 , 247 and 272 with pickets forward as far as 196 ' ' .	42.913235
this system was dependent upon identical maps and thomas supplied them from a mobile lithograph press .	39.078674
orders of the day began to specify the standard map for the movement .	41.915913
sherman proved that a railway base could be movable and the most brilliant feature of the atlanta campaign was the rapid repair of the tracks .	23.895845
to the rebels it seemed as if sherman carried tunnels and bridges in his pockets .	23.082865
the whistle of sherman ' s locomotives often drowned out the rattle of the skirmish fire .	12.001276
as always , the ranks worked out new and better tactics , but there was brilliance in the way the field commands adopted these methods and in the way the army commanders incorporated them into their military thinking .	80.51838
the fossilized , formalized , precedent-based thinking of the legendary military brain was not evident in sherman ' s armies .	35.55816
sherman could never be accused of sticking too long with the old .	38.00261
one of sherman ' s most serious shortcomings , however , was his mistrust of his cavalry .	23.394447
he never saw that it was a complement to his infantry and not a substitute for it .	38.116306
then , in some way , this lack of faith in the cavalry became mixed up in his mind with the dragging effect of wagon trains and was hardened into a prejudice .	44.201767
a horse needed twenty pounds of food a day but the infantryman got along with two pounds .	56.239384
the horseman required eleven times more than the footman .	6.99947
he would ship by rail five pounds per day per animal and the other fifteen pounds that were needed could be picked up off the country .	85.68011
already debilitated by the chattanooga starvation , the quality of sherman ' s horseflesh ran downhill as the campaign progressed .	14.090168
every recorded request by thomas for a delay in a flank movement or an advance was to gain time to take care of his horses .	46.632904
well led , properly organized cavalry , in its complementary role to infantry , had four functions .	68.887375
first , it could locate the enemy infantry , learn what they were doing , and hold them until the heavy foot columns could come up and take over .	81.48071
second , it could screen its own infantry from the sight of the enemy .	13.207512
third , it could threaten at all times , and destroy when possible , the enemy communications .	104.27253
it could reach key tactical points faster than infantry and destroy them or hold them as the case might be for the foot soldier .	95.42613
its climactic role was to pursue and demoralize a defeated enemy but this chance never came in the atlanta campaign .	66.48562
thomas tried hard to have his cavalry ready for the test it was to meet , but his plans were wrecked when it was forced into a campaign without optimum mobility and with its commander stripped from it .	63.31307
sherman knew the uses of cavalry as well as thomas but he imagined a moving base with infantry wings instead of cavalry wings .	73.32701
his conception proved workable but slower and it enabled his enemy to make clean , deft , well organized retreats with small materiel losses .	48.3792
sherman insisted that cavalry could not successfully break up hostile railways , yet garrard ' s covington raid and rousseau ' s opelika raid cut two-thirds of the rail lines he had to break and sherman lived in mortal fear of what forrest might do to his communications .	35.19434
when mcpherson pushed blindly through snake creek gap in a potentially decisive movement , the only cavalry in his van was the ninth illinois mounted infantry , totally inadequate for its role .	29.0989
it stumbled on infantry where no infantry should have been and mcpherson ' s aggressive impulse faded out , overwhelmed by fears of the unknown .	37.281044
a proper cavalry command in his front would have developed the fact that he had run into one division of polk ' s army of the mississippi moving up from the direction of mobile to join johnston at dalton .	39.984962
from the night of august 30 to the morning of september 2 there was no union cavalry east of the macon railway to disclose to sherman that he was missing the greatest opportunity of his career .	43.962967
a great part of the time , thomas ' infantry never knew the location of the enemy line .	49.140587
at such times thomas wondered when and where a counterattack would strike him .	58.905468
it was the hard way to fight a war but thomas did it without making any disastrous mistakes .	186.47829
heat during the atlanta campaign , coupled with unsuitable clothing , caused individual irritation that was compounded by a lack of opportunity to bathe and shift into clean clothing .	20.701916
to relieve the itch and sweat galls , the men got into the water whenever they could and since each sizable stream was generally the dividing line between the armies the pickets declared a private truce while the men went swimming .	71.3374
johnston believed that sherman put his naked engineers into the swimming parties to locate the various fords .	30.62523
lieutenant colonel james p . brownlow , who commanded the first brigade of thomas ' first cavalry division , was ordered across one of these fords .	33.662914
the water was deep and brownlow took his troopers across naked -- except for guns , cartridge boxes and hats .	30.527973
they kicked their horses through the deep water with their bare heels , drove the rebels out of their rifle pits and captured four men .	38.021774
most of the rebels got away since they could make better time through the stiff brush than their naked pursuers .	77.81894
rank was becoming an explosive issue in all three of sherman ' s armies .	29.475822
merited recommendations from army commanders were passed over in favor of political appointees from civil life .	71.29249
in one of the very few letters in which he ever complained of meynell , thompson told patmore of his distress at having had to leave london before this new friendship had developed further ``	129.6523
that was a very absurd and annoying situation in which i was placed by w . m . ' s curious methods of handling me .	32.138767
he never let me know that my visit was about to terminate until the actual morning i was to leave for lymington .	39.794556
the result was that i found myself in the ridiculous position of having made a formal engagement by letter for the next week , only two days before my departure from london .	55.139812
luckily both women knew my position and if anyone suffered in their opinion it was not i ' ' .	44.805115
it need hardly be remarked that thompson was not generally known for his scrupulosity about keeping his social engagements , which makes his irritation in this letter all the more significant .	75.1819
when thompson and her daughter began a correspondence which included fervent verses from pantasaph , mrs . king felt a proper victorian alarm .	37.20234
some , she knew , looked upon thompson almost as a saint , but others read in `` the hound of heaven ' ' what they took to be the confessions of a great sinner , who , like oscar wilde , had -- as one pious writer later put it -- thrown himself `` on the swelling wave of every passion ' ' .	42.329666
consequently , on october 31 , 1896 , mrs . king wrote to thompson , quite against her daughter ' s wishes , asking him not to `` recommence a correspondence which i believe has been dropped for some weeks ' ' .	38.33201
katherine was staying at a convent , and her mother felt that , as thompson himself seems to have suggested , she might eventually stay there .	96.8489
this prospect did not please mrs . king any more than did the possibility that her daughter might marry a bohemian , but she used it to suggest to thompson that , `` it is not in her nature to love you ' ' .	48.88756
for his part , thompson had explained in a previous letter that there would be nothing but an honorable friendship between katie and himself .	46.06246
at no time does he seem to have proposed marriage , and mrs . king was evidently torn between a concern for her daughter ' s emotions and the desire to believe that the friendship might be continued without harm to her reputation .	49.334995
in any case , she told thompson that she saw no reason why he might not see katie again , `` now that this frank explanation has been made & no one can misunderstand ' ' .	63.635956
she ended her letter with the assurance that she considered his friendship for her daughter and herself to be an honor , from which she could not part `` without still more pain ' ' .	60.060513
after thompson came to london to live , he received a letter from katie , which was dated february 8 , 1897 .	21.908726
she regretted what she described as the `` unwarrantable & unnecessary ' ' check to their friendship and said that she felt that they understood one another perfectly .	110.7048
i am a great deal at the little children ' s hospital .	50.6968
i know you are very busy now , you are writing a great deal & your book is coming out , isn ' t it ? ?	58.76054
but if you are able & care to come , you know how glad i shall be .	76.42974
katherine douglas king ' ' the invitation was accepted and other letters followed , in which she spoke of her concern for his health and her delight in seeing him so much at home among the crippled children she served .	111.711266
it is difficult to say what thompson expected would come of their relationship , which had begun so soon after his emotions had been stirred by maggie brien , but when katie wrote on april 11 , 1900 , to tell him that she was to be married to the rev . godfrey burr , the vicar of rushall in staffordshire , the news evidently helped to deepen his discouragement over the failure of his hopes for a new volume of verse .	26.673756
in a letter to meynell , which was written in june , less than a month before katie ' s wedding , he was highly melodramatic in his despair and once again announced his intention of returning to the life of the streets ``	33.214718
a week in arrears , and without means to pay , i must go , it is the only right thing .	56.49079
perhaps mrs . meynell would do me the undeserved kindness to keep my own copy of the first edition of my first book , with all its mementos of her and the dear ones .	24.29445
last , not least , there are some poems which k . king sent me ( addressed to herself ) when i was preparing a fresh volume , asking me to include them .	66.142975
the terrible blow of the new year put an end to that project .	84.32795
i wish you would return them to her .	18.941101
i never had the courage to look at them , when my projected volume became hopeless , fearing they were poor , until now when i was obliged to do so .	58.602894
o my genius , young and ripening , you would swear , -- when i wrote them	128.60753
all chance of fulfilling my destiny is over .	32.149536
i want you to be grandfather to these orphaned poems , dear father-brother , now i am gone	31.66982
and launch them on the world when their time comes .	71.734695
for them a box will be lodgment enough .	4.6118445
since my silence must have ended when i gave the purposed volume to you .	60.655815
i ask you to do me the last favour of reading them by 8 to-morrow evening , about which time i shall come to say my sad good-bye .	77.4341
if you don ' t think much of them , tell me the wholesome truth .	56.12815
if otherwise , you will give me a pleasure .	149.06581
but this -- yes , terrible step i am about to take is lightened with an inundating joy by the new-found hope that here , in these poems , is treasure -- or at least some measure of beauty , which i did not know of ' ' .	49.907368
thompson , of course , was persuaded not to take the `` terrible step ' '	18.373903
meynell once again paid his debts and it was katie , rather than thompson , whose life was soon ended , for she died in childbirth in april , 1901 , in the first year of her marriage .	31.666023
the `` orphaned poems ' ' mentioned in the letter to meynell comprised a group of five sonnets , which were published in the 1913 edition of thompson ' s works under the heading `` ad amicam ' ' , plus certain other completed pieces and rough drafts gathered together in one of the familiar exercise books .	33.727833
the publication of father connolly ' s the man has wings has made more of the group available in print so that a general picture of what it contained can now be had without difficulty .	152.8809
some of the poems express a mood of joy in a newly discovered love	292.23282
